PREFACE
The Village Code of the Village of Rosemont, as supplemented, contains the 1971
Village Code and ordinances up to and including ordinance 2025-3-10D, passed
March 10, 2025. Ordinances of the Village adopted after said ordinance
supersede the provisions of this Village Code to the extent that they are in
conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the Village office in order to
ascertain whether any particular provision of the Code has been amended,
superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not affect the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
TITLE 1: ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1: ROSEMONT VILLAGE CODE
Section
1-1-1:   Title
1-1-2:   Acceptance
1-1-3:   Jurisdiction
1-1-4:   Amendments
1-1-5:   Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the Board of Trustees, this Village Code is hereby declared to
be and shall hereafter constitute the official Village Code of Rosemont. This
Village Code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the ROSEMONT VILLAGE
CODE and is hereby published by authority of the Board of Trustees and shall be
supplemented to incorporate the most recent legislation of the Village as
provided in section
1-1-4  of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title headings, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this Village Code by title in any legal documents.
(2019 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
The Village Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be
received without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of
the State as the ordinances of the Village of general and permanent effect,
except the excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title.
(2019 Code)
1-1-3: JURISDICTION:
This Code shall refer only to the omission or commission of acts within the
territorial limits of the Village and to that territory outside the Village
over which the Village has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any
Constitutional provisions or any law.
(1971 Code § 1-11)
1-1-4: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this Village Code shall set forth the title, chapter and
section numbers of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to
the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this Village Code. All
such amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifier, and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this Village Code. Each such replacement page
shall be properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of
the Village Code.
(2019 Code)
1-1-5: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this Village Code in such a manner that
the meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages
may be inserted according to the official instructions when so authorized by
the Board of Trustees. The Village Clerk shall see that the replacement pages
are properly inserted in the official copies maintained in the Office of the
Clerk. Any person having in his custody an official copy of the Village Code
shall make every effort to maintain said Code in an up to date and efficient
manner. He shall see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement pages
when such are delivered to him or made available to him through the Office of
the Village Clerk. Said Code books, while in actual possession of officials and
other interested persons, shall be and remain the property of the Village and
shall be returned to the Office of the Clerk when directed so to do by order of
the Board of Trustees.
(2019 Code)
CHAPTER 2: SAVING CLAUSE
Section
1-2-1:   Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2:   Provisions Passed Prior To Codification And Prior To Acquisition Of
Home Rule Powers
1-2-3:   Court Proceedings
1-2-4:   Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the Village passed prior to the adoption of this
Village Code are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this Village
Code or are by necessary implications herein reserved from repeal (subject to
the saving clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the
following ordinances which are not hereby repealed:
   A.   Tax levy ordinances and any ordinance abating any portion of a tax
levy;
   B.   Appropriation ordinance;
   C.   Ordinances relating to boundaries, annexations and disconnections;
   D.   Franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to
persons or corporations;
   E.   Contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants;
   F.   Salary ordinances;
   G.   Ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other
public places;
   H.   Improvement ordinances;
   I.   Bond ordinances; any ordinance adopting any policy or procedure for the
management or reporting upon the use of bond proceeds; any ordinance approving
any debt or loan by the Village, including but not limited to taxable and non-
taxable lines of credit;
   J.   Ordinances relating to elections;
   K.   Ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or
from the Village;
   L.   All special ordinances;
   M.   Ordinances establishing, amending, or pertaining to: any Tax Increment
Financing District; any special service area; the adoption of a Property
Assessed Clean Energy (PACE) program or area; any special assessment; or any
other ordinance approving any type of financing district or development area
that may be allowable under Illinois law;
   N.   Ordinances establishing or amending any pension fund, any retirement
annuity plan, or any post-employment benefits trust to the extent they apply to
Village employees;
   O.   Ordinances establishing or amending any pension fund, any retirement
annuity plan, or any post-employment benefits trust to the extent they apply to
the Village President, Village trustees and the Village Clerk holding office as
of June 10, 2020. Said ordinances shall not apply to any newly elected officer
after June 10, 2020;
   P.   Ordinances related to the Village’s participation, or to any of its
employees/officers participation, in any statewide pension fund;
   Q.   Ordinances authorizing or related to the settlement of any litigation;
   R.   Ordinances approving any incentive pertaining to the development of any
property or project;
   S.   Ordinances approving, amending, or pertaining to any intergovernmental
agreement;
   T.   Ordinances approving or adopting any Village policies including, but
not limited to any personnel policy, any investment policy, any employee
expenditure authorization policy, or any fund balance policy;
   U.   Ordinances approving, amending, or pertaining to any employee or
retired employee benefit or insurance plan;
   V.   Ordinances authorizing the pursuit of eminent domain or the Village’s
participation in any court or administrative proceeding;
   W.   Any ordinance not contained in the Village Code which primarily
pertains to the internal operations of the Village, the duties of its employees
or officers, or the Village’s relationships with other governmental bodies or
agencies;
   X.   Ordinances exempting any employee from any other obligation or
requirement of any ordinance;
   Y.   Zoning ordinances, including, but not limited to: ordinances approving
the rezoning of property; ordinances approving special uses; ordinances
approving exceptions to any requirement of the zoning ordinances; ordinances
approving any variation or exception from any sign ordinance; and ordinances
approving any plat, subdivision or resubdivision of property; and
   Z.   Ordinances determining the extent to which any closed meeting minutes
may or may not be released for review by the general public.
(2019 Code)
1-2-2: PROVISIONS PASSED PRIOR TO CODIFICATION AND PRIOR TO ACQUISITION OF HOME
RULE POWERS:
The provisions of this Code which were enacted by the Corporate Authorities
prior to the effective date of the acquisition of home rule powers by the
Village are hereby reaffirmed and reenacted under the increased legislative
power now enjoyed by the Village Board. Each of such ordinance provisions shall
be ratified and reenacted on the effective date hereof in the same manner as if
they were set out in full hereafter. As all other ordinances contained within
the Village Code and passed after the acquisition by the Village of its home
rule powers were passed by a legislative body possessing those powers, the
entire Village Code, as such Code may read from time to time, and such other
ordinances passed after the acquisition of home rule powers which are not
incorporated within this Code, shall all be viewed as the legislative
enactments of a home rule municipality.
(Ord. 75-11-19F, 11-19-1975)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Prior Acts:
      1.   No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former
ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to
any offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any
penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim
arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such
offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment may be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
(2019 Code)
      2.   Neither the adoption of this Code nor the repeal hereby of any
ordinance of the Village shall in any manner be construed as a waiver of any
license or penalty at the effective date due and unpaid under such ordinances,
nor be construed as affecting any of the provisions of such ordinance relating
to the collection of any such license or penalty or the penal provisions
applicable to any violation thereof, nor to affect the validity of any bond or
cash deposit in lieu thereof, required to be posted, filed or deposited
pursuant to any ordinance, and all rights and obligations thereof appertaining
shall continue in full force and effect.
(1971 Code § 1-10; amd. 2019 Code)
   B.   Revival Of Ordinances: Whenever any ordinance repealing a former
ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not
be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision, unless it
shall be therein so expressly provided.
(1971 Code § 1-10)
   C.   Extend To All Repeals: This section shall extend to all repeals, either
by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making
any new provisions upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   D.   Current Pending Actions: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be
construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general
ordinance of the Village herein repealed, and the provisions of all general
ordinances contained in this Code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions
and not a new enactment of the same provisions; nor shall this chapter be
deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or
to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm or corporation, or
as waiving any right of the Village under any ordinance or provision thereof in
force at the time of the adoption of this Village Code.
(2019 Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this
Village Code, or any codes or portions of codes adopted herein by reference, is
for any reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any
court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or
effectiveness of the remaining portions of this Code, or any codes or portions
of codes adopted herein by reference. The Village Board of Trustees hereby
declares that it would have passed each section, subsection, paragraph,
sentence, clause or phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or
more sections, subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be
declared unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective.
(2019 Code)
CHAPTER 3: DEFINITIONS; INTERPRETATION
Section
1-3-1:   General Rules Of Interpretation
1-3-2:   General Definitions
1-3-3:   Catchlines
1-3-1: GENERAL RULES OF INTERPRETATION:
   A.   Liberal Construction: All general provisions, terms, phrases and
expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that
the true intent and meaning of the Mayor and Village Board of Trustees may be
fully carried out.
   B.   Minimum Requirements: In the interpretation and application of any
provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirement adopted
for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare.
   C.   Computation Of Time: The time within which an act is to be done shall
be computed by excluding the first and including the last day. If the last day
is a Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, that day shall be excluded.
   D.   Delegation Of Authority: Whenever a power is granted to or a duty is
imposed upon a public officer or employee, the power may be exercised or the
duty may be performed by a designated deputy of such officer or employee or by
a person otherwise duly authorized pursuant to law or ordinance, unless this
Code expressly provides otherwise.
   E.   Joint Authority: All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or
more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a
majority of such persons or officers.
   F.   Gender: The use of any gender based pronoun should not be construed to
be gender biased, but is only used for grammatical simplicity.
   G.   Shall; Must; May: The words “shall” and “must” are mandatory, and the
word “may” is permissive.
   H.   Definitions: Unless expressly otherwise provided, definitions given
within a chapter, article, or section apply only to words or phrases used in
such chapter, article, or section.
   I.   Nontechnical And Technical Words: Words and phrases shall be construed
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate
meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning.
   J.   Bond: When a bond is required, an undertaking in writing shall be
sufficient unless otherwise required by State law or in this Code.
   K.   Number: A word importing the singular number only may extend and be
applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing.
   L.   Officers And Employees Generally: Whenever any officer or employee is
referred to by title only, such reference shall be construed as if followed by
the words “of the Village of Rosemont”.
   M.   Tense: Words used in the past or present tense include the future as
well as the past and present.
   N.   Chapters, Articles, Sections: All references to chapters, articles, or
sections are to the chapters, articles, and sections of this Code unless
otherwise specified.
   O.   Conflicting Provisions:
      1.   If the provisions of different chapters or articles of this Code
conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions of each chapter or
article shall prevail as to all matters and questions growing out of the
subject matter of that chapter or article.
      2.   If different sections of the same chapter are clearly in conflict,
the provisions of the section which is the latest enacted shall prevail unless
the construction is inconsistent with the meaning of that chapter.
   P.   Ordinance:
      1.   The word “ordinance” contained in the ordinances of the Village has
been changed in the content of this Village Code to “title”, “chapter”,
“section” and/or “subsection” or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to Village ordinances is not meant to
amend passage and effective dates of such original ordinances.
      2.   Any reference in this Code to an ordinance or provision of this Code
shall mean such ordinance or provision as may now exist or as hereafter
amended.
(1971 Code §§ 1-2, 1-4, 1-8, 1-9; amd. 2019 Code)
1-3-2: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the following
definitions shall be observed, unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of
the Board of Trustees or the context clearly requires otherwise:
BOARD: The Board of Trustees of the Village of Rosemont.
CODE: The Village Code of the Village of Rosemont.
COUNTY: The County of Cook, State of Illinois.
GOVERNING BODY: The Board of Trustees.
ILCS: Illinois Compiled Statutes.
MAYOR: See definition of VILLAGE PRESIDENT.
MONTH: A calendar month, unless otherwise expressed.
OATH: Includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may
be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the words “swear” and “sworn”
shall be equivalent to the words “affirm” and “affirmed”.
OWNER: Applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenants by the
entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land.
PERSON: Includes a corporation, firm, partnership, association, executor,
administrator, guardian, trustee, agent, organization and any other group
acting as a unit as well as an individual.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes goods and chattel rights and credits, monies and
effects, evidences of debt, choses in action and all written instruments by
which any right to, interest in, or lien or encumbrances upon, property or any
debt or financial obligation as created, acknowledged, evidenced, transferred,
discharged or defeated, in whole or in part, and everything except “real
property” as herein defined which may be the subject of ownership.
PRECEDING; FOLLOWING: Next before and next after, respectively.
PROPERTY: Includes real and personal property.
PROPRIETOR: Any person, firm, association, corporation, club, or copartnership,
whether acting by themselves or a servant, agent or employee.
PUBLIC GROUNDS OR PUBLIC PLACES: Any park or open place adjacent thereto, any
lake or stream, any and every public ground, public square, public park, street
or sidewalk, or other public place within the Village.
REAL PROPERTY: Includes land, together with all things attached to the land so
as to become a part thereof and all rights thereto and interests therein.
SIDEWALK: Any portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent
property line, or any paved or unpaved walkway, intended for the use of
pedestrians.
SIGNATURE AND SUBSCRIPTION: Includes a mark when the person cannot write.
STATE: The State of Illinois.
STREET: Any public way, road, highway, street, court, avenue, boulevard,
parkway, alley, lane, viaduct and bridge.
TENANT; OCCUPANT: Applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with
others.
VILLAGE: The Village of Rosemont, County of Cook, State of Illinois.
VILLAGE CLERK OR CLERK: The Village Clerk of the Village of Rosemont.
VILLAGE PRESIDENT OR PRESIDENT: The President of the Board of Trustees. The
President of the Village may also be referred to as “Mayor” of the Village for
all purposes.
(1971 Code § 1-2; amd. Ord. 77-3-2B, 3-2-1977; Ord. 2002-12-4H, 12-4-2002; 2019
Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of the Village Code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when
any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted.
(2019 Code)
CHAPTER 4: PENALTIES FOR CODE VIOLATIONS
Section
1-4-1:   General Penalty
1-4-2:   Fines For Provisions Subject To Adjudication
1-4-3:   Application Of Provisions
1-4-4:   Nonliability Of Officers And Employees
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
   A.   Whenever, in this Code or in any other ordinance, rule, regulation or
order of the Village, the doing of any act or the omission to do any act or
duty is declared to be a violation thereof, and there is no penalty specially
provided for such violation, any person, firm or corporation who shall be found
guilty of such violation shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00)
nor more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for each such
violation.
   B.   Each Day A Separate Offense: Each day any violation of this Code or of
any other ordinance of the Village or any rule, regulation or order as
aforesaid shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
   C.   Recovery Of Collection Costs: In the event a fine, penalty or cost is
assessed pursuant to any provision of this Code and/or any other provision of
any other existing or future ordinance adopted by the Village of Rosemont, any
failure to pay the fine, penalty or cost assessed, or any installment of the
fine, penalty or cost, may result in collection activities by any means
authorized for the collection of monetary judgments or personal liability. The
Village or its designees may retain an attorney and/or private collection
agents for the purpose of collecting the payment of any fine, penalty or cost
due to the Village or any installment of that fine, penalty or cost. Any fees
or costs incurred by the Village for attorneys and/or private collection agents
retained by the Village or their authorized designees shall be charged to the
individual or entity liable for the fine, penalty or cost.
(Ord. 81-7-1A, 7-1-1981; amd. Ord. 2021-2-8A, 2-8-2021; Ord. 2021-4-12B, 4-12-
2021)

1-4-3: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: The penalty provided in this chapter shall be
applicable to every section of this Village Code the same as though it were a
part of each and every separate section unless otherwise indicated. Any person
convicted of a violation of any section of this Village Code where a duty is
prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any action which is of a continuing
nature is forbidden or is declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day such
duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise
specifically provided in this Village Code.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this Village Code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed,
but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the
same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be
considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this Village
Code and there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such
breach, the provisions of this chapter shall apply.
(2019 Code)
1-4-4: NONLIABILITY OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
No provision of this Village Code designating the duties of any officer or
employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for
any fine or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the
intent of the Village Board of Trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such
officer or employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section
creating the duty.
(2019 Code)
ARTICLE A: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING SYSTEM
Section
1-4A-1:   System Established; Jurisdiction
1-4A-2:   State Regulations Adopted

1-4A-1: SYSTEM ESTABLISHED; JURISDICTION:
   A.   There is hereby established and created within the Village an
administrative hearing system to adjudicate alleged violations (“violations”),
including but not limited to, the following provisions of the Village as the
same have been, and may from time to time hereafter be, amended:
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004)
      1.   The Village Building Codes (Title 11, sections
11-2-2 and
11-2-3 of this Code), Property Maintenance Code (Section
11-2-4 of this Code), Fire Code (Section
11-2-8 of this Code), Plumbing Code (Section
11-3-1 of this Code), Elevator and Escalator Code (
Title 11, chapter 4 of this Code) and Electrical Code (Section
11-2-5 of this Code).
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004; amd. 2019 Code)
      2.   The following provisions of this Code:
         a.   Title 3, “Finances and Taxation”.
         b.   Title 4, “Business And License Regulations”.
         c.   Title 4, chapter 15, article C, “Public Passenger Vehicles”.
         d.   Title 4, chapter 20, article A, “Food Service Sanitation Code”.

         f.   Title 5, chapter 3, “Solid Waste Collection And Disposal”.
         g.   Title 5, chapter 4, “Litter Control”.

         n.   Title 10, chapter 2A, “Cross-Connection Control”.
         o.   Title 11, chapter 2, “Building Codes”.
         p.   Title 11, chapter 3, “Plumbing Code and Regulations”.
      3.   Such other Village ordinances and Code provisions as the Corporate
Authorities of the Village may from time to time designate.
      4.   All ordinances of the Village imposing any tax that is directly
collected by the Village, including, but not limited to: any tax on the
privilege of renting a hotel or motel room (“hotel tax”); any tax on amusements
(“amusement tax”); any tax on the gross receipts of places for eating (“gross
receipts tax”); any parking and garage operations tax (“parking tax”); and any
tax upon the purchase of gasoline (“gas tax”). Upon a determination that any
violation of any of the above tax ordinances has occurred, the Hearing Officer
shall have the jurisdiction to grant any relief provided for in any of the
above tax ordinances including, but not limited to, the imposition of any fine
or monetary penalty, the revocation of any business or other licenses received
from the Village and/or the issuance of an order compelling compliance.
   B.   The provisions of this article shall apply to administrative
adjudication proceedings to the extent that they are not inconsistent with the
provisions of another Village ordinance or Code which sets forth specific
procedures for the administrative adjudication of particular ordinance or Code
provisions.
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004; Ord. 2019-6-12, 6-12-2019)
1-4A-2: STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The provisions of division 2.1 of article 1 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes section 5/1-2.1-1 et seq., are hereby adopted and
incorporated into this article as if fully set forth herein.
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004)
1-4A-3: COMPOSITION OF SYSTEM:
The administrative hearing system shall be composed of one or more Hearing
Officers and a Code Hearing Unit, which shall have the power and authority and
limitations as set forth in this article.
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004)
1-4A-3-1: HEARING OFFICERS:
   A.   Appointment. The Village President, subject to the advice and consent
of the Village Board of Trustees, shall appoint one or more qualified Hearing
Officers to conduct the adjudicatory hearings (“hearings”) provided under this
article and to otherwise perform the functions of a Hearing Officer as set
forth in this article.
   B.   Independent Contractor; Removal: A Hearing Officer shall be employed as
an independent contractor of the Village and shall not be considered an
employee or officer of the Village. A Hearing Officer may be removed, with or
without cause, by the Village President.
   C.   Qualifications: To qualify as a Hearing Officer, an individual must:
      1.   Be an attorney licensed to practice law in the State of Illinois for
at least three (3) years;
      2.   Be in good standing with the Illinois Supreme Court Attorney
Registration and Disciplinary Commission;
      3.   Complete a formal training program consisting of:
         a.   Instruction on the rules of procedure for administrative
hearings;
         b.   Orientation to each subject area of the ordinances and codes of
the Village that are subject to administrative adjudication under the
provisions of this article or any other ordinance of the Village;
         c.   Observation of hearings conducted on behalf of the Village and/or
in other Illinois municipalities that have adopted the administrative hearing
system; and
         d.   Participation in hypothetical hearings, including ruling on
evidence and issuing final orders.
   D.   Compensation: A Hearing Officer shall be compensated by the Village at
a rate or in an amount to be determined by the Corporate Authorities of the
Village.
   E.   Powers: Hearing Officers shall have all powers necessary to conduct
fair and impartial hearings including, but limited to, the power to:
      1.   Hold conferences for the settlement or simplification of the issues;
      2.   Administer oaths and affirmations;
      3.   Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the
allegation of a violation;
      4.   Issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant
testimony at a hearing, upon the request of the parties of their
representatives;
      5.   Preserve and authenticate the record of a hearing, including all
exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing;
      6.   Issue a determination, based on the evidence presented at the
hearing, on whether a violation occurred or exists; and
      7.   Impose penalties consistent with applicable ordinance or Code
provisions and assess mandatory costs of forty dollars ($40.00) per violation
upon finding a defendant liable for the charged violation; provided, that a
Hearing Officer shall not have the authority to impose a penalty of
incarceration or a fine in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00),
exclusive of costs of enforcement or costs imposed to secure compliance with
the ordinances and codes of the Village. Notwithstanding the foregoing to the
contrary, the fifty thousand dollar ($50,000.00) limitation on the amount of a
fine shall not apply in cases to enforce the collection of any tax imposed by
the Village. (Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004; amd. Ord. 2023-1-9, 1-9-2023)
1-4A-3-2: CODE HEARING UNIT:
   A.   Established: A Code Hearing Unit is hereby established within the
Department of Public Safety. The Code Hearing Unit shall consist of the Hearing
Officers, such Department of Public Safety officers and other personnel as may
be assigned to the Code Hearing Unit by the Chief of Public Safety or who are
assigned to perform the duties and exercise the authority and jurisdiction of
the Code Hearing Unit by the Chief of Public Safety and such other employees of
the Village who may be assigned to perform the duties or exercise the authority
and jurisdiction of the Code Hearing Unit by the Village President.
   B.   Authority And Jurisdiction: The Code Hearing Unit is hereby authorized,
empowered, and directed to:
      1.   Recommend rules and regulations reasonably required to manage the
administrative hearing system;
      2.   Adopt, distribute, and process all notices as may be required under
this article or as may reasonably be required to carry out the purpose of this
article;
      3.   Collect payments made as a result of fines and/or penalties assessed
after a final determination of liability;
      4.   Certify copies of final determinations of violations adjudicated
pursuant to this article, and any factual reports verifying the final
determination of any liability that was issued in accordance with this article
or the laws of the State of Illinois, as from time to time amended; and
      5.   Keep accurate records of appearances and nonappearances at hearings,
pleas entered, fines, and other penalties assessed and paid.
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004)
1-4A-4: VIOLATION NOTICE:
   A.   Issuance Of Notice:
      1.   A notice of any violation ("violation notice") shall be issued by
the persons authorized under this article, shall contain information as to the
type and nature of the violation to be adjudicated, shall be certified, and
shall constitute prima facie evidence of the violation described in the notice.
A notice of violation must state the date and location of the hearing to be
conducted pursuant to this article, the legal authority and jurisdiction under
which the hearing is to be conducted, and the penalties for failure to appear
at the hearing.
      2.   All regular and auxiliary public safety officers, the Village Public
Health and Business License Officer, the Village Public Works Director, the
Village Finance Director, and any persons who are authorized to issue violation
notices pursuant to contract or the designation of the Village Director of
Public Safety, the Village Public Health and Business License Officer, the
Village Public Works Director, or the Village Finance Director, shall have the
authority to issue violation notices.
      3.   Any individual authorized to issue violation notices who detects or
observes a violation is authorized to issue a violation notice for the
violation and shall serve the violation notice, or cause the violation notice
to be served, in the manner set forth in subsection B of this section.
      4.   The accuracy of facts contained in any violation notice shall be
certified by the person issuing the notice through signing his or her name to
the violation notice at the time of issuance.
      5.   The Code Hearing Unit shall retain the original or a facsimile of
the violation notice and keep it as a record in the ordinary course of
business.
      6.   The violation notice or copy thereof shall be admissible in any
subsequent administrative or judicial proceeding to the extent permitted by
law.
   B.   Service Of Notice; Hearing Scheduled:
      1.   Service of any violation notice shall be made as follows:
         a.   Handing the notice to the registered owner, operator or lessee of
the motor vehicle, if present; or
         b.   Handing the notice to the person responsible for the violation;
or
         c.   Mailing the notice by certified mail to the person responsible
for the violation; or
         d.   Posting the notice on property where a violation occurred,
provided the violation occurred as a result of a condition of the property or
an activity that occurred on the property and the party to be notified is the
owner or manager of the property.
      2.   If service of notice is provided by mail for any violation notice or
for any notice of a hearing, said service shall be deemed sent and shall be
complete on the date the notice is deposited, postage prepaid, in the United
States mail. The counting of any time period as set forth in this Code shall
begin to run on the date the notice is deposited, postage prepaid, in the
United States mail.
      3.   A hearing on an alleged violation shall be scheduled with reasonable
promptness; provided, that for hearings scheduled for a violation where the
continuing existence of the violation or failure to take action to correct a
violation does not reasonably constitute a threat to the public interest,
safety or welfare, the defendant or respondent shall have at least fifteen (15)
days after service of the violation notice to prepare for the hearing if the
defendant or respondent requests.
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004; amd. Ord. 2022-9-12A, 9-12-2022)
1-4A-5: BAIL:
   A.   Any person authorized to issue a violation notice under the provisions
of subsection
1-4A-4A2 of this article may require the defendant or respondent to post bail
at the time the violation notice is served, if: 1) the violation notice is
served by handing the violation notice to the defendant or respondent; and 2)
the person issuing the violation notice has reason to believe that the
defendant or respondent may not appear for the hearing on the violation
specified in the violation notice. Reasons to believe that a defendant or
respondent may not appear at the hearing on a violation shall include, but not
be limited to: 1) the defendant or respondent residing outside the Village
corporate limits and not being employed or having a place of business in the
Village; and 2) the defendant or respondent having failed to appear for a
hearing on prior occasions on the same or a different violation.
   B.   Where bail is required to be posted, the bail shall be in the form of
cash or a cash bond. For purposes of this article, cash or cash bond shall mean
United States currency; traveler’s checks issued by major banks or express
companies which, alone or in combination with currency, total the exact amount
required to be deposited as bail; and negotiable drafts on major credit card
companies, under conditions approved by the Chief of Public Safety or such
person as may be designated by the Chief of Public Safety to have the authority
to approve or establish the conditions for the acceptance of negotiable drafts
on credit card companies.
   C.   Bail shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for offenses other than
offenses related to the parking of motor vehicles or violations of subsection
6-11-2B or section
8-1-1 of this Code. Bail for offenses related to the illegal parking of a motor
vehicle shall be thirty five dollars ($35.00); except, that bail for a
violation related to the illegal parking of a motor vehicle in a fire lane, the
illegal parking of a motor vehicle in proximity to a fire hydrant or the
illegal parking of a motor vehicle in a parking space designated for persons
who are handicapped or have a disability shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00). Any bail that may be required where a motor vehicle is seized and
impounded pursuant to the provisions of title 6, chapter 10 of this Code shall
be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any bond that may be required to be
posted under the provisions of said
title 6, chapter 11. Bail for violations of subsection
6-11-2B or section
8-1-1 of this Code shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00).
(Ord. 2011-10-12M. 10-12-2011)
   D.   The Village Public Safety Department shall charge a bail processing fee
as set forth by the Cook County Circuit Court, to each person that is released
on bail following an arrest for violating any bailable Municipal, State or
Federal offense. However, the release of any individual on bail shall not be
denied solely because of the individual's inability to pay the bail processing
fee.
(Ord. 2011-10-12L, 10-12-2011)
1-4A-6: HEARINGS:
All hearings conducted under the administrative hearing system shall be
conducted by a Hearing Officer and shall be conducted in accordance with the
following rules and procedures:
   A.   A record of the hearing shall be made by tape recording or other
appropriate means.
   B.   The parties may be represented by counsel, present witnesses, and cross
examine opposing witnesses.
   C.   The Hearing Officer may grant continuances upon a finding of good
cause.
   D.   All testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation.
   E.   Parties may request the Hearing Officer to issue, and the Hearing
Officer shall have the authority to issue, subpoenas to direct the attendance
and testimony of relevant witnesses and produce relevant documents.
   F.   The formal and technical rules of evidence shall not apply. Evidence,
including hearsay evidence, may be admitted only if it is of a type commonly
relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs.
   G.   In a hearing on the propriety of the seizure and impoundment of a
vehicle, any sworn or affirmed report citation or ticket that: 1) is prepared
in the performance of a law enforcement officer's duties; and 2) sufficiently
describes the circumstances leading to the impoundment, shall be admissible
evidence of the vehicle owner's liability, unless rebutted by clear and
convincing evidence.
   H.   Each hearing shall culminate in a determination of liability or
nonliability by the Hearing Officer or a determination of liability based upon
the failure of the defendant or respondent to appear at the hearing. The
Hearing Officer’s determination shall be in writing and shall include a written
finding of fact, decision, and order, including the fine, penalty, or other
action with which the defendant or respondent must comply.
   I.   The Hearing Officer shall, upon a determination of liability, assess
fines and penalties in accordance with the fine and penalty that is applicable
under the codes and ordinances of the Village for the violation that occurred.
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004)
1-4A-7: JUDICIAL REVIEW:
Any final decision by a Hearing Officer that a violation does or does not exist
shall constitute a final determination for purposes of judicial review and
shall be subject to review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law (735
ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.) as provided in section 1-2.1-7 of the Illinois Municipal
Code.
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004)
1-4A-8: DEBT TO VILLAGE:
Any fine, penalty or part of any fine or penalty assessed in accordance with
the provisions of this article and remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or
the failure to exhaust, administrative procedures under this article, and the
conclusion of any judicial review procedures, shall be a debt due and owing the
Village, and, as such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law.
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004)
1-4A-9: ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS:
   A.   After expiration of the period that judicial review under the Illinois
Administrative Review Law maybe sought for a final determination of any
violation, unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, the
determination, including the findings, decision, and order, of the Hearing
Officer, may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of
competent jurisdiction.
   B.   In any case in which a defendant or respondent has failed to comply
with a judgment ordering a defendant to correct a violation or imposing any
fine or other sanction as a result of a violation, any expenses incurred by the
Village to enforce the judgment including, but not limited to, attorney fees,
court costs and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure, after they
are fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or a Hearing Officer, shall be a
debt due and owing the Village and may be collected in accordance with
applicable law.
   C.   Prior to any expenses being fixed by the Hearing Officer pursuant to
subsection B of this section, the Village shall provide a notice to the
defendant or respondent that states that the defendant or respondent shall
appear at a hearing before the Hearing Officer to determine whether the
defendant or respondent has failed to comply with the judgment. The notice
shall set the date for such hearing that shall not be less than seven (7) days
from the date that notice is served. If notice is served by mail, the seven (7)
day period shall begin to run on the date that the notice is deposited in the
mail.
   D.   Upon being recorded in the manner required by article XII of the
Illinois Code of Civil Procedure (735 ILCS 5/12-101 et seq.), or by the Uniform
Commercial Code (810 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.), a lien shall be imposed on the real
estate or personal estate, or both, of the defendant or respondent in the
amount of any debt due and owing the Village under section 1-4A-8 of this
article. This lien may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment lien
pursuant to a judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction.
   E.   A Hearing Officer may set aside any judgement entered by default and
set a new hearing date, upon a petition filed within twenty one (21) days after
the issuance of the determination or order of default, if the Hearing Officer
determines that a defendant's or respondent's failure to appear at the hearing
was for good cause or at any time if the defendant or respondent establishes
that the Village did not provide proper service of process. If any judgement is
set aside pursuant to this subsection, the Hearing Officer shall enter an order
extinguishing or releasing any lien which has been recorded for any debt due
and owing the Village as a result of the vacated default judgment.
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004)
1-4A-10: PROCEDURES NOT EXCLUSIVE:
The provisions of this article shall not preclude the Village from using other
methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of the codes and
ordinances of the Village specified in subsection 1-4A-1A of this article
including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the Circuit
Court of Cook County or before another administrative tribunal which has
jurisdiction to consider the violation.
(Ord. 2004-12-1F, 12-1-2004)
CHAPTER 5: OFFICIAL ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS
Section
1-5-1:   Corporate Seal
1-5-2:   Inauguration Of Elected Officials
1-5-3:   English Language Required For Documents
1-5-1: CORPORATE SEAL:
   A.   Description: The Corporate Seal of the Village shall be circular in
form, and be so constructed as to impress upon paper the words “Official Seal”,
in a circle formed by the words “Village of Rosemont, Cook County, Illinois.”
(1971 Code § 2-1)
   B.   Use And Custody: The Seal shall be and remain in the custody of the
Village Clerk, and his successor in office, to be used by him in all cases
provided in this Code and the ordinances of the Village or the laws of the
State of Illinois, and in all such other cases where, by the laws and customs
of the State or Nation, the use of the Corporate Seal of the Village becomes
necessary.
(1971 Code § 2-2)
1-5-2: INAUGURATION OF ELECTED OFFICIALS:
The date and time for the inauguration of newly elected Municipal officers of
the Village shall be the first regular meeting of the Village Board of Trustees
during the month of May next following the proclamation of the results of the
general Municipal election at which such officers were elected, and the terms
of office of such officers shall commence from and after such inauguration. In
the event that the proclamation of the results of such general Municipal
election has not been received prior to the first regular meeting of the
Village Board of Trustees during the month of May next following such election,
the date and time for the inauguration of such Municipal officers shall be the
first regular or special meeting of the Village Board of Trustees during the
month of June next following receipt of the proclamation of the results of the
general Municipal election at which such officers were elected, and the terms
of such officers shall commence from and after such inauguration.
(Ord. 2012-10-10, 10-10-2012)
1-5-3: ENGLISH LANGUAGE REQUIRED FOR DOCUMENTS:
All notices, reports, statements, applications and records required or
authorized by this Code shall be made in writing in the English language,
unless specifically provided otherwise.
(1971 Code § 1-14)
CHAPTER 6: VILLAGE PRESIDENT
Section
1-6-1:   Elected Official
1-6-2:   Bond And Oath
1-6-3:   Compensation
1-6-4:   Powers, Duties And Responsibilities
1-6-5:   Responsibilities Regarding Appointive Officials
1-6-6:   Serve As Local Liquor Control Commissioner
1-6-7:   Acting President
1-6-8:   Administrative Aide
1-6-1: ELECTED OFFICIAL:
The President of the Board of Trustees shall be elected for a four (4) year
term by the electors of the Village at a general Municipal election held
therein and shall serve until his successor is elected and qualified as
provided by statute.
(1971 Code § 2-8)
1-6-2: BOND AND OATH:
   A.   Before entering upon the duties of his office, the President shall give
bond as provided in section 1-9-2 of this title.
(1971 Code § 2-11; amd. 2019 Code)
   B.   The President shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute.
(1971 Code § 2-11; amd. 2019 Code)
1-6-3: COMPENSATION:
   A.   The Village President shall be paid an annual salary as determined from
time to time by the Corporate Authorities.
   B.   In addition to the amount provided in subsection A of this section, the
Village President shall also be paid a salary at the annual rate for serving as
the Village Local Liquor Control Commissioner as determined from time to time
by the Corporate Authorities.
(Ord. 2016-8-10F, 8-10-2016)
1-6-4: POWERS, DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
   A.   The Village President shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the
Village and shall exercise all such powers and duties as may be provided by
statute or by this Code or by ordinance.
   B.   The Village President shall have supervision over all of the executive
officers of the Village, and shall have the power and authority to inspect all
books and records kept by any officer of the Village at any reasonable time.
(1971 Code § 2-9)
   C.   The Village President shall also have the following responsibilities:
      1.   To assist in the preparation of the Village annual budget for
Village operations and recommend capital programs, and direct the
implementation of the approved budget after adoption.
      2.   To recommend the necessary appropriations and levies to the Board of
Trustees.
      3.   To establish the agenda for all meetings of the Village Board of
Trustees.
      4.   To review and recommend necessary purchases for the Village.
      5.   To monitor the financial condition and needs of the Village.
      6.   To recommend the measures he deems necessary for the improvement of
the administrative services of the Village or in the best interests of the
Village.
      7.   To coordinate the functions of the various departments, committees,
officers and employees of the Village, and such other department heads or
appointed officers as have been or are hereafter created to ensure that all
Village business is accomplished efficiently and economically.
      8.   To direct and oversee the proper administration of the affairs of
the Village and policies adopted by the Board of Trustees.
      9.   To propose such personnel rules and regulations as deemed necessary
to manage the personnel of the Village. These rules may cover procedures and
policies which may include, but are necessarily limited to, the following:
         a.   The administration of the position description, classification
and pay plans.
         b.   Recruitment, selection, promotion, evaluation, transfer,
discipline and separation of Village personnel.
         c.   Establishment of hours of work, attendance, leave regulations and
working conditions.
      10.   To recommend the creating, consolidating, and combining of offices,
positions, departments or units of the administrative and executive departments
of the Village as deemed necessary for the efficient operation of all of the
Village services and activities.
      11.   To investigate, develop and promote new economic development
opportunities for the Village and negotiate and recommend economic development
agreements deemed to be in the Village’s best interest.
      12.   To oversee Village construction projects in conjunction with the
Village Engineer and other professional consultants and serve as the Village
representative for such projects.
      13.   To represent the Village in its dealings with other governmental
agencies and officials, businesses, not for profit organizations, residents,
and the general public as necessary.
      14.   To evaluate Village projects, programs, agreements and services and
make recommendations on modifications and improvements thereto.
      15.   To serve as the Village Local Liquor Control Commissioner in
accordance with all related Village ordinances governing liquor and related
State laws.
      16.   To perform all other powers granted to village presidents and
mayors by law and to faithfully and honestly discharge the duties and powers
associated with such office.
(Ord. 2016-8-10F, 8-10-2016)
1-6-5: RESPONSIBILITIES REGARDING APPOINTIVE OFFICIALS:
   A.   The President shall appoint, by and with the advice and consent of the
Board of Trustees, all officers of the Village whose appointment or election is
not otherwise provided for. Any vacancies occurring in appointive offices shall
be filled in the same manner.
   B.   Whenever there is a dispute as to the respective duties or powers of
any officer of the Village, this dispute shall be settled by the President
after consultation with the Village Attorney.
   C.   The President shall have the power to delegate to any officer any duty
which is to be performed when no specific officer has been directed to perform
that duty.
(1971 Code § 2-10)
1-6-6: SERVE AS LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
The Village President shall be the Local Liquor Control Commissioner and shall
perform all such duties as may be required of him in that capacity by statute
or this Code.
(1971 Code § 2-12; amd. 2019 Code)
1-6-7: ACTING PRESIDENT:
Whenever any power shall be vested in the Village President or he shall be
required to do any act, or perform any executive function, in his absence, it
shall be the duty of the Acting President, for the time being, to exercise such
power and perform such act or executive function as fully as if especially
named in this Code or in an ordinance, unless it shall be therein otherwise
expressly provided.
(1971 Code § 2-13)
1-6-8: ADMINISTRATIVE AIDE:
   A.   Position Created: The position of Administrative Aide to the Mayor is
hereby created. The Administrative Aide to the Mayor shall report directly to
and take direction from the Mayor.
   B.   Duties And Responsibilities: The duties and responsibilities of the
Administrative Aide to the Mayor shall include the following:
      1.   Assist the Mayor as requested by the Mayor in administering and
managing the operations of the Village.
      2.   At the direction of the Mayor, undertake to implement decisions made
by the Mayor and decisions made by the Village Board of Trustees.
      3.   When appropriate, provide recommendations to the Mayor as to how the
operations and management of the Village may be made more efficient.
      4.   Undertake to perform such assignments and projects as may be
requested by the Mayor.
      5.   Perform such other tasks as may be assigned or directed by the
Mayor.
   C.    Employee Of Village: The position of Administrative Aide to the Mayor
shall not be an office of the Village. The person who occupies the position of
Administrative Aide to the Mayor may be an employee of the Village or an
independent contractor.
   D.   Compensation: If the Administrative Aide to the Mayor is a Village
employee, then the salary and other compensation to be paid to the
Administrative Aide shall be established from time to time by the Corporate
Authorities of the Village. If the Administrative Aide to the Mayor is an
independent contractor, then the salary and other compensation to be paid to
the Administrative Aide shall be established by contract.
(Ord. 2006-6-7G, 6-7-2006)
CHAPTER 7: VILLAGE BOARD OF TRUSTEES
Section
1-7-1:   Elected Officials; Terms
1-7-2:   Oath And Salary
1-7-3:   Meetings And Rules
1-7-4:   Powers And Duties
1-7-5:   Ordinances
1-7-6:   Eminent Domain Powers
1-7-1: ELECTED OFFICIALS; TERMS:
The Board of Trustees shall consist of six (6) members elected for a four (4)
year term by the electors of the Village at a general Municipal election held
therein and shall serve until their successors are elected and qualified as
provided by statute.
(1971 Code § 2-16)
1-7-2: OATH AND SALARY
 
   A.   Oath Of Office: The members of the Board of Trustees, before entering
upon the duties of their office, shall take the oath of office prescribed by
statute.
(Ord. 75-4-16, 4-16-1975)
   B.   Salary: The Village Trustees that serve in a term of office as Village
Trustee that begins after the election held in April 2013 shall continue to be
paid a salary at the annual rate of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00).
(Ord. 2012-11-7, 11-7-2012)
1-7-3: MEETINGS AND RULES:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The regular meetings of the Village Board of Trustees
shall be held on the second Wednesday of each calendar month at nine thirty
o'clock (9:30) A.M. unless otherwise ordered at a regular meeting, as provided
by the Illinois Open Meeting Act.
(Ord. 76-3-17D, 3-17-1976)
   B.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be held at any time on call of
the President or of any three (3) or more Trustees. Such call shall be in
writing, duly signed, and shall be presented to the Village Clerk, who shall
immediately proceed to prepare notices of the same, and shall cause them to be
served on the members of the Board in the usual manner.
(1971 Code § 2-14)
   C.   Procedure At Meetings; Rules Of Order; Quorum; Order Of Business:
      1.   Robert’s Rules of Order shall prevail except where otherwise
provided.
      2.   At the hour appointed for the meeting, the Village Clerk (or someone
appointed to fill his place) shall proceed to call the roll of the members,
mark the absentees and announce whether a quorum is present. If a quorum is
present, the meeting shall be called to order, the President taking the Chair,
if present, and the Board appointing a Temporary Chair if he should be absent.
If a quorum does not appear, the meeting shall not thereby stand adjourned,
unless by a vote of the members present. When a quorum is present, the meeting
shall proceed to the business before it, which shall be conducted in the
following order:
      3.   All questions relating to the priority of business shall be opened
by the Chair, without debate, subject to appeal.
(1971 Code § 2-15)
1-7-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Board of Trustees shall be the legislative body of the Village and shall
perform all such powers and duties as may be provided by statute or by this
Code or by ordinance.
(1971 Code § 2-17)
1-7-5: ORDINANCES:
   A.   Publication And Records: All ordinances passed by the President and
Board of Trustees shall be recorded by the Village Clerk in a book kept for
Village ordinances. The original shall be filed in the Office of the Clerk, and
due proof of publication of all ordinances requiring publication shall be
procured by the Clerk. Such proof or affidavit of publication shall be attached
to and filed away with the ordinances, and the Clerk shall also note on the
book of ordinances, at the foot of the record of each ordinance, a memorandum
of the date of the passage of and, if published or posted, the date of the
publication or posting of the ordinance.
(1971 Code § 1-5)
   B.   Effective Date: All ordinances passed by the President and Board of
Trustees requiring publication shall take effect after due publication thereof,
as required by law or as otherwise determined in the ordinance. Ordinances not
requiring publication shall take effect from and after their passage, unless
otherwise provided therein.
(1971 Code § 1-6)
1-7-6: EMINENT DOMAIN POWERS:
   A.   Exercise Of Powers Generally:
      1.   The Corporate Authorities may exercise their power of eminent domain
to condemn property for any public purpose. The Corporate Authorities may
exercise their condemnation power for any public purpose authorized to the
Municipal Corporation by statute or any other public purpose which will be
useful, advantageous or desirable within its home rule powers as established by
ordinance. The Corporate Authorities shall commence such condemnation by an
ordinance or resolution which shall state the purpose or purposes for which the
property is to be acquired and shall be used.
      2.   A public purpose shall exist if the property, after its acquisition,
is useful, advantageous or desirable for Municipal purposes.
(1971 Code § 2-114)
   B.   Procedures: In all cases where property is acquired or sought to be
acquired by condemnation, the procedure shall be like that provided in the
Eminent Domain Act, as amended (735 ILCS 30/1-1-1 et seq.)
(1971 Code § 2-115; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 8: VILLAGE CLERK
Section
1-8-1:   Elected Official; Oath Of Office
1-8-2:   Bond
1-8-3:   Salary
1-8-4:   Duties
1-8-5:   Vacancy In Office
1-8-6:   Deputy Clerk
1-8-1: ELECTED OFFICIAL; OATH OF OFFICE:
The Village Clerk shall be elected for a term of four (4) years and shall take
the statutory oath of office.
(1971 Code § 2-19)
1-8-2: BOND:
The Village Clerk shall give a bond, with security to be approved by the Board
of Trustees, as provided by law, conditioned upon the faithful performance of
his/her duties.
(1971 Code § 2-19)
1-8-3: SALARY:
The Village Clerk shall be paid an annual salary as determined from time to
time by the Corporate Authorities. This salary shall be in addition to any
salary that is also received for the position as Village Collector.
(Ord. 2016-8-10F, 8-10-2016)
1-8-4: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the Village Clerk to:
   A.   Attend the special and stated meetings of the Board of Trustees and
keep a full record of its proceedings in the journal, and record in a book to
be kept for that purpose, all ordinances which may be passed from time to time
by the Board, and at the foot of the record of each ordinance so recorded, make
a memorandum of the date of the passage and of the publishing of such
ordinance.
   B.   Keep and preserve all papers required by statute to be retained in his
office. The office shall be at the general offices of the Village.
   C.   Notify all officers and employees appointed by the President of their
appointment.
   D.   Have the charge, custody and control of the Corporate Seal.
(Ord. 75-9-17E, 9-17-1975)
1-8-5: VACANCY IN OFFICE:
In the case the office of the Village Clerk shall become vacant for any reason,
and there remains an unexpired portion of the term of at least twenty eight
(28) months, and the vacancy occurs at least one hundred thirty (130) days
before the next general municipal election, then the vacancy shall be filled
for the remainder of the term at that general municipal election. Until said
election, or if the vacancy occurs with less than twenty eight (28) months
remaining or less than one hundred thirty (130) days before the next general
municipal election, the Village President shall appoint a qualified person as
Village Clerk to hold the office until it is filled by election, subject to the
advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
(1971 Code § 2-20)
1-8-6: DEPUTY CLERK:
The Village Clerk may appoint, with the approval of the President and Board of
Trustees, such Deputy Clerk or Clerks as may be necessary.
(1971 Code § 2-19)
CHAPTER 9: VILLAGE OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL
Section
1-9-1:   Residency Requirements Of Full-Time Officers And Employees
1-9-2:   Bond Requirements
1-9-3:   Appointment Of Previously Elected Officials To Appointive Positions
1-9-1: RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS FOR FULL-TIME OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
   A.   Each person hired as a full-time employee or appointed to be a full-
time officer of the Village must, within ninety (90) days of the date he or she
first takes office or is first employed as a full-time officer or employee,
establish and thereafter maintain his or her primary residency within the
corporate limits of the Village, as a continuing condition of such employment
or office; provided, that if the Mayor finds that compliance with the
requirement that residency within the Village be established within ninety (90)
days of the date a person is first employed or first takes office as a full-
time employee or officer would impose a substantial hardship on a person who is
hired to serve as a department head or in another supervisory capacity, either:
1) because it is necessary for such person to sell his or her current residence
in order to reasonably be able to afford to purchase a residence within the
Village; 2) because it would disrupt the education of such a person's child
because the child would have to transfer schools when residency is established
in the Village; or 3) because of a reason that would impose an equivalent
hardship, then the Mayor may extend the time period within which such person
must establish residency within the Village to a date that is not more than
thirty-six (36) months after the date the person first takes office or is first
employed as a full-time officer or employee. Any such extension granted by the
Mayor must be made in writing.
   B.   Each present full-time employee and each present full-time officer of
the Village who, on the effective date hereof, resides within the corporate
limits of the Village, must maintain his or her residence within the corporate
limits of the Village, as a continuing condition of such employment or office.
   C.   For purposes of this section, a person's residence is within the
Village if he or she is an actual bona fide resident of the Village with a
permanent abode therein.
   D.   Noncompliance or violation of the residence requirements set forth in
this section shall constitute grounds for immediate discharge from the service
and employment of the Village.
   E.   The residence requirements imposed by this section do not apply to any
full-time employee or full- time officer of the Village who, on the effective
date hereof, resides outside of the corporate limits of the Village, or to
part-time employees, part-time appointed officers, independent contractors, and
persons who, while performing services for the Village, are actually employed
by another governmental unit or private organization.
   F.   If the Corporate Authorities find that because a position or office
requires specialized technical or professional training, it is not possible to
fill the position or office with a person who is or who will become a resident
of the Village as required by subsection A of this section, the Corporate
Authorities may, by motion, provide that the officer or employee who is
appointed to the office or hired to fill the position shall not be required to
establish residency within the Village as required by said subsection A.
   G.   If the Corporate Authorities find it is not possible to fill an office
or a position with a person who is or who will become a resident of the Village
as required by subsection A of this section, the Corporate Authorities may, by
motion, authorize the employment of a temporary employee or the appointment of
a temporary officer to fill the position or office for a period not to exceed
Thirty-six months. Persons appointed to be temporary employees or temporary
officers pursuant to this subsection shall not be required to be residents of
the Village as a continuing condition of such employment or office.
   H.   If the Corporate Authorities of the Village find that because of an
employee's or officer's experience, knowledge and expertise, it is in the best
interests of the Village to retain a full-time employee or officer who is
otherwise eligible to retire, then the Corporate Authorities may, by motion,
permit such a full-time employee or officer of the Village to establish
residency outside the Village; provided, that the employee or officer: 1) has
been employed by the Village for not less than twenty five (25) years; and 2)
is eligible to receive retirement benefits from either the Illinois Municipal
Retirement Fund or the Village Public Safety Officers' Pension Fund.
   I.   The residency requirements imposed by this section shall be suspended
with respect to any full-time civilian employees of the Department of Public
Safety who are members of the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund and who have
been continuously employed for a period of not less than ten (10) years as
full-time employees of the Village in the Department of Public Safety. The
exceptions from the residency requirement for full-time officers and full-time
employees of the Village stated in this subsection shall terminate
automatically should any such employee or officer subsequently move from his or
her established residency location outside the Village in effect as of the
effective date hereof for any purpose other than immediately establishing a
permanent and full-time residency in the Village. Each such full-time employee
or officer shall, within thirty (30) days of the effective date hereof, submit
a written resignation to the Village; provided, that he or she voluntarily
resigns his or her employment or office with the Village effective immediately
upon any change in the grandfathered residency provided in this section, other
than for the purpose of the immediate establishment of a permanent and full-
time residency in the Village.
   J.   The residency requirements imposed by this section shall be suspended
with respect to any full-time treasurers, full-time assistant treasurers and
full-time ticket sellers working at the Allstate Arena and the Rosemont Theatre
who: 1) as of the effective date hereof, had been continuously employed in such
capacity for a period of not less than one year as the employees of an
independent contractor performing contractual services for the Village under a
multi-year agreement prior to the effective date hereof; and 2) who were
subsequently transferred to direct employment with the Village to continue
performing such services as Village employees.
(Ord. 78-1-18A, 1-18-1978; Ord. 2003-4-2L, 4-2-2003; Ord. 2005-1-12L, 1-12-
2005; Ord. 2013-6-12E, 6-12-2013; Ord. 2014-2-12F, 2-12-2014; Ord. 2021-9-13D,
9-13-2021)
1-9-2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
The Village President and Village Finance Director shall be required to execute
a bond with security to be approved by the Corporate Authorities, as provided
by law, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of their
respective offices. Such bonds shall be filed with the Village Clerk. The
premium for such bonds shall be paid by the Village.
(Ord. 82-5-19, 5-19-1982)
1-9-3: APPOINTMENT OF PREVIOUSLY ELECTED OFFICIALS TO APPOINTIVE POSITIONS:
Any elector within the Village who is otherwise qualified to hold an appointed
Municipal office or employment may accept or be appointed to such Municipal
office or employment by the Village President as hereinafter provided in spite
of the fact that his service in such Municipal appointed office or employment
shall commence or continue during a portion of the term of office as a member
of the Board of Trustees for which he was elected and in which he would have
served but for his resignation. In the event the Village President desires to
appoint a former Village Trustee to an appointive office or employment within
the Village during the unexpired portion of the term of office for which the
Trustee was elected, the appointment must be approved by the vote of two-thirds
(2/3) of the remaining members of the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 75-5-7G, 5-7-1975)

ARTICLE C: VILLAGE ATTORNEY
Section
1-9C-1:   Office Created; Appointment
1-9C-2:   Compensation
1-9C-3:   Powers And Duties
1-9C-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
There shall be the office of Village Attorney, such attorney to be appointed by
the President, with the advice of the Board of Trustees, in the same manner and
form as that of appointments of other appointive officers of the Village.
(1971 Code § 2-42)
1-9C-2: COMPENSATION:
The Village Attorney shall receive such compensation for his ordinary and
routine services as may be set from time to time by the Board of Trustees, and
he shall receive additional compensation for services rendered in connection
with special assessment and for condemnation proceedings, litigated matters,
general obligation bond issues, revenue bond issues, the preparation and
drafting of involved ordinances or resolutions, the revising of ordinances or
the preparation of a code of ordinances, or other matter requiring an unusual
amount of time or services.
(1971 Code § 2-44)
1-9C-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The Village Attorney shall act as Attorney for the Village in
connection with all legal matters pertaining thereto, including attendance at
regular and special meetings of the President and Board of Trustees when
requested to do so, preparation and drafting of ordinances and resolutions,
rendering services in litigated matters, general obligation bond issues, revise
ordinances and act as attorney in connection with all special assessment and
condemnation proceedings to be instituted by the Village.
   B.   The Village Attorney shall consult with and advise any officer or
representative of the Village in connection with Municipal problems and matters
and shall render other legal services when requested so to do by the Board of
Trustees, or any officer or representative of the Village.
   C.   The Village Attorney shall have complete charge of any proceeding or
legal matter referred to him, subject to the control and direction of the Board
of Trustees.
   D.   The Village Attorney is authorized to enter his appearance in and to
take charge of all proceedings now pending or which may hereafter be pending,
including special assessment and/or condemnation proceedings, in which the
Village is a party, in all courts of record in the State of Illinois, and
before all commissions, boards or judicial bodies.
(1971 Code § 2-43)
ARTICLE D: DIRECTOR OF THE HEALTH AND LICENSING DEPARTMENT
Section
1-9D-1:   Office Created; Appointment
1-9D-2:   Qualifications
1-9D-3:   Compensation
1-9D-4:   Duties And Responsibilities
1-9D-5:   Enforcement Authority
1-9D-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
The office of Director of the Health and Licensing Department is hereby
created. The Village President shall appoint the Director, subject to the
advice and consent of the Village Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2002-12-4H, 12-4-2002)
1-9D-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The person appointed to serve as Director of the Health and Licensing
Department must be licensed as an Environmental Health Inspector as provided by
and in accordance with “An Act Regulating the Occupation of Environmental
Health Practitioners (225 ILCS 37/5 et seq.)” and shall possess all other
licenses which may be required in order to perform the duties of Director.
(Ord. 2002-12-4H, 12-4-2002)
1-9D-3: COMPENSATION:
The salary and other compensation to be paid to the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department shall be established from time to time by the Corporate
Authorities of the Village.
(Ord. 2002-12-4H, 12-4-2002)
1-9D-4: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The duties and responsibilities of the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
   A.   Enforce the Village ordinances, rules and regulations that are intended
to maintain or protect the public health including, but not limited to,
ordinances, rules and regulations which relate to sanitation; the storage,
preparation and sale of food and beverages; garbage and trash storage and
disposal; and rodent control.
   B.   Enforce the Village ordinances, rules and regulations that are intended
to prohibit the creation or maintenance of conditions that constitute public
nuisances.
   C.   Enforce the Village ordinances, rules and regulations that provide for
the licensing and regulating of businesses in the Village, except to the extent
that such enforcement has been assigned by ordinance or by the Village
President to another Village department or officer.
   D.   Enforce rules and regulations promulgated by the Illinois Department of
Public Health to the extent that the Village has the authority to enforce such
rules and regulations.
   E.   Conduct inspections of public and private property for the purpose of
determining whether there are violations of applicable ordinances, rules or
regulations of the Village relating to the maintenance and protection of the
public health, the prohibition of nuisances, the regulation of businesses, and
for the purpose of determining whether there are violations of the rules and
regulations of the Illinois Department of Public Health which the Village has
the authority to enforce.
   F.   Make recommendations to the Corporate Authorities relating to the
adoption and revision of ordinances, codes, rules and regulations that are
intended to maintain and protect the public health or prevent the maintenance
or creation of conditions that constitute public nuisances.
   G.   Undertake programs intended to educate the public regarding public
health matters, and where a public health hazard or other problem is found to
exist in the Village, to undertake programs designed to educate the public
regarding the existence of the hazard or other problem and the steps that can
be taken to protect against the hazard or other problem.
   H.   Such other duties and responsibilities as may be assigned or designated
by the Village President or the Corporate Authorities of the Village.
(Ord. 2002-12-4H, 12-4-2002)
1-9D-5: ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITY:
The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall have the authority
to:
   A.   Issue citations and sign complaints on behalf of the Village for
violation of Village ordinances, codes, rules and regulations relating to the
maintenance or protection of the public health, the prohibition of nuisances,
the licensing and regulation of businesses, or which otherwise relate to the
performance of his duties and responsibilities.
   B.   Issue citations and sign complaints on behalf of the Village for
violation of those rules and regulations of the Illinois Department of Public
Health which the Village has the authority to enforce.
   C.   Apply for warrants whenever necessary in order to be able to conduct an
inspection of private property.
(Ord. 2002-12-4H, 12-4-2002)
CHAPTER 10: VILLAGE DEPARTMENTS
ARTICLE A. PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
Section
1-10A-1:   Department Created; Composition
1-10A-2:   Director Of Public Works
1-10A-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED; COMPOSITION:
There shall be the Department of Public Works, an administrative department of
the Village. The department shall consist of a Director of Public Works and
such assistants and employees as may be provided by ordinance.
(1971 Code § 2-51)
1-10A-2: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS:
   A.   Appointment: The President and the Board of Trustees shall appoint the
Director of Public Works who shall observe, obey and carry out the orders and
directions of the President and the Board of Trustees.
(1971 Code § 22-12)

(1971 Code § 2-54)
   C.   Powers And Duties:

(1971 Code § 2-55)
ARTICLE B: ROSEMONT CONVENTION AND TOURISM BUREAU
Section
1-10B-1:   Declared A Village Department
1-10B-2:   Purpose And Function
1-10B-3:   General Manager Of Bureau
1-10B-1: DECLARED A VILLAGE DEPARTMENT:
The Rosemont Convention and Tourism Bureau is hereby declared to be a

(Ord. 84-11-7B, 11-7-1984)

The purpose and function of the Rosemont Convention and Tourism Bureau is to

administer and operate the Rosemont Convention and Tourism Bureau under the

Convention Center and the Village President.
(Ord. 84-11-7B, 11-7-1984)
CHAPTER 11: ETHICS
Section:
1-11-1:   Definitions
1-11-2:   Prohibited Political Activities
1-11-3:   Gift Ban
1-11-4:   Violations; Penalties
1-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall be given these
definitions:
