for the second and each subsequent offense in any one hundred eighty (180) day
period; provided, however, that all actions seeking the imposition of fines
only shall be filed as quasi-criminal actions subject to the provisions of the
Illinois Civil Practice Law (735 ILCS 5/2-101 et seq.) A separate and distinct
offense shall be regarded as committed each day upon which said person shall
continue any such violation or permit any such violation to exist after
notification thereof.
(Ord. 2013-7-10C, 7-10-2013)
3-9-8: DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS OF TAX AND FINES:
All proceeds resulting from the imposition of the tax under this chapter,
including penalties, shall be paid into the Treasury of the Village.
(Ord. 2013-7-10C, 7-10-2013)

Abandoned vehicle                                                                 $100
 
(Ord. 2017-11-8J, 11-8-2017; amd. Ord. 2018-4-11A, 4-11-2018; Ord. 2018-6-13B,
6-13-2018; 2019 Code; Ord. 2020-6-10B, 6-10-2020; Ord. 2022-1-10A, 1-10-2022;

CHAPTER 11: ADDITIONAL FEES AND CHARGES
ARTICLE A: ROSEMONT THEATRE AND
ALLSTATE ARENA SERVICES FEE
Section
3-11A-1:   Fee Established; Exemption
3-11A-2:   Payment Of Fee
3-11A-3:   Waiver Of Fee; Sharing Revenues
3-11A-4:   Implementation Of Fee Approved By Village
3-11A-1: FEE ESTABLISHED; EXEMPTION:
For events occurring at the Rosemont Theatre and the Allstate Arena, a
facilities service fee surcharge in the amount of two dollars ($2.00) or as may
be changed subject to approval by the Corporate Authorities, shall be added to
the amount to be paid by the initial purchaser of a ticket to any event at the
Rosemont Theatre and the Allstate Arena for which tickets are made available
for sale to the general public. The facilities service charge shall be in
addition to the amount paid by the ticket purchaser for the privilege of
witnessing or participating in the event at the Rosemont Theatre and the
Allstate Arena and shall be paid in addition to any amounts included in the
purchase price of the ticket that are collected from the ticket purchaser to
cover taxes that may be due as a result of the sale of the ticket. The
facilities service fee shall not be imposed on any ticket which is not
initially sold for monetary consideration.
(Ord. 2009-1-7D, 1-7-2009, eff. retroactive to 1-1-2009)
3-11A-2: PAYMENT OF FEE:
Any amounts collected as a result of the imposition of the facilities service
fee provided in section
3-11A-1 of this article shall be paid to the Village and shall be paid to the
Village at the time of the settlement for the event for which a ticket is sold
or within not more than thirty (30) days after the date such event occurs,
whichever occurs first.
(Ord. 2009-1-7D, 1-7-2009, eff. retroactive to 1-1-2009)
3-11A-3: WAIVER OF FEE; SHARING REVENUES:
   A.   The Village Executive Director of Entertainment Facilities, with the
approval of the Village President, shall have the authority to waive the
imposition of the facilities service fee provided in section
3-11A-1 of this article for tickets sold to an event where the Executive
Director of Entertainment Facilities, in the reasonable exercise of his
discretion, determines that it is necessary to waive the imposition of the fee
in order to be able to induce the producer, promoter or owner of the event to
agree to have the event occur at the Rosemont Theatre or the Allstate Arena.
   B.   The Village Executive Director of Entertainment Facilities, with the
approval of the Village President, shall also have the authority to share all
or any portion of the revenue generated by the facilities service fee provided
in section
3-11A-1 of this article for tickets sold to an event with the producer,
promoter or owner of the event where the Executive Director of Entertainment
Facilities, in the reasonable exercise of his discretion, determines that it is
necessary to share such revenue in order to be able to induce the producer,
promoter or owner of the event to agree to have the event occur at the Rosemont
Theatre or the Allstate Arena.
(Ord. 2009-1-7D, 1-7-2009, eff. retroactive to 1-1-2009)
3-11A-4: IMPLEMENTATION OF FEE APPROVED BY VILLAGE:
The Corporate Authorities of the Village do hereby approve any and all actions
taken on behalf of the Village by the Village Executive Director of
Entertainment Facilities, the general manager of the Rosemont Theatre or the
Allstate Arena, or by any other officer, employee or independent contractor of
the Village to implement the imposition of the facilities services fee provided
in section
3-11A-1 of this article in a manner which is consistent with the provisions of
this article.
(Ord. 2009-1-7D, 1-7-2009, eff. retroactive to 1-1-2009)
ARTICLE B: 9-1-1 EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SERVICE SURCHARGE
Section
3-11B-1:   Definitions
3-11B-2:   Surcharge Imposed
3-11B-3:   Effective Date Of Surcharge
3-11B-4:   Collector Reimbursement
3-11B-5:   Surcharge Remittance And Return
3-11B-6:   Credit For Erroneous Payments
3-11B-7:   Statute Of Limitations
3-11B-8:   Copy Of Provisions To Collector
3-11B-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply:
NETWORK CONNECTION: The number of voice grade communication channels directly
between a subscriber and a telecommunications carrier’s public switched network
without the intervention of any other telecommunications carrier's switched
network which would be required to carry the subscriber's interpremises
traffic, which connection is capable of providing access through the public
switched network to a 9-1-1 emergency telephone system.
SERVICE ADDRESS: The location of the primary use of the network connection or
connections. With respect to network connections provided for use with pay
telephone services for which there is no billed subscriber, the
telecommunications carrier providing the network connection shall be deemed to
be its own billed subscriber for purposes of applying the surcharge.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS CARRIER: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate,
partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation,
municipal corporation or political subdivision of this State, or a receiver,
trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court
engaged in the business of transmitting messages by means of electricity or
otherwise, but does not include a cellular or other mobile communications
carrier.
(Ord. 2001-2-14J, 2-14-2001, eff. 5-1-2001)
3-11B-2: SURCHARGE IMPOSED:
The monthly surcharge imposed on subscribers of telecommunications carriers
with service addresses located within the corporate limits of the Village shall
be one dollar sixty five cents ($1.65) per month per “network connection”, as
herein defined.
(Ord. 2001-2-14J, 2-14-2001, eff. 5-1-2001)
3-11B-3: EFFECTIVE DATE OF SURCHARGE:
The surcharge as set forth in this article shall be effective on May 1, 2001.
(Ord. 2001-2-14J, 2-14-2001, eff. 5-1-2001)
3-11B-4: COLLECTOR REIMBURSEMENT:
Each telecommunications carrier is hereby authorized and instructed to deduct
three percent (3%) from the gross amount of surcharge collected prior to
remittance under subsection
3-11B-5A of this article in reimbursement for the expense of accounting and
collecting the surcharge.
(Ord. 2001-2-14J, 2-14-2001, eff. 5-1-2001)
3-11B-5: SURCHARGE REMITTANCE AND RETURN:
   A.   Every telecommunications carrier shall remit to the Village Finance
Director the amount of surcharge collected for each calendar month within
thirty (30) days following expiration of each month to which the surcharge
applies, net of any network or other 9-1-1 system charge then due to the
particular telecommunications carrier as shown on an itemized bill and the
three percent (3%) accounting and collection charge described in section
3-11B-4 of this article. Funds remitted to the Village pursuant to this
subsection shall be deposited in the Village Emergency Telephone System Fund.
   B.   Simultaneously with a remittance described in subsection A of this
section, the telecommunications carrier shall make a return to the Village
Finance Director for the period to which the remittance applies stating as
follows:
      1.   The name of the telecommunications carrier.
      2.   The telecommunications carrier's principal place of business.
      3.   The number of network connections to which the surcharge applies.
      4.   The amount of surcharge collected.
      5.   Such other reasonable and related information as the Corporate
Authorities may require.
(Ord. 2001-2-14J, 2-14-2001, eff. 5-1-2001)
3-11B-6: CREDIT FOR ERRONEOUS PAYMENTS:
If it shall appear that an amount of surcharge has been paid which was not due
under the provisions of this article, whether as the result of a mistake of
fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be credited against any
surcharge due, or to become due, under this article; provided, that no amounts
erroneously paid more than three (3) years prior to the filing of a claim
therefor shall be so credited. Ninety (90) days’ prior notice shall be given to
the Emergency Telephone System Board on any credit against a surcharge due.
(Ord. 2001-2-14J, 2-14-2001, eff. 5-1-2001)
3-11B-7: STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS:
No action to recover any amount of surcharge due under the provisions of this
article shall be commenced more than three (3) years after the due date of such
amount.
(Ord. 2001-2-14J, 2-14-2001, eff. 5-1-2001)
3-11B-8: COPY OF PROVISIONS TO COLLECTOR:
The Village Clerk or Village Finance Director shall provide any
telecommunications carrier collecting the surcharge with a certified copy of
this article within thirty (30) days from its passage and approval by the
Village President and Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2001-2-14J, 2-14-2001, eff. 5-1-2001)
ARTICLE C: EMERGENCY SERVICES COSTS
Section
3-11C-1:   Reimbursement Of Village Costs
3-11C-2:   Emergency Medical Transportation Fees Outside Village
3-11C-1: REIMBURSEMENT OF VILLAGE COSTS:
   A.   Definitions: When used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
   EMERGENCY SERVICES: Services provided by or on behalf of the Village of
Rosemont that deal with a situation or circumstances that require immediate
action in order to protect the safety or health of persons or to preserve or
protect property.
   INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR: A person who provides emergency services on behalf
of the Village of Rosemont pursuant to an agreement with the Village including,
but not limited to, vehicle towing services, building demolition services,
board-up services and toxic and hazardous material removal services.
   PERSON: Any natural person, association, corporation, or other entity which
receives emergency services provided by or on behalf of the Village of
Rosemont.
   B.   Reimbursement Required: Any person who receives emergency services from
the Village shall be required to pay the Village the costs the Village incurs:
      1.   For emergency services provided to the person on behalf of the
Village by an independent contractor;
      2.   For materials and commodities consumed in providing the emergency
services; and
      3.   For equipment utilized in the providing of the emergency services
other than costs attributable to ordinary wear and tear.
   C.   Statement Of Costs; Billing; Liability For Payment: The director of the
department of the Village which provides emergency services to a person shall
furnish to the Village Finance Director an itemized statement of the costs
incurred in providing the emergency services. The Finance Director shall then
bill the person to whom the emergency services were provided for the costs such
person is required to pay the Village under the provisions of subsection B of
this section. When emergency services are provided to preserve real or personal
property or are otherwise provided with respect to real or personal property,
the owner of the property shall be liable for paying to the Village the costs
incurred in providing such emergency services as provided in subsection B of
this section.
   D.   Lien Provisions: When emergency services are provided with respect to
real property, the cost of such services shall constitute a lien on the real
property in the amount which the owner of the real property is required to pay
the Village under the provisions of subsections B and C of this section. The
Finance Director is hereby authorized and directed to file a notice of lien on
any real property with respect to which the Village has provided emergency
services where the owner does not pay the Village for the cost of such services
as required by this section within thirty (30) days from the date the Village
issues a bill for such services.
(Ord. 87-5-6B, 5-6-1987)
3-11C-2: EMERGENCY MEDICAL TRANSPORTATION FEES OUTSIDE VILLAGE:
   A.   Fees Established: Persons shall be charged the fees for emergency
medical transportation services (or ambulance service) as set forth in the
Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1(L) of this Code. The levels of service are as defined by the Center for
Medicare and Medicaid Services of the United States Department of Health and
Human Services.
   B.   Rendition of Invoice; Payment of Fees: The Village Public Safety
Department, directly or through a third-party contractor, shall be responsible
for issuing invoices for any fees which may be due to the Village for emergency
medical transportation. Payment of a fee owed for emergency medical
transportation shall be due not more than thirty (30) days after the invoice
for the fee is issued.
   C.   Enforcement of Collection of Fee: The Village Public Safety Department
or designee shall have the authority to take or authorize any and all legal
action which may be required in order to collect the fees that are due the
Village for emergency medical transportation. The Village Public Safety
Department shall at all times have the discretion to waive any emergency
medical transportation fee charged to a resident of the Village of Rosemont to
the extent it not covered by private insurance, Medicare or Medicaid.
(Ord. 2018-4-11A, 4-11-2018; amd. 2019 Code; Ord. 2022-1-10A, 1-10-2022)
ARTICLE D: PROPERTY ASSESSED CLEAN ENERGY (PACE) CHARGES
Section
3-11D-1:   Regulation Of PACE Charges
3-11D-2:   Violation
3-11D-1: REGULATION OF PACE CHARGES:
Any entity receiving funding by participation in the Village’s PACE program
shall be prohibited from describing any charge or amount for the repayment of
such PACE funding on any bill or invoice in any manner represents or infers
that the PACE charge is a tax, assessment, levy, or tariff required by the
Village or is in any manner a requirement imposed by the Village. It shall not
be a violation of this prohibition to describe a PACE charge on a bill or
invoice as a “PACE charge”, a “clean energy charge”, a “PACE clean energy
charge”, or such substantially similar description that does not state or infer
that such charge has been required or imposed by the Village.
(Ord. 2020-7-8, 7-8-2020)
3-11D-2: VIOLATION:
The failure to comply with section
3-11D-1 shall be violation of the Village Code, and after a hearing at which a
determination is made that such violation has occurred, result in the
imposition of a fine in an amount not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00)
nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with each day a violation has
occurred being a separate and distinct offense. The Village, at its discretion,
may enforce any violation by an action seeking injunction relief requiring
compliance and/or a monetary fine in either the Circuit Court of Cook County or
the Village’s system for administrative adjudication.
(Ord. 2020-7-8, 7-8-2020)
CHAPTER 12: TEMPORARY DEFERMENT OF TAXES
DUE TO COVID 19
Section
3-12-1:   Temporary Deferment Of Taxes Due To Be Paid To The Village
3-12-2:   Continued Collection Of Taxes
3-12-3:   Taxes Collected On And After July 1, 2020
3-12-4:   Temporary Amendment
3-12-1:    TEMPORARY DEFERMENT OF TAXES DUE TO BE PAID TO THE VILLAGE:
   A.   Subject to strict compliance with each and every one of the conditions
set forth in this section, the payments due to the Village for the locally
imposed taxes identified below in this section that were required to be
collected in the months of March, April, May and June of calendar year 2020
shall be delayed and deferred. The Village’s locally imposed taxes to which
this section applies are:
      1.   The Village’s hotel and motel use tax as ratified and reapproved by
Ordinance 78-9-11 and amended by ordinances, including but not limited to
Ordinances 92-2-5A and 2003-12-3D.
      2.   The Village’s parking tax as ratified and reapproved by Ordinance
78-9-11 and amended by ordinances, including but not limited to Ordinance 2000-
12-6C.
      3.   The Village’s amusement tax, ratified and reapproved by Ordinance
78-9-11 and amended by ordinances, including but not limited to, Ordinances
2012-840 and 2013-5-8.
      4.   The Village’s gross receipts tax on places for eating adopted by
Ordinance 81-11-18B, as amended by ordinances, including but not limited to,
Ordinance 2013-9-11A.
   B.   The deferment or delay in the payment of the collected taxes to the
Village are only applicable if, and only if, the individual or entity
responsible for the collection of the taxes has satisfied each and every one of
the following conditions:
      1.   Condition 1: All tax returns required for the Village imposed hotel
tax, parking tax, amusement tax and gross receipts tax on places for eating for
the revenues received in February, 2020 have been filed with the Village on or
before April 30, 2020;
      2.   Condition 2: All taxes collected pursuant to the Village imposed
hotel tax, parking tax, amusement tax and gross receipts tax on places for
eating on the revenues received in February, 2020 have been paid to the Village
on or before April 30, 2020; and
      3.   Condition 3: All tax returns for the Village imposed hotel tax,
parking tax, amusement tax and gross receipts tax on places for eating have
been correctly and timely filed on or before July 31, 2020 for taxes collected
in the months of March 2020, April 2020, May 2020 and June 2020. Even if the
amount of the any tax collected for any of these months is zero, a return shall
be filed showing zero collections.
   C.   Those individuals or entities meeting each and every one of the
requirements of the above conditions shall pay the Village’s locally imposed
hotel tax, parking tax, amusement tax and gross receipts tax on places for
eating they were required to collect in the months of March, April, May, and
June of 2020 (the “deferred taxes:) to the Village on or before September 1,
2020. Any interest and penalties shall not begin to accrue on the deferred
taxes until after September 1, 2020.
(Ord. 2020-8-12A, 7-8-2020; amd. Ord. 2020-8-12B, 8-12-2020)
3-12-2: CONTINUED COLLECTION OF TAXES:
This chapter is not intended to, and shall not be interpreted as, waiving or
abating the imposition of, or the collection of, any of the Village’s locally
imposed hotel tax, parking tax, amusement tax or gross receipts tax on places
for eating. Any individual or entity that fails to meet each and every one of
the conditions that are necessary to receive a temporary deferral of their
payment of collected taxes to the Village pursuant to section
3-12-1 of this chapter shall remain subject to all interest, penalties, fees
and fines that are applicable for both the failure to file tax returns and the
failure to pay any collected taxes to the Village.
(Ord. 2020-8-12A, 7-8-2020)
3-12-3: TAXES COLLECTED ON AND AFTER JULY 1, 2020:
Nothing contained in this chapter shall in any manner impact the collection of
the Village’s motel tax, parking tax, amusement tax or gross receipts tax on
places for eating on or after July 1, 2020; or the payment of such collected
taxes to the Village.
(Ord. 2020-8-12A, 7-8-2020)
3-12-4: TEMPORARY AMENDMENT:
This chapter is intended to be a temporary amendment to the ordinances imposing
the Village’s hotel tax, parking tax, amusement tax and gross receipts tax on
places for eating that are identified in section
3-12-1 of this chapter, but only to the limited extent necessary to accomplish
the intent and purposes of this chapter.
(Ord. 2020-8-12A, 7-8-2020)
TITLE 4: BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1: GENERAL LICENSE REGULATIONS
Section
4-1-1:   License Required; More Than One License
4-1-2:   Subjects Of License Authority
4-1-3:   Applications For Licenses
4-1-4 :   Investigation Or Inspection Of Applicants
4-1-5:   Approval Or Disapproval Of License
4-1-6:   Term Of License; Renewals
4-1-7:   Nontransferability Of License; Unlawful Use
4-1-8:   Posting License; Destruction Or Removal Prohibited
4-1-9:   Building And Premises Requirements
4-1-10:   Location Requirements
4-1-11:   Nuisance Conditions Prohibited
4-1-12:   Working Conditions
4-1-13:   Businesses Open To The Public
4-1-14:   Inspections And Analyses Samples
4-1-15:   Suspension Or Revocation Of License; Hearing
4-1-16:   Appeals
4-1-17:   Penalties And Enforcement
4-1-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; MORE THAN ONE LICENSE:
No person, firm, or corporation shall conduct, engage in, maintain, operate,
carry on or manage any business, occupation, activity or establishment, either
by himself or itself, or through an agent, employee or partner, for which a
license is required by this Code or by any Village ordinance, without first
having obtained a license for such business, occupation, activity or
establishment. Any person, firm or corporation convicted of violating this
subsection shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975; amd. Ord. 2023-12-11D, 12-11-2023)
4-1-2: SUBJECTS OF LICENSE AUTHORITY:
Whenever a license is required for the maintenance, operation or conduct of any
business or establishment, or for doing business or engaging in any activity or
occupation, any person, firm or corporation shall be subject to the requirement
if, by himself or itself, or through an agent, employee or partner, he or it is
held forth as being engaged in the business, activity, or occupation, or if he
or it solicits patronage therefor, actively or passively, or if he or it
performs or attempts to perform any part of such business, activity, or
occupation in the Village.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-3: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES:
   A.   Applications for all licenses shall be made to the Health and Licensing
Department in writing on a form provided for that purpose, except as otherwise
provided.
   B.   If the applicant is an individual (sole proprietorship), the
application shall contain his name, residence address and telephone number. If
the applicant is a partnership or other noncorporate business entity, the
application shall contain the name and address of each partner, principal or
member thereof. If the applicant is a corporation, the application shall
contain the name and address of each principal officer and the registered agent
thereof.
   C.   Each application also shall contain:
      1.   A designation of the type or kind of license or permit desired;
      2.   The location or proposed location of the place of business,
occupation or activity;
      3.   The applicable fee to be paid as provided in the Village Fee
Schedule, section 3-10-1 of this Code;
      4.   The number of the certificate of registration required under the
Retailers’ Occupation Tax Act (35 ILCS 120/1 et seq.), Service Occupation Tax
Act (35 ILCS 115/1 et seq.) and/or Use Tax Act (35 ILCS 105/1 et seq.), if
applicable; and
      5.   Such additional information as may be needed for the proper guidance
of Village officials in the evaluation of such application, including proof of
any insurance policy or bond required by this Code.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-4: INVESTIGATION OR INSPECTION OF APPLICANTS:
   A.   Where this Code authorizes or necessitates an investigation or
inspection by any department or official of the Village before the issuance of
a license and requires the approval by such department or official regarding
the proper location or condition of the premises in which the business,
occupation or activity for which a license is applied is to be managed,
conducted, operated or carried on, or regarding the condition and nature of the
equipment and methods intended to be used by the applicant in such business,
occupation or activity, then the Health and Licensing Department shall transmit
to the appropriate official or department such information necessary for the
required investigation or inspection.
   B.   The designated official or department:
      1.   Shall make all necessary investigations and inspections, and the
results thereof shall be reported in writing to the Health and Licensing
Department; and
      2.   Shall indicate on the application a recommendation for the approval
or disapproval thereof.
   C.   Upon receipt of all related investigative and inspection reports, the
Health and Licensing Department shall forward such reports, together with the
application, to the Village President for final determination.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-5: APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL OF LICENSE:
   A.   Approval And Issuance: If, after due consideration of the information
contained within the application and related investigative and inspection
reports, the Village President shall determine that the application is
satisfactory, he shall approve the application. Thereupon, the Health and
Licensing Department shall notify the applicant that his or its application is
approved, and the license shall be issued.
   B.   Disapproval: If, after due consideration of the information contained
within the application and related investigative and inspection reports, the
Village President shall determine that matters concerning the application are
unsatisfactory, he shall disapprove the application, indicating the reasons
therefor. Thereupon, the Health and Licensing Department shall notify the
applicant that his or its application has not been approved and that no license
will be issued.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-6: TERM OF LICENSE; RENEWALS:
   A.   Each license shall indicate the term thereof. All annual licenses shall
be operative, and the license year for the Village shall commence on January 1
of each year. No license shall be granted for a period longer than one (1)
year. Except where otherwise provided herein, every license shall expire on
December 31 following the date of issuance.
   B.   The Health and Licensing Department shall endeavor to notify each
annual licensee of the expiration of time of the license held by the licensee
at least twenty one (21) days prior to such expiration date. Provided, however,
that a failure to make such notification or the licensee’s failure to receive
it shall not exclude the licensee from the obligation to obtain a new license
or a renewal thereof.
   C.   Except as otherwise provided herein, each license may be renewed upon
proper application and payment of the required fee. The requirements and
procedures for granting and issuing a license renewal shall be the same as
provided in sections
4-1-1 through
4-1-5 of this chapter.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-7: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE; UNLAWFUL USE:
   A.   No license may be assigned, sold, loaned, transferred, used as
collateral or otherwise encumbered.
   B.   No person, firm or corporation shall use or display any license
certificate, tag, badge, or sticker which has been improperly acquired.
   C.   No person, firm or corporation shall alter, deface, forge, or
counterfeit any license, certificate, plate, tag, badge or sticker issued by
the Village.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-8: POSTING LICENSE; DESTRUCTION OR REMOVAL PROHIBITED:
   A.   It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in
the Village to keep his license in a prominent place on the premises used for
such business at all times.
   B.   No person shall destroy, obliterate, take, remove or carry away without
the consent of the owner any license, certificate, plate or sticker which has
been issued by the Village, except if such license, certificate, plate or
sticker has been discontinued or the licensed premises has been abandoned.
Nothing herein shall prevent the Village President or his duly authorized
representative from removing any license, certificate, plate or sticker from
the possession of a former licensee, his premises, any vehicle or any machine
when said license has been revoked under the provisions of this Code.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-9:    BUILDING AND PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business and no permit shall
be issued for any purpose or activity if the premises and building to be used
for the purpose do not fully comply with all applicable ordinances and
regulations of the Village and the State of Illinois.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-10: LOCATION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   No license for the operation of a business, establishment, or activity
in the Village shall be construed to permit its operation in more than one
location in the Village. A separate license shall be required for each
location. For the purposes of this Code, the existence of a single location
shall be evidenced by the fact that all buildings containing the principal or
accessory uses:
      1.   Shall be connected or shall be located on the same lot or parcel;
      2.   Shall be operated and managed by the same person or owner; and
      3.   Shall be an establishment with the same classification.
   B.   The location of any licensed business or occupation, other than the
sale of alcoholic liquors or the location of any permitted act, may be changed;
provided, that the Health and Licensing Department shall be given sufficient
notice of such intended change in location to determine the operation for which
the license is required conforms with all applicable ordinances and regulations
of the Village at its new location.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-11: NUISANCE CONDITIONS PROHIBITED:
   A.   Generally: No business or establishment, whether or not licensed, shall
be so conducted or operated as to constitute a nuisance in fact; and no
building, vehicle, structure, yard, lot, premises, or part thereof shall be
used, kept, maintained, or operated in connection with any business or
establishment so as to occasion any nuisance, or so as to be dangerous to life
or detrimental to health.
   B.   Unsafe Or Unhealthful Businesses:
      1.   No building or structure utilized, constructed, or maintained in
connection with any business or occupation shall evidence an unsanitary,
unsafe, or dangerous condition.
      2.   No substance, matter, or thing of any kind whatever, which shall be
dangerous or detrimental to health, shall be allowed to exist in connection
with any business or occupation, or be used in any work or labor performed in
the Village.
   C.    Refuse Collection And Disposal:
      1.    Containers:
         a.    The standard refuse container required by this Code shall be a
receptacle of not less than twenty (20) nor more than thirty two (32) gallons’
capacity, of impervious material and sturdy construction, with a tightfitting
cover, and equipped with handles properly placed to facilitate handling.
         b.   The occupant of every building, structure, or premises used or
maintained in connection with any business or occupation shall provide and
maintain in good condition and repair a sufficient number of refuse containers
for the temporary storage of all refuse accumulating between collections.
         c.   All refuse which is placed for collection service outside any
building or structure must be kept in standard refuse containers unless another
type of container is approved by the Health and Licensing Department due to the
unusual nature of the refuse produced by the business.
      2.    Removal Of Refuse:
         a.   It shall be the duty of the occupant of every building,
structure, or premises used or maintained in connection with any business or
occupation to cause to be removed at his own cost and expense, at least once
each week, all refuse produced therein.
         b.   Every person owning or controlling any hotel, restaurant, café,
retail food establishment or other business or occupation where more than
thirty (30) gallons of refuse is normally produced weekly shall cause all
substances deposited in such containers to be removed as often as shall be
necessary including daily removal from his premises to ensure the healthful
environment surrounding such establishment. Such removal shall be at his own
expense.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-12: WORKING CONDITIONS:
   A.   Health Requirements: No owner, lessee, manager or superintendent of any
business or commercial establishment, or any room or part thereof, shall allow
such premises to be overcrowded or inadequate or faulty in respect to light,
ventilation, heat or cleanliness.
   B.   Sanitation: All such places of employment shall be kept in a clean
condition, free from the effluvia of a sewer, drain, or other nuisance; also,
as far as practicable, such premises shall be free from all gases, vapors,
dust, or otherwise which are injurious to health. Sufficient washroom
facilities for male and female employees shall be provided, and such facilities
shall be properly ventilated.
   C.   Heat Requirements: It shall be the duty of every person owning or
controlling the heating plant which furnishes heat to any factory, workshop,
retail business or other commercial establishment to maintain a temperature
when workers are present within such factory or workshop of not less than sixty
eight degrees Fahrenheit (68°F) without such undue restriction of ventilation
as to interfere with proper sanitary conditions therein; provided, however,
that this requirement shall not apply to any factory or workshop where the
business conducted therein is of such a nature that a lower temperature than
sixty eight degrees Fahrenheit (68°F) is necessary or expedient for the work or
manufacturing process of such business.
   D.   Inspections: The appropriate Village officials shall visit or cause to
be visited all such places of employment in the Village as often as they shall
deem necessary to assure compliance with the provisions of this section, and to
have such arrangements made as may be deemed necessary for the health and
safety of the employees.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-13: BUSINESSES OPEN TO THE PUBLIC:
All businesses or commercial establishments licensed under this Code which
invite the public generally into their establishments for the purpose of
conducting business or commercial activities shall be subject to the following
regulations in addition to all other applicable provisions of this Code:
   A.   Sanitation Facilities: All areas within the licensed premises where the
public may enter shall be kept in a safe and sanitary condition, and at least
one (1) restroom shall be provided for use by the business invitees of the
licensee.
   B.   Insurance Requirements: All such businesses shall purchase and maintain
at all times a public liability insurance policy in an amount determined by the
Village with a responsible insurer qualified to do business in Illinois, to
secure payment of any loss or damage to the public resulting from the operation
of the licensee’s business. Said insurance policy shall provide for the payment
and satisfaction of any final judgment rendered against the licensee and that
suit may be brought in any court of competent jurisdiction upon such policy by
any person having claims arising from the operation of the licensee’s business.
Proof of such insurance policy shall be presented to the Director of the Health
and Licensing Department prior to the issuance or renewal of any annual license
to which this section applies.
   C.   Consumer Protection: All business or commercial establishments subject
to this section shall refrain from all deceptive trade practices as defined by
State or Federal law or regulation and shall comply with all applicable laws
and regulations regarding consumer protection and deceptive trade practices. In
the event of any such violation, the business license of the establishment may
be revoked pursuant to section 4-1-16 of this chapter.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-14: INSPECTIONS AND ANALYSES SAMPLES:
   A.   Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the
operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for, or required by
ordinance, or are reasonably necessary to assure compliance with the provisions
of any ordinance or regulation of the Village, or to detect violations thereof,
it shall be the duty of the licensee or the person in charge of the premises to
admit thereto for the purpose of making the inspection any officer or employee
of the Village who is duly authorized to make such inspection at any reasonable
time that such admission or entry is requested.
   B.   Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably
necessary to assure compliance with the provisions of any ordinance or
regulations, or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the
licensee or the person in charge of the premises to give to any duly authorized
officer or employee of the Village requesting the same sufficient samples of
such material or commodity for such analysis upon official request.
   C.   In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the Village
President may revoke, under the provisions of subsection
4-1-15A of this chapter, the license of any owner or operator of a licensed
business in the Village who refuses to permit any duly authorized officer or
employee to make such inspection or to take an adequate sample of said
commodity, or who interferes with such officer or employee while in the
performance of his duties.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-15: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE; HEARING:
   A.   When the conduct or operation of any business, occupation, activity or
establishment, whether licensed or unlicensed, shall constitute a nuisance in
fact and a clear and present danger to the public health, safety or general
welfare, or where the holder of any license shall have refused to allow an
inspection of his premises or has refused to furnish a sample of his goods for
testing, the Village President shall be authorized to summarily order the
cessation of business and the closing of the premises until the danger no
longer exists, and the suspension of any license or permit for a period not to
exceed ten (10) days.
   B.   Within eight (8) days after a license is suspended, the Village
President shall call a hearing for the purpose of determining whether or not
the license should be revoked.
   C.   1. Licenses issued under the ordinances of the Village, unless
otherwise provided, may be revoked by the Village President after notice and
hearing as provided in subsections D and E of this section for any of the
following causes:
         a.   Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application for the license.
         b.   Any violation by the licensee of ordinance provisions relating to
the license, the subject matter of the license or the premises occupied.
         c.   Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor
where such conclusion indicates their inability to operate a safe, honest and
legitimate business operation within the Village.
         d.   Failure of the licensee to pay any fine or penalty or charge
owing to the Village.
         e.   Refusal to permit an inspection or sampling, or any interference
with a duly authorized Village officer or employee while in the reasonable
performance of his duties in making such inspections, as provided in section
4-1-14 of this chapter.
      2.   Such revocation, if ordered, shall not preclude prosecution and
imposition of any other penalties provided for the violation of other
applicable ordinances of the Village.
   D.   Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in
writing setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time
and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be sent by certified mail (return
receipt requested) to the licensee at his last known address at least five (5)
days prior to the date set for the hearing. If the licensee shall request a
continuance in the date of the hearing, the ten (10) day suspension shall be in
effect until two (2) days after the final hearing date.
   E.   At the hearing, the Village Attorney shall present the complaint and
shall represent the Village. The licensee shall be permitted counsel and shall
have the right to submit evidence and cross examine witnesses. The Village
President shall preside and shall render the decision.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
Cross-reference:
   See also section
1-4-4  of this Code
4-1-16: APPEALS:
Any person aggrieved by the decision of the Village President in regard to the
denial of an application for a business license, as provided in subsection
4-1-5B of this chapter, or in connection with the revocation of a license, or
the closing of an establishment dangerous to the public, as provided in section
4-1-16 of this chapter, shall have the right to appeal to the Board of
Trustees. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the Director of the Health
and Licensing Department within ten (10) days after notice of a denial of an
application or a revocation of a license, a written statement under oath
setting forth specifically the grounds for appeal. The Board of Trustees shall
thereupon set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal, and notice of
such hearing shall be given to the applicant or licensee in the same manner as
provided in section
4-1-16 of this chapter. The decision of the Board of Trustees on the appeal
shall be final.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-1-17: PENALTIES AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Unless otherwise expressly provided, any person, firm or corporation
convicted of violating any provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less
than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00).
   B.   Whenever a person, firm or corporation shall neglect or refuse to
procure any license required by this Code, or otherwise violates the terms of
this chapter, the Health and Licensing Department is authorized to cause
appropriate legal action and proceedings to be instituted to enforce the
license requirement.
   C.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall take all
necessary and appropriate action to compel compliance with the regulatory
provisions of this chapter. When necessary and expedient, he may call upon the
Chief of Public Safety to assist in such enforcement, and it shall be the duty
of the Chief of Public Safety to perform such enforcement acts as may be
required of him. The Director of the Health and Licensing Department, and each
of his license inspectors, shall be conservators of the peace with police
powers for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this Code and other
Village ordinances relating to the licensing of businesses and occupations and
their regulations.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 2: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
