4-2-1:   DEFINITIONS:
All words and phrases used in this chapter, not otherwise defined herein, shall
have the meanings accorded to such words or phrases in the Liquor Control Act
of 1934 (“act”), as amended (235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.).
ALCOHOLIC SPIRITS OR SPIRITS: Any beverage which contains alcohol obtained by
distillation, mixed with water or other substance in solution, and includes
brandy, rum, whiskey, gin or other spirituous liquors, and such liquors when
rectified, blended or other mixed with alcohol or other substances.
BYOB: The consumption of a customer’s beer or wine brought by the customer onto
the premises of a restaurant possessing a BYOB license issued pursuant to this
chapter for consumption by such customer and his or her guests on the premises
of the licensed restaurant as a complement to the consumption of a meal
purchased from the restaurant, subject to such further limits as may be adopted
by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner.
BEER: A beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or
concoction of barley, or other grain, malt, and hops in water, and includes,
among other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter and the like.
DRINK: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 4-2-15C of this chapter,
which applies only to Class L licenses, DRINK, when used as a noun in this
chapter, shall mean a single serving of alcoholic spirits in a glass or other
container that holds not more than eight (8) ounces, a single serving of beer
in a glass bottle or other container, or a single serving of wine in a glass or
other container that holds not more than nine (9) ounces.
WINE OR VINOUS BEVERAGES: Any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation
of the natural contents of fruits, or vegetables, containing sugar, including
such beverages fortified by the addition of alcohol or “spirits” as defined
herein.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011; amd. Ord. 2014-11-12F, 11-12-2014; Ord. 2018-2-
14R, 2-14-2018; Ord. 2025-1-13, 1-13-2025)
4-2-2: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Local Liquor Control Commissioner, in addition to those powers and duties
set out in this chapter, shall also have the following powers, functions and
duties with respect to licenses:
   A.   To grant and/or suspend for not more than thirty (30) days or revoke
for cause all local licenses issued to persons or entities for premises within
his jurisdiction.
   B.   To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any time
upon any premises licensed hereunder to determine whether any of the provisions
of State law, this Code or Village ordinances or any rules or regulations
adopted by him or by the State Commission have been or are being violated, and
at such time to examine the premises of the licensee in connection therewith.
   C.   To receive complaint from any citizen within his jurisdiction that any
of the provisions of State law or this chapter have been or are being violated
and to act upon such complaints in the manner provided by law.
   D.   To notify the Secretary of State where a club incorporated under the
General Not for Profit Corporation Act of 1986 (805 ILCS 105/101.01 et seq.) or
a foreign corporation functioning as a club in this State under a certificate
of authority issued under that act has violated this chapter by selling or
offering for sale at retail alcoholic liquors without a retailer’s license.
   E.   To receive local license fees and pay the same forthwith to the
Director of the Health and Licensing Department.
   F.   To notify the Secretary of State of any convictions or dispositions of
court supervision for a violation of section 6-20 of the Liquor Control Act
(235 ILCS 5/6-20), or a similar provision of any Village ordinance.
   G.   To levy fines in accordance with section 7-5 of the Liquor Control Act
(235 ILCS 5/7-5) and to conduct all hearings in accordance with the procedural
requirements of the act.
   H.   To appoint a hearing officer to conduct any hearing that may be
required.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2 011)
4-2-3: LICENSES REQUIRED:
   A.   Local License: No person shall sell at retail or offer for sale at
retail in the Village any alcoholic liquor without having a retail liquor
license issued by the Village President, in his capacity as Local Liquor
Control Commissioner of the Village.
   B.    State License: No licensee under this chapter shall operate a liquor
business without having obtained a retailer’s license issued by the Illinois
Liquor Control Commission.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-4: INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Except as otherwise provided in subsection B of this section, no
license of any kind shall be issued to:
      1.    A person who is not of good character and reputation.
      2.   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
      3.   A person who has been convicted of a felony under any Federal or
State law unless the Liquor Control Commissioner determines that such person
has been sufficiently rehabilitated to warrant the public trust after
considering matters set forth in such person’s application and the
Commissioner’s investigation. The burden of proof of sufficient rehabilitation
shall be on the applicant. However, a person that is not otherwise disqualified
from holding a liquor license under subsection A4 of this section (conviction
for keeping a place of prostitution or juvenile prostitution), subsection A11
of this section (conviction of a liquor law violation) or any other provision
in this chapter or State Statute, shall be deemed to be sufficiently
rehabilitated to warrant the public trust, and no hearing before the Liquor
Control Commissioner shall be required if the felony conviction occurred more
than twenty (20) years before the date of the liquor license application and
the person:
         a.   Is a shareholder or owner of not more than fifteen percent (15%)
of the corporation or limited liability company that is applying for the liquor
license; and
         b.   The corporation or limited liability company applying for the
license certifies in writing that the person that was convicted of the felony
is not involved in the management of the premises for which a liquor license is
being sought.
(Ord. 2015-10-14H, 10-14-2015)
      4.   A person who has been convicted of keeping a place of prostitution
or keeping a place of juvenile prostitution, promoting prostitution that
involves keeping a place of prostitution, or promoting juvenile prostitution
that involves keeping a place of prostitution; or a person who has been
convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and
morality.
      5.   A person whose license issued under the State act or this chapter
has been revoked for cause.
      6.   A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application.
      7.   A copartnership if any general partnership thereof or any limited
partnership thereof, owning more than five percent (5%) of the aggregate
limited partner interest in such copartnership, would not be eligible to
receive a license hereunder for any reason other than residence within the
Village.
      8.   A corporation or limited liability company if any member, officer,
manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the
aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, would
not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than
citizenship and residence within the Village.
      9.   A corporation or limited liability company unless it is incorporated
or organized in Illinois, or unless it is a foreign corporation or foreign
limited liability company which is qualified under the Business Corporation Act
of 1983 (805 ILCS 5/1.01 et seq.) or the Limited Liability Company Act (805
ILCS 180/1-1 et seq.) to transact business in Illinois.
      10.   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless the manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required by the
licensee.
      11.   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any Federal or
State law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor,
subsequent to the passage of the State act, or has forfeited his bond to appear
in court to answer charges for any such violation.
      12.   A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a
license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for
which the license is to be issued.
      13.   Any law enforcing public official, including members of the local
liquor control commission, the Village President, or any member of the
Village’s Board of Trustees; except, that a license may be granted to member of
the Village’s Board of Trustees in relation to a premises located within the
Village if: a) the sale of alcoholic liquor pursuant to the license is
incidental to the selling of food; b) the issuance of the license is approved
by the State Commission; c) the issuance of the license is in accordance with
all applicable local ordinances in effect where the premises is located; and d)
the Trustee granted a license does not vote on alcoholic liquor issues pending
before the Board of Trustees.
      14.   A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be
operated by the licensee.
      15.   A person who has been convicted of a gambling offense as proscribed
by any of subsections (a)(3) through (a)(11) of section 28-1 of, or as
proscribed by section 28-1.1 or 28-3 of, the Criminal Code of 1961 or the
Criminal Code of 2012 (720 ILCS 5/28-l (a)(3) through (a)(11); 5/28-1.1; 5/28-
3), or as proscribed by a statute replaced by any of the aforesaid statutory
provisions.
      16.   A person or entity to whom a Federal wagering stamp has been issued
by the Federal government, unless the person or entity is eligible to be issued
a license under the Raffles and Poker Runs Act (230 ILCS 15/0.01 et seq.) or
the Illinois Pull Tabs and Jar Games Act (230 ILCS 20/1 et seq.).
      17.   A person who intends to sell alcoholic liquors for use or
consumption on his licensed retail premises who does not have liquor liability
insurance coverage for that premises in an amount that is at least equal to the
maximum liability amounts set out in subsection (a) of section 6-21 of the
Liquor Control Act (235 ILCS 5/6-21(a)).
   B.   A criminal conviction of a corporation is not grounds for the denial,
suspension, or revocation of a license applied for or held by the corporation
if the criminal conviction was not the result of a violation of Federal or
State law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor or
the offense that led to the conviction did not result in any financial gain to
the corporation and the corporation has terminated its relationship with each
director, officer, employee, or controlling shareholder whose actions directly
contributed to the conviction of the corporation. The Liquor Control
Commissioner shall determine if all provisions of this subsection have been met
before any action on the corporation’s license is initiated.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-5: EFFECT OF VIOLATIONS OF TAX PROVISIONS:
In addition to other grounds specified in this chapter, the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner may refuse the issuance or renewal of a retail license, or
suspend or revoke such license, for any of the following violations of any tax
act administered by the Illinois Department of Revenue:
   A.   Failure to make a tax return.
   B.   The filing of a fraudulent return.
   C.   Failure to pay all or part of any tax or penalty finally determined to
be due.
   D.   Failure to keep books and records.
   E.   Failure to secure and display a certificate or subcertificates of
registration.
   F.   Wilful violation of any rule or regulation of the Department of Revenue
relating to the administration and enforcement of tax liability.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-6: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Applications for licenses shall be made to the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner, in writing, on forms that can be obtained from the Director of
the Health and Licensing Department.
   B.   All corporations licensed under this chapter shall report to the Local
Liquor Control Commissioner within thirty (30) days, all internal changes in
such corporation pertaining to officers and stockholders holding more than five
percent (5%) of such corporation’s stock.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-7: CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES; FEES:
There shall be the following classes of licenses with an annual license fee as
indicated:
   A.   Class A License: A Class A license authorizes the retail sale on the
premises specified of alcoholic spirits by the drink for consumption on the
premises and beer or wine by the drink, pitcher, bottle or carafe for
consumption on the premises. The “premises” of all Class A licenses shall mean
a “hotel” as defined in section 1-3.25 of the Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235
ILCS 5/1-3.25). A motel shall be deemed a hotel under this subsection. The
annual license fee for a Class A license shall be as set forth in the Village
Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1A of this Code. The Local Liquor Control
Commissioner is authorized to issue a Class A license to a hotel which is
proposed to be constructed or is under construction within the Village;
provided, that such license shall be subject to revocation in the event that a
certificate of occupancy is not issued for the premises for which the license
is issued within three (3) years after the initial issuance of the license.
   B.   Class B License: A Class B license authorizes the retail sale on the
premises specified of all alcoholic spirits by the drink for consumption on the
premises and beer or wine by the drink, pitcher, bottle or carafe for
consumption on the premises. The “premises” of all Class B licenses shall mean
a restaurant with or without a cocktail lounge. “Restaurant” shall mean that
definition as set forth in section 1-3.23 of the Liquor Control Act of 1934
(235 ILCS 5/3-1.23). The annual license fee for a Class B license shall be as
set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code. The Local Liquor Control Commissioner is authorized to
issue a Class B license to a restaurant which is proposed to be constructed or
is under construction within the Village; provided, that such license shall be
subject to revocation in the event that a certificate of occupancy is not
issued for the premises for which the license is issued within three (3) years
after the initial issuance of the license.
   C.   Class B(1) License: A Class B(1) license authorizes the retail sale on
the premises specified of alcoholic spirits by the drink for consumption on the
premises and beer or wine by the drink, pitcher, bottle or carafe for
consumption on the premises. The “premises” of all Class B(1) licenses shall
mean a cocktail lounge without a restaurant. The annual license fee for a Class
B(1) license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   D.   Class B(2) License: A Class B(2) license authorizes the retail sale on
the premises specified of beer and wine by the drink by a tenant within an
indoor retail shopping mall that exceeds four hundred thousand (400,000) square
feet for consumption on the premises. The “premises” for all Class B(2)
licenses shall mean a kiosk or other space leased by the tenant in the indoor
retail shopping mall. An application for a Class B(2) license shall be jointly
made by both the tenant that will be offering the retail sale of beer and/or
wine and the landlord that owns the indoor retail shopping mall. In addition to
meeting all requirements of this chapter for the issuance of a liquor license,
the co-applicants for a Class B(2) license shall include with their application
a written plan, signed and approved by both the tenant and the landlord, for
policing and monitoring the sale and consumption of alcohol within both the
tenant space and the entirety of the indoor retail shopping mall. A Class B(2)
license shall only be issued if the written plan that is signed by the tenant
and landlord is approved by the Liquor Control Commissioner. Any Class B(2)
license issued shall be contingent upon compliance with the written plan that
is signed by both the tenant and landlord and approved by the Liquor Control
Commissioner. Prior to getting a license, proof that the tenant and the
landlord are covered by dramshop insurance shall be provided. The failure to
comply with any provision of this subsection shall be a violation of this
chapter and subject the violator to all the penalties allowed by this chapter
and the Illinois Liquor Control Act up to and including the revocation of any
Class B(2) license that has been issued. The annual license fee for a Class B
(2) license shall be as set forth in the Village’s schedule of fees, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   E.   Class B(3) License: A Class B(3) license authorizes the holder of a
Class B License to sell sealed, unopened bottles of wine for consumption on or
off the premises. It shall be unlawful for any patron to leave the premises
with a partially consumed container of wine unless it is securely sealed by
restaurant personnel prior to the removal from the premises and placed in a
transparent one time use tamperproof bag, as required by state law and in
accordance with the Illinois Liquor Control Act. The license fee for each Class
B(3) license shall be set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   F.   Class B(4) License: A Class B(4) license authorizes the self-service
pouring of beer, wine and cider for consumption and related sealed package
sales of the beer, wine and cider served from an enclosed kiosk or tenant space
that is located within or adjacent to a food court within an indoor regional
shopping mall. The hours of operation of the kiosk/tenant space used for the
service and or package sales of beer, wine and cider shall be the same as the
hours of operation of the indoor regional shopping mall in which the kiosk/
tenant space is located. During all hours of operation the kiosk/tenant space
shall be manned by a BASSET certified individual that shall ensure that each
person receiving beer, wine or cider is of sufficient legal age to consume
alcohol. After confirming that each individual is legally able to consume
alcohol, each individual shall be given a card that will allow for the self-
service pouring of no more than thirty-two (32) ounces and only one container
with the emblem identifying the kiosk/tenant space. A customer may contain an
additional card only from the BASSET certified individual in charge of the
kiosk/tenant space. The container with the emblem shall: (1) be sufficient to
readily identify that it is being used for the consumption of beer, wine or
cider; (2) dissimilar to any other drinking container being used within the
indoor shopping mall; and (3) approved by the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner. The container provided for the self-service pouring of beer or
cider shall not hold more than sixteen (16) ounces. The container provided for
the self-service pouring of wine shall not exceed eight (8) ounces. A Class B
(4) license shall not be issued or renewed unless the applicant provides proof
of dramshop insurance. The failure to comply with all the requirements set
forth herein for a Class B(4) liquor license shall be a violation of this
chapter and subject the violator to all the penalties allowed by this chapter
and the Illinois Liquor Control Act up to and including license revocation. The
license fee for each Class B(4) license shall be as set forth in the Village
Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1A of this Code.
   G.   Class C License: A Class C license authorizes the retail sale on the
premises specified of alcoholic liquor in its original package, not for
consumption on the premises. The annual license fee for a Class C license shall
be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   H.   Class D License: A Class D license authorizes the retail sale, on the
premises specified, of alcoholic spirits by the drink for consumption on the
premises and beer or wine by the drink, pitcher, bottle or carafe for
consumption on the premises. This class of license shall only allow for retail
sale from a service bar to tables in a restaurant; provided, that the licensee
may be permitted to allow seating at such service bar, but such seating shall
not exceed ten (10) chairs or bar stools. The annual license fee for a Class D
license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1A
of this Code. The Local Liquor Control Commissioner is authorized to issue a
Class D license to a restaurant which is proposed to be constructed or is under
construction within the Village; provided, that such license shall be subject
to revocation in the event that a certificate of occupancy is not issued for
the premises for which the license is issued within three (3) years after the
initial issuance of the license.
   I.   Class E License: A Class E license authorizes the retail sale of
alcoholic spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises at a government
owned stadium, recreational facility, or exposition center; beer or wine by the
drink, pitcher, bottle or carafe for consumption on the premises at a
government owned stadium, recreational facility, or exposition center;
alcoholic spirits by the bottle in private suites with a maximum occupancy of
not less than ten (10) and not more than forty (40) persons on the premises of
a government owned stadium; and alcoholic spirits by the bottle in banquet
areas on the premises of a government owned exposition center during events
that are not generally open to the public. The annual license fee for a Class E
license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   J.   Class E(1) (Entertainment District) License: A Class E(1) license
authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic spirits by the drink for consumption on
the premises and beer or wine by the drink, pitcher, bottle or carafe for
consumption on the premises. A Class E(1) license additionally authorizes the
retail sale of alcoholic spirits by the bottle for consumption within private
rooms that are not open to all members of the general public located within the
interior of the premises. The premises for a Class E(1) license shall be the
interior and any exterior patio or seating areas, if any, that are located
within The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District. Any exterior patio or
seating areas located within the premises shall be subject to the rules and
regulations that are set forth in subsection
4-2-15 B.1. of this chapter, as amended from time to time. A Class E(1) license
also authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic liquor by the drink on the
licensed premises for consumption on the Village owned common outdoor area of
The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District pursuant to such rules and
regulations established for the consumption of alcohol in the Village owned
common area of The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District that are set forth
in subsection
4-2-15 B.2. of this chapter, as amended from time to time. The annual license
fee for a Class E(1) license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule,
subsection
3-10-1 A. of this Code. The Local Liquor Control Commissioner is authorized to
issue a Class E(1) license to the lessee of a facility which is proposed to be
constructed or is under construction within The Park at Rosemont Entertainment
Districts; provided, that such license shall be subject to revocation in the
event that a certificate of occupancy is not issued for the premises for which
the license is issued within three (3) years after the initial issuance of the
license.
   K.   Class E(2) (Entertainment District Special Event) License: A Class E(2)
license authorizes a Class E(1) license holder to engage in the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor by the drink from a serving area located on the Village owned
common outdoor area of The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District for
consumption within the outdoor area of The Park at Rosemont Entertainment
District at such locations and subject to such restrictions and regulations as
deemed necessary by the Village for the special event. Prior to the issuance of
a Class E(2) license, the Class E(1) license holder must provide adequate proof
of dramshop insurance which names the Village and its officers and employees as
additional insureds with limits of insurance satisfactory to the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner or his designee. If the proof of dramshop insurance
expires during the period the Class E(2) license is in effect, the license
holder shall submit updated proof that they have the insurance required. At all
times, it shall be the sole responsibility of the Class E(2) license holder to
maintain the insurance required during the entire period the Class E(2) license
is in effect. A Class E(2) license holder shall also comply with the rules and
regulations established for the consumption of alcohol in the Village owned
common area of The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District that are set forth
in subsection
4-2-15B2 of this chapter, as amended from time to time. The license fee for an
annual Class E(2) license shall be that set forth in the Village Fee Schedule,
subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   L.    Class E(3) (Entertainment District Brew Pub) License: A Class E(3)
license authorizes a Class E(1) license holder to additionally operate, on the
licensed premises, a “brew pub” as that term is defined in section 1-3.33 of
the Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/1-3.33). The Local Liquor Control
Commissioner is authorized to issue a Class E(3) license for a premises which
is proposed to be constructed or is under construction within the Village;
provided, that: 1) such license shall be subject to revocation in the event
that a certificate of occupancy is not issued for the premises for which the
license is issued within three (3) years after the initial issuance of the
license; and 2) no sale of alcoholic beverages shall occur on the premises for
which the license is issued until a brew pub license is issued by the Illinois
Liquor Control Commission which covers the same premises.
   M.   Class F License: A Class F license authorizes the retail sale on the
premises specified of beer and wine only. The annual license fee for a Class F
license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   N.   Class G License: A Class G license authorizes the sale and dispensing
of alcoholic spirits by the drink and beer or wine by the drink, pitcher,
bottle or carafe for consumption only on premises owned or leased by the
Village or the Rosemont Park District. Such license shall be granted on a one
day basis and shall allow the sale and dispensing of alcoholic liquor only
between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00)
P.M. The license fee for a Class G license shall be as set forth in the Village
Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code. An applicant for a Class G license must submit with the
application proof satisfactory to the Local Liquor Control Commissioner that
the applicant has made arrangements to provide dramshop liability insurance
under or pursuant to section 6-21 of the Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS
5/6-21). If the applicant is seeking the Class G license for the sale and
dispensing of alcoholic liquor on premises owned or leased by the Village, the
applicant must provide proof that the required dramshop liability insurance
policy names the Village as an additional insured.
   O.   Class I License: A Class I license authorizes the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor not for consumption on the premises, where the alcoholic
liquor is both delivered and served by the licensee incidental to the sale,
delivery and serving of food by the licensee. A Class I license shall permit a
licensee to deliver and serve alcoholic liquors on the same premises on not
more than five (5) days during any thirty (30) day period. Except, A Class I
licensee may deliver and serve alcoholic liquors incidental to the sale,
delivery and serving of food on the same premises for more than five (5) days
during any thirty (30) day period if the premises is a banquet hall, banquet
room or similar facility. All beer and wine that is served by a Class I liquor
license holder shall be served in a glass bottle or other container that holds
not more that sixteen (16) ounces; provided, that an open bottle containing not
more than two (2) liters of wine may be placed on a table where food is to be
served if the wine is intended to be consumed as part of a meal. All alcoholic
liquor, other than beer and wine, that is served by a Class I liquor license
holder shall be served in a glass or other container that holds not more than
eight (8) ounces. The license fee for a Class I license shall be as set forth
in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code. If the holder of a Class I license delivers and serves
alcoholic liquor on premises that is located outside the corporate limits of
the Village, the license holder must comply with all ordinances and other laws
applicable to the delivery and serving of alcoholic liquor on such premises.
   P.   Class I(1) License: A Class I(1) license authorizes a holder of a Class
B license to serve alcoholic liquor where the alcoholic liquor is both
delivered and served by the licensee incidental to the catering of food by the
licensee. The serving size for beer shall not exceed twelve (12) ounces. The
serving size for wine and alcoholic beverages other than beer shall not exceed
eight (8) ounces. Except, open bottles or containers of wine containing not
more than one (1) liter of wine may be placed on a table where food is to be
served if the wine is intended to be consumed as part of a meal. The license
fee for a Class I(1) license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule,
subsection
3-10-1A of this Code. If the holder of a Class I(1) license delivers and serves
alcoholic liquor on premises that are located outside the corporate limits of
the Village of Rosemont, the license holder must comply with all ordinances and
other laws applicable to the delivery and serving of alcoholic liquor on such
premises.
   Q.   Class J License: A Class J license authorizes the holder of a Class A,
B, B(1), D, E, E(1) or K license to sell alcoholic liquor for consumption on
the premises for which the Class A, B, B(1), D, E, E(1) or K license has been
issued during the hours when the sale of alcoholic liquor is otherwise
prohibited . A Class J license shall not be valid for more than one twenty-four
(24) hour period and only during the hours as set forth in the application for
the license as approved by the Liquor Commissioner. A Class J license shall not
allow for the sale of any alcoholic liquor between the hours of four o'clock
(4:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. A holder of a Class A, B, B(1), D, E,
E(1) or K license shall not be issued a Class J license more than five (5)
times during any calendar year. Effective as of January 1, 2024 and thereafter,
a Class J License shall only be issued for private ticketed events that are not
open to the public. The license fee for each Class J license shall be as set
forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   R.   Class K License: A Class K license authorizes the retail sale on the
premises specified of alcoholic spirits by the drink and beer or wine by the
drink, pitcher, bottle or carafe for consumption on the premises and the retail
sale of beer in its original package for consumption off of the premises. The
“premises” of a Class K license shall mean a “restaurant” as that term is
defined in section 1-3.23 of the Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/1-3.23)
that is part of a “brew pub” as that term is defined in section 1-3.33 of the
Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/1-3.33). The annual license fee for a
Class K license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code. The Local Liquor Control Commissioner is authorized to
issue a Class K license to a brew pub which is proposed to be constructed or is
under construction within the Village; provided, that: 1) such license shall be
subject to revocation in the event that a certificate of occupancy is not
issued for the premises for which the license is issued within three (3) years
after the initial issuance of the license; and 2) no sale of alcoholic
beverages shall for which the license is issued until a brew pub license is
issued by the Illinois Liquor Control Commission which covers the same
premises.
   S.   Class L License: A Class L license authorizes the retail sale of
alcoholic spirits by the drink and beer or wine by the drink for consumption on
the premises pursuant to such rules and regulations that are set forth in
subsection
4-2-15C of this chapter, as amended from time to time. The “premises” of a
Class L license shall mean a movie or live performance theater that is not
owned/operated by the Village. The annual fee for a Class L license shall be as
set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code. The Local Liquor Control Commissioner is authorized to
issue a Class L license to a theater which is proposed to be constructed or is
under construction within the Village; provided, that such license shall be
subject to revocation in the event that a certificate of occupancy is not
issued for the premises for which the license is issued within two (2) years
after the initial issuance of the license.
   T.   Class M License: A Class M license authorizes the holder of a Class A
license to sell alcoholic spirits by the drink and beer or wine by the drink,
pitcher, bottle or carafe where the alcoholic spirits, beer and wine are both
delivered and served by the licensee on premises located outside the corporate
limits of the Village which are contiguous to the premises for which the Class
A license was issued. The annual fee for a Class M license shall be as set
forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code. The Local Liquor Control Commissioner is authorized to
issue a Class M license to a hotel where the premises on which the alcoholic
liquor is to be sold or delivered is under construction; provided, that such
license shall be subject to revocation in the event that a certificate of
occupancy is not issued for such premises within one year after the initial
issuance of the license.
   U.   Class N License: A Class N license authorizes the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor for consumption on premises located in the Village for which a
license authorizing the sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor has not been
issued where the alcoholic liquor is both delivered and served by the licensee
incidental to the sale, delivery and serving of food by the licensee. A Class N
license shall permit a licensee to deliver and serve alcoholic liquor on the
same premises on not more than one day during any thirty (30) day period. All
beer and wine that is served by a Class N liquor license holder shall be served
in a glass bottle or other container that holds not more that sixteen (16)
ounces; provided, that an open bottle containing not more than two (2) liters
of wine may be placed on a table where food is to be served if the wine is
intended to be consumed as part of a meal. All alcoholic liquor, other than
beer and wine, that is served by a Class N liquor license holder shall be
served in a glass or other container that holds not more than eight (8) ounces.
The license fee for a Class N license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee
Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   V.   Class N(1) License: A Class N(1) license authorizes the retail service
of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the licensed premises in conjunction
with the serving of food by the licensee. The premises for which a Class N(1)
license is issued shall not have any other license authorizing the sale or
delivery of alcoholic liquor. The premises for which a Class N(1) license is
issued shall only serve alcoholic liquor during the hours between five o'clock
(5:00) P.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. on no more than six (6) days per
calendar year and shall not be allowed to serve alcoholic liquor on more than
two (2) days during any calendar month. The Class N(1) licensee shall give the
Liquor Control Commissioner at least five (5) business days’ written notice of
the dates and times in which it intends to sell and/or serve alcoholic liquor
on the licensed premises. The premises of a Class N(1) license shall not be
open to the general public on the dates and times when alcoholic liquor is
being served as the sale and service of alcoholic liquor shall only be to those
that have been invited to be in attendance. During the dates and hours when
alcoholic liquor is allowed to be served on the premises, a Class N(1) licensee
shall also be allowed to sell unopened bottles and/or cases of wine and spirits
for off premises consumption to individuals invited to the premises. The holder
of a Class N(1) license shall be allowed to sell and ship bottles and cases of
alcoholic liquor to fulfill orders received through its Internet website in
accordance with all the requirements of State law. The annual fee for a Class N
(l) license shall be that set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection 3-
10-1A of this Code.
   W.   Class O License: A Class O license authorizes the holder of a Class B
license to open and serve previously unopened bottles of wine that are brought
to the premises by a customer as part of the customer’s purchase of a meal. The
license fee for each Class O license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee
Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   X.   Class P License: A Class P license authorizes the holder of a Class A,
Class B, Class B(1), Class D, Class F, Class G, or Class K license to utilize
their respective liquor license in a patio or seating area that is not located
within the interior of the licensed premises. After January 1, 2012, the holder
of a Class A, Class B, Class B(1), Class D, Class F, Class G, or Class K liquor
license shall not utilize his respective liquor license in a patio or seating
area that is not located within the interior of the licensed premises unless he
also possesses a Class P license. A Class P license shall not be issued unless
the applicant submits an application which includes: 1) written documentation
from the landlord of a leased facility which consents and agrees to the
applicant’s use of the outdoor patio or seating area; 2) written proof that the
applicant’s dramshop coverage includes the outdoor patio and seating area; 3) a
dimensioned drawing showing: a) the location of the outdoor patio or seating
area and its relationship to the interior of the premises, and any adjacent
buildings, walkways, drive aisles and parking lots; b) that the patio or
outdoor area is not located within any applicable side, front or rear setback
area; c) a safe means of ingress and egress to and from the patio or outdoor
seating area from the interior of the premises; and d) the use of barricades,
railings or similar devices that are at least three feet (3') in height to
surround the patio or outdoor area and serve to hinder entry into the area
without the knowledge of the applicant or its employees. The license fee for a
Class P license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   Y.   Class S License: A Class S license authorizes the serving of alcoholic
beverages on the premises specified for the purpose of tasting or sampling
alcoholic beverages on the premises for a period not to exceed ten (10)
consecutive days. The "premises" of a Class S license shall mean a government
owned exposition center, stadium or the Village of Rosemont owned common area
of the Parkway Bank Entertainment District. The license fee for a Class S
license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code. The holder of a Class S License shall comply with all the
requirements of the Illinois Liquor Control Commission's rules and regulations
for the tasting and sampling of alcoholic beverages, including, but not limited
to, any limitations in effect on the volume of the serving being sampled. An
applicant for a Class S license must submit with the application proof
satisfactory to the Local Liquor Control Commissioner that the applicant has
made arrangements to provide dramshop liability insurance which shall provide
coverage for any liability arising under or pursuant to section 6-21 of the
Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/6-21). If the applicant is seeking a
Class S license for the serving of alcoholic liquor on premises owned or leased
by the Village, the applicant must provide proof that the required dramshop
liability insurance policy names the Village as an additional insured.
   Z.   Class W (Wine Tasting With Related Package Sales) : A Class W license
authorizes the holder of a Class B license to hold a wine tasting event at
which the Class B license holder may engage in the retail package sale of
bottles of the wine presented for tasting during the event. The wine tasting
event must be held on the premises for which the Class B License was granted
with the retail package sale of the wine presented for tasting only being
allowed during the period of the wine tasting event. A Class W license is a
temporary license that shall only be granted for a specific date and time
period, the duration of which shall not be for more than five (5) hours. The
license fee for a temporary Class W license shall be as set forth in the
Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   AA.   Class W(1) License (Special Event Wine Tasting With Related Package
Sales) : A Class W(1) license authorizes the holding of a wine tasting special
event on the premises specified and the retail sale of unopened bottles and/or
cases of wine presented for tasting. The wine tasting special event must be
held on the premises for which the Class W(1) license was granted at a time
that shall not be earlier than six o'clock (6:00) P.M. and shall not be later
than nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. The holder of a Class W(1) license shall not hold
more than six (6) wine tasting special events in a calendar year. The Class W
(1) license holder shall give the Village written notice of each date and time
he is holding a wine tasting special event at least ten (10) business days
prior to the date of the special wine tasting event. The written notice for
each event must include the date and time of the wine tasting special event,
identify the wines and vintages that will be presented for tasting at the event
and include a certificate showing that the Class W(1) licensee has dramshop
insurance coverage for the event which names the Village as an additional
insured. The conduct of the wine tasting special event shall comply with all
requirements of the Illinois Liquor Control Act and all the rules and
regulations of the Illinois Liquor Commission. The license fee for a Class W(1)
license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code.
   BB.   Class BYOB License: A Class BYOB license authorizes the holder to
allow the consumption of a customer’s beer or wine brought by the customer onto
the premises of a restaurant possessing a BYOB license for consumption by the
customer and his or her guests being of legal age on the premises of the
restaurant as a complement to the consumption of a meal purchased from the
restaurant. The consumption of BYOB beer or wine must be incidental and
complementary to the service of a meal, and only during the time that the
restaurant’s kitchen is open and offering full menu service. The licensee may
charge a corkage fee for opening a bottle of wine. Every container of wine
brought onto the premises by a patron must be opened by restaurant personnel.
It shall be unlawful for any patron to leave the premises with a partially
consumed container of wine unless it is securely sealed by restaurant personnel
prior to removal from the premises and placed in a transparent one time use
tamperproof bag, as required by State law and in accordance with the Illinois
Liquor Control Act.
   CC.   Class VG License: A Class VG license authorizes a holder of a Class A,
Class B, Class E(1), Class E(3) and Class L liquor license to conduct video
gaming upon receipt and compliance with a video gaming establishment license
received from the Village. The license fee for each class VG license shall be
set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code, and shall be in addition to the fee charged for the Class
A, Class B, Class E(1), Class E(3) and Class L liquor licenses. The Village
shall create a combined application for both the Class VG and video gaming
establishment license and charge a combined application fee as set forth in the
Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code. The Village shall also charge a combined license fee as
set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1A of this Code. Class VG liquor licenses and a video gaming establishment
license shall be valid for a full twelve (12) month period beginning as of the
first day of the month the license was issued by the Village and may thereafter
be renewed upon compliance with the terms of all Village ordinances and the
payment of all applicable application and license fees.

4-2-7.5: RETAILER'S LICENSE:
Holders of a Village of Rosemont Liquor license authorizing the sale of any
alcoholic liquor at retail that also have received a retailer's license from
the Illinois Liquor Control Commission that is necessary to sell and transfer
cocktails, mixed drinks and single servings of wine shall have the ability to
sell and transfer cocktails, mixed drinks and single servings of wine as
provided in this Section
4-2-7.5 as follows:
   A.   In this Section:
COCKTAIL OR MIXED DRINK. Any beverage obtained by combining ingredients
alcoholic in nature, whether brewed, fermented, or distilled, with ingredients
non-alcoholic in nature, such as fruit juice, lemonade, cream, or a carbonated
beverage.
ORIGINAL CONTAINER. For the purposes of this Section only, a container that is:
      1.   Filled, sealed, and secured by a retail licensee's employee at the
retail licensee's location with a tamper-evident lid or cap; or
      2.   Filled and labeled by the manufacturer and secured by the
manufacturer's original unbroken seal.
SEALED CONTAINER. A rigid container that contains a mixed drink or a single
serving of wine, is new, has never been used, has a secured lid or cap designed
to prevent consumption without removal of the lid or cap, and is tamper-
evident. SEALED CONTAINER includes a manufacturer's original container as
defined in this subsection. SEALED CONTAINER does not include a container with
a lid with sipping holes or openings for straws or a container made of plastic,
paper, or polystyrene foam.
TAMPER-EVIDENT. A lid or cap that has been sealed with tamper-evident covers,
including, but not limited to, wax dip or heat shrink wrap.
   B.   A cocktail, mixed drink, or single serving of wine placed in a sealed
container by a retail licensee at the retail licensee's location or a
manufacturer's original container may be transferred and sold for off-premises
consumption if the following requirements are met:
      1.   the cocktail, mixed drink, or single serving of wine is transferred
within the licensed premises, by a curbside pickup, or by delivery by an
employee of the retail licensee who:
         a.   Has been trained in accordance with a Beverage Alcohol Sellers
and Servers Education and Training (BASSET) program pursuant to Section
4-2-14 at the time of the sale;
         b.   Is at least twenty-one (21) years of age; and
         c.   Upon delivery, verifies the age of the person to whom the
cocktail, mixed drink, or single serving of wine is being delivered;
      2.   If the employee delivering the cocktail, mixed drink, or single
serving of wine is not able to safely verify a person's age or level of
intoxication upon delivery, the employee shall cancel the sale of alcohol and
return the product to the retail license holder;
      3.   The sealed container is placed in the trunk of the vehicle or if
there is no trunk, in the vehicle's rear compartment that is not readily
accessible to the passenger area;
      4.   Except for a manufacturer's original container, a container filled
and sealed at a retail licensee's location shall be affixed with a label or tag
that contains the following information:
         a.   The cocktail or mixed drink ingredients, type, and name of the
alcohol;
         b.   The name, license number, and address of the retail licensee that
filled the original container and sold the product;
         c.   The volume of the cocktail, mixed drink, or single serving of
wine in the sealed container; and
         d.   The sealed container was filled less than seven (7) days before
the date of sale; and
      5.   A manufacturer's original container shall be affixed with a label or
tag that contains the name, license number, and address of the retail licensee
that sold the product.
   C.   Third-party delivery services are not permitted to deliver cocktails
and mixed drinks under this Section.
   D.   If there is an executive order of the Governor in effect during a
disaster, the employee delivering the mixed drink, cocktail, or single serving
of wine must comply with any requirements of that executive order, including,
but not limited to, wearing gloves and a mask and maintaining distancing
requirements when interacting with the public.
   E.   Delivery or carry out of a cocktail, mixed drink, or single serving of
wine is prohibited if:
      1.   A third party delivers the cocktail or mixed drink;
      2.   A container of a mixed drink, cocktail, or single serving of wine is
not tamper-evident and sealed;
      3.   A container of a mixed drink, cocktail, or single serving of wine is
transported in the passenger area of a vehicle;
      4.   A mixed drink, cocktail, or single serving of wine is delivered by a
person or to a person who is under the age of twenty-one (21); or
      5.   The person delivering a mixed drink, cocktail, or single serving of
wine fails to verify the age of the person to whom the mixed drink or cocktail
is being delivered.
   F.   Violations of this Section shall be subject to any applicable
penalties, including, but not limited to, the penalties specified under Section
11-502 of the Illinois Vehicle Code.
   G.   This Section
4-2-7.5 is repealed on January 3, 2024.
(Ord. 2021-9-13C, 9-13-2021; Ord. 2021-11-8A, 11-8-2021)
4-2-7.6: DELIVERY OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR - EFFECTIVE JANUARY 1, 2022:
   A.   Definitions. In this section
4-2-7.6 :
DELIVERY. The movement of alcoholic liquor in its original container purchased
from a licensed retailer to a consumer through the following methods:
         a.   Delivery within a licensed retailer's parking lot, including
curbside, for pickup by the consumer;
         b.   Delivery by an owner, officer, director, shareholder, or employer
of the licensed retailer; or
         c.   Delivery by a third-party contractor, independent contractor, or
agent with whom the licensed retailer has contracted to make deliveries of
alcoholic liquors.
Under the above Subsections a., b., or c., delivery shall not include the use
of common carriers.
   B.   Permitted Deliveries. On and after January 1, 2022, the holder of a
Village of Rosemont liquor license authorizing retail sales may make a delivery
of alcoholic liquor in its original container to the purchaser for use or
consumption provided that all of the following requirements are met:
      1.   The Village license holder shall also hold a retailer's license
issued by the State of Illinois that authorizes the delivery of liquor
allowable by this section.;
      2.   The delivery shall be made only within twelve (12) hours from the
time the alcoholic liquor leaves the licensed premises of the retailer for
delivery;
      3.   All the applicable requirements, conditions and limitations of 235
ILCS 5/6-16 are complied with including, but not limited to:
         a.   The prohibition against delivering or giving alcoholic liquor to
any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years;
         b.   The prohibition against delivering or giving alcoholic liquor to
any person that is intoxicated;
         c.   The requirement that a contract carrier or any agent or employee
of a contract carrier obtain a signature at the time of delivery acknowledging
receipt of the alcoholic liquor by an adult that is at least twenty-one (21)
years of age; and
         d.   The requirement that a contract carrier or any agent or employee
of a contract carrier delivering to a residential address obtain an
acknowledgement of the consignee and a signature at the time of delivery
acknowledging receipt of the alcoholic liquor by an adult that is at least
twenty-one (21) years of age;
      4.   If the delivery is made by a State of Illinois wine shippers'
licensee, the delivery shall also be in full compliance with all the applicable
requirements, conditions and limitations of 235 ILCS 5/6-29; and
      5.   The delivery is not in violation of 235 ILCS 5/6-29.1 which
prohibits certain shipments of alcoholic liquor from points outside of the
State of Illinois.
(Ord. 2021-9-13C, 9-13-2021; Ord. 2021-11-8A, 11-8-2021)
4-2-7.7: DELIVERY OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR - PRIOR TO JANUARY 1, 2022:
In accordance with Section 5/5-1(d) of the Illinois Liquor Control Act (235
ILCS 5/5-1(d)) in effect prior to January 1, 2022 which allows the delivery of
alcoholic liquor pursuant to any local law or ordinance subject to the
requirements, conditions and limitations of 235 ILCS 5/6-16, 5/6-29 and 5/6-
29.1, the holder of a Village of Rosemont liquor license authorizing retail
sales may, effective immediately make a delivery of alcoholic liquor in its
original container to the purchaser for use or consumption upon compliance with
all the same requirements, conditions and limitations set forth in Section
4-2-7.6. This section
4-2-7.7 shall be automatically repealed on January 1, 2022.
(Ord. 2021-9-13C, 9-13-2021; Ord. 2021-11-8A, 11-8-2021)
4-2-7.8: PROHIBITION ON THE DELIVERY OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR BY A RETAIL LICENSEE
IN ANY MANNER OTHER THAN THOSE AUTHORIZED BY SECTIONS 4-2-7.5, 4-2-7.6, AND 4-
2-7.7 OF THE CODE OF ORDINANCES:
The holder of a Village of Rosemont liquor license authorizing sale at retail
may only deliver alcoholic liquor as may be authorized in Sections
4-2-7.5,
4-2-7.6 and
4-2-7.7 of the Village of Rosemont's Code of Ordinances.
(Ord. 2021-9-13C, 9-13-2021; Ord. 2021-11-8A, 11-8-2021)
4-2-8: PAYMENT OF FEES; PRORATION; DISPOSITION:
   A.   1.   The application fee and the license fee for each retail liquor
license must be paid in full to the Village at the time the application for
liquor license is filed and at each time renewal of a liquor license is
requested. Except, the license fee for new licensees shall be pro-rated by
quarter based upon the date of the initial application as follows:
         First quarter (January 1 through March 31): One hundred percent (100%)
of license fee.
         Second quarter (April 1 through June 30): Seventy five percent (75%)
of license fee.
         Third quarter (July 1 through September 30): Fifty percent (50%) of
license fee.
         Fourth quarter (October 1 through December 31): Twenty five percent
(25%) of license fee.
      2.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, the amounts owed for a new Class M or
a new Class O liquor license shall not be prorated.
   B.   Where an application for a Class A, B, D, or E(1) liquor license is
applied for at a time when the premises to which such application is applicable
is proposed to be constructed or is under construction, the payment of the
amount of the license fee shall be prorated as in subsection A1 of this section
based upon the date an occupancy permit is requested and paid as a condition to
the issuance of the occupancy permit.
   C.   In the event the license applied for is denied, the license fee shall
be returned to the applicant. If the license is granted, the license fee shall
be deposited in the General Corporate Fund or in such other fund as shall have
been designated by the Board of Trustees.
   D.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, the Liquor
Commissioner may pro-rate or rebate any liquor license fee when special or
extraordinary circumstances arise or as otherwise deemed advisable to promote
the development of property.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011; amd. Ord. 2021-1-11D, 1-11-2021; Ord. 2021-3-8K,
3-8-2021)

classification that may be issued or in effect at any one time shall not exceed
the number set forth below for each classification:

Class C    10 licenses
Class D    0 license
Class E    6 licenses
Class E(1) 9 licenses
Class E(2) 11 licenses
Class E(3) 1 license
Class F    2 licenses
Class G    Temporary license issued on a one day basis
Class I    2 license
Class I(1) 1 license
Class J    Temporary licenses - see Section
           4.2.7 - Class J licenses

           4.2.7 - Class P licenses

In the event the holder of any of the above liquor license classifications has
their license/licenses revoked or fails to renew their license(s) or ceases
operations, the number of the allowable liquor licenses in each of the
categories held by such liquor license holder shall automatically be reduced
by one without any action required by the Village Board of Trustees. An
increase in the number of any liquor license classification can only occur
