2021)
   B.   Reduction Of Number: Nothing in this chapter contained shall be
construed as limiting or defeating, in any way, the lawful right of the
Corporate Authorities of the Village to decrease the number of liquor licenses
to be issued or to decrease the number of licenses from time to time
outstanding.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011; amd. Ord. 2018-2-14R, 2-14-2018; Ord. 2020-6-20A,
6-10-2020; Ord. 2021-11-8A, 11-8-2021; Ord. 2024-2-12, 2-12-2024)
4-2-10: TERM OF LICENSE:
Each retail liquor license shall be issued on an annual basis covering the
period from January 1 to December 31.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-11: NATURE OF LICENSE:
   A.   A liquor license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for the
period ending as of December 31 of the year in which it was granted unless
sooner revoked as provided by law, and shall not constitute property nor shall
it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be
alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily or subject to being
encumbered or hypothecated.
   B.   A liquor licensee shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate
devolution, but it shall cease upon the death of the licensee; provided, that
executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the
trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee may continue the business of the
sale of alcoholic liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise
the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the
death of such decedent or such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of
such license, but not longer than six (6) months after the death, bankruptcy or
insolvency of such licensee.
(Ord. 2011-8-1OA, 8-10-2011)
4-2-12: POSTING LICENSE:
Every licensee shall cause his license to be framed and hung in plain view in a
conspicuous place on the licensed premises.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-13: INTERIM LICENSES:
   A.   If the ownership or leasehold interest in the premises for which a
liquor license has been issued changes as a result of: 1) the sale of the
liquidated premises or leasehold interest; 2) the foreclosure of a mortgage; 3)
the filing of a bankruptcy petition or other petition seeking relief or any
other form of debtor’s relief; 4) as the result of an entry of a court order;
or 5) if the management of the premises for which a liquor license has been
issued is changed, then the Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall have the
authority to issue an interim liquor license for the licensed premises for a
period not to exceed sixty (60) days, provided:
      1.   The interim liquor license is for the same class of license as had
previously been issued for the premises.
      2.   The new owner or manager has filed an application for a new liquor
license.
      3.   The new owner or manager has paid the applicable license fee to the
Village.
      4.   It appears, based on the information contained in the application
for a new liquor license, that the applicant will meet the requirements for the
issuance of a liquor license, and the Local Liquor Control Commissioner is not
otherwise aware of any reason that the applicant will not meet the requirements
of this Code or any other applicable ordinance or law for the issuance of a
Village liquor license.
   B.   In the event that the interim liquor license expires and a regular
liquor license is not issued to the applicant for the premises, the applicant
shall not be entitled to a refund of all or any part of the license fee paid to
the Village.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-14: BASSETT TRAINING REQUIRED:
The manager of any premises licensed to sell or serve any alcoholic liquor, all
individuals engaged in the serving of any alcoholic liquor on any licensed
premises and all individuals that supervise any individuals that serve
alcoholic liquor on any licensed premises shall provide the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner with current valid certification that they have
successfully completed a beverage alcohol sellers and servers education and
training (BASSET) program licensed by the State of Illinois Liquor Control
Commission on or before the later of: a) January 1, 2012; b) ninety (90)
calendar days within the first date of their employment at a licensed premises;
or c) ninety (90) days after the receipt of an occupancy permit for a licensed
premises. Each person required to provide certification of their successful
completion of a beverage alcohol sellers and servers education and training
(BASSET) program shall be required to maintain and renew their certification
prior to its expiration date. Copies of all BASSET certificates shall be kept
on the licensed premises and shall be made available to Village employees upon
request.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-15: ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS FOR CERTAIN LICENSEES:
   A.   Partially Consumed Bottles Of Wine: Notwithstanding any other provision
of this chapter, any Class B, B(2), D, E(1) , K, or L licensee may permit a
patron to remove one partially consumed bottle of wine for off premises
consumption so long as there is compliance with the following conditions: 1)
the patron has purchased a meal or hors d’oeuvres and consumed a portion of the
bottle of wine with the meal or hors d’oeuvres on the licensed premises; and 2)
the partially consumed bottle of wine that is to be removed from the premises
pursuant to this subsection is recorked or capped to prevent spillage and
placed in a securely sealed one time use transparent tamperproof bag by the
licensee prior to removal from the premises; and 3) the licensee has provided a
dated and time-stamped receipt for the specific bottle of wine to the patron.
It shall be the absolute duty of the licensee to assure that the type of
“tamperproof” bag that is used is such that any removal or attempted removal of
the bottle from the bag will be obvious to any law enforcement officer. The
wine that is resealed in accordance with the provisions of this subsection and
not tampered with shall not be deemed an unsealed container for the purposes of
section 11-502 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-502).
(Ord. 2014-2-12N, 2-12-2014)
   B.    Class E(1) Licensees:
      1.   Exterior Patios And/Or Seating Areas: A Class E(1) license holder
that leases any exterior patio or seating area at which it serves any alcoholic
liquor and, to the extent applicable, all patrons of any exterior patio or
seating area, must comply with all of the following:
         a.   The exterior patio or seating area must be defined and separated
from the common area of The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District by fencing
which is not less than three feet (3') in height or other materials or methods
designed to prevent access to the area by individuals that are not customers of
the licensed premises.
         b.   The transfer of any alcoholic liquor over the fence or other
material or method used to define the exterior patio or seating area shall be
strictly prohibited.
         c.   Access to any nonemergency exits from the patio or seating area
shall only be through the interior of the premises or through no more than one
exterior access point that is monitored by employees of the premises that have
successfully completed a beverage alcohol sellers and servers education and
training (BASSET) program licensed by the State of Illinois Liquor Control
Commission.
      2.   Sale Of Alcoholic Liquor To Be Consumed In Common Area Of The Park
At Rosemont Entertainment District: A Class E(1) license holder that serves any
alcoholic liquor for consumption on the common area of The Park at Rosemont
Entertainment District and, to the extent applicable, all patrons purchasing or
consuming any alcoholic liquor for consumption on the common area of the Park
at Rosemont Entertainment District must comply with all of the following:
         a.   No person shall be allowed to consume any alcoholic liquor within
the common area of The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District unless that
alcoholic liquor is purchased from an authorized vendor with a Class E(1)
liquor license.
         b.   All beverages, including any alcoholic liquor, served by a Class
E(1) license holder for consumption in the common area of The Park at Rosemont
Entertainment District shall be in a plastic cup bearing the name, insignia or
other approved logo of the vendor of the drink. The plastic cups for any
alcoholic liquor shall be easily distinguishable from the plastic cups used for
beverages that do not contain any alcoholic liquor. The cups used by each
vendor shall also be easily distinguishable from the cups used by any other
vendor serving the common area of The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District.
All cups used for alcoholic liquor and other beverages shall be approved by the
Village.
         c.   No person shall be allowed to bring any beverage or alcoholic
liquor into the premises of any Class E(1) license holder unless it was
purchased upon the premises for which entry is sought. However, any Class E(1)
license holder may, in its discretion, adopt its own policy preventing anyone
from entering its leased premises with any alcoholic liquor or beverage.
         d.   No person shall leave The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District
with any alcoholic liquor or any other beverage.
         e.   No cans, bottles, or glass beverage containers shall be permitted
within the common area of The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District.
         f.   No more than two (2) drinks of any type of alcoholic liquor may
be served as part of any transaction to any individual for consumption on the
common area of The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District.
         g.   The Village shall be authorized to further restrict and/or ban
the consumption of any alcoholic liquor or other beverages on the common area
of The Park at Rosemont Entertainment District for any event(s) held in the
common area if the Village, in its sole discretion, determines that: 1) the
consumption of any particular type or brand of beverage on the common area
would be inappropriate for the event being held; 2) the additional restrictions
are required as a result of any contractual agreement related to the event
being held; or 3) the public health, safety and welfare requires further
restrictions.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
   C.   Class L Licensees: A movie or live performance theater that holds a
Class L liquor license shall, in addition to complying with all State and
Village requirements for the sale of alcohol, also comply with each and every
one of the following restrictions:
      1.   No alcoholic beverages shall be sold or served to individuals under
twenty one (21) years of age.
      2.   No alcoholic beverages shall be sold or served to intoxicated
persons.
      3.   There must be a manager that is over age twenty one (21) on duty at
the
      premises of the Class L license holder at all times when alcohol is
available for sale .
(Ord. 2019-10-9A, 10-9-2019)
      4.   Any employee mixing and/or pouring alcohol must be twenty one (21)
years of age or older.
(Ord. 2019-10-9A, 10-9-2019)
      5.   There shall be no open spaces within theater auditoriums allowing
for patron standing or dancing during film showings or any performance. All
auditoriums must have fixed seats available for each patron with the exception
of open spaces reserved for patrons using wheelchairs.
      6.   Alcoholic beverages can only be sold or served to individuals that
have purchased a ticket to view a film showing or performance.
      7.   Fixed concession stands located outside of the auditorium must offer
food and nonalcoholic beverages for purchase at any time alcoholic beverages
are available for purchase.
      8.   The identification of any ticketed patron being sold or served an
alcoholic beverage must be checked before the sale or service of any alcoholic
beverage. The identification must be a current (not expired) state issued
picture identification or a current valid federally issued military
identification. The identification must establish that the patron purchasing or
being served alcohol is twenty one (21) years of age or older. The
identification shall be checked before the transfer of any alcoholic beverage
to the patron at the alcohol sales register. If the purchase/service of alcohol
is made through waitstaff, the waitstaff shall check the identification at the
time of ordering.
      9.   The manager on duty at the licensed premises and all individuals
engaged in the selling or serving of any alcoholic liquor on the licensed
premises shall provide the Local Liquor Control Commissioner with current valid
certification that they have successfully completed a beverage alcohol sellers
and servers education and training (BASSET) program licensed by the State of
Illinois Liquor Control Commission. Each person required to provide
certification of their successful completion of a beverage alcohol sellers and
servers education and training (BASSET) program shall be required to maintain
and renew its certification prior to its expiration date. The BASSET training
shall include instruction on the types of acceptable identification and on
determining the validity of identification (i.e., forged, altered, counterfeit
and expired).
      10.   Employees shall receive training on patron removal procedures for
any and all patrons that appear to be intoxicated or who are found or suspected
of violating this subsection. Records of training each employee receives shall
be maintained on the premises and made available to Village employees upon
request. Employees shall alert the on duty manager to evaluate any patron
exhibiting signs of intoxication if the sale/service of alcoholic beverages to
the patron must be stopped or if the patron must be removed from the premises.
      11.   Containers used to serve alcoholic drinks shall be clearly
distinguishable from those used to serve nonalcoholic beverages. All cups used
for alcoholic liquor and other beverages shall be approved by the Village in
advance.
      12.   A patron shall not be served more than two (2) drinks at a time.
For the purposes of this subsection only, a “drink” shall mean, regardless of
glass or container size, a single serving of alcoholic spirits which has no
more than three (3) ounces of spirits of one hundred (100) proof or less, a
single serving of beer which is not more than twenty four (24) ounces, or a
single serving of wine which is not more than eight (8) ounces. Notwithstanding
the foregoing, the sale and service of bottles of wine shall also be permitted.
However, partially consumed bottles of wine may not be removed from the
auditorium where it was opened or consumed.
(Ord. 2019-10-9A, 10-9-2019)
      13.   If a patron appears underage and is in possession of an alcoholic
beverage container, an employee must ask to see the patron’s identification and
verify he can purchase and consume alcohol.
      14.   Any minor found with an alcoholic beverage will have the beverage
immediately removed, and the minor will be required to leave the premises. Any
person found to have given an alcoholic beverage to a minor will be required to
immediately leave the premises.
      15.   No alcoholic beverage will be sold or served before eleven o'clock
(11:00) A.M. No alcoholic beverage shall be sold or served one-half (1/2) hour
before the end of the last film/performance or after two o'clock (2:00) A.M.,
whichever is earlier.
      16.   Alcoholic beverages shall not be permitted beyond the exits of the
Class L premises. Signage shall be posted at each exit stating that no
alcoholic beverages may be permitted beyond the Class L premises.
      17.   Staff shall periodically visually monitor each auditorium for the
consumption of alcoholic beverages in violation of this subsection. A log sheet
showing the dates and times monitoring was accomplished and the identity of the
person performing the monitoring shall be made and maintained for and shall be
turned over to Village employees upon request.
(Ord. 2019-10-9A, 10-9-2019)
      18.   A record shall be maintained of all on site incidents requiring
removal of a patron from the premises or calls to law enforcement related to
the consumption of alcohol on the premises. These records shall be provided to
Village employees upon request and shall include the date and time of the
incident, the identity of the patron involved, if it can be determined, and a
description of the incident and the employees involved.
(Ord. 2018-2-14R, 2-14-2018)
4-2-16: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic
liquor within one hundred feet (100) of any church, school, other than an
institution of higher learning, hospital, home for the aged or indigent persons
or for veterans, their spouses or children, or any military or naval station;
provided, that this prohibition shall not apply to hotels or motels offering
restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or restaurants, food shops or
other places where the sale of alcoholic liquor is not the principal business.
   B.   Subsection A of this section shall not prohibit the renewal of a
license for the sale at retail of alcoholic liquor on premises within one
hundred feet (100) of any church or school where the church or school has been
established within such one hundred feet (100) since the issuance of the
original license. In the case of a church, the distance of one hundred feet
(100) shall be measured to the nearest part of any building used for worship
services or educational programs and not to property boundaries.
   C.   Subsection A of this section shall not prohibit the issuance of a
retail license authorizing the sale of alcoholic liquor incidental to a
restaurant if: 1) the primary business of the restaurant consists of the sale
of food where the sale of liquor is incidental to the sale of food and the
applicant is a completely new owner of the restaurant; 2) the immediately prior
owner or operator of the premises where the restaurant is located operated the
premises as a restaurant and held a valid retail license authorizing the sale
of alcoholic liquor at the restaurant for at least part of the twenty four (24)
months before the change of ownership; and 3) the restaurant is located seventy
five feet (75) or more from a school.
   D.   This section shall not apply to any location within or upon the
premises of a hotel or motel.
   E.   No license shall be issued to any person for the sale at retail of any
alcoholic liquor at any store or other place of business where the majority of
customers are minors of school age or where the principal business transacted
consists of school books, school supplies, food, lunches or drinks for such
minors.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-17: ACCESS FROM LICENSED PREMISES TO DWELLING QUARTERS:
   A.   Except in the case of hotels and motels, no alcoholic liquor shall be
sold at retail upon any premises which has any access which leads directly from
such premises to any other portion of the same building or structure used for
dwelling or lodging purposes and which is permitted to be used or kept
accessible for use by the public.
   B.   This section shall not prevent any connection between such premises and
such other portion of the building or structure which is used only by the
licensee, his family and personal guests.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-18: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
   A.   Premises: All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, or
for the storage of such liquor for such sale, shall be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition, and shall be kept and maintained in full compliance with
this Code, the Building Code, Fire Code, Health Code and other ordinances of
the Village regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale
of food for human consumption.
   B.   Employees:
      1.   No person shall employ in any premises used for the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with, or who is the carrier of,
any contagious, infectious or venereal disease.
      2.   No person who is afflicted with or a carrier of any such disease
shall work in or about any premises, or engage in any way in the handling,
preparation or distribution of such liquor.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-19: DAYS AND HOURS OF SALES:
   A.   Closing Hours:
      1.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class A license, shall
sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the hours
of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
      2.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class B, B(1), or O
license, shall sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor
between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
      3.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class B(2) license,
shall sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the
hours seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. on Sunday and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. on
Monday and between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and eleven o'clock
(11:00) A.M. on all other days.
      4.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class C license, shall
sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the hours
of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. on Sunday and
between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. on
other days.
      5.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class D license, shall
sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the hours
of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
      6.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class E license, shall
sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the hours
of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M.
      7.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class E(1) license,
shall sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the
hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
      8.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class F license, shall
sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the hours
of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. Saturday and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. on Sunday,
and on other days, between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. the following day.
      9.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class I license, shall
sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the hours
of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
      10.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class K license, shall
sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the hours
of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
      11.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class L license, shall
sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the hours
of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M.
      12.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class M license, shall
deliver any alcoholic liquor to premises located outside the corporate limits
of the Village between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eight o'clock
(8:00) A.M.
      13.   No licensee under a Class N license shall deliver or serve any
alcoholic liquor between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M.
      14.   No licensee hereunder, as a retailer under a Class S license, shall
sell or permit to be sold or give away any alcoholic liquor between the hours
of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. the following day.
      15.   Effective on and after March 8, 2021, no recipient of a liquor
license shall receive any privilege which allows or permits the extension of
the time for selling alcoholic liquor until the hour of four o'clock (4:00)
A.M. Except, any liquor license holder that was previously granted the
privilege of remaining open and selling alcoholic liquor until the hour of four
o'clock (4:00) A.M. during the 2020 calendar year, shall, upon renewal of this
privilege for the 2021 calendar year, be allowed to continue to remain open and
sell alcoholic liquor until four o'clock (4:00) A.M. on December 31, 2021,
after which their privilege to remain open and sell alcoholic liquor until four
o'clock (4:00) A.M. shall expire and not be renewed. In the event any liquor
license holder advises the Village in writing of their intent to abandon their
privilege of selling alcoholic liquor until four o'clock (4:00) A.M. prior to
May 1, 2021, and ceases their practice of selling liquor until four o'clock (4:
00) A.M., the Village shall fully refund the five hundred dollar ($500.00) fee
previously paid by them for the extended four o'clock (4:00) A.M. hours.
      16.   No person shall keep open for business, or admit the public to any
premises in or on which alcoholic liquor is sold at retail or served during the
hours within which the sale of such liquor is prohibited; provided, that in the
case of restaurants, motels and hotels, such establishments may keep open
during such hours, but no alcoholic liquor may be sold to, given away or
consumed by the public during such hours.
   B.   Sunday Sales: Licensees under this chapter are authorized to sell
alcoholic liquor on Sunday in accordance with the authority granted by the type
of license they hold. However, the closing hours prescribed in subsection A of
this section shall apply to Sunday as well as the other days of the week.
   C.   Sales On Election Days: The sale at retail of alcoholic liquor shall be
allowed within the Village on the day of any National, State, County or
Municipal election, including primary elections, during the hours the polls are
open.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011; amd. Ord. 2013-10-16F, 10-16-2013; 2019 Code; Ord.
2021-3-8K, 3-8-2021)
4-2-20: SALES TO CERTAIN PERSONS PROHIBITED:
No licensee nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or
employee of such licensee shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any
person under the age of twenty one (21) years, or to any intoxicated person,
except as provided in 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-16.1.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-21: MINORS:
   A.   Providing To: No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining
alcoholic liquor, shall sell, give or deliver such alcoholic liquor to another
person under the age of twenty one (21) years except in the performance of a
religious ceremony or service, and except, that a parent or guardian may allow
the consumption of alcoholic liquor by an underage person under such parent’s
or guardian’s direct supervision and approval in the privacy of a home.
   B.   Purchase Or Acceptance: Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery
of alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of age shall not, except as provided
in this section, purchase or accept a gift of alcoholic liquor or have
alcoholic liquor in his possession; except, that persons under the age of
twenty one (21) may be in possession of alcoholic liquor while making a
delivery of an alcoholic liquor pursuant to the order of his parent or in
pursuance of his lawful employment.
   C.   Consumption By: The consumption of alcoholic liquor by any person under
the age of twenty one (21) years is forbidden; except, that the possession and
dispensing or consumption by a person under the age of twenty one (21) years of
alcoholic liquor in the performance of a religious service or ceremony, or the
consumption by a person under the age of twenty one (21) years under the direct
supervision and approval of the parents or parent or legal guardian of such
underage person in the privacy of a home is not prohibited.
   D.   Identification:
      1.   If a licensee, his agents or employees believes or has reason to
believe that a sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of
the nonage of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making such sale or
delivery, demand presentation of some form of positive identification
containing proof of age issued by a public officer in the performance of his
official duties.
      2.   No person shall transfer, alter or deface such an identification
card; use the identification card of another; carry or use a false or forged
identification card; or obtain an identification card by means of false
information.
   E.   Employment: It shall be unlawful for any person under twenty one (21)
years of age to draw, pour, mix or serve any alcoholic liquor in any licensed
premises. Except, a person under twenty one (21) years of age that is eighteen
(18) years of age or older may be in possession of alcoholic liquor on any
licensed premises while making a delivery of an alcoholic liquor pursuant to
his or her lawful employment.
   F.   Violations: No person shall purchase, accept delivery or have
possession of alcoholic liquor in violation of this section.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-22: ADDITIONAL PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Refilling Original Packages:
      1.   No person licensed under this chapter or his employee or agent shall
fill or refill, in whole or in part, any original package of alcoholic liquor
with the same or any other kind or quality of alcoholic liquor.
      2.   No person shall have in his possession for sale at retail any
bottles, casks or other containers containing alcoholic liquor, except in
original packages.
   B.   Solicitations: No holder of a liquor license, his agent or employee,
shall allow, permit, or suffer to remain on his premises any person who shall
solicit for themselves or for others for prostitution, or solicit any patron to
purchase alcoholic or nonalcoholic beverages.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-23: EXAMINATION OF BOOKS AND RECORDS OF APPLICANTS AND LICENSEES:
The Local Liquor Control Commissioner or his designee shall have the right to
examine, or cause to be examined, under oath, any applicant for a local license
or for a renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation or
suspension has been served, or any licensee against whom a citation proceeding
has been instituted by the State of Illinois Liquor Control Commission and to
examine or cause to be examined the books and records of any such applicant or
licensee or respondent, to hear testimony and take proof for his information in
the performance of his duties, and for such purpose, to issue subpoenas which
shall be effective in any part of this State. For the purpose of obtaining any
of the information desired by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner under this
section, he may authorize his agent to act on his behalf. It shall be the duty
of every retail licensee to make books and records available upon reasonable
notice for the purpose of investigation and control by the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner having jurisdiction over the licensee.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-24: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
   A.   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner may, in accordance with law and
the provisions of the Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934, as amended, revoke
or suspend any license issued by him if he determines that the licensee has
violated any of the provisions of the act, this Code or any ordinance or
resolution enacted by the Corporate Authorities of the Village, or any
applicable rule or regulation established by the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner or the State Commission which is not inconsistent with law.
   B.   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner may, in accordance with law and
the provisions of the Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934, as amended, revoke a
license any time it is determined that any of the requirements of section
4-2-4 of this chapter are no longer met or any time the license holder has
ceased operations for a period of more than sixty (60) consecutive days at the
premises for which the license was issued.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-25: APPEALS TO STATE:
Any appeal of a decision of the Village Liquor Control Commissioner to the
Illinois Liquor Control Commission that is allowed by State law shall be
limited to a review of the official record of the proceedings before the
Village Liquor Control Commissioner.
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
4-2-26: PENALTIES:
Any liquor license holder that violates any provision of this chapter shall not
be fined more than the maximum amount allowed by section 7-5 of the Liquor
Control Act, as amended (235 ILCS 5/7-5). Any person, other than a liquor
license holder, who violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not
less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 2011-8-10A, 8-10-2011)
CHAPTER 3: COMMERCIAL FILMING AND TAPING
Section
4-3-1:   Village Authority; Application For Permit; Inspections
4-3-2:   Investigation Of Applicant
4-3-3:   Insurance; Indemnification; Security
4-3-4:   Permit Fees And Other Costs
4-3-5:   Time Restrictions On Activities
4-3-6:   Report Of Vehicles And Equipment
4-3-7:   Village Control Over Public Streets, Buildings And Filming Activities
4-3-8:   Storage Or Parking Of Vehicles And Equipment
4-3-9:   Notification Of Affected Persons
4-3-10:   Village Recognition Required
4-3-11:   Termination Of Permit
4-3-12:   Conflicting Provisions
4-3-1: VILLAGE AUTHORITY; APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; INSPECTIONS:
   A.   The Village President may authorize the use of any street, right-of-
way, or public building, equipment or personnel for commercial uses in the
filming or taping of movies, television programs, commercials, or training
films and related activities.
   B.   In conjunction with the above uses, the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department shall require that all of the conditions and/or
remuneration as specified on the application be met as a prerequisite to that
use. The application must be filed with the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department within the following time lines:
      1.   Feature films: Fourteen (14) days prior to filming.
      2.   Episodic television and any commercial film that is not a feature
film or a commercial: Seven (7) days prior to filming.
      3.   Commercials: Three (3) days prior to filming.
   C.   The applicant shall agree to allow the Department of Public Safety to
inspect all structures and/or devices and equipment to be used in connection
with the filming and taping if required by the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department.
(Ord. 2008-7-2G, 7-2-2008)
4-3-2: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall refer the application
to the Department of Public Safety and to the Building Department, as deemed
necessary, for investigation.
(Ord. 2008-7-2G, 7-2-2008)
4-3-3: INSURANCE; INDEMNIFICATION; SECURITY:
   A.   Liability Insurance: The applicant shall furnish the Director of the
Health and Licensing Department with a certificate of liability insurance
naming the Village, its agents, officials and employees as additional insureds
with respect to the particular commercial filming or taping activity for which
a permit is sought, in the general liability amount (and automobile liability
amount, if applicable) of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury
or death to any person or for damage to any property from any occurrence
arising out of or in any way related to the applicant within the Village. The
applicant shall also submit to the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department proof of the appropriate workers’ compensation and employers
Liability insurance in force with respect to employees of the applicant.
   B.   Indemnification: In addition to the insurance requirement, the
applicant shall enter into a hold harmless and indemnification agreement, on
the form as provided by the Director of the Health and Licensing Department to
hold the Village harmless, defend and indemnify the Village with respect to any
loss, judgment, damages, costs and expenses, settlement and compromises, claims
and causes of action of every kind or nature, arising out of or in connection
with the commercial filming or taping activities within the Village for which a
permit is issued.
   C.   Security: In addition to the other requirements of this section and
this chapter, the applicant shall, as a part of his application, deposit with
the Village Finance Director or a surety bond in an amount as required by the
Village as security for the payment of any damage which may result to any
public way, public park or public building by reason of the applicant’s use of
the same pursuant to a permit to be issued herein. Any part of said deposit not
needed or used to repair, replace or restore damage so occasioned to public
property by the applicant at the end of the permit period shall be returned to
the applicant within ten (10) days after the expiration date. The surety bond
is required before a permit can be issued.
(Ord. 2008-7-2G, 7-2-2008)
4-3-4: PERMIT FEES AND OTHER COSTS:
The applicant shall pay the permit fees and costs for use of public buildings
and areas, and Village personnel, vehicles and equipment as set forth in the
Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1B of this Code. The Director of the Health and Licensing Department may
waive part or all the fees for a nonprofit organization upon approval of the
Village President.
(Ord. 2008-7-2G,7-2-2008)
4-3-5: TIME RESTRICTIONS ON ACTIVITIES:
   A.    The Director of the Health and Licensing Department may restrict or
limit the time for filming or taping activities during rush hour traffic or
during periods when schools or churches are in session within the affected
area, or whenever, in his judgment, circumstances warrant such limitation. The
Director of the Health and Licensing Department and a representative of the
filming company shall agree to times during each day after which no filming or
other activity related to the filming shall occur. The filming company shall be
fined at a rate not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for any filming or other related
activities that occur past the agreed upon time.
   B.   Unless the Village President authorizes otherwise, only one filming or
taping production shall be authorized in the Village on any given day. The
Village restricts the commercial filming of the exterior or interior of any
single private residence to less than ten (10) days per calendar year unless
the express written permission of the Village President is given.
(Ord. 2008-7-2G, 7-2-2008)
4-3-6: REPORT OF VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT:
   A.   The applicant shall provide a report listing the number of vehicles and
types of equipment to be used during the filming or taping, including the
proposed hours of use and the proposed parking locations. All such parking
locations shall be reviewed and approved by the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department prior to their use.
   B.   Every applicant shall pay the full daily rate for every metered or
permit parking space occupied by any vehicles and equipment.
   C.   Equipment nonessential to actual filming should be kept at a project
base camp which will be determined in conjunction with the Director of the
Health and Licensing Department.
(Ord. 2008-7-2G, 7-2-2008)
4-3-7: VILLAGE CONTROL OVER PUBLIC STREETS, BUILDINGS AND FILMING ACTIVITIES:
   A.   The Village shall have full and complete control over the use of public
streets and buildings of the Village while being used for filming or taping
activities, as well as control over the hours of production and the general
location of the production.
   B.   For purposes of this chapter a “total disruptive use” of a public
building shall mean any use which completely interrupts all business conducted
within the public building. A “partial disruptive use” of a public building
shall mean any use which interrupts only a portion of the business conducted
within the public building.
   C.   The Village reserves the full and absolute right to prohibit all
filming or to order cessation of filming if determined to be detrimental to the
public health, safety and welfare, and the applicant shall acknowledge its
understanding and agreement of these Municipal powers as part of the
application.
(Ord. 2008-7-2G, 7-2-2008)
4-3-8: STORAGE OR PARKING OF VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT:
No public or private vehicles or equipment shall be stored on any park area,
sidewalk or public way or parked on any street in violation of any parking
restrictions without the prior written permission of the Director of the Health
and Licensing Department.
(Ord. 2008-7-2G, 7-2-2008)
4-3-9: NOTIFICATION OF AFFECTED PERSONS:
The applicant will assume full responsibility for notifying residents, business
owners, or other affected individuals within the two hundred (200) yard area of
the proposed filming activity. The notification shall include a resident
acknowledgement document. Residents will sign off on this document stating that
they either approve or disapprove of the proposed activity and the hours
involved. Seventy five percent (75%) of residents within the two hundred (200)
yard area must give their approval before a project can commence.
(Ord. 2013-11-13D, 11-13-2013)
4-3-10: VILLAGE RECOGNITION REQUIRED:
The Village shall be duly recognized in the publication of any film, tape or
periodical, which includes therein, public buildings or public areas of the
Village.
(Ord. 2008-7-2G, 7-2-2008)
4-3-11: TERMINATION OF PERMIT:
Any permit issued herein may be terminated by the Village President in the
event of a violation of any of the conditions and requirements established by
the Director of the Health and Licensing Department pursuant to this chapter,
or of any traffic law or other Village regulation, or of a deviation in the
production schedule, number of vehicles, equipment location or any other
information furnished by the applicant with respect to the permit application.
(Ord. 2013-11-13D, 11-13-2013)
4-3-12: CONFLICTING PROVISIONS:
In the event that there is a conflict between this chapter and chapter 4,
article A of this title, chapter 4, article A of this title shall govern and
control.
(Ord. 2008-7-2G, 7-2-2008)
CHAPTER 4: PHOTOGRAPHERS
Section
4-4-1:   Definition
4-4-2:   License Required; Application
4-4-3:   Sanitary And Safety Requirements
4-4-4:   Compliance With Fire Regulations; Inspections
4-4-5:   Exemptions From Provisions
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1B of this Code for license fee
4-4-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, the word “photographer” means any person operating or
maintaining a photographic studio, a finishing or developing plant for
photographs exposed by persons owning or employed by the portrait photograph
business of taking photographs for any commercial purpose whatsoever, or
itinerant or transient photographs.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
   A.   No person shall engage in the business of a photographer without first
having obtained a license therefor.
   B.   An application for a license under this chapter shall be made in
conformity with the general requirements of this title relating to applications
for licenses.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-4-3: SANITARY AND SAFETY REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Every building, place or establishment in which the business of a
photographer is carried on shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
   B.   All necessary measures shall be taken to safeguard properly the lives
and health of all persons employed in such establishments.
   C.   All necessary appliances and devices shall be installed to prevent the
emission of noxious fumes, odors, or dust, and provisions shall be made to
prevent the occlusion or obstruction of the drains or sewers through which the
sewage or wastes of such establishments are discharged.
   D.    Adequate and convenient washing and toilet facilities shall be
provided for employees and such establishments.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-4-4: COMPLIANCE WITH FIRE REGULATIONS; INSPECTIONS:
Every person conducting the business of a photographer shall comply with the
fire regulations of this Code. The Department of Public Safety shall
periodically inspect each such place of business to determine whether there is
compliance with such regulations.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-4-5: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to photographing for or
developing motion picture films.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
ARTICLE A: COMMERCIAL PHOTOGRAPHERS IN CERTAIN PARKS
Section
4-4A-1:   Definition
4-4A-2:   Permit Required; Exemptions
4-4A-3:   Contents Of Permit
4-4A-4:   Permit Fee; Exemptions
4-4A-5:   Number Of Permits
4-4A-6:   Term Of Permit
4-4A-7:   Nontransferability Of Permit
4-4A-8:   Administration Of Provisions
4-4A-9:   Penalties
4-4A-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this article, the term “commercial photography” means the taking of
photographs, making of videotapes or other forms of visual recordings by a
photographer who charges a fee for his services, i.e, a “commercial
photographer”.
(Ord. 95-2-1K, 2-1-1995)
4-4A-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   No person shall engage in the business of commercial photography in
Monument Park and/or Dunne Park or otherwise take a photograph or shoot a
videotape or film for any kind of remuneration without first having obtained a
Monument Park/Dunne Park photography permit (a “commercial photography
permit”); provided, however, where the person who hires and pays the
photographer’s fee or other remuneration is a resident of the Village, the
photographer shall not be required to obtain a commercial photography permit in
order to engage in commercial photography in said parks on a weekday unless the
weekday is also a holiday on which the offices of the Village are closed.
   B.   A single commercial photography permit may be issued to allow the
taking of photographs and the shooting of videotapes and film at both Monument
Park and Dunne Park.
(Ord. 95-2-1K, 2-1-1995)
4-4A-3: CONTENTS OF PERMIT:
The permit shall specify the date and time period, when the permit holder may
take photographs or shoot videotapes and film at Monument Park and Dunne Park.
(Ord. 95-2-1K, 2-1-1995)
4-4A-4: PERMIT FEE; EXEMPTIONS:
The fee for each commercial photography permit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00)
for each photography session, i.e., “photo shoot”; provided, that no fee shall
be charged for a commercial photography permit where the person who hires the
commercial photographer and pays the photographer’s fee or other remuneration
is a resident of the Village and provides proof of Village residency at the
time application for the permit is made.
(Ord. 95-2-1K, 2-1-1995)
4-4A-5: NUMBER OF PERMITS:
No more than two (2) commercial photography permits shall be issued to the same
commercial photographer on a single day.
(Ord. 95-2-1K, 2-1-1995)
4-4A-6: TERM OF PERMIT:
A commercial photography permit shall only be valid for the date and time
period specified on the permit.
(Ord. 95-2-1K, 2-1-1995)
4-4A-7: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF PERMIT:
A commercial photography permit shall allow only the person or company who is
named on the permit to take photographs or shoot videotapes or film in Monument
Park and/or Dunne Park at the time specified on the permit. A commercial
photography permit may not be transferred or assigned.
(Ord. 95-2-1K, 2-1-1995)
4-4A-8: ADMINISTRATION OF PROVISIONS:
The Rosemont Park District shall be and hereby is authorized to issue the
commercial photography permits and collect the permit fee provided in this
article and otherwise administer the implementation of the provisions of this
article; provided, that the issuance of the permits, the collection of permit
fees and the administration of this article by the Rosemont Park District is
done in accordance with an intergovernmental agreement between the Rosemont
Park District and the Village of Rosemont.
(Ord. 95-2-1K, 2-1-1995)
4-4A-9: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any provisions of this article or who shall
refuse, neglect or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this article
shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) and not more than two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for
each photography session that is conducted in violation of this article. In
addition, the Village shall have the right to refuse to issue a permit for a
period of ninety (90) days to any person who violates any provisions of this
article.
(Ord. 95-2-1K, 2-1-1995)
CHAPTER 5: RESIDENTIAL RENTAL REGULATIONS
Section
4-5-1:   Definitions
4-5-2:   License Required; Exceptions

4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
APPLICABLE ORDINANCES: Refers to all applicable Village of Rosemont ordinances
and codes including, but not limited to, the Village Zoning Ordinance, Building
Code, Property Maintenance Code, and Health and Safety Codes.
DWELLING UNIT: One or more rooms containing cooking, sleeping and sanitary
facilities which is designed, occupied or intended for use by an individual or
one family or household; a house designed for occupancy is a dwelling unit.
Each apartment in a building which contains one or more apartments is a
separate dwelling unit.
LICENSEE: A person to whom a residential rental license has been issued.
OWNER: The following:
   A.   Any person who alone, jointly, or severally with others has legal title
to any land or premises on which a rental dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming
house or rooming unit is located; or
   B.   Any person who acts as a manager or oversees the maintenance, operation
or rental of a rental dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit
for a legal title holder of the land or premises on which the rental dwelling,
dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit is located; or
   C.   Any person authorized to act as the agent of a legal title holder of
the land or premises on which the rental dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming house
or rooming unit is located in connection with management or rental of the
rental dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit; or
   D.   Any person who is an executor, administrator, trustee or guardian of
the estate of a legal title holder of the land or premises on which the rental
dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit is located; or
   E.   Any person who is a mortgagee in possession, or has been appointed to
serve as the trustee, of the land or premises on which the rental dwelling,
dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit is located.
PERSON: A natural person, corporation, partnership, joint venture, limited
liability company, trust, unincorporated association and any other entity which
has the authority to enter into a contract under the laws of the State of
Illinois.
RENTAL DWELLING: Except as provided in this definition, a building in which
there is a single dwelling unit, where a rent in the form of a monetary payment
or the provision of services is received from or on behalf of one or more
occupants of the dwelling in return for the right to occupy the dwelling. A
dwelling occupied by an owner is not a rental dwelling for purposes of this
chapter. A rectory, parsonage or similar religious facility where living
quarters are provided for persons who perform religious services or provide
religious counseling and/or for persons who provide janitorial or maintenance
services in consideration for providing such services or counseling is not a
rental dwelling for purposes of this chapter. A dwelling owned by the Village
of Rosemont or another unit of local government or by the State of Illinois or
the United States of America is not a rental dwelling for purposes of this
chapter.
RENTAL DWELLING UNIT: A dwelling unit in a building which contains more than
one dwelling unit, other than a unit in which an owner resides, where a rent in
the form of a monetary payment or the provision of services is received from or
on behalf of one or more occupants of the dwelling unit in return for the right
to occupy or use such unit. A dwelling unit located in a building owned by the
Village of Rosemont or another unit of local government or by the State of
Illinois or the United States of America is not a rental dwelling unit for
purposes of this chapter.
ROOMING HOUSE: Except as provided in this definition, a building containing
more than one bedroom where rent in the form of a monetary payment or the
provision of services is received from or on behalf of one or more occupants of
the building in return for the right to occupy or use one or more of the
bedrooms in the building for sleeping purposes where such occupant or occupants
are required to share dining, cooking or bathroom facilities with persons who
occupy different rooms in the same building for sleeping purposes. A building
which is licensed by the Village as a hotel or motel is not a rooming house for
purposes of this chapter. A group home, daycare facility or medical care
facility which is licensed by the State of Illinois or has been issued a permit
by the State of Illinois is not a rooming house for purposes of this chapter.
ROOMING UNIT: Except as provided in this definition, any room or group of rooms
located in a building which form a single habitable unit used or intended to be
used for sleeping, but not for dining and/or cooking purposes, where rent in
the form of a monetary payment or the provision of services is received from or
on behalf of one or more occupants of the room or group of rooms in return for
the right to occupy or use the room or group of rooms for sleeping purposes. A
room located in a building which is licensed by the Village as a hotel or motel
is not a rooming unit for purposes of this chapter. A room located in a group
home, daycare facility or medical care facility which is licensed by the State
of Illinois or for which a permit has been issued to the owner by the State of
Illinois is not a rooming unit for purposes of this chapter. A room or group of
rooms in a rectory, parsonage or similar religious facility where living
quarters are provided for persons who perform religious services or provide
religious counseling or to persons who provide janitorial and maintenance
services in consideration for providing such services or counseling is not a
rental unit for purposes of this chapter.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   License Required: Except as provided in subsection B of this section,
no person shall lease or otherwise rent or offer to lease or otherwise rent
either: 1) a rental dwelling; 2) a rental dwelling unit; 3) a room in a rooming
house; or 4) a rooming unit, unless such person has been issued a valid
residential rental license by the Department of Public Safety for the rental
dwelling, rental dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit which is being
leased or rented or offered for lease or rental.
   B.   Exceptions:
      1.   The license requirements contained in subsection A of this section
shall not apply where the owner is a natural person and a rental dwelling, a
rental dwelling unit, a rooming house or rooming unit is being leased or
otherwise rented to a parent, grandparent, child, stepchild, aunt, uncle,
niece, first cousin, nephew, parent-in-law, or grandchild of the owner.
      2.   The license requirements contained in subsection A of this section
shall not apply where the owner is a natural person and the. rental dwelling or
rental dwelling unit; 1) has been occupied by the owner within the past twelve
(12) month period; and 2) is being offered for sale or has been sold, pending
closing; provided, that such rental dwelling or rental dwelling unit shall not
be rented by the same owner for a continuous period of time that exceeds six
(6) months.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-3: APPLICATIONS FOR INITIAL AND RENEWAL LICENSES:
   A.   The owner of a rental dwelling, a rental dwelling unit, a room in a
rooming house or a rooming unit which is required to be licensed under this
chapter shall apply for the initial residential rental license and any
subsequent renewal of the residential rental license on a form provided by the
Department of Public Safety. The Department shall develop such forms and make
them available to the public.
   B.   The application for a residential rental license shall require the
applicant to disclose the names and addresses of all persons who are considered
to be owners under section 4-5-1 of this chapter, definition of “owner”, of the
premises for which the license is being applied.
   C.   If the owner does not reside or have an office in either Cook, Lake or
DuPage County, Illinois, the owner, on its application for a residential rental
license, shall designate an agent who resides or has an office in Cook County,
Illinois and who is authorized to receive service of any notices of violations
of the provisions of this chapter.
   D.   The owner, as part of its application for an initial residential rental
license, shall include an authorization which provides the Village with the
authority to enter onto the premises and inspect each rental dwelling, rental
dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit which is to be covered by the
license for which the application is being submitted on any nonholiday weekday
between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and four o'clock (4:00) P.M. The
purpose of the inspection shall be to determine whether the premises is in
compliance with all applicable ordinances and any other applicable laws, rules
or regulations.
   E.   Applications for the renewal of a residential rental license must be
submitted no later than March 1 to renew a license that expires on the
following April 30.
   F.   The application for an initial or renewal residential rental license
must include the applicable license, fee. If the license is denied, the license
fee shall be returned to the applicant, unless a temporary license was issued
as provided in subsection 4-5-4A of this chapter.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-4: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   The Department of Public Safety, or its duly authorized agent, shall
conduct an inspection to determine whether the rental dwelling, rental dwelling
unit, rooming house or rooming unit for which an initial residential rental
license is sought is in compliance with all applicable ordinances and any other
applicable laws, rules or regulations, before issuing an initial residential
rental license; a temporary license for not more than ninety (90) days, may be
issued pending the completion of an inspection. In the event the first
inspection indicates that there are conditions on the premises of the rental
dwelling, rental dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit which violate
this chapter or any other applicable ordinance, law, rule or regulation, the
Department, or its designee, shall notify the applicant as to the steps which
must be taken in order to bring the premises into compliance with all
applicable ordinances and any other applicable laws, rules or regulations and
shall schedule a followup inspection to determine whether sufficient corrective
action has been taken to bring the premises into compliance with all applicable
ordinances and any other applicable laws, rules or regulations. Additional
followup inspections may be scheduled; provided, that if there are more than
two (2) followup inspections after the first inspection, the applicant shall be
assessed a noncompliance inspection service charge as established in subsection
4-5-5B of this chapter. A residential rental license shall not be issued for
any premises until all violations on the premises have been corrected; except,
that any temporary residential rental license may remain in effect until it is
due to expire.
   B.   The Department of Public Safety, or its duly authorized agent, is
hereby authorized and directed to inspect the premises of any rental dwelling,
rental dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit in response to a complaint
that there is a violation of this chapter or any other applicable ordinance,
law, rule or regulation. The Department has the authority to make periodic
inspections of any premises for which a residential rental license has been
issued for the purpose of determining whether the premises is in violation of
this chapter or any other applicable ordinance, law, rule or regulation. If the
owner or occupant of the premises to be inspected does not consent to the
inspection, the Department or its duly authorized agent, is authorized to apply
to the Circuit Court of Cook County for a warrant that will permit the
Department or its duly authorized agent, to enter onto the premises for the
purpose of making the inspection. In the event the inspection indicates that
there are conditions on the premises of the rental dwelling, rental dwelling
unit, rooming house or rooming unit which violate this chapter or any other
applicable ordinance, law, rule or regulation, the Department or its designee,
shall take action as provided in subsection 4-5-9A of this chapter.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-5: LICENSE AND INSPECTION FEES:
   A.   The annual fee for a residential rental license which includes an
annual inspection are as provided in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1E of this Code.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007; amd. 2019 Code)
   B.   The noncompliance inspection service charge shall be equal to fifty
percent (50%) of the applicable annual license fee.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-6: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL LICENSES:
   A.   The Department of Public Safety is authorized, upon application, to
issue initial residential rental licenses and to thereafter renew residential
rental licenses to the owners of rental dwellings, rental dwelling units,
rooming houses or rooming units; provided, that there is compliance with the
provisions of this chapter.
   B.   No initial residential rental license shall be issued to an owner
unless the owner attends and successfully completes the Crime Free Multi
Housing Program seminar, administered by the Department of Public Safety, prior
to issuance of the license as provided in section
4-5-12 of this chapter. If the owner is not a natural person, then the Crime
Free Multi Housing Program seminar shall be attended by a corporate or
association officer if the owner is a corporation or unincorporated
association, an officer of a member of the joint venture, if the owner is a
joint venture, a partner if the owner is a partnership, or the manager if the
owner is a limited liability company or such other person who is approved in
writing prior to attendance at the Crime Free Multi Housing Program seminar by
the Department.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-7: TERM OF LICENSE; PRORATION OF FEE:
A residential rental license shall be valid from its date of issuance until the
next April 30, unless the residential rental license is issued as a temporary
license pursuant to the provisions of this chapter; provided, that if an
application for an initial residential rental license is submitted after
October 31, the license fee shall be one-half (1/2) the annual fee set forth in
the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1E of this Code.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007; amd. 2019 Code)
4-5-8: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE:
A residential rental license is not transferable either as to location or as to
licensee. Each time there is any change in the ownership of a rental dwelling,
a rental dwelling unit, a rooming house or a rooming unit that is required to
be licensed under this chapter, the new owner must obtain a new residential
rental license. Every person holding a residential rental license shall give
notice in writing to the Department of Public Safety no later than the second
business day after conveying or otherwise transferring or relinquishing his
ownership interest in a rental dwelling, a rental dwelling unit, a room in a
rooming house or a rooming unit. Such notice shall include the name and address
of the new owner(s) of the rental dwelling, rental dwelling unit, rooming house
or rooming unit formerly owned by the person giving the notice.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-9: VIOLATIONS:
   A.   If the Department of Public Safety determines that a rental dwelling, a
rental dwelling unit, a rooming house or a rooming unit fails to meet the
requirements set forth in this chapter or otherwise is in violation of this
chapter or any applicable ordinance, law, rule or regulation, the Department
may either: 1) revoke any residential rental license covering the rental
dwelling, rental dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit as provided in
section
4-5-10 of this chapter; 2) initiate the prosecution or request the initiation
of the prosecution of the violation pursuant to section
4-5-16 of this chapter; or 3) issue a notice to the licensee describing the
violation and advising the licensee that the violation must be corrected. The
notice shall:
      1.   Be in writing.
      2.   Set forth the violation(s).
      3.   Describe the common area, dwelling, dwelling unit, area in a rooming
house, or rooming unit where the violations are alleged to exist or to have
been committed.
      4.   Specify a specific date for the correction of the violation(s) .
      5.   State that unless the violation(s) cited is corrected within the
time specified for correction of the alleged violation(s), the residential
rental license may be revoked and/or prosecution initiated for the purpose of
the imposition of a fine and/or obtaining injunctive relief.
      6.   Be served personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested,
upon the licensee if a residential rental license has been issued for the
premises on which the violation is located or occurred and, if no residential
rental license has been issued for the premises, then on an owner of the
premises.
   B.   If the violation is not corrected by the date specified in the notice
sent pursuant to subsection A of this section, then the Department of Public
Safety shall revoke the residential rental license for the premises as provided
in section
4-5-10 of this chapter or shall initiate enforcement proceedings to prosecute
the violation as provided in section
4-5-16 of this chapter; provided, that if the Department finds that the reason
the violation has not been corrected by the date specified in the notice is due
to circumstances beyond the control of the licensee, and that reasonable
progress has been made towards correcting the violation, the Department may
instead extend the date by which the violation must be corrected from the date
initially specified in the notice.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-10: REVOCATION OF LICENSE; HEARING:
   A.   The Department may revoke a residential rental license if the licensee
or the premises, or any part thereof, covered by the residential rental license
violates this chapter or any other applicable ordinance, law, rule or
regulation and has not been corrected as provided in section
4-5-9 of this chapter or the premises or any part thereof covered by the
residential rental license is in violation of section
4-5-14 of this chapter. In the event the Department determines that revocation
of a residential rental license is appropriate, he shall send a notice by
certified mail, return receipt requested, to the licensee at the address
specified on the last residential rental license application filed by the
licensee unless the licensee has notified the Department in writing that
notices relating to the premises covered by the residential rental license are
to be sent to another address. The notice shall state the reason the
residential rental license is to be revoked and shall state that the revocation
shall become effective fifteen (15) days after the date the notice was mailed,
unless the licensee files a notice with the Department within the fifteen (15)
day period which requests that the Village President appoint a hearing officer
to hear evidence and make a report and recommendation to the Village President
as to whether the license should be revoked.
   B.   If a licensee timely files a notice with the Department of Public
Safety requesting that the Village President appoint a hearing officer to hear
evidence and to make a report and recommendation to the Village President as to
whether the residential rental license should be revoked, the revocation shall
not become effective until such time as the Village President issues a written
decision revoking the license.
   C.   If a licensee files a notice with the Department of Public Safety
requesting that the Village President appoint a hearing officer to hear
evidence and to make a report and recommendation to the Village President as to
whether the residential rental license should be revoked, the Village President
shall appoint a hearing officer. The hearing officer may be an employee of the
Village, but shall not be employed in the Department. The hearing officer shall
schedule a hearing at which the licensee and the Department shall be entitled
to present evidence as to whether the residential rental license should be
revoked. The hearing officer shall cause written notice of the hearing to be
given to the licensee and to the Department not less than seven (7) calendar
days prior to the date which the hearing is scheduled to begin. The licensee
and the Department shall each be entitled to be represented by an attorney at
the hearing. The rules of evidence applicable in courts of law shall not apply
to the hearing, but shall be probative as well as relevant, material and
germane.
   D.   Following the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall
submit a report to the Village President summarizing the evidence presented at
the hearing, making any determinations that may be required as to the
credibility of witnesses and making a recommendation as to whether the
residential rental license should be revoked.
   E.   The Village President shall, after the report is submitted by the
hearing officer, issue a written decision affirming or reversing the decision
of the Department of Public Safety to revoke the residential rental license.
   F.   A new application for an initial residential rental license for any
premises for which a prior residential rental license has been revoked may be
submitted, but no sooner than six (6) months after the effective date of the
revocation of the prior residential rental license. No residential rental
license shall be issued for any premises for which a prior residential rental
license was revoked unless the Department of Public Safety determines that all
of the conditions that led to the revocation of the prior residential rental
license have been corrected, and that there is a reasonable likelihood that
such conditions will not recur should a new residential rental license be
issued for the premises.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-11: LIST OF RENTAL UNITS IN CONDOMINIUM AND HOMEOWNERS ASSOCIATIONS:
During the month of February of each year, each condominium association and
each homeowners’ association which includes dwelling units located in the
Village shall provide the Department of Public Safety with a written list
identifying all dwelling units under the jurisdiction of the condominium
association or homeowners’ association which are being leased or otherwise
rented out by the owner of the dwelling unit. The list shall contain the name
and address of the owner of each dwelling unit under the jurisdiction of the
condominium association or homeowners’ association which is being leased.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-12: CRIME FREE MULTI HOUSING PROGRAM SEMINAR:
   A.   All applicants for an initial residential rental license shall attend
and satisfactorily complete a Village Crime Free Multi Housing Program seminar
prior to being issued a residential rental license.
   B.   In the event an initial residential rental license cannot be issued
because there has not been a Village Crime Free Multi Housing Program seminar
held during the time the application for the initial residential rental license
was being processed, a temporary initial residential rental license may be
issued or the duration of an existing temporary license extended to give the
applicant the opportunity to attend a Village Crime Free Multi Housing Program
seminar. If a temporary license is issued and the applicant attends and
satisfactorily completes the Village Crime Free Multi Housing Program seminar
prior to the expiration of the temporary license, and all other requirements
for an initial residential rental license are met, then an initial residential
rental license shall be issued.
   C.   Each person who acts as the manager or rental agent for any premises
for which a residential rental license has been issued shall attend and
satisfactorily complete a Village Crime Free Multi Housing Program seminar
within three (3) months after first becoming a manager or rental agent or
within six (6) months of the effective date hereof, whichever is the last to
occur. Each president (or equivalent officer) of a condominium association or
homeowners’ association which has jurisdiction over dwelling units shall attend
and satisfactorily complete a Village Crime Free Multi Housing Program seminar
within three (3) months after first becoming the president (or equivalent
officer) of the condominium association or homeowners’ association or within
six (6) months of the effective date hereof, whichever is the last to occur.
   D.   A licensee shall be required to attend and satisfactorily complete a
Village Crime Free Multi Housing Program seminar at least once every three (3)
years.
   E.   1.   A licensee may be required to reattend the Village Crime Free
Multi Housing Program seminar at any time if the Program’s Coordinator
recommends reattendance to the Department of Public Safety concurs in said
recommendation. The Department, in determining whether or not to have the
licensee reattend the Crime Free Multi Housing Program seminar shall consider
the following factors:
         a.   Whether the property rented by the licensee is in danger of
becoming a nuisance residential rental property as defined in section
4-5-14 of this chapter; or
         b.   Whether criminal activity has been occurring on the premises for
which a residential rental license has been issued and the licensee has failed
to initiate eviction proceedings.
      2.   The failure of a licensee to attend and satisfactorily complete a
Village Crime Free Multi Housing Program seminar when directed to do so by the
Department of Public Safety as provided in this subsection shall constitute a
violation of this chapter.
   F.   The Chief of Public Safety shall designate a Village public safety
officer to serve as the Crime Free Multi Housing Coordinator. The Crime Free
Multi Housing Coordinator shall be responsible for scheduling and conducting
the Village Crime Free Multi Housing Program seminars. The Crime Free Multi
Housing Coordinator shall provide the Department of Public Safety with a list
of those persons who have attended the Village Crime Free Multi Housing Program
seminar, along with the date of attendance and verification that the licensee
has complied with this chapter and is eligible to obtain an initial residential
rental license, or renew a residential rental license.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-13: CRIME FREE LEASE PROVISIONS REQUIRED:
   A.   The leases for all premises covered by a residential rental license
shall be in writing and shall contain a crime free lease addendum or have a
clause in the lease similar to a crime free lease addendum. The Crime Free
Multi Housing Coordinator shall provide, at no cost, samples of the crime free
lease addendum and shall review any clauses within actual leases with the
Village Attorney to determine if. the clause is similar to the crime free lease
addendum.
   B.   For purposes of this chapter, a crime free lease addendum is a
provision which makes it a violation of the lease for a lessee, an occupant of
the premises, a guest of the lessee or an occupant of the premises or any other
party on the premises with the permission or consent under the control of the
lessee or an occupant of the premises to engage in, facilitate or conspire to
commit criminal activity while on the leased premises. A crime free lease
addendum shall provide the lessor with the authority to evict the lessee in
accordance with the Illinois forcible entry and detainer statute (735 ILCS 5/9-
101 et seq.), if it is established by a preponderance of the evidence that a
violation of the crime free lease addendum has occurred.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-14: NUISANCE PROPERTIES:
It is hereby declared a public nuisance and a danger to the public safety,
health, welfare and morals of the Village and its residents for any person to
permit or allow any of the following:
   A.   The rental of a rental dwelling, a rental dwelling unit, a room in a
rooming house or a rooming unit to a tenant who allows any of the following
offenses to occur on the premises being rented or leased by the tenant: murder,
kidnaping, aggravated kidnaping, prostitution, solicitation of prostitution,
pandering, obscenity, child pornography, harmful materials, sale of obscene
publication, criminal housing management, possession of explosives, unlawful
use of weapons, sale of firearms, gambling, keeping a gambling place,
concealing a fugitive, violation of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act (720
ILCS 570/100 et seq.); violation of the Cannabis Control Act (720 ILCS 550/1 et
seq.); or commission of any two (2) or more offenses punishable by imprisonment
for a period of more than six (6) months under the laws of the State of
Illinois or the United States.
   B.   Rental of a residential unit, rental dwelling, a rental dwelling unit,
a room in a rooming house or a rooming unit to a tenant who allows any of the
following offenses to occur on the premises being rented by the tenant:
commission of four (4) or more Village ordinance violations in a six (6) month
period or an unreasonably high number of calls for public safety service
including, but not limited to, calls that may fall within the descriptions
listed in subsection A of this section that, when compared to other properties
in the Village of similar type, reasonably indicate that activity on the rented
premises is adversely affecting the health, safety, welfare or morals of other
persons residing in the area.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-15: PENALTY:
Violation of this chapter, upon conviction thereof, shall be punishable by a
fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day on which a violation of this chapter
occurs shall be considered a separate and distinct violation.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
4-5-16: PROSECUTION OF VIOLATIONS; INJUNCTIONS:
Violations of this chapter are subject to prosecution under the Village
administrative adjudication proceedings established pursuant to
title 1, chapter 4, article A of this Code, as now or hereafter amended. The
provisions of this section shall not preclude the Village from using other
methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of this chapter
including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the Circuit
Court of Cook County, or before another administrative tribunal which has
jurisdiction to consider the violation. In the event that a person commits
