repeated violations of this chapter, the Village may institute an action to
enjoin such person from committing further violations of this chapter. In the
event such action is instituted and an injunction is issued, the person whose
conduct is enjoined shall be required to compensate the Village for the
attorney fees and other costs incurred in obtaining the injunction.
(Ord. 2007-3-6H, 3-6-2007)
CHAPTER 6: TOBACCO PRODUCTS AND ACCESSORIES DEALERS; VENDING MACHINES
Section
4-6-1:   Definitions
4-6-2:   Licenses Required; Exceptions
4-6-3:   Applications For Licenses; Approval Or Denial
4-6-4:   License Fees
4-6-5:   Sanitary And Health Requirements
4-6-6:   Responsibility For Violations
4-6-7:   Administrative Official; Suspension Or Revocation Of License; Fine In
Lieu
4-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
definitions ascribed to them in this section:
TOBACCO ACCESSORIES: Cigarette papers, pipes, holders of smoking materials of
all types, cigarette rolling machines, and other items designed primarily for
the smoking or ingestion of tobacco products.
TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Any substance containing tobacco leaf including, but not
limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco or dipping
tobacco.
VENDING MACHINE: Any mechanical, electric or electronic, self-service device
which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment, dispenses
tobacco products.
(Ord. 2008-7-2H, 7-2-2008, eff. 1-1-2009)
4-6-2: LICENSES REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail, deliver, or
to keep with the intention of selling at retail or delivering, tobacco products
or tobacco accessories within the Village without having first obtained a
tobacco dealer’s retail sale of tobacco license. Such license shall be in
addition to any other license required by this Code.
   B.   In addition, it shall be unlawful to permit smoking at an establishment
which also sells tobacco products, tobacco related products, or tobacco
accessories without having first obtained a tobacco dealer’s retail sale of
tobacco and smoking license. Such license shall be in addition to any other
license required by this Code.
   C.   A tobacco dealer’s retail sale of tobacco license shall not be required
if one makes no over the counter sales of cigarettes, cigars, or tobacco in any
form, but merely permits the sale of cigarettes from a vending machine located
on his premises which is properly licensed and for which license stickers have
been purchased as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 2008-7-2H, 7-2-2008, eff. 1-1-2009)
4-6-3: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES; APPROVAL OR DENIAL:
   A.   Tobacco Dealers:
      1.   Application for a tobacco dealer’s retail tobacco license and a
tobacco dealer’s retail sale of tobacco and smoking license shall be made in
conformity with the general requirements of this title relating to the
applications for licenses.
      2.   The original application shall be referred to the Department of
Public Safety for investigation and verification of the facts stated therein
and the business methods of the applicant. Unless the department shall find
that the applicant has been convicted of a felony or criminal offense related
to the sale or distribution of tobacco or alcohol to minors; or the sale of
controlled substances; or that the applicant has violated any law or ordinance
imposing any cigarette excise tax; or that the applicant has employed coercive
or illegal measures to promote the sale of any brands of cigarettes; or that
the applicant is not qualified under the provisions of this chapter, the
Department of Public Safety shall return the application to the Director of the
Health and Licensing Department with approval, otherwise the department shall
return the application with a statement of the reasons for refusing approval
thereof. If the applicant is a firm, corporation, partnership, or association,
the application shall not be approved if the department shall find that any
member, officer, director or manager of the firm, corporation, partnership or
association, or any stockholder owning more that five percent (5%) of the stock
of such corporation, would not be eligible for a certificate of registration if
he were the sole owner.
   B.   Vending Machines:
      1.   Application for a license for each vending machine shall be filed
with the Director of the Health and Licensing Department by the owner of the
vending machine, stating his name and address, the name of the make of such
machine and factory number thereof, the name of the person to be in control of
the vending machine, and the street address of the premises in which the
vending machine is to be used.
      2.   The original application shall be referred to the Department of
Public Safety for investigation and verification of the facts stated therein
and the business methods of the owner. Unless the department shall find that
the owner has been convicted of a felony or criminal offense related to the
sale or distribution of tobacco or alcohol to minors; or the sale of controlled
substances; or that he has violated any law or ordinance imposing any cigarette
excise tax; or that the place where said vending machine is to be used or the
person in control thereof has employed coercive or illegal measures to promote
the use of the vending machine; or to promote the sale of any brands of
cigarettes; or that the place where the vending machine is to be used or the
person in control thereof is not qualified under the provisions of this
chapter, the Department of Public Safety shall return the application to the
Director of the Health and Licensing Department with approval; otherwise, the
department shall return the application with a statement of the reasons for
refusing approval of the application. If the owner is a firm, corporation,
partnership, or association, the application shall not be approved if the
department shall find that any member, officer, director or manager of such
firm, corporation, partnership or association, or any stockholder owning more
that five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible
for a certificate of registration if he were the sole owner.
      3.   Upon approval of the application by the Department of Public Safety
and payment of the annual fee to the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department, as provided in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1B of this
Code, the Director shall issue a license sticker. The license sticker shall be
affixed to the vending machine so as to be clearly visible when in use.
(Ord. 2008-7-2H, 7-2-2008, eff. 1-1-2009)
4-6-4: LICENSE FEES:
The license fee for a tobacco dealer’s retail tobacco license, tobacco dealer’s
retail sale of tobacco and smoking license, and cigarette vending machine
license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1B
of this Code.
(Ord. 2008-7-2H, 7-2-2008, eff. 1-1-2009)
4-6-5: SANITARY AND HEALTH REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   It shall be the duty of all persons licensed hereunder, upon the demand
of the Director of the Health and Licensing Department to furnish for
inspection samples of all cigarettes, cigars or tobacco in any form sold or
offered for sale by them, and it shall be the duty of such persons to keep
their premises and buildings in a clean and sanitary condition.
   B.   No person shall expose for sale, sell or offer for sale to any person,
directly or indirectly, within the Village any cigarettes, cigars or tobacco
containing opium, morphine, jimson weed, belladonna, strychnia, cocaine or any
poisonous substance or controlled substance.
   C.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall inspect and
examine, or cause to be inspected and examined, as often as is deemed
necessary, all places where cigarettes, cigars, or tobacco in any form are
licensed to be sold at retail within the Village, and all such cigarettes,
cigars or tobacco in any form, to determine whether there is compliance with
all applicable laws of the State and provisions of this Code.
(Ord. 2008-7-2H, 7-2-2008, eff. 1-1-2009)
4-6-6: RESPONSIBILITY FOR VIOLATIONS:
Every act or omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter by an officer, director, manager or other agent
or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such
licensee. The licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act or
omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally.
(Ord. 2008-7-2H, 7-2-2008, eff. 1-1-2009)
4-6-7: ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICIAL; SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE; FEE IN
LIEU:
   A.   The Village President shall be charged with the administration of this
chapter. He may suspend or revoke any license issued under the provisions of
this chapter if he determines that the licensee has violated any of the
provisions of this, chapter. In lieu of suspension or revocation of a license,
the Village President may instead levy a fine on the licensee. The fine imposed
shall not be less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor exceed seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each day on which a
violation continues shall constitute a separate violation.
   B.   No such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee shall be
fined except after seven (7) days’ written notice to the licensee affording the
licensee a public hearing before the Village President and giving the licensee
an opportunity to appear and defend against the charges contained in such
notice. The seven (7) day notice provision shall begin the day following
delivery by certified mail or by personal service.
   C.   The Village President shall, within seven (7) days after the hearing
and the imposition of a suspension, revocation, or fine, state in a written
order the reason for such determination. The written order shall also state: 1)
the duration of any suspension; 2) whether the license has been revoked; or 3)
the amount of any fine. A copy of the written order shall be served upon the
licensee within the same period.
   D.   Any licensee determined by the Village President to nave violated any
of the provisions of this chapter shall pay to the Village the costs of the
hearing before the Village President for such violation. The Village President
shall determine the costs incurred by the Village for the hearing including,
but not limited to: court reporter’s fees, the costs of transcripts of records,
attorney fees, the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders and all
other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the Village or such lesser sum as the
Village President may allow.
   E.   The licensee shall pay the costs to the Village within thirty (30) days
of notification of the costs by the Village President. Failure to pay the costs
within thirty (30) days of notification is a violation of this chapter and may
be cause for license suspension or revocation, or the imposition of a fine.
   F.   When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license
shall be granted to said licensee for a period of six (6) months thereafter to
conduct the business of selling “tobacco products” or “tobacco accessories”, as
defined in this chapter, within the premises described in the revoked license.
(Ord. 2008-7-2H, 7-2-2008, eff. 1-1-2009)
CHAPTER 7: AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS
ARTICLE A: AMUSEMENTS AND AMUSEMENT DEVICES GENERALLY
Section
4-7A-1:   Definitions
4-7A-2:   Licenses Required
4-7A-3:   Application For License
4-7A-4:   Location Restrictions
4-7A-5:   Regulations
4-7A-6:   Amusement Machines
4-7A-7:   Insurances Required; Bond In Lieu
Cross-reference:
   See
title 3, chapter 8  of this Code for amusement tax
4-7A-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated, the following words, for the purposes of
this article, shall have the meanings indicated in this section:
AMUSEMENT: 
   A.   Any amusement park, arcade, golf driving range, golf course, miniature
or otherwise, public skating rink (ice or roller), “go-kart” tracks, public
dance hall, pool or billiards hall, bowling alley or shooting gallery;
   B.   Any theater, indoor or outdoor, displaying film, television or live
dramatic performances; and
   C.   Any concert, athletic contest or exhibition, public picnic, circus,
carnival, or flower, animal or dog show.
AUTOMATIC AMUSEMENT MACHINE: Any mechanical amusement machine or device, the
operation of which is governed or controlled by the deposit of a coin or token
including, without being limited thereto, any such coin-controlled instrument
or device capable of producing any vocal or instrumental sounds.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-7A-2: LICENSES REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall own, promote, operate, conduct, control, manage,
produce, present, sponsor or permit, for gain or profit, any amusement without
first having obtained a license as hereinafter provided.
   B.   No person shall install, keep, maintain or use, or permit the
installation, keeping, maintenance or use, upon his premises of any automatic
amusement machine for which a license has not been issued.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-7A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   An application for a license shall be made in conformity with the
general requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses.
   B.   The application shall be signed by the owner or lessee of the property
in his own proper person or in his name by his duly authorized agent.
   C.   The application shall set forth a description of the property used or
intended for use as a public place of amusement, indicating the seating
capacity and the floor area or ground area of the place, and such other
information as the Director of the Health and Licensing Department may require.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-7A-4: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
No license shall be issued for any place within two hundred feet (200') of any
church, hospital, or building used exclusively for educational purposes, unless
the place to be licensed has been established as a public place of amusement
before the establishment of the church, hospital or educational institution.
The distance shall be measured from the nearest point of the premises for which
application for license has been made and the nearest point of the church,
hospital, or educational institution.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-7A-5: REGULATIONS:
   A.   Admission Price On Face Of Ticket: It is unlawful for any licensee to
sell or permit any person to sell any ticket of admission to the licensed
premises unless it has conspicuously printed upon its face the price of
admission.
   B.   False Advertising Prohibited: No licensee shall place, maintain, or
allow to be placed or maintained, in front of or in connection with any such
place any sign, picture, or other announcement which in any manner misstates or
misrepresents the picture or other amusements which are being shown in said
place, or which announces a picture or other form of amusement or entertainment
which is not, at the time such announcement is displayed, being shown and
exhibited in said place.
   C.   Billiard Or Pool Rooms:
      1.   It is unlawful for any person who has not reached the age of
eighteen (18) years, unless accompanied by a parent or guardian, to play
billiards or to be permitted to remain in a billiard room for any purpose, or
to play any coin-operated pool table; and it is unlawful for any person to
represent himself to have reached the age of eighteen (18) years in order to
obtain admission to such billiard room or to be permitted to remain therein, or
to play any coin-operated pool table, when such person is, in fact, under
eighteen (18) years of age.
      2.   No person conducting or operating a billiard or pool room shall
allow or permit any screens, curtains, blinds, partitions or other obstructions
to be placed between the front windows and back or rear wall of such room. An
unobstructed view of the entire interior must be maintained at all times.
   D.   Ventilation In Dancing Establishments: In all rooms or halls in which
dancing is permitted, ventilation shall be provided as required in this Code.
   E.   Raffles, Lotteries, Gifts And Gambling Prohibited: It is unlawful for
any licensee to conduct, or permit any person to conduct, any raffle, lottery
or chance distribution of money, or article of value, or any gift enterprise,
or any form of gambling upon the licensed premises.
   F.   Supplying Water Required: The licensee of every public place of
amusement shall provide sufficient drinking water at each fountain required to
be installed by this Code.
   G.   Lighting: Every licensee under this article shall provide adequate
lighting within the establishment and in all areas adjacent thereto with
respect to usual and customary safety.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-7A-6: AMUSEMENT MACHINES:
   A.   License Required: No person shall operate or maintain in the Village
any amusement machine without having obtained a license for each of such
amusement machines as provided in this article.
   B.   Application For License: Any person desiring to operate or maintain an
amusement machine within the Village shall make application for a license for
that purpose to the Director of the Health and Licensing Department, in which
application shall be set forth the full name of the applicant and the number of
machines for which the applicant desires licenses.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
   C.   Qualifications Of Licensee; Issuance Of License: The application shall
be accompanied by evidence that the applicant, if an individual, or the person
or persons in charge of the business, if a firm or corporation, is or are
responsible persons of good character and reputation having a residence or
business address in the Village, and if the Village President shall be
satisfied that such persons are of good character and reputation, he shall
cause a license or licenses to be issued upon the payment of the license fee as
set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1F of this Code, entry
reading “amusement device”.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975; amd. 2019 Code)
4-7A-7: INSURANCES REQUIRED; BOND IN LIEU:
   A.   Every applicant for a license under this article shall carry public
liability and property damage insurance and workers’ compensation insurance for
employees with responsible insurers authorized to transact insurance business
in the State of Illinois, to secure payment of any loss or damage resulting
from an occurrence arising out of or caused by the operation of the business
licensed herein.
   B.   The insurance shall provide for the payment and satisfaction of any
final judgment rendered against the owner or operator of a licensed business,
and that suit may be brought in any court of competent jurisdiction upon such
policy by any person having claims arising from the operation of such business.
   C.   In lieu of any insurance policy or contract as cited in this section, a
surety bond or bonds of the corporate surety or sureties authorized to do
business under the laws of Illinois may be accepted for all or any part of such
insurance; provided, that each bond shall be conditioned for the payment and
satisfaction of any final judgment in conformity with the provisions set forth
in this section.
(Ord. 76-11-3A, 11-3-1976)
ARTICLE B: VIDEO GAMING
Section
4-7B-1:   Definitions
4-7B-2:   License Required; Prohibited Licensees
4-7B-3:   Video Gaming Establishment License Application
4-7B-4:   Video Gaming Establishment Licensing Requirements
4-7B-5:   Operational Duties; Video Gaming Establishment Licensees
4-7B-6:   Terminal Operator’s License Application
4-7B-7:   Terminal Operator Licensing Requirements
4-7B-8:   Operational Duties; Terminal Operator Licensees
4-7B-9:   Duration Of Licenses; Renewal
4-7B-10:   Video Gaming Terminal Tax
4-7B-11:   Loss Of Licenses
4-7B-12:   Suspension Or Revocation Of Licenses
4-7B-13:   Examination Of Applicants And Licensees
4-7B-14:   Monetary Violations; Fines
4-7B-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
ENTERTAINMENT DISTRICT: The property located within the plat of the Rosemont
Entertainment District Subdivision recorded on May 2, 2007 as document no.
0712215139 in the office of the Cook County Recorder of Deeds.
LARGE TRUCK STOP ESTABLISHMENT: The same definition as set forth in the Video
Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.
TERMINAL OPERATOR: An individual, partnership, corporation, or limited
liability company that has been issued a Terminal Operator’s License by the
Illinois Gaming Board pursuant to the Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.
for the purpose of owning, servicing and maintaining video gaming terminals for
placement in a VIDEO GAMING ESTABLISHMENT.
TRUCK STOP ESTABLISHMENT: The same definition as set forth in the Video Gaming
Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq. for licensed truck stop establishment.
VIDEO GAMING ESTABLISHMENT: Any retail business located within the Village of
Rosemont that has each and every one of the following licenses: (1) a valid
Class A, Class B, Class E(1), Class B(3), or a Class L liquor license issued by
the Village of Rosemont; (2) a valid Class VG liquor license issued by the
Village of Rosemont; (3) a valid licensed establishment license issued by the
Illinois Gaming Board pursuant to the Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.;
and (4) a video gaming license issued by the Village of Rosemont.
VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL: Any electronic video game machine that, upon insertion
of cash, is available to play or simulate the play of a video game, including
but not limited to video poker, line up, and blackjack, as authorized by the
Illinois Gaming Board utilizing a video display and microprocessors in which
the player may receive free games or credits that can be redeemed for cash. The
term does not include a machine that directly dispenses coins, cash, or tokens
or is for amusement purposes only.
VIDEO GAMING CAFÉ: A business establishment whose primary or major focus is
video gaming where the service of alcohol and food is incidental to the
operation of video gaming.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; PROHIBITED LICENSEES:
   A.   No person, firm, corporation or other entity shall permit or allow any
video gaming terminal to be operated within the Village at any location unless
they have first been issued both a valid video gaming establishment license and
a Class VG liquor license by the Village and thereafter at all times remain in
full compliance with all licensing requirements and regulations. An applicant
seeking a video gaming establishment license and a Class VG liquor license for
more than one location shall submit separate applications for each location. No
terminal operator shall own, service, operate or maintain any video gaming
terminal within the Village at any location unless they have first been issued
a valid terminal operator’s license by the Village and thereafter at all times
remain in full compliance with all licensing requirements and regulations. A
separate application shall be submitted for each location where the terminal
operator intends to place any video gaming terminal. The applicant seeking a
video gaming establishment license, a Class VG liquor license or a terminal
operator’s license shall have the burden to prove, by clear and convincing
evidence, that they are entitled to such licenses in the Village.
   B.   Video gaming cafes, large track stop establishments and truck stop
establishments shall not be eligible for either: (1) a Village video gaming
establishment license; or (2) a Class VG liquor license.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-3: VIDEO GAMING ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE APPLICATION:
The Village shall prepare a combined application form for a video gaming
establishment license and a Class VG liquor license that shall require
submission of the following information:
   A.   Identification of the applicant, its corporate status, address,
business name and location in the Village for which the licenses are sought and
any assumed name by which it is doing business at the location for which a
license is being sought;
   B.   The name and address of all individuals that are managers and members
or otherwise have any ownership interest in any limited liability company
seeking the licenses. The name and address of all individuals that are
officers, directors or have any ownership interest in any corporate entity for
which a license is being sought. The name and address of all individuals that
have any ownership in any partnership, limited partnership, joint venture or
any other type of entity for which a license is being sought;
   C.   The name and address of all individuals that have, or will have, the
responsibility for the management of the location for the licenses are being
sought;
   D.   The name and address of the primary point of contact for any
communication concerning the licenses applied for;
   E.   A true and correct copy of the full application form and all other
documents submitted to the Illinois Gaming Board for the location for which a
license is being sought;
   F.   A copy of all licenses and approvals given to the applicant by the
Illinois Gaming Board;
   G.   Proof of ownership or of a lease for the location for which the video
gaming establishment license and a Class VG liquor license are being sought;
   H.   Dimensioned construction plans for the interior room restricted to
persons of age twenty one (21) or older in which the video gaming terminals
will be located. These plans shall include:
      1.   A site plan clearly indicating the proposed location of all video
gaming terminals with clearly provided dimensioned distances to the locations
where individuals of age twenty one (21) or over will be continuously
monitoring the video gaming area any time it is in use. No barrier shall
visually obscure the gaming area from an employee of the location who is twenty
one (21) years of age or older.
      2.   Dimensioned construction plans showing that video gaming will be
located in a separate fully enclosed interior room that has partition walls
covering the full height of the area from the floor to the ceiling.
      3.   All partition walls shall include windows located between the
necessary vertical structural elements of the wall which are no lower than
three (3) feet off the floor and no higher than seven (7) feet off the floor.
The partition walls shall be fixed to the floor and the ceiling and shall not
be movable. The window areas of all partition walls shall not be open spaces
but shall have fully transparent glass or another fully transparent material.
Except, as long as an unobstructed view of the interior of the video gaming
area can be maintained at all limes, the wall against which the video gaming
terminals are to be located may not require any windows.
      4.   Any door or doors for the separate video gaming area shall be full
size and fully closable at all times. The interior portion of any door shall
have fully transparent glass or any other fully transparent material that does
not obstruct the view into the interior of the separate gaming area. The
transparent portion of any entry door into the video gaming area shall have
lettering restricting entry to only those age twenty one (21) or older. The
doors shall have the ability to be locked by the establishment at such times
that gaming will not be permitted.
      5.   The construction plans shall conclusively establish to Village’s
sole satisfaction that the view of each video gaming terminal and seating area
serving each video gaming terminal within the separate video gaming area will
not be obstructed and will be visible to an employee age twenty one (21) or
over at all times. The construction plans must be approved by the Village
before any construction can begin.
   I.   A dimensioned site plan of both the dining and kitchen areas for the
location for which a license is being sought;
   J.   A statement of any enforcement actions taken against the applicant and
each of its managers, members, officers, directors and owners by the Illinois
Gaming Board or any other body charged with the approval or regulation of any
type or form of gaming activity;
   K.   A sworn statement by the applicant and each of its managers, members,
officers, directors and owners stating that they have not had any involvement
or relationship as either a manager, member, officer, director or owner with
any entity that has had a license denied or revoked by either the Illinois
Gaming Board or any other body charged with the approval or regulation of any
type or form of gaming activity;
   L.   A copy of all documents related to any enforcement or investigatory
actions taken against the applicant and any of its managers, members, officers,
directors and owners by the Illinois Gaming Board or any other body charged
with the approval or regulation of any type or form of gaming activity and all
documents related to any final or non-final decision rendered;
   M.   A signed copy of the agreement between the entity applying for the
video gaming establishment and Class VG licenses and the terminal operator that
will be supplying the gaming machines for the location for which the licenses
are being sought;
   N.   Any documents and applications for a Class A, Class B, Class E(1),
Class E(3), or a Class L liquor license in the Village if the applicant does
not already possess one of these licenses;
   O.   Any additional documents, statements, affidavits or other proof of
compliance that may be reasonably required by the Village;
   P.   If an applicant has previously received a video gaming establishment
license and a Class VG license from the Village, the applicant may rely upon
the documentation previously submitted upon providing a sworn notarized
certification identifying:
      1.   The previous submittals being relied upon;
      2.   The extent to which the previously submitted information remains
true and correct; and
      3.   Any new information to the extent it has changed from the previous
submittal.
   Q.   A sworn notarized certification indicating all the information
submitted represents a true, and complete response to all the required
application information;
   R.   Payment of the non-refundable initial or renewal application fee for a
video gaining establishment license as set forth in the Village’s Fee Schedule;
and
   S.   All documentation, information, and sworn statements that may be
required to establish that the applicant is in strict compliance with all the
requirements of section
4-7B-4.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-4: VIDEO GAMING ESTABLISHMENT LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
The Village shall issue a video gaming establishment license, a Class VG liquor
license or any renewal of such licenses only if the applicant establishes by
clear and convincing evidence that it meets every one of the following
requirements:
   A.   The applicant has a valid video gaming establishment license issued by
the Illinois Gaming Board in accordance with the provisions of the Video Gaming
Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq., and is not in violation of the Video Gaming Act or
any Illinois Gaming Board rules or regulations;
   B.   The applicant has, or has been approved to receive, a valid Class A,
Class B, Class E(1), Class E(3), or a Class L liquor license issued by the
Village and is not in violation of the Illinois Liquor Code, the rules or
regulations of the Illinois Liquor Commission or any provisions of the
village’s liquor ordinances;
   C.   The location for which the application is made provides a full service
dinner menu for on-premises dining where the food is prepared at a kitchen
located within the premises for which the applicant is seeking a license;
   D.   The location for which the application is made does not receive more
than fifty percent (50%) of its gross revenues from video gaming. An applicant
that is seeking an initial license may satisfy this requirement by the
submission of a certified good faith estimate. For a renewal application, the
applicant shall satisfy this requirement by providing a sworn statement that
includes the actual gaming revenue received;
   E.   The applicant must be in good standing on all payments due the Village
and all taxes due. To be in good standing the applicant:
      1.   Shall not by in arrears on any amounts or payments owed to the
Village at the time of its application including, but not limited to, rent,
common area maintenance charges, water charges, promotional charges, permit/
inspection fees, fines, and penalties due the Village;
      2.   Must have paid and timely filed lax returns for all locally imposed
taxes, penalties and interest due for all relevant taxes imposed by the Village
to the extent relevant, including, but not limited to the Village’s:
         a.   Hotel tax;
         b.   Amusement tax;
      c.   Parking tax;
      d.   Tax on the gross receipts of places for eating; and
      e.   Any other current or future Village imposed tax:
      3.   Must be in compliance with the Village’s rules and regulations for
video gaming; and
      4.   Must have a valid Village business license.
   F.   The applicant has paid all liquor license fees and application fees
due;
   G.   The applicant has a use agreement with a terminal operator that has a
terminal operator’s license issued by the Illinois Gaming Board and a terminal
operator’s license issued by the Village for the location applied for by the
applicant. The agreement between the applicant seeking a video gaming
establishment license from the Village and the terminal operator shall be in
compliance with the Video Gaming Act, the Rules of the Illinois Gaming Board,
and all Village ordinances, and it shall specifically state:
      1.   That no inducement was offered or accepted regarding the placement
or operation of video gaming terminals in the establishment seeking a license;
and
      2.   A provision that releases the video gaming location from any
continuing contractual obligation to the terminal operator in the event that
the terminal operator has its license revoked or denied, has its renewal
denied, or surrenders its license.
   H.   The applicant’s full payment of the combined license fee due for a
Class VG and video gaming establishment license as set forth in the Village’s
Fee Schedule;
   I.   The application submitted by the applicant is complete in accordance
with the requirements of
4-7B-3 and free from any misstatements or inaccuracies; and
   J.   The required separate video gaming area is constructed and completed in
compliance with construction plans submitted with its application that have
been approved by the Village and are in accordance with all relevant building
codes. If the location for which the license is sought is a hotel or space
within a hotel structure, the separate segregated gaming room shall be located
within the area where food/liquor is served and shall not be located in the
hotel lobby.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-5: OPERATIONAL DUTIES; VIDEO GAMING ESTABLISHMENT LICENSEES:
The holder of any video gaming establishment license issued by the Village
shall at all times have the following obligations and duties:
   A.   The licensee shall comply with all provisions of the Illinois Video
Gaming Act and all rules, regulations and restrictions imposed by the Illinois
Gaming Board.
   B.   The operation of video gaming terminals shall not be permitted during
the hours alcoholic liquor sales are prohibited.
   C.   The video gaming terminals, shall only be located in the separate
segregated room constructed in accordance with plans and specifications that
were approved by the Village prior to the issuance of a video gaming
establishment license. The video gaming terminal area shall be restricted to
persons twenty one (21) years of age or older. The video gaming area shall at
all times be monitored by at least one employee who is over twenty one (21)
years of age. If video monitoring of the video gaming area is used, the video
monitoring shall only be in addition to, and not in lieu of direct monitoring
by at least one employee that is over age twenty one (21). A video gaming
establishment licensee shall have an affirmative duty to remove any minor form
the video gaming area. No barrier shall visually obscure the entrance to the
gaming area from an employee of the location who is twenty one (21) years of
age or over. If the location for which the license is sought is a hotel or
space within a hotel structure, the separate segregated gaming room shall be
located within the area where food/liquor is served and shall not be located in
the hotel lobby.
   D.   The total number of video gaming terminals located in the establishment
shall not exceed the maximum number allowed by the Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS
40/1 et seq.
   E.   There shall be no exterior signage advertising the availability of
video gaming that is visible from any street, alley or public right-of-way
within the Village. Limited signage that is affirmatively required by the Video
Gaming Act or the Illinois Gaining Board shall be allowed, but only to the
minimum extent required by the Act or the Gaming Board.
   F.   The Village’s licensing personnel shall have access to the licensee’s
location for the purpose of determining compliance with the video gaming laws
and regulations and also for the purpose of performing any activities required
for the licensing and management of video gaming.
   G.   If the video gaming establishment licensee operates and maintains a
video camera surveillance system of the video gaming area, it shall retain the
video recordings produced therefrom for a minimum of thirty (30) days. Said
video recordings shall be subject to inspections by the Public Safety
Department upon request.
   H.   The video gaming establishment licensee shall have an affirmative duty
to at all times remain in compliance with all requirements necessary to receive
a Village video gaming establishment licensee and a Class VG liquor license and
shall immediately notify the Village of any occurrences or circumstances which
has resulted in any lack of compliance or any claim that the licensee is not in
compliance.
   I.   The video gaming establishment licensee shall immediately notify the
Village if it, or any of its managers, members, officers, directors or owners,
are the subject of any enforcement or investigatory actions taken by the
Illinois Gaming Board or any other body charged with the approval or regulation
of any type or form of gaming activity and provide the Village with all
relevant documents, including any every final or non-final decision rendered.
   J.   The video gaming establishment licensee shall immediately notify the
Village if any information submitted to the Village as part of the application
or licensing process is no longer true and shall provide a full explanation and
relevant documents.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-6: TERMINAL OPERATOR’S LICENSE APPLICATION:
The Village shall prepare an application form for a terminal operator’s license
that shall require submission of the following information:
   A.   Identification of the applicant, its corporate status, address,
business name and locations in the Village for which the license is sought and
any assumed name by which it is doing business at the location for which a
license is being sought;
   B.   The name and address of all individuals that are a managers and members
or otherwise have any ownership interest in any limited liability company
seeking the license. The name and address of all individuals that are officers,
directors or have any ownership interest in any corporate entity for which a
license is being sought. The name and address of all individuals that have any
ownership in any partnership, limited partnership, joint venture or any other
type of entity for which a license is being sought;
   C.   The name and address of all individuals that have, or will have, the
responsibility for the management of the video gaming terminals at the location
for which the license is being sought;
   D.   The name and address of the primary point of contact for any
communication concerning the license applied for;
   E.   A true and correct copy of the full application form and all other
documents submitted to the Illinois Gaming Board seeking their issuance of a
terminal operator’s license;
   F.   A copy of all licenses and approvals given to the applicant by the
Illinois Gaming Board;
   G.   A copy of all documents provided to the Illinois Gaming Board for any
license or approval that has been denied or revoked;
   H.   A statement of any enforcement actions taken against the applicant and
each of its managers, members, officers, directors and owners by the Illinois
Gaming Board or any other body charged with the approval or regulation of any
type or form of gaming activity;
   I.   A sworn statement by the applicant and each of its managers, members,
officers, directors and owners stating that they have not had any involvement
or relationship as either a manager, member, officer, director or owner with
any entity that has had a license denied or revoked by either the Illinois
Gaming Board or any other body charged with the approval or regulation of any
type or form of gaming activity;
   J.   A copy of all documents related to any enforcement or investigatory
actions taken against the applicant and any of its managers, members, officers,
directors and owners by the Illinois Gaming Board or any other body charged
with the approval or regulation of any type or form of gaming activity and all
documents related to any final or non-final decision rendered;
   K.   A signed copy of the agreement between the entity applying for the
video gaming establishment and Class VG licenses and the terminal operator that
will be supplying the gaming machines for the location for which the licenses
are being sought;
   L.   A description of the type of video gaming terminals that will be used
at the licensed location in the Village and the unique serial number or other
number used to specifically identify each video gaming terminal to be used at
the locations for which a Village terminal operator’s license is sought;
   M.   Identification of the location for which the applicant is seeking a
terminal operator’s license and all other locations in the Village for which
the applicant has received a terminal operator’s license from the Village;
   N.   Any additional documents, statements, affidavits or other proof of
compliance that may be reasonably required by the Village;
   O.   If an applicant has previously received a terminal operator’s license
from the Village, the applicant may rely upon the documentation previously
submitted upon providing a sworn notarized certification identifying:
      1.   The previous submittals being relied upon;
      2.   The extent to which the previously submitted information remains
true and correct; and
      3.   Any new information to the extent it has changed from the previous
submittal.
   P.   A sworn notarized certification indicating all the information
submitted represents a true, and complete response to all the required
application information;
   Q.   Payment of the non-refundable initial or renewal application fee for a
terminal operator’s license as set forth in the Village’s Fee Schedule; and
   R.   All documentation, information, and sworn statements that may be
required to establish that the applicant is in strict compliance with all the
requirements of section
4-7B-7.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-7: TERMINAL OPERATOR LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
The Village shall issue a terminal operator’s license or a renewal of a
terminal operators licenses only if the applicant establishes by clear and
convincing evidence that it meets every one of the following requirements:
   A.   The applicant has a terminal operator’s license issued by the Illinois
Gaming Board in accordance with the provisions of the Video Gaming Act, 230
ILCS 40/1. et seq., and is not in violation of the Video Gaming Act or any
Illinois Gaming Board rules or regulations;
   B.   The applicant must be in good standing on all payments due the Village
and all taxes due. To be in good standing the applicant:
      1.   Shall not by in arrears on any amounts or payments owed to the
Village at the time of its application;
      2.   Must have paid all locally imposed taxes, penalties and interest due
for all relevant taxes imposed by the Village, including, but not limited to
the Village’s tax on video gaming terminals and any other Village tax to the
extent relevant;
      3.   Must be in compliance with the Village’s rules and regulations for
video gaming;
      4.   Must have a valid Village business license; and
      5.   Must not be in violation of any tax requirements imposed by the
Video Gaming Act or the Illinois Gaming Board.
   C.   The applicant has a use agreement with a video gaming establishment
that has a video gaming establishment license issued by the Illinois Gaming
Board, a video gaming establishment license issued by the Village, and a Class
VG liquor license issued by the Village. The agreement between the applicant
seeking a terminal operator’s license and the video gaming establishment in
which the terminal operator intends to place video gaming terminals shall be in
compliance with the Video Gaming Act, the Rules of the Illinois Gaming Board,
all Village ordinances and shall specifically state:
      1.   That no inducement was offered or accepted regarding the placement
or operation of video gaming terminals in the establishment seeking a license;
and
      2.   A provision that releases the video gaming location from any
continuing contractual obligation to the terminal operator in the event that
the terminal operator has its license revoked or denied, has its renewal
denied, or surrenders its license.
   D.   The number of licensed video gaming establishment locations served by a
terminal operator in the Village shall not exceed twenty percent (20%) of the
total allowable number of video gaming locations in the Village; and
   E.   The application submitted by the applicant is complete in accordance
with the requirements of section
4-7B-6 and free from any misstatements or inaccuracies.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-8: OPERATIONAL DUTIES; TERMINAL OPERATOR LICENSEES:
The holder of any terminal operator’s license issued by the Village shall at
all limes having the following obligations and duties:
   A.   The licensee shall comply with all provisions of the Illinois Video
Gaming Act and all rules, regulations and restrictions imposed by the Illinois
Gaming Board;
   B.   Assume the primary responsibility for the operation and maintenance of
video gaming terminals and for payment of tax remittance to the State as
required by the Video Gaming Act. All applications fees, license fees and taxes
due to the Village are in addition to any fees or taxes imposed by the Illinois
Gaming Board or the Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.;
   C.   Ensure the timely repair and continued, approved operation and play of
the video gaming terminals it operates;
   D.   Assume responsibility for terminal and associated video gaming
equipment malfunctions, including any claim for the payment of credits arising
from malfunctions;
   E.   Promptly notify the Illinois Gaming Board and Village of electronic or
mechanical malfunctions or problems experienced in a terminal that affect the
integrity of terminal play;
   F.   Respond to service calls within a reasonable time from the time of
notification by the video gaming location;
   G.   Immediately remove all video gaming terminals from the restricted area
of play:
      1.   Upon order of the Illinois Gaming Board or the Village; or
      2.   That have been out of service or otherwise inoperable for more than
seventy two (72) hours.
   H.   Provide the Village on a monthly basis a current list of video gaming
terminals acquired for use in the Village and their unique identifying number;
   I.   Not install, remove or relocate any video gaming terminal without prior
notification and approval of the Illinois Gaming Board Administrator or his
designee and prior notification to the Village;
   J.   Service, maintain or repair video gaming terminals at licensed video
gaming locations only by licensed technicians or licensed terminal handlers;
   K.   The terminal operator licensee shall immediately notify the Village if
it, or any of its managers, members, officers, directors or owners, are the
subject of any enforcement or investigatory actions taken by the Illinois
Gaming Board or any other body charged with the approval or regulation of any
type or form of gaming activity and provide the Village with all relevant
documents, including any every final or non-final decision rendered; and
   L.   The terminal operator licensee shall immediately notify the Village if
any information submitted to the Village as part of the application or
licensing process is no longer true and shall provide a full explanation and
relevant documents.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-9: DURATION OF LICENSES; RENEWAL:
Unless revoked or suspended, all video gaming establishment licenses, all class
VG liquor licenses, and all terminal operator’s licenses shall be valid for a
full twelve (12) month period beginning as of the first day of the month the
license was issued by the Village, and may thereafter be renewed upon
compliance with the terms of this article and the payment of all applicable
application and license fees.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-10: VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL TAX:
   A.   A tax is herein imposed on each video gaming terminal installed or
operated within the Village by a terminal operator in the amount set forth in
the Village’s Fee Schedule for each video gaming terminal. The tax shall be due
and paid prior to the date each video gaming terminal is placed in operation
and shall satisfy the tax due for the full twelve (12) month registration
period beginning as of the first day of the month in which each video gaming
terminal is placed in operation. At the expiration of the initial twelve (12)
month registration period, the registration may be renewed for subsequent
twelve (12) month periods by the payment of the tax amount set forth in the
Village’s Fee Schedule at the time of the renewal.
   B.   Upon the payment of the video gaming terminal tax for each video gaming
terminal, the Village shall maintain a registry of each video gaming terminal
that includes: a description of the video gaming terminal; its location; the
unique serial number or other unique number used to specifically identify each
video gaming terminal; the date the video gaming terminal tax was paid; the
date the registration period for the video gaming terminal expires, which date
shall be the last day of the full twelve (12) month period beginning as of the
first day of the month in which each video gaming terminal is placed in
operation; and each date the registration is renewed by the payment of the tax
amount due at the time of the renewal as set forth in the Village’s Fee
Schedule.
   C.   Upon the payment of the video gaming terminal tax for each video gaming
terminal, the Village shall, prior to the operation of the terminal, affix a
decal or sticker identifying the last month and year in which the video gaming
terminal’s registration will be valid. In the event a terminal operator
permanently removes a video gaming terminal from the location for which it is
registered, the terminal operator may provide the registration information for
a replacement and request that the remaining registration period for the
removed video gaming terminal be allocated to the replacement video gaming
terminal operated at the same location. In the event a terminal operator adds
an additional video gaming terminal to a location for which it has been
licensed, the terminal operator shall immediately notify the Village and shall
not operate the additional terminal until the registration and the payment of
the video gaming terminal tax for the additional video gaming terminal has been
completed. A video gaming terminal that does not display a Village decal or
sticker identifying the last month and year in which the video gaming
terminal’s registration will be valid is subject to seizure and may be turned
over to the Illinois Gaming Board or other appropriate jurisdiction unless
otherwise ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction.
   D.   A terminal operator shall not under any circumstances operate any video
gaming terminal if the video gaming terminal tax has not been paid; or the
video gaming terminal has not been registered by the Village.
   E.   A terminal operator shall not allow or permit any tampering or removal
of any decal or sticker affixed to any video gaming terminal by the Village and
shall immediately give notice to the Village of the removal of, or any damage
sustained to, any decal or sticker affixed to any video gaming terminal by the
Village.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-11: LOSS OF LICENSES:
A video gaming terminal shall not under any circumstances be operated in the
Village if:
   A.   The terminal operator responsible for the operation of the video gaming
terminal no longer has a terminal operator’s license issued by both the
Illinois Gaming Board and the Village for the location where a video gaming
terminal is located;
   B.   If the location where the video gaming terminal is located does not
possess a valid video gaming establishment license issued by both the Illinois
Gaming Board and the Village;
   C.   If the location where the video gaming terminal is located does not
possess a valid Class VG liquor license issued by the Village; or
   D.   If the location where the video gaming terminal is located does not
possess a valid Class A, Class B, Class E(1), Class E(3), or a Class L liquor
license issued by the Village.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-12: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
The Village’s Local Liquor Control Commissioner or his designee shall have the
jurisdiction to suspend or revoke any video gaming establishment license and
any terminal operator’s license issued by the Village if, after a hearing, he
determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of any
ordinance enacted by the corporate authorities of the Village. The hearing
shall be based upon written charges setting forth the facts for the alleged
violation that are served upon the licensee with a notice to appear at a
specific date, time and place for a hearing that is not less than fourteen (1)4
days after date of service of the notice to appear and the written charges. The
charges and the notice to appear may be served by certified mail to the address
for the licensee, by personal delivery to the licensee’s manager or agent at
the location in the Village for which the license has been granted, or
otherwise in any manner allowed for the service of a summons under the Illinois
Code of Civil Procedure. At the hearing, the licensee may be represented by an
attorney at its own expense and shall have the right to cross-examine
witnesses, receive and review documentary evidence presented, call its own
witnesses and present documentary evidence on their behalf. All testimony shall
be given under oath and the hearing shall not be subject to the strict
application of the rules of evidence provided the testimony is of a type that
is reasonable deemed reliable and probative of a matter relevant to the
hearing. The hearing shall be transcribed by a certified court reporter. The
Village’s Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall issue a written decision
based on the facts presented at the hearing as to whether the license shall be
suspended or revoked. A suspension of a license shall not be for more than
thirty (30) days. If the hearing is conducted by a hearing officer designee of
the Village’s Local Liquor Control Commissioner, the hearing officer shall
submit, written findings with the hearing officer's recommendation to the Local
Liquor Control Commissioner.. The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall
obtain and review a transcript of the hearing, review the findings and
recommendation of the hearing officer and render written decision as to whether
the license shall be suspended or revoked. In any action where the license is
suspended or revoked, the licensee shall pay to the Village all costs and
reasonable attorney’s fees incurred by the Village and the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-13: EXAMINATION OF APPLICANTS AND LICENSEES:
The Local Liquor Control Commissioner or his designee shall have the right to:
   A.   Examine, or cause to be examined, under oath, any applicant for a
Village video gaming establishment license and any applicant for a Village
terminal operators license;
   B.   Examine or cause to be examined, the books and records of any such
applicant or licensee; or
   C.   Hear testimony and take proof for his information related to any
application for Village video gaming establishment license or a Village
terminal operator’s license. It shall be the duty of every applicant or
licensee for a Village video gaming establishment license or a Village terminal
operator’s license to make books and records available upon reasonable notice
for the purpose of investigation and control as provided herein.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
4-7B-14: MONETARY VIOLATIONS; FINES:
It shall be a violation of this article for any applicant or holder of a
Village video gaming establishment license or a Village terminal operator’s
license to act in any manner that is contrary to any of the duties,
obligations, and requirements of this article. The charges or citation for any
such violation may, at the discretion of the Village, be pursued through the
Village’s system for the administrative adjudication of ordinance violations or
otherwise by an action filed in the Circuit Court. Each day that a violation
occurs shall be a new violation. If it is determined that a violation has
occurred, a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) but not more
than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) may be imposed for each violation.
(Ord. 2020-6-10, 6-10-2020)
ARTICLE C: RESALE OF TICKETS FOR AMUSEMENTS
Section
4-7C-1:   Definitions
4-7C-2:   Sale Of Tickets Other Than At Box Office Prohibited; Exceptions
4-7C-3:   Service Charge Permitted
4-7C-4:   Penalty
4-7C-5:   Seizure And Forfeiture Of Tickets
4-7C-6:   Prosecution Of Violations
4-7C-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
AMUSEMENT: Any exhibition, performance or show for entertainment purposes
including, but not limited to, any theatrical, dramatic, musical or spectacular
performance; promotional show; motion picture show; flower or animal show;
circus; rodeo; athletic contest; sport; game; or similar exhibition, such as
boxing, wrestling, skating, dancing, basketball, soccer, football, track and
field games, or hockey to which tickets are sold to the public.
AUTHORIZED AGENT: When used in the context of an authorized agent of the owner
or operator of an amusement or a place where an amusement is held, includes
persons, firms and corporations authorized by the owner or operator to sell
tickets to the amusement over the Internet, through the mail, over the
telephone or at a remote location.
(Ord. 2008-1-9G, 1-9-2008)
4-7C-2: SALE OF TICKETS OTHER THAN AT BOX OFFICE PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   Except as provided in subsection B of this section, it is unlawful for
any person, firm or corporation within the corporate limits of the Village,
other than the owner or operator of an amusement or a place where an amusement
is held or their employees or their authorized agents, to sell, or to solicit
the sale of, an admission ticket to an amusement.
   B.   The restrictions set forth in subsection A of this section do not apply
to the sale of an admission ticket or soliciting the sale of an admission
ticket to an amusement:
      1.   If the amount for which the admission ticket is sold, bartered or
exchanged, or offered to be sold, is equal to either the price of the ticket as
stated on the ticket or the amount for which the ticket was sold when first
issued; or
      2.   If the admission ticket is sold by a ticket broker who is registered
with the Office of the Secretary of State as provided in section 1.5(b) of the
Illinois Ticket Sale and Resale Act (720 ILCS 375/1.5(c)); or
      3.   If the admission ticket is sold by a reseller engaged in interstate
or intrastate commerce on an Internet auction listing service duly registered
with the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation under the
Auction License Act (225 ILCS 407/5-1 et seq.) and with the Illinois Office of
the Secretary of State; provided, that the operator of the Internet auction
listing service meets the requirements set forth in section 1.5(c) of the
Illinois Ticket Sale and Resale Act (815 ILCS 414/1.5(c)). This subsection B3
applies to both sales through an online bid submission process and sales at a
fixed price on the same website or interactive computer service as an Internet
auction listing service registered with the Illinois Department of Financial
and Professional Regulation; or
      4.   If the admission ticket is sold at an auction solely by or for a not
for profit organization for charitable purposes under clause (a)(1) of section
10-1 of the Illinois Auction License Act (225 ILCS 407/10-1(a)(1)); or
      5.   If the admission ticket is sold through an Internet website whose
operator meets the requirements set forth in section 1.5(e) of the Illinois
Ticket Sale and Resale Act (815 ILCS 414/1.5(e)).
(Ord. 2008-1-9G, 1-9-2008)
4-7C-3: SERVICE CHARGE PERMITTED:
Nothing contained in this article prohibits a ticket seller, with the consent
of the owner or operator of an amusement or a place where an amusement is held,
from collecting a reasonable service charge in addition to the price as stated
on the admission ticket or the price for which an admission ticket was sold
when issued from a ticket purchaser in return for service actually rendered.
(Ord. 2008-1-9G, 1-9-2008)
4-7C-4: PENALTY:
Any person found to have violated any of the provisions of this article shall,
upon conviction, be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2008-1-9G, 1-9-2008)
4-7C-5: SEIZURE AND FORFEITURE OF TICKETS:
Any admission ticket sold or offered for sale in violation of section
4-7C-2 of this article is declared to be contraband subject to seizure, and any
such admission ticket shall be subject to forfeiture upon a finding of guilty
of any person for a violation of said section
4-7C-2. Upon appropriate order of a court or an administrative hearing officer,
the admission ticket shall be disposed of in accordance with applicable law.
(Ord. 2008-1-9G, 1-9-2008)
4-7C-6: PROSECUTION OF VIOLATIONS:
Violations of the provisions of section
4-7C-2 of this article are subject to prosecution under the Village
administrative adjudication proceedings established pursuant to
title 1, chapter 4, article A of this Code, as now or hereafter amended. The
provisions of this section shall not preclude the Village from using other
methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of this article
including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the Circuit
Court of Cook County, or before another administrative tribunal which has
jurisdiction to consider the violation.
(Ord. 2008-1-9G, 1-9-2008)
CHAPTER 8: HOTELS AND MOTELS
Section
4-8-1:   Definition
4-8-2:   License Required
4-8-3:   Application For License
4-8-4:   Regulations
4-8-5:   Annual Inspections
Cross-reference:
   See
title 3, chapter 5  of this Code for hotel and motel use tax; see subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-8-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
HOTEL/MOTEL: Every building or structure kept, used or maintained as, or held
out to the public to be, an inn, hotel, motel or public lodging house or place
where sleeping accommodations are furnished for hire to transient guests,
whether with or without meals, in which ten (10) or more rooms are used for the
accommodation of guests.
(Ord. 75 12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-8-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate any hotel or motel
within the Village without first obtaining a license therefor as provided
herein.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-8-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
A license application shall be made conformity with the general requirements of
this title pertaining to applications for business licenses.
(Ord. 76-11-3B, 11-3-197 6)
4-8-4: REGULATIONS:
   A.   Clean And Sanitary Premises:
      1.   Every establishment licensed under this chapter and every part
thereof shall be clean and free from any accumulation of dirt, filth, garbage
and other matter in or on the same, or in the yard, court, passage area or
alley connected with or belonging to the same.
      2.   The owner or keeper shall thoroughly cleanse all the rooms,
passages, stairs, floors, windows, doors, walls, ceilings, privies, cesspools
and drains of the house or part of the house of which he is the owner, lessee
or keeper to the satisfaction of the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department as often as shall be required by or in accordance with any
regulation or order of the Director.
      3.   Plumbing fixtures and floors shall be thoroughly cleaned at least
once daily, or more often if necessary.
   B.   Garbage And Refuse Receptacles: Every licensee shall have proper and
suitable conveniences or receptacles for receiving garbage and other refuse
matter.
   C.   Sanitation Facilities:
      1.   Each sleeping unit shall be furnished with its own sanitary
facilities which shall consist of a minimum of one flush toilet and one
lavatory and one bath or shower.
      2.   All water closets and urinals in, or used in connection with, any
hotel or lodging house shall be disinfected as often as may be necessary to
keep them in sanitary condition.
      3.   Hot and cold running water shall be available at all times at
lavatory, bath and shower fixtures.
      4.   Each licensee having a public washroom shall keep therein at all
times a sufficient supply of individual clean towels in a place in sight of and
of easy access to guests.
   D.    Water Supply And Sewage Disposal Facilities: Water supply and sewage
disposal facilities shall be maintained and operated so as to perform their
function.
   E.   Beds And Bedding, Soap And Towels:
      1.   Each sleeping unit shall be furnished with beds and bedding which
shall be in good condition, clean and adequate to maintain body comfort.
      2.   All beds for the accommodation of guests shall be provided with a
sufficient supply of clean bedding and with clean sheets. All beds shall be
provided with clean sheets as often as the beds are assigned to different
persons, or as requested by the hotel guest.
      3.   Each occupant of a sleeping unit shall be furnished with soap and at
least one clean, freshly laundered bath towel and hand towel daily.
   F.   Temperature: A comfortable temperature shall be maintained in sleeping
units heated from a central plant. Where central heating is not provided,
sleeping units shall be furnished with safe, convenient and adequate facilities
for use by occupants as necessary.
   G.   Lighting: During hours of darkness, adequate lighting shall be
maintained at all buildings and on the site.
   H.   Fire Extinguishers: Fire extinguishers shall be maintained in a filled
and workable condition.
   I.   Building Requirements: The layout, development and facilities of the
licensee shall conform to the standards, and requirements of this Code, the
Building Code and all other valid ordinances of the Village.
   J.   Parking Space: Parking spaces shall be provided as set forth in the
Village Zoning Code.
   K.   Registration And Recordkeeping Area: There shall be an office or room
where incoming occupants will be registered and where the registration records
shall be maintained in approved form and kept available at all times for
inspection by Village officials.
   L.   Manager:
      1.   The licensed premises shall be in the charge of a manager who shall
be of good moral character, available and responsible at all times for
maintaining the grounds, buildings, and facilities in a sanitary, safe and
orderly and usable condition.
      2.   The manager shall comply with such other applicable health and
sanitation rules and regulations that have been adopted under the powers
granted State or County Health Departments.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-8-5: ANNUAL INSPECTIONS:
Every hotel or motel operated in the Village shall be inspected under and by
authority of the Director of the Health and Licensing Department at least once
every year. Such inspections shall cover all matters pertaining to the sanitary
conditions of the rooms, beds and bedding, including the ventilation of all
rooms or occupied rooms, and also all rooms occupied by the servants or other
employees, to ascertain the condition of such rooms with respect to light,
heat, ventilation and general sanitation. The investigation shall be
sufficiently accurate and complete to convince the Director or his duly
authorized representative whether the building and premises and parts thereof
comply in all respects with this Code or the ordinances of the Village and the
laws of the State pertaining to such establishments.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 9: PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
Section
4-9-1:   Definitions
4-9-2:   Peddlers And Commercial Solicitors
4-9-2-1:   License Required
4-9-2-2:   Application For License
4-9-2-3:   License Fee
4-9-2-4:   Issuance Or Denial Of License
4-9-2-5:   Term Of License
4-9-2-6:   Peddling And Commercial Soliciting Prohibited In Certain Areas
4-9-2-7:   Suspension Or Revocation Of License; Hearing
4-9-3:   Noncommercial Solicitors
4-9-4:   Restrictions Applicable To All Peddlers And Solicitors
4-9-5:   Prohibited Peddling And Soliciting
4-9-6:   Charitable Highway Solicitations
4-9-7:   Penalty
4-9-1:    DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
COMMERCIAL SOLICITING OR SOLICITATION: The door-to-door selling or offering for
sale of property, goods, wares, merchandise, food or services of any kind,
character or description whatever, for any kind of consideration, for future
delivery or performance, but excluding “noncommercial solicitation”, as defined
in this section. “Commercial solicitation” shall not include the sale of goods
by persons conducting fundraising activities for local schools or youth
scouting organizations where the goods will be delivered at a future date.
DEPARTMENT: The Rosemont Public Safety Department.
NONCOMMERCIAL SOLICITING OR SOLICITATION: The door-to-door soliciting of gifts,
contributions of money or goods, or support for any bona fide charitable,
political, religious or not for profit organization purpose.
PEDDLING: The door-to-door sale or offering for sale of property for immediate
delivery from other than a fixed place of business on private property,
including the sale of charitable or religious books or pamphlets. PEDDLING
shall not include the sale of goods by charitable organizations for charitable
purposes for not to exceed one day in any calendar year, or the sale of goods
by persons as part of fundraising activities for local schools or local youth
organizations.
SOLICITATION: Does not include any of the activities described in the
definition of “commercial soliciting or solicitation” or “noncommercial
soliciting or solicitation” in this section when undertaken by any person
granted a previous invitation or appointment.
SUPERINTENDENT: The Superintendent of Public Safety, or his designee.
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
4-9-2: PEDDLERS AND COMMERCIAL SOLICITORS:
4-9-2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddling or
commercial solicitation in the Village without having first obtained a license
therefor as provided herein.
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
4-9-2-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Persons desiring to engage in peddling or commercial solicitation within the
Village shall make application for a license to the department upon a form
provided by the Village. The applicant shall provide the following information
concerning the applicant and the persons who will be engaged in the proposed
activities:
   A.   The full name, date of birth (if a person), mailing address and the
telephone number of the person or organization, if any, sponsoring, promoting,
or conducting the proposed activities.
   B.   The full name, date of birth, mailing address and telephone number of
the individual person or persons who have supervision of or responsibility for
the proposed activities.
   C.   The full name, date of birth, mailing address and telephone number of
the individual person or persons who will be engaged in the proposed
activities, and color photographs of each such person.
   D.   The dates and hours which the activities or solicitation are proposed
to begin and end, within time limits allowed under this chapter.
   E.   The date, or approximate date, of the last previous application
submitted by the applicant for a license under this chapter.
   F.   Whether the applicant or any of the persons identified in the
application has ever been convicted of the commission of a felony under the
laws of the State of Illinois or any other state or under the Federal laws of
the United States.
   G.   Evidence that the applicant is authorized to solicit for the
organization represented.
   H.   The number and description of all vehicles that will be used.
   I.   A certificate of insurance issued by an insurance company licensed to
do business in Illinois shall be provided to the department with the
application, showing that the applicant and his solicitors or peddlers are
insured against liability for damages for personal injuries and property damage
arising out of the negligent acts of the applicant and the applicant’s
solicitors or peddlers. The certificate may not expire or be canceled during
the period of solicitation and will provide at least the following coverage:
      1.   Personal injury: Five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per
person, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence.
      2.   Property damage: One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00).
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
4-9-2-3: LICENSE FEE:
The fee for a peddler/commercial solicitor license shall be the fee established
in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-15-1B of this Code.
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
4-9-2-4: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF LICENSE:
The Superintendent of Public Safety, upon receipt of a properly completed
application, but in no event later than ten (10) working days after receipt of
the application, shall either issue a license or notify the applicant in
writing that the application has been denied because of the applicant’s failure
to comply with the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
4-9-2-5: TERM OF LICENSE:
A license for peddling or soliciting referred to herein shall be valid for the
period stated in the license, but in no event for a period longer than ninety
(90) days from the date of the issuance of same. Nothing herein, however, shall
prevent the reissuance of licenses to peddlers or solicitors in compliance with
the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
4-9-2-6: PEDDLING AND COMMERCIAL SOLICITING PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN AREAS:
   A.   No person, including a person who has been issued a license under this
chapter, shall sell, offer or expose for sale, or solicit anyone to purchase
any property, goods, merchandise, food or services of any kind within the
following areas:
      1.   The area in the vicinity of the Allstate Arena bounded on the east
by Mannheim Road, on the north by Touhy Avenue, on the west by Barry Street
extended to Higgins Road, and on the south by Higgins Road;
      2.   The area in the vicinity of the Donald E. Stephens Convention Center
bounded on the west by River Road, on the north by the Kennedy Expressway, on
the east by the Des Plaines River, and on the south by the northern boundary
line of Balmoral Avenue extended to the Des Plaines River; or
      3.   The area in the vicinity of the Rosemont Theater and the Rosemont
Entertainment District bounded on the west by the Tri-State Tollway, on the
north by Bryn Mawr Avenue extended from River Road Tri-State Tollway, on the
east by River Road, and on the south by Foster Avenue and the Village corporate
limits.
   B.   The aforementioned prohibited boundaries apply unless such person has
been properly authorized by the owner of the premises on which the person is
located to sell, offer, expose for sale, or solicit the purchase of any
property, goods, merchandise, food or services.
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
4-9-2-7: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE; HEARING:
   A.   Provided, that the solicitor or peddler has been given prior notice and
an opportunity to respond to the charges of a violation, the Superintendent may
suspend or revoke a license for violation of any provisions of this chapter. If
the Superintendent suspends or revokes such license, the solicitor or peddler
may, within five (5) days after notice of the revocation or suspension, request
an informal hearing to review the suspension or revocation by written notice to
the Superintendent.
   B.   At the hearing, the aggrieved licensee may be represented by counsel
with the right to confront and cross examine the witness(es) against him. The
Superintendent shall appoint a hearing officer to determine whether substantial
evidence supports the suspension or revocation, and whether the suspension or
revocation is contrary to the manifest weight of the evidence. Strict rules of
evidence shall not apply. The decision of the hearing officer shall be final.
   C.   Within ten (10) days of the conclusion of the hearing, the findings and
order of the hearing officer shall be sent to the licensee at the address
listed on the applicant’s application by personal service, by certified mail,
return receipt requested, by electronic mail, or by first class United States
mail to the licensee’s attorney, if any.
(Ord. 20I2-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
4-9-3: NONCOMMERCIAL SOLICITORS:
No application or license fee shall be required for any person who intends to
engage in noncommercial solicitation in the Village. Any person desiring to
engage in noncommercial solicitation with the Village shall provide the
following information for identification purposes only upon registering with
the department, or upon request by a public safety officer of the department:
   A.   The full name, date of birth (if a person), mailing address and
telephone number of the person or organization, if any, sponsoring, promoting,
or conducting the proposed activities.
   B.   The full name, date of birth, mailing address, and telephone number of
the individual person or persons who have supervision of or responsibility for
the proposed activities.
