   C.   The full name, date of birth, mailing address and telephone number of
the individual person or persons who will be engaged in the proposed
activities, and color photographs of such person(s).
   D.   The date or dates on which the solicitation is proposed to occur, and
the hours during which the solicitation will begin and end, within the limits
established in this chapter.
   E.   Evidence that the applicant is authorized to solicit for the
organization represented.
   F.   The number and description of all vehicles that will be used.
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
4-9-4: RESTRICTIONS APPLICABLE TO ALL PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to engage in
solicitation or peddling at any time prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A. M. or
after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. local time.
   B.   Uninvited Peddling Or Soliciting:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in solicitation or
peddling upon the premises of any dwelling, house, apartment, or other
residential premises, or upon any commercial, institutional or industrial
premises, after having been asked by the owner or lawful occupant thereof to
leave such premises.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in solicitation or
peddling upon the premises of any dwelling, house, apartment, or other
residence located thereon if such premises or residence is posted against
solicitation or peddling by means of a prominently displayed notice as defined
in subsection 4-9-5A of this chapter.
   C.   False Statements Or Information:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person who engages in solicitation or
peddling to use any false plan, scheme, or ruse, or to make any false statement
which indicates or implies that the purpose of such person’s visit is other
than to obtain contributions or orders for sale of goods or services.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person who engages in solicitation or
peddling to misrepresent the right of a buyer to rescind or cancel a sale under
the provisions of applicable law.
   D.   Presenting Items Not Specified In License: It shall be unlawful for any
person who engages in solicitation or peddling to barter, sell, or peddle any
goods, merchandise, or wares other than those specified in his application for
a license.
   E.   Interfering With Traffic: It is unlawful and a violation of this
chapter for any solicitor or peddler to interfere with either vehicular or
pedestrian traffic on the public right-of-way.
   F.   Sound Amplification: It is unlawful and a violation of this chapter for
any solicitor or peddler to use sound or voice amplification systems or other
mechanical sound devices in any solicitation or peddling.
   G.   Identification:
      1.   Each solicitor and peddler licensee shall wear an identification
badge on his outer garments so as to be visible at all times, which badge shall
be issued by the department, and which shall contain, in a form authorized by
the department, the following:
         a.   Name of the licensee;
         b.   Name of the group or organization, if any, on whose behalf the
licensee is conducting regulated activities;
         c.   The issuance and expiration date of the license.
      2.   Each noncommercial solicitor shall bear a government issued photo ID
at all times that he is engaged in soliciting and shall display such ID upon
request to any Village public safety officer, and to any person being solicited
by the solicitor.
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
4-9-5: PROHIBITED PEDDLING AND SOLICITING:
   A.   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to
engage in solicitation or peddling upon the premises of any dwelling or
residence located thereon if such dwelling or residence premises is posted
against solicitation or peddling by means of a notice prominently displaying a
message in substantially the following terms:
   ONLY SOLICITORS OR PEDDLERS
   LICENSED OR REGISTERED IN ROSEMONT INVITED
   or
   NO SOLICITORS OR PEDDLERS
   B.   Any landowner or lawful resident upon the premises desiring to take
advantage of this section may obtain such decals at the Village Hall. Such
decal shall then be prominently displayed on the front door or window where it
can be readily seen from the public sidewalk or other entryway in front of the
premises.
   C.   Any peddler or solicitor entering any premises so posted with a sign or
decal shall be guilty of violating this section and may be prosecuted
accordingly.
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
4-9-6: CHARITABLE HIGHWAY SOLICITATIONS:
   A.   Permit And Compliance Required: It shall be unlawful for any person,
firm, or corporation to go upon any public street within the Village boundaries
for the purpose of soliciting from motorists or others using any public street;
provided, however, charitable solicitation may be permitted on public streets
in accordance with the provisions of this section when a permit has been
issued, and in accordance with the conditions stated in the permit.
   B.   Eligibility For Permit:
      1.   Charitable solicitation permits under this section shall be issued
only to a soliciting agency that is a bona fide religious, charitable, labor,
fraternal, educational, or veterans’ organization that operates without profit
to its members and which has been in existence continuously for a period of
five (5) years immediately before making application for a permit and which has
had, during that entire five (5) year period, a bona fide membership engaged in
carrying out their objectives.
      2.   No soliciting agency is eligible for a permit under this section
unless it is registered with the Illinois Attorney General as required under
section 11-1006 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-1006).
   C.   Application For Permit:
      1.   Any eligible organization seeking to conduct charitable
solicitations on public streets shall file an application with the department
in the same calendar year as, and not less than thirty (30) days before, the
date that the solicitation is proposed to occur.
      2.   The application shall contain the following information, which must
be updated by the applicant as circumstances warrant:
         a.   The name, address, and telephone number of the person signing the
application.
         b.   The date(s) of the proposed charitable solicitation.
         c.   The public streets and directions of travel on which the
charitable solicitation is proposed to occur.
         d.   The approximate number of people who will participate in the
charitable solicitation.
         e.   The name, address, and telephone number of all persons who will
participate as street solicitors.
         f.   Proof of registration as a charitable organization with the
Illinois Attorney General.
      3.   Except as hereafter provided, all applications for a charitable
solicitation permit shall be processed on a first-in-time basis. During the
final business day of each calendar year, the Public Safety Department shall
accept all applications for a charitable solicitation permit filed hereunder
without giving priority to applications filed first in time. Any conflict
between or among two (2) or more such applicants filed during that period for
the same day(s) shall be resolved by a lottery to be conducted by the Chief.
Applications for charitable solicitation permits received during the first
business day of the calendar year shall be given priority over applications
received thereafter.
   D.   Number Of Permits Limited; Days And Hours: The number of charitable
solicitation permits for use of public streets shall be limited to thirty six
(36) permits annually. Each permit shall be valid only for one period of three
(3) consecutive days during the course of one calendar year. The permit shall
only be valid during daylight hours on the dates specified and for the public
street locations identified in the permit. No charitable organization shall be
issued more than one charitable solicitation permit in any calendar year.
   E.   Regulations:
      1.   Location Under Construction: No solicitation shall be permitted at
any time at a specific location if the adjacent right-of-way or the roadway is
under construction.
      2.   Minimum Age; High Visibility Vest: Any person engaged in the act of
solicitation shall be eighteen (18) years of age or more and shall be wearing a
high visibility orange or lime green high visibility vest.
      3.   Obstructing Traffic Prohibited: In no event shall solicitors
obstruct or impede the flow of traffic on the roadway.
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 F of this Code for permit fee
4-9-7: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, or corporation violating an of the provisions of this chapter
shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs.
(Ord. 2012-8-8J, 8-8-2012)
CHAPTER 10: FIREARMS DEALERS
Section
4-10-1:   Definitions
4-10-2:   Sales, Purchases, Trading At Other Than Gun Shows Prohibited
4-10-3:   Gun Show Permit Requirements
4-10-4:   Firearms And Ammunition At Gun Shows
4-10-5:   Violations
4-10-6:   Revocation Of Permit
4-10-7:   Penalties
4-10-8:   Cook County Regulations Do Not Apply
4-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
ATF: Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, and any
successor agency.
ANTIQUE FIREARM:
   A.   Any firearm, including any firearm with a matchlock; flintlock,
percussion cap or similar type of ignition system, manufactured in or before
1898; and
   B.   Any replica of any firearm described in subsection A of this definition
if such replica is not designed or redesigned for using rimfire or conventional
centerfire fixed ammunition, or uses rimfire or conventional centerfire fixed
ammunition which is no longer manufactured in the United States and which is
not readily available in the ordinary channels of commercial trade.
DEADLY WEAPONS: Any bowie knife, dirk or other weapon of like character which
can be concealed upon the person.
ENGAGE IN THE BUSINESS: A person, firm or entity who devotes time, attention
and labor to selling, trading, bartering or otherwise dealing in firearms as a
regular course of trade or business with the principal objective of profiting
from the repetitive purchase, acquisition, sale and resale of firearms, but
such term shall not include a person who makes occasional sales, exchanges or
purchases of not more than one firearm a month for the enhancement of a
personal collection, or for a hobby, without a view to profit.
FOID: A valid firearm owner’s identification card issued to a private citizen
by the Illinois State Police.
FIREARM: Any pistol, revolver, rifle, shotgun, machine gun, assault weapon or
other device that fits within the definition of “firearm” contained in the
Illinois Firearm Owner’s Identification Card Act (430 ILCS 65/0.01 et seq.).
GUN SHOW: An event or function that is sponsored by any national, State or
local organization devoted to the collection, competitive use or other sporting
use of firearms, or by an organization or association that sponsors functions
devoted to the collection, competitive use or other sporting use of firearms,
and that is conducted on exposition property owned by the Village.
(Ord. 2012-10-10L, 10-10-2012)
4-10-2: SALES, PURCHASES, TRADING AT OTHER THAN GUN SHOWS PROHIBITED:
No person shall engage in the business of selling, dealing, bartering,
purchasing or trading firearms anywhere within the Village, except at gun shows
conducted on exposition premises owned by the Village, and pursuant to a permit
issued under this chapter by the Chief of Public Safety.
(Ord. 2012-10-10L, 10-10-2012)
4-10-3: GUN SHOW PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or entity
required to be licensed under Federal law to engage in the business of dealing,
selling, bartering, trading, giving away or otherwise transferring any firearm
to engage in the business anywhere in the Village of dealing, selling,
purchasing, bartering, trading, giving away or otherwise transferring any
firearm, except at a gun show as authorized in this chapter and only pursuant
to a permit issued by the Chief of Public Safety.
   B.   Application For Permit: Any person desiring a permit authorizing the
sale of any firearms or deadly weapons at a gun show shall make application in
writing to the Chief of Public Safety, on a form to be provided by the Chief,
setting out the following information:
      1.   The full name and residence of the applicant, if the applicant is an
individual. If applicant is a firm, corporation, partnership or other entity,
the name and address of the applicant, the legal nature of applicant’s firm,
corporation, partnership or other entity, the nature and location of
applicant’s business, and the name and residence of each of applicant’s
officers, members, partners and persons or entities having a five percent (5%)
or more ownership or income interest in the entity.
      2.   The date, time and place of the gun show for which the applicant is
requesting a permit.
      3.   Evidence that the sponsor of the gun show has invited the applicant
to participate.
      4.   Evidence that the applicant possesses a Federal firearms dealer
license.
      5.   Evidence that the gun show has been reported to and recognized by
the Illinois Department of State Police.
      6.   A statement that the applicant will comply with all Federal, State
and Village regulations concerning the acquisition and disposition of firearms
including, but not limited to, gun show rules established by ATF.
      7.   A statement that the applicant has performed a background check to
determine that all employees who will be involved in the transfer, sale,
handling, assembly, shipping, packing, receiving or display or demonstration of
firearms at a gun show would be qualified to obtain a FOID.
   C.   Permit Fee: The fee for a gun show permit shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00).
   D.   Restrictions On Issuance: No permit shall be issued to a firearms
dealer to participate in a gun show unless the applicant presents sufficient
evidence to the Chief of Public Safety demonstrating:
      1.   The applicant possesses a Federal firearms dealer license.
      2.   The applicant has arranged to have appropriate security present
throughout the duration of the gun show.
      3.   The gun show has been reported to and recognized by the Illinois
Department of State Police.
      4.   The gun show shall be held for no more than five (5) consecutive
days.
      5.   The applicant will not engage in bartering or trading firearms at
the gun show with delivery occurring anywhere in the Village.
      6.   All firearms displayed at the gun show shall be secured and rendered
safe and unfireable through the use of a plastic cable tie or other lockable
mechanical device.
      7.   All firearms not currently being displayed at the gun show shall be
secured in locked containers.
      8.   Ammunition at the gun show shall be secured in the following
fashion:
         a.   Modern boxed ammunition shall be taped or sealed at both ends.
         b.   Vintage or collectible ammunition must be in sealed plastic bags
or in a locked glass case.
         c.   Except for law enforcement officers, no firearm may contain
ammunition.
         d.   May be contained in a firearm, magazine or clip.
      9.   The applicant will comply with all recordkeeping requirements
concerning the acquisition and disposition of firearms.
      10.   The applicant shall submit an application for a gun show permit in
writing to the Chief of Public Safety on a form provided for that purpose.
(Ord. 2012-10-10L, 10-10-2012)
4-10-4: FIREARMS AND AMMUNITION AT GUN SHOWS:
   A.   Except for law enforcement officers, no persons except firearms dealers
possessing a gun show permit may bring, carry or transport firearms or
ammunition into a gun show.
   B.   All firearms sold or transferred during a gun show may only be
delivered in a safe and unfireable condition.
   C.   Firearms which are physically transferred to a buyer during the gun
show on the premises of the exposition center shall be maintained in a safe and
unfireable condition by the buyer at all times while on the premises of the
exposition center.
   D.   Before transferring possession of any firearm pursuant to a sale
occurring at a gun show, any firearms dealer possessing a permit from the Chief
of Public Safety to engage in the sale of firearms at a gun show shall obtain
any information required by law for each firearm sought to be sold or
transferred, and shall provide such information to the Chief of Public Safety
at the end of each day during the conduct of the gun show. If the purchaser is
a resident of the State of Illinois, a photocopy of the purchaser’s firearm
owner’s identification card shall also be provided. The information provided to
the Chief of Public Safety shall include the following information with respect
to firearms sold or transferred during a gun show:
      1.   FOID card number.
      2.   Weapon number.
      3.   Name of purchaser.
      4.   Address of purchaser.
      5.   Age of purchaser.
      6.   Kind or description of firearm.
      7.   For what purpose purchased.
      8.   Price.
(Ord. 2012-10-10L, 10-10-2012)
4-10-5: VIOLATIONS:
It shall be a violation of this chapter for a firearms dealer to:
   A.   Fail to display a valid Federal firearms license.
   B.   Fail to comply with all State and Federal recordkeeping requirements
concerning the acquisition or disposition of firearms.
   C.   Barter or trade firearms during a gun show with delivery to occur
anywhere in the Village.
   D.   Transfer, acquire or dispose of firearms within the Village except as
authorized by a gun show permit.
   E.   Fail to secure firearms displayed during a gun show by rendering them
safe and unfireable through the use of a plastic cable tie or other lockable
mechanical device.
   F.   Fail to keep any firearms in a locked container during the time that
they are not being displayed during a gun show.
   G.   Fail to require a private citizen to display a FOID card prior to
allowing the buyer to handle a firearm.
   H.   Fail to provide the Chief of Public Safety with information required by
law for each firearm sought to be sold or transferred at the end of each day
during a gun show.
   I.   Violate the exposition center rules governing conduct of the gun show.
(Ord. 2012-10-10L, 10-10-2012)
4-10-6: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
The Chief of Public Safety may revoke a gun show permit for any violation of
this chapter.
(Ord. 2012-10-10L, 10-10-2012)
4-10-7: PENALTIES:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to
immediate revocation of the person’s gun show permit and/or a fine of not less
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and not more than two thousand dollars
($2,000.00) for each offense. Every purchase, sale or gift of any weapon
mentioned in this chapter shall be deemed as a separate offense.
(Ord. 2012-10-10L, 10-10-2012)
4-10-8: COOK COUNTY REGULATIONS DO NOT APPLY:
Articles I through IV, inclusive, of the Cook County deadly weapons dealer
control ordinance shall not apply within the corporate limits of the Village.
(Ord. 2012-10-10L, 10-10-2012)
CHAPTER 11: CONTRACTORS
ARTICLE A: BUILDING TRADE CONTRACTORS
Section
4-11A-1:   License Required
4-11A-2:   Application For License; Ineligibility
4-11A-3:   License Fee
4-11A-4:   Bond Requirements
4-11A-5:   Term Of License; Expiration
4-11A-6:   Nontransferability Of License
4-11A-7:   Exemptions From Provisions
4-11A-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Except as set forth in section 4-11A-7 of this chapter, no person, firm or
corporation shall engage in, conduct or carry on the business of any
construction work, or any building or structure remodeling or rehabilitation
work including, but not limited to carpentry, roofing, and heating,
ventilating, air conditioning and electrical work, including installing or
altering electrical equipment without first obtaining a building trade license
issued by the Health and Licensing Department of the Village.
(Ord. 2003-12-3G, 12-3-2003)
4-11A-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INELIGIBILITY:
Each application for a building trade license shall state: a) the name,
address, and telephone number of the applicant; and b) whether the applicant
has been issued any business or professional licenses by an agency of the State
of Illinois and/or by any other unit of local government and shall contain any
other information requested by the Village Director of Building and Code
Enforcement and the Director of the Health and Licensing Department. No license
shall be issued to an applicant unless the applicant demonstrates that he is in
full compliance with any and all applicable licensing requirements of the State
of Illinois and any other governmental body which has jurisdiction over work
being performed by the applicant within the Village.
(Ord. 93-4-7K, 4-7-1993)
4-11A-3: LICENSE FEE:
The fee for each building trade license issued to a licensee who performs work
or provides services in the Village shall be as set forth in the Village Fee
Schedule, subsection 3-10-1B of this Code.
(Ord. 2003-12-3G, 12-3-2003; amd. 2019 Code)
4-11A-4: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
No person, firm or corporation required to have a building trade license under
the provisions of section
4-11A-1 of this article shall perform any construction work or any building or
structure remodeling or rehabilitation work where the cost of such work exceeds
one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00), unless and until such person,
firm or corporation has filed with the Village a surety bond in the amount of
ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) issued by a surety company authorized to do
business in the State of Illinois, which is conditioned for the payment of any
loss, damage or injury resulting to persons or property for the performance of
construction, or building, remodeling, or rehabilitation work by the person,
firm or corporation or the failure of the person, firm or corporation to either
complete such work in a timely manner or in compliance with all applicable
codes, rules and regulations. The form of the bond shall be subject to the
approval of the Village.
(Ord. 93-5-5J, 5-5-1993)
4-11A-5: TERM OF LICENSE; EXPIRATION:
No building trade license shall be granted for a period longer than one year,
and every license shall expire on the December 31 following the date of its
issuance.
(Ord. 2003-12-3G, 12-3-2003)
4-11A-6: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE:
A building trade license is nontransferable.
(Ord. 93-4-7K, 4-7-1993)
4-11A-7: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this article including, but not limited to, the requirement
that a business trade license be obtained, shall not apply to the following:
(Ord. 2003-12-3G, 12-3-2003)
   A.   Plumbers and plumbing contractors, as defined in section 2 of the
Illinois Plumbing Licensing Law (225 ILCS 320/2).
(Ord. 2003-12-3G, 12-3-2003; amd. 2019 Code)
   B.   Electrical contractors as defined in section 11-33-1 of the Illinois
Municipal Code who have registered with or who are licensed by another
municipality.
   C.   Land surveyors.
   D.   Architects licensed by the State of Illinois.
   E.   Engineers licensed by the State of Illinois.
(Ord. 2003-12-3G, 12-3-2003)
   F.   Locksmiths and private alarm contractors, as defined in section 5-10 of
the Illinois Private Detective, Private Alarm, Private Security, Fingerprint,
Vendor and Locksmith Act of 2004 (225 ILCS 447/5-10).
(Ord. 2003-12-3G, 12-3-2003; amd. 2019 Code)
   G.   Water well pump installation contractors and water well and pump
installation contractors as defined in section 2 of the Illinois Water Well and
Pump Installation Contractors License Act (225 ILCS 345/2).
(Ord. 2003-12-3G,12-3-2003)
CHAPTER 12: EXTERMINATORS
Section
4-12-1:   Definition
4-12-2:   License Required
4-12-3:   Application For License; Qualifications Of Applicant
4-12-4:   Investigation Of Applicant
4-12-5:   Employee Insurance Required
4-12-6:   Sale Or Providing Hydrocyanic Acid Gas
4-12-7:   Fumigation Procedures
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-12-1: DEFINITION:
The term “extermination by fumigation”, as used in this chapter, is hereby
defined to mean the use of hydrocyanic acid gas, cyanogen, chloropicrin, methyl
bromide, or any other poisonous, noxious, or dangerous gases or fumes specified
by the Health and Licensing Department as liable to affect human beings by
causing severe sickness or death, for the extermination by fumigation of
household insects, vermin, rats, or other household pests in any place in the
Village; provided, however, that it shall not apply to the fumigation of
greenhouses, grain elevators, or cereal or tobacco warehouses.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-12-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of extermination by fumigation without a
license to so do.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-12-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; QUALIFICATIONS OF APPLICANT:
An application for the license shall be made in conformity with the general
requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses. In addition,
the applicant shall file with the Village a sworn statement listing the
training and experience tending to qualify the applicant for the performance of
fumigating with hydrocyanic acid gas and other dangerous and noxious gases. In
the case of firms or corporations, said statement shall cover the training and
experience of the responsible officers.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-12-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall make a thorough
investigation of the training, experience, general qualifications, character,
and reputation of the applicants for licenses to exterminate by fumigation with
poisonous or noxious gases.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-12-5: EMPLOYEE INSURANCE REQUIRED:
The employees of the licensee engaged in fumigation shall be covered by
liability insurance providing for indemnification in case of bodily injury,
sickness, or death, in accordance with the Illinois Workers’ Compensation Act
(820 ILCS 305/1 et seq.).
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-12-6: SALE OR PROVIDING HYDROCYANIC ACID GAS:
No person shall sell or give away material for the purpose of fumigating
premises with hydrocyanic acid gas, except to a person licensed as herein
provided, unless a signed statement in writing is first obtained from the buyer
or recipient of the material to the effect that it will not be used for the
purpose of fumigating any place of domestic habitation or any building or
portion thereof as set forth in this chapter.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-12-7: FUMIGATION PROCEDURES:
   A.   Permit Requirements: It shall be the duty of every person licensed
under this chapter intending to generate or release hydrocyanic acid gas or
other dangerous gases or fumes for fumigation purposes, before starting such
generation or release, to file written notice with the Director of Building and
Code Enforcement, giving the location of the building or enclosed space to be
fumigated, and to secure from the Director a permit, which shall state the day
and hour when the work will be performed. Each application for such permit
shall be accompanied by a fee as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule,
subsection
3-10-1B of this Code. The permit shall be kept on the premises to be fumigated.
The time of the permit may be extended if the applicant is unable to perform
the work on the hour and day set forth in the permit, and so notifies the
Director of Building and Code Enforcement sixteen (16) hours prior to the time
set forth in the permit.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975; amd. 2019 Code)
   B.   Notice To Vacate Premises: When hydrocyanic gas or other dangerous
gases or fumes are used for exterminating purposes, before fumigation, the
operator shall personally inspect the premises, and shall serve notice, over
his signature, upon all responsible occupants of each room or apartment within
the danger area, stating the danger of the process and the precautions to be
observed, designating the rooms or apartments which must be vacated and
indicating the time when the gas is to be generated or liberated. The form of
this notice shall be approved by the Health and Licensing Department. Every
room in the danger area shall be vacated. In the case of a building in which
there is an inner court, vent shaft, or light well, or a lot line court with a
party wall, or in the case of two (2) buildings having adjacent lot line
courts, upon which any room being gassed opens, every room with windows or
other apertures opening to such inner or lot line courts, vent shafts, or light
wells shall be vacated and securely locked. Where the walls of any adjoining
buildings are located within ten feet (10') of the rooms or apartments being
gassed, the operator shall notify, over his signature, all responsible
occupants of rooms or apartments with window openings in such walls, that such
windows as are directly opposite or above the area of the adjoining building
which is under gas, must remain closed, or the rooms vacated during the time
the building gassed is being flushed or aired. All rooms or apartments ordered
vacated, but not under gas, shall be well ventilated during the process by
keeping the windows of the rooms or apartments open. Provided, however, that
such vacation of premises and notification of occupants shall not be necessary
where the fumigation is done in special rooms or vaults in furniture stores,
secondhand stores, or household goods warehouses, or vaults in candy and other
food processing plants, when such special rooms or vaults are approved as to
their location, construction, and gas-tightness by the Health and Licensing
Department and a provision is made for the airing of such vaults so as to allow
the escape of gases at such a location where it is not dangerous by a system of
ducts and ventilation approved by the Health and Licensing Department.
   C.   Rooms Sealed: Before fumigating with hydrocyanic acid gas or other
dangerous gases or fumes, the operator shall securely seal all cracks, holes,
crevices, openings, and apertures in walls, ceilings, and floors in such a way
as to confine the gas to the premises intended to be fumigated.
   D.   Inspection Of Rooms And Apartments; Locking And Placarding Required:
Before fumigation, the operator shall personally inspect all rooms and
apartments ordered vacated under subsection C of this section, and be assured
that they are unoccupied by persons or domestic animals, after which all doors
to all rooms or apartments, excepting one exit door to the rooms or apartments
to be gassed, shall be securely locked. In addition, such windows or other wall
openings as might possibly be used to gain entrance shall be locked or barred
in such a way as to prevent entrance while still permitting thorough airing of
the room. Immediately upon generating or liberating the gas, the door through
which the operator leaves shall be securely locked and sealed, and all keys
obtainable to all rooms or apartments ordered vacated shall be retained by the
operator until all danger is passed. As an additional precaution, all rooms and
apartments vacated shall be placarded.
   E.   Guards: Whenever hydrocyanic acid or other dangerous gases or fumes are
generated or liberated in any room or portion of a structure in the Village, a
sufficient number of capable, alert watchmen shall remain on duty at the
entrance or entrances to the room, building, or enclosed space vacated for
gassing, to prevent people from entering while gas is present and for two (2)
hours after the room or area gassed is open for airing.
   F.   Removal Of Food:
      1.   Before fumigation, the operator shall see that all ice, food and
drink are removed from the rooms ordered vacated; except, that such food or
drink, as is in sealed airtight containers need not be removed. Provided, that
in industrial fumigations such as flour mills, cereal mills, food warehouses,
macaroni plants, candy manufacturing plants, cheese processing plants, etc.,
where fumigation is for the purpose of destroying vermin or insect pests
infesting these foodstuffs, only liquid fats, oils and moist foodstuffs not
sealed in airtight containers need be removed. The fumigator shall state in the
application for a permit to fumigate foodstuffs the amount of moisture content
of the various foods it is wished to fumigate. No fumigated food shall be sold
or shipped until it has been aerated by every reasonable means, including the
use of fans wherever indicated, for a period not less than thirty six (36)
hours following fumigation and suitable tests approved by the Health and
Licensing Department of the air immediately around it are negative for the
fumigant used.
      2.   An impermeable receptacle for containing the ingredients is required
in fumigating with hydrocyanic acid or other dangerous gases.
   G.   Spilling Cyanide: No cyanic crystals shall be dropped on the floor or
left exposed where people or domestic animals may come in contact with them in
fumigating with hydrocyanic acid or other dangerous gases.
   H.   Opening Rooms After Fumigation:
      1.   At the conclusion of the gassing process in fumigation, it shall be
the duty of the operator to throw open doors and windows of the premises, until
all rooms have been opened for free access of air.
      2.   No person other than the operator shall be permitted to enter the
premises until all traces of the gas have disappeared, and in no case shall the
occupants of the rooms or areas gassed be permitted to enter until twelve (12)
hours after airing.
      3.   The operator or watchmen shall keep all persons away from the doors
and windows of the premises for two (2) hours after airing. Infants and
children under six (6) years of age shall not be permitted to re-enter the
premises until eighteen (18) hours after the rooms or apartments are opened for
airing. The licensee shall inform all occupants having children of this
provision in writing over his signature.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 13: WASTE DISPOSAL AND INCINERATOR BUSINESS
Section
4-13-1:   Application For License
4-13-2:   Bond Requirements
4-13-3:   Inspections
4-13-4:   License Required
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-13-1: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a waste disposal and incinerator business license shall be made
in conformance with the general requirements of this title pertaining to
applications for licenses.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-13-2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Before obtaining the license required by this chapter, the applicant shall
execute a bond to the Village in an amount as required by the Village, with
surety to be approved by the Village President and Board of Trustees,
conditioned that the licensee will comply with this Code, the ordinances and
the regulations of the Village and the laws of the State of Illinois.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-13-3: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the Health and Licensing Department to periodically,
and at least annually, inspect all establishments licensed under this chapter
to ensure that no danger of fire exists, that sanitary conditions are
maintained, that all applicable pollution standards are being satisfied, and
that all other provisions of this Code and State law are satisfied.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-13-4: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of waste disposal and incinerator,
without first obtaining a license for such business as provided in this
chapter.
CHAPTER 14:  AUCTIONEERS
Section
4-14-1:   Definition
4-14-2:   License Required
4-14-3:   Single Location
4-14-4:   Daily License
4-14-5:   Terms Of Sales
4-14-6:   Right Of Return
4-14-7:   Prohibited Acts
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-14-1: DEFINITION:
The term “auctioneer”, as used in this chapter, shall mean any person who sells
real or personal property at public or private auction for another or for
himself. Any person who sells his own real or personal property at a public or
private auction is an “auctioneer”.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-14-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall sell or attempt to sell at public or private auction any real
or personal property of any kind whatsoever (except under and by virtue of
legal process or under and by virtue of a mortgage) without first having
obtained a license as an auctioneer.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-14-3: SINGLE LOCATION:
No licensed auctioneer shall sell or offer for sale at public auction any real
or personal property at or in any place, house, store, or building other than
the place, house, store, or building designated in his license, except as
provided in section
4-14-4 of this chapter.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-14-4: DAILY LICENSE:
Licensed auctioneers may obtain daily licenses to conduct auctions at locations
other than the premises licensed under their annual license when the goods to
be auctioned are owned by the owner or occupant of the premises where the
auction will be held. A daily auction license shall not be issued for the same
premises for more than seven (7) days in any one calendar year.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-14-5: TERMS OF SALES:
It shall be the duty of every auctioneer, before beginning any auction sale of
real or personal property of any kind whatsoever, to state fully the terms and
conditions upon which the sale will be made and to announce to the persons
present the character, quality, and description of the property offered for
sale.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-14-6: RIGHT OF RETURN:
The purchaser at an auction sale of any watch, plate or jewelry shall have the
right to return it to the auctioneer at any time within five (5) days from the
day of sale if the watch, plate or jewelry is not of the quality represented to
him, and the auctioneer shall return to the purchaser the price of the article.
No auctioneer shall close his office at any time for the purpose of avoiding an
offer to return any such article so sold, and the violation of this provision
shall be cause for the revocation of the license of the auctioneer.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-14-7: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   False Representations: No auctioneer or person being present when any
real or personal property is offered for sale shall knowingly, with intent to
induce any person to purchase the same or any part thereof, make any false
representation or statement as to the ownership of, or the character or quality
of, the property so offered for sale, or as to the poverty or circumstances of
the owner or pretended owner of such property; and if such false representation
is made by the auctioneer or by any other person with such auctioneer’s
knowledge and consent or connivance, the license of such auctioneer shall be
revoked.
   B.   Substitutions: No auctioneer shall exhibit and offer for sale at
auction any article, and induce its purchase by any bidder, and then afterward
substitute any article in lieu of that offered to and purchased by the bidder.
   C.   Fictitious Bidding: Any auctioneer who shall procure any person to make
a fictitious bid at any auction sale of real or personal property, or who shall
conspire with any person to make a fictitious bid at any such auction sale, or
any auctioneer who shall himself fictitiously raise any bids in any such
auction sale shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
nor more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the first offense, and shall,
on conviction thereof for a second or subsequent offense, be fined the sum of
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for such offense, and upon conviction for
such second offense, the license of such auctioneer shall be revoked.
   D.   Sales On Public Ways: No real or personal property shall be sold at
auction, or exposed for sale, by any auctioneer in any public way or public
place in the Village.
   E.   Attracting Attention: No bellman or crier, nor any drum, fife, or other
instrument of music, nor any show signal or other means of attracting the
attention of the public, other than a sign or flag, shall be employed or
permitted to be used in connection with any auction sale at or near any place
of such sale or at or near any auction room.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 15: MOTOR VEHICLE AND TRAVEL RELATED BUSINESSES
ARTICLE A: MOTOR VEHICLE SALES, REPAIR, WASHING
AND PARTS SALES
Section
4-15A-1:   Definitions
4-15A-2:   License Required
4-15A-3:   Application For License
4-15A-4:   Maintenance Of Business
4-15A-5:   Additional Regulations For Repair Shops And Miscellaneous Businesses
4-15A-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
MOTOR VEHICLE: All species of self-propelled vehicles operated by gasoline or
any kind of oil, steam, electricity, alcohol or other substance or method that
are operated on the public ways of the Village, otherwise than on rails.
MOTOR VEHICLE PARTS SHOP: Any business conducted in the Village in which new or
used parts and accessories for motor vehicles are sold or offered for sale at
retail or wholesale.
MOTOR VEHICLE REPAIR SHOP. Any building, structure, premises, enclosure or
other place in the Village where the business of repairing motor vehicles or
any component part thereof, or the business of replacing parts or adding parts
to motor vehicles; or the business of greasing, painting, or refinishing motor
vehicles is conducted or operated.
MOTOR VEHICLE SALES DEALERSHIP. Any business conducted in the Village in which
new or used motor vehicles are sold or offered for sale at wholesale or retail.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate a motor vehicle sales dealership, a motor vehicle
repair shop, or motor vehicle parts shop in the Village without first having
obtained a license therefor.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a license under this article shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this title relating to the issuance of
licenses. Any establishment in the Village which conducts two (2) or more of
the businesses which require a license under this article shall be required to
obtain only one license and shall pay the highest license fee of those
applicable (see subsection 3-10-1B of this Code for license fees).
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15A-4: MAINTENANCE OF BUSINESS:
   A.   No person who is the owner, proprietor, lessee, manager or
superintendent of any sales room, shop, garage or other place where persons are
employed for wages in and about motor vehicles shall cause, permit or allow the
same or any portion of such salesroom, shop, garage or other place to be
overcrowded, crowded or inadequate, faulty or insufficient in respect to light,
ventilation, heat and cleanliness. Fresh air shall be supplied by ventilation
in accordance with the building regulations of this Code.
   B.   All such places of employment or service shall be kept in a clean
condition, free from the effluvia of a sewer, drain, or other nuisance; also,
free as far as practicable from all gases, vapors, dust or other impurities
generated by manufacturing processes or the operation of motors or other
machinery, or otherwise, which are injurious to health.
   C.   Sufficient and separate water closets shall be provided for male and
female employees, and such water closet compartments shall be properly
ventilated.
   D.   Lockers for employee clothing shall be of metal.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15A-5: ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS FOR REPAIR SHOPS AND MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESSES:
   A.   Location Restrictions:
      1.   No person shall locate, build, construct or maintain any motor
vehicle repair shop within two hundred feet (200') of any building used for and
as a hospital, church, or school, or the grounds thereof, or locate, build,
construct or maintain any repair shop in the Village in any block in which two-
thirds (2/3) of the buildings on both sides of the street are used exclusively
for residence purposes, or within one hundred feet (100') of any such block,
without the written consent of the majority of the property owners, according
to the frontage on both sides of the street.
      2.   Written consent shall be obtained and filed with the Director of the
Health and Licensing Department before any license shall be issued; provided,
however, that in determining whether two-thirds (2/3) of the buildings on both
sides of the street are used exclusively for residence purposes, and any
building fronting upon another street and located upon a corner shall not be
considered.
      3.   The word “block”, as used in this subsection, shall not be held to
mean a square, but to embrace only that part of the street in question which
lies between the two (2) nearest intersecting streets, one on either side of
the lot on which such repair shop is to be located, built, constructed or
maintained.
   B.   Building And Fire Regulations: The construction of motor vehicle repair
shops shall be made and maintained in accordance with the building regulations
of this Code; shall be kept clean and free from flammable wastes; and shall be
conducted and operated in accordance with the fire regulations of this Code.
   C.   Changing Vehicle Identification Marks: It shall be unlawful for any
person to change the identification marks on the engine of any car or
automobile in any motor vehicle repair shop. It shall also be unlawful to
change the license tags on such cars except in accordance with the register of
motor vehicles kept by the Secretary of State of Illinois.
   D.   Inspections: The Department of Public Safety and Building and Code
Enforcement Department shall inspect or cause to be inspected, as often as they
deem necessary, every motor vehicle repair shop in the Village to determine
whether there is compliance with all applicable provisions of this Code.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
ARTICLE B: CAR WASHES
Section
4-15B-1:   Definition
4-15B-2:   License Required
4-15B-3:   Building, Electrical And Fire Regulations
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-15B-1: DEFINITION:
The term “car wash”, as used/in this article, means the carrying on of the
business of washing, polishing or cleaning motor vehicles or trailers for a fee
or charge or other consideration, within a building or structure, except where
such cleaning or washing is incidental to the operation of a garage or filling
station.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15B-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation shall operate a car wash without first having
obtained a license therefor.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15B-3: BUILDING, ELECTRICAL AND FIRE REGULATIONS:
   A.   The construction of car washes and car washing equipment shall conform
to the Building, Electrical and Fire Codes of the Village.
   B.   Gasoline, benzine, naphtha and similar flammable liquids shall not be
used for washing and cleaning purposes.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
ARTICLE C: PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLES
Section
4-15C-1:   Definitions
4-15C-2:   Service Regulations Generally
4-15C-3:   Enforcement Officials; Powers And Duties
4-15C-4:   Licenses Required; Exemption And Term
4-15C-5:   Applications For Taxicab Operator And Livery Service Licenses
Operator Licenses
4-15C-6:   Public Convenience And Necessity For Taxicab Service
4-15C-7:   Taxicab Service And Livery Service
4-15C-8:   Vehicle Regulations
4-15C-8-1:   Taxicab Vehicles
4-15C-8-2:   Livery Vehicles
4-15C-8-3:   Age, Condition And Type Of Vehicles
4-15C-9:   Chauffeurs
4-15C-9-1:   Licensing Provisions
4-15C-9-2:   Random Controlled Substance Testing Of Licensees

4-15C-11:   Taxicab Stands
4-15C-12:   Taximeters

4-15C-16:   Immediate Removal From Service
4-15C-17:   Recordkeeping
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code, entry reading “taxicabs and limousines”, entry reading
“chauffeur’s license”, for license fees
4-15C-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
LICENSE YEAR: December 1 through November 30 of each year.
LIVERY OPERATOR’S LICENSE: A license issued to the owner of a livery service
that is eligible to operate livery vehicles or limousines in the Village.
LIVERY VEHICLE: Any public passenger vehicle transporting passengers for hire
on a pre-arranged contract, trip, or hourly basis. Also referred to as
“limousine”.
LIVERY VEHICLE LICENSE: A license issued for a public passenger vehicle which
allows the vehicle to be operated as a limousine within the Village.
OWNER: Any person having the use or control of one or more taxicabs or livery
vehicles as herein defined.
PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE: Taxicabs and livery vehicles used for transportation
of passengers for hire.
PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE LICENSE: A taxicab vehicle license or a livery vehicle
license which has been issued pursuant to the provisions of this article.
ROSEMONT CHAUFFEUR’S LICENSE OR CHAUFFEUR’S LICENSE: A license which is issued
to an individual and which authorizes the individual to operate a taxicab or
limousine within the Village.
SAFETY INSPECTION STATION: Official State of Illinois testing station or such
other facility designated by the Chief of Public Safety to conduct the safety
inspections required or provided for by this article.
TAXICAB: Any public passenger vehicle equipped with a taximeter and used for
the carriage of passengers for hire to or from destinations as directed by such
passenger(s) and any vehicle registered as a taxicab by the Secretary of State.
A TAXICAB also includes a public passenger vehicle equipped with a taximeter
that also has the ability to use an application-based ride share program to
determine the amount charged.
TAXICAB OPERATOR’S LICENSE: A license issued to the owner of a taxicab service
that is eligible to operate taxicabs in the Village.
TAXICAB VEHICLE LICENSE: A license issued for a public passenger vehicle which
allows the vehicle to be operated as a taxicab within the Village.
TAXIMETER: Any mechanical or electrical device attached to a taxicab which
records and indicates a charge or fare in dollars and cents measured by
distance traveled or waiting time, or both.
TAXIMETER TESTING CENTER: A taximeter service center designated by the Chief of
Public Safety to conduct testing, certification and sealing of taximeters
required by this article.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997; amd. Ord. 2019-12-11, 12-11-2019; Ord. 2022-10-10C,
10-10-2022)
4-15C-2: SERVICE REGULATIONS GENERALLY:
Every public passenger vehicle is required to furnish clean, comfortable, and
safe service. Taxicabs shall provide service at rates not to exceed the rates
established in section
4-15C-13 of this article. Limousines shall provide service at reasonable rates.
All public passenger vehicles shall be operated in accordance with this article
and all other applicable statutes ordinances, codes, rules and regulations.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-3: ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS; POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The licensing of taxicab operators, livery operators and public
passenger vehicles, the examination of applicants for chauffeur’s licenses and
the issuance of chauffeur’s licenses to operate said vehicles shall be under
the control and supervision of the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department. The enforcement of the provisions of this article shall be under
the control and supervision of the Superintendent of Public Safety, including
the making of any vehicle and taximeter inspections required or provided by
this article.
   B.   The Superintendent of Public Safety shall have the power to appoint
such persons as he may deem necessary to enforce the provisions of this article
and to perform any inspections or other duties which are assigned to him by
this article.
   C.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall have the
authority to appoint such persons as he may deem necessary to serve as a
License Officer pursuant to the provisions of this article and to perform the
duties that are under the control and supervision of the Director.
   D.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall have the
authority to establish fees for the licenses to be issued pursuant to this
article and for the inspections that are required or provided for under this
article. The amount of any fee established by the Director shall be equivalent
to or based upon the costs incurred by the Village in enforcing the provisions
of this article including, but not limited to, the costs of issuing licenses
and conducting examinations and inspections.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-4: LICENSES REQUIRED; EXEMPTION AND TERM:
   A.   Taxicab Service: It shall be unlawful for any person to own or operate
a taxicab service within the corporate limits of the Village without having
first obtained a taxicab operator’s license from the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department. Each taxicab operator’s license shall specify the maximum
number of taxicabs that may be operated by the taxicab service. It shall be
unlawful for any person who has been issued a taxicab operator’s license to
operate more taxicabs than the maximum number authorized by the license.
   B.   Livery Service: It shall be unlawful for any person to own or operate a
livery service within the corporate limits of the Village without having first
obtained a livery service operator’s license from the Director of the Health
and Licensing Department.
   C.   Taxicab Vehicle: It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to solicit
business, to accept for transportation any passengers within the Village
boundaries, or to otherwise operate as a taxicab within the Village unless the
vehicle has been issued a valid Village taxicab vehicle license. Any vehicle
which is operated in violation of this subsection shall be subject to immediate
removal from service.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
   D.   Livery Vehicle Registration And License:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to solicit business, or to
accept for transportation any passenger, or otherwise operate as a livery
vehicle within the Village, unless the vehicle has been issued “livery vehicle”
registration plates by the Office of the Secretary of State of the State of
Illinois, which plates have an “LY” suffix as set forth in 92 Illinois
Administrative Code section 1010.430.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to solicit business, or to
accept for transportation any passenger, or otherwise operate as a livery
vehicle within the Village, unless either: the vehicle has been issued a valid
Village livery vehicle license; or b) arrangements for the transportation of
the passenger were made in advance by the passenger or someone acting on his
behalf.
      3.   Any vehicle which is operated in violation of this subsection shall
be subject to immediate removal from service.
(Ord. 98-9-2D, 9-2-1998)
   E.   Exemptions From Provisions:
      1.   The provisions of this article shall not prevent taxicabs licensed
by other municipalities from entering the Village for the purpose depositing
passengers who were legally picked up outside the Village.
      2.   This article shall not prevent limousines licensed by other
municipalities from entering the Village for the purpose depositing passengers
who are legally picked up outside the Village.
      3.   The provisions of this article shall not apply to taxicabs and
limousines which do not stop within the Village for the purpose of picking up
or depositing passengers.
   F.   Chauffeur’s License: Except as provided in subsections D and E of this
section, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate a taxicab or
limousine within the Village unless such person currently holds a valid
Rosemont chauffeur’s license. Any taxicab or limousine which is being operated
by a person who does not hold a valid Rosemont chauffeur’s license shall be
subject to immediate removal from service.
   G.   Term Of License: All licenses provided in this article shall be valid
only for the license year for which or during which the license is issued.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
   H.   Number Of Licenses: There shall be no more than sixty (60) taxicab
licenses issued by the Village. No single license holder shall have more than
thirty (30) licenses. Each holder of more than twenty (20) licenses shall, at
their request, be allowed to have up to five (5) inactive licenses. The holder
of an inactive license shall only be required to pay the license fee for an
inactive license at the time it is activated. Each licensed taxicab shall at
all times be in compliance with all Village regulations and safety requirements
applicable to taxicabs. The annual fee for a taxicab license shall be the fee
set forth in Village’s schedule of fees.
(Ord. 2019-12-11, 12-11-2019)
4-15C-5: APPLICATIONS FOR TAXICAB OPERATOR AND LIVERY SERVICE OPERATOR
LICENSES:
Application for a taxicab operator’s license or a livery service operator’s
license shall be made by the owner upon forms furnished by the Village. Such
application shall contain the full name and address of the licensee. The
Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall not issue a taxicab
operator’s license unless the Village President has determined that the public
safety and convenience requires the operation of the taxicab service to be
licensed.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-6: PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY FOR TAXICAB SERVICE:
   A.   No taxicab operator’s license shall be issued unless the Village
President after a hearing, shall, by resolution, declare that public
convenience and necessity require the proposed service for which application
for a license is made.
   B.   In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the
issuance of taxicab operator’s license, the Village President shall take into
consideration the following:
      1.   Whether the demands of public convenience and necessity require the
proposed or additional service within the Village.
      2.   The financial responsibility of the applicant, kind, number, type of
equipment and color scheme to be used by the applicant.
      3.   The increased traffic congestion which may result.
      4.   Whether the safe use of the streets by vehicular or pedestrian
traffic will be affected by the granting of such additional license.
      5.   Any other relevant facts that the Village President may deem
advisable and necessary.
   C.   No such declaration of public convenience and necessity shall be
necessary for the renewal of a taxicab operator’s license for the maximum
number of vehicles for which the applicant has already received declaration of
public convenience and necessity.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-7: TAXICAB SERVICE AND LIVERY SERVICE:
   A.   Every taxicab service and every livery service which is licensed by the
Village shall operate public passenger vehicles regularly in the Village so as
to meet the public demand for passenger service. Each service shall maintain a
central place of business open twenty four (24) hours a day for receiving calls
and dispatching vehicles.
   B.   Every taxicab service and every livery service which is licensed by the
Village shall answer all calls received for service within the Village as soon
as possible. If service cannot be rendered within a reasonable time, each
service will notify the customer of such and give the reason(s) for the delay.
It shall be unlawful for any taxicab service or livery service which is
licensed by the Village to refuse to accept a request for service anywhere
within the Village at any time vehicles are available to provide the service.
   C.   It is unlawful for any taxicab service or livery service which is
licensed by the Village to knowingly encourage or allow a vehicle to operate as
a taxicab or limousine without having first obtained the appropriate type of
public passenger vehicle license. It is unlawful for any taxicab service or
livery service which is licensed by the Village to knowingly encourage or allow
a person to operate a taxicab or limousine in violation of the provisions of
this article.
   D.   If a taxicab service or a livery service which is licensed by the
Village is completely abandoned for ten (10) consecutive days or more, the
Public Passenger Vehicle Review Board will conduct a hearing after giving five
(5) days’ notice to the owner or operator of such service. After the hearing,
the Review Board shall make a recommendation to the Village President as to
whether the taxicab operator’s or livery service operator’s license should be
revoked.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-8: VEHICLE REGULATIONS:
4-15C-8-1: TAXICAB VEHICLES:
   A.   Licenses And Inspections:
      1.   Application for a taxicab vehicle license shall be made by the owner
of the vehicle upon forms furnished by the Village. Such application shall
identify the vehicle owner and contain a complete description of the vehicle
including make, model, year, color, State registration number, vehicle
identification number, cab company name, and company assigned vehicle number.
Also required are copies of vehicle registration card and documentation
confirming that there has been compliance with the insurance requirements of
section
4-15C-14 of this article.
      2.   No taxicab vehicle license shall be issued for any vehicle that is
not owned or affiliated with a taxicab service which has been licensed by the
Village and for which a declaration of public convenience and service has been
issued.
      3.   No taxicab shall be licensed until it has been thoroughly and
carefully examined at a safety inspection station and found to be in safe
condition for passengers, of good appearance, and well painted.
      4.   Taxicabs shall be subject to re-inspections at any time. All
taxicabs shall be thoroughly inspected no less than two (2) times annually to
determine compliance with subsections B and C of this section. The
Superintendent of Public Safety or his designee shall determine the scope of
each inspection, however, the inspection must include a thorough examination of
the vehicle's electrical system, brakes, transmission, tires, exhaust system
and engine.
      5.   Any time a taxicab is involved in an accident that causes damage
which may affect the safety of prospective passengers, it must be taken out of
service immediately and repaired. Before such vehicle may be returned to
service, it must be re-inspected and certified at a safety inspection station.
      6.   The Superintendent of Public Safety and his designees shall have the
authority to immediately remove from service any taxicab which has been
designated unfit for service or unsafe.
      7.   The Superintendent of Public Safety may require a taxicab to be re-
inspected as a result of a complaint by any person, or if the Superintendent
has reason to believe that the condition of the taxicab may pose a threat to
the safety of its passengers, or has reason to believe that the taxicab is not
in compliance with the provisions of this article.
      8.   Upon passing all test categories at an approved safety testing
station, the taxicab will be issued a safety inspection sticker to indicate
that it has been deemed street worthy. Said sticker must be prominently
displayed in the right lower corner of the vehicle's windshield.
      9.   Any taxicab that does not pass a safety inspection for any reason
shall be immediately put out of service until the taxicab passes the safety
inspection.
      10.   It is unlawful for any taxicab for which a taxicab vehicle license
has been issued by the Village to operate without a valid safety inspection
sticker being displayed in the lower right corner of the vehicle's windshield.
      11.   The Superintendent may conduct unannounced spot checks of the
safety inspection station to ensure compliance with inspection procedures and
requirements. He will also investigate any allegations of misconduct by the
inspection station or its employees. If the inspection station or its employees
are not complying with the requirements of this article, the Superintendent may
suspend or revoke the designation of the inspection station as an authorized
safety inspection station for purposes of this article.
      12.   A taxicab which fails to pass a safety inspection, fails to appear
for a safety inspection when directed to do so or otherwise is in violation of
any provision of this section may be immediately removed from service.
      13.   Safety inspection stickers are not transferable from one vehicle to
another. A safety inspection sticker shall not be affixed to any vehicle other
than the vehicle for which the sticker was originally issued.
      14.   When a taxicab is removed from service by the owner, the taxicab
vehicle license issued to that vehicle must be immediately surrendered to the
Director of the Health and Licensing Department.
      15.   a.   The owner of any vehicle for which a Village taxicab vehicle
license has been issued must keep thorough and complete records relating to the
maintenance of the vehicle and make such records available, upon request, to
the Superintendent of Public Safety or his designee. The maintenance records
shall contain the following information:
            (1)   The type of maintenance work performed.
            (2)   The location where the maintenance work was performed.
            (3)   The date the maintenance work was performed.
            (4)   The mileage of the vehicle when the maintenance work was
performed.
            (5)   The amount paid by the owner for the maintenance work.
         b.   The owner must also maintain for a period of not less than two
(2) years all work orders, receipts and other documents relating to any
maintenance work performed on the vehicle.
   B.   License Sticker And Display:
      1.   A taxicab vehicle license issued by the Village shall be in the form
of an adhesive sticker which shall contain the official license number of the
public passenger vehicle.
      2.   Taxicab vehicle licenses shall be of a distinctly different color
and/or design every year. Taxicab vehicle licenses must be affixed to the lower
right portion of the windshield of the vehicle for which the license has been
issued.
      3.   A taxicab vehicle sticker is not transferable to any vehicle other
than the vehicle for which it has been issued.
   C.   Identification:
      1.   Every taxicab licensed in the Village shall bear on both sides of
the vehicle, in a color contrasting to that of the vehicle itself, the name and
phone number of the company which it serves. The lettering shall be a minimum
of two inches (2") in height and one-fourth inch (1/4") brush stroke.
      2.   The identification number assigned to the taxicab by the company
shall be affixed to the exterior of the vehicle on each front fender and trunk.
These letters must be a minimum of three inches (3") in height and one-fourth
inch (1/4") brush stroke.
      3.   A taxicab may be painted any color provided that the identifying
information required by subsections C1 and C2 must at all times be in a
contrasting color that is determined by the Superintendent/Director of Public
Safety to make the identifying information clearly visible.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997; amd. Ord. 98-9-2D, 9-2-1998; Ord. 2022-10-10C, 10-10-
2022)
4-15C-8-2: LIVERY VEHICLES:
   A.   Licenses And Inspections:
      1.   Application for a livery vehicle license shall be made by the owner
of the vehicle upon forms furnished by the Village. Such application shall
identify the vehicle owner and contain a complete description of the vehicle
including make, model, year, color, State registration number, vehicle
identification number, livery company name, and company assigned vehicle
number. Also required are copies of the vehicle registration card and the
document confirming that there has been compliance with the insurance
requirements of section
4-15C-14 of this article.
      2.   No livery vehicle license shall be issued for any vehicle which is
not owned or affiliated with a livery service which has been licensed by the
Village.
      3.   No livery vehicle shall be licensed until it has been thoroughly and
carefully examined at a safety inspection station and found to be in safe
condition for passengers, of good appearance, and well painted.
      4.   Livery vehicles shall also be subject to re-inspections at any time.
All livery vehicles will be inspected no less than two (2) times annually.
      5.   Any time a livery vehicle is involved in an accident that causes
damage which may affect the safety of prospective passengers, it must be taken
out of service immediately and repaired. Before such vehicle may be returned to
service, it must be re-inspected and certified at a safety inspection station.
      6.   The Superintendent of Public Safety and his designees shall have the
authority to immediately remove from service any livery vehicle which has been
designated unfit for service or unsafe.
      7.   The Superintendent of Public Safety may require a livery vehicle to
be re-inspected as a result of a complaint by any person, or if the
Superintendent has reason to believe that the condition of the livery vehicle
may pose a threat to the safety of its passengers, or has reason to believe
that the livery vehicle is not in compliance with the provisions of this
article.
      8.   Upon passing all test categories at an approved safety testing
station, the livery vehicle will be issued a safety inspection sticker to
indicate that it has been deemed street worthy. Said sticker must be
prominently displayed in the right lower corner of the vehicle’s windshield.
      9.   Any livery vehicle that does not pass a safety inspection for any
reason shall be immediately put out of service until the livery vehicle passes
the safety inspection.
      10.   It is unlawful for any livery vehicle for which a livery vehicle
license has been issued by the Village to operate without a valid safety
inspection sticker displayed in the lower right corner of the vehicle’s
windshield.
      11.   A livery vehicle which fails to pass a safety inspection, fails to
appear for a safety inspection when directed to do so, or otherwise is in
violation of any provision of this section may be immediately removed from
service.
      12.   Safety inspection stickers are not transferable from one vehicle to
another. A safety inspection sticker shall not be affixed to any vehicle other
than the vehicle for which the sticker was originally issued.
      13.   When a livery vehicle is removed from service by the owner, the
livery vehicle license issued to that vehicle must be immediately surrendered
to the Director of the Health and Licensing Department.
   B.   License Sticker And Display:
      1.   A livery vehicle license issued by the Village shall be in the form
of an adhesive sticker which shall contain the official license number of the
public passenger vehicle.
      2.   Livery vehicle licenses shall be of a distinctly different color
and/or design every year. Livery vehicle licenses must be affixed to the lower
right portion of the windshield of the vehicle for which the license has been
issued.
      3.   A livery vehicle sticker is not transferable to any vehicle other
than the vehicle for which it has been issued.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-8-3: AGE, CONDITION AND TYPE OF VEHICLES:
   A.   No vehicle shall be operated as a limousine that is more than six (6)
years old.
   B.   All vehicles licensed to operate as taxicabs must comply with all other
requirements of this article:
      1.   There shall not be any rust on the exterior or interior of the
vehicle.
      2.   The body and interior of the vehicle shall not have any visible
damage or defects. The exterior surfaces on the body of the vehicle must be
painted so that colors used in different areas of the vehicle body match.
      3.   All windows in the vehicle, lights on the exterior and lights in the
interior of the vehicle shall be in proper working condition and shall not
contain any cracks or holes.
      4.   The upholstery within the vehicle shall not be ripped, torn or
otherwise damaged.
      5.   The exterior of the vehicle must be maintained in a clean condition
taking into account weather conditions.
      6.   The interior of the vehicle must be maintained in a clean condition.
There shall be no litter, garbage or other debris inside the vehicle. There
shall not be any pungent odors emanating from within the interior of the
vehicle or the vehicle itself.
      7.   All mechanical components of the vehicle shall operate properly. The
vehicle shall not emit any noise or fumes which are not emitted by a vehicle
that is in excellent operating condition.
      8.   The vehicle must be equipped with an operating heater and an
operating air conditioning system. The interior of the vehicle, while
transporting a passenger, must be maintained at a temperature that is not less
than sixty five degrees Fahrenheit (65°F) or more than seventy two degrees
Fahrenheit (72°F)
   C.   The Superintendent shall have the authority to issue additional
regulations which contain requirements relating to the condition in which
vehicles licensed as taxicabs must be maintained and operated; provided, that
such regulations are consistent with the provisions of subsection B of this
section including, but not limited to, regulations which restrict or limit the
items and materials which may be displayed on the exterior or interior of a
vehicle licensed as a taxicab.
   D.   1.   All public passenger vehicles licensed in the Village shall meet
the following criteria:
         a.   The vehicle shall be “full size” or larger automobile or van or
shall be a vehicle which is a make, model and model year that is listed on the
current list of eligible models issued by the Chief of Public Safety pursuant
to subsection D2 of this section.
         b.   It shall be equipped with at least four (4) operable doors.
         c.   It shall have a compartment to contain luggage or similar items.
      2.   The Superintendent of Public Safety may determine that motor
vehicles other than “full size” or larger automobiles and vans may be licensed
as public passenger vehicles in the Village. If the Superintendent determines
that motor vehicles other than “full size” and larger automobiles and vans
shall be eligible to be licensed as public passenger vehicles in the Village,
the Superintendent shall maintain a list which states the make, model and model
year of those motor vehicles other than “full size” and larger automobiles and
vans which are eligible to be licensed as public passenger vehicles.
   E.   Any vehicle found operating in violation of this section is subject to
being immediately removed from service.
(Ord. 98-9-2D, 9-2-1998)
4-15C-9: CHAUFFEURS:
4-15C-9-1: LICENSING PROVISIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any public passenger
vehicle in the Village without having first obtained a Rosemont chauffeur’s
license.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person owning or controlling any public
passenger vehicle to employ or permit any person to operate such vehicle for
hire within the Village unless the driver has a valid chauffeur’s license
issued by the Village.
   C.   Any person desiring to obtain a public passenger vehicle chauffeur’s
license must file a written application with the License Officer.
   D.   The contents of the application shall be determined by the License
Officer.
   E.   Applicants must meet the following qualifications:
      1.   Be no less than twenty one (21) years of age.
      2.   Not be afflicted with any infirmity of body or mind which may render
him or her unfit for safe operation of a public passenger vehicle.
      3.   Have a valid Illinois driver’s license.
      4.   Not have been convicted of a class A misdemeanor or felony charge
within the last five (5) years, or show a previous background that indicates a
tendency to act in a manner that may place the public at risk.
      5.   Not have had his license suspended or revoked in any state within
the last three (3) years for any violation of law concerning the operation of a
motor vehicle.
      6.   Be able to read, write and speak the English language at a level of
expertise sufficient to effectively function as a public passenger vehicle
operator.
      7.   Be able to pass a written examination which tests the applicant’s
knowledge of local geography and traffic laws.
   F.   When the application is filed and its processing fee paid, the
Superintendent of Public Safety will conduct a thorough applicant background
check.
   G.   If the results of the background check are favorable, the applicant
will be required to pass a written and/or oral exam to prove proficiency in the
areas of reading, writing, and speaking the English language, local geography
and traffic laws.
   H.   If the applicant fails to pass the examination on the first attempt, he
will be allowed to re-test a maximum of four (4) times in a one hundred eighty
(180) day period from the date of first attempt. If the applicant fails the
four (4) subsequent tests, he must wait until at least January 1 of the
following year to re-apply for a chauffeur’s license. Once all testing criteria
is successfully met and the applicant is deemed fit, a public passenger vehicle
license will be issued promptly.
   I.   The public passenger vehicle chauffeur’s license shall be prominently
displayed in the vehicle at all times.
   J.   It shall be unlawful to transfer any public passenger vehicle
chauffeur’s license from one person to another.
   K.   Any public passenger vehicle found being operated by a driver who has
not obtained a chauffeur’s license from the Village shall be immediately
removed from service.
   L.   Any person issued a chauffeur’s license must inform the Director of the
Health and Licensing Department within ten (10) days of any change of address
or phone number.
   M.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department may suspend a
chauffeur’s license for a period not to exceed three (3) days as a result of a
failure to comply with the provisions of this article or for any violation of
Federal, State or Municipal law. Prior to suspending a chauffeur’s license
pursuant to this subsection, the Director shall give the licensee the
opportunity to appear before the Director and explain why the chauffeur’s
license should not be suspended. Any person whose chauffeur’s license has been
suspended pursuant to this subsection may appeal the suspension to the Public
Passenger Vehicle Review Board by filing a notice of appeal with the Office of
the Chief of Public Safety within twenty four (24) hours after the suspension
is issued. If an appeal is filed, the suspension shall be deferred until such
time as the Public Passenger Review Board has conducted a hearing and decided
the appeal.
   N.   1.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department may
temporarily suspend, for a period not to exceed seven (7) days pending a
hearing by the Public Passenger Vehicle Review Board, a chauffeur’s license for
the following:
         a.   Failure to comply with the provisions of this article or for any
violation of Federal, State, or Municipal law.
