         b.   The licensee being physically, mentally or emotionally unfit to
perform his duties as a public passenger vehicle operator.
         c.   The fraudulent use of the license by or with consent of the
licensee.
      2.    Before suspending a chauffeur’s license pursuant to this
subsection, the Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall give the
licensee an opportunity to appear before the Director and explain why the
chauffeur’s license should not be suspended pending a hearing by the Review
Board.
   O.   A person requesting that a chauffeur’s license be renewed shall submit
an application to the Director of the Health and Licensing Department prior to
the date the chauffeur’s license is scheduled to expire. No chauffeur’s license
shall be renewed until after the Superintendent of Public Safety has conducted
a review of the renewal applicant’s driving record and criminal background. No
chauffeur’s license will be renewed unless the Superintendent of Public Safety
and the Director of the Health and Licensing Department and the determine that
the applicant for renewal continues to meet the requirements for receiving a
chauffeur’s license.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-9-2: RANDOM CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE TESTING OF LICENSEES:
   A.   No person holding a valid Rosemont chauffeur’s license shall operate
any public passenger vehicle in the Village while having in his possession or
being under the influence of any “controlled substance”, as defined in section
102 of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act (720 ILCS 570/102), including
“cannabis”, as defined in section 3 of the Cannabis Control Act (720 ILCS 550/
3), or any prescription drug unless such prescription drug was obtained
directly or pursuant to a valid prescription order from a duly licensed
physician who is acting in the course of his professional practice.
   B.   Random controlled substances testing shall be conducted on unannounced
dates and times. The Superintendent of Public Safety or his designated agents
shall randomly select persons holding valid Rosemont chauffeurs’ licenses for
controlled substance testing. Such license holders shall be escorted to the
testing site by a designated public safety officer.
   C.   The controlled substances testing shall be conducted by analyzing the
Rosemont chauffeur’s license holder’s urine specimen. The analysis shall be
performed at laboratories designated by the Village and certified and monitored
by the United States Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). All
samples shall be “split-samples”. The “primary sample” shall be at least thirty
milliliters (30 mL) of urine; the “split-sample” shall be at least fifteen
milliliters (15 mL). The failure of the holder of a Rosemont chauffeur’s
license to provide that quantity, even after a two (2) hour second opportunity
following drinking up to twenty four (24) ounces of water, shall cause the
license holder to be referred for a medical evaluation to develop pertinent
information as to whether such license holder’s inability to provide a specimen
is genuine or constitutes a refusal to test. A written conclusion shall be
submitted to the Village by a medical review officer (“MRO”) designated by the
Village.
   D.   The MRO shall be responsible for receiving laboratory results of a
licensee’s controlled substances tests.
   E.   The first test is the initial test to determine if any of the specified
prohibited controlled substances are present in the licensee’s urine sample. If
the initial test is positive for one or more of the prohibited controlled
substances, then a confirmation test for each drug identified in the initial
test shall be performed on the remainder of the tested primary urine specimen
sample.
   F.   If the confirmation test is required, the MRO shall notify the Rosemont
chauffeur’s license holder. The license holder will then be entitled to request
a confirming test on the untested split-sample, provided the license holder
requests the test of the split-sample within seventy two (72) hours of the
notification.
   G.   Refusal by a Rosemont chauffeur’s license holder to provide the urine
sample shall be a violation of this section and subject the license holder to
immediate suspension of his Rosemont chauffeur’s license. The Superintendent of
Public Safety, after a hearing, shall suspend for thirty (30) days any license
holder who refuses to provide a urine sample. At the conclusion of the thirty
(30) day suspension, the license holder will not have his license reinstated
until he produces a negative test result.
   H.   1.   If, after a hearing, a Rosemont chauffeur’s license holder is
found to be in violation of this section as a result of a positive controlled
substance test or being in possession of a controlled substance in a manner not
permitted by law, his Rosemont chauffeur’s license shall be suspended until
such time as his condition has been evaluated by a substance abuse professional
to the satisfaction of the Superintendent of Public Safety.
      2.   After such a professional evaluation, if the license holder’s
condition proves nonaddictive, the license holder’s Rosemont chauffeur’s
license shall be reinstated, provided he can produce a negative controlled
substance test result and agrees to further testing, at the discretion of the
Superintendent of Public Safety, to ensure that the license holder is no longer
using controlled substances in a manner not permitted by law.
      3.   After such a professional evaluation, if the license holder’s
condition proves addictive, the license holder’s Rosemont chauffeur’s license
shall not be reinstated until such time as he can produce a negative controlled
substance test result and show documented proof to the satisfaction of the
Superintendent of Public Safety that he has successfully completed a certified
drug rehabilitation program approved by the Village. The license holder must
agree to indefinite testing at the discretion of the Superintendent to ensure
that the license holder is no longer impaired.
   I.   Positive test results will be reported to the Superintendent of Public
Safety who will immediately notify the Rosemont chauffeur’s license holder and
schedule a hearing. The license holder’s Rosemont chauffeur’s license may be
suspended pending the outcome of the hearing. If, after a hearing, a Rosemont
chauffeur’s license holder is determined to be in violation of this section, he
shall have his license suspended until such time as he complies with subsection
H of this section.
   J.   If a Rosemont chauffeur’s license holder is found to have violated the
provisions of this section a second time, his Rosemont chauffeur’s license
shall be revoked, and such person shall no longer be qualified to obtain a
Rosemont’s chauffeur’s license at any time.
   K.   All controlled substances test results shall be maintained under strict
confidentiality by the Village, the designated testing laboratory, the MRO,
and, where applicable, the substance abuse professional. Controlled substances
test results shall be released only in the following circumstances:
      1.   To the Rosemont chauffeur’s license holder upon written request;
      2.   To third parties, when the license holder has given written consent;
      3.   To any Federal, State or local officials with regulatory control
over the Village or the license holder;
      4.   To a decision maker in a litigation or administrative proceeding
arising from a positive test result or license holder initiated action;
      5.   To a subsequent employer upon receipt of a written request by the
license holder; or
      6.   Where otherwise required by law.
(Ord. 98-12-2H, 12-2-1998)
4-15C-10: OPERATION OF PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLES:
   A.   No operator of a public passenger vehicle shall carry more than the
rated passenger load per vehicle.
   B.   After a public passenger vehicle has been hired by one or more persons
traveling together, the operator shall not pick up other passengers.
   C.   It is the duty of the driver of any public passenger vehicle licensed
in the Village to accept as a passenger any person who seeks service; provided,
that the person conducts himself in an orderly manner.
   D.   The driver of a public passenger vehicle shall transport his passenger
to the point of destination by the most direct route available.
   E.   Each public passenger vehicle driver shall maintain personal hygiene,
be clean and orderly in dress, and neatly maintain his scalp and facial hair.
Such operator will be required to wear a collared shirt, full length pants and
shoes which fully cover the driver’s feet. Clothing shall not have any visible
rips or tears.
   F.   No person shall operate a public passenger vehicle within the Village
who is under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or a controlled substance
or who, at any time within ninety (90) minutes prior to operating such vehicle,
has consumed an alcoholic beverage or a controlled substance.
   G.   It shall be unlawful for any operator of a public passenger vehicle to
use obscene or profane language in the presence of any passenger.
   H.   It shall be unlawful for any public passenger vehicle licensed by the
Village to advertise for the purpose of business or commercial uses unrelated
to the public passenger vehicle company.
   I.   It shall be unlawful for any public passenger vehicle which transports
passengers to convey toxic, hazardous or biological waste at any time.
   J.   It shall be unlawful for any public passenger vehicle operator or
company to use a radio frequency scanner or scanning type radio to monitor the
radio frequency of a competing company for the purpose of stealing the fares of
the scanned company.
   K.   It shall be unlawful for any public passenger driver or company
representative to offer compensation to the employees of any business in
Rosemont in order to direct prospective customers to that driver or company. It
shall be unlawful for any person to accept or solicit compensation from a
public passenger driver or company representative in return for directing
prospective customers to that driver or company.
   L.   The operator of a public passenger vehicle shall be courteous to
passengers, prospective passengers and other drivers at all times.
   M.   If any public passenger vehicle driver violates the provisions of this
section, the vehicle he is operating may be immediately removed from service.
   N.   It is unlawful to transfer any public passenger vehicle license from
one vehicle to another.
   O.   The driver of any public passenger vehicle, while posted at any
location in Rosemont awaiting a fare, shall remain in or in close proximity to
the vehicle he is operating. He may leave his vehicle unattended for a period
of no longer than ten (10) minutes.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
   P.   A public passenger vehicle which has not been issued a public passenger
vehicle license pursuant to this article shall not stand or park on any
privately owned or privately controlled property except as follows:
      1.   A livery vehicle may stand or park on privately owned property;
provided, that the operator of the livery vehicle is waiting for a passenger as
allowed under subsection 4-15C-4D2 of this article; provided, that the operator
shall remain in or in close proximity to the vehicle he is operating and does
not leave the vehicle unattended for a period of longer than ten (10) minutes.
      2.   A public passenger vehicle may stand or park in a parking lot which
is located on the same premises as a restaurant with drive-up facilities for a
period of not longer than fifteen (15) minutes.
      3.   A public passenger vehicle may stand or park in a parking lot which
is located on the same premises as a grocery store, delicatessen or convenience
food store for a period of no longer than ten (10) minutes.
(Ord. 98-1-14M, 1-14-1998)
   Q.   A public passenger vehicle shall not be parked and left unattended on
any public street in the Village or within any publicly owned surface parking
lot where a fee is not charged for parking.
(Ord. 2001-9-5B, 9-5-2001)
4-15C-11: TAXICAB STANDS:
   A.   The Superintendent of Public Safety shall have the authority to create
on public property and, with the permission from the owner, on private property
taxicab stands where cabs licensed by the Village may wait for passengers.
   B.   The Superintendent of Public Safety shall also have the authority to
limit the number of taxis permitted to use a taxicab stand at any given time.
   C.   Rules of conduct at cab stands shall include, but are not limited to,
the following:
      1.   Taxicabs entering a cab stand or line shall take the rear positions.
Overcrowding cab stands or lines is prohibited.
      2.   While taxis occupy designated cab stands, no other taxi shall bypass
the cab line and accept passengers for service or payment that is to be made by
a third party through use of a voucher.
      3.   The first cab in line shall be eligible for the first available
fare, unless a passenger indicates a preference for another cab in that line.
      4.   No taxicab shall accept a load along side of, in front of, or
adjacent to an established occupied cab stand.
      5.   Livery vehicles shall not park in taxicab stands.
   6.   Public passenger vehicle drivers shall not sleep or lounge while posted
in a cab stand.
   7.   There shall not be more than two (2) occupants in any vehicle posted at
a cab stand.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-12: TAXIMETERS:
   A.   No taxicab shall be issued a Village taxicab vehicle license until its
taximeter is tested and certified to be accurate and sealed.
   B.   No taxicab shall operate for hire in the Village unless the taximeter
is accurately recording the fare to be charged.
   C.   The taximeter will be located so that its face can be seen by any
passenger riding in the taxi.
   D.   Adequate illumination shall be provided for the face of the taximeter
so that it may be read by the passenger whenever the vehicle is in operation.
   E.   The Superintendent of Public Safety shall have the authority to
designate an official taximeter testing center.
   F.   Each taximeter, after being certified as accurate by the official meter
testing center, will be sealed with a numbered adhesive seal issued by the
Village which will indicate that the taximeter has been inspected and found to
be accurate.
   G.   No person operating or owning any taxicab shall transfer any taximeter
to any other vehicle unless the meter is inspected, reprogrammed and certified
at the authorized taximeter testing center.
   H.   If a taxicab has service performed on or changes made to the
transmission, any drive train component, or the size of the tire, the owner of
the taxicab must have the taximeter inspected, reprogrammed and certified at
the authorized taximeter testing center.
   I.   There shall be programmed into the meter of any taxicab licensed in the
Village only one rate of fare. The rates shall be those which are provided in
subsection 4-15C-13B of this article.
   J.   It shall be unlawful to have in any taxicab more than one taximeter.
   K.   It shall be unlawful to attempt to remove, tamper with, or alter a
taximeter seal.
   L.   Any person convicted of tampering with or otherwise manipulating a
taximeter and any person found to have tampered with a taximeter seal or found
with a fraudulently obtained taximeter seal will be subject to a two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) fine for the first offense. A seven hundred fifty
dollar ($750.00) fine wi11 be assessed for the second offense. In addition, the
public passenger vehicle chauffeur’s license of such person will be revoked for
a second offense.
   M.   It shall be unlawful for any holder of a taxicab operator’s license to
knowingly allow or encourage a driver working for that company to operate a
taxi which is in violation of any provision of this section.
   N.   The Superintendent of Public Safety shall have the authority to specify
the brand and model of taximeter to be used by taxicabs licensed in the
Village.
   O.   The Superintendent of Public Safety shall have the authority to require
that taximeters be re-certified and resealed on a semiannual basis. The Chief
of nubble Safety shall also have the authority to require that a taximeter be
recertified and resealed at any time the Superintendent has reason to believe
that the taximeter may not be accurate or that there may have been tampering
with or an unauthorized adjustment made to the taximeter.
   P.   Any taxicab which has a taximeter found to be in violation of any
provisions of this section may be immediately removed from service.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-13: RATES OF FARE:
   A.   Fixing Rates: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation
licensed under the provisions of this article to conspire among themselves or
with other persons to fix or control rates for public passenger vehicles within
the Village. It is the purpose of this article to provide for free and
uncontrolled rates except as to maximum rates of fare for taxicabs as provided
in subsection B of this section. Any scheme, device or other subterfuge
employed by any person to evade this purpose shall be deemed to be in violation
of this article and grounds for revocation.
   B.   Rates Established: Taxicab rates as determined when a taximeter is in
use shall be as follows:
      1.   Three dollars ($3.00) upon hire for the first passenger and one
dollar ($1.00) for each additional passenger above the age of twelve (12);
provided, that there shall be no more than four (4) passengers over the age of
twelve (12) permitted in a taxicab which is an automobile or more than seven
(7) passengers over the age of twelve (12) in a taxicab which is a minivan.
      2.   Twenty four cents ($0.24) for each one-tenth (1/10) mile or fraction
thereof that is traveled in the taxicab; except, that a) person(s) whose
domicile is in the Village shall be charged a flat rate of four dollars ($4.00)
per trip to any single destination within the Village; and b) persons whose
domicile is in the Village who are age sixty two (62) years or older shall be
charged the flat rate indicated when transported to the following destinations:
      Cumberland and Higgins Shopping Area: Six dollars ($6.00).
      Oakton and Lee Shopping Area: Six dollars ($6.00).
      Holy Family Hospital: Nine dollars $9.00.
      Lutheran General Hospital: Nine dollars ($9.00).
      Resurrection Hospital: Nine dollars ($9.00).
      3.   Forty cents ($0.40) for each one minute of waiting time or traffic
delay unless the fare for the trip is a flat rate as provided in subsection B2
of this section.
      4.   Unless there is a passenger in the taxicab for a trip who is sixty
two (62) years old or older, if the taxicab operator handles more than two (2)
items, including packages and luggage, which weigh over ten (10) pounds each,
then there shall be an additional charge of fifty cents ($0.50) for each item
other than the first two (2) such items.
      5.   If a passenger presents a Village senior subsidy card that has been
issued to the passenger, the fare charged to the passenger shall be discounted
one dollar fifty cents ($1.50) off the fare that would otherwise be charged
pursuant to the rates specified in subsections B1, B2 and B3 of this section.
      6.   A fuel surcharge may be added by the driver of a taxicab when the
fare for a ride is calculated under subsection B(1) of this section as follows:
         a.   If the price of gasoline equals or exceeds two dollars seventy
cents ($2.70) for seven (7) consecutive business days and the Director of the
Health and Licensing Department issues a tax industry advisory notice
authorizing a fifty cent ($0.50) fuel surcharge on the rates of fare, the
driver of a taxicab may add to the total taxicab fare that would otherwise
apply a fuel surcharge not to exceed fifty cents ($0.50). Provided, however,
that if the price of gasoline falls below two dollars seventy cents ($2.70) per
gallon for seven (7) consecutive business days at any time after such taxi
industry advisory notice is issued under this subsection B6a, the fuel
surcharge authorized under this subsection B6a shall expire at twelve o'clock
(12:00) midnight on such seventh consecutive business day.
         b.   If the price of gasoline equals or exceeds three dollars twenty
cents ($3.20) per gallon for seven (7) consecutive business days and the
Director of the Health and Licensing Department issues a tax industry advisory
notice authorizing a one dollar ($1.00) fuel surcharge on the rates of fare,
the driver of a taxicab may add to the total taxicab fare that would otherwise
apply a fuel surcharge not to exceed one dollar ($1.00). Provided, however,
that if the price of gasoline falls below three dollars twenty cents ($3.20)
per gallon for seven (7) consecutive business days at any time after such tax
industry advisory notice is issued under this subsection B6b but remains at or
above two dollars seventy cents ($2.70) per gallon throughout such seven (7)
consecutive business day period, the driver of the taxicab shall adjust the one
dollar ($1.00) fuel surcharge downward to an amount not to exceed fifty cents
($0.50). Such downward adjusted fuel surcharge shall not be readjusted upward
to one dollar ($1.00) by any taxicab driver unless a taxi industry advisory
notice authorizing such upward adjustment is issued by the Director of the
Health and Licensing Department. Provided, further, that if the price of
gasoline falls below $2,709 per gallon for seven (7) consecutive business days
at any time after a taxi industry advisory notice is issued under this
subsection B6, any fuel surcharge authorized under this subsection B6 shall
expire at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on such seventh consecutive business
day.
         c.   If a fuel surcharge is authorized under subsection B6a or B6b of
this section, no taxicab driver shall add such fuel surcharge to any rate of
fare unless a clearly visible sign approved by the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department and notifying passengers of the surcharge, is posted in a
prominent place within the taxicab. The Director may, by regulation or
directive, specify the location, wording, size and other features of the sign
required by this subsection B6c.
         d.   If the Corporate Authorities of the Village enact an ordinance
which revises the rates of fare set forth in subsection Bl of this section, the
provisions of subsections B6a and B6b of this section shall not apply for a
period of twelve (12) months, as measured from the effective date of such
ordinance.
         e.   It shall be unlawful for any person to add any fuel surcharge to
any rate of fare in violation of the requirements of this subsection B6. In
addition to any other penalty or sanction provided by law, any person who
violates this subsection B6 shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty ($750.00) for each offense.
Each occasion on which a fuel charge is added to a taxicab fare in violation of
the requirements of this subsection B6 shall constitute a separate and distinct
violation to which a separate fine shall apply.
         f.   As used in this subsection B6, the term "price of gasoline" means
the average retail regular reformulated gasoline price as for the Chicago
Metropolitan Statistical Area published in the AAA's Daily Fuel Gauge Report.
      7.   Rates Established: When the fee is determined by a ride share
application program. When the cost of transportation services provided by a
Taxicab is determined by a computerized application ride share program in which
the passenger participates by initiating the call for service through a
computer application, the fee shall be based upon the terms and conditions as
established for the time of the service under the program.
   C.   Rates Displayed: The taxi rates of fare established by this section for
a taximeter will be printed upon a card in plain and legible type. This card
will only be created, printed and distributed by the Village. The card will be
affixed to the interior of each taxicab in a conspicuous place so that it may
be easily read by any passenger riding in the vehicle.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997; amd. Ord. 2008-5-7E, 5-7-2008, eff. 5-16-2008; Ord.
2009-4-1H, 4-1-2009, eff. 4-15-2009; Ord. 2022-10-10C, 10-10-2022)
4-15C-14: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   No person will be issued a Village chauffeur’s license and no taxicab
vehicle license or livery vehicle license shall be issued until all the
requirements of the State laws concerning insurance issued to compensate any
person who may suffer damage as a result of operation of this vehicle have been
met.
   B.   All applicants for licenses provided by this article shall, as part of
their application, submit proof of insurance in the amounts required by current
State law.
   C.   There shall be affixed on a conspicuous part of each public passenger
vehicle a sticker which indicates that the vehicle has complied with the
requirements of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-101 through 5/8-116.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-15: PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE REVIEW BOARD:
   A.   1.   The Village President shall appoint a Review Board which shall
have the power to impose fines and to suspend, for periods greater than three
(3) days, or revoke taxicab and livery vehicle licenses and chauffeur’s
licenses where the Review Board finds that the licensee or a vehicle for which
a public passenger vehicle license has been issued:
         a.   Has violated the provisions of this article or any applicable
Federal, State, or Municipal Law; or
         b.   Has, in the case of a person holding a chauffeur’s license,
become physically, mentally or emotionally unfit to perform his duties as a
public passenger vehicle operator; or
         c.   Has, in the case of a licensee, fraudulently used or consented to
the fraudulent use of the license.
      2.   The Review Board shall also have the authority to impose fines on
holders of taxicab operators’ licenses and to recommend to the Village
President that a taxicab operator’s license or a livery service operator’s
license be suspended or revoked if the Review Board finds that a licensee has
violated a provision of this article. The Review Board shall consider appeals
of decisions made by the Director of the Health and Licensing Department to
suspend a chauffeur’s license as provided in subsection
4-15C-9-1M of this article.
   B.   The decision of the Review Board will not be affected by the outcome of
any court decision relating to any violation for which the Review Board
suspended or revoked a license or recommended the suspension or revocation of a
license unless the court decision reverses or vacates the Review Board’s
decision.
   C.   The Review Board shall include but, is not limited to, the Director of
the Health and Licensing Department and two (2) members of the Rosemont Public
Safety Department o who hold a rank above the rank of public safety officer.
   D.   1.   The Review Board shall have the authority to levy fines against
license holders according to the following schedule and as otherwise provided
in this article:
         a.   First offense: Up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
         b.   Second offense: Up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
         c.   Third or subsequent offense: Up to seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) and mandatory license revocation; except, that in the case of the
operator of a livery or taxicab service, the third or subsequent offense shall
result in a mandatory recommendation that the operator’s license be revoked by
the Village President.
      2.   In addition to or instead of imposing a fine as provided in this
subsection, the Review Board may also suspend or revoke a chauffeur’s license
or a public passenger vehicle license and may recommend to the Village
President that a taxicab operator’s license or a livery service operator’s
license be suspended or revoked.
   E.   Prior to 1) suspending or revoking a license; 2) recommending the
suspension or revocation of a taxicab or livery operator’s license; 3) imposing
a fine as provided in this section; or 4) considering an appeal of a suspension
issued by the License Officer pursuant to subsection
4-15C-9-1M of this article, the Review Board shall conduct an informal hearing.
Notice of the date and time of the hearing shall be delivered to the licensee
or mailed to the licensee’s last known address on file with the Village not
less than five (5) days before the date of the hearing. The licensee shall be
entitled to present testimony and documentary evidence at the hearing as to why
the license should not be revoked or suspended and why a fine should not be
imposed. The licensee shall have the right to cross examine any person who
testifies against the licensee during the hearing. The licensee may be
represented at the hearing by counsel. The decision of the Review Board shall
be made by majority vote of those members of the Review Board who were in
attendance at the hearing.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-16: IMMEDIATE REMOVAL FROM SERVICE:
   A.   Where this article provides that a public passenger vehicle shall be or
may be immediately removed from service, the vehicle may be removed from
service by towing.
   B.   If a vehicle is removed from service, the owner or operator is wholly
responsible for any towing and impound charges that occur, unless the Review
Board determines that there was no basis for removing the vehicle from service.
   C.   Any public passenger vehicle which is operated in violation or contains
a condition which violates a provision of this article may be immediately
removed from service.
   D.   If a public passenger vehicle is immediately removed from service as
provided in this article, a hearing shall be scheduled before the Review Board
within not more than ten (10) days after the date the vehicle is immediately
removed from service, if the owner of the public passenger vehicle files a
request for a hearing with the Office of the Chief of Public Safety within
forty eight (48) hours after the vehicle is removed from service.
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
4-15C-17: RECORDKEEPING:
The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall keep records of any
pertinent information concerning public passenger vehicles and chauffeurs.
These records shall be available for inspection by the public in accordance
with the provisions of the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (5 ILCS 140/1 et
seq).
(Ord. 97-1-8Q, 1-8-1997)
ARTICLE D: BUS TRANSPORT BUSINESS
Section
4-15D-1:   Definition
4-15D-2:   License Required
4-15D-3:   Application For License
4-15D-4:   Investigation Of Applicant; Approval Or Disapproval Of License
4-15D-5:   Insurances Or Bond Required
4-15D-6:   Condition Of Vehicles; Inspections
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-15D-1: DEFINITION:
The term “bus transport business”, when used in this article, shall mean any
business which is not a public utility under State law, owning or operating for
profit any type of vehicle, having a rated seating capacity of more than seven
(7) persons, for the transportation of passengers as a result of individual
contract or on a per trip or per hourly basis.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15D-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the bus transport business in the Village without
first having obtained a license therefor.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15D-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a license to engage in the bus transport business shall be
made in conformity with the general requirements of this title relating to
applications for licenses. The application shall also state the number of
vehicles owned or operated by the applicant and which of such vehicles are to
be used for the transportation of children to and from school.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15D-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL OF LICENSE:
The Superintendent of Public Safety shall make or cause to be made such
investigations as he deems necessary to determine whether the vehicles used by
the applicant and the drivers employed by the applicant comply with all the
applicable provisions of this Code. No license shall be issued to any applicant
whose proposed vehicles and drivers to not comply with the applicable
provisions of this Code. The Superintendent shall indicate on the application
for a license the results of his investigations and his approval or disapproval
of the application.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15D-5: INSURANCES OR BOND REQUIRED:
   A.   Every bus transport business shall carry public liability and property
damage insurance and workers’ compensation insurance for employees with
responsible insurers authorized to transact insurance business in the State of
Illinois and qualified to assume the risks under the laws of Illinois to secure
payment of any loss or damage resulting from occurrence arising out of or
caused by the operation or use of any of the vehicles belonging to the
licensee.
   B.   The public liability insurance policy or contract may cover one or more
vehicles, but each one shall be insured in an amount as required by the
Village. Every insurance policy or contract for such insurance shall provide
for the payment and satisfaction of any final judgment rendered against the
owner or any person driving any insured vehicle, and that suit may be brought
in any court of competent jurisdiction upon such policy or contract by any
person having claims arising from the operation or use of such vehicles. It
shall contain a description of each vehicle insured, manufacturer’s name and
serial number, the State license number, and the Village license number.
   C.   In lieu of an insurance policy or contract, a surety bond or bonds with
a corporate surety or sureties authorized to do business under the laws of
Illinois may be accepted by the Village for all or any part of such insurance;
provided, that each bond shall be conditioned for the payment and satisfaction
of any final judgment, in conformity with the provisions of an insurance policy
required by this section.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15D-6: CONDITION OF VEHICLES; INSPECTIONS:
   A.   General Condition Of Vehicles; Inspections:
      1.   No bus transport business license shall be granted until all
vehicles used by the applicant for such license have been thoroughly and
carefully inspected and approved by the Superintendent of Public Safety or his
designee and found to be in a thoroughly safe condition for the transportation
of passengers; clean, fit, of good appearance and well painted and varnished
and complying with the provisions of this article.
      2.   All vehicles used in a bus transport business licensed under this
article must be kept in a safe, clean and sanitary condition, and must be
equipped with properly working brakes, lights and warning signals, in
accordance with the motor vehicle laws of the State of Illinois, this article
and the other regulations of the Village, and no bus transport business license
shall be issued hereunder until it is shown that all vehicles to be used in
such business are in good mechanical condition.
   B.   Mechanical Tests: Mechanical tests of each vehicle used by an applicant
for a bus transport business license shall be made by any testing garage or
testing station approved by the Department of Public Safety and shall include
the following: brakes, wheel alignment, horn, windshield wiper, rear view
mirror, steering mechanism, headlights, taillights and stop lights.
   C.   Physical Inspection: Physical inspection shall be made by the Public
Safety Department and shall include condition of tires, including spare tire,
cleanliness, and general appearance.
   D.   Duty Of Owner: It is the duty of the owner of each vehicle to be used
in a bus transport business to submit to the Superintendent of Public Safety
each vehicle for inspection prior to the issuance of the license and at least
once in every six (6) months thereafter or at any time upon complaint. Also,
the Superintendent may inspect these vehicles at such other times as the
Superintendent may deem necessary, and it is unlawful for the owner or person
in charge or any such vehicle to use or permit its use, in case it has been
condemned by the Superintendent until the vehicle has been repaired or replaced
to the satisfaction of the Superintendent.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
ARTICLE E: MOTOR VEHICLE RENTAL AGENCIES
Section:
4-15E-1:   Definitions
4-15E-2:   License Required
4-15E-3:   Application For License
4-15E-4:   Insurances Or Bond Required
4-15E-5:   Condition Of Vehicles; Inspections
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-15E-1: DEFINITION:
The term “car rental agency”, when used in this article, shall mean any
business primarily engaged in the rental of motor vehicles of any kind, by the
day, week, month or mileage, for a consideration.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15E-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the car rental agency business in the Village without
first having obtained a license therefor.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15E-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any application for a license to engage in the car rental agency business shall
be made in conformity with the general requirements of this title relating to
applications for licenses.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15E-4: INSURANCES OR BOND REQUIRED:
   A.   All licensees under this article shall carry at all times public
liability insurance with a responsible insurer qualified to do business in
Illinois to secure payment of loss or damage resulting from an occurrence
arising out of or caused by the operation or use of any of the vehicles rented
by the licensee.
   B.   The public liability insurance may cover one or more vehicles, but each
one shall be insured in an amount as required by the Village. Every insurance
policy or contract for such insurance shall provide for the payment and
satisfaction of any final judgment rendered against the owner or any person
driving any insured vehicle, and that suit may be brought in any court of
competent jurisdiction upon such policy or contract by any person having claims
arising from the operation or use of such vehicles. It shall contain a
description of each vehicle insured, manufacturer’s name and serial number, the
State license number and the Village license number.
   C.   In lieu of an insurance policy or contract, a surety bond or bonds,
with a corporate surety or sureties authorized to do business under the laws of
Illinois, may be accepted by the Village for all or any part of such insurance;
provided, that each bond shall be conditioned for the payment and satisfaction
of any final judgment, in conformity with the provisions of an insurance policy
required by this section.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15E-5: CONDITION OF VEHICLES; INSPECTIONS:
All vehicles rented to the public by a car rental agency located in the Village
shall be maintained in a safe and properly functioning condition. The
Superintendent of Public Safety or his representative may inspect any vehicle
owned by a licensed car rental agency if he determines there is danger to the
public from such vehicle, and it is the duty of the licensee to permit such
inspections at any time the licensee is open for business. If the
Superintendent or his representative determines that the vehicle is not safe to
operate, the licensee shall make the vehicle safe, to the satisfaction of the
Superintendent, before renting the vehicle.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
ARTICLE F: PARKING LOTS AND GARAGES
Section
4-15F-1:   Definitions
4-15F-2:   License Required
4-15F-3:   Application For License
4-15F-4:   Bond Or Insurance Required
4-15F-5:   Rates And Charges
4-15F-6:   Rate And Hour Signs
4-15F-7:   Additional Commercial Parking Lot Provisions
4-15F-8:   Claim Checks; Return Of Vehicle
4-15F-9:   Entrances, Exits And Barriers
4-15F-10:   Maintenance Of Lots
4-15F-11:   Fire Protection
4-15F-12:   Vehicle Care After Closing
4-15F-13:   Notices Of Claims And Unclaimed Vehicles
4-15F-14:   Prohibited Acts
4-15F-15:   Revocation Of License
4-15F-16:   Moratorium On The Installation Of New Electric Vehicle Charging
Stations In Parking Garage Structures
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-15F-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
COMMERCIAL PARKING LOT OR GARAGE. Any parking lot or garage where a fee is
charged to a person who parks a motor vehicle in or upon the parking lot or
garage other than a parking lot or garage owned' or operated by a unit of
government.
GARAGE: A building or shed, or any portion thereof, in which more than five (5)
motor vehicles may be parked, stored, housed or kept, for which any charge is
made.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Any automobile, truck, motor scooter, or self-propelled vehicle
not operated on tracks or from trolleys.
PARKING FEE: The consideration paid by a person in return for being permitted
to park a motor vehicle in a commercial parking lot or garage.
PARKING LOT: Any outdoor space or uncovered plot, place, lot, parcel, yard or
enclosure, or any portion thereof, where more than five (5) motor vehicles may
be parked, stored, housed or kept for which any charge is made.
PERSON: Any person, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a business of storing motor
vehicles for hire on a parking lot in a garage within the Village without first
having obtained a license therefor in the manner herein set forth.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for license required by this article shall be made in conformance
with the general requirements of this title relating to the issuance of
licenses. The application shall include:
   A.   A plot or drawing of the parking lot or garage showing:
      1.   The location, size and capacity;
      2.   The location and size of entrance and exit;
      3.   The kind of floor or ground surface;
      4.   The location, size and construction of the attendant’s station;
      5.   The wall or barriers surrounding the premises;
   B.   The hours for storage or parking of the vehicles and whether night
storage is to be maintained upon the licensed premises;
   C.   The hours during which parking attendants will be on duty;
   D.   A complete schedule of the rates to be charged for storing or parking
of vehicles; and
   E.   Such other information as the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department may deem necessary for the issuance of the license.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-4: BOND OR INSURANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Every application for a license hereunder shall be accompanied by a
bond, approved by the Village Attorney, executed by a bonding or surety company
authorized to do business in the State, in an amount as required by the
Village, conditioned upon the payment by the licensee of any and all final
judgments for damages resulting to persons or property, including the theft of
any motor vehicle or any part or accessory thereof arising out of the operation
or maintenance of any parking lot or garage. The bond shall run to the Village
for the benefit of any person who may claim redress for property damage or
theft resulting from the operation or maintenance of a parking lot or garage.
The bond shall remain in full force and effect for the full period of time for
which the license is effective.
   B.   A liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company to do
business in the State of Illinois conforming to the requirements of this
section may be permitted in lieu of a bond.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-5: RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Schedule Filed With The Director Of The Health And Licensing
Department: Every licensee shall file with the Director at the time of
application for license a complete schedule of rates and charges to be made for
storing or parking motor vehicles on the premises to be licensed.
   B.   Day And Night Rates: Where separate rates or charges are made for day
parking and night parking, the night rate shall become effective at six thirty
o’clock (6:30) P.M., and notice thereof shall be posted on the signs described
in section 4-15F-6 of this article.
   C.   Change In Rates:
      1.   No licensee shall make any charge for storing or parking any vehicle
in a parking lot or garage in excess of that set forth in his application for a
license unless and until he has notified the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department in writing of the new schedule of rates and posted signs
showing such increase in the same manner as required by subsection C2 of this
section.
      2.   Every application for a change in the schedule of rates or charges,
as filed under subsection A of this section, shall first be submitted in
writing to the Village Board, who shall hold hearings on the applications to
determine the necessity of the change. In making its decision, the Village
Board shall take into consideration, in each case where application is made,
operating and labor costs, increases in rental or maintenance costs, and such
other factors as may reasonably enter into the conduct of the business. If the
Village Board approves the proposed change in rates and charges, the schedule,
as filed, shall be amended.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-6: RATE AND HOUR SIGNS:
   A.   Required; Contents: Each licensee shall maintain at each entrance to a
parking lot or garage a permanently affixed sign suitable to apprise persons
using the same of the name of the licensee, the hours of the day or night when
such places are open for parking or storing motor vehicles, the rates charged
for periods of up to twenty four (24) consecutive hours and the closing hours
of the parking lot or garage.
   B.   Specifications For More Than One Rate: Where more than one rate is
charged for parking, the figures for each rate will be of the same size and
dimensions, and such figures shall measure not less than six inches (6") in
height. The letters and figures indicating the closing hours shall be not less
than six inches (6") in height. All such signs shall be subject to the approval
of the Director of Building and Code Enforcement or his representative.
   C.   Height; Interference With Traffic Prohibited: All signs shall be
erected at a height not less than ten feet (10') and not more than twelve feet
(12') above the sidewalk level, and shall not be erected in such a manner as to
interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-7: ADDITIONAL COMMERCIAL PARKING LOT PROVISIONS:
   A.   Separate Areas For Vehicles Charged A Fee And Vehicles Not Charged A
Fee:
      1.   The operator of a commercial parking lot or garage shall designate
separate areas within the parking lot or garage for the parking of motor
vehicles which are charged a parking fee and the parking of motor vehicles
which are not charged a parking fee. These areas may be changed from time to
time; provided, that at any time a motor vehicle is parked within the lot for
which a parking fee is charged, the operator of the parking lot or garage must
clearly delineate, by means of signs, markings or barriers, the areas within
the parking lot or garage where motor vehicles which are charged a parking fee
are to be parked and the areas within the parking lot or garage where motor
vehicles which are not charged a parking fee are to be parked.
      2.   The operator of a commercial parking lot or garage shall not allow
or permit any person who is charged a parking fee to park the motor vehicle in
any area within the parking lot or garage which is designated for the parking
of motor vehicles which are not charged a parking fee, nor shall the operator
of a commercial parking lot or garage allow or permit any person who is not
charged a parking fee to park the motor vehicle in any area of the parking lot
or garage designated for the parking of motor vehicles for which a parking fee
is charged.
   B.   Recordkeeping:
      1.   The operator of each commercial parking lot within the Village must
keep records for each day which show the number of vehicles parked in the
commercial parking lot or garage on that date for which a parking fee was
charged, the rate at which the fee was calculated, and the total amount of
parking fees collected by the operator on the date. These records shall also
include the records and tickets required to be kept by subsection C of this
section.
      2.   Entries in these records must be made on a daily basis and must
state the name, address and telephone number of each person who makes an entry
into the records.
      3.   These records must be kept by the operator for a period of not less
than one year and shall be made available for inspection upon written request
by the Village Finance Director or any other person authorized to inspect such
records on behalf of the Village by the Finance Director.
      4.   These records shall be maintained in addition to the records
operators are required to maintain by subsection
3-6A-3A of this Code.
   C.   Receipts And Tickets:
      1.   If a parking fee is collected at the time a motor vehicle enters a
commercial parking lot or garage, the operator must cause the person who is
driving the motor vehicle to be given a receipt which contains instructions
stating that the receipt is to be placed so that it is visible through the
front windshield of the motor vehicle. All such receipts issued at an entrance
to the parking lot or garage on a single day shall be numbered consecutively.
The operator of the commercial parking lot or garage shall maintain a record
showing the numbers of the receipts issued on each day as provided in
subsection B of this section.
      2.   If a parking fee is collected at the time a motor vehicle exits a
commercial parking lot or garage, then, at the time the motor vehicle is driven
into the commercial parking lot or garage, the operator of the commercial
parking lot or garage must provide for a ticket to be given to the person
driving the motor vehicle which is stamped with the date and time the motor
vehicle entered the parking lot or garage. This ticket must be collected and a
receipt given to the driver of the motor vehicle at the time the motor vehicle
exits from the parking lot or garage. The operator shall maintain the tickets
collected each day as provided in subsection B of this section.
   D.   Penalties: Any operator of a commercial parking lot or garage or other
person who shall violate any provisions of this section or who shall refuse,
neglect or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this section shall,
upon conviction of any such violation, refusal, neglect or failure to comply be
fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the first offense and not less seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) nor more than one thousand five hundred dollars
($1,500.00) for the second and each subsequent offense within any one hundred
eighty (180) day period.
   E.   Closing Parking Lot Or Garage; Hearing:
      1.   In addition to the penalty provided by subsection D of this section,
the Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall be authorized to
order closed any commercial parking lot or garage if the operator of the
commercial parking lot or garage has been found by the Director to have
violated any provision of this section or to have refused, neglected, or failed
to comply with any of the requirements of this section on more than one day
within any one hundred eighty (180) day period.
      2.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall not issue
an order to close pursuant to this subsection unless the Director has first
conducted a hearing to determine whether the business ordered to close has
violated a provision of this section or has refused, neglected or failed to
comply with any of the requirements of this section on two (2) or more days
within a one hundred eighty (180) day period.
      3.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall give
notice of the hearing to the operator of the commercial parking lot or garage
as shown on the business application last filed with the Village. Such notice
shall be given not less than seven (7) days prior to the date of the hearing
and shall advise the operator of the date, time and place of the hearing and
shall state that the operator may appear at the hearing and present testimony
or other evidence.
      4.   The owner or operator of the commercial parking lot or garage shall
be entitled to be represented at the hearing by an attorney.
      5.   The Public Safety Department shall be and hereby is directed to seal
and take any and all other reasonable action necessary to close a commercial
parking lot or garage which has been ordered by the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department to close pursuant to the provisions of this subsection.
      6.   Any person who continues to operate a commercial parking lot or
garage which has been ordered closed by the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department pursuant to this subsection shall be subject to a fine of
not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) nor more than two thousand
dollars ($2,000.00) for each day or part thereof that the parking lot or garage
is operated after it has been ordered closed.
      7.   Any commercial parking lot or garage ordered closed pursuant to this
subsection shall remain closed for a period of one hundred twenty (120) days
the first time it is ordered closed and for a period of not less than three
hundred sixty five (365) days each subsequent time the commercial parking lot
or garage is ordered closed.
(Ord. 90-8-1C, 8-1-1990)
4-15F-8: CLAIM CHECKS; RETURN OF VEHICLE:
When a vehicle is left for storing or parking, the licensee of the parking lot
or garage, or his agent, servant or employee, shall furnish the owner or
operator of the vehicle with a distinctive claim check which shall have printed
thereon the full name and address of the parking lot or garage and a number
corresponding to a coupon placed upon the vehicle, and shall have written or
stamped thereon the date and license number of the motor vehicle. The licensee
shall not deliver any vehicle without the proper claim check being presented or
without satisfactory proof of ownership of the vehicle. This section shall not
apply where vehicles are stored or parked on a weekly or monthly fee basis.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-9: ENTRANCES, EXITS AND BARRIERS:
   A.   Entrances And Exits: Each parking lot or garage shall have one common
entrance and one common exit, which may or may not be combined, and the
operator of such parking lot or garage shall keep such entrance and exit
properly attended at all times during the period the parking lot or garage is
in operation.
   B.   Barriers:
      1.   Except for places of entrance and exit, every parking lot shall be
completely enclosed by barriers constructed and maintained so as to withstand
the shocks and stresses to which they will normally be subjected by vehicles
using the premises and shall be of such height as to engage the bumper of any
motor vehicle parked on the lot so that no portion of the vehicle shall extend
over the property lines.
      2.   When the lot abuts on a building, barriers shall be erected as
provided in this subsection to prevent motor vehicles from striking the
building.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-10: MAINTENANCE OF LOTS:
   A.   Sidewalks: Every operator of a parking lot or garage shall keep the
sidewalk surrounding the premises free from dirt, ice, sleet and snow, and
shall keep the sidewalk and driveways in a safe condition for the travel of
pedestrians.
   B.   Dust And Water: The ground or floor space of each parking lot or
garage, if made of dirt, sand, cinders or other loose mixture, shall at all
times be kept thoroughly sprinkled or treated with water, calcium chloride or
other means so that the dust, sand, cinders or other substance of which the
ground or floor space is made will not be raised, carried or blown by the wind,
movement of vehicles or other causes, into or upon public property or the
adjacent property of others. The surface or floor of the premises shall be
constructed so as to prevent retention of water thereon.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-11: FIRE PROTECTION:
Every parking lot or garage shall be equipped with proper fire extinguishing
apparatus subject to the approval of the Department of Public Safety, and all
vehicles shall be so parked or stored that they may be reached readily in case
of fire or other emergency.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-12: VEHICLE CARE AFTER CLOSING:
When vehicles are not called for at closing time, the attendant shall leave the
keys and parking coupon for safekeeping at a place within a reasonable distance
of the parking lot or garage, with a responsible person whose name and address
shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-13: NOTICES OF CLAIMS AND UNCLAIMED VEHICLES:
   A.   Claims: Every licensee shall immediately notify the Department of
Public Safety of every claim made by reason of loss, theft, or conversion, or
any damage or injury to person or property from the operation of a parking lot
or garage, and occurring during the hours the premises is regularly open for
business. The obligation created by this subsection shall not extend beyond the
regular posted hours of attendance as posted upon the premises and printed upon
the regular receipt furnished to the owner or person parking a vehicle.
   B.   Unclaimed Vehicles: Every licensee shall immediately notify the
Department of Public Safety, in writing, of the license number, make, and the
name of the owner, if known to him, of every vehicle left in the parking lot or
garage for a period of more than forty eight (48) consecutive hours.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-14: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Refusing Vehicles: No licensee shall refuse to park or store any
vehicle for which there shall be accommodation in a parking lot or garage on
tender of the stated fee for such parking.
   B.   Unauthorized Use Or Removal Of Vehicles: No licensee of a parking lot
or garage shall make or permit any use for any purpose whatsoever of any
vehicle parked in such place, unless the use shall have first been expressly
authorized by the owner or person having control of the vehicle. No licensee
shall transfer, or cause to be moved or transferred, any parked vehicle through
or upon the streets or alleys of the Village without the written consent of the
owner or person having control of the vehicle.
   C.   Obstructing Streets Or Sidewalks: The loading or unloading of
passengers or drivers of vehicles across or upon a public sidewalk is hereby
expressly prohibited, and any operator or employee who, by receiving or
delivering vehicles other than within the property line of the parking lot or
garage, aids or assists in blocking any sidewalk or street and shall be deemed
to have violated the provisions of this article.
   D.   Affixing Coupons To License Plates: It shall be unlawful to affix any
parking coupon upon any vehicle so as to obliterate in whole or in part any
portion of the license plates on such vehicle.
   E.   Handbill Distribution: No person shall distribute literature or place
handbills in or upon any vehicle while parked in a parking lot or garage.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-15: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
In addition to those causes stated elsewhere in this title, any parking lot
license may be revoked for the following reasons, pursuant to the procedures
contained in chapter 1 of this title:
   A.   The licensee knowingly violates or knowingly permits or countenances
the violation of any provision of this article;
   B.   The licensee has made any charge for parking or storing a vehicle other
than those set forth in his license application;
   C.   The licensee knowingly violates or knowingly permits or countenances
the violation of any provision of any penal law or ordinance regarding theft,
larceny or conversion of a motor vehicle or the operation of a motor vehicle
without the owner’s consent, whether the licensee or other person has been
convicted of such offense or not; and
   D.   The licensee fails to keep an attendant on duty during the times
specified on his application.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15F-16:   MORATORIUM ON THE INSTALLATION OF NEW ELECTRIC VEHICLE CHARGING
STATIONS IN PARKING GARAGE STRUCTURES:
Notwithstanding any other provisions of the Village of Rosemont's Code of
Ordinances or any applicable Building Code, there shall be a temporary
moratorium preventing the installation or approval or permitting of any new
electric vehicle charging station in any parking garage structure located in
the Village of Rosemont for the period from March 10, 2025 through and
including September 30, 2025. This moratorium is in place in order to protect
against the hazards caused by the risk of fires in electric vehicles while they
are being charged within a parking structure. Existing electric charging
stations located within parking structures prior to March 10, 2025 may continue
to operate. This moratorium may be extended if the electric vehicle industry
has not come up with safety improvements designed to sufficiently safeguard
against the occurrence of runaway fires in electric vehicles that are charging.
This section shall be applicable to both Commercial Parking Garages and all
other single-family and multi-family residential parking structures.
(Ord. 2025-3-10D, 3-10-2025)
 
ARTICLE G: MOTOR VEHICLE TOWING, STORAGE AND WRECKING
Section
4-15G-1:   Definitions
4-15G-2:   License Required
4-15G-3:   Qualifications Of Licensee
4-15G-4:   Application For License
4-15G-5:   Structural Evidence Required
4-15G-6:   License Fee
4-15G-7:   Contents Of License
4-15G-8:   Prohibited Locations
4-15G-9:   Towing Unauthorized Vehicles
4-15G-10:   Rules And Regulations For Maintenance Of Premises
4-15G-11:   Lost Or Stolen Vehicles
4-15G-12:   Inspections
4-15G-13:   Revocation Or Denial Of License
4-15G-14:   Penalty
4-15G-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
AUTHORIZING A TOW: To authorize a tow or approve a tow by someone with
authority to authorize or approve a tow.
BUSINESS: The motor vehicle towing, storage and/or wrecking business.
FENCE: Any place for the purchase, reception or keeping of stolen goods or
motor vehicles.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Among other things, automobile, car, truck, bus, motorcycle,
motor bicycle, scooter, moped, van, carriage, cab, sedan, coupe, motorcar,
wagon, taxi and motorbus and all other species of self-propelled vehicles
operated by gasoline and/or any kind of oil, steam, electricity, alcohol,
gasohol or other substance or method that are operated on the public ways of
the Village of Rosemont.
OPERATOR: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or entity that has been
issued a license under this article, and their authorized agents.
OWNER: The owner, agent or lessee, or any other person in possession or in
control of the premises.
PERSON: Any natural person, partnership, corporation or towing firm.
PREMISES: The location at or on which is situated a motor vehicle towing,
storage and/or wrecking business.
STORAGE YARD OR WRECKING YARD: That enclosed area on the premises where towed
vehicles are stored, wrecked or demolished.
TOW: That event which takes place when the towing vehicle is attached to the
towed vehicle.
TOW VEHICLE: Any vehicle used by an operator or his/its authorized agent to tow
or otherwise transport a vehicle to the premises.
TOWING FIRM: Any individual, partnership, corporation, or association of
individuals in the business of towing vehicles.
UNAUTHORIZED VEHICLE ON PRIVATE PROPERTY: Any vehicle parked or abandoned on
private property without the consent of the property owner or his authorized
agent, or any vehicle parked or abandoned on private property in violation of
any provisions of this Code.
VILLAGE: The Village of Rosemont.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall be an operator of nor conduct “business”, as defined in
section 4-15G-1 of this article, without being first licensed for such purpose
by the Village. Licenses shall be issued on an annual basis.
   B.   Every person who shall keep, maintain or conduct more than one
“business”, as defined in section 4-15G-1 of this article, shall procure a
separate license for each such business. A separate business license shall be
procured by every prospective operator for each separate business located on
separate premises.
   C.   When a business located upon the same or contiguous or adjoining
premises is kept, maintained or conducted by the same person, such business
shall be considered as one business, and only one license shall be required
therefor.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-3: QUALIFICATIONS OF LICENSEE:
The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall grant licenses to
such persons as shall produce to him satisfactory evidence of good character or
reputable standing to keep, maintain or conduct business in compliance with
this article.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a business license under this article shall be made in
conformity with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications
for licenses. In addition, the application shall describe the premises where
the business is to be conducted, shall state that the applicant will observe
and comply with all provisions of this Code now in force or which may hereafter
be passed respecting motor vehicle towing, storage, and/or wrecking businesses,
and shall meet all other requirements of this article.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-5: STRUCTURAL EVIDENCE REQUIRED:
Prior to the issuance of any license under this article, the prospective
operator shall present satisfactory evidence to the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department that there is constricted and maintained on the premises a
permanent, substantial, solid structure in accordance with the building
provisions of this Code and the Village with a minimum of one thousand (1,000)
square feet of area with adequate running water and plumbing facilities.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-6: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for an operator’s license shall be as set forth in the Village
Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1B of this Code.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983; amd. 2019 Code)
4-15G-7: CONTENTS OF LICENSE:
Every license granted to an operator shall designate the house, store, place,
building, warehouse, yard, or enclosure in which the person receiving the
license shall be authorized to conduct or operate such business, and such
business shall not be conducted or operated in any place other than the place
designated in the license.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-8: PROHIBITED LOCATIONS:
   A.   No person shall locate, establish, conduct or maintain any business
within four hundred feet (400') of a church, hospital, or public or parochial
school, such distance to be measured by the shortest straight line between the
business sought to be located, established, conducted or maintained, and any
such building used for the purpose of a church, hospital, or public or
parochial school.
   B.   No person shall locate, establish, conduct or maintain any business in
any block in which two-thirds (2/3) of the buildings on both sides of each
street are used exclusively for residence, or for residence and wholesale, or
retail store purposes, or exclusively for wholesale or retail store purposes,
without the written consent of the majority of the property owners according to
frontage on both sides of the street; provided, that in determining whether
two-thirds (2/3) of the buildings on both sides of the street in such block are
used exclusively for residence, or residence and wholesale, or retail store
purposes, any building fronting upon another street and located upon the corner
lot shall not be considered; and provided further, that the word “block”, as
used in this subsection, shall not be held to mean a square, but shall be held
to embrace only that part of the street in question which lies between the two
(2) nearest intersecting streets on either side of the lot on which such
business is to be located, established, maintained or conducted.
   C.   The written consent of the property owners shall be filed with the
Director of the Health and Licensing Department, who shall cause an inspection
of the premises to be made and shall cause a verification of such written
consents of the property owners to be made, and if, upon such inspection and
verification, the Director shall find that there has been compliance with this
section, this Code and the ordinances of the Village in respect to buildings,
he shall issue a license for the location, establishment, conduct or
maintenance of such business after receipt of the applicable fee under this
article.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-9: TOWING UNAUTHORIZED VEHICLES:
   A.   Notice Of Tow; Information Required: Within one-half (1/2) hour after
towing any unauthorized vehicle from private property, any person towing a
vehicle from private property or his agent or employee shall notify the
Department of Public Safety by using the emergency Department of Public Safety
telephone number to report the year, make, model and State license plate number
of the vehicle, and the location from which the vehicle was towed. In addition
to this notification, within twenty four (24) hours after towing an
unauthorized vehicle from private property, the towing firm or its agent shall
submit a written report to the Superintendent of Public Safety containing the
following information:
      1.   Name, address and telephone number of the towing firm and of the
person or persons making the tow;
      2.   State license plate number of the vehicle towed;
      3.   Color, make, and model of the towed vehicle;
      4.   Date and time of towing;
      5.   Address of place from which the vehicle was towed;
      6.   Names and addresses of any witnesses to the towing;
      7.   Name of the person with whom the towing agreement was made;
      8.   Address of the place where the vehicle is stored; and
      9.   State license plate number of the tow truck which made the tow.
   B.   Consent To Tow; Exceptions: Before a towing firm may remove an
unauthorized vehicle from private property, the firm must first obtain written
consent from the owner of the private property or his authorized agent to
remove the specific vehicle in question, unless the firm has an agreement to
remove all unauthorized vehicles from said private property. This subsection
shall not apply to driveways or parking areas that serve three (3) cars or
fewer.
   C.   Agreement For Towing: When any owner enters into an agreement with a
towing firm to remove unauthorized vehicles from his private parking area,
before a tow is made, the towing firm shall post a notice of this arrangement
prominently at all entrances and exits to the parking areas, in clear view,
free from interference from any natural or manmade objects. The lettering on
these signs shall be in prominent type at least three inches (3") high, and in
a color that contrasts with the background color of the sign. The sign must
also be legible at night. The sign shall contain the following information:
      1.   A general statement indicating who is allowed to park in the area.
The statement may use classes of persons as well as individuals;
      2.   A warning that unauthorized vehicles will be towed;
      3.   The name, address, and telephone number of the towing firm and the
location to which the car will be towed, if different;
      4.   The fee charged by the towing firm to recover the vehicle and
whether cash, check or credit cards will be accepted in payment.
   D.   Voluntary Removal By Owner: No vehicle may be towed by any person from
private property if the owner or other person entitled to possession of the
vehicle is present and offers to remove the vehicle voluntarily prior to the
time such person attempting to tow removes the vehicle from the premises in
question; provided, that the owner or other person so removes the vehicle
immediately thereupon.
   E.   Insurance Requirements: No person shall tow any vehicle from private
property nor shall any person accept in storage a vehicle towed from private
property unless, at the time of the tow, there shall be insurance in effect in
the name of such person covering damage in an amount required by the Village.
   F.   Penalties: Any person, or any officer of any corporation, or any
partner or any partnership making a tow or authorizing a tow in violation of
any provisions of this section shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the
first offense and not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) nor more
than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for the second each
subsequent offense. Repeated offenses in excess of three (3) may also be
punishable as a misdemeanor by incarceration in the County Jail for a term not
to exceed six (6) months under the procedure set forth in section 1-2-1.1 of
the Illinois Municipal Code and under the provisions of the Illinois Code of
Criminal Procedure (725 ILCS 5/100-1 et seq.) in a separate proceeding. Any
person or any officer of any corporation, if such person is a corporation and
the corporation has been guilty of such repeated offenses, or any partner of
any partnership, if such person is a partnership and the partnership has been
guilty of such repeated offenses, shall be subject to incarceration as
aforesaid.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-10: RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR MAINTENANCE OF PREMISES:
   A.   Nuisance And Health Conditions:
      1.   The premises shall at all times be maintained so as not to
constitute a nuisance or menace to the health, safety, welfare and/or morals of
the community or residents nearby or a place for the breeding of rodents and
vermin.
      2.   All premises shall be kept in a clean condition, free from any
nuisance; also, free as far as practicable, from all gases, vapors, dust, or
other impurities generated by wrecking or demolition processes or the operation
of motors or other machinery, or otherwise, which are injurious to health.
   B.   Storage Of Garbage, Refuse And Flammables: No garbage or other organic
waste and no paper, rubbish, tags or other flammable articles or materials
shall be stored in or on the premises.
   C.   Stagnant Water And Access To Firefighters: The manner of storage,
wrecking, demolition and arrangement of motor vehicles on the premises shall be
such as to prevent the accumulation of stagnant water, gasoline and oil upon
the premises, and to facilitate access for firefighting purposes.
   D.   Enclosed Premises: All outdoor storage facilities shall be enclosed in
a substantial, solid, secure, nontransparent fence not less than eight feet
(8') nor more than ten feet (10') high. Such enclosure shall at all times be
painted and kept in good order.
   E.   Containment Of Wastes Or Materials: No materials or wastes shall be
deposited on the premises in such form or manner that they may be transferred
off such premises by natural causes or forces.
   F.   Storage Of Vehicles In Front Of Enclosure: No motor vehicles shall be
stored or wrecked in front of the enclosure provided in subsection D of this
section.
   G.   Burning: No person shall burn on the premises any material, including
rubber tires, batteries and rubber from wires which may cause fumes or odors
injurious to the health, safety and welfare of the community.
   H.   Compliance With Fire Regulations: All businesses shall be conducted and
operated in accordance with the fire regulations of this Code and shall be
inspected by the Deputy Chief of the Bureau of Fire Suppression or his duly
authorized representative at least once every six (6) months.
   I.   Sanitation Facilities: Sufficient and separate water closets shall be
provided for male and female employees on the premises, and such water closet
compartments shall be properly ventilated.
   J.   Recordkeeping: It is hereby made the duty of each operator to keep for
public inspection a record of the license numbers and engine numbers of all
motor vehicles taken in or held in charge by the operator for the purpose of
sale, rental, livery, storage, or repair.
   K.   Inspections: The Village shall inspect all such premises within the
Village as often as it shall deem necessary to see that there is compliance
with the provisions of this article, and if it finds such premises in an
unsanitary or unsafe condition, it shall require such alterations or
arrangements to be made as may be necessary for the safety and health of the
employees, pursuant to the provisions of this article, other provisions of this
Code, and such laws of the State as may be in force concerning health and
sanitary measures.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-11: LOST OR STOLEN VEHICLES:
   A.   Every operator who shall receive or be in possession of any goods,
articles, things, or motor vehicles which may have been lost or stolen, or are
alleged or supposed to have been lost or stolen, shall forthwith on demand
exhibit the same to any member of the Department of Public Safety.
   B.   Whenever there shall be filed with the Department of Public Safety, by
the operator, or authorized agent of the operator, a sworn written statement
that the operator or the agent has reason to believe that certain stolen motor
vehicles, goods or things specifically described in the sworn statement are in
the possession of any operator, any member of the Department of Public Safety
shall have the right to inspect the premises of the operator at any reasonable
hour and view all motor vehicles, goods or things which have been towed,
received, collected, or stored in the premises occupied by the business.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-12: INSPECTIONS:
The places of business and all motor vehicles towed, collected or stored by any
operator shall, at all reasonable times, be subject to inspection by the
Village or any member of the Department of Public Safety.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-13: REVOCATION OR DENIAL OF LICENSE:
   A.   The license of any operator who shall have been convicted of keeping,
maintaining or conducting a “fence” shall, upon such conviction, be revoked by
the Village, as provided in this title.
   B.   No person who shall have been convicted of keeping, maintaining or
conducting a “fence” shall be granted a license as an operator during the
period of one year after such conviction.
   C.   No corporation which shall have been convicted of keeping, maintaining
or conducting a “fence” shall be granted a license as an operator during the
period of one year after such conviction.
   D.   No corporation, any one of whose officers, stockholders or employees
has been convicted of keeping, maintaining or conducting a “fence” shall be
granted a license as an operator during a period of one year after such
