conviction, unless the corporation shall produce satisfactory evidence to the
Village that the officer, stockholder or employee has disposed of his entire
interest in the corporation and has completely severed his connection with the
corporation.
   E.   Every person applying for a license as an operator shall state in his
written application, under oath, that he has not kept, maintained or conducted,
and that he has not been convicted of keeping, maintaining or conducting, a
“fence” within one year prior to the date of the application.
   F.   Every corporation making application for a license as an operator shall
state in its written application through an authorized agent, under oath, that
it has not, nor has any of its officers, stockholders or employees kept,
maintained or conducted and that it has not, nor has any of its officers,
stockholders or employees been convicted of keeping, maintaining or conducting
a “fence” during the period of one year prior to the date of the application.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
4-15G-14: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, where no
other penalty is provided, shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense, and every day on which such violation continues shall be regarded as
constituting a separate offense.
(Ord. 83-1-5F, 1-5-1983)
ARTICLE H: GAS STATIONS
Section
4-15H-1:   Definitions
4-15H-2:   License Required
4-15H-3:   Application For License
4-15H-4:   Investigation Of Applicant
4-15H-5:   Insurances Required; Bond In Lieu
4-15H-6:   Location
4-15H-7:   Waste Storage And Disposal
4-15H-8:   Construction, Equipment And Safety
4-15H-9:   Metal Lockers Required
4-15H-10:   Restricted And Prohibited Acts
4-15H-11:   Self-Service Gas Stations
4-15H-12:   Inspections
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-15H-1: DEFINITIONS:
The term “gas station”, as used in this article, is hereby defined as any
building, structure, premises, enclosure, or other place within the Village
where a container or containers, tank or tanks, either portable or stationary,
and containing ether, carbon bisulfite, gasoline, naphtha, benzol, hydrocarbon
(gas drips), liquefied petroleum gas, acetone, kerosene, turpentine, or other
flammable liquids having a flashpoint below one hundred sixty five degrees
Fahrenheit (165°F) are kept or located for the purpose of selling, offering for
sale, or distributing any such liquids from such container or tank; provided,
however, that the provisions of this article shall not apply to any place where
such flammable liquids are kept or sold for medicinal purposes only.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15H-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of a gas station without first having
obtained a license therefor.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15H-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a license shall be made in conformity with the general
requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses. The applicant
shall also specify the capacity in gallons of every container or tank installed
or to be installed upon the premises.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15H-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
Every application shall be investigated by the Public Safety Department and
Director of Building and Code Enforcement to determine whether there is
compliance with the applicable provisions of this Code and the approval of such
officers noted thereon, before a license shall be issued.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15H-5: INSURANCES REQUIRED; BOND IN LIEU:
   A.   Every applicant for a license under this article shall carry public
liability and property damage insurance and workers’ compensation insurance for
employees with responsible insurers authorized to transact insurance business
in the State of Illinois, to secure payment of any loss or damage resulting
from an occurrence arising out of or caused by the operation of the business
herein licensed as required by the Village. Said insurance shall provide for
the payment and satisfaction of any final judgment rendered against the owner
or operator of a licensed business, and that suit may be brought in any court
of competent jurisdiction upon such policy by any person having claims arising
from the operation of such business.
   B.   In lieu of an insurance policy or contract, a surety bond or bonds with
a corporate surety or sureties authorized to do business under the laws of the
State of Illinois may be accepted for all or any part of such insurance;
provided, that each bond shall be conditioned for the payment and satisfaction
of any final judgment in conformity with the provisions of an insurance policy
as required by this section.
(Ord. 76-11-3A, 11-3-1976)
4-15H-6: LOCATION:
   A.   Prohibited Locations: No tank, container, pipe or other equipment for
the storage and handling of flammable liquids shall be installed within two
hundred feet (200') of the nearest boundary of any lot or plot of ground used
for a school, hospital, church, or theater.
   B.   Frontage Consents Required: No person shall locate, construct, or
maintain any gas station in connection with which there is installed any tank
for the storage of flammable liquids on any lot or plot of ground without first
obtaining the written consents of the property owners representing the majority
of the total frontage in feet of any lot or plot of ground lying wholly or in
part within lines one hundred fifty feet (150') distant from and parallel to
the boundaries of the entire lot or plot of ground to be used for and with such
gas station, driveways and enclosing fences, if any; provided, however, that
for the purpose of this section, only the frontage of any such lot or plot of
ground or that part of the frontage of any part of such lot or plot of ground
as comes within the one hundred fifty foot (150') limit herein prescribed shall
be considered; and provided, further, that any and all petitions containing
such consents of property owners shall be based on and contain the legal
description of the property affected, and that, for the purposes of this
section, whenever the lot or plot of ground in which such tank is to be
installed is in any shape other than a rectangle, the one hundred fifty foot
(150') limiting line aforementioned shall not exceed in distance one hundred
fifty feet (150') from any point of the boundaries of such lot or plot of
ground.
   C.   Change Of Location: If any person licensed to engage in the business of
a gas station shall, before the expiration of such license, desire to change
the location of the business engaged in thereunder, the licensee shall notify
the Director of the Health and Licensing Department, and shall furnish all of
the information which is required to be furnished on an original application
for a license. Every such application for change of location shall be approved
by the Superintendent of Public Safety and the Director of Building and Code
Enforcement before a change in location shall be authorized, and the new
location shall be subject to the same conditions and restrictions as are
prescribed for the premises for which the license was first issued.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15H-7: WASTE STORAGE AND DISPOSAL:
   A.   Waste oil or other flammable liquids shall be stored in metal
containers pending removal from the premises.
   B.   No such waste shall be permitted to drain into any sewers or stormwater
drainage system.
   C.   Rags and soiled waste shall be kept in metal containers.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15H-8: CONSTRUCTION, EQUIPMENT AND SAFETY CLEARANCES:
The construction and equipment of gas stations, including tanks and the
requirements for safety clearances around same, shall be made and maintained in
accordance with the provisions of this Code regulating buildings and flammable
liquids.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15H-9: METAL LOCKERS REQUIRED:
Lockers for employee clothing shall be of metal.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15H-10: RESTRICTED AND PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Smoking: It shall be unlawful for any person to permit smoking in any
gas station.
   B.   Use Of Flammable Liquids: Gasoline, benzine, naphtha and similar
flammable liquids shall not be used for washing or cleaning purposes within any
gas station nor in the open air within a distance of fifty feet (50') of any
repair pit or any opening from any basement space.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-15H-11: SELF-SERVICE GAS STATIONS:
   A.    Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
   PERSON: Any individual, corporation, company, firm, partnership, association
or group, trust or beneficiary thereof.
   SELF-SERVICE STATION: That portion of property where flammable and
combustible liquids used as motor fuels are stored and subsequently dispensed
from fixed approved dispensing equipment into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles
by persons other than the service station attendant.
   B.   Self-Service Dispensing Devices Permitted; Supervision: Approved self-
service dispensing devices are permitted at service stations available and open
to the public; provided, that all dispensing of motor fuels, except LPG, by a
person other than the service station attendant, is under the supervision and
control of a qualified attendant, and the dispensing nozzle is a listed
automatic losing type without a latch-open device.
   C.   Permit Required; Display Of Permit: No self-service station shall open
for business without first having a permit therefor, which permit must be
displayed prominently at all times at such self-service station.
   D.   Investigation of Applicant; Conditions Of Permit: Every application
shall be investigated by the Superintendent of Public Safety and the Director
of Building and Code Enforcement to determine whether there is compliance with
the applicable provisions of this Code and the approval of such offices noted
thereon, before a permit shall be issued. No such permit may be issued unless
the applicant has been issued a gas station license in accordance with the
provisions of this Code.
   E.   Rules: The following rules shall be followed and observed at all self-
service stations:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to provide for or use live-in facilities or
accommodations for the benefit of any owner, operator or employee of a self-
service station on the premises of the station.
      2.   All self-service stations shall have at least one attendant on duty
while the station is open to the public. The attendant’s primary function shall
be to supervise, observe and control the dispensing of Class I liquids while
said liquids are actually being dispensed. This shall not be interpreted as
prohibiting a split-island type of operation.
      3.   The dispensing area shall at all times be in clear view of the
attendant, and the placing or allowing of any obstacle to come between the
dispensing area and the attendant control area shall be prohibited. The
attendant shall at all times be able to communicate with persons in the
dispensing area.
      4.   The attendant shall have immediate access to emergency cutoff
switches provided at a location removed from the dispensing devices, which
location shall be subject to approval by the Department of Public Safety.
      5.   The attendant shall supervise the dispensing of motor fuels, shall
refuse service to any person who is smoking or who appears, for any reason, to
be unable to dispense the motor fuel safely, and shall shut off the dispensing
unit if a patron fails to follow instructions in compliance with this section.
      6.   All attendants and other employees shall be thoroughly instructed in
the operation and use of the communication system, the control station, the
fire extinguishing equipment, the operation of the dispensing units and safety
regulations for the dispensing of motor fuels.
      7.   For minimum safety standards for the location and operation of self-
service dispensing units, dispensing pumps shall be located a minimum of ten
feet (10') inside station property lines and a maximum of five feet (5') from
any building opening.
      8.   Gasoline dispensing nozzles shall not be of the “latch-open type”.
      9.   At least one type ABC file extinguisher, with a capacity of ten (10)
pounds, shall be at the attendant’s control station.
      10.   Conspicuous and legible signs prohibiting smoking and directing
customers to turn off ignitions while dispensing motor fuel shall be posted and
maintained. The lettering on such signs shall be red on white background and
not less than four inches (4") in height. The signs shall be made of an all-
weather rigid material. The wording, lettering, size, design, material,
mounting and location of the signs shall be subject to the approval of the
Department of Public Safety.
      11.   Dispensing units shall be mounted either on a concrete island or
protected against collision damage by suitable means in a manner approved by
the Department of Public Safety.
      12.   No portable containers of more than six (6) gallons shall be filled
with gasoline, except as dispensed directly into the fuel tanks attached to a
motor vehicle. All portable receptacles for gasoline shall be red and shall be
labeled in letters of a contrasting color and a height of not less than one-
half inches (1/2"), and it shall be unlawful to put any other liquids or oils,
except gasoline, in such receptacles are so painted and labeled “gasoline”. In
all circumstances, the container shall be metal.
(Ord. 77-3-16A, 3-16-1977)
4-15H-12: INSPECTIONS:
Gas stations shall be inspected by the designated Village personnel.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 16: BUSINESSES DEALING WITH FLAMMABLE, HAZARDOUS MATERIALS
ARTICLE A: FLAMMABLE AND HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS
Section
4-16A-1:   Acetylene Gas
4-16A-1-1:   Generation Of Acetylene Gas
4-16A-1-2:   Portable Generators Of Acetylene Gas
4-16A-1-3:   Compression Or Sale Of Acetylene Gas
4-16A-2:   Generation Or Compression Of Hydrogen Or Oxygen
4-16A-3:   Storage Of Calcium Carbide
4-16A-4:   Nitrocellulose And Nitrocellulose Products
4-16A-5:   Miscellaneous Flammables And Hazardous Materials
4-16A-6:    Investigations, Inspections And Tests
4-16A-7:   Revocation Of Licenses
Cross-reference:
   See subsections
3-10-1  of this Code for license and permit fees
4-16A-1: ACETYLENE GAS:
4-16A-1-1: GENERATION OF ACETYLENE GAS:
   A.   License Required: No person shall generate acetylene gas in any form of
generator, holder, container or associated apparatus at a pressure of not to
exceed fifteen (15) pounds to the square inch in the generator without first
obtaining a license therefor.
   B.   Application For License: An application for said license shall be in
writing and shall conform to the general requirements of this title relating to
applications for licenses, and shall set forth the proposed location of the
generator or generators, together with the name and type of generator or
generators to be used.
   C.   Investigation Of Applicant: Upon receipt of such application, the
Superintendent of Public Safety shall make or cause to be made an investigation
for the purpose of ascertaining whether the generator or generators are of a
type and so located that they would not be so dangerous as to constitute a
nuisance or be a menace to the safety of the employees, the public, or the
adjoining property.
   D.   Regulations:
      1.   Marking Generators: Generators shall be plainly marked with the
maximum rate in cubic feet of acetylene per hour for which they are designed,
the amount of carbide necessary for a single charge, the manufacturer's name
and address, and the name and number of the type of machine.
      2.   Warning Cards: Printed warning and instruction cards provided by the
maker shall be posted in a conspicuous position near the generator so that the
operator may consult them conveniently from time to time.
      3.   Repairs: Any necessary repairs to the generator or system shall be
made during daylight hours by natural light or by the fixed lights in the
generator room. The use of portable lights is strictly prohibited.
      4.   Appliances: All blow torches, regulators and other appliances shall
be maintained in good condition at all times. No appliances shall be installed
in any line which causes or allows the mixture of air or other oxygen carrier
with acetylene, except directly at the torch or burner. The use of an expansion
tank or tanks in any part of the system is prohibited.
      5.   Housing Generators: Stationary acetylene gas generators shall be
installed in a suitable building which shall be constructed and maintained in
accordance with the building provisions of this Code applicable to buildings
housing such apparatus.
   E.   Exemptions From Provisions: The provisions of this section relating to
the generation of acetylene gas shall not apply to portable generators used
exclusively for lighting, to generators used in connection with vehicle
lighting, or to plants devoted to the manufacture and compression of dissolved
acetylene for sale purposes.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16A-1-2: PORTABLE GENERATORS OF ACETYLENE GAS:
   A.   Definition: The term “portable generator”, as used in this section, is
hereby defined as an acetylene generator, of not more than thirty (30) pounds
carbide capacity, which has been approved for portable use by the Underwriters
Laboratories.
   B.   Permit Required; Inspection; Issuance: Portable generators shall not be
installed or used inside of buildings unless a permit for such use in said
location shall first be secured. It shall be the duty of the Deputy Chief of
the Bureau of Fire Suppression to inspect the premises wherein such generator
is to be used before issuing such permit. Should the inspection show that there
is compliance with the provisions of this section, the Deputy Chief shall issue
a permit for such installation and use.
   C.   Location In Rooms:
      1.   Portable generators shall not be used in rooms of total volume less
than thirty five (35) times the nominal aggregate gas generating capacity, per
hour, of all such generators in the room.
      2.   Portable generators shall not be used in any room containing
flammable liquids or gases, or in which any dust producing process is carried
on, or in which any highly combustible or explosive materials are contained.
Portable generators shall not be used in any poorly ventilated room.
   D.   Restrictions On Operation:
      1.   Before any cutting or welding operation begins, the floor shall be
swept clean and, if of wood, shall be sprinkled with water. The scene of such
work shall be inspected thirty (30) minutes after every such cutting or welding
operation, and all smoldering sparks shall be extinguished.
      2.   Extra gas cylinders shall not be stored in the same room in which a
portable generator is used.
      3.   Generators shall be cleaned and recharged and the air mixture shall
be blown off outside of the building. Generators, when charged, shall not be
moved by crane or derrick. When not in use, they shall not be stored in any
room in which open lights or fires are used unless free of carbide and
thoroughly purged of gas.
      4.   Storage rooms for portable generators shall be thoroughly
ventilated.
      5.   Cutting or welding operations shall not be carried on within ten
feet (10') of any combustible material other than the floor.
      6.   Generators shall not be placed where water will freeze. Salt or
other corrosive chemicals shall not be used as a protection against freezing.
      7.   Not more than one cutting or welding flame shall be used with any
portable generator unless permanently attached and piped.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16A-1-3: COMPRESSION OR SALE OF ACETYLENE GAS:
   A.   License Required: Except as herein otherwise provided, no person shall
engage in the business of collecting or compressing acetylene gas at any
pressure in excess of fifteen (15) pounds to the square inch, or of selling or
distributing acetylene gas at any pressure in excess of fifteen (15) pounds to
the square inch, or of selling or distributing acetylene gas under pressure,
unless such person shall have first procured a license so to do.
   B.   Application For License: An application for the license shall be made
in conformity with the general requirements of this title relating to
applications for licenses. The application shall set forth the location and
description of the building in which such business is to be carried on.
   C.   The application shall be referred to the Department of Public Safety,
which shall cause an inspection to be made to determine whether the location,
buildings, premises, machinery and equipment comply with the provisions of this
Code applicable thereto.
   D.   Nontransferability Of License: Every license shall be nontransferable
and shall be good only at the location named in the license.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16A-2: GENERATION OR COMPRESSION OF HYDROGEN OR OXYGEN:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to generate or
compress oxygen or hydrogen in any form of generator, holder, container, or
associated apparatus without first obtaining a license so to do.
   B.   Application For License: An application for the license shall be made
in conformity with the general requirements of this title relating to
applications for licenses and shall give the proposed location of such
generator or generators, holders, containers and associated apparatus, together
with the name and type of the equipment to be used.
   C.   Investigation Of Applicant: Upon receipt of the application, the
Department of Public Safety shall cause to be made an investigation for the
purpose of ascertaining whether the apparatus and equipment is of such type and
so located that it would not constitute a nuisance or be a menace to the safety
of the employees or to the public or to adjoining property.
   D.   Oxygen Containers:
      1.   Cylinders of oxygen shall never be stored in the same room or
compartment used for the storage of calcium carbide, or cylinders containing
fuel gases, or in an acetylene generator compartment.
      2.   Cylinders of oxygen, except those in actual use, shall be stored
away from highly flammable material, especially oil, grease or any substance
likely to cause or accelerate fire.
      3.   Cylinders of oxygen shall be stored in locations where they are not
likely to be stuck by passing or falling objects.
      4.   Cylinders of oxygen shall be protected against excessive rise of
temperature, may be stored in the open, but in such cases, shall be protected
against extremes of weather and during winter, if stored in the open, shall be
protected against accumulations of ice or snow.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16A-3: STORAGE OF CALCIUM CARBIDE:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or store
calcium carbide in excess of six hundred (600) pounds within the Village
without first obtaining a license so to do for each location where such
quantity of calcium carbide is to be kept or stored.
   B.   Application For License: An application for the license shall be made
in writing and shall conform to the general provisions of this title relating
to applications for licenses. The application shall set forth the location,
plans and description of the building in which such calcium carbide is to be
kept or stored, and the quantity to be so stored.
   C.   Approval Of Application; Issuance Of License; Fee: Every application
shall be approved by the Director of Building and Code Enforcement and the
Department of Public Safety before a license is issued. If it shall appear from
the application so filed and approved that the premises in which the applicant
proposes to keep or store such calcium carbide conforms to the requirements of
this Code, then, upon the payment by the applicant to the Director of the
Health and Licensing Department of the license fee as set forth in the Village
Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1B of this Code, entry reading “flammable and
hazardous chemical handling”, there shall be issued a license authorizing the
applicant to keep and store calcium carbide in the place designated in the
license for the period therein stated.
   D.    Method Of Storage:
      1. Calcium carbide in quantities not to exceed six hundred (600) pounds
may be stored, when contained in approved metal packages, inside of buildings
used for other purposes; provided, that the place of storage shall be dry,
waterproof and well ventilated; and provided also, that all but one of the
packages of each size of carbide shall be sealed, and the seals shall not be
broken so long as there is carbide in excess of one pound in any other unsealed
package in the building.
      2. Calcium carbide in excess of six hundred (600) pounds shall be stored
in accordance with the building provisions of this Code.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16A-4: NITROCELLULOSE AND NITROCELLULOSE PRODUCTS:
   A.   Definition: The term "nitrocellulose products", when used in this
section, is hereby defined to mean any substance, material or compound having
soluble cotton, or similar nitrocellulose, as a basis, including pyralin,
celluloid, viscoloid, X-ray film, and similar materials and compounds by
whatever name known, whether the raw or finished product, excepting motion
picture films.
   B.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture,
store or keep any nitrocellulose products in excess of twenty five (25) pounds
without first obtaining a license therefor.
   C.   Application For License: An application for the license shall be made
in conformity with the general requirements of this Code relating to
applications for licenses, and shall state the amount and kind of
nitrocellulose products to be stored or manufactured and the address where same
shall be kept.
   D.   Regulations:
      1.   Location: It shall be unlawful for any person to store or
manufacture nitrocellulose products in any building which is situated within
one hundred feet (100') of any building occupied as a school building, hospital
or any other place of public assembly or amusement.
      2.   Heating Products: Softening or heating nitrocellulose products when
not done by hot water shall be done on steam or electric heaters, dies, and so
forth, with at least six inches (6") clearance to all combustible material.
      3.   Machinery Used:
         a.   Stamping, perforating and similar machines shall be equipped with
a metal receptacle containing water for receiving waste material.
         b.   Metal receptacles with automatic or self-closing covers shall be
provided for nitrocellulose scraps and clippings, and said scraps and clippings
shall be removed from the premises each evening and disposed of in a manner
approved by the Department of Public Safety.
   E.   Inspections: The Department of Public Safety shall cause to be
inspected the building, process of manufacture, and storage of nitrocellulose
products at the premises described in the application to determine whether
there has been compliance with the provisions of this Code applicable thereto.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16A-5: MISCELLANEOUS FLAMMABLES AND HAZARDOUS MATERIALS:
   A.   Liquid Acetylene: The manufacture, transportation, storage, sale or use
of liquefied acetylene is hereby prohibited within the corporate limits of the
Village.
   B.   Chlorine Gas:
      1.   The sale, storage, use or handling of chlorine gas is hereby
prohibited within the limits of the Village unless chlorine gas is stored in
buildings constructed and maintained in accordance with the building provisions
of this Code in containers constructed in compliance with the Interstate
Commerce Commission rules and regulations.
      2.   No combustible material of any kind shall be placed or kept in any
room or building used for the storage of chlorine gas.
   C.   Corrosive Liquids:
      1.   No corrosive liquids shall be stored in any building other than a
corrosive liquids storage building constructed as required by this Code, except
as otherwise provided by this subsection.
      2.   It shall be permissible to store corrosive liquids in one or more
standard fireproof vaults in any building other than a corrosive liquids
storage building.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16A-6: INVESTIGATIONS, INSPECTIONS AND TESTS:
The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall have power to make or
cause to be made all investigations, inspections and tests which are necessary
to enforce the provisions of this article, and all buildings, rooms, premises
and equipment mentioned and referred to in this article shall comply with the
applicable provisions of the Fire Code and, for the enforcement of this
article, shall be open at all times to periodical inspection, investigation and
tests by the Department of Public Safety.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16A-7: REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
Any license which may be granted under the provisions of this article may, upon
recommendation of the Superintendent of Public Safety or otherwise, be revoked
for any good and sufficient cause.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
ARTICLE B: STORAGE AND HANDLING OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS
Section
4-16B-1:   License Required; Exemptions
4-16B-2:   Application For License
4-16B-3:   Investigation Of Applicant
4-16B-4:   Insurances Required; Bond In Lieu
4-16B-5:   Regulations
4-16B-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
No person shall keep on hand or store for use in any business any flammable
liquid having a flashpoint below one hundred eighty seven degrees Fahrenheit
(187°F) (86°C), closed cup tester, without first procuring a license so to do
for each location, place or premises where such person keeps on hand or stores
for use any such flammable liquid. Provided, however, that nothing herein
contained shall require any gasoline station; dry cleaner and spotter; drug,
chemical or paint factory; drug, chemical or paint store; fuel oil dealer; fuel
oil storer; wholesale gasoline dealer; retail hardware store; or retail paint
store, duly licensed under any other provisions of this Code, to obtain a
license hereunder.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16B-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for license shall be made in conformity with the general
requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses and, in
addition, the applicant shall state the location of the place at which it is
desired or intended to store flammable liquids for use in the applicant's
business, the maximum aggregate quantity to be so stored for use, and shall
give a description of the business in which engaged, the location and capacity
of all containers or tanks having a capacity of fifty (50) gallons or more for
the storage of any flammable liquid, and such other information as may be
required by the Superintendent of Public Safety.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16B-3: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
The Superintendent of Public Safety, upon receipt of such application, shall
investigate or cause to be investigated the place of business described in such
application and the methods and equipment intended to be used by the applicant.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16B-4: INSURANCES REQUIRED; BOND IN LIEU:
   A.   Every applicant for a license under this article shall carry public
liability and property damage insurance and workers' compensation insurance for
employees with responsible insurers, authorized to transact insurance business
in the State of Illinois, to secure payment of any loss or damage resulting
from an occurrence arising out of or caused by the operation of the business
herein licensed in an amount as required by the Village. Said insurance shall
provide for the payment and satisfaction of any final judgment rendered against
the owner or operator of a licensed business, and that suit may be brought in
any court of competent jurisdiction upon such policy by any person having
claims arising from the operation of such business.
   B.   In lieu of an insurance policy or contract, a surety bond or bonds with
a corporate surety or sureties authorized to do business under the laws of the
State of Illinois may be accepted for all or any part of such insurance;
provided, that each bond shall be conditioned for the payment and satisfaction
of any final judgment, in conformity with the provisions of an insurance policy
as required by this section.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-16B-5: REGULATIONS:
   A.   All containers, tanks and other equipment used for the storage or use
of flammable liquids and all buildings and premises wherein the same are stored
or used shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the provisions
of the fire prevention provisions of this Code.
   B.   Every container or tank for flammable liquids of a capacity of fifty
(50) gallons or more, either aboveground or within a building, and the premises
and equipment used for the storage or handling of flammable liquids by any
person subject to license under this article, shall be inspected by the Chief
of Public Safety, or his duly authorized representative, at least once each
year.
   C.   Rags and soiled waste shall be kept in metal containers pending removal
from the premises.
   D.   No person shall smoke in that part of any premises where flammable
liquids having a flashpoint below one hundred eighty seven degrees Fahrenheit
(187°F) (86°C), closed cup tester, are stored or handled.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-197 5)
CHAPTER 17: PYROTECHNIC DISPLAYS
Section
4-17-1:   Definitions
4-17-2:   License Required; Authority To Issue
4-17-3:   Compliance With Applicable Laws; Conditions Of License Issuance
4-17-4:   Application For License
4-17-5:   License Fee
4-17-6:   Insurances Required
4-17-7:   Inspections
4-17-8:   Rules And Regulations
4-17-9:   Penalty
Cross-reference:
   See also subsection
4-7A-5 G of this title
4-17-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
FIREWORKS: Any explosive composition or any substance or combination of
substances or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or
audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by explosion, combustion,
deflagration or detonation, and shall include blank cartridges, toy cannons in
which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require fire underneath
to propel the same; firecrackers, torpedoes, sky rockets, roman candles, bombs
or other fireworks of like construction and any fireworks containing any
explosive compound; or any tablets or other device containing any explosive
substance, or containing combustible substances producing visual effects. The
term FIREWORKS shall not include snake or glow worm pellets; smoke devices;
sparklers; trick noisemakers known as “party poppers”, “booby traps”,
“snappers”, “trick matches”, “cigarette loads” and “auto burglar alarms”; toy
pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper or plastic caps
containing twenty five hundredths (0.25) grain or less of explosive compound
are used, provided they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact
with the cap when in place for the explosion, and toy pistol paper or plastic
caps which contain less than twenty five hundredths (0.25) grain of explosive
mixture, the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times.
PYROTECHNIC DISPLAY: Any use of pyrotechnics which occurs on property that is
not owned by the Village of Rosemont.
PYROTECHNIC DISPLAY LICENSE: A license which is issued by the Village of
Rosemont Department of Public Safety pursuant to section 4-17-2 of this chapter
which permits a person to present a pyrotechnic display.
PYROTECHNIC OPERATOR: Each company, association or person who will have direct
supervision over a pyrotechnic display, or direct supervision of a component of
a pyrotechnic display, such as furnishing the pyrotechnic materials or
providing or operating the equipment to be used in a pyrotechnic display.
Persons who are employees of a pyrotechnic operator shall not be considered to
be separate pyrotechnic operators.
PYROTECHNIC OR PYROTECHNICS: FIREWORKS, as defined in this section, smoke
machines, fog machines, light show displays utilizing lasers and other
materials or combination of materials utilized or intended to be utilized to
generate or simulate light beams, explosions, smoke or noise. PYROTECHNICS do
not include any item which is excluded from the definition of FIREWORKS, as set
forth in this section.
SMOKE MACHINE: A machine which generates smoke, haze or a similar airborne
substances which is intended to simulate smoke or haze. SMOKE MACHINES include,
but are not limited to, machines commonly referred to as “haze machines”.
(Ord. 98-1-14N, 1-14-1998)
4-17-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; AUTHORITY TO ISSUE:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to present a pyrotechnic display or
use pyrotechnics in any manner within the Village, except on property that is
owned by the Village, unless the Department of Public Safety has issued a
pyrotechnics display license which permits the pyrotechnic display or use of
pyrotechnics.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for the owner or person in control of any
property, other than property owned by the Village, to permit a pyrotechnic
display to occur on the property or to allow pyrotechnics to be used on the
property unless a pyrotechnics display license has been issued for such use by
the Department of Public Safety.
   C.   Pyrotechnic display licenses shall be issued, by the Village Department
of Public Safety. The Superintendent of Public Safety shall designate the
Public Safety Department personnel who are authorized to issue pyrotechnic
display licenses as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 98-1-14N, 1-14-1998)
4-17-3: COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAWS; CONDITIONS OF LICENSE ISSUANCE:
No pyrotechnic display license shall be issued unless the applicant has
complied with the provisions of this chapter and has established that the
pyrotechnic display or other use of pyrotechnics will comply with all other
applicable laws, rules and regulations. As a condition for issuance of a
pyrotechnic display license, the person applying for the license shall be
required to establish that all permits required by other governmental bodies
having jurisdiction over the use of pyrotechnics and pyrotechnic displays have
either been issued or will be issued prior to the time the pyrotechnic display
or use of pyrotechnics is scheduled to occur.
(Ord. 98-1-14N, 1-14-1998)
4-17-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
All applications for pyrotechnic display licenses shall be made in writing. The
Department of Public Safety may require that an application for a pyrotechnic
display license be made on a form provided by the Public Safety Department. All
applications for a pyrotechnic display license must include a written plan
which describes in detail the type of pyrotechnics that will be used, the
equipment that will be used and the precautions that will be taken to minimize
the likelihood of personal injury or property damage. The plan shall include
the following information:
   A.   The name of the person, group or organization sponsoring the
pyrotechnic display.
   B.   The date(s) and time(s) of the pyrotechnic display.
   C.   The exact location where the pyrotechnic display will occur.
   D.   The names and addresses of all pyrotechnic operators who will be
involved with the pyrotechnic display.
   E.   The license number and date of issuance of all licenses that have been
issued to the pyrotechnic operator(s) and to any employees or agents of the
pyrotechnic operator(s) who will be furnishing pyrotechnics or equipment for
the pyrotechnic display or who will be directly involved in the presentation of
the pyrotechnic display, including operating any equipment that is used in
presenting the pyrotechnic display.
   F.   The date and number of all licenses and permits that have been issued
by other governmental units for the pyrotechnics display or, if such licenses
or permits have been applied for but not issued, the date and status of the
application.
   G.   An insurance certificate or other proof establishing that each
pyrotechnic operator has obtained the insurance coverage required by section
4-17-6 of this chapter.
   H.   The types and amounts of pyrotechnics and the equipment that will be
used in the pyrotechnic display and an outline of the number of persons who
will be working on the pyrotechnic display and what each person's
responsibility or duties will be with respect to the pyrotechnic display.
   I.   A description of each pyrotechnic operator’s experience with the types
of pyrotechnics and the equipment that will be used in the pyrotechnic display.
   J.   A diagram of the grounds or facilities at which the pyrotechnic display
will occur. This diagram must show the point at which any pyrotechnics are to
be wired or set off, the fallout radius for each pyrotechnic device to be used
in the pyrotechnic display and the lines behind which the audience for the
pyrotechnics display shall be restrained.
   K.   The manner and place where the pyrotechnics and the equipment to be
used in the pyrotechnics display will be stored during the period before and
after the pyrotechnics display.
   L.    description of the safety measures that will be taken to reduce the
likelihood that persons or property will be injured or damaged during the
pyrotechnic display, including the measures that will be taken to protect
against personal injury or property damage in the event a pyrotechnic device or
the equipment used in the pyrotechnic display malfunctions.
(Ord. 98-1-14N, 1-14-1998)
4-17-5: LICENSE FEE:
The fee for a pyrotechnics display license shall be as set forth in the Village
Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1B of this Code, entry reading “fireworks display”.
(Ord. 98-1-14N, 1-14-1998; amd. 2019 Code)
4-17-6: INSURANCES REQUIRED:
All pyrotechnics operators who are involved in a pyrotechnics display for which
a pyrotechnics display license is issued or applied for shall carry insurance
insuring against liabilities, judgments, costs, damages and expenses which may
accrue against, be charged to or recovered from the pyrotechnics operator by
reason or on account of damage to property of, or injury to or death of, any
person arising from the pyrotechnics display. This insurance shall be carried
with insurers authorized to do business in the State of Illinois. The policy or
policies shall be in the following kinds and amounts:
   A.   Comprehensive public liability insurance: One million dollars
($1,000,000.00) per person and five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) per
occurrence, or such higher policy limits as may be required by another
applicable law, rule or regulation.
   B.   Comprehensive property damage insurance: One million dollars
($1,000,000.00) per occurrence, or such higher policy limits as may be required
by another applicable law, rule or regulation.
(Ord. 98-1-14N, 1-14-1998)
4-17-7: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   All pyrotechnics, pyrotechnic devices and equipment that are intended
to be used in a pyrotechnics display for which a pyrotechnics display license
has been issued or applied for shall be made available upon request for
inspection by authorized representatives of the Village Public Safety
Department.
   B.   The premises for which pyrotechnics display license has been applied
for or issued shall be open for inspection by authorized representatives of the
Village Public Safety Department at all reasonable times including, but not
limited to, during the period which begins three (3) hours before the
pyrotechnics display is scheduled to begin and ends one hour after the
pyrotechnics display concludes.
(Ord. 98-1-14N, 1-14-1998)
4-17-8: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Superintendent of Public Safety shall be authorized to issue rules and
regulations relating to the use pyrotechnics in the Village; provided, that
such rules and regulations shall not be less stringent than any applicable
State or Federal law, rule or regulation. The Superintendent is also authorized
to issue rules and regulations relating to the issuance of pyrotechnics display
licenses.
(Ord. 98-1-14N, 1-14-1998)
4-17-9: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any term or provision of this chapter, or any
regulation issued by the Superintendent of Public Safety pursuant to section 4-
17-8 of this chapter, shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not less
than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for each offense. Each separate twenty four (24)
hour period or part thereof in which a violation occurs shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Ord. 98-1-14N, 1-14-1998)
CHAPTER 18: FIRE EXTINGUISHER SERVICES
Section
4-18-1:   Definitions
4-18-2:   License Required
4-18-3:   Application For License
4-18-4:   Installation
4-18-5:   Inspections And Tests
4-18-6:   Tags On Extinguishers
4-18-7:   Rules And Regulations
Cross-reference:
   See subsection 3-105-1B of this Code for license fee
4-18-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
SERVICE: Where used in reference to fire extinguishers, means the inspection,
repair, recharging or testing of fire extinguishers.
SERVICEMAN: A person licensed by the Village to inspect, repair, recharge or
test fire extinguishers.
STANDARD FIRE EXTINGUISHER: A portable fire extinguisher which bears the label
of approval of a national testing laboratory acceptable to the Deputy Chief of
the Bureau of Fire Suppression.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-197 5)
4-18-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of servicing fire extinguishers unless
he shall first have obtained a license as herein provided.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-18-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Every applicant for a license as a fire extinguisher serviceman shall file with
the Superintendent of Public Safety a written application, signed by the
applicant, stating his address, age, present occupation, business activities
during the previous five (5) years, experience with the repair, recharging,
testing and use of fire extinguishers, knowledge of the ordinances pertaining
to fire extinguishers and such other information as may be deemed necessary.
Every application shall be accompanied by two (2) one inch by one inch (1" x
1") prints of a bust photograph of the applicant.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-18-4: INSTALLATION:
   A.   All standard fire extinguishers shall be installed in the manner
prescribed in NFPA No. 10 entitled “Standards for Portable Extinguishers”,
published by the National Fire Protection Association in June 1956, and as
amended, in every location where required by this Code.
   B.   Every required or nonrequired fire extinguisher, when installed, shall
be fully charged and ready for immediate use.
   C.   Where an extinguisher is likely to be obscured by piles of stock,
lumber or otherwise, a sign shall be installed and maintained which will make
the location of the extinguisher in a manner legible at a distance of at least
fifty feet (50').
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-18-5: INSPECTIONS AND TESTS:
   A.   Extinguishers shall be inspected annually, shall be recharged as
specified in NFPA No. 10, as referenced in subsection 4-18-4A of this chapter,
and maintained in good condition and ready for immediate use at all times.
   B.   Every such fire extinguisher which employs a cylinder shell at a static
or working pressure in excess of one hundred (100) pounds per square inch shall
be subjected to a hydrostatic pressure test five (5) years after the date of
manufacture and every five (5) years thereafter as prescribed in said NFPA No.
10.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-18-6: TAGS ON EXTINGUISHERS:
   A.   Every standard fire extinguisher shall have attached thereto a tag
which clearly indicates the dates of inspection and recharging, the signature
of the person performing the work, and the license number of the serviceman.
The color and form of the tag shall be determined by the Superintendent of
Public Safety; provided, however, that the color used for any one year shall be
different from the color used for the previous year. The tag shall have clearly
imprinted thereon, in numerals no less than one half inch (½") in height, the
year for which it is issued.
   B.   Every fire extinguisher which has passed the hydrostatic pressure test
as herein required shall be provided with a metal label or tag as prescribed in
NFPA No. 10.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-18-7: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Department of Public Safety, in its discretion, may make or cause to be
made an inspection of the contents and working condition of any fire
extinguisher, and may promulgate such reasonable rules and regulations as he
deems necessary to carry out the purposes of the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 19: HEALTH RELATED BUSINESSES
ARTICLE A: LABORATORIES
Section
4-19A-1:   Definition
4-19A-2:   License Required
4-19A-3:   Application For License
4-19A-4:   Investigation Of Applicant
4-19A-5:   Sanitary And Safety Conditions
4-19A-6:   Reports Required
4-19A-7:    Inspections
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-19A-1: DEFINITION:
The word LABORATORY, when used in this article, shall mean any building, place
or establishment maintained or operated for the purpose of making medical,
bacteriological, pathological, physiological, serological, chemical,
industrial, agricultural, physical, optical, veterinary, pharmaceutical,
engineering, electrical, X-ray, or other scientific examinations, analyses,
determinations, or experiments.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-19A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct or operate any laboratory or laboratory agency for a
fee without first having obtained a license therefor.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-19A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a laboratory license shall be made in conformity with the
general requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses. In
addition, the applicant shall describe the premises where such business is to
be conducted.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-19A-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
   A.   The Health and Licensing Department shall make, or cause to be made, an
investigation of the premises described in the application for the purpose of
determining the fitness and suitability of the premises for the conduct of such
business from a sanitary standpoint, and as to whether the applicant has
complied with the State laws and provisions of this Code regulating health,
sanitation, and safety so as to safeguard properly the lives and health of the
employees engaged or to be engaged in the premises.
   B.   The Health and Licensing Department shall also investigate the accuracy
and reliability of the work done or to be done in the laboratory, and as to
whether the person in charge or to be in charge of the laboratory is of good
reputation and experienced and qualified to do or supervise the work for which
the laboratory is to be maintained.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-19A-5: SANITARY AND SAFETY CONDITIONS:
   A.   Every laboratory shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
   B.   All necessary measures shall be taken to safeguard properly the lives
and health of all persons employed in the laboratory against accidents and
contagious diseases.
   C.   All necessary appliances and devices shall be installed to prevent the
emission of obnoxious fumes, odors, or dust into the laboratory proper or into
adjoining or contiguous structures, and provisions shall be made to prevent the
occlusion or obstruction of the drains or sewers through which the sewage or
wastes of the establishment are discharged.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-19A-6: REPORTS REQUIRED:
It shall be the duty of every person operating or conducting a laboratory to
report to the Health and Licensing Department within twenty four (24) hours the
results of all bacteriological and serological examinations, showing the
presence of any actively contagious, epidemic, or communicable disease,
together with the name and address of the person showing evidence of such
disease, and the name and address of the physician in attendance on such case.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-19A-7: INSPECTIONS:
Every laboratory shall at all times be open to inspection by the Health and
Licensing Department and the Director of Building and Code Enforcement whenever
and as often as they shall deem proper.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 20: FOOD AND FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS
ARTICLE A: FOOD SERVICE SANITATION CODE
Section
4-20A-1:   Code Adopted
4-20A-2:   Enforcement
4-20A-3:   Emergencies
4-20A-4:   Penalties
4-20A-1: CODE ADOPTED:
A certain document, copies of which are on file in the Health and License
Department, being marked and designated as the Federal Drug Administration
(“FDA”) Food Code, and as amended from time to time, shall be and hereby is
adopted by reference as the Food Service Sanitation Code of the Village, and
each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions, and terms of the FDA
Food Code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof by reference
as if set out fully in this article. Any additions or revisions to the FDA Food
Code after the effective date hereof shall become applicable within the Village
on the date that such addition or revision becomes an applicable provision of
the FDA Food Code and shall thereafter be a part of the Food Service Sanitation
Code, of the Village, unless the Corporate Authorities of the Village take
action to repel or amend such addition or revision.
(Ord. 2003-5-7G, 5-7-2003)
4-20A-2: ENFORCEMENT:
The provisions of the Food Service Sanitation Code adopted pursuant to section
4-20A-1 of this article shall be enforced by the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department and those persons designated or assigned by the Director
to enforce the provisions of the Food Service Sanitation Code.
(Ord. 2003-5-7G, 5-7-2003)
4-20A-3: EMERGENCIES:
   A.   Cessation Of Business: In addition to any other remedy that may be
available, in the event that the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department determines that conditions on premises which violate the Food
Service Sanitation Code adopted pursuant to section 4-20A-1 of this article
pose an immediate danger to persons who may consume food or beverages that are
sold, distributed or served from or on the premises, the Director may order
that the operations on the premises involving the sale, distribution or service
of food and beverages immediately cease.
   B.   Notice Of Cessation:
      1.   If the Director of the Health and Licensing Department orders that
the sale, distribution or service of food on premises cease as provided in
subsection A of this section, a notice shall be posted in a prominent place on
the premises stating that the Director of the Health and Licensing Department
has ordered that the sale, distribution and\or service of food and beverages on
the premises cease.
      2.   It shall be a violation of this article for any person to modify,
remove or deface any notice that is posted pursuant to subsection B1 of this
section.
   C.   Hearing: If the Director of the Health and Licensing Department orders
that the sale, distribution or service of food on premises cease as provided in
subsection A of this section, the owner or operator of the food service
operation on the premises shall be entitled to a hearing before the Village
President or a hearing officer appointed or designated by the Village
President. The hearing will commence within seventy two (72) hours after a
written request for a hearing is filed in the Office of the Village Clerk. The
purpose of the hearing is to allow for evidence to be presented as to whether
there are conditions on the premises which violate the Food Service Sanitation
Code adopted pursuant to section 4-20A-1 of this article and pose an immediate
danger to persons who may consume food or beverages that are sold, distributed
or served from or on the premises. At the hearing, the owner or operator of the
premises shall be entitled to be represented by an attorney and shall be
entitled to present evidence on his or her own behalf.
   D.   Decision Or Recommendation:
      1.   Following the conclusion of the hearing, if based on the testimony,
documents and other evidence, the Village President determines that either
there are no conditions on the premises which violate the Food Service
Sanitation Code adopted pursuant to section 4-20A-1 of this article or that any
conditions which do violate the Food Sanitation Code or do not pose an
immediate danger to persons who may consume food or beverages that are sold,
distributed or served from or on the premises, the Village President shall
allow operations on the premises involving the sale, distribution or service of
food and beverages to recommence.
      2.   If the hearing provided for in this section is conducted by a
hearing officer, the hearing officer shall make a written report and
recommendation to the Village President based on the testimony, documents and
other evidence presented at the hearing.
(Ord. 2003-5-7G, 5-7-2003)
4-20A-4: PENALTIES:
   A.   Any person violating any provision of the Food Service Sanitation Code
adopted pursuant to sections 4-20A-1 and 4-20A-2 of this article shall be
subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such violation. Each day
that a violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate violation.
   B.   In addition, the Director of the Health and Licensing Department is
authorized to apply to any court that has jurisdiction over violations of the
Food Service Sanitation Code adopted pursuant to section 4-20A-l of this
article for appropriate relief that seeks to enjoin the continued existence of
a condition, situation or circumstance that constitutes a violation of the
provisions of the Food Service Sanitation Code.
(Ord. 2003-5-7G, 5-7-2003)
ARTICLE B: FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS
Section
4-20B-1:   Definition
4-20B-2:   License Required
4-20B-3:   Application For License; Inspection Required
4-20B-4:   Compliance With Federal Regulations; Inspections; Handwashing Sinks
4-20B-5:   Violations And Remedies
Cross-reference:
   See
title 3, chapter 7  of this Code for eating establishments tax; see subsection
3-10-1 H of this Code for license fees
4-20B-1: DEFINITION:
When used in this article, the term FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT shall mean “food
processing establishments”, “food service establishments”, “mobile food units”,
“temporary food service establishments” and “retail food stores”, as these
terms are defined in the rules and regulations referenced herein.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-20B-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct or operate any food service establishment without first
having obtained a license for such food service establishment as provided
herein.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-20B-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INSPECTION REQUIRED:
An application for a license shall be made in conformity with the general
requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses. No such food
service establishment license shall be issued until the premises shall have
been inspected and approved by the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-20B-4: COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS; INSPECTIONS; HANDWASHING SINKS:
   A.   All food service establishments shall comply with the requirements of
the FDA Food Code as adopted in section
4-20A-1 of this Chapter. The Director of the Health and Licensing Department or
their representative, in conjunction with the Health and Licensing Department,
shall regularly inspect all food service establishments at intervals not
greater than six (6) months to ensure compliance with said Code.
   B.   In addition to the requirements of the FDA Food Code, all food service
establishments shall have an automatic handwashing facility installed in
accordance with the manufacturer's instructions that meet the following
requirements:
      1.   The handwashing sink shall provide water at a temperature of at
least 29.4ºC (85ºF) through a mixing valve or combination faucet.
      2.   A self-closing, slow-closing, or metering faucet shall provide a
flow of water for at least 15 seconds without the need to reactivate the
faucet.
      3.   A steam mixing valve may not be used at a handwashing sink.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975; amd. Ord. 2023-9-11B, 9-11-2023)
4-20B-5: VIOLATIONS AND REMEDIES:
   A.   Correction Of Violation: If no immediate hazard exists, any violations
may be corrected in a reasonable time at the direction of the Director of the
Health and Licensing Department.
   B.   Revocation Of License: In the case of serious or repeated violations,
the Director of the Health and Licensing Department may begin proceedings to
revoke the Village license pursuant to chapter 1 of this title.
   C.   In the case of an immediate, serious health hazard, the Director of the
Health and Licensing Department may order the food service establishment closed
until such hazard no longer exists.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
ARTICLE C: MOBILE FOOD VENDORS AND DISPENSERS
Section
4-20C-1:   Mobile Food Vendors
4-20C-1-1:   Definition
4-20C-1-2:   License Required
4-20C-1-2.5:   Temporary License
4-20C-1-3:   Regulations
4-20C-1-4:   Penalties
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 C of this Code for license fee
4-20C-1: MOBILE FOOD VENDORS:
4-20C-1-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this section 4-20C-1, the term MOBILE FOOD VENDOR shall mean any
person or persons who operate or sell food from a stationary cart or trailer
mounted on a chassis, but without an engine, or from a food truck with an
engine specifically outfitted with the necessary equipment for the safe
handling, storage and/or preparation of the food products being served as
determined by the Director of Health and Licensing. All mobile food vendors
must be inspected by the Director of the Health and Licensing Department.
(Ord. 2013-7-10K, 7-10-2013; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11B, 4-11-2022)
4-20C-1-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of mobile food vendor
without first having obtained a license from the Director of Health and
Licensing.
(Ord. 2013-7-10K, 7-10-2013; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11B, 4-11-2022)
4-20C-1-2.5: TEMPORARY LICENSE:
A temporary license may be issued for a mobile food vendor that has a
demonstrated ownership or leasehold interest in a property located in the
Village for the period that is six (6) months prior to the anticipated opening
of a permanent food service establishment being constructed pursuant to a
Village issued building permit for the vendor's use in the Village. The fee for
a temporary license shall be that set forth in the fee schedule subsection
3-10-1C of this Code. Any temporary license issued shall automatically expire
upon the issuance of an occupancy permit for the permanent food service
establishment.
(Ord. 2022-4-11B, 4-11-2022)
4-20C-1-3: REGULATIONS:
Mobile food vendors are subject to the following regulations:
   A.   Only mobile food vendors that have obtained a license from the Village
may operate within the Village of Rosemont.
   B.   A mobile food vendor cart, trailer or truck shall bear signage or other
insignia identifying the food service establishment with which it is
affiliated.
   C.   A mobile food vendor may be located and operated on private property
with the written permission of the owner of the privately owned property only
such dates and times as permitted by the private property owner and the license
required from the Village. The mobile food vendor may operate on public owned
property, including any Village owned right of way, only upon receipt of the
written permission of the public entity only on such dates, times and specific
locations as permitted by the public entity owning or operating the property. A
mobile food shall not operate on any non-Village owned public right of way and
shall not interfere with travel on such rights of way.
   D.   A mobile food vendor desiring permission to operate within any public
common areas shall submit a written application to the Director of the Health
and Licensing Department stating the dates, times and place for which
permission is being requested, together with a site plan depicting the proposed
location of the mobile food vendor. The Village's Director of Health and
Licensing shall contact the Village's manager of the location where permission
is sought and/or any other public entity that owns or controls the property for
which the permission is sought (i.e.: Park District or School District) and not
issue any license unless permission is granted by the Village's manager of the
location or the public entity that operates the proposed location in which the
mobile food vendor has applied to operate.
   E.   Mobile food vendors may operate only during the days, hours and
locations established in the license issued by the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department.
   F.   Mobile food vendors may not be operated in parking spaces, driveways,
fire lanes or public roads unless permission is specifically granted by the
Village.
   G.   A drive-through is not permitted in conjunction with a mobile food
vendor.
   H.   A mobile food vendor cart or chassis shall be stored in an appropriate
location approved by the Director of Health and Licensing at all times when it
is not being operated for food service purposes.
   I.   All food must be protected from any type of contamination and must be
stored and served in accordance with all applicable food service sanitation
codes and ordinances.
   J.   Mobile Food Vendors shall be inspected by the Village's Health
Department whether they are operating on public or private property.
(Ord. 2013-7-10K, 7-10-2013; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11B, 4-11-2022; Ord. 2023-7-10D,
7-10-2023)
4-20C-1-4: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm, corporation or business entity found to be in violation of
any provision of this article or, of the terms of a mobile food vendor license
issued pursuant to this article, by the Village's Administrative Hearing
Officer after a notice and hearing required pursuant to the Village's
Administrative Hearing System established in article A of chapter 4 of title 1
of this Code shall be subject to: a) revocation or suspension of their mobile
food vendor license; and b) a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense.
The provisions of this section shall not preclude the Village from using other
methods or proceedings to enforce this article or to adjudicate alleged
violations of this article including, without limitation, the institution of an
action in the Circuit Court of Cook County or before another administrative
tribunal which has jurisdiction to consider violations of this article.
(Ord. 2013-7-10K, 7-10-2013; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11B, 4-11-2022)
ARTICLE D: TEMPORARY FOOD VENDORS
Section
4-20D-1:   Definitions
4-20D-2:   License Required
4-20D-3:   Application For License; Fee
4-20D-4:   Conditions Of License
4-20D-5:   Term Of License; Days Of Sales
4-20D-6:   Display Of License
4-20D-7:   Regulations
4-20D-8:   Prohibited Food Sales
4-20D-9:   Inspections
4-20D-10:   Enforcement Of Provisions
4-20D-11:   Penalties
4-20D-12:   Administrative Adjudication
4-20D-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
FOOD: Any nonliquid item that is intended to be eaten by a human being.
FRESH PRODUCE: Fruits and vegetables that have not been cooked at the time that
they are sold or offered for sale.
PERSON: A natural person, corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship,
limited liability company, unincorporated association, joint venture or other
entity.
PREPACKED FOOD: Any food that is wrapped or contained in a package at the time
it is sold or being offered for sale.
PREPARED FOOD: Any food item that has been cooked in any manner prior to being
sold.
TEMPORARY LOCATION: Any location that is outside of an enclosed building or
structure and any location inside an enclosed building or structure, other than
the Donald E. Stephens Convention Center, that is not regularly used as a site
for the sale of food.
VENDOR: Any person or business that sells or offers food for sale. Persons that
provide food in connection with an event that is catered and which is not open
to the general public are not considered to be vendors for purposes of this
article. Persons who do not regularly engage in the sale of food and who sell
or offer to sell food at an event where the proceeds from the sale go to
support an educational or religious institution or where the proceeds of the
sale are used solely for a charitable purpose are not considered to be vendors
for purposes of this article.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
4-20D-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall act as a vendor who sells food or offers food for sale at a
temporary location within the Village without first obtaining a temporary food
vendor's license issued by the Village pursuant to the provisions of this
article for each and every temporary location at which food is sold by such
person or business. The applicant for a temporary food vendor's license must be
at least eighteen (18) years of age.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
4-20D-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
All applications for a temporary food vendor's license shall be submitted on an
application form to be provided by the Village. The fee for a temporary food
vendor's license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1B of this Code, as amended; except, that no license fee shall be required
for a temporary food vendor's license that authorizes the sale of food on
premises owned or occupied by a school, a park district, the Village, or a
church or other religious institution. All applications for a temporary food
vendor's license shall be accompanied by the applicable license fee.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
4-20D-4: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
No person shall be issued a temporary food vendor's license unless such person
has obtained any and all other licenses or permits that may be required in
order for the person to be able to engage in the business of selling food or
offering food for sale.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
4-20D-5: TERM OF LICENSE; DAYS OF SALES:
A temporary food vendor's license shall be valid for the period from April 1
through October 31 during a calendar year and shall allow the sale of food and
the offering of food for sale on Saturdays and Sundays only, unless the
Director of the Health and Licensing Department issues a permit that allows a
licensee to sell food on a day other than Saturday or Sunday; provided, that no
such permit shall allow food to be sold on more than three (3) consecutive
days, not including Saturdays And Sundays.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
4-20D-6: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
A temporary food vendor’s license shall be kept on the premises for which the
license was issued and shall be shown upon request to any officer of the
Village authorized to administer or enforce this article.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
4-20D-7: REGULATIONS:
   A.   All food vendors at a temporary location must at all times be in
compliance with any and all applicable Federal, State and local laws, rules and
regulations.
   B.   All locations where a vendor who has been issued a temporary food
vendor’s license sells food or offers food for sale must be maintained in a
clean, neat and sanitary manner.
   C.   Each vendor who has been issued a temporary food vendor’s license shall
maintain a tightfitting container for waste and garbage at the location where
the vendor sells food or offers food for sale.
   D.   Any food on display at a location for which temporary food vendor’s
license has been issued that is outside of an enclosed structure must be
protected from dirt or other contamination.
   E.   No food at a location for which a temporary food vendor’s license has
been issued shall be stored or placed on the ground or floor.
   F.   Any food on display at a location for which a temporary food vendor’s
license has been issued must be protected from handling by the public; except,
that fresh produce which is on display for sale may be made available for
handling by prospective purchasers.
   G.   No animals, other than service dogs, are to be in the area where food
is stored or where food is sold or offered for sale at a location for which a
temporary food vendor's license has been issued.
   H.   Samples of fresh produce shall be offered to prospective purchasers or
other members of the public only if the sample has first been washed in a
sanitizing solution. Samples of food that are offered to prospective purchasers
or other members of the public must be served either: 1) with an eating
utensil, such as a fork or spoon; 2) with a toothpick or similar type of
skewer; or 3) served on a disposable plate or bowl.
   I.   Fresh produce may only be cut or sliced for display purposes. Fresh
produce that has been sliced or cut shall not be sold.
   J.   Baked goods which do not contain cream, custard or other egg-based
filling must be produced and packaged at a facility for which a permit or
license authorizing food to be produced and packaged at the facility has been
issued by a unit of government having jurisdiction over the facility unless the
proceeds from the sale are to be donated to a recognized not-for-profit
organization such as a public, parochial or private not-for-profit educational
institution, a religious institution or a charitable organization.
   K.   Baked goods containing cream, custard or other egg-based filling must
also be kept refrigerated at a temperature of forty one degrees Fahrenheit
(41°F) or less.
   L.   The packaging for prepackaged foods must contain the following
information:
      1.   The common name of the product in the package;
      2.   The name and address, including zip code, of the packer of the
package;
      3.   The net weight of the contents of the package; and
      4.   A list of ingredients contained in the package, including any
artificial colors, artificial flavors and preservatives.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
4-20D-8: PROHIBITED FOOD SALES:
The following shall not be sold by a vendor of food at a temporary location:
   A.   Canned foods that were not canned at a facility for which a permit or
license authorizing the canning of foods at the facility has been issued by a
unit of government having jurisdiction over the facility.
   B.   Raw milk, raw cheese, raw yogurt or any other raw dairy product.
   C.   Ice cream that was not made at a facility for which a permit or license
authorizing ice cream to be made at the facility has been issued by a unit of
government having jurisdiction over the facility.
   D.   Food in packages where the food was not packaged at a facility for
which a permit or license authorizing food to be packaged at the facility has
been issued by a unit of government having jurisdiction over the facility.
   E.   Sandwiches which were prepared at a location other than the premises
for which the temporary food vendor’s license was issued or at a business
location or other facility for which a permit or license authorizing the
preparation of sandwiches has been issued by a unit of government having
jurisdiction over the business location or other facility.
   F.   Garlic in oil unless packaged at a facility for which a permit or
license authorizing food to be packaged at the facility has been issued by a
unit of government having jurisdiction over the facility.
   G.   Pickles, relishes and salsa unless packaged at a facility for which a
permit or license authorizing food to be packaged at the facility has been
issued by a unit of government having jurisdiction over the facility.
   H.   Any food that contains mold or is contaminated, rancid, or would
otherwise be unhealthy for a natural person to consume.
   I.   Any food for which the expiration or “consume by” or “sell by” date as
shown on the package or container for the food has passed.
   J.   Baked goods containing cream, custard or other egg-based filling unless
produced and packaged at a facility for which a permit or license authorizing
food to be produced and packaged at the facility has been issued by a unit of
government having jurisdiction over the facility.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
4-20D-9: INSPECTIONS:
All locations where a vendor who has been issued a temporary food vendor's
license operates shall be subject to inspection at any reasonable time during
which food is present at the location for compliance with applicable laws,
rules and regulations including, but not limited to, the FDA Food Code.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
4-20D-10: ENFORCEMENT OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department and his deputies
shall have the duty to enforce the provisions of this article.
   B.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department is authorized to
issue regulations for the purpose of implementing and enforcing the
requirements of this article. All such regulations shall be consistent with the
provisions of this article.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
4-20D-11: PENALTIES:
   A.   Any person found guilty of violating any provisions of this article
shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
   B.   Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this article
shall not be issued a temporary food vendor’s license for a period of sixty
(60) days beginning on the date of the guilty finding.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
4-20D-12: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION:
Violations of the provisions of this article are subject to prosecution under
the Village administrative adjudication proceedings established pursuant to
title 1, chapter 4, article A of this Code, as now or hereafter amended. The
provisions of this section shall not preclude the Village from using other
methods or proceedings to enforce this article or to adjudicate alleged
violations of this article including, without limitation, the institution of an
action in the Circuit Court of Cook County or before another administrative
tribunal which has jurisdiction to consider violations of this article.
(Ord. 2009-11-4K, 11-4-2009)
ARTICLE E: VENDING MACHINES; FOOD
Section
4-20E-1:   License Required; Exemptions
4-20E-2:   Application For License
4-20E-3:   Adulterated Or Misbranded Foods Or Beverages
4-20E-4:   Sanitation Requirements
4-20E-5:   Inspections; Violations
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fees
4-20E-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
No person, firm or corporation who owns, leases or has a possessory interest in
any premises within the Village shall install, keep, maintain, use or permit
the maintenance or use upon such premises of any vending machine, automatic
vending machine, coin-operated machine or other mechanical device requiring
more than one cent ($0.01) for the activation thereof, which is used or
