intended to be used for the sale or distribution of any product unless the same
shall have been first licensed under the provisions of this article, and no
owner of any vending machine, automatic vending machine, coin-operated machine
or other mechanical device requiring more than one cent ($0.01) for the
activation thereof, which is used or intended to be used for the sale or
distribution of any product, shall install the same on any premises located
within the Village without first obtaining a license therefor pursuant to the
provisions of this article. This article shall not apply, however, to cigarette
vending machines, jukeboxes, or amusement machines.
(Ord. 76-3-27A, 3-27-1976)
4-20E-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license shall be made in conformity with the general
requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses. Such
application shall include the owner of the premises upon which the machine is
to be located for use and the product to be sold or distributed by the machine.
(Ord. 76-3-27A, 3-27-1976)
4-20E-3: ADULTERATED OR MISBRANDED FOODS OR BEVERAGES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person within the Village to sell, offer,
or expose for sale through vending machines, or to have in possession with
intent to sell therefrom, any food, beverage or ingredient which is adulterated
or misbranded.
   B.   Samples of food, beverage or ingredient may be taken and examined by
the Village as often as may be necessary to determine freedom from adulteration
or misbranding. The Village may, on written notice to the operator, impound and
forbid the sale of any food or beverage which is adulterated or misbranded, or
which it has probable cause to believe to be adulterated or misbranded. After
the operator has been given an opportunity for a hearing, the Village may cause
to be removed or destroyed any food or beverage which is adulterated or
misbranded; provided, that in the case of misbranding which can be corrected by
proper labeling, such food or beverage may be released to the operator for
correct labeling under the supervision of the Village.
(Ord. 76-3-27A, 3-27-1976)
4-20E-4: SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Foods, beverages and ingredients intended for sale through vending
machines shall be obtained from sources complying with the regulations of the
Village and with other applicable State and Federal laws and regulations. Such
products shall be clean and wholesome, free from spoilage, and processed,
prepared, handled and stored in such a manner as to be protected against
contamination and adulteration. All product contact surfaces of containers and
equipment shall be protected from contamination.
   B.   All foods, beverages and ingredients shall be stored or packaged in
clean protective containers and shall be handled, transported and vended in a
sanitary manner. Wet storage of packaged products is prohibited.
   C.   Readily perishable foods offered for sale through vending machines
shall be dispensed to the consumer in the individual original container or
wrapper into which it was placed at the commissary or at the manufacturer's or
processor's plant, or such products shall be dispensed into single service
containers.
   D.   In those vending machines dispensing readily perishable foods,
beverages, or ingredients in bulk, the bulk supplies of such foods, beverages
or ingredients shall be transferred only to a bulk vending machine container
and appurtenances which are clean and have been subjected to an approved
bactericidal process.
   E.   1.   Readily perishable foods or ingredients within the vending machine
shall be maintained at a temperature not lower than thirty three degrees
Fahrenheit (33°F) nor higher than fifty degrees Fahrenheit (50°F). Vending
machines dispensing readily perishable foods shall be provided with controls
which ensure the maintenance of these temperatures at all times; provided, that
an exception may be made for the actual time required to fill or otherwise
service the machine and for a maximum recovery period of thirty (30) minutes
following completion of filling or servicing operations. Such controls shall
also place the machine in an inoperative condition until serviced by the
operator, in the event of power failure or other condition, which permits the
food storage compartment to attain a temperature above fifty degrees Fahrenheit
(50°F) or below thirty three degrees Fahrenheit (33°F), whichever is
applicable. Vending machines dispensing readily perishable food shall be
provided with a thermometer which, to an accuracy of plus or minus two degrees
Fahrenheit (±2°F), indicates the air temperature of the food storage
compartment.
      2.   The temperature for hot liquid foods or beverages shall be not less
than one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) and for frozen foods, not
more than thirty two degrees Fahrenheit (32°F).
   F.   Milk offered for sale through vending machines shall be dispensed only
in individual containers or from bulk containers into which the milk was placed
at the plant.
   G.   The machine location shall be such as to minimize the potential for
contamination of the product, shall be easily cleanable and shall be kept
clean.
   H.   The exterior construction of the vending machine shall be such as to
facilitate cleaning and to minimize the entrance of insects and rodents, and
the exterior of the machine shall be kept clean. Service connections shall be
such as to protect against unintentional or accidental interruption of service
to the machine.
   I.   Unless the vending machine is sealed to the floor so as to prevent
seepage underneath or can be manually moved with ease, one or more of the
following provisions shall be utilized to facilitate cleaning operations:
      1.   The machine shall be mounted on legs six inches (6") or more in
height; or
      2.   The machine shall be mounted on casters or rollers; or
      3.   The machine shall be mounted on gliders which permit it to be easily
moved.
   J.   All interior surfaces and component parts of the vending machine shall
be so designed and constructed as to permit easy cleaning and shall be kept
clean. All product contact surfaces of the machine shall be of smooth,
nontoxic, corrosion resistant, and relatively nonabsorbent material and shall
be capable of withstanding repeated cleaning and bactericidal treatment by
normal procedures. Such surfaces shall be protected against contamination.
   K.   Water used in vending machines shall be from an approved source and
shall be of a safe and sanitary quality.
   L.   1.    All wastes shall be properly disposed of and, pending
disposition, shall be kept in suitable containers so as to prevent creating a
nuisance.
      2.   This subsection shall be deemed to have been satisfied when the
following requirements are met:
         a.   All trash and other waste material shall be removed from the
machine location as frequently as may be necessary to prevent nuisance and
unsightliness and shall be disposed of in a manner approved by the health
authority.
         b.   Self-closing, leakproof, readily cleanable, and plainly labeled
and designated waste container or containers shall be provided in the vicinity
of each machine or machines to receive used cups, cartons, wrappers, straws,
closures and other single service items. Such waste containers shall not be
located within the vending machine; provided, that an exception may be made for
those machines dispensing only packaged products with crown closures, in which
case, the closure receptacle may be located within the machine. Suitable racks
or cases shall be provided for multi-use containers or bottles.
         c.   Containers shall be provided within all machines dispensing
liquid products in bulk for the collection of drip, spillage, overflow, or
other liquid wastes.
      3.   An automatic shutoff device shall be provided which will place the
vending machine out of operation before a container overflows. Containers or
surfaces on which wastes may accumulate shall be readily removable for
cleaning, shall be easily cleanable, and shall be corrosion resistant. If
liquid wastes from drip, spillage or overflow, which originate within the
machine, are discharged into a sewerage system, the connection to the sewer
shall be through an air gap.
   M.   Foods, beverages and ingredients and product contact surfaces of
containers, equipment and supplies shall be protected from contamination while
in transit to the machine location. Readily perishable foods and beverages,
while in transit, shall be maintained at a temperature not higher than fifty
degrees Fahrenheit (50°F).
(Ord. 76-3-27A, 3-27-1976)
4-20E-5: INSPECTIONS; VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Inspections: The appropriate Village officials shall inspect the
servicing, maintenance and operation of vending machines dispensing readily
perishable foods at least once every six (6) months. Vending machines
dispensing other than readily perishable foods may be inspected as often as
deemed necessary.
   B.   Entry Powers: Village officers or employees, after proper
identification, shall be permitted to enter at any reasonable time upon any
private or public property within the Village where vending machines are
operated for the purpose of determining compliance with the provisions of this
article. The operator shall make provision for the Village to have access to
the interior of all vending machines operated by him.
   C.   Violations:
      1.   Notice Of Violation; Hearing: Whenever the Village discovers a
violation of any provision of this article, the operator concerned shall be
notified. Such notice shall: a) describe the condition found and state which
section of this article is violated by such condition; b) provide a specific
and reasonable period of time for the correction of the condition; and c) state
that an opportunity for a hearing on inspection findings will be provided if a
written request for such hearing is filed with the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice.
      2.   Suspension Or Revocation Of License Or Court Action: The Director of
the Health and Licensing Department may advise the operator in writing that
unless the violations are corrected within the specified period of time, any
license issued under the provisions of this article may be suspended or revoked
or court action may be initiated.
(Ord. 76-3-27A, 3-27-1976)
ARTICLE F: COTTAGE FOOD OPERATIONS
Section
4-20F-1:   Definitions
4-20F-2:   Regulations Of Cottage Food Operations
4-20F-3:   Registration
4-20F-4:   Consumer Complaint; Foodborne Illness Outbreak
4-20F-5:   Complaints From Other Jurisdictions
4-20F-6:   Exemptions
4-20F-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to this Article:
ACIDIFIED: A food is "acidified" if:
   1.   Acid or acid ingredients are added to it to produce a final equilibrium
pH of 4.6 or below; or
   2.   It is fermented to produce a final equilibrium pH of 4.6 or below.
CANNED FOOD: Food that has been heat processed sufficiently under United States
Department of Agriculture guidelines to enable storing the food at normal home
temperatures.
COTTAGE FOOD OPERATION: An operation conducted by a person who produces or
packages food or drink, other than foods and drinks listed as prohibited in
paragraph (1.3) of Section
4-20F-2  of this Article, in a kitchen located in that person's primary
domestic residence or another appropriately designed and equipped kitchen on a
farm for direct sale by the owner, a family member, or employee.
CUT LEAFY GREENS: Fresh leafy greens whose leaves have been cut, shredded,
sliced, chopped, or torn. CUT LEAFY GREENS does not mean cut-to-harvest leafy
greens.
DEPARTMENT: The Illinois Department of Public Health.
EQUILIBRIUM PH: The final potential of hydrogen measured in an acidified food
after all the components of the food have achieved the same acidity.
FARMERS' MARKET: A common facility or area where farmers gather to sell a
variety of fresh fruits and vegetables and other locally produced farm and food
products directly to consumers.
LEAFY GREENS: Iceberg lettuce; romaine lettuce; leaf lettuce; butter lettuce;
baby leaf lettuce, such as immature lettuce or leafy greens; escarole; endive;
spring mix; spinach; cabbage; kale; arugula; and chard. LEAFY GREENS does not
include microgreens or herbs such as cilantro or parsley.
LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENT: The Village of Rosemont's Health Department.
LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENT ASSOCIATION: An association solely representing
two (2) or more State-certified local health departments.
LOW-ACID CANNED FOOD: Any canned food with a finished equilibrium pH greater
than 4.6 and a water activity (aw) greater than 0.85.
MICROGREEN: An edible plant seedling grown in soil or substrate and harvested
above the soil or substrate line.
POTENTIALLY HAZARDOUS FOOD: A food that is potentially hazardous according to
the Department's administrative rules. Potentially hazardous food (PHF) in
general means a food that requires time and temperature control for safety
(TCS) to limit pathogenic microorganism growth or toxin formation.
SPROUT: Any seedling intended for human consumption that was produced in a
manner that does not meet the definition of microgreen.
(Ord. 2023-7-10C, 7-10-2023)
4-20F-2: REGULATION OF COTTAGE FOOD OPERATIONS:
A cottage food operation may produce homemade food and drink provided that all
of the following conditions are met:
   A.   The cottage food operation complies with all the requirements of the
Village's Zoning Code (Rosemont Code: Title 12), including the requirement that
the handling of food or foodstuffs requires a special use permit for the Home
Occupation that is issued by the Village Board after a Public Hearing before
the Zoning Board of Appeals.
      1.   The cottage food operation is in compliance with all State statutes
and Illinois Department of Revenue requirements for the collection of sales
taxes.
      2.   A cottage food operation must register with the Village of
Rosemont's local Health Department, but may sell products outside of the
Village of Rosemont. A copy of the certificate of registration must be
available upon request by any local health department.
      3.   A cottage food operation shall not sell or offer to sell the
following food items or processed foods containing the following food items,
except as indicated:
         a.   Meat, poultry, fish, seafood, or shellfish;
         b.   Dairy, except as an ingredient in a non-potentially hazardous
baked good or candy, such as caramel, subject to paragraph A.4., or as an
ingredient in a baked good frosting, such as buttercream;
         c.   Eggs, except as an ingredient in a non-potentially hazardous
food, including dry noodles, or as an ingredient in a baked good frosting, such
as buttercream, if the eggs are not raw;
         d.   Pumpkin pies, sweet potato pies, cheesecakes, custard pies, creme
pies, and pastries with potentially hazardous fillings or toppings;
         e.   Garlic in oil or oil infused with garlic, except if the garlic
oil is acidified;
         f.   Low-acid canned foods;
         g.   Sprouts;
         h.   Cut leafy greens, except for cut leafy greens that are
dehydrated, acidified, or blanched and frozen;
         i.   Cut or pureed fresh tomato or melon;
         j.   Dehydrated tomato or melon;
         k.   Frozen cut melon;
         l.   Wild-harvested, non-cultivated mushrooms;
         m.   Alcoholic beverages; or
         n.   Kombucha.
      4.   In order to sell canned tomatoes or a canned product containing
tomatoes, a cottage food operator shall either:
         a.   Follow exactly a recipe that has been tested by the United States
Department of Agriculture or by a state cooperative extension located in this
State or any other state in the United States; or
         b.   Submit the recipe, at the cottage food operator's expense, to a
commercial laboratory according to the commercial laboratory's directions to
test that the product has been adequately acidified; use only the varietal or
proportionate varietals of tomato included in the tested recipe for all
subsequent batches of such recipe; and provide documentation of the annual test
results of the recipe submitted under this subparagraph upon registration and
to an inspector upon request during any inspection authorized by Section
4-20F-4.
   B.   In order to sell a fermented or acidified food, a cottage food
operation shall either:
      1.   Submit a recipe that has been tested by the United States Department
of Agriculture or a cooperative extension system located in this State or any
other state in the United States; or
      2.   Submit a written food safety plan for each category of products for
which the cottage food operator uses the same procedures, such as pickles,
kimchi, or hot sauce, and a pH test for a single product that is representative
of that category; the written food safety plan shall be submitted annually upon
registration and each pH test shall be submitted every three (3) years; the
food safety plan shall adhere to guidelines developed by the Department.
   C.   A fermented or acidified food shall be packaged according to one of the
following standards:
      1.   A fermented or acidified food that is canned must be processed in a
boiling water bath in a Mason-style jar or glass container with a tight-fitting
lid.
      2.   A fermented or acidified food that is not canned shall be sold in
any container that is new, clean, and seals properly and must be stored,
transported, and sold at or below forty-one (41) degrees.
   D.   In order to sell a baked good with cheese, a local health department
may require a cottage food operation to submit a recipe, at the cottage food
operator's expense, to a commercial laboratory to verify that it is non-
potentially hazardous before allowing the cottage food operation to sell the
baked good as a cottage food.
   E.   If the cottage food operation does not utilize a municipal water
supply, a water sample test shall be required to verify that the water source
being used meets public safety standards related to E. coli coliform. The test
must be conducted at the cottage food operator's expense.
   F.   A person preparing or packaging a product as part of a cottage food
operation must be an Illinois Department of Public Health approved certified
food protection manager.
   G.   Food packaging must conform with the labeling requirements of the
Illinois Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act. A cottage food product shall be
prepackaged and the food packaging shall be affixed with a prominent label that
includes the following:
      1.   The name of the cottage food operation and unit of local government
in which the cottage food operation is located;
      2.   The identifying registration number provided by the Village of
Rosemont's health department on the certificate of registration and the name of
the municipality or county in which the registration was filed;
      3.   The common or usual name of the food product;
      4.   All ingredients of the food product, including any color, artificial
flavor, and preservative, listed in descending order by predominance of weight
shown with the common or usual names;
      5.   The following phrase in prominent lettering: “This product was
produced in a home kitchen not inspected by a health department that may also
process common food allergens. If you have safety concerns, contact your local
health department.”;
      6.   The date the product was processed; and
      7.   Allergen labeling as specified under federal labeling requirements.
   H.   Food packaging may include the designation "Illinois-grown", "Illinois-
sourced", or "Illinois farm product" if the packaged product is a local farm or
food product as that term is defined in Section 5 of the Illinois Local Food,
Farms, and Jobs Act.
   I.   In the case of a product that is difficult to properly label or
package, or for other reasons, the Rosemont health department may grant
permission to sell products that are not prepackaged, in which case other
prominent written notice shall be provided to the purchaser.
   J.   At the point of sale, notice must be provided in a prominent location
that states the following: “This product was produced in a home kitchen not
inspected by a health department that may also process common food allergens.”
At a physical display, notice shall be a placard. Online, notice shall be a
message on the cottage food operation's online sales interface at the point of
sale.
   K.   Food and drink produced by a cottage food operation shall be sold
directly to consumers for their own consumption and not for resale. Sales
directly to consumers include, but are not limited to, sales at or through:
      1.   Farmers' markets;
      2.   Fairs, festivals, public events, or online;
      3.   Delivery to the customer; and
      4.   Pickup from a third-party private property with the consent of the
third-party property holder.
   L.   Only food that is non-potentially hazardous may be shipped. A cottage
food product shall not be shipped out of State. Each cottage food product that
is shipped must be sealed in a manner that reveals tampering, including, but
not limited to, a sticker or pop top.
(Ord. 2023-7-10C, 7-10-2023)
4-20F-3: REGISTRATION:
A cottage food operation that meets the requirements of this Article and shall
be issue a certificate of registration with a unique identifying registration
number by the Village of Rosemont's Health Department. Registration shall be
completed annually and an annual fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) paid.
(Ord. 2023-7-10C, 7-10-2023)
4-20F-4: CONSUMER COMPLAINT; FOODBORNE ILLNESS OUTBREAK:
In the event of a consumer complaint or foodborne illness outbreak, upon notice
from a different local health department other than the Rosemont Department of
Public Health, or if the Rosemont Health Department has reason to believe that
an imminent health hazard exists or that a cottage food operation's product has
been found to be misbranded, adulterated, or not in compliance with the
conditions for cottage food operations set forth in this Article, the Illinois
Department of Public Health or the Rosemont Health Department may:
   A.   Inspect the premises of the cottage food operation in question;
   B.   Get a reasonable fee for the inspection which shall be at least one
hundred dollars ($100.00) per hour; and
   C.   Invoke penalties and the cessation of the sale of cottage food products
until it deems that the situation has been addressed to the satisfaction of the
Illinois Department of Public Health or the Rosemont Health Department; if the
situation is not amenable to being addressed, the Rosemont Health Department
may revoke the cottage food operation's registration after a final decision
revoking the registration is made following a written charge, service of the
charge and notice of hearing upon the Cottage Food Operator, and a hearing
before the Village's Administrative Adjudication Hearing Officer. The Cottage
Food Operator shall have the right to Counsel, the ability to cross-examine
witnesses and the right to submit documents, testimony, evidence and argument
in its defense.
(Ord. 2023-7-10C, 7-10-2023)
4-20F-5: COMPLAINTS FROM OTHER JURISDICTIONS:
If the Rosemont Health Department receives a consumer complaint or a report of
foodborne illness related to a cottage food operator in another jurisdiction,
it shall refer the complaint or report to the local health department where the
cottage food operator is registered.
(Ord. 2023-7-10C, 7-10-2023)
4-20F-6: EXEMPTIONS:
A person who produces or packages a non-potentially hazardous baked good for
sale by a religious, charitable, or nonprofit organization for fundraising
purposes is exempt from the requirements of this Article.
(Ord. 2023-7-10C, 7-10-2023)
ARTICLE G: INSECT AND VERMIN CONTROL
Section
4-20G-1:   Definitions/Applicability.
4-20G-2:   Control Measures
4-20G-3:   Storage of Poisonous Compounds
4-20G-4:   Pest Control Information Log Book
4-20G-1: DEFINITION/APPLICABILITY:
When used in this article, the term FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT shall mean "food
processing establishments", "food service establishments", "mobile food units",
"temporary food service establishments" and "retail food stores", as these
terms are defined in the rules and regulations referenced herein. This
Article F of Chapter 20 shall be applicable to all Food Service establishments
and any other individual or entity that is required to be licensed under
Articles A, B, C, D and E of this Chapter 20 of Title 4 of the Village of
Rosemont's Code of Ordinances.
(Ord. 2023-9-11C, 9-11-2023)
4-20G-2: CONTROL MEASURES:
   A.   All necessary control measures shall be used to effectively minimize
and eliminate the presence of rodents, flies, roaches and other insects and
vermin on the premises.
   B.   When flies are prevalent, all openings to the outside shall be
effectively screened with 16-mesh wire or plastic cloth. All doors shall be
self-closing and screen doors to the outside shall open outward. In cases of
other unprotected openings, properly operating and approved air curtains or
fans of sufficient power, or other approved means to prevent the entrance of
flies shall be used.
   C.   Windows, doors, skylights, transoms and other openings shall be
screened. Screens shall be tight fitting and free from holes. All Food Service
Establishments shall be effectively rat-proofed to prevent the entrance of
rodents.
(Ord. 2023-9-11C, 9-11-2023)
4-20G-3: STORAGE OF POISONOUS COMPOUNDS:
All poisonous compounds used in the control or extermination of rodents or
insects or vermin shall be so colored as to be easily identified. The
containers of such insecticides and rodenticides shall be distinctly labeled
and stored in locked cabinets separate and apart from foods, food additives or
ingredients.
(Ord. 2023-9-11C, 9-11-2023)
4-20G-4: PEST CONTROL INFORMATION LOG BOOK:
All entities and individuals to which this Article G is applicable shall
maintain a log book on its premises containing the following pest control
information:
   A.   A record of any and all visits to the food establishment by any pest
control company describing all pest control-related activities conducted,
including inspections and applications of pesticides and or other methods to
control pests;
      1.   All food establishments shall contract with licensed exterminator
who shall provide insect and vermin service at the establishment at least once
per month.
   B.   The log book record shall include a copy of the service ticket that
sets forth the pest control company's Illinois Department of Public Health
license, and all information required by Section 830.820 of the Illinois
Administrative Code:
      1.   Written verification (i.e. signature and certification number) of
the certified technician responsible for using pesticides, or overseeing the
use of pesticides by non-certified personnel;
      2.   Date of application;
      3.   Specify the pest being targeted;
      4.   Pesticide use recorded in the following manner:
         a.   Brand or common name;
         b.   USEPA Registration Number;
         c.   Percent active ingredient in the finished product; and
         d.   Estimate the amount of each finished product used.
   C.   A record of all locations of all applications of pesticides, trap and
monitoring stations placed or monitored during the inspection;
   D.   A record of any recommended corrective action needed to eliminate the
condition, such as housekeeping deficiencies, pest harborages, or structural
deficiencies; and
   E.   All information in the log books shall be kept at the business location
and be available for inspection for a period of twelve (12) months.
(Ord. 2023-9-11C, 9-11-2023)
CHAPTER 21: BUSINESSES DEALING WITH ANIMALS
ARTICLE A: VETERINARY HOSPITALS
Section
4-21A-1:   Definition
4-21A-2:   License Required
4-21A-3:   Application for License
4-21A-4:   Regulations
4-21A-5:   Noisy Animals Prohibited
4-21A-6:   Inspections
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-21A-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this article, the term VETERINARY HOSPITAL shall mean any
institution, place or enclosure used for the harboring or reception for care or
treatment of two (2) or more horses, dogs, cats or other animals.
(Ord. 75-I2-I7D, 12-17-1975)
4-21A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall manage, conduct, operate or carry on the business of a
veterinary hospital without first having obtained a license as provided in this
title.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-21A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license under this article shall be made in conformance with
the general requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses.
The applicant shall provide all information requested by the Health and
Licensing Department.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-21A-4: REGULATIONS:
   A.   All veterinary hospitals shall be kept free and clean from decaying
food and from filth of any kind.
   B.   Every licensed person shall make a report to the Health and Licensing
Department of any communicable diseases or disease due to poisoning which may
exist in the veterinary hospital.
   C.   Provisions shall be made in the veterinary hospital for securely
impounding any animal confined for observation for rabies. Special precaution
shall be taken to securely and separately confine any such animals during such
period of observation, and report shall be made to the Health and Licensing
Department of any such animal confined in any veterinary hospital.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-21A-5: NOISY ANIMALS PROHIBITED:
No person in the Village licensed under this article shall keep or harbor any
dog or other animal shut up or tied up in any yard, enclosure or on the
premises of a veterinary hospital, which by barking, howling, bawling, or other
noises, shall disturb the peace and quiet of any family, individual or
neighborhood.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-21A-6: INSPECTIONS:
Every veterinary hospital conducted, maintained or managed by any licensed
person shall at all times be open to the inspection by the Health and Licensing
Department, and the Health and Licensing Department is hereby authorized and
empowered to inspect the same, or cause inspection thereof to be made, whenever
and as often as it may deem proper; and if, upon such inspection, any such
hospital shall be found to be conducted, managed or maintained in violation of
the terms of the application for the license under which the hospital was
opened, conducted, managed or maintained, or any of the health or sanitary
ordinances, rules or regulations of the Village or of this Code, proceedings to
suspend or revoke the license may be initiated under this title.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 22: GENERAL BROKERS
Section
4-22-1:   Definition
4-22-2:   License Required
4-22-3:   Application Of Provisions To Employees
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-22-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this article, the term GENERAL BROKER shall mean any person, other
than an employee of the principal for whom the business is done, that
negotiates, buys, sells, trades, leases, or handles for another, on a
commission basis, or on the basis of compensation in proportion to the amount
of the transaction, any stocks, bonds, mortgages, loans, investment securities,
certificates of indebtedness, foreign exchange letters of credit, steamship
transportation tickets, grain, provisions, produce, livestock, goods, wares,
merchandise or any other commodity, article or property (except real property),
whether similar or dissimilar to those herein mentioned, or acts through the
medium of another licensed broker in the capacity and for any of the purposes
aforesaid.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-22-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of, or to
act in the capacity of, a general broker without first having obtained a
license to do so.
   B.   Where a person desires to engage in the business of a general broker at
more than one place within the Village, a separate license shall be required
for each of such places, and the full license fee shall be charged for each
such license issued.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-22-3: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS TO EMPLOYEES:
Any person employed by a person licensed as a general broker under the
provisions of this article who shall himself, on his own account and not as
such employee, be amenable to all the provisions of this article,
notwithstanding the fact of such employment, and shall be required to obtain a
general broker1s license.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 23: BARBERSHOPS/HAIR SALONS
Section
4-23-1:   Definition
4-23-2:   License Required
4-23-3:   Sanitation Requirements
4-23-4:   Location; Ventilation
4-23-5:   Inspections
4-23-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, the term BARBERSHOP/HAIR SALON shall mean any
building, room, place or establishment wherein the occupation is carried on of
cutting and dressing the hair of patrons for a consideration.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975; amd. 2019 Code)
4-23-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall establish, maintain or operate a barbershop/hair salon without
first having obtained a license therefor.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975; amd. 2019 Code)
4-23-3: SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   It shall be the duty of every person licensed under this article to at
all times keep the licensed premises in a clean and properly sanitary
condition. All necessary measures shall be taken to properly safeguard the life
and health of patrons and all persons engaged therein against communicable and
contagious diseases. No person shall be permitted to be employed who shall be
afflicted with any communicable or contagious disease.
   B.   All persons employed or working in the licensed premises shall keep
themselves and their clothing clean, and shall be required to wash their hands
immediately before serving a customer. All towels and washcloths shall be
washed with soap and water and boiled before being used. All receptacles,
finger bowls, utensils, vessels, appliances, combs, brushes, hair management
and all similar items shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. Separate
receptacles shall be provided for soiled towels and separate receptacles for
receiving material and paper.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-23-4: LOCATION; VENTILATION:
No barbershop/hair salon shall be located or conducted except as an independent
unit, completely equipped as such, and separated from any living, dining or
sleeping apartment, restaurant or food establishment. The premises shall be
adequately ventilated in accordance with the requirements of this Code.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975; amd. 2019 Code)
4-23-5: INSPECTIONS:
The Health and Licensing Department shall cause periodic inspections to be made
of all establishments licensed hereunder to determine whether there is
compliance with the health and sanitation regulations of this Code.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 24: MASSAGE AND MICROBLADE BUSINESSES
ARTICLE A: MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS AND THERAPISTS
Section
4-24A-1:   Definitions
4-24A-2:   State Therapist License Required
4-24A-3:   Business License Regulations
4-24A-3-1:   License Required
4-24A-3-2:   Application For License
4-24A-3-3:   License And Application Fees
4-24A-3-4:   Issuance Or Denial Of License
4-24A-3-5:   Number Of Licenses
4-24A-3-6:   Renewal Of License
4-24A-3-7:   Conditions Of And Restrictions Of License
4-24A-3-8:   Revocation Of License
4-24A-4:   Temporary Business License
4-24A-5:   Convention Massage And FOC Massage License Requirements
4-24A-5-1:   General License Requirements And Conditions
4-24A-5-2:   Applications For Permits
4-24A-5-3:   Issuance Or Denial Of Licenses
4-24A-6:   Display Of Licenses
4-24A-7:   Continued Reporting Of Identity Of Therapists And Employees
4-24A-8:   Sanitation And Safety Requirements
4-24A-9:   Hotel Massages
4-24A-10:   Prohibitions On And Conditions Of Giving Massages
4-24A-11:   Exemptions From Provisions
4-24A-12:   Enforcement Officials
4-24A-13:   Penalties
4-24A-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
CHAIR MASSAGE: A massage performed in a specialized chair used specifically for
the purpose of massage and limited to a client's head, neck, back, arms,
shoulders and legs.
CONVENTION MASSAGE: A chair massage performed by a massage therapist licensed
by the Illinois Department of Professional Regulation in an exhibit booth at
the Donald E. Stephens Convention Center or in an exhibit booth at a trade show
or public exhibition being held at another hotel or publicly owned exposition
site in the Village.
EMPLOYEE: Any person over sixteen (16) years of age, other than a massage
therapist, who renders any service in connection with the operation of a
massage establishment and receives compensation from the owner or operator of
the establishment or patrons.
FOC: Any retail shopping mall in excess of five hundred thousand (500,000)
square feet in floor area, including the Fashion Outlets of Chicago fashion
outlet shopping mall located at 5220 Fashion Outlets Way, Rosemont, Illinois.
FOC MASSAGE: A chair massage performed by a massage therapist licensed by the
Illinois Department of Professional Regulation and that possesses an FOC
massage license issued pursuant to this article, and that is performed in a
public kiosk space in the FOC that is provided, leased or licensed by the FOC
owner to the massage therapist for the purpose of providing chair massage as an
amenity for FOC shoppers.
FOC MASSAGE PREMISES: Public kiosk space within the FOC that is provided,
leased or licensed to a massage therapist with an FOC massage permit for the
purpose of providing chair massage as an amenity for FOC shoppers.
HEALTH CLUB: An indoor facility designed, intended and used as a location where
persons can exercise and where the providing of massages is ancillary to the
facility’s primary business. To qualify as a health club under this article, a
facility must have not less than ten (10) exercise machines and must comply
with the sanitation and safety requirements set forth in section 4-24A-8 of
this article.
HOME MASSAGE: A massage performed by a massage therapist licensed by the
Illinois Department of Professional Regulation at a patron’s place of
residence.
HOTEL ROOM MASSAGE: A massage performed by a massage therapist licensed by the
Illinois Department of Professional Regulation in a hotel or motel room for
which the patron is registered as an overnight guest.
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT: Any place of business where any person, for any
consideration whatsoever, engages in the practice of massage but does not
include any hospitals, nursing homes, facilities or offices at which a
healthcare worker duly licensed by the State of Illinois provides, on an
ongoing basis, professional health services to individuals including, but not
limited to, the Illinois Occupational Therapy Practice Act (225 ILCS 75/1 et
seq.); the Illinois Physical Therapy Act (225 ILCS 90/1 et seq.); the Medical
Practice Act (225 ILCS 60/1 et seq.); or the Illinois Naprapathic Practice Act
(225 ILCS 63/1 et seq.). For the purpose of this article, locations in the
Village where convention massages, hotel room massages, FOC massages,
promotional business massages or workplace massages may be allowed shall not be
considered as a massage establishment place of business.
MASSAGE OR MASSAGE THERAPY: A system of structured palpation or movement of the
soft tissue of the body. The system may include, but is not limited to,
techniques such as effleurage or stroking and gliding, petrissage or kneading,
tapotement or percussion, friction, vibration, compression, and stretching
activities as they pertain to massage therapy. These techniques may be applied
by a licensed massage therapist with or without the aid of lubricants, salt or
herbal preparations, hydromassage, thermal massage, or a massage device that
mimics or enhances the actions possible by human hands. "Massage" does not
include the diagnosis of a specific pathology. MASSAGE does not include those
acts of physical therapy or therapeutic or corrective measures that are outside
the scope of massage therapy practice as defined herein.
MASSAGE SERVICES: The providing of a massage or massages by any person, firm,
association or corporation and shall include chair massages, convention
massages, FOC massages, home massages, hotel massages, workplace massages,
promotional business massages or massages at a massage establishment.
MASSAGE THERAPIST: A person who is licensed by the Illinois Department of
Professional Regulation and administers massage for compensation. The use of
the masculine gender shall include in all cases the feminine gender as well.
PATRON: Any person who receives a massage under such circumstances that it is
reasonably expected that he will pay money or give other consideration for such
service.
PROMOTIONAL BUSINESS MASSAGE: A chair massage given at a place of business,
other than a massage establishment, which has been issued a business license by
the Village of Rosemont during regular business hours in order to promote the
business at the location where the massage is given. Promotional business
massages may be given at businesses where alcoholic beverages are consumed on
the premises; provided, that the business has a current Village of Rosemont
liquor license.
SHOW: A convention, trade show or public exhibition held on show premises.
SHOW PREMISES: Public exhibition space located within the Donald E. Stephens
Convention Center or within a hotel located in the Village of Rosemont where
convention massages will be given within public exhibit booths as part of a
show being presented on the show premises.
WORKPLACE MASSAGE: A chair massage performed by a massage therapist licensed
pursuant to the provisions of this article on a fully clothed patron in the
patron’s office or business setting in an area of the Village which is zoned
for commercial use.
(Ord. 2014-8-13N, 8-13-2014)
4-24A-2: STATE THERAPIST LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall provide massage services in the Village to any person unless he
or she has a valid and current massage therapist license issued to him or her
by the Illinois Department of Professional Registration or is exempt from
obtaining a massage therapist license from the Illinois Department of
Professional Registration under the provisions of section 25 of the Illinois
Massage Licensing Act (225 ILCS 57/25)
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-3: BUSINESS LICENSE REGULATIONS:
4-24A-3-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in or carry on the business
of a massage establishment in the Village without first obtaining a massage
business license issued by the Village pursuant to the provisions of this
article for each and every premises used for the business of providing massage
services. The applicant for such a business license must be at least eighteen
(18) years of age.
   B.   A person, firm or corporation that does not operate a massage
establishment in the Village shall not provide massage services in the Village
unless there has first been obtained a massage business license issued by the
Village pursuant to the provisions of this article. The applicant for such
business license must be at least eighteen (18) years of age.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-3-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a massage business license shall be filed with the Director
of the Health and Licensing Department. The application fee for a massage
business license shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00). The application
shall be made upon a form provided by the Director and shall be completed in
full and signed by the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized
agent thereof, if not an individual, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall
set forth:
      1.   The type of ownership of the business, i.e., whether individual,
partnership, corporation, limited liability company, or otherwise.
      2.   Federal employee identification number (FEIN) and State of Illinois
tax number.
      3.   The name and business address under which the business is to be
conducted and, if different, the address of any massage establishment locations
within the Village.
      4.   For each massage establishment, the location and description of each
premises in which a massage establishment is to be operated in the Village
under such license, the square footage of the premises, a description of all
business activities performed on the premises, a detailed floor plan for the
premises and:
         a.   If a leased premises, a copy of the lease shall be provided. The
term of such lease must not end until after the expiration date of the license
for which application is being made.
         b.   The name and address of the owner(s) of the premises and if said
premises is held in trust, the names and addresses of all the owners of the
beneficial interest of the trust.
      5.   In the case of an individual, the full name, home address with zip
code, social security number, date of birth, sex, a photo of the applicant and
a physical description of the applicant, including height, weight, color of
hair and eyes.
      6.   In the case of a partnership, the full names, home addresses with
zip codes, social security numbers, dates of birth, sex, photos and physical
descriptions including height, weight, color of hair and eyes of all partners
and any other persons entitled to share in the profits thereof.
      7.   In the case of a corporation or limited liability company, the
object for which organized, the names, home addresses with zip codes, dates of
birth, social security numbers, sex, photos and physical descriptions including
height, weight, color of hair and eyes of all officers, directors, managers,
members and all persons owning directly or beneficially more than ten percent
(10%) of the stock/interest of such corporation/limited liability company and
the persons acting as managers or assistant managers or other persons
principally in charge of the operation of the business.
      8.   The date of formation of the partnership, if a partnership; the date
of incorporation, if an Illinois corporation; the date of organization, if a
limited liability company; and the date of becoming qualified to transact
business in Illinois, if a foreign corporation or a foreign limited liability
company.
      9.   A description of the exact type of massages administered.
      10.   A complete list of the names, residence addresses with zip codes,
dates of birth, social security numbers, sex, photos and physical descriptions
including height, weight, color of hair and eyes, of all massage therapists and
employees working for the applicant.
      11.   A copy of the massage therapist licenses issued by the Illinois
Department of Financial and Professional Regulation for every massage therapist
providing massage services for the applicant.
      12.   The business, occupation, and employment of the applicant, if an
individual, for three (3) years preceding the date of application.
      13.   Whether applicant ever made an application for a license under this
article or a massage business license or similar license to a state or county,
city, village or other unit of local government, and if so, where and when, and
if such application was granted or denied, and if such application was denied,
the reasons for the denial.
      14.   Whether a license was ever issued to the applicant under this
article or a massage business license or similar license was ever issued by any
state or county, city or village or other unit of local government, and if so,
where and when, and if such license has ever been suspended or revoked and the
reasons for the suspension or revocation.
      15.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any
of the provisions of this article or any ordinance of any other Illinois
municipality which regulates massage establishments or the providing of
massages, or any Illinois statute regulating massage establishments or the
providing of massages.
      16.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of
a felony under the laws of this state or any other state, or under the laws of
the United States.
   B.   The applicant(s) shall submit a complete set of fingerprints with the
application. An applicant that is a partnership, corporation or a limited
liability company shall submit a complete set of fingerprints for all persons
that have a ten percent (10%) or greater interest in the entity. All such
fingerprinting shall be done by the Village Department of Public Safety. The
fingerprints shall be submitted to the appropriate State and/or Federal
agencies for processing as available. The cost of fingerprinting shall be paid
by the applicant in addition to any application or license fee.
   C.   The applicant shall submit a written authorization for the Village, its
agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation
(including the submittal of fingerprint records to State and/or Federal
agencies) for the purpose of determining the truth of the statements set forth
in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for a license.
   D.   The applicant shall submit such other information, documentation, and
identification of the applicant as the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department and/or the Chief of Public Safety shall deem necessary to determine
the identity of the applicant or to process the application.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-3-3: LICENSE AND APPLICATION FEES:
The annual license fee for a massage business license shall be as provided in
the Village Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1B of this Code. The fee for an
application and/or a renewal application shall be three hundred dollars
($300.00). All applicable license fees and any other required fees shall be
paid prior to the issuance of any license.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011; amd. 2019 Code)
4-24A-3-4: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF LICENSE:
   A.   Upon receipt of a properly completed application for a massage business
license, the Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall submit the
completed application to the Chief of Public Safety for evaluation. Upon
receiving the application for a massage business license, the Chief of Public
Safety shall conduct an investigation into the applicant's personal and
criminal history.
   B.   Where a massage establishment is proposed to be located in the Village,
the Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall cause the premises to
be licensed to be inspected to assure that the proposed operation complies with
all applicable laws, including Building, Electrical, Plumbing, Health, Housing,
Zoning, and Fire Codes of the Village and any other regulations of the Village
relating to the public health, safety and welfare.
   C.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall either issue
a massage business license or notify the applicant in writing that the
application has been denied. The license shall be denied if the applicant fails
to comply with the requirements of this article or with the requirements of any
other provision of this Code which is applicable to the business and/or
activities of the applicant. In addition, no license shall be issued to any
applicant if:
      1.   The proposed premises or place of business for the massage
establishment does not comply with all applicable laws including, but not
limited to, Building, Electrical, Plumbing, Health, Housing, Zoning and Fire
Codes of the Village; or
      2.   The applicant, if an individual; or any of the officers, directors,
members, managers, or any person owning directly or beneficially more than ten
percent (10%) of the stock/interest of the corporation/limited liability
company if the applicant is a corporation or limited liability company; or any
of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership;
and the manager, assistant manager or any other person principally in charge of
the operation of the business, has been:
         a.   Convicted of a felony under the laws of the State of Illinois or
any other state, or under the Federal laws of the United States, within five
(5) years of the date of the application; or
         b.   Convicted of a sex offense as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes section 5/11, or any equivalent law of any state within five (5) years
of the date of the application; or
         c.   The applicant has been convicted of a violation of any provision
of this article; or
         d.   The applicant has had a massage business, massage therapist or
similar license denied, suspended or revoked by the Village, by a state or by a
unit of local government within five (5) years of the date of the application;
or
         e.   The applicant has been convicted of a violation of an ordinance
of any other Illinois municipality regulating massage establishments or massage
therapists; or
         f.   The applicant has been convicted of any other criminal offense
involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or moral turpitude within five (5) years of
the date of the application; or
         g.   The applicant has knowingly made false, misleading or fraudulent
statements of fact in the license application or in any document required by
the Village in conjunction with the license application.
   D.   In the event that the massage business license is denied for failure to
comply with the requirements of this article, the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department shall immediately notify the applicant in writing of the
reasons for the denial. If the failure is not cured within ten (10) days after
the date on which the Director denies the issuance of said license, the
application shall be null and void.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-3-5: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
No more than four (4) massage business licenses shall be issued at any given
time.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-3-6: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
An application for renewal of a massage business license shall be filed with
the Director of the Health and Licensing Department. The application shall be
made upon a form provided by the Director and shall be completed in full and
signed by the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent
thereof, if not an individual, and verified by oath or affidavit. Except, the
Director may allow the renewing applicant to only submit any information that
has changed from the last application, provided the renewal applicant certifies
that all the other information remains the same. The Director, in his
discretion, may also waive the submission of fingerprints for the renewal
application.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-3-7: CONDITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS OF LICENSE:
   A.   Supervision:
      1.   A massage business licensee that operates a massage establishment
shall have the premises supervised at all times when open for business.
      2.   Any massage establishment rendering massage services shall have at
least one person who has a valid massage therapist's license issued by the
Illinois Department of Professional Regulation on the premises at all times
while the establishment is open.
      3.   The licensee shall personally supervise the massage establishment
and shall not violate, or permit others to violate, any applicable provisions
of this article.
      4.   The violation of any provisions by any agent or employee of a
massage establishment shall constitute a violation of the licensee.
   B.   Separate Licenses For Each Premises: A license issued for a massage
establishment shall apply only to the premises described in the application and
in the license issued thereon, and only one location shall be so described in
each license.
   C.   Nontransferability Of License: A massage business license shall be a
purely personal privilege, effective for a period not to exceed one year after
issuance unless sooner revoked as provided in this article, and shall not
constitute property. No massage business license is transferable, separate or
divisible, and such authority as a license confers shall be conferred only on
the licensee named therein.
   D.   Appointment Books: Every massage business licensee shall at all times
keep an appointment book in which the name of each and every patron shall be
entered, together with the time, date and place of service, and the service
provided. Such book shall be available at all times for inspection by the
Director of the Health and Licensing Department or his authorized
representative.
   E.   Minors: No person, firm or corporation licensed under the provisions of
this article shall permit any person under the age of eighteen (18) to come or
remain on the premises of any massage establishment or receive any type of
massage, unless such person is an employee of the massage business
establishment or is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
   F.   Alcoholic Beverages Prohibited: No person, firm or corporation shall
sell, give, dispense, provide, or keep, or cause to be sold, given, dispensed,
provided or kept, any alcoholic beverage on the premises of any massage
establishment.
   G.   Entry Powers For Inspections: The Director of the Health and Licensing
Department, any duly authorized public safety officer, or a health inspector of
the Village shall have the right to enter the premises of any massage
establishment for the purpose of inspecting the premises or operations therein.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-3-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Any license issued under this article may, after a hearing, be revoked
by the Director of the Health and Licensing Department, during the term of such
license for the violation by the licensee of any provision of this article, a
violation of any other ordinance of the Village relating to the license, the
subject of the license or to the premises occupied, or any applicable provision
of Federal or State law. Such revocation may be in addition to any fine
imposed. Prior to a revocation hearing, the licensee shall be provided with
notice of the reasons revocation is being sought. At the hearing, the licensee
may be represented by counsel, who may call witnesses to testify and who may
cross examine witnesses. After the hearing, the Director shall prepare a
written decision stating the reasons for his decision. The licensee may appeal
a decision revoking the license to the Village President whose decision shall
be final.
   B.   In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the massage
business license of any licensed proprietor who refuses to permit a public
safety officer or other employee of the Village who is authorized to make an
inspection of the licensed premises, or who interferes with such public safety
officer or other employee while in the performance of his/her duty in making
such inspection may be revoked pursuant to the procedures set forth in
subsection A of this section.
   C.   If a massage business license is revoked for any cause, no massage
business license shall be granted to any person for a period of one year after
the date of the revocation that will allow a massage business to be operated on
the premises described in the revoked license unless the revocation order has
been vacated.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-4: TEMPORARY BUSINESS LICENSE:
The Director of the Health and Licensing Department may in his discretion,
award a temporary massage business license for up to thirty (30) calendar days
to an applicant who has filed a complete application and paid the required fee
so long as the Director is aware of no reason that would require the denial of
a massage business license.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-5: CONVENTION MASSAGE AND FOC MASSAGE; LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
4-24A-5-1: GENERAL LICENSE REQUIREMENTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   A massage therapist licensed by the Illinois Department of Professional
Regulation may provide convention massage services at a show for a period not
to exceed three (3) days; provided that, the therapist has first obtained a
convention massage license issued by the Village pursuant to the provisions of
this article. The applicant for such license must be at least eighteen (18)
years of age.
   B.   A massage therapist licensed by the Illinois Department of Professional
Regulation may provide Fashion Outlets of Chicago (FOC) massage services at the
FOC; provided, that the therapist has first obtained an FOC massage license.
FOC massage license shall be valid for a license year commencing January 1, or
on the date of issuance, and expiring on December 31 of the same year. An
applicant for an FOC massage license 1) must be at least eighteen (18) years of
age; and 2) shall demonstrate that the therapist has either been hired by the
FOC to provide FOC massage services or has leased or licensed an FOC kiosk
space from the FOC owner for the purpose of providing chair massage at the FOC
as an amenity for FOC shoppers.
   C.   A massage establishment business license is not required for the
issuance of a convention massage license or an FOC massage license.
   D.   Convention massage services may only be provided in show premises, and
only during the term of the convention massage license issued to the massage
therapist.
   E.   FOC massage services may only be provided in FOC massage premises, and
only during the term of the FOC massage license issued to the massage
therapist.
(Ord. 2014-8-13N, 8-13-2014)
4-24A-5-2: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES:
A.    An application for a convention massage license shall be filed with the
Director of the Health and Licensing Department. The fee for a convention
massage permit shall be twenty dollars ($20.00).
   B.   An application for an FOC massage license shall be filed with the
Director of the Health and Licensing Department. The annual fee for an FOC
massage license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   C.   Applications shall be made upon a form provided by the Director and
shall be completed in full and signed by the applicant, if an individual, or by
a duly authorized agent thereof, if not an individual, verified by oath or
affidavit, and shall set forth:
      1.   The type of ownership of the business, i.e., whether individual,
partnership, corporation, limited liability company, or otherwise.
         a.   In the case of an individual, the full name, home address with
zip code, social security number, date of birth, sex, a photo of the applicant
and a physical description of the applicant, including height, weight, and
color of hair and eyes.
         b.   In the case of a partnership, the full names, home addresses with
zip codes, social security numbers, dates of birth, sex, photos and physical
descriptions including height, weight, and color of hair and eyes of all
partners.
         c.   In the case of a corporation or limited liability company, the
names, home addresses with zip codes, dates of birth, social security numbers,
sex, photos and physical descriptions including height, weight, and color of
hair and eyes of all officers, directors, managers and members.
      2.   In the case of a convention massage license, a complete list of the
names, residence addresses with zip codes, dates of birth, social security
numbers, sex, photos and physical descriptions including height, weight, and
color of hair and eyes of all massage therapists that will provide convention
massage services during the show.
      3.   In the case of an FOC massage license, a complete list of the names,
residence addresses with zip codes, dates of birth, social security numbers,
sex, photos and physical descriptions including height, weight, and color of
hair and eyes of all massage therapists that will provide FOC massage services.
      4.   A copy of the massage therapist licenses issued by the Illinois
Department of Financial and Professional Regulation for every massage therapist
that will provide convention massage or FOC massage services, as applicable.
      5.   The names and addresses of any massage establishment at which the
applicant or applicant's massage therapists have worked in the two (2) years
prior to the date of the application.
      6.   Whether the applicant or the applicant's massage therapists that
will provide convention massage or FOC massage services has ever:
         a.   Had a massage business license or similar license revoked,
suspended or denied by a state or county, city, village or other unit of local
government. If so, the applicant shall state where and when such license was
revoked, suspended or denied, and the reasons for such action.
         b.   Has ever been convicted of a violation of any state, county or
municipal statute or ordinance regulating massage establishments or the
providing of massages.
         c.   Has ever been convicted of the commission of a felony under the
laws of this State, or any other state, or under the laws of the United States.
   D.   The applicant shall submit a complete set of fingerprints for all
massage therapists that will provide convention massage or FOC massage services
pursuant to the application. All such fingerprinting shall be done by the
Village Department of Public Safety. The fingerprints shall be submitted to the
appropriate State and/or Federal agencies for processing as available. The cost
of fingerprinting shall be paid by the applicant in addition to any application
or license fee.
   E.   If required by the Director of the Health and Licensing Department, the
applicant shall submit a written authorization for the Village, its agents and
employees to seek information and conduct an investigation (including the
submittal of fingerprint records to State and/or Federal agencies) for the
purpose of determining the truth of the statements set forth in the application
and the qualifications of the applicant for a license.
   F.   The applicant shall submit such other information, documentation, and
identification of the applicant as the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department and/or the Chief of Public Safety shall deem necessary to determine
the identity of the applicant or to process the application.
(Ord. 2014-8-13N, 8-13-2014)
4-24A-5-3: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF LICENSES:
   A.   Upon receipt of a properly completed application for a convention
massage or FOC massage license, the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department shall submit the completed application to the Superintendent of
Public Safety for evaluation. The Superintendent shall conduct an investigation
into the applicant’s personal and criminal history.
   B.   The Director shall cause the show premises to be inspected to assure
that convention massage services to be provided will comply the requirements of
this article and any other regulations of the Village relating to public
health, safety and welfare.
   C.   The Director shall cause the FOC massage premises to be inspected to
assure that FOC massage services to be provided will comply the requirements of
this article and any other regulations of the Village relating to public
health, safety and welfare.
   D.   A massage license under this section shall be denied if the applicant
fails to comply with the requirements of this article or with the requirements
of any other provision of this Code which is applicable to the business and/or
activities of the applicant. In addition, no license shall be issued to any
applicant if:
      1.   The proposed show premises or FOC massage premises (as applicable)
does not comply with the requirements of this article; or
      2.   The applicant, if an individual; or any of the officers, directors,
members, managers, or any person owning directly or beneficially more than ten
percent (10%) of the stock/interest of the corporation/limited liability
company if the applicant is a corporation or limited liability company; or any
of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership;
and the manager, assistant manager or any other person principally in charge of
the operation of the business, does not meet the requirements of subsection 4-
24A-3-4C2 of this article.
   E.    In the event that the application, for convention massage license or
FOC massage license is denied for failure to comply with the requirements of
this article, the Director shall immediately notify the applicant in writing of
the reasons for the denial. If the failure is not cured within ten (10) days
after the date on which the Director denies the issuance of the license, the
application shall be null and void.
(Ord. 2014-8-13N, 8-13-2014)
4-24A-6: DISPLAY OF LICENSES:
   A.   The massage business license and the massage therapist license issued
by the Illinois Department of Professional Regulation for each and every
massage therapist working in a massage establishment shall be displayed in an
open and conspicuous place on the premises of the massage establishment. A
massage therapist who performs a hotel room massage, promotional business
massage or workplace massage shall have a copy of his massage therapist license
issued by the Illinois Department of Professional Regulation and a copy of the
Village issued massage business license he is working under with him when
performing such massages and shall display said licenses upon request by the
massage patron or an officer or other employee of the Village authorized to
administer this article.
   B.   A massage therapist who performs a convention massage pursuant to a
convention massage license, shall have a copy of his massage therapist license
issued by the Illinois Department of Professional Regulation and a copy of the
Village issued convention massage license he is working under with him when
performing such massages and shall display said licenses upon request by the
massage patron, the show sponsor, or an officer or other employee of the
Village authorized to administer this article.
   C.   A massage therapist who performs FOC massages pursuant to an FOC
massage license shall have a copy of his massage therapist license issued by
the Illinois Department of Professional Regulation and a copy of the Village
issued FOC massage license he is working under with him when performing such
massages, and shall display said license upon request by the massage patron
customer, FOC management, or an officer or other employee of the Village
authorized to administer this article.
(Ord. 2014-8-13N, 8-13-2014)
4-24A-7: CONTINUED REPORTING OF THE IDENTITY OF THERAPISTS AND EMPLOYEES:
   A.   All massage business licensees shall have a continuing duty to provide
the Director of the Health and Licensing Department with a list of all massage
therapists authorized to work for the licensed business. A licensed massage
business shall not allow any massage therapist to work on its behalf in the
Village until after the Director has received information on the massage
therapist’s name, residence address with zip code, date of birth, social
security number, sex, photo and a physical description including height,
weight, and color of hair and eyes. All massage business licensees shall advise
the Director of the identity of any massage therapist that is no longer
authorized to work on its behalf in writing within two (2) business days after
this change in status. The written notice of the massage therapist’s change in
status shall include the last date the massage therapist was authorized to work
for the licensee.
   B.   All massage business licensees shall have a continuing duty to provide
the Director with a list of all employees and agents (other than massage
therapists) working for the licensed business. A licensed massage business
shall not allow any such employee or agent to work on its behalf in the Village
until after the Director has received information on the individual’s name,
residence address with zip code, date of birth, social security number, sex,
photo and a physical description including height, weight, and color of hair
and eyes. All massage business licensees shall advise the Director of the
identity of any employee that is no longer working on its behalf in writing
within two (2) business days after this change in status. The written notice of
the employee’s change in status shall include the last date the employee was
authorized to work for the licensee.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-8: SANITATION AND SAFETY REQUIREMENTS:
All massage establishments shall be periodically inspected by the Director of
Public Works and/or the Director of the Health and Licensing Department, or
their duly authorized representatives, for safety of the structure and adequacy
of plumbing, ventilation, heating, illumination and fire protection. In
addition, the premises of all massage establishments shall comply with the
following regulations:
   A.   The walls shall be clean and painted with washable, mold resistant
paint in all rooms where water or steam baths are given;
   B.   Floors shall be free from any accumulation of dust, dirt or refuse;
   C.   All equipment used in the massage operation shall be maintained in a
clean and sanitary condition;
   D.   Soap, towels and laundered sheets must be provided, and all such
towels, linen and items for personal use of operators and patrons shall be
clean and freshly laundered;
   E.   Towels, cloths and sheets shall not be used for more than one patron;
provided, however, heavy white paper may be substituted for sheets; provided,
that such paper is changed for every patron.
   F.   All massage services or practices are prohibited in any cubicle, room,
or booth or any area within a massage establishment which is fitted with a door
capable of being locked.
   G.   Separate toilets, dressing room facilities, lockers, steam baths, tubs
and showers shall be provided for each sex.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-9: HOTEL MASSAGES:
Hotel massages are only allowable if there is compliance with each and every
one of the requirements of this article and all of the following conditions:
   A.   Hotel massages shall only be given between the hours of six o'clock (6:
00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. Hotel massages shall only be scheduled by
appointment. No appointment shall be scheduled to begin after nine o'clock (9:
00) P.M. The massage therapist shall not remain in the room after ten o'clock
(10:00) P.M.
   B.   The massage therapist shall maintain a book/binder into which the
following information for each hotel massage shall be recorded: 1) the name of
the massage therapist; 2) the massage therapist's Illinois massage therapy
license number; 3) the name of the Village massage business licensee for whom
the massage therapist is working; 4) the name of the client for the hotel
massage; 5) the date of the hotel massage; 6) the hotel name and the hotel room
number for the massage; and 7) a copy of an e-mail to the hotel's designated
representative sent prior to the hotel massage that advises the hotel of the
client's name, date, time and room number for massage services. The e-mail
shall also contain the massage therapist's Illinois massage therapy license
number and Village license number under which the therapist is working at the
time and date of the scheduled massage services. The massage therapist shall
have a copy of the book/binder required by this subsection at all times the
therapist is on the premises of a hotel for the purpose of performing a hotel
massage and shall turn his book/binder over to any Village employee immediately
upon request. Within one business day after a request of the Director of the
Health and Licensing Department or any other Village representative, the
massage therapist shall submit a copy his book/binder to the Village.
   C.   The massage therapist shall at all times wear an identification badge
stating his name and the name of the Village massage business licensee he is/
are working for.
   D.   The message therapist shall wear a uniform of the type and kind
determined by the Village massage business licensee.
   E.   A massage therapist who performs a hotel room massage shall have a copy
of his massage therapist's license issued by the Illinois Department of
Professional Regulation and a copy of the Village issued massage business
license he is working under with him when performing such massage and shall
display said licenses upon request by the patron or an officer or other
employee of the Village authorized to administer this article.
   F.   It shall be a violation of this section for the owner and/or operator
of any hotel or motel and/or any employee or agent of any hotel or motel to
refer a guest desiring a hotel massage to: 1) any business providing massage
services that does not have a Village massage business license; or 2) to any
massage therapist that does not have a Village massage business license and is
not working for a business that has a massage business license.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-10: PROHIBITIONS ON AND CONDITIONS OF GIVING MASSAGES:
   A.   A patron’s sexual or genital area, including the genitals, pubic area,
buttocks, anus, or perineum of the patron, or the vulva or breasts of a female,
must be covered by towels, cloths or undergarments when in the presence of a
massage therapist or employee.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person, intentionally, in a massage
establishment, or while a home massage, convention massage, promotional
business massage or workplace massage is being provided, to place his hand
upon, to touch with any part of his body, to fondle in any manner, or to
massage the genital area of another person.
   C.   No massage therapist or employee shall perform or offer or agree to
perform any act which would require the touching of the patron’s genital area.
   D.   No massage therapist shall administer a massage to a patron exhibiting
any skin fungus, skin infection, skin inflammation, or skin eruption, unless a
physician duly licensed by the State of Illinois certifies in writing that such
person may be safely massaged prescribing the conditions thereof.
   E.   A massage therapist providing any type of massage shall wear
appropriate undergarments and outer garments, including a brassiere, if the
massage therapist is a woman. The outer garments being worn must be clean and
suitable. A massage therapist providing any type of massage shall not
intentionally display the undergarments he is wearing to the patron.
   F.   A home massage shall not be given to any person except in the dwelling
unit where the person resides.
   G.   A workplace massage shall be performed in an open communal area, or in
an office, but only if the door to the office is unlocked and is open at least
six inches (6") while the massage is being performed. For purposes of this
article, an office or business shall not include a hotel room.
   H.   No massage shall be given by a massage therapist in a massage
establishment to any person who is less than eighteen (18) years of age unless
such person’s parent or legal guardian is present and signs a consent
authorizing his child to receive a massage. No convention massage, promotional
business massage or workplace massage shall be given to any person who is less
than eighteen (18) years of age.
   I.   Promotional business massages may be given only on weekdays and only
during the hours from six o'clock (6:00) A.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and
