must be given in the area that is accessible to all persons who are legally on
the premises where the promotional business massage is being given.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-11: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
   A.   The provisions of this article shall not apply to the Village,
hospitals, sanitariums, persons holding an unrevoked certificate to practice
the healing arts under the laws of the State of Illinois, or persons working
under the direction of any such person or in any such establishment; nor shall
this article apply to barbers or cosmetologists lawfully carrying out their
respective businesses under a valid, unrevoked license or certificate of
registration issued by the State of Illinois.
   B.   No provisions contained in this article shall be construed to apply to
any person, business, or conduct regulated by the provisions of the Illinois
Physical Therapy Registration Act (225 ILCS 90/1 et seq.).
   C.   The provisions of this article shall not apply to a HEALTH CLUB, as
defined in section 4-24A-1 of this article; provided, that there is compliance
with section 4-24A-8 of this article while any massages are given on the
premises of a health club.
   D.   The provisions of this article shall not apply to a massage therapist
licensed by the Illinois Department of Professional Regulation employed by a
hotel to provide massages to registered overnight guests of the hotel.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-12: ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS:
The Director of the Health and Licensing Department and his deputies shall have
the duty to enforce the provisions of this article.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
4-24A-13: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation including, but not limited to, the owner or
operator of any hotel or motel in the Village; any employee, agent, or
individual working at any hotel or motel in the Village; any massage therapist;
and any Village massage business licensee found guilty of violating any
obligation imposed upon them in this article shall be fined not less than two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than one thousand five hundred dollars
($1,500.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed
on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. The license of
any person found guilty of violating any provision of this article may be
revoked.
(Ord. 2011-12-14N, 12-14-2011)
ARTICLE B: MICROBLADE ESTABLISHMENTS AND ARTISTS
Section
4-24B-1:   Definitions
4-24B-2:   Licenses Required; Qualifications; Expiration And Renewal
4-24B-3:   Applications For Licenses
4-24B-4:   License Fees
4-24B-5:   Issuance Or Denial Of Licenses
4-24B-6:   Display Of Licenses
4-24B-7;   Sanitation And Safety Requirements
4-24B-8:   Conditions Of And Restrictions On Business License
4-24B-9:   Prohibited Acts And Conditions
4-24B-10:   Suspension Or Revocation Of Licenses
4-24B-11:   Enforcement
4-24B-12:   Violations A Nuisance
4-24B-13:   Penalties
4-24B-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
DEPARTMENT: The Village of Rosemont Health and Licensing Department.
DIRECTOR: The Director of the Village of Rosemont Health and Licensing
Department.
EMPLOYEE: Any person, including an independent contractor, who works in or at
or renders any service directly related to the operation of a microblade
establishment, whether or not such person is paid compensation by the operator
of the business or patrons.
MANAGER: Any person who manages, directs, supervises, administers, or is in
charge of the affairs and/or the conduct of a microblade establishment.
MICROBLADE ARTIST: A person who conducts or practices microblading activities
and/or procedures.
MICROBLADE ESTABLISHMENT OPERATOR OR OPERATOR: An individual, partnership,
corporation, association, or other entity engaged in the business of owning,
managing, or offering services of microblade.
MICROBLADE ESTABLISHMENT OR ESTABLISHMENT: A microblade business or operation,
whether public or private, temporary or permanent in nature or location, profit
or not for profit.
MICROBLADE OR MICROBLADING: A semipermanent coloration of the skin or mucosa by
placing ink or other pigment into the skin or mucosa by the aid of needles or
any other instrument or process to simulate hair, skin, or makeup. MICROBLADING
may include, but is not limited to, the application of fine deposits of
cosmetic ink or tattoo pigments to skin or mucosa, a semipermanent application
of pigment to emulate the application of makeup, lip coloring, eye liner, or a
process that provides a means to partially or fully camouflage missing eyebrow
hair with the appearance of simulated hair using fine deposits of cosmetic
tattoo pigments. MICROBLADING may also be known as embroidery, microstroking,
feather touch and hair-like strokes. MICROBLADING does not include any of the
following: a) the practice of “electrolog”, as defined in the Electrology
Licensing Act (225 ILCS 412/1 et seq.); b) the practice of “acupuncture”, as
defined in the Acupuncture License Act (225 ILCS 2/1 et seq.); and c) the use
by a physician licensed to practice medicine in all its branches of colors,
dyes, or pigments for the purpose of obscuring scar tissue or imparting color
to the skin for cosmetic, medical or figurative purposes.
PERSON: Any individual, group of individuals, association, trust, partnership,
corporation, or limited liability company.
SANITATION: The effective bactericidal and virucidal of clean equipment
surfaces by a process that effectively destroys pathogens.
SINGLE USE: Products or items that are intended for one-time, one-person use
and are disposed of after use on each client including, but not limited to,
cotton swabs or balls, tissues or paper products, paper or plastic cups, gauze
and sanitary coverings, razors, piercing needles, needles, scalpels, blades,
microblades, stencils, ink cups and protective gloves.
STERILIZE: To destroy all living organisms including spores.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
4-24B-2: LICENSES REQUIRED; QUALIFICATIONS; EXPIRATION AND RENEWAL: 
   A.   Microblade Business License:
      1.   No person shall engage in or carry on the business of operating a
microblade establishment in the Village without first obtaining a microblade
business license issued by the department in accordance with the provisions, of
this article.
      2.   The applicant for such a business license must be at least eighteen
(18) years of age.
      3.   A license shall expire one year from the date of its issuance. The
renewal of a license shall follow the same provisions under this article for
the application, issuance and denial of a license.
      4.   The Department shall not issue more than two (2) microblade business
licenses.
   B.   Microblade Artist License:
      1.   No person shall conduct or practice microblading on any premises for
which a business license has been issued or is required under subsection A of
this section unless that person has a valid and current microblade artist
license issued by the Department in accordance with the provisions of this
article.
      2.   The applicant for such a license must be at least eighteen (18)
years of age.
      3.   A license shall expire one year from the date of its issuance. The
renewal of a license shall follow the same provisions under this article for
the application, issuance and denial of a license.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
4-24B-3: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES:
   A.   Microblade Business License:
      1.   An application for a microblade business license shall be filed with
the Director of the Health and Licensing Department. The application shall be
made upon a form provided by the department, and shall be completed in full and
signed by the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent
thereof, if not an individual, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall set
forth:
         a.   The type of ownership of the business, i.e., whether individual,
partnership, corporation, or otherwise.
         b.   The name under which the business is to be conducted.
         c.   The location and description of the premises or place of business
which is to be operated under such license.
            (1)   If a leased premises, a copy of the lease shall be provided.
The term of such lease must not end until after the expiration date of the
license for which application is being made.
            (2)   The name and address of the owner(s) of the premises and, if
said premises is held in trust, the names and addresses of all the owners of
the beneficial interest of the trust.
         d.   In the case of an individual, the full name, home address with
zip code, social security number, date of birth, sex and a physical description
of the applicant, including height, weight, and color of hair and eyes.
         e.   In the case of a partnership, the full names, home addresses with
zip codes, social security numbers, dates of birth, sex and physical
descriptions including height, weight, and color of hair and eyes of all
partners and any other persons entitled to share in the profits thereof.
         f.   In the case of a corporation, the object for which organized, the
names, home addresses with zip codes, dates of birth, social security numbers,
sex and physical descriptions including height, weight, and color of hair and
eyes of all officers, directors, and all persons owning directly or
beneficially more than ten percent (10%) of the stock of such corporation and
the persons acting as managers or assistant managers or other persons
principally in charge of the operation of the business.
         g.   The date of formation of the partnership, if a partnership; the
date of incorporation, if an Illinois corporation; or the date of becoming
qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act (805 ILCS 5/1.01 et seq.)
to transact business in Illinois if a foreign corporation.
         h.   A complete list of the names and residence addresses of all
microblade artists and employees employed by the business and the names and
residence addresses of all managers, assistant managers or other persons
principally in charge of the operation of the business.
         i.   The business, occupation, and employment of the applicant, if an
individual, for three (3) years preceding the date of application.
         j.   Whether the applicant ever made an application for a license
under this article or a microblade business license or similar license to a
state or county, city, village or other unit of local government, and if so,
where and when, and if the application was granted or denied, and if the
application was denied, the reasons for the denial.
         k.   Whether a license was ever issued to the applicant under this
article or a microblade business license or similar license was ever issued by
any state or county, city or village or other unit of local government, and if
so, where and when, and if such license has ever been suspended or revoked and
the reasons for the suspension or revocation.
         l.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of
any of the provisions of this article or any ordinance of any other Illinois
municipality which regulates microblade establishments or microblade artists,
or any Illinois statute regulating microblade establishments.
         m.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission
of a felony under the laws of this State, or any other state, or under the laws
of the United States.
         n.   Evidence that the applicant is covered by policies of
comprehensive general liability insurance, including bodily injury and property
damage; and adequate workers’ compensation and vehicle insurance unless the
Village President, in his sole discretion, waives any or all of these insurance
requirements.
      2.   The applicant shall submit a complete set of fingerprints with the
application. All such fingerprinting shall be done by the Village Department of
Public Safety. The fingerprints shall be submitted to the appropriate State
and/or Federal agencies for processing as available. The cost of fingerprinting
shall be paid by the applicant in addition to any application or license fee.
      3.   The applicant shall submit a written authorization for the Village,
its agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into
the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications
of the applicant for a license.
      4.   The applicant shall submit such other information, documentation,
and identification of the applicant as the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department shall deem necessary to determine the identity of the applicant or
to process the application.
      5.   The applicant shall submit such other documentation or information
showing the following:
         a.   Proof of completion of a bloodborne pathogen training program,
compliant with the OSHA Bloodborne Pathogens requirement (29 CFR 1910.1030),
for each body artist employed by the applicant.
         b.   The type and year of manufacture of the equipment proposed to be
used for microblading.
         c.   The sterilization and operation procedures to be used by the
microblading establishment.
         d.   A floor plan of the licensed premises, showing the location of
required facilities and work stations.
         e.   Compliance with the sanitation and safety requirements under
section 4-24B-7 of this article.
         f.   Compliance with applicable Property Maintenance, Zoning and
Building Codes.
      6.   The applicant shall submit to an inspection of the licensed premises
by the Village to verify information contained in the application.
   B.   Microblade Artist License:
      1.   An application for a microblade artist license shall be filed with
the Director of the Health and Licensing Department. The application shall be
made upon a form provided by the department, and shall be completed in full and
signed by the applicant, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall set forth:
         a.   The business address and telephone numbers where the applicant
will be providing microblading.
         b.   The full name, home address with zip code, social security
number, date of birth, sex and a physical description of the applicant,
including height, weight, and color of hair and eyes.
         c.   The business, occupation, and employment of the applicant for
three (3) years preceding the date of application.
         d.   Whether the applicant has ever made an application for a
microblade artist license under this article, or a microblade artist or similar
license to a state or county, city or village or other unit of local
government, and if so, where and when and if such application was granted or
denied, and if such application was denied, the reasons for the denial.
         e.   Whether a microblade artist license was ever issued to the
applicant under this article or a microblade artist or similar license was ever
issued by any state or county, city or village or other unit of local
government, and if so, where and when, and if such license has ever been
suspended or revoked and the reasons for the suspension or revocation.
         f.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of
any of the provisions of this article or any ordinance of any other Illinois
municipality which regulates microblade establishments or the practice of
microblading, or any Illinois statute regulating microblading.
         g.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission
of a felony under the laws of this State, or any other state, or under the laws
of the United States.
      2.   The applicant shall submit a statement in writing from a physician
duly licensed in the State of Illinois that he has examined the applicant and
believes the applicant to be free of all communicable diseases. An applicant is
required to undergo an annual physical examination and to furnish a medical
certificate relating to communicable diseases with his annual fee.
      3.   The applicant shall submit a complete set of fingerprints with the
application for a microblade artist license. All such fingerprinting shall be
done by the Department of Public Safety. The fingerprints shall be submitted to
the appropriate State and/or Federal agencies for processing as available. The
cost of fingerprinting shall be paid by the applicant in addition to any other
required license or application fee.
      4.   The applicant shall submit a written authorization for the Village,
its agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into
the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications
of the applicant for a license.
      5.   The applicant shall submit such other information, documentation,
and identification of the applicant as the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department shall deem necessary to determine the identity of the applicant or
to process the application.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
4-24B-4: LICENSE FEES:
The annual license fees for a microblade business license and a microblade
artist license shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule in section 3-
10-1 of the Village Code. All applicable license fees and any other required
fees shall be paid prior to the issuance of any license.
(Ord, 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
4-24B-5: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF LICENSES:
   A.   Upon receipt of a properly completed application for a microblade
business license or a microblade artist license, the Director of the Health and
Licensing Department shall submit the completed application to the
Superintendent of Public Safety, who shall conduct an investigation into the
applicant's moral character and personal and criminal history.
   B.   In the case of an application for a microblade business license, the
Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall cause the premises to be
licensed to be inspected to determine that the proposed operation complies with
all applicable laws, including Building, Electrical, Plumbing, Health, Housing,
Zoning, and Fire Codes of the Village and any other regulations of the Village
relating to the public health, safety and welfare.
   C.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall either issue
a license or notify the applicant in writing that the application has been
denied. The license shall be denied if the applicant fails to comply with the
requirements of this article or with the requirements of any other provision of
this Code which is applicable to the business and/or activities of the
applicant. In addition, no license shall be issued to any applicant if:
      1.   The proposed operation does not comply with all applicable laws
including, but not limited to, Building, Electrical, Plumbing, Health, Housing,
Zoning and Fire Codes of the Village; or
2 .   The applicant, if an individual; or any of the officers, directors, any
person owning directly or beneficially more than ten percent (10%) of the stock
of the corporation, if the applicant is a corporation; or any of the partners,
including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; and the manager,
assistant manager or any other person principally in charge of the operation of
the business, has been:
         a.   Convicted of a felony under the laws of the State of Illinois or
any other state, or under the Federal laws of the United States, within five
(5) years of the date of the application; or
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
         b.   Convicted of an offense involving the unlawful tattooing or body
piercing of a minor as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12C-35, 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12C-40, or any equivalent law of any state within
five (5) years of the date of the application; or
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018; amd. 2019 Code)
         c.   The applicant has been convicted of a violation of any provision
of this article; or
         d.   The applicant has had a microblade business license, microblade
artist license or similar license denied, suspended or revoked by the Village,
by a state or by a unit of local government within five (5) years of the date
of the application; or
         e.   The applicant has been convicted of a violation of an ordinance
of any other Illinois municipality regulating microblade establishments or
microblade artists; or
         f.   The applicant has been convicted of any other criminal offense
involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or moral turpitude within five (5) years of
the date of the application; or
         g.   The applicant has knowingly made false, misleading or fraudulent
statements of fact in the license application or in any document required by
the Village in conjunction with the license application; or
         h.   The applicant has failed to provide information required by the
license application or this article; or
         i.   The applicant is currently under suspension or revocation of a
license related to microblading issued by the Village or any other jurisdiction
for a violation which would be a violation under the provisions of this
article; or
         j.   The applicant is overdue on payment to the Village of fees,
fines, or penalties assessed against the applicant or imposed upon the
applicant in relation to microblading.
   D.   In the event that the license is denied for failure to comply with the
requirements of this article, the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department shall immediately notify the applicant in writing of the reasons for
the denial. If the failure is not cured within ten (10) days after the date on
which the Director denies the issuance of the license, the application shall be
null and void.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
4-24B-6: DISPLAY OF LICENSES:
The microblade business license and the microblade artist license of all
microblade artists employed by the microblade establishment shall be displayed
in an open and conspicuous place of the premises to be licensed.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
4-24B-7: SANITATION AND SAFETY REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Required Information On File: The following information shall be kept
on file on the premises of a microblade establishment and shall be available
for inspection by the Director of the Health and Licensing Department or the
Director’s authorized representative:
      1.   Microblade Artist Information:
         a.   Full names and exact duties;
         b.   Dates of birth;
         c.   Home addresses;
         d.   Home and work telephone numbers;
         e.   Identification photographs;
         f.   Current places of employment;
      g.   Training documentation/certificates; and
         h.   Proof of completion of a bloodborne pathogen training program
compliant with bloodborne pathogens, OSHA, 29 CFR 1910.1030.
      2.   Establishment Information:
      a.   Name of establishment;
         b.   Hours of operation;
         c.   Owner’s name and home address;
         d.   A copy of the operation procedure required under this section;
         e.   Owner’s telephone numbers; and
         f.   A complete description of all body art procedures performed.
      3.   Operation Procedure Information: The microblade establishment
operator shall prepare, maintain and implement an operation procedure that
meets the following requirements:
         a.   The operation procedure shall provide for response to the
occurrence of any sudden, serious and unexpected sickness or injury that would
lead a reasonable person, possessing an average knowledge of health, to believe
that the sick or injured person requires urgent or unscheduled medical care.
         b.   The operation procedure shall include a method to address
emergency situations including, but not limited to, adverse reactions,
anaphylactic reactions, and accidental needle sticks.
         c.   The operation procedure shall include procedures to be used when
blood, plasma, serum or body fluids, such as semen, saliva, breast milk,
vaginal secretions and any fluid contaminated with blood, are exposed to:
mucous membranes, including eye, mouth or other mucous membranes; broken or
nonintact skin; abraded or irritated skin; or skin surfaces that are otherwise
compromised.
         d.   The operation procedure shall describe methods for obtaining
appropriate medical care in the event of such an exposure and designate
personnel to be notified in the event of an emergency.
         e.   The operation procedure shall be maintained in the establishment
in a location accessible to all employees, and the operator shall train all
employees in the maintenance and implementation of the operation procedure.
   B.   Public Notification Requirements: All licensed microblade
establishments and artists shall provide the following public notification
requirements to all clients:
      1.   Written public education materials, provided by the department,
shall be offered and explained to all clients prior to receiving microblade
procedures.
      2.   Verbal and written instructions for the aftercare of the
microblading shall be provided to each client.
      3.   The written public education materials shall advise the client to
consult a physician or dentist as appropriate at the first sign of infection.
The written public education materials shall also contain the name, address and
phone number of the establishment. These documents shall be signed and dated by
both parties, with a copy given to the client, and the operator shall retain
the original with all other required records for a period of not less than
three (3) years. In addition, all establishments shall prominently display a
disclosure warning poster, provided by the department, which advises the public
of the potential health risks of microblading services.
      4.   The microblade establishment operator and microblade artist shall
report in writing to the department all infections or diseases resulting from a
microblade procedure that required medical attention. The written report shall
be sent to the Department within twenty four (24) hours after receiving a
report that medical attention was required. The report shall include:
      a.   The name, address and phone number of the affected individual;
      b.   The date of the microblade procedure;
      c.   Identification of the microblade artist who performed the service;
         d.   The name, address and certificate of registration number of the
microblade establishment involved;
      e.   The anatomical location, condition and description of the affected
site;
         f.   The name, address and phone number of the affected individual’s
healthcare provider;
         g.   The date that medical attention was sought; and
         h.   Any other information considered relevant to the situation.
   C.   Disclosure Of Pre-Existing Conditions: All microblade establishments
and artists shall request, in writing, that all clients disclose information
reasonably necessary to ensure proper healing from a microblade procedure,
which shall include the disclosure of the following medical conditions:
   1.   Diabetes;
   2.   History of hemophilia (bleeding);
   3.   History of skin diseases, skin lesions or skin sensitivities to soaps,
disinfectants, etc.;
      4.   History of allergies or adverse reactions to pigments, dyes or other
skin sensitivities such as, but not limited to, latex;
      5.   History of epilepsy, seizures, fainting or narcolepsy;
      6.   Medications used, such as anticoagulants that thin the blood and/or
interfere with blood clotting;
      7.   Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV);
      8.   Hepatitis; and
      9.   Any other information that would aid a body art establishment and
body artists in evaluating a client’s body art healing process.
   D.   Operational Safety And Sanitation Requirements: All microblade
establishments and artists shall comply with the following operational safety
and sanitation requirements:
      1.   All walls, floors and procedure surfaces of an establishment shall
be smooth, free of open holes and cracks, and washable. Walls, floors and
ceilings shall be in good repair and maintained in a clean condition. All
procedure surfaces, including client chair/benches, shall be of such
construction as to be easily cleaned and disinfected after each client. All
procedure surfaces shall be cleaned and disinfected after each procedure. The
body art establishment shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at
all times.
      2.   The establishment shall be completely separated by solid partitions
or by walls extending from floor to ceiling from any room used for human
habitation, any food establishment or room where food is prepared, any hair
salon, or any other such activity that may cause potential contamination of
work surfaces.
      3.   Effective measures shall be taken by the operator, manager, and
microblade artist to protect against the presence of insects, vermin and
rodents in the establishment. Exterior doors shall be self-closing and tight
fitting. If windows open, they shall have tightfitting screens.
      4.   The establishment shall have an area that may be screened from
public view for clients requesting privacy. Dividers, curtains or partitions,
at a minimum, shall be available to separate multiple work stations.
      5.   The establishment shall be well ventilated and provided with an
artificial light source equivalent to at least twenty (20) foot candles.
      6.   No animals of any kind shall be allowed in an establishment, except
service animals used by persons with disabilities. Fish aquariums may be
allowed in waiting rooms and nonprocedural areas.
      7.   A separate hand washing sink shall be readily accessible to the
microblade artists within the establishment. The hand sink shall be supplied
with liquid soap and disposable paper towels. One hand sink shall serve no more
than six (6) stations.
      8.   The establishment shall have a minimum of one hand washing sink,
excluding any service sinks, and one toilet facility. The toilet facility shall
be equipped with a hand washing sink, as well as liquid soap and paper towels
in dispensers. Toilet facilities shall have tightfitting, self-closing doors.
Such doors shall not be left open except during cleaning or maintenance. A
supply of toilet tissue shall be provided at each toilet at all times. Toilet
facilities shall also be equipped with mechanical ventilation to the outside
air.
      9.   At least one covered waste receptacle shall be provided at each work
station, lavatory facility, and toilet facility. Receptacles in the work
station shall be emptied daily, and solid waste shall be removed from the
premises at least weekly. All refuse containers shall be cleanable and kept
clean. Waste receptacles shall be kept uncovered during use and covered while
not in use.
      10.   All instruments and supplies shall be stored in clean, dry, covered
containers. The dirty contaminated equipment, including the autoclave and
ultrasonic units, along with cleaning supplies and cleaning equipment, shall be
stored in an area separate from the procedure area. This area shall not be
publicly accessible.
      11.   If reusable cloth items are used, they shall be mechanically washed
with detergent and dried after each use. The cloth items shall be stored in a
dry, clean environment until used.
      12.   The operator shall hire and retain microblade artists whom the
operator has determined possess proficiency and knowledge of the following
subjects, and the microblade artist shall demonstrate proficiency and knowledge
of the following subjects:
      a.   Anatomy;
         b.   Infectious disease control, including waste disposal, handwashing
techniques, sterilization equipment operation and methods, and sanitization/
disinfection/sterilization methods and techniques; and
      c.   Skin diseases, disorders and conditions (including diabetes).
      13.   The microblade artist shall maintain a high degree of personal
cleanliness, conform to good hygienic practices, and wear clean clothes when
performing microblade procedures. Before performing body art procedures,
microblade artists shall thoroughly wash their hands for a minimum of twenty
(20) seconds in tempered running water with liquid soap, then rinse hands and
dry with disposable paper towels. This shall be done as often as necessary to
remove contaminants.
      14.   In performing microblade procedures, the microblade artist shall
wear single-use, medical grade gloves. Gloves shall be changed if they become
contaminated by contact with any nonclean surfaces or objects or by contact
with a third person. The gloves shall be discarded, at a minimum, after the
completion of each procedure on an individual client, and hands shall be washed
before the next pair of gloves is donned. Under no circumstances shall a single
pair of gloves be used on more than one person. The use of single-use, medical
grade gloves does not preclude or substitute for hand washing procedures as
part of a good personal hygiene program.
      15.   If, while performing a microblade procedure, the microblade
artist's glove is pierced, torn or otherwise compromised, the procedures in
subsections D13 and 14 above shall be repeated immediately. The contaminated
gloves shall be immediately discarded, and the hands washed thoroughly before a
fresh pair of gloves is applied. Any item or instrument used for microblading
that is contaminated during the procedure shall be replaced immediately with a
new disposable item or a new sterilized instrument or item before the procedure
resumes.
      16.   Regulated waste that may release liquid blood or body fluids when
compressed, or may release dried blood or body fluids when handled shall be
placed in an approved bag marked with the international biohazard symbol. The
regulated waste shall then be disposed of in compliance with 29 CFR 1910.1030.
Sharps ready for disposal shall be disposed of in approved sharps disposal
containers. Storage of regulated waste on site shall comply with the
regulations in 29 CFR 1910.1030, and storage of regulated waste awaiting pick
up shall not exceed thirty (30) days.
      17.   Waste that does not release liquid blood or body fluids when
compressed or does not release dried blood or body fluids when handled may be
placed in a covered receptacle and disposed of through normal disposal methods.
      18.   Any skin or mucosal surface that is to receive a microblade
procedure shall be free of rash, irritation or any visible infection.
      19.   Before a microblade procedure is performed, the immediate skin area
and the areas of skin surrounding the location of the microblade procedure
shall be washed with liquid soap and water or a skin antiseptic. If shaving is
necessary, single-use, disposable razors shall be used. Following shaving, the
skin and surrounding area shall be washed with liquid soap and water or a skin
antiseptic. The single-use, disposable razor and washing pad shall be discarded
after a single use.
      20.   If bleeding occurs, all products used to check the flow of blood or
to absorb blood shall be single use and shall be disposed of immediately after
use in appropriate covered containers.
      21.   All nondisposable instruments used for microblading shall be
cleaned after each use by scrubbing with an appropriate soap or disinfectant
solution and hot water or by following the manufacturer’s instructions to
remove blood and tissue residue and shall then be placed in an ultrasonic unit
operated in accordance with manufacturer's instructions.
      22.   After cleaning, all nondisposable instruments used for microblading
shall be packed individually in sterilization packaging and subsequently
sterilized. All sterilization packaging shall contain either a sterilization
indicator or internal temperature indicator. Sterilization packaging shall be
dated with an expiration date not to exceed six (6) months or in accordance
with manufacturer’s instructions. If sterilization packaging is compromised or
expired, the instrument shall be removed, repackaged and resterilized.
      23.   All cleaned, nondisposable instruments used for microblading shall
be sterilized in an autoclave that meets the criteria specified in this
article. The autoclave shall be used, cleaned and maintained according to
manufacturer’s instruction. The operator shall retain on site a copy of the
manufacturer’s recommended procedures for the operation of the sterilization
unit and a daily temperature log for each day's use. If the microblade
establishment uses only single-use, disposable instruments and products and
uses sterile, single-use needles and tubes, an autoclave shall not be required.
      24.   After sterilization, the instruments used for microblading
procedures shall be stored in a dry, clean cabinet or tightly covered container
reserved for the storage of such instruments.
      25.   All instruments shall remain stored in sterile packages until just
prior to the performance of a microblading procedure. When assembling
instruments used for microblading procedures, the operator or artist shall wear
single-use, disposable, medical grade gloves and use aseptic techniques to
ensure that the instruments and the gloves are not contaminated.
      26.   All inks, pigments, needles and equipment shall be specifically
manufactured for performing microblading procedures and shall be used according
to manufacturer’s instructions. Single-use needles, specifically manufactured
for microblading, may be purchased and used to construct a needle bar by the
microblade artist.
      27.   Pigment shall be reconstituted using only distilled or sterile
water or a glycerin product.
      28.   Immediately before the microblading is applied, the quantity of the
ink to be used shall be transferred from the ink bottle and placed into single-
use containers. Upon completion of the microblading, these single-use
containers and their contents shall be discarded.
      29.   Each licensee shall demonstrate, by monthly spore destruction
tests, that the autoclave used is capable of attaining sterilization. These
tests shall be verified through an independent laboratory. Test records shall
be retained on site by the operator for a period of one year.
      30.   Single-use items shall not be used on more than one client for any
reason. After use, all single-use needles, razors and other sharps shall be
immediately disposed of in approved sharps disposal containers.
      31.   All products applied to the skin, including body art stencils,
shall be single-use and disposable. Petroleum jellies, soaps and other products
used in the application of stencils shall be dispensed and applied to the area
to be microbladed with gauze or in a manner to prevent contamination of the
original container and its contents.
      32.   Single-use items must be stored in a clean, covered location, in a
manner to prevent any contamination.
      33.   All bandages and surgical dressings used in connection with the
microblading of a person shall be sterile and single-use.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
4-24B-8: CONDITIONS OF AND RESTRICTIONS ON BUSINESS LICENSE:
   A.   Supervision: The microblade establishment shall have the premises
supervised at all times when open for business by a manager who is on the site
of the licensed premises. The microblade establishment shall have at least one
person who has a valid microblade artist license on the premises at all times
while the establishment is open for business. The microblade establishment
licensee, operator or manager shall personally supervise the business, and
shall not violate, or permit others to violate, any applicable provisions of
this article. The violation of any provisions by any agent or employee of the
licensee shall constitute a violation of the licensee.
   B.   Separate License For Each Premises: Licenses apply only to the premises
described in the application and in the license issued thereon, and only one
location shall be so described in each license.
   C.   Nontransferability Of License: A license shall be a purely personal
privilege, effective for a period not to exceed one year after issuance unless
sooner revoked as provided in this article, and shall not constitute property.
No license is transferable, separate or divisible, and such authority as a
license confers shall be conferred only on the licensee named therein.
   D.   Books And Records: The microblade establishment shall at all times keep
an appointment book in which the name of each and every patron shall be
entered, together with the time, date and place of service, and the service
provided. Such books and records shall be maintained by the licensee, manager,
or operator for a period of at least three (3) years, and shall be available at
all times for inspection by the Director of the Health and Licensing Department
or an authorized representative.
   E.   Right Of Entry For Inspections: The Director of the Health and
Licensing Department, any duly authorized public safety officer, or a health
inspector of the Village shall have the right to enter the licensed premises
for the purpose of inspecting the premises or operations for compliance with
this article. No licensee, operator, manager, or employee shall deny, impede,
frustrate, limit, prevent, refuse or restrain such an inspection.
   F.   Provisions Not Exclusive: The express enumeration of the specified
conditions and restrictions under this section shall not be construed to limit,
exclude or preclude any other conditions and restrictions required under this
article.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
4-24B-9: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   No person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be permitted to
undergo a microblading procedure unless the person’s parent or legal guardian
signs a written consent form in the presence of an operator, manager or
microblade artist. The consent form shall indicate that the parent or legal
guardian has read and understood the disclosure warning statement and shall be
maintained by the licensee and exhibited upon demand of the Village;
   B.   No establishment shall permit or allow a microblade procedure to be
performed upon any person who appears to be under the influence of drugs or
alcohol or who appears to be incoherent or impaired for any reason;
   C.   No microblade artist affected with infected wounds, open sores, boils,
abrasions, keloids, weeping dermatological lesions or acute respiratory
infection shall work in any area of a body art establishment in which he comes
in contact with members of the public seeking a microblade procedure or with
the equipment, supplies, instruments or working surfaces of the establishment;
   D.   No establishment shall permit the performance of any microblade
procedure which utilizes the implantation of any object(s), such as ball
bearings or beads, under the skin;
   E.   No establishment shall permit or allow smoking, eating or drinking in
the area of the premises in which microblading procedures are performed. No
alcoholic beverages shall be permitted upon the premises of the establishment
during business hours;
F.    No microblade artist may perform any microblade procedure while under the
influence or impairment of alcohol or drugs;
   G.   No microblade procedure shall be performed on skin surfaces where
sunburn, rash, acne, infection, open lesions, or other questionable skin
lesions exist without medical clearance in the form of a written and signed
statement by a physician; and
   H.   The express enumeration of the specified prohibited acts and conditions
under this section shall not be construed to limit, exclude or preclude any
other prohibited acts and conditions required under this article.
   I.   No person, firm or corporation shall sell, give, dispense, provide or
keep, or cause to be sold, given, dispensed, provided or kept, any alcoholic
beverage, marijuana or opioids on the premises of any establishment.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
4-24B-10: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
   A.   Any license issued under this article may be suspended or revoked by
the Village President during the life of such license for the violation by the
licensee of any provision of this article or other ordinance of the Village
relating to the license, the subject of the license, or the premises occupied.
Such revocation may be in addition to any fine imposed.
   B.   If at any time after the granting of the license, a licensee shall have
violated any applicable provisions of Federal or State law, or provisions of
this article or other ordinances of the Village in the conduct of his business,
the Village President may suspend or revoke the license therefor.
   C.   In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the Village
President may suspend or revoke the license of any licensed operator who
refuses to permit a public safety officer or other employee of the Village who
is authorized to make an inspection of the licensed premises, or who interferes
with the public safety officer or other employee while in the performance of
his duty in making such inspection.
   D.   If a license is revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to
any person for a period of one year after the date of the revocation that will
allow a microblade establishment to be operated on the premises described in
the revoked license unless the revocation order has been vacated.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
4-24B-11: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   The Department shall have the duty to enforce the provisions of this
article.
   B.   The Department, Village Prosecutor or Village Attorney shall have the
duty to prosecute violations of any provisions of this article in an
administrative hearing before the Village Administrative Hearing Officer or
Village President. The licensee shall be given due notice of the administrative
hearing and an opportunity to contest any alleged violation or penalty. The
licensee's ignorance of the violation shall not be considered as evidence in
mitigation of any penalty.
   C.   Additionally, if the Department reasonably suspects that a communicable
disease is or may be transmitted by an employee or body artist by use of
unapproved or malfunctioning equipment or by unsanitary or unsafe conditions
and practices or other imminent health hazard that may adversely affect the
health of the public, the department shall either issue a written order
excluding any or all employees or body artists from the body art establishment
who are responsible, or appear to be responsible, for the transmission of a
communicable disease until the department determines there is no further risk
to public health, or the department shall issue a written order to immediately
suspend the license of the body art establishment or body artist until the
department determines that there is no further risk to the public health. Such
written orders shall state the cause for the action and be provided to the
operator, manager or microblade artist.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018).
4-24B-12: VIOLATIONS A NUISANCE:
Any business or building used as a microblade establishment in violation of
this article, together with all fixtures and other property used in violation
of this article, are hereby declared to be a public nuisance which may be
abated by injunctive relief by a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
4-24B-13: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation found guilty of violating any provisions of
this article shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense, and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues. The license of any person found guilty of violating any
provision of this article may be suspended or revoked.
(Ord. 2018-3-14L, 3-14-2018)
CHAPTER 25: DRY CLEANING
ARTICLE A: DRY CLEANING
Section
4-25A-1:   Definitions
4-25A-2:   License Required
4-25A-3:   Application For License
4-25A-4:   Location
4-25A-5:   Building And Equipment Requirements
4-25A-6:   Other Use Of Premises
4-25A-7:   Separation Of Cleaned And Uncleaned Articles
Cross-reference:
   See subsection 3-10-1B of this Code, entry reading “cleaning and dyeing”,
for license fee
4-25A-1: DEFINITIONS:
DRY CLEANER OR PERSON ENGAGED IN THE BUSINESS OF DRY CLEANING: Any person
keeping or using more than two (2) quarts of any solvent other than water
including, but not by way of limitation, solvents of the petroleum distillate
type, coal tar distillate type or chlorinated hydrocarbon type for the purpose
of cleaning, dyeing or renovating wearing apparel, fabrics, textiles, drapes,
curtains, rugs, blankets, furs, leather, or other material for profit or reward
including such establishments operating on a self-service coin-operated basis.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of dry cleaning,
without first obtaining a license for each dry cleaning establishment to be
conducted by such person.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   An application for the license shall be made in conformity with the
general requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses. A
separate application shall be made for each dry cleaning establishment engaged
in by the applicant wherever located within the Village.
   B.   At the time of filing the application, the applicant shall also file an
affidavit specifying the type of cleaning solvent to be used and stating that
no cleaning solvent other than that specified in the affidavit will be
employed. If at any time subsequent to the filing of the application and
affidavit, the applicant desires to change the type of solvent specified in the
affidavit, he may do so only upon the filing of an amendment to his application
and affidavit describing the proposed change; provided, that compliance is made
with all ordinances relating to the use of such solvent.
   C.   Every application shall be approved by the Building and Code
Enforcement Department and the Public Safety Department as to compliance of the
premises named therein with the building provisions and fire regulations of
this Code, respectively, before a license shall be issued.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25A-4: LOCATION:
No dry cleaning establishment in which a flammable solvent having a flashpoint
below one hundred forty degrees Fahrenheit (140°F) (closed cup tester) is used
shall be located on any lot or plot of ground where any of the boundaries of
such lot or plot of ground are within one hundred feet (100') of the nearest
boundary of any lot or plot of ground used for a school, church, hospital, or
theater.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25A-5: BUILDING AND EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Every new building constructed for the purpose of dry cleaning shall be
built and equipped as required by the building provisions of this Code.
   B.   Every dry cleaning establishment shall be equipped with an asbestos
blanket of a size not less than six feet by nine feet (6' x 9'). Said blanket
shall be placed inside of dry cleaning rooms near the door thereof and in such
position that it shall be accessible for use in case of fire.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25A-6: OTHER USE OF PREMISES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate the business of dry
cleaning in which a flammable solvent having a flashpoint below one hundred
forty degrees Fahrenheit (140°F) (closed cup tester) is used in any building,
any portion of which is used or intended to be used for other than dry cleaning
or dyeing purposes.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25A-7: SEPARATION OF CLEANED AND UNCLEANED ARTICLES:
Every person engaged in the business of dry cleaning shall provide proper
facilities and equipment for the separate handling of cleaned and soiled
articles, and no clean article shall be allowed to come in contact with any
uncleaned or soiled article of any kind at any time.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
ARTICLE B: LAUNDRIES
Section
4-25B-1:   Laundries
4-25B-1-1:   Definition
4-25B-1-2:   License Required
4-25B-1-3:   Application For License
4-25B-1-4:   Investigation Of Applicant
4-25B-1-5:   Sanitary Conditions
4-25B-1-6:   Establishments Separate From Living Facilities; Seating Required
4-25B-1-7:   Operation Of Laundries
4-25B-1-8:   Floor Construction
4-25B-1-9:   Locker Room
4-25B-1-10:   New Laundries
4-25B-2:   Self-Service, Coin-Operated Laundry Establishments
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fees
4-25B-1: LAUNDRIES:
4-25B-1-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this article, the word LAUNDRY shall have the following meanings:
   A.   Anyplace, building, structure, room, or establishment, or portion
thereof, which is used for the purpose of washing, drying, starching, or
ironing shirts, dresses, underwear, collars, cuffs, or other wearing apparel,
table, bed or other household linens, towels, curtains, draperies or other
washable fabrics, such work being done for the general public.
   B.   Any towel or linen supply laundry maintained or operated for the
purpose of washing, drying, starching or ironing towels, aprons, napkins, table
linens, washable clothing, or other similar articles, the property of such
laundry, but rented or loaned for a consideration to patrons or customers of
the laundry.
   C.   Any private laundry maintained or operated in connection with any
hotel, restaurant, or public institution, except a hospital or charitable
institution where no charge is made for laundry services.
   D.   Any establishment wherein washing machine units are available for use
by the general public upon the deposit of a coin or the payment of a fee to the
operator of such establishment or his agent.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25B-1-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the laundry business without first obtaining a
license so to do.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25B-1-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for the license shall be made in conformity with the general
requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses. In addition,
the applicant shall state the maximum number of persons to be employed therein.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25B-1-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
The Building and Code Enforcement Department and Health and Licensing
Department shall cause an investigation to be made of the premises named and
described in the application for the purpose of determining whether there is
full compliance with the sanitary conditions and other requirements of this
article.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25B-1-5: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
   A.   Every room or place used as a laundry, or for the storage of
unlaundered or laundered fabrics in connection therewith, shall at all times be
kept in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition as to
floors, walls, ceilings, windows, woodwork, machinery, utensils, and fixtures,
and every such room or place shall be kept free from rats, mice, vermin, and
all matters of an infectious or contagious nature.
   B.   No person who has tuberculosis, any acute or active venereal disease,
any communicable or loathsome skin disease, or any other communicable disease
shall work in any laundry, and no owner, proprietor, manager, or person in
charge of any laundry shall knowingly require, permit or suffer any such person
to be employed therein.
   C.   No wallpaper shall be applied upon the walls or ceilings of any room
used for laundry purposes.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25B-1-6: ESTABLISHMENTS SEPARATE FROM LIVING FACILITIES; SEATING REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall be permitted to sleep in any laundry, nor shall any
sleeping room or living room be in direct communication with any laundry.
   B.   No laundered or unlaundered article belonging to the trade of any
laundry shall be stored or kept in any room which is used for living purposes.
   C.   Proper seating facilities shall be provided for each employee who, in
the discharge of his duties, is required to remain stationed at any one place
for any extended period of time.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25B-1-7: OPERATION OF LAUNDRIES:
   A.   Emissions: Vapors, smoke, or odors emanating from any laundry shall not
be permitted at any time to become a nuisance to any portion of the premises in
which the laundry is located, nor to any adjoining or nearby premises.
   B.   Excessive Heat: Every machine or mechanical device in any laundry that
is operated by an employee, in case it emits or sends off excessive heat, shall
be equipped with proper heat defectors, hood and exhaust, or other apparatus
that will carry the heat from the room or place in which the same is located.
   C.   Separation Of Laundered And Unlaundered Articles. Every person
conducting or operating any laundry shall be required to provide proper
facilities and equipment for the separate handling of clean and soiled
articles, and no clean or laundered articles shall be allowed to come in
contact with any unlaundered or soiled articles of any kind at any time.
   D.   Sterilization Of Articles: No person conducting or operating any
laundry in which wearing apparel, household linens, towels, bedding, or any
other fabrics are received and treated through the process of washing, shall
remove or cause to be removed from the premises any laundered article, until
the same has been thoroughly sterilized by keeping it in the washing machine,
vat, or other vessel provided for that purpose and the water therein has been
brought to a boiling temperature or maintained at a temperature of one hundred
seventy five degrees Fahrenheit (175°F) for at least twenty (20) minutes; or by
subjecting it to live steam under pressure; or by keeping it in a drying house
or drying tumbler, in which the temperature is not less than two hundred
fifteen degrees Fahrenheit (215°F) for a period of not less than fifteen (15)
minutes; or by passing it through any ironing machine where the ironing surface
is at a temperature of not less than two hundred twenty five degrees Fahrenheit
(225°F); except in the case of silks and woolens or other fabrics which would
be injured by the foregoing processes, in which event, the same shall be
treated with soap, bleach, or such other standard disinfectant solutions as
shall be approved by the Health and Licensing Department.
   E.   Sprinkling Restrictions: No owner, proprietor, or manager of any
laundry, or any person employed therein, shall be permitted to sprinkle any
fabric with water or other liquid substance ejected from the mouth or blown out
of any other device communicating or coming in contact with the mouth of such
person.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25B-1-8: FLOOR CONSTRUCTION:
The floor of every laundry and every room or place in connection therewith,
except the room or rooms in which apparel, household, linens, bedding, towels,
or other fabrics are washed, shall be constructed of hardwood or any impervious
material. The floor of the room or rooms in which wearing apparel, household
linens, bedding, towels, or other fabrics are washed shall be constructed of
hardwood with tight joints, concrete, cement, tile or stone laid in cement, or
other impervious material, and shall be watertight and properly drained to the
public sewer. The angles where the floor and wall join shall likewise be
watertight. The floor of the washroom shall be of concrete, cement, tile or
stone laid in cement, or other impervious material, and shall be watertight and
properly drained to the public sewer.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25B-1-9: LOCKER ROOM:
A separate room, or sufficient space in a room, which is entirely separate from
the room or rooms in which wearing apparel, linen, or other fabrics are washed
or dried, and which can be maintained in a dry and sanitary condition, shall be
provided and maintained in every laundry as a cloakroom or locker room in which
employees may keep their wraps or outer clothing, and if the management of any
laundry shall require the persons employed therein to wear any special or
designated garment during the hours of employment, such space or room shall be
so arranged that employees may make such changes as may be necessary with a
reasonable degree of privacy.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25B-1-10: NEW LAUNDRIES:
Any person establishing a new laundry shall be required to submit to the Health
and Licensing Department, for its approval, a complete set of plans and
specifications of the building in which any new laundry is to be located, also
a complete diagram of the floor plan of each room to be occupied by the new
laundry, correctly showing the arrangement or setting of all machinery and
equipment to be installed therein.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-25B-2: SELF-SERVICE, COIN-OPERATED LAUNDRY ESTABLISHMENTS:
Any person establishing a laundry of the coin-operated, self-service type shall
be required to submit to the Director of Building and Code Enforcement, for his
approval, a complete set of plans and specifications and a complete diagram of
the floor plan of each room to be occupied by such establishment, showing the
arrangement or setting of all machinery and equipment to be installed therein.
Each plan shall be explicit and complete.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 26: DAY NURSERIES
Section
4-26-1:   Definition
4-26-2:   License Required
4-26-3:   Application For License
4-26-4:   Rules, Regulations And Minimum Standards
4-26-5:   Ill Or Injured Children
4-26-6:   Recordkeeping
4-26-7:   Inspections
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-26-1:    DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, the term DAY NURSERY shall mean any institution or
place in which are received three (3) or more children, not of common
parentage, for nursing or care apart from their parents or guardian, between
the ages of two (2) years and fourteen (14) years, for care during part or all
of a day but not later than nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. The term is further
construed to include similar units operating under any other name whatsoever
with or without stated educational purpose.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-26-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person other than the regularly constituted
authorities of the United States, the State, the County, or the Village to
conduct or operate any day nursery within the Village without first obtaining a
license therefor.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-26-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license to conduct and operate a day nursery shall be made in
conformity with the general requirements of this title relating to applications
for licenses. The application shall be under oath and shall contain:
   A.   The location of the day nursery for which a license is sought.
   B.   The number of children to be cared for.
   C.   The name and address of the applicant, if an individual; and if a firm,
partnership, or association, of every member thereof; and in the case of a
corporation, the principal address of the corporation and names and addresses
of its officers.
   D.   The name of the person or persons under whose management or supervision
the day nursery will be conducted.
   E.   Such information relating to the number, experience and training of
employees of the day nursery and establishing the moral character of the
applicant and employees.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-26-4: RULES, REGULATIONS AND MINIMUM STANDARDS:
   A.   The premises and facilities used as a day nursery shall comply with the
building, zoning, fire and health provisions of this Code and the State of
Illinois “Minimum Standards for Licensed Day Care Centers”.
   B.   The day nursery shall comply with the program standards as set forth in
the State of Illinois “Minimum Standards for Licensed Day Care Centers”.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-26-5: ILL OR INJURED CHILDREN:
   A.   Each day nursery shall be provided with a room to be used for the
observation of an ill or injured child and suspect cases of contagious,
infectious or communicable diseases.
   B.   It shall be the responsibility of every person conducting or operating
a day nursery to minimize the danger of transmission of communicable diseases
as set forth by the State of Illinois Department of Public Health Rules and
Regulations for the Control of Communicable Diseases.
   C.   It shall be the duty of every person conducting or operating a day
nursery to make a report to the Health and Licensing Department daily of all
cases and suspect cases of contagious and communicable diseases.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-26-6: RECORDKEEPING:
Each day nursery shall maintain individual records for each child and personnel
records for each employee. All records shall be open at all times to the
inspection of the Health and Licensing Department or its duly authorized
representative.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-26-7: INSPECTIONS:
Every day nursery shall be open at all reasonable times to inspection by the
Health and Licensing Department, the Building and Code Enforcement Department
and the Department of Public Safety, as often as is deemed necessary.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 27: FUNERAL HOMES AND UNDERTAKING ESTABLISHMENTS
Section
4-27-1:   License Required; Restrictions
4-27-2:   Application For License
4-27-3:   Qualifications Of Applicant
4-27-4:   Insurances Required; Bond In Lieu
4-27-5:   Soliciting Business Prohibited
4-27-6:   Undertaking Rooms
4-27-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any individual to prepare a dead body for
burial or cremation in or to conduct, manage, or be in charge of, any room,
store, or place in any way advertised or held out to the public by card, sign
solicitation or otherwise as a funeral home or undertaking establishment
without first obtaining a license for such room, store or place.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
   B.   Any license issued pursuant to this chapter shall entitle the licensee
to operate a funeral home or undertaking establishment only at and from the
store, room, or place designated in the license, and if the applicant for the
license shall desire to engage in the business of undertaking at more than one
store, room or place in the Village, he shall be permitted to do so only upon
the payment of a license fee as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule,
subsection 3-10-1B of this Code, for each such store, room, or place.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975; amd. 2019 Code)
   C.   In conducting any business under a license herein provided, no licensee
shall use or join in using, as part of or in connection with the name under
which said business is conducted, the name of any person who is not licensed as
an undertaker and actually engaged in the business.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-27-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license under this chapter shall state the applicant’s name
and residence address, that a certificate of registration as a funeral director
has been issued to him by the State of Illinois and the number of his State
registration certificate, and the location of the room, store or place where he
intends to engage in the business of undertaking.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-27-3: QUALIFICATIONS OF APPLICANT:
Every applicant shall also furnish to the Health and Licensing Department
evidence that he has successfully completed a course of instruction in a
professional school or college teaching the practice of undertaking, which is
recognized and approved by the Illinois Department of Financial and
Professional Regulation; that he has knowledge of, and is familiar with, the
State laws, the provisions of this Code, and the rules and regulations of the
Health and Licensing Department governing and concerning the removal,
preparation, and burial or cremation of the dead; and that the applicant has a
practical knowledge of approved and sanitary methods of caring for dead bodies
and preparing the same for burial or cremation, including the disinfection of
dead bodies.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975; amd. 2019 Code)
4-27-4: INSURANCES REQUIRED; BOND IN LIEU:
   A.   Every applicant for a license under this chapter shall carry public
liability and property damage insurance and workers' compensation insurance for
employees with responsible insurers, authorized to transact insurance business
in the State of Illinois, to secure payment of any loss or damage resulting
from an occurrence arising out of or caused by the operation of the business
herein licensed. Said insurance policy or contract shall be for an amount as
required by the Village. The insurance shall provide for the payment and
satisfaction of any final judgment rendered against the owner or operator of a
licensed business, and that suit may be brought in any court of competent
jurisdiction upon such policy by any person having claims arising from the
operation of the business.
   B.   In lieu of an insurance policy or contract, a surety bond or bonds with
a corporate surety or sureties authorized to do business under the laws of the
State of Illinois may be accepted for all or any part of such insurance;
provided, that each bond shall be conditioned for the payment and satisfaction
of any final judgment, in conformity with the provisions of an insurance policy
as required by this section.
(Ord. 76-11-3A, 11-3-1976)
4-27-5: SOLICITING BUSINESS PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person, including any licensee, agent or employee, or other person
acting on behalf of a licensee with his knowledge or consent, express or
implied, shall, directly or indirectly, pay or cause to be paid any sum or
money or other valuable consideration for the securing of business or to obtain
any deceased human body or authority to dispose of any deceased human body;
provided, that this subsection shall not be deemed to prohibit general
advertising.
   B.   No licensee or agent or employee of a licensee or other person acting
for or on behalf of a licensee with his knowledge or consent, express or
implied, shall solicit a dead human body while death is impending or after
death; provided, that this subsection shall not be deemed to prohibit general
advertising.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person not a licensee to solicit for
money, fee, commission or other remuneration, directly or indirectly, in any
manner whatsoever, a dead human body for any licensee.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-27-6: UNDERTAKING ROOMS:
No location, store or place shall be licensed as an undertaking establishment
where any other occupation is carried on, unless the establishment, store, or
place used for the undertaking business shall be provided with a compartment or
room completely shut off or capable of being completely shut off from the other
parts of the establishment, store, or place. The compartment or room shall have
free outside ventilation and light, and its floor shall be constructed of or
covered with a nonabsorbent material and shall be connected with a sewer by an
approved sanitary drain.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 28: MISCELLANEOUS RETAIL BUSINESSES
ARTICLE A: FLORISTS
Section
4-28A-1:   Definition
4-28A-2:   License Required
4-28A-3:   Application For License
4-28A-4:   Investigation Of Applicant
4-28A-5:   Insurances Required; Bond In Lieu
4-28A-6:   Sanitation Regulations
4-28A-7:   Storage Of Hazardous Materials
4-28A-8:   Off Premises Sales
4-28A-9:   Inspections
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-28A-1   DEFINITION:
When used in this article, the term RETAIL FLORIST shall mean any person or
persons regularly engaged in the conduct of an established business for
selling, offering for sale, or keeping with the intention of selling at retail
cut flowers, bridal bouquets, funeral designs, or growing plants from a fixed
and permanent business location.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall engage in the business of retail florist or the
business of wholesale florist without first having procured a license therefor.
   B.   Every person who shall engage in both a retail florist business and a
wholesale florist business shall procure a separate license for each. A
separate license shall be required for each location, place or premises where
the person is located to engage in business, and in the case of an itinerant
wholesale florist, a separate license shall be required for each vehicle from
which flowers, bouquets, funeral floral designs and growing plants are sold.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   An application for any license under this article shall be made in
conformity with the general requirements of this title relating to applications
for licenses.
   B.   Every application for license as an itinerant wholesale florist shall
also contain the address of the applicant.
   C.   The application shall indicate the nature of the business in which the
applicant desires to engage.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28A-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
Every application for a license to engage in business at a fixed location shall
be investigated by the Director of Building and Code Enforcement to determine
whether there is compliance with the applicable provisions of this Code, and
the approval of the officer shall be noted thereon before the license is
issued.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28A-5: INSURANCES REQUIRED; BOND IN LIEU:
   A.   Every applicant for a license under this article shall carry public
liability and property damage insurance and workers' compensation insurance for
employees with responsible insurers, authorized to transact insurance business
in the State of Illinois, to secure payment of any loss or damage resulting
from an occurrence arising out of or caused by the operation of the business
herein licensed. The insurance policy or contract shall be in an amount as
required by the Village. The insurance shall provide for the payment and
satisfaction of any final judgment rendered against the owner or operator of a
licensed business, and that suit may be brought in any court of competent
jurisdiction upon such policy by any person having claims arising from the
operation of the business.
   B.   In lieu of an insurance policy or contract, a surety bond or bonds with
a corporate surety or sureties authorized to do business under the laws of the
State of Illinois may be accepted for all or any part of such insurance;
provided, that each bond shall be conditioned for the payment and satisfaction
of any final judgment, in conformity with the provisions of an insurance policy
as required by this section.
(Ord. 76-11-3A, 11-3-1976)
4-28A-6: SANITATION REGULATIONS:
   A.   Every location, place or establishment where the business of a florist
is conducted, managed or carried on shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition and free from vermin.
   B.   No decayed, decaying, unwholesome, contaminated or diseased flowers or
plants shall be allowed to remain in or about the establishment.
   C.   No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any flowers or plants, the
sale of which is restricted by any Federal or State law.
   D.   Adequate and convenient washing and toilet facilities shall be
provided.
   E.   Every itinerant wholesale florist shall thoroughly clean each vehicle
operated by him in his business once daily and dispose of all decaying flowers
or plants in a suitable sanitary manner, subject to the approval of the Health
and Licensing Department.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28A-7: STORAGE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS:
All pesticides and any other material which may be hazardous to employees or
the public shall be stored in florist establishments in a safe manner and shall
be plainly identified.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28A-8: OFF PREMISES SALES:
Except in the case of an itinerant wholesale florist, no license shall be
issued except for a fixed location. The sale of flowers, plants or floral
bouquets or designs on the public way or at places other than those at which
the licensee is licensed is hereby prohibited.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28A-9: INSPECTIONS:
The Director of Building and Code Enforcement may inspect at any reasonable
time all florist establishments to determine whether there is compliance with
the requirements of this Code relating to health, sanitation, and safety
applicable thereto.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
ARTICLE B: HARDWARE STORES AND PAINT STORES
Section
4-28B-1:   Hardware Stores
4-28B-1-1:   Definition; Exemptions
4-28B-1-2:   License Required
4-28B-1-3:   Application For License
4-28B-1-4:   Investigation Of Applicant
4-28B-1-5:   May Provide A Paint Store With No License
4-28B-2:   Paint Stores
4-28B-2-1:   Definition; Exemptions
4-28B-2-2:   License Required
4-28B-2-3:   Application For License; Approval
4-28B-2-4:   Investigation Of Applicant
4-28B-3:   Sanitation Requirements
4-28B-4:   Ventilation
4-28B-5:   Inspections
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-28B-1: HARDWARE STORES:
4-28B-1-1: DEFINITION; EXEMPTIONS:
When used in this section 4-28B-1, the term HARDWARE STORE shall mean any
building, room, enclosure, premises, place, or establishment in the Village
operated, maintained, or conducted for the sale or offering for sale at retail
of any of the following articles: hardware; tinware; aluminum ware; enamelware;
cutlery; tools; implements; apparatus; machinery; plumbing; engineers’,
janitors’, blacksmiths’, contractors’, or electrical supplies; gas, plumbing,
or electrical fixtures; other articles or wares made largely of metals;
kerosene; rifles, shotguns, and loaded shot shells or cartridges where not more
than twenty five thousand (25,000) are kept on hand at one time; provided,
however, that dealers or establishments or parts of establishments of a similar
nature specifically defined and licensed by other parts of this Code shall be
exempt from the provisions licensing hardware stores.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28B-1-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of a hardware store without first having
obtained a license therefor.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28B-1-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a hardware store license shall be made in conformity with
the general requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses.
The applicant shall also describe the premises to be licensed and state the
location of the same.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28B-1-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
   A.   The Director of Building and Code Enforcement shall cause an
investigation to be made of the premises named and described in the application
for a license to conduct a hardware store for the purpose of determining the
fitness and suitability of the premises for such business from a sanitary
standpoint, and determining whether or not the premises complies with all the
provisions of this Code and laws of the State regulating health, safety, and
sanitation so as to safeguard properly the lives and health of the employees
engaged therein.
   B.   The Superintendent of Public Safety shall investigate the premises to
determine whether there has been compliance with the fire regulations of this
Code applicable thereto.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28B-1-5: MAY PROVIDE A PAINT STORE WITH NO LICENSE:
Every licensed hardware store shall have the privilege of engaging in the
business of a paint store within the same building, room enclosure, premises,
place, establishment, or part of an establishment without the necessity of
