obtaining an additional license.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28B-2: PAINT STORES:
4-28B-2-1: DEFINITION; EXEMPTIONS:
When used in this section 4-28B-2, the term PAINT STORE shall mean any
building, room, enclosure, premises, place, establishment, or part of an
establishment in the Village operated, or conducted for the sale or offering
for sale at retail, of any paints, dry colors, wallpaper, varnishes, calcimine,
raw or boiled linseed oil, turpentine, dryer, benzine, naphtha, painters'
tools, supplies and equipment; provided, that dealers or establishments or
parts of establishments of a similar nature specifically defined and licensed
by other provisions of this Code shall be exempt from the provisions of that
part of this section.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28B-2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of a paint store without first having
obtained a license therefor.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28B-2-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; APPROVAL:
An application for a paint store license shall be made in conformity with the
general requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses. The
applicant shall also describe the premises as well as the location of the same.
Every application shall be approved by the Superintendent of Public Safety and
by the Director of Building and Code Enforcement before a license shall be
issued.
(Ord. 75-12-I7D, 12-17-1975)
4-28B-2-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
   A.   The Director of Building and Code Enforcement shall cause an
investigation to be made of the premises named and described in the application
for a license to conduct a paint store for the purpose of determining the
fitness and suitability of the premises for such business from a sanitary
standpoint, and of determining whether or not the premises complies with all
the provisions of this Code and laws of the State regulating health, safety,
and sanitation so as to safeguard properly the lives and health of the
employees engaged therein.
   B.   The Superintendent of Public Safety shall also cause an investigation
to be made of the premises for the purpose of determining whether the same
complies with all of the fire regulations of this Code applicable thereto.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28B-3: SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Every place wherein any business licensed under this article is carried
on shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
   B.   All necessary measures shall be taken to safeguard the lives and health
of all persons employed in such establishments, and adequate and convenient
washing and toilet facilities shall be provided for the employees.
   C.   No person suffering from an active contagious or infectious disease
shall be employed in the business.
   D.   All articles kept for sale in the establishments shall be kept free
from vermin or any matter of a contagious or infectious nature.
   E.   All decomposed, fetid, or putrescent matter and all refuse, waste, and
sweepings shall he removed and disposed of at least once each day and in such a
manner as not to cause a nuisance.
   F.   All cleaning shall be done as far as possible outside of working hours,
but if done during working hours, it shall be done in such a manner as to avoid
the necessary raising of dust or noxious material.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28B-4: VENTILATION:
No owner, proprietor, manager or superintendent of any business licensed under
this article where one or more persons are employed shall cause, permit, or
allow the same, or any portion or apartment of any room within the same, to be
overcrowded or inadequate, faulty, or insufficient in respect to light,
ventilation, heat, and cleanliness; and fresh air shall be supplied by
ventilation in accordance with the building regulations of this Code. No part
of the air supply shall be taken from any cellar or basement.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-28B-5: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   The Director of Building and Code Enforcement, in addition to making
the initial inspections provided herein, shall visit or cause to be visited all
such places of business licensed under this article as often as he shall deem
necessary, but at least once a year, to see that there is compliance with the
provisions of this article, and the Director shall have the authority to
require that arrangements be made as may be deemed necessary for the safety and
health of the employees pursuant to the terms of this Code and such laws as may
be in force concerning health and sanitary conditions.
   B.   It shall be the duty of every person licensed under this article to
comply with the fire regulations of this Code applicable thereto, and the
Superintendent of Public Safety shall periodically inspect each place of
business to determine whether there is compliance with the said regulations.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-197 5)
CHAPTER 29: INDUSTRIAL RELATED BUSINESSES
ARTICLE A: MACHINE SHOPS
Section
4-29A-1:   Definition
4-29A-2:   License Required
4-29A-3:   Application For License
4-29A-4:   Fire Prevention
4-29A-5:   Safety, Sanitation And Health Requirements
4-29A-6:   Prohibited Hours Of Operation; Nuisance Declared
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-29A-1: DEFINITION:
When used in this article, the term MACHINE SHOP shall mean a workshop in which
a machine shop business is conducted and in which machines are made or metal
parts thereof are repaired for the public, or in which parts of machines or
tools, implements, gears, dies, screws or other metal articles are cut, filed,
shaped, punched, stamped or repaired by means of a lathe or other machinery for
the public.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-29A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate a machine shop business without first having obtained a
license therefor.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-29A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a license under this article shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this title relating to the issuance of
licenses.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-29A-4: FIRE PREVENTION:
Each person conducting a machine shop shall comply with the fire regulations of
this Code. It shall be the duty of the Deputy Chief of the Bureau of Fire
Suppression to inspect periodically each such premises to determine if the
person conducting the business is complying with such regulations.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-29A-5: SAFETY, SANITATION AND HEALTH REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   No building, structure or part thereof used for or in connected with
any machine shop shall be so used as to endanger the health or property of the
employees or of the public.
   B.   The owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or manager of any machine shop
shall cause all floors and other surface around or beneath any machine or
workbench to be kept in good order and repair and shall have suitable and
convenient sanitary receptacles for receiving waste and cloths used in and
about the machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines or parts thereof or
which are intended for any other necessary use.
   C.   The owner, lessee, tenant, occupant, or manager shall not permit any
steel cuttings or machine parts to accumulate on or about any machine or
workbench so that the same may become detrimental to the health or safety of
any person therein engaged.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-29A-6: PROHIBITED HOURS OF OPERATION; NUISANCE DECLARED:
No machine shop shall be operated between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00)
P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. in any block in which a majority of the
buildings on both sides of the street are used exclusively for residential
purposes, or within one hundred feet (100') of such block, and it shall be
within the power of the Director of the Health and Licensing, after reasonable
notice, to treat the operation during such hours as a public nuisance and to
abate the same.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 30: CURRENCY EXCHANGES
Section
4-30-1:   Definition
4-30-2:   License Required
4-30-3:   Application For License
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 B of this Code for license fee
4-30-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, the term CURRENCY EXCHANGE shall mean any person,
except banks incorporated under the laws of the State of Illinois and national
banks organized pursuant to the laws of the United States, engaged in the
business of and providing facilities for cashing checks, drafts, money orders
and all other evidences of money acceptable to the currency exchange for a fee
or service charge or other consideration, or engaged in the business of selling
or issuing money orders under his or its name or any other money orders (other
than United States Post Office money orders, or Western Union money orders), or
engaged in both such businesses. Provided, however, that nothing herein shall
be held to apply to any person engaged in the business of transporting for hire
bullion, currency, securities, negotiable or nonnegotiable documents, jewels or
other property of great monetary value, nor to any person engaged in the
business of selling tangible personal property at retail who, in the course of
such business and as an incident thereto, cashes checks, drafts, money orders
or other evidences of money.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-30-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of or conduct a currency exchange within
the Village without first having obtained a license so to do.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
4-30-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for the license shall be made in conformity with the general
requirements of this title relating to applications for licenses.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
CHAPTER 31: REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS FOR NONRESIDENTIAL PROPERTY OCCUPANTS
Section
4-31-1:   Definitions
4-31-2:   Tenant Registration Required
4-31-3:   Change In Tenant Information; Time Limit For Registering
4-31-4:   Registration Fee
4-31-5:   Issuance And Display Of Certificate Of Registration
4-31-6:   Maintenance And Distribution Of Registration Forms
4-31-7:   Verification Of Tenants By Owners Required
4-31-8:   Penalty
4-31-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the
following terms shall have the following meanings:
COMMERCIAL BUILDING: A structure, or part thereof, enclosing space designed or
used for nonresidential purposes when such space is leased, rented or otherwise
occupied and utilized for purposes other than as a residence. Commercial
buildings do not include churches, synagogues, temples, mosques or other
buildings which are designed and used primarily for religious purposes and
which are not subject to ad valorem real estate taxes. If a building is used
for both residential and nonresidential purposes, then the portion of the
building that is used for nonresidential purposes shall constitute a COMMERCIAL
BUILDING for purposes of this chapter. If an area within a building or
structure is used for religious purposes and is not subject to ad valorem real
estate taxes, while another area of the same building or structure is not used
for religious purposes and is subject to ad valorem real estate taxes, then
that portion of the building not used for religious purposes shall be
considered to be a COMMERCIAL BUILDING.
OWNER: The legal title holder or holders of the realty; except, if legal title
is held by an Illinois land trust, OWNER shall mean the beneficial owner or the
beneficiary of the trust.
PERSON: Natural persons, individuals, partnerships, associations,
organizations, corporations of all types and any other entity which constitutes
a legal person; provided, that PERSON shall not include agencies or departments
of the government of the United States of America, the State of Illinois, or
the Village. A PERSON does not include public school districts, community
college districts or public universities or colleges.
TENANT: One or more persons, as defined in this section, who occupy all or a
portion of the premises within a commercial building under a lease, rental
agreement, license or any other similar arrangement. If a commercial building
is occupied by an owner of the building, the owner shall be considered to be a
tenant. Persons who occupy rooms in hotels or persons who obtain a license or
lease to temporarily occupy or use space in a hotel, restaurant or other
similar building or facility for purposes of holding a conference, meeting,
banquet or similar type of activity are not tenants for purposes of this
chapter. Tenants do not include persons who obtain licenses to use or occupy
the Donald E. Stephens Convention Center, the Allstate Arena or the Rosemont
Theatre and do not include persons who obtain licenses to use or occupy the
Rosemont Health and Fitness Club for a period of less than thirty (30) days.
(Ord. 2005-11-2E, 11-2-2005, eff. 1-1-2006)
4-31-2: TENANT REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
   A.   Each tenant shall annually register with the Village during the month
of January by completing and filing a registration form with the Director of
the Health and Licensing Department which, when completed fully and accurately,
sets forth the following information relating to the tenant:
      1.   The tenant’s name and the street address, suite number if
applicable, and telephone number of the premises within a commercial building
occupied by the tenant. If the tenant is not a natural person, the statement
shall include the name, street address, telephone number and position of the
individual who supervises the management of the premises occupied by the tenant
within the commercial building.
      2.   The name, street address and telephone number of a person twenty one
(21) years of age or older designated by the tenant as the person who is to be
contacted in the event an emergency situation arises relating to the tenant's
occupancy of premises within a commercial building.
      3.   A description of the types of commercial activities in which the
tenant engages on the premises of the commercial building.
   B.   For purposes of this section, a post office box does not suffice as an
address.
   C.   All information included within the registration form required to be
filed pursuant to this section shall be accurate as of the date the
registration form is filed with the Village.
   D.   The registration form shall be provided by the Village.
   E.   A separate registration form shall be filed for each commercial
building in which the tenant occupies premises.
(Ord. 2005-11-2E, 11-2-2005, eff. 1-1-2006)
4-31-3: CHANGE IN TENANT INFORMATION; TIME LIMIT FOR REGISTERING:
   A.   If any of the information contained in a registration form which is
filed pursuant to section
4-31-2 of this chapter changes or otherwise becomes inaccurate, the tenant
shall file an amended and updated registration form within thirty (30) days
which contains accurate and complete information.
   B.   A person who becomes a tenant and who has not filed a registration form
pursuant to section
4-31-2 of this chapter in connection with the premises in a commercial building
occupied by the tenant, shall file the required registration form within thirty
(30) days after the date the premises in the commercial building is first
occupied or used by the tenant.
(Ord. 2005-11-2E, 11-2-2005, eff. 1-1-2006)
4-31-4: REGISTRATION FEE:
At the time that a tenant files the registration form required under section
6-9-2 of this chapter, the tenant shall pay a registration fee as set forth in
the Village's schedule of fees (Rosemont Code, Section 3-10-1 et seq.) to the
Village. Except, no registration fee shall be paid by a nonprofit corporation
or limited liability company or by a tenant who presents proof that they have
been issued an exemption identification number by the Illinois Department of
Revenue which indicates that personal property sold to the tenant is exempt
from the Illinois retailers' occupation tax ( commonly referred to as "Illinois
sales tax").
(Ord. 2005-11-2E, 11-2-2005, eff. 1-1-2006; amd. Ord. 2023-7-10A, 7-10-2023)
4-31-5: ISSUANCE AND DISPLAY OF CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION:
The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall issue, or cause to be
issued, a certificate of registration to each tenant that registers in
accordance with the requirements of this chapter. The tenant shall display the
certificate of registration in a prominent place within the premises in a
commercial building for which the certificate of registration was issued.
(Ord. 2005-11-2E, 11-2-2005, eff. 1-1-2006)
4-31-6: MAINTENANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF REGISTRATION FORMS:
The Director of the Health and Licensing Department, or his designee, shall
maintain the registration forms filed pursuant to sections
4-31-2 and
4-31-3 of this chapter and shall either provide a copy of the registration
forms or otherwise provide the information contained in the registration forms
to the Village Department of Public Safety. The registration forms filed
pursuant to sections
4-31-2 and
4-31-3 of this chapter and the information contained in the registration forms
are gathered and maintained by the Village for emergency, safety and law
enforcement purposes.
(Ord. 2005-11-2E, 11-2-2005, eff. 1-1-2006)
4-31-7: VERIFICATION OF TENANTS BY OWNERS REQUIRED:
Each owner of a commercial building shall, prior to allowing any person to
become a tenant of the commercial building, require such person to provide
proof that the person has obtained all Village licenses which are needed in
order for such person to be able to lawfully carry on the business activities
which such person intends to undertake within the commercial building. The
owner shall keep and maintain the proof provided and shall furnish such proof
to the Director of the Health and Licensing Department, or his designee, upon
request.
(Ord. 2005-11-2E, 11-2-2005, eff. 1-1-2006)
4-31-8: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or who shall
refuse, neglect or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this chapter
shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day such violation continues.
(Ord. 2005-11-2E, 11-2-2005, eff. 1-1-2006)
TITLE 5: HEALTH, SANITATION AND ENVIRONMENT
CHAPTER 1: WEEDS AND OVERGROWN VEGETATION
Section
5-1-1:   Weeds Prohibited; Nuisance Declared
5-1-2:   Excessive Height Of Vegetation; Nuisance Declared
5-1-3:   Notice To Abate Unlawful Vegetation
5-1-4:   Abatement By Village; Costs A Lien
Cross-reference:
   See also section 7-8-9 of this Code
5-1-1: WEEDS PROHIBITED; NUISANCE DECLARED:
Any weeds such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur, or other weeds
of a like kind found growing in any lot or tract of land in the Village are
hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for any owner or
occupant of a lot or tract of land in the Village to permit any such weeds to
grow or remain on the lot or tract of land.
(Ord. 2007-7-11R, 7-11-2007)
5-1-2: EXCESSIVE HEIGHT OF VEGETATION; NUISANCE DECLARED:
It shall be unlawful for anyone to permit any weeds, grass or plants, other
than trees, bushes, flowers, shrubs, vines, ground cover, common garden crops
such as farm food, or other ornamental plants to grow to a height exceeding
eight inches (8") anywhere in the Village, except in natural and buffer areas
or preserves as provided under the Illinois Natural Areas Preservation Act (525
ILCS 30/1 et seq.) Any such plants or weeds exceeding such height are hereby
declared to be nuisances.
(Ord. 2007-7-11R, 7-11-2007)
5-1-3: NOTICE TO ABATE UNLAWFUL VEGETATION:
The Director of the Health and Licensing Department may serve or cause to be
served, by certified United States mail or personal service, on the person to
whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the last
preceding year of any property on which weeds, grass or plants are permitted to
grow in violation of section 5-1-1 or 5-1-2 of this chapter a notice to abate
such weeds, grass or plants. The notice shall demand that the weeds, grass or
plants be cut or otherwise removed within five (5) days from the date of the
notice so that the weeds, grass or plants no longer constitute a nuisance under
the provisions of this chapter. Where the last taxpayer of record cannot be
found or otherwise served with notice by mail, then alternatively, notice to
abate a violation of section 5-1-1 or 5-1-2 of this chapter may be given by
posting a sign in a conspicuous place near the main entrance of a structure or
on the property. In either event, the text of the notice shall contain a
reference to the provision of this chapter violated and may contain such other
information respecting the nature of the violation as the Director deems
advisable.
(Ord. 2007-7-11R, 7-11-2007)
5-1-4: ABATEMENT BY VILLAGE; COSTS A LIEN:
   A.   If the person or persons served with a notice pursuant to section 5-1-
3 of this chapter do not cut or otherwise remove the weeds, grass or plants as
provided in said section 5-1-3 within five (5) days from the date of the
notice, then the Village Director of Public Works or such persons as may be
designated by the Director of Public Works may proceed to cut or otherwise
remove the weeds, grass or plants so that the weeds, grass and plants no longer
constitute a nuisance under the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   1.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department, or another
Village official designated by the Village President, shall keep a record of
the costs incurred by the Village in cutting or otherwise removing the weeds,
grass or plants, and such costs shall be charged to the person to whom was sent
the tax bill for general taxes for the last preceding year on the property
where the weeds, grass or plants were cut or otherwise removed, and while
unpaid, such cutting or removal costs shall constitute a lien against the
property where the weeds, grass or plants were otherwise removed.
      2.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department or such other
person as may be designated by the Village President shall cause notice of the
costs and lien to be personally served or served by certified mail on the
person to whom was sent the tax bill for general taxes for the last preceding
year for property where the weeds, grass or plants were cut or otherwise
removed.
      3.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department, or such other
person as may be designated by the Village President, shall cause notice of the
lien to be filed in the Office of the Recorder of Cook County within sixty (60)
days after the date the weeds, grass or plants were cut or otherwise removed.
(Ord. 2007-7-11R, 7-11-2007)
CHAPTER 2: INFECTED TREES
Section
5-2-1:   Definitions
5-2-2:   Nuisances Declared And Prohibited
5-2-3:   Notice To Remove
5-2-4:   Removal By Village Or Contractor
5-2-5:   Notice Of Removal Costs; Lien Provisions
5-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
INFECTED TREE: An elm tree infected with Dutch elm disease or an ash tree
infected with the emerald ash borer.
REMOVAL COST: The total cost of the removal of an infected tree.
(Ord. 2011-11-9G, 11-9-2011)
5-2-2: NUISANCES DECLARED AND PROHIBITED:
   A.   Dutch Elm Disease: All species and varieties of elm trees (trees of the
genus Ulmus) infected with the fungus known as “Dutch elm disease” (Ophistoma/
Ceratostomella) are declared to be public nuisances and shall be removed and
properly disposed of by the owners of the properties on which such infected
trees are located within twenty (20) days following written notice from the
Village.
   B.   Emerald Ash Borer: All species and varieties of ash trees (trees of the
genus Fraxinus) infected with emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis Fairmaire)
are declared to be public nuisances and shall be removed and properly disposed
of by the owners of the properties on which such trees are located within
twenty (20) days following written notice from the Village.
   C.   Offense: It is unlawful to maintain an infected tree within the Village
after notice from the Village as provided in this chapter to remove and dispose
of an infected tree.
(Ord. 2011-11-9G, 11-9-2011)
5-2-3: NOTICE TO REMOVE:
   A.   Duty To Remove: It shall be the duty of the owner of the property to
remove and properly dispose of any infected trees located on the owner's
property within twenty (20) days following written notice from the Village to
remove the infected trees.
   B.   Serving Notice: Written notice to remove infected trees shall be deemed
served upon the owner of the property upon which the trees are located when
delivered by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service,
to the person, firm or entity listed in the records of the Cook County
Treasurer as the taxpayer of record for the property.
   C.   Contents Of Notice: The notice shall state that:
      1.   A tree located on the owner’s property is infected with Dutch elm
disease or with emerald ash borers and has been declared to be a public
nuisance;
      2.   That the public nuisance must be remedied by the properly removing
and disposing of the infected tree within twenty (20) days of the date of the
notice;
      3.   That if the owner refuses, fails or neglects to properly remove and
dispose of the infected tree within twenty (20) days, the Village will enter
upon the property with its own forces, or with the forces of an independent
contractor, to cause the infected tree to be removed and properly disposed of;
and
      4.   That the removal cost incurred by the Village will be a lien upon
the owner’s property.
(Ord. 2011-11-9G, 11-9-2011)
5-2-4: REMOVAL BY VILLAGE OR CONTRACTOR:
If the owner of the property upon which an infected tree is located shall
refuse, fail, or neglect to remove and properly dispose of an infected tree
within twenty (20) days after written notice is served upon the owner in
accordance with this chapter, the infected tree shall be removed by Village
forces, or by the forces of an independent contractor engaged by the Village,
and the removal costs incurred by the Village shall be a debt collectible by
the Village from the owner of the property.
(Ord. 2011-11-9G, 11-9-2011)
5-2-5: NOTICE OF REMOVAL COSTS; LIEN PROVISIONS:
   A.   After an infected tree has been removed by the Village as provided in
section 5-2-4 of this chapter, the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department shall cause a written notice to be personally served on, or sent by
certified mail to, the person listed in the records of the Cook County
Treasurer as the taxpayer of record for the property. Such notice shall:
      1.   Identify the property from which the infected tree was removed by
common address or street description;
      2.   State that the owner of the property has failed, refused or
neglected to remove and dispose of a tree infected with Dutch elm disease or
emerald ash borer after notice from the Village as required by this chapter;
      3.   Describe the removal activity taken by the Village; and
      4.   State that the Village has incurred actual costs  and stating those
costs, for removing and disposing of a tree infected with Dutch elm disease or
emerald ash borer.
   B.   Pursuant to the authority contained within section 11-20-15 of the
Illinois Municipal Code and this chapter, the cost incurred by the Village for
removal of infected trees shall be a lien upon the underlying parcel of
property. Within one year from the date that the removal cost is incurred, the
Director of the Health and Licensing Department may file a notice of lien in
the Office of the Recorder of Deeds of Cook County, Illinois, which shall set
out:
      1.   A description of the underlying property that sufficiently
identifies the parcel;
      2.   The amount of the removal cost incurred by the Village; and
      3.   The date or dates when the removal cost was incurred by the Village.
(Ord. 2011-11-9G, 11-9-2011)
CHAPTER 3: SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL
Section
5-3-1:   Definitions
5-3-2:   Collection, Removal And Disposal Requirements
5-3-3:   Containers
5-3-3-1:   Containers Required
5-3-3-2:   Container And Accessibility Requirements
5-3-3-3:   Placement Of Containers
5-3-4:   Waste Not Subject To Removal By Village
5-3-5:   Restrictions On Contents And Removal Of Waste From Containers
5-3-6:   Additional Prohibited Acts
5-3-7:   Regulations Authorized
5-3-8:   Penalty
5-3-9:   Intent Of Provisions
5-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
ASHES: Residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke or other combustible
materials.
GARBAGE: Waste resulting from the handling, processing, preparation, cooking
and consumption of food and wastes from the handling, processing, storage and
sale of produce.
LANDSCAPE: All accumulations of grass or shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree limbs
and other materials accumulated as the result of the care of lawns, shrubbery,
vines and trees.
LITTER: Any discarded, used or unconsumed substance or waste. LITTER may
include, but is not limited to, any garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish,
grass clippings, motor vehicle parts, furniture, oil, carcass of a dead animal,
noxious or offensive matter of any kind, object likely to injure any person or
create a traffic hazard, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature
which has been discarded, abandoned or otherwise disposed of improperly.
Materials that are disposed of in accordance with the requirements of this
chapter shall not be considered to be LITTER.
OPEN BURNING: The combustion of any material in the open or in an open dump.
OPEN DUMPING: The consolidation of waste from one or more sources at a site
that does not fulfill the requirements of a sanitary landfill under the
Illinois Environmental Protection Act (415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.)
RECYCLABLE WASTE: Clear glass, aluminum cans and newsprint and any other type
of waste designated by the Director of Public Works as recyclable.
REFUSE: All waste, except body waste and landscape waste, including, but not
limited to, garbage, rubbish, ashes and recyclable waste.
RUBBISH: All waste, including garbage but excluding ashes, landscape waste and
recyclable waste.
WASTE: Rubbish, refuse, garbage, ashes, landscape waste and recyclable waste.
(Ord. 90-8-1B, 8-1-1990)
5-3-2: COLLECTION, REMOVAL AND DISPOSAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Single-Family Homes And Condominiums: Except for waste described in
section 5-3-4 of this chapter, the Village will collect waste from single-
family houses and condominiums in accordance with the terms and conditions of
sections 5-3-3-1 and 5-3-3-2 of this chapter. All waste not collected by the
Village shall be disposed of by the owner or occupant of the premises on which
the waste is produced or located in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter applicable to premises which are not single-family houses or
condominiums.
   B.   Other Than Single-Family Homes And Condominiums:
      1.   Except as provided in subsection B2 of this section, the owners,
managers or occupants of premises in the Village, other than single-family
houses and condominiums, must provide for removal of waste from the premises by
a scavenger service licensed by the Village at least once in every seven (7)
day period.
      2.   The owners, managers or occupants of premises in the Village, other
than single-family houses and condominiums, that are either: a) in the area of
the Village that is located north and west of the intersection of Mannheim Road
and Lunt Avenue; or b) in the area of the Village bounded by Higgins Road on
the north, River Road on the east, Glen Lake Street on the south and Shafer
Court on the west must provide for removal of waste from the premises by a
scavenger service licensed by the Village at least twice in every seven (7) day
period. If there are two (2) removals of waste from premises that are either:
a) in the area of the Village that is located north and west of the
intersection of Mannheim Road and Lunt Avenue; or b) in the area of the Village
bounded by Higgins Road on the north, River Road on the east, Glen Lake Street
on the south and Shafer Court on the west during a seven (7) day period, each
removal shall occur no earlier than the third day after the day on which the
previous removal occurred. If there are three (3) removals during a seven (7)
day period from premises that are either located north and west of the
intersection of Mannheim Road and Lunt Avenue or in the area of the Village
that is located north and west of the intersection of Mannheim Road and Lunt
Avenue, at least one of the removals shall occur no earlier than the second day
after the day on which the previous removal occurred.
      3.   The obligation of the owner, manager and occupant of premises to
provide for the removal of waste from the premises as required by this
subsection is a joint and several obligation of the owner, manager and
occupant.
(Ord. 2007-11-7C, 11-7-2007)
5-3-3: CONTAINERS:
5-3-3-1: CONTAINERS REQUIRED:
   A.   Every owner or occupant of a single-family house or condominium for
which the Village provides waste removal service shall place or deposit ashes,
landscape waste, rubbish and recyclable waste in separate containers. The
containers shall be of the material, construction and capacity set forth in
section
5-3-3-2 of this section
5-3-3 for refuse and landscape waste.
   B.   Every owner of a multi-family building other than a condominium located
within the Village shall provide at least one container of the material,
construction and capacity described in subsection
5-3-3-2A1 of this section
5-3-3 for use by the occupants of each dwelling unit within the multi- family
building.
   C.   Every owner or occupant of premises within the Village which is not
used for residential purposes must provide a sufficient number of containers
for the deposit of waste produced or located on the premises.
(Ord. 90-8-1B, 8-1-1990)
5-3-3-2: CONTAINER AND ACCESSIBILITY REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Requirements:
      1.   A container into which rubbish or ashes are deposited on the
premises of a single-family house or a condominium shall be watertight and made
of durable rigid plastic or galvanized iron or other metal with a close fitting
cover. All such containers shall have a capacity of not less than five (5)
gallons nor more than thirty (30) gallons and shall be provided with suitable
handles. All such containers shall at all times be maintained in good
condition.
      2.   Except as provided in subsection A4 of this section, a container
into which refuse is deposited that is located on the premises of multi-family
residential buildings shall meet the requirements of subsection A1 of this
section or be a dumpster provided by a scavenger service licensed by the
Village which has a close fitting cover.
      3.   Except as provided in subsection A4 of this section, containers in
which refuse is deposited located on premises that are not used for residential
purposes shall meet the requirements of subsection A1 of this section or be a
dumpster provided by a scavenger service licensed by the Village. If garbage is
deposited in a dumpster, the dumpster must have a close fitting cover.
      4.   Containers in which refuse is deposited located on premises in the
area of the Village located north and west of the intersection of Mannheim Road
and Lunt Avenue or in the area of the Village bounded by Higgins Road on the
north, River Road on the east, Glen Lake Street on the south and Shafer Court
on the west must be dumpsters provided by a scavenger service licensed by the
Village which have close fitting covers and which have a capacity or size of
not more nor less than 1.5 cubic yards, unless the premises is a residential
condominium unit to which the Village provides waste collection service as
provided in subsection 5-3-2A of this chapter.
      5.   All containers in which landscape waste is placed must be
biodegradable and must be closed or sealed.
      6.   In addition to being placed in a container or dumpster in accordance
with subsection A1, A2, A3 or A4 of this section, all garbage must be placed in
a closed or sealed bag.
      7.   Recyclable waste produced or located on the premises of a single-
family house or a condominium shall be deposited into the container provided by
the Village for recyclable waste or if no such container has been provided by
the Village, into a container that meets the requirements of subsection A1 of
this section.
      8.   The owners, managers and occupants of all premises are prohibited
from placing furniture, appliances or any other item too large to be placed
inside a dumpster or other waste container in such a manner that either persons
entitled to use a dumpster or other waste container or a scavenger or waste
disposal service that has been retained to remove or empty a dumpster or other
waste container is hindered or prevented from being able to access the waste
container. Any furniture, appliance or other item too large to be placed inside
a dumpster or other waste container that is located on the outside of any
premises and is intended for disposal shall be removed from such premises
within not more than twenty four (24) hours after such item is first placed
outside the premises. It shall be the joint and several obligation of the owner
and manager of the premises and any occupant of the premises who placed such an
item outside on the premises to notify a waste disposal company to remove the
item from the premises. Any failure to have an item removed or to notify a
waste disposal company as required by this subsection A8 shall constitute a
violation of this chapter.
      9.   The owners, managers and occupants of all premises, other than the
premises of single-family homes, shall be jointly and severally responsible for
keeping the area on the premises where a dumpster or other waste container in
which refuse, garbage, trash or other waste is deposited sufficiently clear and
unobstructed so that a scavenger or waste disposal service is not hindered or
prevented from removing or emptying the dumpster or other waste container. Any
failure to maintain a premises as required by this subsection A9 shall
constitute a violation of this chapter.
      10.   The owners, managers and occupants of all premises, other than the
premises of single-family homes, are prohibited from parking a motor vehicle in
the area on the premises where a dumpster or other waste container is located
in such a manner that persons entitled to use the dumpster or other waste
container are hindered or prevented from accessing the waste container or in
such a manner that a scavenger or waste disposal service is hindered or
prevented from removing or emptying the dumpster or other waste container.
      11.   The owners and managers of all premises, other than the premises of
single-family homes, shall be jointly and severally responsible for keeping the
area on the premises where a dumpster or other waste container in which refuse,
garbage, trash or other waste is deposited sufficiently clear of snow and ice
so that persons entitled to use the dumpster or other waste container are not
hindered or prevented from accessing the waste container and so that a
scavenger or waste disposal service is not hindered or prevented from removing
or emptying the dumpster or other waste container. Any failure to maintain a
premises as required by this subsection A11 shall constitute a violation of
this chapter.
   B.   Administrative Adjudication:
      1.   Violations of the provisions of this section are subject to
prosecution under the Village administrative adjudication proceedings
established pursuant to title 1, chapter 4, article A of this Code, as now or
hereafter amended.
      2.   The provisions of this subsection shall not preclude the Village
from using other methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of
this section including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the
Circuit Court of Cook County or before another administrative tribunal which
has jurisdiction to consider the violation.
   C.   Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section
shall, upon conviction or upon an administrative determination that a violation
occurred, be fined in an amount of not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) or more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
Each twenty four (24) hour period that a violation continues shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Ord. 2009-1-7F, 1-7-2009)
5-3-3-3: PLACEMENT OF CONTAINERS:
   A.   The owner or occupant of a single-family house or a condominium to
which the Village provides waste removal service may place waste containers
that meet the requirements of subsection
5-3-3-1A and section
5-3-3-2 of this section
5-3-3, and which contain waste along the curb of a public street or on the
public right-of-way or in an alley adjacent to the single-family house or
condominium during the eighteen (18) hour period prior to the time the waste is
scheduled to be removed by, or on behalf of, the Village. Any such waste
containers that are placed in a public street or alley or on a public right-of-
way must be removed from the public street, alley or public right-of-way prior
to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. of the day after the waste is collected from the
waste container.
   B.   The Director of Public Works or his designee may authorize the owner or
occupant of a single- family house or a condominium to which the Village
provides waste removal service to place waste containers or large bulk waste
along the curb of a public street or on the public right-of-way or in an alley
adjacent to the single-family house or condominium at times other than those
specified in subsection A of this section; provided, that such authorization
must be given in writing and must be due to the existence of circumstances
which make it reasonably impractical or impose a hardship for the owner or
occupant to comply with the provisions of subsection A of this section.
(Ord. 2003-8-6H, 8-6-2003)
5-3-4: WASTE NOT SUBJECT TO REMOVAL BY VILLAGE:
   A.   The Village shall not remove the following types of waste from single-
family houses and condominiums:
      1.   Garbage that is not within a bag and container as required by
subsections
5-3-3-2A1 and A6 of this chapter.
      2.   Any waste which is produced or generated other than through the use
of the premises as a residence.
      3.   Any waste produced or generated as the result of construction or
repair activity unless such waste is placed in a container that meets the
requirements of subsection
5-3-3-2A1 of this chapter.
      4.   Any landscape waste that is not within a biodegradable container as
required by subsection
5-3-3-2A5 of this chapter.
      5.   Any appliances, furniture or other items which cannot be placed in a
container which meets the requirements of subsection
5-3-3-2A1 of this chapter.
      6.   Any waste which has not been placed along the curb or other location
designated by the Village as the area or place where waste to be removed by the
Village will be picked up by the Village.
   B.   No person shall place any waste on a street, parkway, sidewalk, alley
or other public right-of-way which is not subject to removal by the Village
under the provisions of this chapter; except, that large items otherwise not
subject to removal under subsection A5 of this section may be placed on a
public right-of-way adjacent to a single-family house or condominium on days
designated by the Director of Public Works as days on which the Village will
remove large waste items from the premises of single-family houses and
condominiums.
(Ord. 2002-11-6H, 11-6-2002)
5-3-5: RESTRICTIONS ON CONTENTS AND REMOVAL OF WASTE FROM CONTAINERS:
   A.   No person shall deposit or place in any container in which ashes have
been deposited, any article or thing but ashes.
   B.   No person shall deposit or place in any container in which landscape
waste has been deposited, any article or thing other than landscape waste.
   C.   No person shall place or deposit in any container located on or
adjacent to the premises of a single- family house or condominium in which
recyclable waste has been deposited, any article or thing except recyclable
waste.
   D.   No person other than the Village shall remove any waste from the
premises of a single-family house or condominium or remove any waste from a
street, sidewalk, parkway or other public right-of-way adjacent to such
premises without the permission of the owner or occupant of the premises.
   E.   No person shall remove any waste from any premises for which the
Village does not provide waste removal service without the permission of the
owner, occupant or a tenant of the premises.
   F.   No person shall deface or destroy any waste container without the
permission of the owner, occupant or tenant of the premises on which the
container is located.
   G.   No person other than a collector employed by the Village or a scavenger
service licensed by the Village shall displace, uncover or in any way disturb a
waste container or the contents of a waste container without the permission of
the owner, occupant or tenant of the premises on which the container is
located. If a container has been placed on a street, in accordance with
subsection 5-3-3-3A of this chapter for waste removal by the Village, then no
person other than a collector employed by the Village, or another Village
employee, or the person who caused the container to be placed on the street or
parkway shall displace, uncover or in any way disturb the container or its
contents.
(Ord. 90-8-1B, 8-1-1990)
5-3-6: ADDITIONAL PROHIBITED ACTS:
No persons shall:
   A.   Cause or allow the open dumping of any waste within the Village.
   B.   Abandon, dump or deposit any waste upon any street, sidewalk, alley,
park or other public place within the Village; except, that the owner or
occupant of a single-family house or condominium to which the Village provides
waste removal service may place waste in a street, alley or other public right-
of-way in accordance with and subject to subsection
5-3-3-3A of this chapter.
   C.   Cause or allow the open burning of waste within the Village which is
not in accordance with the requirements of the Illinois Environmental
Protection Act or any other applicable law, ordinance, rule or regulation.
(Ord. 2003-8-6H, 8-6-2003)
   D.   Store, cast, throw, drop, place or deposit anywhere within the Village
any waste in such a manner that the waste may be carried by the action of the
sun, wind, rain or snow into or upon any street, sidewalk, alley, park or other
place in the Village or into or upon adjacent premises.
   E.   Store, place or deposit any landscape waste, except firewood, within an
enclosed structure. All firewood stored within an enclosed structure must be
stored in a place and manner so that it is not susceptible to spontaneous
combustion.
(Ord. 90-8-1B, 8-1-1990)
5-3-7: REGULATIONS AUTHORIZED:
The Director of Public Works is authorized to issue regulations consistent with
the provision of this chapter which are reasonably necessary to provide for the
efficient collection of waste by the Village from single-family houses and
condominiums or which are reasonably necessary to implement the requirements
and restrictions of this chapter.
(Ord. 90-8-1B, 8-1-1990)
5-3-8: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or who shall refuse,
neglect or fail to comply with any or all of the requirements of this chapter,
shall, upon conviction of any such violation, refusal, neglect or failure to
comply, be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more
than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. A separate and distinct
offense shall be deemed to have occurred for every day during which a person
violates, refuses, neglects or fails to comply with any or all of the
requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 90-8-1B, 8-1-1990)
5-3-9: INTENT OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   It is the intent of the Corporate Authorities of the Village that this
chapter be interpreted consistent with the requirements of the Illinois
Environmental Protection Act.
   B.   It is the intention of the Corporate Authorities of the Village, in
enacting this chapter, to supplement, not supersede or replace, the
requirements of the Illinois Environmental Protection Act.
(Ord. 90-8-1B, 8-1-1990)
CHAPTER 4: LITTER CONTROL
Section
5-4-1:   Littering On Public Ways And Places
5-4-2:   Littering From Vehicles
5-4-3:   Littering From Aircraft
5-4-4:   Littering On Private Property
5-4-5:   Litter Regulations For Businesses
5-4-6:   Depositing Litter Into Receptacles
5-4-7:   Distributing Handbills
5-4-8:   Posting Notices
5-4-9:   Enforcement
5-4-10:   Administrative Adjudication/Penalty
5-4-1: LITTERING ON PUBLIC WAYS AND PLACES:
   A.   No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk
or other public place within the Village except in public receptacles, in
authorized private receptacles for collection, or in official Village dumps.
(1971 Code § 18-16; amd. Ord. 2001-9-5D, 9-5-2001)
   B.   1. No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other
public place within the Village the accumulation of litter from any building or
lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway.
      2.   Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in
front of their premises free of litter.
(1971 Code § 18-18)
5-4-2: LITTERING FROM VEHICLES:
No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit
litter upon any street or other public place within the Village, or upon
private property.
(1971 Code § 18-20)
5-4-3: LITTERING FROM AIRCRAFT:
No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the Village
any litter, handbill or any other object.
(1971 Code § 18-26)
5-4-4: LITTERING ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private
property within the Village, whether owned by such person or not; except, that
the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized
private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be
prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street,
sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property.
(1971 Code § 18-28)
   B.   The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all
times maintain the premises free of litter. This subsection shall not prohibit
the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection.
(1971 Code § 18-29)
   C.   No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private
property within the Village, whether owned by such person or not.
(1971 Code § 18-30; amd. Ord. 2001-9-5D, 9-5-2001)
5-4-5: LITTER REGULATIONS FOR BUSINESSES:
   A.   No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or
deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the Village the
accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private
sidewalk or driveway.
   B.   Persons owning or occupying places of business within the Village shall
keep the sidewalk in front of their business premises free of litter.
(1971 Code § 18-19)
5-4-6: DEPOSITING LITTER INTO RECEPTACLES:
Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private
receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or
deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or
upon private property.
(1971 Code § 18-17)
5-4-7: DISTRIBUTING HANDBILLS:
   A.   Public Ways: No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or
noncommercial handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street, or other public place
within the Village or hand out or distribute or sell any commercial handbill in
any public place. It shall not be unlawful on any sidewalk, street, or other
public place within the Village for any person to hand out or distribute,
without charge to the receiver thereof, any noncommercial handbill to any
person willing to accept it.
(1971 Code § 18-21)
   B.   Vehicles: No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or
noncommercial handbill in or upon any vehicle; provided, however, that it shall
not be unlawful in any public place for a person to hand out or distribute,
without charge to the receiver thereof, a noncommercial handbill to any
occupant of a vehicle who is willing to accept it.
(1971 Code § 18-22)
   C.   Vacant Property: No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or
noncommercial handbill in or upon any private premises which is temporarily or
continuously uninhabited or vacant.
(1971 Code § 18-23)
   D.   Private Property:
      1.   No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or
noncommercial handbill upon any private premises if requested by anyone thereon
not to do so, or if there is placed on such premises, in a conspicuous position
near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words “No Advertisement”, “No
Trespassing”, “No Peddlers or Agents” or any similar notice indicating in any
manner that the occupants of such premises do not desire to have their right of
privacy disturbed or to have any handbills left upon such premises.
(1971 Code § 18-24)
      2.   No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or
noncommercial handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited, except
by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant,
or other person then present in or upon such private premises. In case of
inhabited private premises which are not posted, as provided in this
subsection, the person, unless requested by anyone upon the premises not to do
so, may place or deposit any handbill in or upon the inhabited private premises
if the handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent the handbill
from being blown or drifted about the premises or sidewalks, streets, or other
public places; except, that mailboxes may not be so used when so prohibited by
Federal postal law or regulations. The provisions of this subsection D2 shall
not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States, nor to newspapers;
except, that newspapers shall be placed on private property in such a manner as
to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street,
sidewalk or other public place or upon private property.
(1971 Code § 18-25)
5-4-8: POSTING NOTICES:
No person shall post or affix any notice, poster or other paper or device
calculated to attract the attention of the public to any lamppost, public
utility pole or shade tree or upon any public structure or building, except as
may be authorized or required by law.
(1971 Code § 18-27)
5-4-9: ENFORCEMENT:
The Superintendent of Public Safety and all public safety officers are hereby
required to enforce this chapter.
(1971 Code § 18-31)
5-4-10: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION/PENALTY:
   A.   Administrative Adjudication:
      1.   Violations of the provisions of this chapter are subject to
prosecution under the Village’s administrative adjudication proceedings set
forth in Title 1, Chapter 4, Article A, of the Village Code, as of now or
hereafter amended.
      2.   The provisions of this section shall not preclude the Village from
using other methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of this
chapter, including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the
Circuit Court of Cook County or before another administrative tribunal which
has jurisdiction to consider the violation.
   B.   Penalty: Any person violating any provisions of this chapter, shall,
upon conviction or upon an administrative determination that a violation
occurred, be fined in the amount of not less than two hundred and fifty dollars
($250.00) or more than seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense. Each twenty-four (24) hour period that a violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2001-9-5D, 9-5-2001)
CHAPTER 5: WATER POLLUTION
Section
5-5-1:   Definitions
5-5-2:   Water Pollution Prohibited
5-5-3:   Discharge Of Treated Liquids Permitted
5-5-4:   Permit To Discharge
5-5-5:   Pollution Of Swimming Pools
5-5-6:   Penalty
5-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
EFFLUENT: The liquids or other substance flowing out of any plant or facility
constructed and operated for the discharge of sewage, industrial wastes and any
liquid or other discharge.
OUTLET: The point of discharge of an effluent or other substance into the
atmosphere, underground, ditch, or other area, watercourse, or other body of
surface water or groundwater, and onto any surface or place.
WATER POLLUTION: An impairment of the quality of the underground or surface
waters by sewage, dead animals, garbage, discarded metal articles, industrial
wastes or any other thing which adversely affects the use of the water for
domestic, industrial, agricultural, navigational, recreational or other
purposes.
WATERCOURSE: Any channel, either natural or artificial, for the flow of water.
(1971 Code § 16-11)
5-5-2: WATER POLLUTION PROHIBITED:
No person shall discharge or deposit wastes or sewage which creates a public
nuisance, a menace to the public safety, pollution or contamination of
underground or surface waters, or impairs the use of any private sewer, storm
drain channel or public or private property.
(1971 Code § 16-12)
5-5-3: DISCHARGE OF TREATED LIQUIDS PERMITTED:
No person shall discharge into any outlet any sanitary sewage, industrial
wastes or other polluted liquids, except when the same has been treated as
required by law.
(1971 Code § 16-13)
5-5-4: PERMIT TO DISCHARGE:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall discharge any wastes or sewage into
any watercourse, or tributary thereof, or into the ground by percolation or
injection without a permit from the Village Engineer subject to prior approval
of the President and Board of Trustees.
(1971 Code § 16-14)
   B.   Application For Permit: The application for a discharge permit shall be
in writing, signed by the applicant and filed with the Village Engineer. The
application shall state:
      1.   The name and address of the applicant.
      2.   The type of wastes or sewage to be discharged.
      3.   The quantity to be discharged, maximum amounts per hour per day.
      4.   The treatment given to discharge, if any.
      5.   Proof by affidavit of compliance with all Village, County, State and
Federal laws concerning pollution of waterways.
(1971 Code § 16-15)
   C.   Investigation Of Applicant; Inspection Of Facilities:
      1.   The Village Engineer or his designee shall cause an investigation to
be made of the facts stated in the application for a permit to discharge into
the Village waterways.
      2.   The Village Engineer or his designee shall cause an inspection to be
made of the premises and facilities to be used for the discharges to ascertain
the fitness of the premises and facility to comply with the Village, County,
State, and Federal laws concerning water pollution.
(1971 Code § 16-16)
   D.   Periodic Inspections: The Village Engineer or his designee shall
inspect the premises and facilities of any permittee under this section to
ensure there is compliance with all Village, County, State and Federal laws
concerning water pollution.
(1971 Code § 16-17)
   E.   Issuance Of Permit: Upon completion of the requirements of subsections
B, C and E of this section, the Village Engineer may grant a discharge permit
to the applicant.
(1971 Code § 16-19)
5-5-5: POLLUTION OF SWIMMING POOLS:
Every person who illegally pollutes in any manner the water of any swimming
pool shall be guilty of violating this chapter.
(1971 Code § 16-20)
5-5-6: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or
who shall fail to comply herewith or with any of the requirements hereof shall
be punishable by a fine not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   B.   The violation of any section of this chapter shall constitute a
separate and distinct offense independent of the violation of any other section
of this chapter or of any order issued pursuant to this chapter. Each day of
violation shall constitute an additional, separate and distinct offense.
(1971 Code § 16-21)
CHAPTER 6: AIR POLLUTION
Section
5-6-1:   Title
5-6-2:   Findings And Declaration Of Policy
5-6-3:   Definitions
5-6-4:   Air Pollution Prohibited; Exceptions
5-6-5:   Open Burning
5-6-6:   Smoke Emissions From Fuel Burning Equipment
5-6-7:   Inspections; Entry Powers
5-6-8:   Search Or Access Warrant
5-6-9:   Penalty
5-6-10:   Interpretation Of Provisions
5-6-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the AIR POLLUTION CONTROL CODE
OF THE VILLAGE OF ROSEMONT.
(1971 Code § 16-1)
5-6-2: FINDINGS AND DECLARATION OF POLICY:
It is hereby declared that pollution of the atmosphere by smoke, cinders, soot,
fly ash, gases, fumes, vapors, odors, dust and other contaminants is a menace
to the health, welfare, and comfort of the residents of the Village and a cause
of substantial damage to property. For the purpose of controlling and reducing
atmospheric pollution, it is hereby declared to be the policy of the Village to
minimize AIR POLLUTION, as defined in section 5-6-3 of this chapter, and
prohibit excessive emission of the same, to establish standards governing the
installation, maintenance, and operation of equipment and appurtenances
relating to combustion which are a source of potential source of air pollution
and, in furtherance of this purpose, to cooperate and coordinate these efforts
with the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and Title II “Air Pollution”
of the Environmental Protection Act (415 ILCS 5).
(1971 Code § 16-2)
5-6-3: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms, wherever used in this chapter or referred to in this
chapter, shall have the respective meanings assigned to them in this section
unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context:
AIR POLLUTION: The presence in the outdoor atmosphere of one or more air
contaminants in such quantities and duration as are, or tend to be, injurious
to human health or welfare, to animal or plant life, or to property or would
unreasonably interfere with the enjoyment of life or property throughout the
Village or such portion as shall be affected thereby, and excludes all aspects
of employer-employee relationship as to health and safety hazards.
ECONOMIC POISONS: Those chemicals used as insecticides, rodenticides,
fungicides, herbicides, nematocides, or defoliants.
FUEL BURNING EQUIPMENT: Any furnace, boiler, water heater, device, mechanism,
stoker, burner, stack, oven, stove, kiln, still, or other apparatus, or a group
or collections of such units in the process of fuel burning for the generation
of heat or power. Refuse burning equipment shall be considered incinerators, as
herein defined, and not as fuel burning equipment under this definition. Ovens,
stoves, or ranges used exclusively for domestic cooking purposes are not
included herein.
INCINERATOR: Any device, apparatus, equipment, or structure used for
destroying, reducing, or salvaging by fire any material or substance including,
but not limited to, refuse, rubbish, garbage, debris, or scrap, or facilities
for cremating human or animal remains.
ODOR: A property of a substance which affects the sense of smell.
OPEN BURNING: Any fire wherein the products of combustion are emitted into the
open air and are not directed through a stack or chimney.
OPERATOR: Any person who has care, custody, or control of a building or
premises, or a portion thereof, whether with or without knowledge of the owner
thereof.
OWNER: Any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others, shall have
legal or equitable title to any premises, with or without accompanying actual
possession thereof; or who shall have charge, care, or control of any premises
or part thereof including, but not limited to, a dwelling or dwelling unit as
owner or agent of the owner, or as a fiduciary including, but not limited to,
executor, administrator, trustee, receiver, guardian, or as a mortgagee in
possession regardless of how such possession was obtained. Any person who is a
lessee or sublessee of all or any part of any premises including, but not
limited to, a dwelling or dwelling unit shall be deemed to be a co-owner with
the lessor and shall have joint responsibility with the owner over the premises
or portion thereof so leased or subleased.
REFUSE: All putrescible and nonputrescible wastes (except body wastes) and
shall include, but not be limited to, garbage, rubbish, yard trimmings, leaves,
ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and solid market
and industrial wastes.
RINGELMANN SMOKE CHART: Ringelmann’s Scale for Grading the Density of Smoke,
published by the United States Bureau of Mines, or any chart, recorder,
indicator, or device for the measurement of smoke density which is approved by
the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency as the equivalent of the
Ringelmann’s scale.
RUBBISH: Solids not considered to be highly flammable or explosive and shall
include, but not be limited to, rags, old clothes, leather, rubber, carpets,
wood, excelsior, paper, ashes, tree branches, yard trimmings, furniture, tin
cans, glass, crockery, masonry, and other similar materials.
SALVAGE OPERATIONS: Any business, trade, or industry engaged in whole or in
part in salvaging or reclaiming any product or material including, but not
limited to, metals, chemicals, shipping containers, or drums.
SMOKE: Small gasborne and airborne particles arising from a process of
combustion in sufficient number to be observable.
TRADE WASTE: All solid or liquid material or rubbish resulting from
construction, building operations, or the prosecution of any business, trade,
or industry, and shall include, but not be limited to, plastic products,
cartons, paint, grease, oil and other petroleum products, chemicals, cinders,
and other forms of solid or liquid waste materials.
(1971 Code § 16-3)
5-6-4: AIR POLLUTION PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS:
No person or owner of property, and no person having possession or control of
property, shall cause, suffer, allow or permit to be emitted into the open air
substances in such quantities as shall result in air pollution. The provisions
of this section shall not apply to the use of economic poisons.
(1971 Code § 16-7)
5-6-5: OPEN BURNING:
   A.   No person shall cause, suffer, allow, or permit open burning of refuse
or plant life nor conduct a salvage operation by open burning except as
provided in subsection B of this section.
   B.   The open burning of trade waste is not prohibited where no other known
method of disposal can be used without hazard to health or property; provided,
that such person complies with the provisions of the Illinois Environmental
Protection Act (415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.)
(1971 Code § 16-4)
5-6-6: SMOKE EMISSIONS FROM FUEL BURNING EQUIPMENT:
   A.   No person shall cause, suffer, allow, or permit smoke from any fuel
burning equipment, the shade or appearance of which is darker than No. 1 of the
Ringelmann Smoke Chart, to be emitted into the open air.
   B.   The provisions of this section shall not apply to smoke emitted during
the cleaning of a fire box or the building of a new fire, the shade or
appearance of which is not darker than No. 2 of the Ringelmann Smoke Chart, for
a period or periods aggregating no more than three (3) minutes in any fifteen
(15) consecutive minutes.
(1971 Code § 16-5)
5-6-7: INSPECTIONS; ENTRY POWERS:
   A.   All buildings and premises subject to this chapter are subject to
inspection from time to time by the Director of the Health and Licensing
Department or Director of Building and Code Enforcement, or his designee.
   B.   All rooms and areas in the building shall be available and accessible
for such inspection which shall be made during usual business hours if the
premises is used for nonresidential purposes; provided, however, that
inspections may be made at other times if:
      1.   The premises is not available during the foregoing hours for
inspection;
      2.   There is reason to believe that violations are occurring on the
premises which can only be apprehended and proved by inspection during other
than the prescribed hours; or
      3.   There is reason to believe a violation exists of a character which
is an immediate threat to health or safety requiring inspection and abatement
without delay.
   C.   Emergency inspections may be authorized without warrant if the Director
of the Health and Licensing Department or Director of Building and Code
Enforcement, or his designee, has reason to believe that a condition exists
which poses an immediate threat to life, health, or safety. Such procedure
shall take place only where the time required to apply for and secure the
issuance of a warrant would render ineffective the immediate action necessary
to abate the condition.
   D.   Emergency inspections may also be authorized in times of air pollution
emergencies as provided by law.
(1971 Code § 16-8)
5-6-8: SEARCH OR ACCESS WARRANT:
   A.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department or the Director of
Building and Code Enforcement, or his designee, may, upon affidavit, apply to a
judge of competent jurisdiction for a search warrant setting forth factually
the actual conditions and circumstances that provide a reasonable basis for
believing that a nuisance or violation of this chapter may exist on the
premises, including one or more of the following:
      1.   That the premises requires inspection according to the cycle
established by the Director of the Health and Licensing Department or Director
of Building and Code Enforcement, or his designee, for periodic inspections of
premises of the type involved;
      2.   That observation of external conditions (for example, smoke, ash,
soot, odors) of the premises and its public areas has resulted in the belief
that violations of this chapter exist; or
      3.   Circumstances such as age and design of fuel burning equipment and/
or system, types of incinerator, particular use of premises or other factor
which renders systematic inspections of the buildings necessary in the interest
of public health and safety.
   B.   If a judge of competent jurisdiction is satisfied as to the matters set
forth in the affidavit, he shall authorize the issuance of a search warrant
permitting access to and inspection of that part of the premises on which the
nuisance or violation may exist.
(1971 Code § 16-9)
5-6-9: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or
who shall fail to comply herewith or with any of the requirements hereof shall
be punishable by a fine not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   B.   The violation of any section of this chapter shall constitute a
separate and distinct offense independent of the violation of any other section
of this chapter or of any order issued pursuant to this chapter. Each day of
violation shall constitute an additional, separate and distinct offense.
(1971 Code § 16-21)
5-6-10: INTERPRETATION OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter is to be liberally construed to effectuate the purposes herein
described. Nothing herein is to be construed as repealing or abridging the
emergency powers of any agency of government except to the extent expressly set
forth herein.
(1971 Code § 16-10)
CHAPTER 7: SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES
Section
5-7-1:   Definitions
5-7-2:   Nonsmoking Areas Designated
5-7-3:   Authority To Designate Other Nonsmoking Areas
5-7-4:   Posting Signs; Removal Of Ashtrays
5-7-5:   Exemptions From Provisions
5-7-6:   Nonretaliation
5-7-7:   Violations; Penalties
5-7-8:   Prosecution Of Violations; Injunctions
5-7-9:   Application Of Other Laws
5-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the
following terms shall have the following meanings:
BAR: An establishment that is devoted to the serving of alcoholic beverages for
consumption by guests on the premises and that derives no more than ten percent
(10%) of its gross revenue from the sale of food consumed on the premises. BAR
includes, but is not limited to, taverns, nightclubs, cocktail lounges, adult
entertainment facilities, and cabarets.
EMPLOYEE: A person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct
or indirect monetary wages or profits or a person who volunteers his or her
services for a nonprofit entity.
EMPLOYER: A person, business, partnership, association, or corporation, unit of
local government, trust, or nonprofit entity that employs the services of one
or more individual persons.
ENCLOSED AREA: All space between a floor and a ceiling that is enclosed or
partially enclosed with: a) solid walls or windows, exclusive of doorways; or
b) solid walls with partitions and no windows, exclusive of doorways, that
extend from the floor to the ceiling including, without limitation, lobbies and
corridors.
ENCLOSED OR PARTIALLY ENCLOSED SPORTS ARENA: Any sports pavilion, stadium,
gymnasium, health spa, boxing arena, swimming pool, roller rink, ice rink,
bowling alley, or other similar place where members of the general public
assemble to engage in physical exercise or participate in athletic competitions
or recreational activities or to witness sports, cultural, recreational, or
other events.
GAMING EQUIPMENT OR SUPPLIES: “Gaming equipment/supplies” as defined in the
Illinois Gaming Board Rules of the Illinois Administrative Code.
GAMING FACILITY: An establishment utilized primarily for the purposes of gaming
and where gaming equipment or supplies are operated for the purposes of
accruing business revenue.
HEALTHCARE FACILITY: An office or institution providing care or treatment of
diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical,
physiological, or psychological conditions including, but not limited to,
hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals, weight control clinics, nursing homes,
homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons,
chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, dentists, and all specialists
within these professions. HEALTHCARE FACILITY includes all waiting rooms,
hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, and wards within healthcare
facilities.
PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT: Any area under the control of a public or private employer
that employees are required to enter, leave, or pass through during the course
of employment including, but not limited to, entrances and exits to places of
employment, including a minimum distance as set forth in subsection
5-7-2 D of this chapter, of fifteen feet (15') from entrances, exits, windows
that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is
prohibited; offices and work areas; restrooms; conference rooms and classrooms;
break rooms and cafeterias; and other common areas. A private residence or home
based business, unless used to provide licensed child care, foster care, adult
care, or other similar social service care on the premises, is not a PLACE OF
EMPLOYMENT, nor are enclosed laboratories, not open to the public, in an
accredited university or government facility where the activity of smoking is
exclusively conducted for the purpose of medical or scientific health related
research.
PRIVATE CLUB: A not-for-profit association that (1) has been in active and
continuous existence for a least three (3) years prior to February 4, 2009,
whether incorporated or not; (2) is the owner, lessee, or occupant of a
building or a portion thereof used exclusively for club purposes at all times;
(3) is operated solely for a recreational, fraternal, social, patriotic,
political, benevolent, or athletic purpose, but not for pecuniary gain; and (4)
only sells alcohol beverages incidental to its operation. For purposes of this
definition, PRIVATE CLUB means an organization that is managed by a board of
directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members at an
annual meeting, has established bylaws, a constitution, or both to govern its
activities, and has been granted an exemption from the payment of federal
income tax as a club under 26 U.S.C. 501.
PRIVATE RESIDENCE: The part of a structure used as a dwelling including,
without limitation, a private home, townhouse, condominium, or apartment. For
the purposes of this definition, a hotel, motel, inn, resort, lodge, bed and
breakfast or other similar public accommodation, hospital, nursing home, or
assisted living facility shall not be considered a PRIVATE RESIDENCE.
PUBLIC PLACE: That portion of any building or vehicle used by and open to the
public, regardless of whether the building or vehicle is owned in whole or in
part by private persons or entities, the State of Illinois, or any other public
entity and regardless of whether a fee is charged for admission, including a
minimum distance, as set forth in subsection
5-7-2 D of this chapter, of fifteen feet (15') from entrances, exits, windows
that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is
prohibited. A PUBLIC PLACE does not include a private residence unless the
private residence is used to provide licensed child care, foster care, or other
similar social service care on the premises. A PUBLIC PLACE includes, but is
not limited to, hospitals, restaurants, retail stores, offices, commercial
establishments, elevators, indoor theaters, libraries, museums, concert halls,
public conveyances, educational facilities, nursing homes, auditoriums,
enclosed or partially enclosed sports arenas, meeting rooms, schools,
exhibition halls, convention facilities, polling places, private clubs, gaming
facilities, all government owned vehicles and facilities, healthcare facilities
or clinics, enclosed shopping centers, retail service establishments, financial
institutions, retail tobacco stores, educational facilities, ticket areas,
public hearing facilities, public restrooms, waiting areas, lobbies, bars,
taverns, bowling alleys, skating rinks, reception areas, and no less than
seventy five percent (75%) of the sleeping quarters within a hotel, motel,
resort, inn, lodge, bed and breakfast, or other similar public accommodation
that are rented to guests, but excludes private residences.
RESTAURANT:
   A.   An eating establishment including, but not limited to, coffee shops,
cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias that
gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees; and
   B.   A kitchen or catering facility in which food is prepared on the
premises for serving elsewhere.
   C.   RESTAURANT includes a bar area within the restaurant.
RETAIL TOBACCO STORE: A retail establishment that derives more than eighty
percent (80%) of its gross revenue from the sale of loose tobacco, plants, or
herbs and cigars, cigarettes, pipes, and other smoking devices for burning
tobacco and related smoking accessories and in which the sale of other products
is merely incidental. RETAIL TOBACCO STORE includes an enclosed workplace that
manufactures, imports, or distributes tobacco or tobacco products, when, as a
necessary and integral part of the process of making, manufacturing, importing,
or distributing a tobacco product for the eventual retail sale of that tobacco
