in an amount as required by the Village.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
6-4A-5: EMPLOYEE RESTRICTIONS:
No burglar or fire alarm systems licensee shall employ and no persons shall
accept employment as an employee of a burglar or fire alarm system licensee who
has been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude.
(Ord. 75-12-17D, 12-17-1975)
ARTICLE B: WIRELESS ALARM SYSTEMS
Section
   
6-4B-1:   Wireless Systems Required
6-4B-1: WIRELESS SYSTEMS REQUIRED:
   A.   Effective as set forth in subsection E of this section, all existing
fire alarm systems shall transmit trouble, supervisory, and fire signals
directly to the Village's 9-1-1 Dispatch Center via the Village's municipal
alarm system vendor by using a wireless transmitter.
   B.   All new fire alarm systems shall be directly connected to the Village's
9-1-1 Dispatch Center via the Village's municipal alarm system vendor by using
a wireless transmitter. All required test results shall be transmitted to the
Village's municipal alarm system vendor in a timely manner.
   C.   All new and existing burglar, hold-up, and any other alarm systems
which are not considered to be a fire alarm system under subsection A of this
section shall be connected to the Village's 9-1-1 dispatch center via a
wireless transmitter. All required test results shall be transmitted to the
Village's municipal alarm system vendor in a timely manner.
   D.   All wireless fire, burglar, and hold-up alarm systems installed in the
Village, and any other alarm system installed in the Village that is intended
to be monitored by the Village's 9-1-1 dispatch center, must consist of
equipment that is certified and approved by the Village's Public Safety
Department or its designee as being compatible with the Village's 9-1-
1 dispatch center. The company or person installing a radio transmitter that is
intended to transmit alarms from an alarm system located on premises within the
Village to the Village's 9-1-1 dispatch center must be approved by the
Village's Public Safety Department.
   E.   All fire alarm systems installed in the Village shall be directly
connected to the Village's 9-1-1 dispatch center utilizing the Village's
municipal alarm system vendor upon the earliest occurrence of one of the
following events:
      1.   When the term of any existing fire alarm system contract has been
expired, terminated, canceled, or voided;
      2.   When the existing fire alarm system is updated by the installation
of new equipment; or
      3.   April 1, 2023.
   F.   Violations of this section may be subject to the Village's
administrative hearing system as provided by this Code and a penalty of not
less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation and each day of any violation shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2006-11-1C, 11-1-2006; Ord. 2020-3-11H, 3-11-2020; Ord. 2023-9-11E, 9-11-
2023)
ARTICLE C: CONTROL OF ALARM SYSTEMS
Section
6-4C-1:   Definitions
6-4C-2:   Registration Required
6-4C-3:   Standards For Alarm Systems
6-4C-4:   Inspections
6-4C-5:   False Alarms And False Dials
6-4C-6:   Service Charge For False Alarms
6-4C-7:   Nonliability Of Village
6-4C-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
ALARM SYSTEM: Any assembly of equipment, mechanical, electrical or otherwise,
arranged to signal the occurrence of any illegal activity, fire or other
emergency situation requiring urgent attention and to which public safety
personnel are expected to respond.
FALSE ALARM: A visual and/or audible signal transmitted by an alarm system
which indicates the existence of an emergency situation when in fact no such
emergency situation exists.
FALSE DIAL: Any contact by telephone, whether land-based or mobile/cellular,
with the Department of Public Safety, via an emergency contact telephone
number, indicating an emergency situation requiring urgent attention and to
which public safety personnel are expected to respond when in fact no such
emergency situation exists.
(Ord. 2009-1-7E, 1-7-2009, eff. 2-1-2009)
6-4C-2: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
Each person operating or maintaining an alarm system in the Village shall be
required to register the system with the Department of Public Safety. Any
person, business, corporation, or other entity operating or maintaining an
alarm system in the Village who fails to register such system with the
Department of Public Safety shall be fined in an amount not less than two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00).
(Ord. 2009-1-7E, 1-7-2009, eff. 2-1-2009)
6-4C-3: STANDARDS FOR ALARM SYSTEMS:
   A.   All alarm systems installed shall utilize equipment which shall be
substantially equivalent to or exceed the minimum applicable UL standard 1023
(ANSI 2.4-1972) “household burglar alarm systems units”. Fire and smoke
detection systems shall be substantially equivalent to or exceed the minimum
applicable UL standard testing procedure UL 217, and the installation shall
conform to NFPA standards or better, and such equipment shall be installed in a
safe, reliable and workerlike manner.
   B.   All alarm systems must conform to the standards set forth in article B
of this chapter which requires alarm systems to have wireless connections to
the Village Public Safety Department’s communications center.
(Ord. 2009-1-7E, 1-7-2009, eff. 2-1-2009)
6-4C-4: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article, the
Superintendent of Public Safety or a public safety officer designated by the
Superintendent shall have the authority, at reasonable times and upon
reasonable oral notice, to enter any premises in the Village in or upon which
alarm systems or alarm businesses subject to this article are located, for the
sole purpose of inspecting the installation and operation of such alarm systems
or alarm businesses on official Public Safety Department business. The fee for
such inspection shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection
3-10-1H of this Code.
   B.   If the owner or occupant of any premises refuses to allow an inspection
in a nonemergency situation, then the Superintendent of Public Safety shall
have the authority to request the issuance of a search warrant or other court
order that will authorize entry onto the premises for purposes of making the
inspection.
   C.   If the inspection reveals any violations of the provisions of this
article, a written report detailing the violations shall be sent promptly to
the Superintendent of Public Safety and to the owner, lessee or other person
responsible for the alarm system or business in violation of this article. The
report shall require the correction within thirty (30) days after receipt of
the notice of the violation discovered, and shall state that a failure to
comply may result in a fine not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). The alarm user or alarm
business may be granted a reasonable extension of time by the Superintendent to
correct the violation upon good cause shown.
(Ord. 2009-1-7E, 1-7-2009, eff. 2-1-2009)
6-4C-5: FALSE ALARMS AND FALSE DIALS:
   A.   Responsibility: Each person operating or maintaining an alarm system in
the Village shall be liable for any false alarm transmitted by the device which
the person operates or maintains, whether or not the false alarm transmission
is intentional, unintentional or a result of a malfunction in the alarm system.
   B.   Response To Signal Or False Dial:
      1.   Whenever the Public Safety Department responds to a signaling device
or contact of the Public Safety Department via an emergency contact telephone
number, a member of the responding department shall inspect the premises and
shall determine whether the response was caused by a false alarm or false dial.
      2.   If the responding department member determines the alarm or dial to
be false, the incident number corresponding to the response shall reflect the
determination of a false alarm or false dial, and an incident report shall be
drafted by the responding department member and forwarded to the Superintendent
of Public Safety, as well as to the owner/operator, or person charged with
maintaining the alarm system or premises from which the false dial originated.
      3.   The Village shall maintain reasonable proof that the owner/operator
or person charged with maintaining the alarm system was provided with a copy of
the false alarm incident report.
   C.   Silencing Alarm/Resetting Alarm System Board Prohibited: The owner/
operator of an alarm system which transmits a false alarm, or his/her
respective agents, employees, or household members, as the case may be, is
prohibited from silencing such alarm or resetting the alarm system board prior
to the arrival of a member of the Public Safety Department. Any silencing of a
false alarm or resetting of the alarm system board transmitting a false alarm
prior to the arrival of a member of the Public Safety Department will result in
a fine not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   D.   Exceptions: For purpose of this section, the following shall not be
subject to penalty:
      1.   Attempted or actual criminal activity or forcible or unauthorized
entry;
      2.   Structural damage to the protected premises due to earthquake, high
winds, lightning, flooding caused by the overflow of natural drainage, or other
extreme, violent conditions of nature;
      3.   Telephone line malfunction;
      4.   Electrical service interruption;
      5.   System malfunction within thirty (30) days of a new installation or
modification of an existing system; provided, that the Chief of Public Safety
has received prior written notice of the work performed and appropriate permits
have been issued;
      6.   Sudden surge or drop in water pressure in the Village water mains;
and
      7.   Malicious false alarms caused by persons other than the operator of
the alarm system, property owner, or his or her respective agents, employees,
or household members, as the case may be.
(Ord. 2009-1-7E, 1-7-2009, eff. 2-1-2009)
6-4C-6: SERVICE CHARGE FOR FALSE ALARMS:
   A.   To reimburse the Village for costs incurred by it in responding to
false alarms and false dials, other than those listed in section 6-4C-5 of this
article, any person operating/maintaining an alarm system, or any owner/manager
of a premises from which a false dial originated, shall pay to the Village a
service charge for each such false alarm or false dial occurrence according to
the Village Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1L of this Code. The annual number of
false alarm or false dial occurrences shall be calculated during the period of
one calendar year, beginning January 1 and ending December 31.
   B.   In the event that the Village must take legal action to collect unpaid
fines or assessments, the owner operating/maintaining the alarm system whose
fees remain unpaid shall reimburse the Village for the reasonable attorney fees
incurred as a result of such legal action.
   C.   All charges assessed according to this section are a debt to the
Village and shall be collectible within thirty (30) days of assessment.
(Ord. 2009-1-7E, 1-7-2009, eff. 2-1-2009)
6-4C-7: NONLIABILITY OF VILLAGE:
   A.   The Village assumes no liability for any defects in operation of an
alarm system, nor for any failure or neglect to respond appropriately upon
receipt of an alarm from such a source, nor for the failure or neglect of any
person in connection with the installation and operation of equipment, the
transmission of alarm signals and prerecorded alarm messages or the relaying of
such signals and messages.
   B.   Deactivation and/or reactivation of an alarm system shall be the
responsibility of the owner/operator of the alarm system. The owner/operator of
the alarm system shall be responsible for notifying the Public Safety
Department when the system is restored to service. The Corporate Authorities of
the Village or their agents shall not be liable for damage or loss due to
disconnecting of alarms which are in violation of this article, and shall not
be responsible for reconnection or reactivation of any alarm disconnected or
deactivated by Public Safety Department personnel in attempting to determine
the reason for and/or validity of an alarm transmission. Disconnection,
deactivation, or reactivation shall be the sole responsibility of the alarm
system owner/operator.
(Ord. 2009-1-7E, 1-7-2009, eff. 2-1-2009)
CHAPTER 5: ANIMAL CONTROL
Section
6-5-1:   Definitions
6-5-2:   Prohibited Animals
6-5-3:   At Large Animals Prohibited
6-5-4:   Animal Noise
6-5-5:   Offensive Animal Houses And Premises
6-5-6:   Cruelty To Animals
6-5-7:   Feeding Birds On Public Property
6-5-8:   Wild Animals
6-5-9:   Enforcement And Penalty
6-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, including article A, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
ANIMALS: Any and all types of animals, both domesticated and wild, male and
female.
AT LARGE: Off the premises of the owner or custodian of the animals and not
under the immediate control of the owner or custodian.
DANGEROUS ANIMAL: Any wild animal including, but not limited to, wild mammal,
reptile, fowl, poultry, insect or arachnid which is not naturally tame or
gentle, but is of a wild nature or disposition and which, because of its size,
vicious nature, unpleasant odor, poisonous venom or other characteristics of
the same nature, could constitute a danger to human life, health or property.
DOG: Any dog of either male or female.
DOG LICENSE: A license and registration tag required to be issued annually for
each individual dog.
KEEP OR HARBOR: To maintain, possess, control and use.
OWNER: Any person owning, controlling, keeping or harboring a dog or other
animal or fowl.
POUND: An establishment for the confinement of dogs seized either under the
provisions of this chapter or otherwise.
(1971 Code § 6-1)
6-5-2: PROHIBITED ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any cattle, goats, swine, horses,
poultry, fowl or pigeons of any kind, nature or description or any animal
defined as a dangerous animal. All cattle, goats, swine, horses, poultry, fowl,
pigeons or dangerous animals so harbored, kept or maintained are declared a
public nuisance. Any person who keeps or maintains a prohibited animal shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). A separate
offense shall be considered for each day such person shall keep and maintain a
prohibited animal, having been notified by a Village official or any member of
the Public Safety Department that a violation exists.
(1971 Code § 6-4)
6-5-3: AT LARGE ANIMALS PROHIBITED:
No domestic animal shall be permitted to run at large within the limits of the
Village at any time.
(1971 Code § 6-6)
6-5-4: ANIMAL NOISE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit his animal to bark, whine, howl,
or in any manner disturb the quiet of any person or neighborhood so as to cause
an annoyance or discomfort to the public. All such animals are hereby declared
a public nuisance.
(1971 Code § 6-3)
6-5-5: OFFENSIVE ANIMAL HOUSES AND PREMISES:
It shall be unlawful to own, keep or use any yard, pen, place or premises in or
upon which any permitted animal shall be confined, kept or harbored so as to
create a public health or safety hazard or public nuisance. Any person found in
violation of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). A separate offense shall be considered for
each day such nuisance shall continue, after notice to remove and abate the
nuisance is given.
(1971 Code § 6-5)
6-5-6: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
A person shall be guilty of cruelty to any animal in any of the ways mentioned
in this section:
   A.   By cruelly beating, torturing, tormenting, mutilating or killing any
animal, or causing or knowingly allowing the same to be done;
   B.   By unnecessarily failing to provide any animal in his charge or
custody, as owner or otherwise, with proper food, drink, shelter and air;
   C.   By abandoning any animal;
   D.   By keeping any animal in any unnecessarily cruel manner;
   E.   By carrying or causing to be carried, keeping or causing to be kept,
any animal bound or tied by its legs, or bound down by the neck, or so that it
cannot freely stand in an upright position while being transported, or by
carrying or causing to be carried, keeping or causing to be kept, any animal in
any crate or cage so constructed as to permit such animal to push its head
between the slats, wires or other openings of such cage, unless the space
between such wires or slats is also sufficient to permit such animal to freely
withdraw its head therefrom.
(1971 Code § 6-2)
6-5-7: FEEDING BIRDS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY:
   A.   No person shall feed any bird including, but not limited to, geese,
ducks, pigeons and similar fowl while such person is in or on any property
owned, controlled, or under the jurisdiction of the Village or the Rosemont
Park District including, but not limited to, parks, the premises of public
buildings and structures, parkways, streets and other public rights-of-way.
   B.   No person shall leave any seed, bread or bread crumbs, or other
foodstuff which is intended to be or which may constitute bird food on any
property owned, controlled or under the jurisdiction of the Village or the
Rosemont Park District.
   C.   Any person violating the provisions of either subsection A or B of this
section shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not less than two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 94-7-6D, 7-6-1994)
6-5-8: WILD ANIMALS:
   A.   Prohibited In Residential Areas: No lion, tiger, leopard, ocelot,
jaguar, cheetah, margay, mountain lion, Canada lynx, bobcat, jaguarundi, hyena,
coyote, bear, poisonous reptile or other animal which is ferae naturae (wild by
nature and not usually tamed) shall be kept in any residence or on any
residential property within the corporate limits of the Village.
   B.   Running At Large Prohibited: No lion, tiger, leopard, ocelot, jaguar,
cheetah, margay, mountain lion, Canada lynx, bobcat, jaguarundi, hyena, coyote,
bear, poisonous reptile or other animal ferae naturae shall be permitted to run
at large within the corporate limits of the Village at any time.
   C.   Authority To Kill: The members of the Public Safety Department and any
other person in the Village are authorized to kill any lion, tiger, leopard,
ocelot, jaguar, cheetah, margay, mountain lion, Canada lynx, bobcat,
jaguarundi, hyena, coyote, bear, poisonous reptile or other animal ferae
naturae when it is necessary for the protection of any person or property.
(Ord. 78-1-18B, 1-18-1978)
6-5-9: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY:
   A.   Administrative Adjudication:
      1.   Violations of the provisions of this chapter are subject to
prosecution under the Village’s administrative adjudication proceedings set
forth in Title 1, Chapter 4, Article A, of the Village Code, as of now or
hereafter amended.
      2.   The provisions of this section shall not preclude the Village from
using other methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of this
chapter, including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the
Circuit Court of Cook County or before another administrative tribunal which
has jurisdiction to consideration the violation.
   B.   Penalty: Any person violating any provisions of this chapter, shall,
upon conviction or upon an administrative determination that a violation
occurred, be fined in the amount of not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
Each twenty four (24) hour period that a violation continues shall constitute a
separate offense.
ARTICLE A: DOGS
Section
6-5A-1:   Reporting And Inoculation Required
6-5A-2:   Leashed Dogs; Running At Large Prohibited
6-5A-3:   Dog Bites; Quarantine
6-5A-4:   Impoundment Provisions
6-5A-5:   Removal Of Waste Required
6-5A-6:   Enforcement And Penalty
6-5A-1: REPORTING AND INOCULATION REQUIRED:
   A.   Every person who owns or keeps a dog within the limits of the Village
shall report annually before January 1 in each year to the Village's Department
of Public Safety his or her name and address and shall give the name, breed,
color, sex, and proof of inoculations of each and every dog owned or kept by
such person within the Village.
   B.   No person shall keep or harbor any dog that has not been inoculated
within the year.
(1971 Code § 6-12; amd. Ord. 2001-9-5C, 9-5-2001; 2019 Code; Ord. 2023-9-11F,
9-11-2023)
6-5A-2: LEASHED DOGS; RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED:
   A.   No owner or keeper of any dog shall permit such dog to be upon any
street, alley or other public place or upon any private property other than
that in the possession and under the control of the owner or keeper unless the
dog shall be on a leash which is not more than six feet (6') in length.
   B.   Any dog found in or upon any street, alley or other public place or
upon any private property other than that in possession or under the control of
the owner or keeper of the dog, and not licensed and/or leashed as herein
provided, shall be considered a dog that is running at large.
(Ord. 79-4-4B, 4-4-1979; amd. Ord. 2001-9-5C, 9-5-2001; Ord. 2023-9-11F, 9-11-
2023)
6-5A-3: DOG BITES; QUARANTINE:
No owner or keeper of any dog shall permit such dog, without provocation, to
bite, attack, attempt to attack, or injure any person. Anyone treating or in
any way having knowledge of the infliction of a dog bite shall at once report
such case to the Village's Department of Public Safety. If the identity of the
dog can be ascertained, the dog may be impounded wherever found, placed in
quarantine in the care of a veterinarian for a period of five (5) days unless
there is sufficient proof of the dog's inoculation presented to the Village's
Department of Public Safety, or destroyed following an administrative order
that the dog shall be destroyed as a dangerous dog pursuant to the Village's
administrative adjudication procedures. As used in this section, a "dog bite"
shall be defined as the infliction of a break in the skin or a wound by the
teeth of a dog, and a "dangerous dog" shall be defined as (i) any individual
dog anywhere other than upon the property of the owner or custodian of the dog
and unmuzzled, unleashed, or unattended by its owner or custodian that behaves
in a manner that a reasonable person would believe poses a serious and
unjustified imminent threat of serious physical injury or death to a person or
(ii) a dog that, without justification, bites a person upon at least one (1)
prior occasion.
(Ord. 79-4-4B, 4-4-1979; Ord. 2023-9-11F, 9-11-2023)
6-5A-4: IMPOUNDMENT PROVISIONS:
Any dog that is running at large in the Village shall be immediately captured
and confined in the Village pound or other place designated by the Public
Safety Department of the Village. If the owner or keeper shall reclaim the dog
within five (5) days of its capture and pay the sum of twenty dollars ($20.00)
per day to the Village for the expense of confining the dog, it shall be
released to the owner or keeper; provided, however, that such redemption by the
owner shall not relieve the owner from the penalty for the violation of this
chapter. If the dog is not reclaimed by the owner or keeper within five (5)
days from the date of impounding thereof, the dog shall be destroyed or sold.
All fees derived from the redemption or sale of dogs under this section shall
be placed in the General Fund of the Village.
(Ord. 79-4-4B, 4-4-1979; Ord. 2023-9-11F, 9-11-2023)
6-5A-5: REMOVAL OF WASTE REQUIRED:
   A.   If any dog defecates on any street, alley or other public place or upon
private property other than that in the possession or under the control of the
owner or keeper of the dog, the owner or keeper shall immediately, after the
dog defecates, remove the feces from the public place or private property and
dispose of the feces in a clean, safe and sanitary manner.
   B.   The owner or keeper of a dog who is walking his dog on any street,
alley or other public place or on any private property not in his possession or
under his control is required to carry with him a "pooper-scooper" or similar
device which will, if the dog defecates, enable the owner or keeper to remove
the feces in a clean and sanitary manner.
(Ord. 79-4-4B, 4-4-1979; amd. Ord. 2001-9-5C, 9-5-2001; Ord. 2023-9-11F, 9-11-
2023)
6-5A-6: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY:
   A.   Administrative Adjudication:
      1.   Violations of the provisions of this chapter are subject to
prosecution under the Village's administrative adjudication proceedings set
forth in
Title 1, Chapter 4, Article A, of the Village Code, as of now or hereafter
amended.
      2.   The provisions of this section shall not preclude the Village from
using other methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of this
chapter, including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the
Circuit Court of Cook County or before another administrative tribunal which
has jurisdiction to consideration the violation.
   B.   Penalty: Any person violating any provisions of this Chapter shall,
upon conviction or upon an administrative determination that a violation
occurred, be fined in the amount of not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
Each twenty-four (24) hour period that a violation continues shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Ord. 2023-9-11F, 9-11-2023)
CHAPTER 6: JUVENILES
Section
6-6-1:   Sales, Distribution Of Harmful Materials To
Cross-reference:
   See also title 7, chapter 8 of this Code for curfew regulations
6-6-1: SALES, DISTRIBUTION OF HARMFUL MATERIALS TO:
   A.   Sales Or Distribution To Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any
person with knowledge that a person is seventeen (17) years of age or younger,
or who fails to exercise reasonable care in determining the age of such person,
to sell, deliver, offer for sale, distribute, publish, print or exhibit to any
person seventeen (17) years of age or younger any harmful material with
knowledge of the content thereof, or recklessly fail to exercise reasonable
inspection which would have disclosed the nature or content thereof, whether
writing, picture, moving picture, record, or other representation or embodiment
of harmful material, or to present or to direct a harmful play or other
performance, or to perform a harmful act, or otherwise promote the sale of
harmful material to any person seventeen (17) years of age or younger.
   B.   Determination Of Harmful Materials: A thing shall be deemed to be
harmful which, in whole or in part, depicts or describes nude persons, sexual
acts, normal or perverted sexual conduct, whether actual or simulated,
representations of masturbation, excretory functions, or the human genitals. A
thing shall also be deemed harmful which, when taken as a whole, appeals to an
interest in violence, lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific
value, and which depicts or describes the shooting, stabbing, mutilating,
maiming, torturing, burning, strangling or striking of a human being.
   C.   Exemptions: Nothing in this section shall prohibit any public library
or accredited educational institution from circulating harmful material to any
person under the age of eighteen (18) years, provided such circulation was with
parental consent and was for a legitimate scientific or educational purpose.
Nothing in this section shall prohibit a parent from distributing to his child
any harmful material.
   D.   Penalty: Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of
this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than
two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) and may be incarcerated in a penal institution other than the
penitentiary not to exceed six (6) months.
(Ord. 75-7-16A, 7-16-1975)
ARTICLE A: TOBACCO PRODUCTS AND ACCESSORIES REGULATIONS
Section
6-6A-1:   Definitions
6-6A-2:   Sales Or Delivery To Persons Under Eighteen Prohibited; Signs Posted
6-6A-3:   Minimum Age To Sell Tobacco Products
6-6A-4:   Purchase, Possession By Persons Under Eighteen Prohibited
6-6A-5:   Providing, Gifting Tobacco Products
6-6A-6:   Certain Free Distributions Prohibited
6-6A-7:   Vending Machines
6-6A-8:   Suspension Or Revocation Of Business License
6-6A-9:   Penalty
6-6A-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
PERSON: Any natural person, corporation, partnership, or other entity.
TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Any substance containing tobacco leaf including, but not
limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco, or
dipping tobacco.
VENDING MACHINE: Any mechanical, electrical or electronic self-service device
which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment, dispenses
tobacco products.
(Ord. 94-9-6F, 9-6-1994)
6-6A-2: SALES OR DELIVERY TO PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN PROHIBITED; SIGNS POSTED:
   A.   Prohibitions: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for
sale, give away or deliver tobacco products to any natural person under the age
of eighteen (18) years.
   B.   Signs:
      1.   Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided in this
section shall be posted on every premises for which a cigarette and tobacco
dealer's license has been issued and on every vending machine which offers
tobacco products for sale. Each such sign shall be plainly visible and shall
state:
VILLAGE OF ROSEMONT ORDINANCE PROHIBITS THE PURCHASE OR POSSESSION OF TOBACCO
PRODUCTS BY PERSONS UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE
      2.   Each such sign shall be in red letters on a white background, with
each letter on the sign to be at least one inch (1") high.
(Ord. 94-9-6F, 9-6-1994)
6-6A-3: MINIMUM AGE TO SELL TOBACCO PRODUCTS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any natural person under the age of eighteen
(18) years to sell tobacco products within the Village; except, that natural
persons who are at least sixteen (16) years old may sell tobacco products as
provided in subsection B of this section.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage, employ or permit any
natural person under eighteen (18) years of age to sell tobacco products;
except, that a natural person younger than eighteen (18) years of age, but at
least sixteen (16) years of age, may sell tobacco products on premises for
which a cigarette and tobacco dealer's license has been issued if any officer,
agent or employee of the licensee who is at least twenty one (21) years of age
shall also be on the premises for which the license has been issued at the time
of such sale.
(Ord. 94-9-6F, 9-6-1994)
6-6A-4: PURCHASE, POSSESSION BY PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN PROHIBITED:
   A.   Purchase: It shall be unlawful for any natural person under the age of
eighteen (18) years to purchase tobacco products or to misrepresent his/her
identity or age or to use any false or altered identification for the purpose
of purchasing tobacco products.
   B.   Possession: It shall be unlawful for a natural person under the age of
eighteen (18) years to possess any tobacco products; provided, that the
possession by a natural person under the age of eighteen (18) years under the
direct supervision of a parent or guardian of such person in the privacy of the
parent’s or guardian's home shall not be prohibited.
(Ord. 94-9-6F, 9-6-1994)
6-6A-5: PROVIDING, GIFTING TOBACCO PRODUCTS:
No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining tobacco products, shall
sell, give or deliver such tobacco products to a natural person under the age
of eighteen (18) years; provided, that the gift of a tobacco product to a
person under the age of eighteen (18) years made under direct supervision of
the parent or guardian of such person in the privacy of the parent's or
guardian's home shall not be prohibited.
(Ord. 94-9-6F, 9-6-1994)
6-6A-6: CERTAIN FREE DISTRIBUTIONS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person in the business of selling
or otherwise distributing, promoting or advertising tobacco products, or any
employee or agent of any such licensee or person, in the course of such
licensee's or person's business, to distribute, give away or deliver tobacco
products, free of charge, to any natural person on any public right-of-way
within the Village.
(Ord. 94-9-6F, 9-6-1994)
6-6A-7: VENDING MACHINES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale, give
away, deliver or keep with the intention of selling, giving away or delivering
tobacco products by use of a vending machine, unless such vending machine is
equipped with a manual, electric or electronic locking device which can be and
is controlled so as to prevent the operation of the vending machine by natural
persons under the age of eighteen (18) years.
   B.   Any premises where access by natural persons under the age of eighteen
(18) years is prohibited by law, or premises where the public is generally not
permitted and where vending machines are maintained strictly for the use of
employees and businesses which are located on such premises shall not be
subject to the requirements of subsection A of this section.
(Ord. 94-9-6F, 9-6-1994)
Cross-reference:
   See also section
7-2-15 of this Code
6-6A-8: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF BUSINESS LICENSE:
   A.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall be authorized
to suspend or revoke a cigarette and tobacco dealer's license or any license
which has been issued for vending machine products if the Director finds that a
violation of this article has occurred on the premises for which the cigarette
dealer's license has been issued or in connection with the vending machine for
which the license has been issued.
   B.   1.   During the period that a cigarette and tobacco dealer's license is
suspended, such business for which the license was issued shall not engage in
the sale or distribution of tobacco products.
      2.   During the period that a vending machine license has been suspended,
the vending machine shall not be used for the sale or dispensing of tobacco
products.
   C.   1.   Following the revocation of a cigarette dealer's license, there
shall be no sale or distribution of tobacco products on the premises for which
the license has been issued.
      2.   Following the revocation of a license for a vending machine, the
machine shall not be used for the sale or distribution of tobacco products.
   D.   The Director of the Health and Licensing Department shall not issue an
order suspending or revoking a license pursuant to this section unless the
Director has first conducted a hearing to determine if a violation of this
article has occurred in connection with either the premises or the vending
machine for which the license has been issued. The Director shall give notice
of the hearing to the licensee as shown on the license application last filed
with the Village, not less than seven (7) days prior to the date of the
hearing. Such notice shall advise the licensee of the date, time and place of
the hearing and shall state that the licensee may appear at the hearing and
present testimony or other evidence as to why the alleged violation of this
article did not occur. The licensee shall be entitled to be represented at the
hearing by an attorney.
   E.   Any person who continues to sell tobacco products on the premises for
which a cigarette dealer's license has been revoked or suspended or to operate
and maintain a vending machine for which the vending machine license has been
revoked or suspended shall be subject to a fine of not less than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for each
offense. Each day or part thereof that tobacco products are sold or dispensed
on premises or through a vending machine for which a license has been revoked
or suspended pursuant to this section shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 94-9-6F, 9-6-1994)
6-6A-9: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the terms or provisions of this article shall,
upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense.
(Ord. 94-9-6F, 9-6-1994)
ARTICLE B: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES AND JUVENILES
Section
6-6B-1:   Definitions
6-6B-2:   Purchase, Possession, Consumption By Underage Persons
6-6B-3:   Sale, Delivery, Giving To Underage Persons
6-6B-4:   Rental Of Hotel And Motel Rooms For Consumption
6-6B-5:   Use Of False Identification
6-6B-6:   Driving Under The Influence; Transporting Alcoholic Beverages
6-6B-7:   Vicarious Liability
6-6B-8:   False Identification Not A Defense
6-6B-9:   Impoundment Of Vehicle Involved In An Offense
6-6B-10:   Penalties
6-6B-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES OR LIQUOR:
   A.   Any spirits, wine, beer, ale or other liquid containing more than one-
half of one percent (0.5%) alcohol by volume, which is used or intended for use
as a beverage.
   B.   Any beverage containing zero percent (0.0%) or more alcohol by volume
commonly known as “near beer”, “nonalcoholic beer”, or “nonalcoholic wine”,
whose taste, color, odor, and consistency are similar to the alcoholic
beverages known as beer and wine and, except for the reduced alcohol content,
is marketed as being similar to beer or wine.
FALSE IDENTIFICATION: Any document used for identification or proof of age that
has been altered or defaced or that contains false or misleading information or
that contains a name that is not the actual name of the person using it.
IMPAIRMENT: Any diminution or compromise of a person’s physical, mental or
perceptual abilities due to the consumption of an alcoholic beverage.
IMPAIRMENT does not require that the blood alcohol content be in excess of any
particular gram of alcohol to milliliters of blood or breath ratio.
OPERATION OF A MOTOR VEHICLE: The exercise of any control over the motor
vehicle on a street or other public right-of-way or public property within the
Village of Rosemont including, but not limited to, physical control of the
motor vehicle. To be in control of the motor vehicle, the person need only be
in or around the motor vehicle and need not be actually driving the motor
vehicle and the vehicle need not be running. If there is only one person inside
of a motor vehicle, that person is presumed to be in control, regardless of the
person's location within the vehicle. If there is more than one person in the
motor vehicle, but only one person in the front seat or front passenger area of
the motor vehicle, the person in the front seat or passenger area shall be
presumed to be in control of the motor vehicle. If there are persons in the
motor vehicle, but not in the front seat or front passenger area, the owner of
the vehicle or the person to whom permission was given to operate the vehicle
is presumed to be in control. If there are persons in the presence of the motor
vehicle, but no persons in the vehicle, and the owner of the motor vehicle is
present, then the owner is presumed to be in control of the vehicle. If there
are persons in the presence of the motor vehicle, but no persons in the motor
vehicle, and the owner is not present, then the person to whom permission was
given to operate the vehicle is presumed to be in control of the vehicle.
PARENT: A natural or adoptive parent or a court designated guardian.
TO BE IN CONTROL OF A PREMISES OR TO HAVE A PREMISES UNDER ONE’S CONTROL: To
have legal or beneficial ownership of the premises, or to rent, lease, license
or otherwise have a right to be in the possession or control of the premises.
UNDERAGE PERSON: Any person under twenty one (21) years of age.
VICARIOUS LIABILITY: The liability that is implied as a matter of law even
though the person may not have directly caused an injury to another person.
(Ord. 94-9-6G, 9-6-1994)
6-6B-2: PURCHASE, POSSESSION, CONSUMPTION BY UNDERAGE PERSONS:
It shall be unlawful for any underage person to purchase, possess or consume an
alcoholic beverage; provided, that the possession or consumption of an
alcoholic beverage by an underage person is not prohibited when the possession
or consumption occurs under the direct supervision of the underage person’s
parent in the residence of the parent or guardian.
(Ord. 94-9-6G, 9-6-1994)
6-6B-3: SALE, DELIVERY, GIVING TO UNDERAGE PERSONS:
   A.   No person shall sell or offer for sale an alcoholic beverage to any
underage person.
   B.   No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic beverage,
shall sell or offer for sale such alcoholic beverage to an underage person.
   C.   Except as provided in subsections D and E of this section, no person
shall knowingly or negligently permit, on premises under his or her control,
the consumption of an alcoholic beverage by an underage person, and no person
shall deliver or give any alcoholic beverage to any underage person. This
subsection shall apply to both residential and commercial property including,
but not limited to, hotel or motel rooms.
   D.   The prohibition on the consumption, giving and delivery of alcoholic
beverages contained in subsection C of this section shall not apply to the
delivery of an alcoholic beverage to an underage person by the underage
person’s parent within a residence where such delivery, giving or consumption
occurs in the presence of the underage person’s parent. However, the following
shall apply where an alcoholic beverage is delivered, given, or consumed by an
underage person in the presence of the underage person’s parent:
      1.   The parent shall be vicariously liable for any damages which may
result from the delivery, giving or consumption of the alcoholic beverage by
the underage person as set forth in section
6-6B-7 of this article.
      2.   In any prosecution of an underage person for the commission of any
act which violates an ordinance of the Village, the prosecutor, upon reasonable
grounds, may request a ruling as to whether the consumption of an alcoholic
beverage as permitted by the parent was a contributing factor in the commission
of the offense. If the court rules that the consumption of an alcoholic
beverage was a contributing factor, then the penalty set forth in section 6-6B-
10 of this article shall be imposed by the court.
   E.   The prohibition on the consumption, delivery, or giving of an alcoholic
beverage to an underage person contained in subsection C of this section shall
not apply where the consumption, delivery or giving of the alcoholic beverage
occurs in the performance of a religious service or ceremony.
(Ord. 94-9-6G, 9-6-1994)
6-6B-4: RENTAL OF HOTEL AND MOTEL ROOMS FOR CONSUMPTION:
No person shall rent a hotel or motel room for the purpose of or with the
knowledge that such room is to be used for the consumption of alcoholic
beverages by an underage person.
(Ord. 94-9-6G, 9-6-1994)
6-6B-5: USE OF FALSE IDENTIFICATION:
No underage person shall use or attempt to use false identification to purchase
or otherwise obtain an alcoholic beverage.
(Ord. 94-9-6G, 9-6-1994)
6-6B-6: DRIVING UNDER THE INFLUENCE; TRANSPORTING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES:
   A.   No underage person shall, in any manner, operate a motor vehicle on a
street or other public right- of-way within the Village while in a state of
impairment due to the consumption of an alcoholic beverage.
   B.   No underage person shall operate a motor vehicle if there is an
alcoholic beverage in the vehicle unless:
      1.   The alcoholic beverage is in its original package;
      2.   The package is unopened; and
      3.   The underage person’s parent is present in the motor vehicle at the
time it is being operated by the underage person.
(Ord. 94-9-6G, 9-6-1994)
6-6B-7: VICARIOUS LIABILITY:
   A.   The following persons are liable to any individual who is injured or
whose property is injured or damaged by an alcohol impaired underage person
when the impairment is a contributing cause of the injury:
      1.   Any person who delivers to the underage person any alcoholic
beverage which contributes to the impairment. The person who makes the initial
delivery to an underage person remains liable to anyone injured by the same or
different underage person regardless of how many times the alcoholic beverage
changed hands.
      2.   Any person in control of a premises who knowingly or negligently
fails to maintain supervision to such an extent that an alcoholic beverage is
consumed on the premises by an underage person.
      3.   Any person who knowingly or negligently permits the operation of a
motor vehicle under his or her control by an underage person when the person
knew, or in the exercise of ordinary and reasonable judgment should have known,
that the underage person was either impaired or had consumed any amount of
alcohol within two (2) hours prior to when the permission was granted to
operate the motor vehicle.
   B.   The vicarious liability established by this section is not subject to
the limitations on damages as set forth in 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-
21.
(Ord. 94-9-6G, 9-6-1994)
6-6B-8: FALSE IDENTIFICATION NOT A DEFENSE:
It is not a defense to any action of any type brought pursuant to this article
or any other ordinance of the Village against any liquor licensee or any other
person charged with the sale, the offering for sale, or the delivery of an
alcoholic beverage to an underage person that such the underage person produced
false identification or proof of age.
(Ord. 94-9-6G, 9-6-1994)
6-6B-9: IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLE INVOLVED IN AN OFFENSE:
The following apply when any underage person is found in the Village operating
any motor vehicle in which or on which is found any alcoholic beverage of any
kind or nature, or when the underage person is in a state of impairment due to
the consumption of an alcoholic beverage:
   A.   The motor vehicle shall be immediately impounded by the Village Public
Safety Department.
   B.   The motor vehicle may be released only to another person showing proof
of ownership or lease rights to the motor vehicle, unless the underage operator
is the owner or lessor of the vehicle, in which case, the vehicle shall be
released only to a parent or legal guardian of the underage owner.
   C.   The motor vehicle will not be released until the person seeking the
release of the vehicle has paid any and all towing, storage or other costs
resulting from the impoundment of the motor vehicle.
(Ord. 94-9-6G, 9-6-1994)
6-6B-10: PENALTIES:
   A.   Any person who is found guilty of violating any of the provisions of
this article shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than two hundred fifty
dollar ($250.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for
the first offense and not less than three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) nor
more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for the second and
subsequent offenses.
   B.   Any underage person convicted of violating a provision of section 6-6B-
6 of this article shall be prohibited from operating a motor vehicle on any
street or public right-of-way of the Village for a period of one year after the
date of the conviction. If such a person is found guilty of having operated a
motor vehicle in violation of section 6-6B-6 of this article, such person
shall, upon conviction be fined not less than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) nor more than three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 94-9-6G, 9-6-1994)
CHAPTER 7: AIR RIFLES
Section
6-7-1:   Definition
6-7-2:   Prohibitions
6-7-3:   Exemptions
6-7-4:   Penalty
6-7-5:   Seizure And Forfeiture
6-7-6:   Prosecution Of Violations
6-7-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, the term AIR RIFLE shall mean any air gun, air pistol,
spring gun, spring pistol, B-B gun, paint ball gun, pellet gun, or any
implement that is not a firearm that:
   A.   Impels a breakable paint ball containing marking colors; or
   B.   Impels a pellet constructed of hard plastic, steel, lead, or other hard
materials with a force can reasonably be expected to cause bodily harm if it
strikes a human being.
(Ord. 2007-8-1G, 8-1-2007)
6-7-2: PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person under eighteen (18) years of age to
carry or otherwise possess any air rifle on the public streets, roads,
highways, parks, and rights-of-way and on any other publicly owned property
located within the Village.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person, irrespective of age, to discharge
any air rifle from or across any street, sidewalk, road, highway or other
public right-of-way.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person, irrespective of age, to discharge
any air rifle while within a park or while on any other publicly owned property
within the Village except on an authorized target range.
   D.   It shall be unlawful of any person to sell, rent or transfer ownership
of an air rifle to any person under the age of eighteen (18), where such person
knows or has cause to believe that the person is under eighteen (18) years of
age, or where such person has failed to make reasonable inquiry relative to the
age of such person and such person is under eighteen (18) years of age.
   E.   It is unlawful for any person to lend or otherwise transfer possession
of any air rifle to any person under eighteen (18) years of age except with the
prior permission of the parent or such other person who stands in loco parentis
to the person under eighteen (18) years of age.
(Ord. 2007-8-1G, 8-1-2007)
6-7-3: EXEMPTIONS:
Notwithstanding any provisions of section 6-7-2 of this chapter, it is lawful
for any person under eighteen (18) years of age to have an air rifle in his
possession:
   A.   If the air rifle is being stored within his house of residence or other
privately owned, enclosed structure;
   B.   If the person under eighteen (18) years of age is a duly enrolled
member of a club, team or association organized for educational or recreational
purposes which maintains as part of its facilities or which has written
permission to use an indoor or outdoor rifle range; provided, that the air
rifle is actually being used by the person under the age of eighteen (18) in
connection with the activities of the club, team or association under the
supervision, guidance and instruction of a responsible adult; or
   C.   If the air rifle is being used in or on any privately owned property
with the permission of the owner or occupant of the property in a manner that
the projectile from the air rifle will not pass over any grounds or space
outside the privately owned property, and provided the discharge or firing of
the air rifle does not otherwise endanger persons or property.
(Ord. 2007-8-1G, 8-1-2007)
6-7-4: PENALTY:
Any person found to have violated any of the provisions of this chapter shall,
upon conviction, be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2007-8-1G, 8-1-2007)
6-7-5: SEIZURE AND FORFEITURE:
Any air rifle possessed or used in violation of section 6-7-2 of this chapter
is declared to be contraband subject and to seizure, and any such air rifle
shall be subject to forfeiture upon a finding of guilty of any person for a
violation of said section 6-7-2. Upon appropriate order of a court or
administrative hearing officer, the air rifle shall be disposed of in
accordance with applicable law.
(Ord. 2007-8-1G, 8-1-2007)
6-7-6: PROSECUTION OF VIOLATIONS:
Violations of the provisions of section 6-7-2 of this chapter are subject to
prosecution under the Village administrative adjudication proceedings
established pursuant to title 1, chapter 4, article A of this Code, as now or
hereafter amended. The provisions of this section shall not preclude the
Village from using other methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged
violations of this chapter including, without limitation, the institution of an
action in the Circuit Court of Cook County or before another administrative
tribunal which has jurisdiction to consider the violation.
(Ord. 2007-8-1G, 8-1-2007)
CHAPTER 8: MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES
Section
6-8-1:   Offenses Involving Theft
6-8-1-1:   Theft
6-8-1-2:   Retail Theft
6-8-1-3:   Theft Of Lost Or Mislaid Property
6-8-1-4:   Penalties
6-8-2:   Use Of Laser Pointers In Places Of Public Assembly
6-8-3:   Firearms In Parkway Bank Park Entertainment District
Cross-reference:
   See also title 7 of this Code
6-8-1: OFFENSES INVOLVING THEFT:
6-8-1-1: THEFT:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to commit theft of property.
   B.   A person commits theft when he or she knowingly:
      1.   Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner;
or
      2.   Obtains by deception control over property of the owner; or
      3.   Obtains by threat control over the property of the owner; or
      4.   Obtains control over stolen property knowing the property to have
been stolen or under such circumstances as would reasonably induce him or her
to believe that the property was stolen, and:
         a.   Intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of
the property; or
         b.   Knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the property in such a
manner as to deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit; or
         c.   Uses, conceals, or abandons the property knowing such use,
concealment or abandonment probably will deprive the owner permanently of such
use or benefit; or
         d.   Obtains or exerts control over property in the custody of any law
enforcement agency which is explicitly represented to him by any law
enforcement officer or any individual acting in behalf of a law enforcement
agency as being stolen.
   C.   A person commits theft from a coin-operated machine when he or she
knowingly and without authority and with intent to commit a theft from such
machine, opens, breaks into, tampers with, or damages a coin-operated machine.
As used in this subsection, the term "coin-operated machine" shall include any:
      1.   Automatic vending machine or any part thereof;
      2.   Parking meter;
      3.   Coin telephone;
      4.   Coin laundry machine;
      5.   Coin dry cleaning machine;
      6.   Amusement machine;
      7.   Music machine;
      8.   Vending machine dispensing goods or services; and
      9.   Money changer.
   D.   It shall be prima facie evidence that a person "knowingly obtains or
exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner" when a lessee of the
personal property of another fails to return it to the owner within thirty (30)
days after written demand from the owner for its return. A notice in writing,
given after the expiration of the leasing agreement, addressed and mailed, by
registered mail, to the lessee at the address given by him and shown on the
leasing agreement shall constitute proper demand.
   E.   It is no defense to a charge of theft of property that the offender has
an interest therein, when the owner also has an interest in which the offender
is not entitled.
(Ord. 99-9-1D, 9-1-1999; amd. Ord. 2021-1-11B, 1-11-2021)
6-8-1-2: RETAIL THEFT:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to commit retail theft of property.
   B.   A person commits the offense of retail theft when he or she knowingly:
      1.   Takes possession of, carries away, transfers or causes to be carried
away or transferred any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale
in a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of retaining such
merchandise or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the
possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail
price of such merchandise; or
      2.   Alters, transfers or removes any label, price tag or marking
indicative of value or any other markings which aid in determining value
affixed to any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a
retail mercantile establishment and attempts to purchase such merchandise
personally or in consort with another at less than the full retail value with
the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such
merchandise; or
      3.   Transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for
sale in a retail mercantile establishment from the container in or on which
such merchandise is displayed to any other container with the intention of
depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or
      4.   Under-rings with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full
retail value of the merchandise; or
      5.   Removes a shopping cart from the premises of a retail mercantile
establishment without the consent of the merchant given at the time of such
removal with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the
possession, use or benefit of such cart; or
      6.   Represents to a merchant that he, she, or another is the lawful
owner of property, knowing that such representation is false, and conveys or
attempts to convey that property to a merchant who is the owner of the property
in exchange for money, merchandise credit or other property of the merchant; or
      7.   Uses or possesses any theft detection shielding device, theft
detection device remover, or any laminated or coated bag or device designed and
intended to shield merchandise from detection by an electronic or magnetic
theft alarm sensor, with the intention of using such device to deprive the
merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of any merchandise
displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile
establishment without paying the full retail value of such merchandise; or
      8.   Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner
and thereby intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of
the property when a lessee of the personal property of another fails to return
it to the owner, or if the lessee fails to pay the full retail value of such
property to the lessor in satisfaction of any contractual provision requiring
such, within ten (10) days after written demand from the owner for its return.
A notice in writing, given after the expiration of the leasing agreement, by
registered mail, to the lessee at the address given by the lessee and shown on
the leasing agreement shall constitute proper demand.
   C.   Presumptions: If any person conceals upon his or her person or among
his or her belongings unpurchased merchandise displayed, held, stored or
offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment and removes that
merchandise beyond the last known station for receiving payments for that
merchandise in that retail mercantile establishment, such person shall be
presumed to have possessed, carried away or transferred such merchandise with
the intention of retaining it or with the intention of depriving the merchant
permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without
paying the full retail price of such merchandise. For the purposes of this
section, to "conceal" merchandise means that, although there may be some notice
of its presence, that merchandise is not visible through ordinary observation.
   D.   Detention: Any merchant who has reasonable grounds to believe that a
person has committed retail theft and immediately pursues such person may
detain such person on or off the premises of a retail mercantile establishment
in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable length of time for all or any of
the following purposes:
      1.   To request identification;
      2.   To verify such identification;
      3.   To make reasonable inquiry as to whether such person has in his or
her possession unpurchased merchandise, and to make reasonable investigation of
the ownership of such merchandise;
      4.   To inform a law enforcement officer of the detention and surrender
that person to the custody of the law enforcement officer; and
      5.   In the case of a minor, to inform a law enforcement officer, the
parents, guardian or other private person interested in the welfare of that
minor of this detention and to surrender custody of such minor to such person.
   E.   Affirmative Defense: A detention as permitted by this section, does not
constitute an arrest or an unlawful restraint, nor shall it render the merchant
liable to the person so detained.
(Ord. 99-9-1D, 9-1-1999; amd. Ord. 2021-1-11B, 1-11-2021)
6-8-1-3: THEFT OF LOST OR MISLAID PROPERTY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to commit of property which has
been lost or mislaid.
   B.   A person who obtains control over lost or mislaid property commits
theft when he or she:
      1.   Knows or learns the identity of the owner or knows or is aware of,
or learns of a reasonable method of identifying the owner; and
      2.   Fails to take reasonable measures to restore the property to the
owner; and
      3.   Intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of
the property.
(Ord. 99-9-1D, 9-1-1999; amd. Ord. 2021-1-11B, 1-11-2021)
6-8-1-4: PENALTIES:
Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be
subject to the following penalties for each offense:
   A.   A fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more
than twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00); or
   B.   An order to make restitution or reparation in an amount not to exceed
actual loss or damage to property and pecuniary loss in those cases involving
damage to property and pecuniary loss; or
   C.   In the case of a minor or indigent person, an order of community
service of not less than fifty (50) community service hours.
(Ord. 99-9-1D, 9-1-1999; amd. Ord. 2021-1-11B, 1-11-2021)
6-8-2: USE OF LASER POINTERS IN PLACES OF PUBLIC ASSEMBLY:
   A.   Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following words and
phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this subsection:
   LASER POINTER: A helium neon (HeNe) laser which operates at a wavelength of
632.8 nMe with the mandated power limit of 5mW; a diode laser which operates at
a wavelength of 670 nMe with a power source providing 5mW; and any other laser
pen, laser pointer or similar device which emits lasers or beams of light.
   PLACE OF ASSEMBLY: A sports arena, concert hall, theater, movie theater,
exposition center, trade show facility, exhibition hall, ballroom, and any
other structure or places which are used or intended for use as locations for
entertainment, sporting events, lectures, concerts, plays, dances and similar
events, productions and performances. Places of public assembly shall include,
but not be limited to, the Allstate Arena, the Rosemont Theater, the Donald E.
Stephens Convention Center, Impact Field, and the Dome and Ballpark at
Rosemont.
   UNAUTHORIZED PERSON: Any person who does not have permission from the owner
or operator of a place of assembly or from the producer or performer of an
event occurring in a place of public assembly to use a laser pointer in the
place of assembly.
   B.   Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to use,
display, point or shine a laser pointer in a place of assembly.
   C.   Penalties:
      1.   Any unauthorized person who uses a laser pointer in violation of the
provisions of subsection B of this section will be subject to removal from the
place of assembly and, in addition, shall be subject to a fine of not less than
two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense.
      2.   Each instance of the use of a laser pointer in violation of
subsection B of this section shall constitute a separate offense.
      3.   Any laser pointer used in violation of subsection B of this section
shall constitute contraband and shall be subject to confiscation by the
Department of Public Safety.
(Ord. 99-1-6H, 1-6-1999)
6-8-3: FIREARMS IN PARKWAY BANK PARK ENTERTAINMENT DISTRICT:
   A.   Designation Of Park; Firearms Prohibited: “Parkway Bank Park” is hereby
designated as a prohibited area under section 65 of the Firearm Concealed Carry
Act (430 ILCS 66/65).
   B.   Signs Posted:
      1.   The tenants of all Village owned property located within Parkway
Bank Park shall post signs at the entrance or entrances to the building,
premises or real property stating that the carrying of firearms is prohibited.
The signs to be posted shall be a uniform design as established by the Illinois
Department of State Police and shall be provided by the Department of Public
Safety.
      2.   Signs indicating that the carrying of firearms is prohibited within
Parkway Bank Park shall be posted in each elevator lobby and at each walkway
entering Parkway Bank Park. Such signs shall be clear and conspicuous and shall
contain the uniform design established by the Illinois Department of State
Police.
   C.   Penalties:
      1.   Any person that violates any provision of this section shall be
fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense.
      2.   Any person found in violation of this section shall be expelled from
Parkway Bank Park.
(Ord. 2014-3-12N, 3-12-2014)
CHAPTER 9: CHECKPOINTS AT SCOTT STREET SUBDIVISION
Section
6-9-1:   Authority To Establish And Operate; Hours
6-9-2:   Signs Posted
6-9-3:   Persons Passing Through Stopped And Questioned
6-9-4:   Visual Inspections; Information Required
6-9-5:   Vehicle Decals For Employees Or Service Providers
6-9-1: AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH AND OPERATE; HOURS:
The Superintendent of Public Safety (the “Superintendent”) is hereby authorized
to establish and operate “checkpoints” at the entrances to the Scott Street
Subdivision. Any checkpoint established pursuant to this chapter shall be
manned by either a full-time uniformed officer or auxiliary officer of the
Public Safety Department during such times when the checkpoint is being
operated. The Superintendent shall determine the hours during which the
checkpoints will be operated.
(Ord. 94-9-6E, 9-6-1994)
6-9-2: SIGNS POSTED:
The Superintendent shall cause signs to be posted at those entrances to the
Scott Street Subdivision where checkpoints are established stating that all
persons, motorists, and passengers who intend to pass through the checkpoint
are subject to questioning.
(Ord. 94-9-6E, 9-6-1994)
6-9-3: PERSONS PASSING THROUGH STOPPED AND QUESTIONED:
All persons, motorists, and passengers who pass through a checkpoint shall be
stopped and questioned except for those motorists operating a motor vehicle
which displays either a current Village vehicle sticker or displays a decal
issued by the Village Clerk to those persons who are employed at or performing
services at locations within the Scott Street Subdivision pursuant to section
6-9-5 of this chapter.
(Ord. 94-9-6E, 9-6-1994)
6-9-4: VISUAL INSPECTIONS; INFORMATION REQUIRED:
The public safety officer operating a checkpoint established pursuant to this
chapter shall conduct a visual inspections of the motor vehicles passing
through the checkpoint. All persons, motorists, and passengers in the motor
vehicles shall be asked to state their names, addresses and the purpose for
entering the Scott Street Subdivision; provided, however, any person, motorist
and/or passenger who refuses to state his or her name and address or his or her
purpose for entering the Scott Street Subdivision shall be allowed to enter the
subdivision.
(Ord. 94-9-6E, 9-6-1994)
6-9-5: VEHICLE DECALS FOR EMPLOYEES OR SERVICE PROVIDERS:
   A.   The Village Clerk shall be and hereby is authorized to issue, without
charge, decals to persons who do not reside within the Village who are employed
or who regularly perform services at locations within the Scott Street
Subdivision.
   B.   The decals shall be affixed to the lower left hand corner of the
windshield of a motor vehicle.
   C.   No decal shall be issued to any person unless and until the person has
completed an application which states the person's name, address, and driver's
license number, and contains a description of the make, model, color and
license plate number of the vehicle to which the decal is to be attached.
(Ord. 94-9-6E, 9-6-1994)
CHAPTER 10: SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES INVOLVED IN CERTAIN OFFENSES
Section
6-10-1:   Definitions
6-10-2:   Violations Enumerated
6-10-3:   Seizure And Impoundment
6-10-4:   Administrative Hearing
6-10-5:   Requirements For Recovery Of Vehicle
6-10-6:   Posting Bond
6-10-7:   Disposition Of Unclaimed Vehicle
6-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
BUSINESS DAY: Any day in which the Office of the Village Clerk of the Village
of Rosemont is open to the public for a minimum of seven (7) hours.
ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ("IVC"): The Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100, et
seq., and any amendments of the IVC.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Every vehicle which is self-propelled including, but not limited
to, automobiles, trucks, vans, motorcycles, and motor scooters.
OWNER OF RECORD: The record title holder(s) of the motor vehicle.
(Ord. 2004-12-1G, 12-1-2004; amd. Ord. 2023-10-9, 10-9-2023)
6-10-2: VIOLATIONS ENUMERATED:
   A.   A motor vehicle that is used in connection with any of the following
violations shall be subject to seizure and impoundment by the Village, and the
owner of record of the vehicle, or the agents of that owner, shall be liable to
the Village for administrative fees of seven hundred and fifty dollars
($750.00), plus any applicable towing and storage charges:
      1.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and
forfeited pursuant to Section 36-1 of the Criminal Code of 2012, 720 ILCS 5/36-
1, and any amendments thereof, which includes, but is not limited to: first
degree murder, involuntary manslaughter and reckless homicide, aggravated
kidnaping, criminal sexual assault, aggravated criminal sexual assault,
predatory criminal sexual assault of a child, criminal sexual abuse, aggravated
criminal sexual abuse, indecent solicitation of a child, child pornography,
aggravated battery, stalking, aggravated stalking, retail theft, armed robbery,
burglary, possession of burglary tools, residential burglary, arson, possession
of explosives or explosive or incendiary devices, unlawful use of weapons,
aggravated discharge of a firearm, reckless discharge of a firearm, gambling,
or possession of a deadly substance; or
      2.   Driving under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs, an
intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof, in violation of
Section 11-501 of the IVC; or
      3.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, a felony or in violation of the Cannabis Control Act, 720
ILCS 550/1, et seq., and any amendments thereof; or
      4.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of the Illinois Controlled
Substances Act, 720 ILCS 570/101, et seq., and any amendments thereof; or
      5.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of 720 ILCS 5/24-1 (unlawful use of
weapons), 720 ILCS 5/24-1.5 (reckless discharge of a firearm), or 720 ILCS 5/
24-3.1 (unlawful possession of firearms and firearm ammunition) and any
amendments thereof; or
      6.   Driving while a driver's license, permit, or privilege to operate a
motor vehicle is suspended or revoked pursuant to Section 6-303 of the IVC,
except that a motor vehicle shall not be subjected to seizure or impoundment if
the suspension is for an unpaid citation (parking or moving) or due to failure
to comply with emission testing; or
      7.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting, possessing, or
attempting to solicit or possess cannabis or a controlled substance, as defined
by the Cannabis Control Act or the Illinois Controlled Substances Act and any
amendments thereof; or
      8.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired driver's
license, in violation of Section 6-101 of the IVC, if the period of expiration
is greater than one (1) year; or
      9.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle without ever having been issued
a driver's license or permit, in violation of Section 6-101 of the IVC, or
operating a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or
permit due to a person's age; or
      10.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle by a person against whom a
warrant has been issued by a circuit clerk in Illinois for failing to answer
charges that the driver violated Sections 6-101 (drivers must have licenses or
permits), 6-303 (driving while driver's license, permit, or privilege is
suspended or revoked), or 11-501 (driving while under the influence of alcohol,
other drug or drugs, intoxicating compound or compounds or any combination
thereof) of the IVC; or
      11.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of Article 16 of the Criminal Code
of 2012 (Theft and Related Offenses) and any amendments thereof; or
      12.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, any other misdemeanor or felony offense in violation of the
Criminal Code of 2012, 720 ILCS 5/1-1, et seq., and any amendments thereof; or
      13.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in violation of Section 11-503
(reckless driving and aggravated reckless driving) of the IVC; or
      14.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in violation of Section 11-506
(street racing, aggravated street racing, or street sideshows) of the IVC; or
      15.   Operation of a motor vehicle in violation of Section 3-707
(operation of uninsured motor vehicle) of the IVC.
   B.   No administrative fees shall be imposed on the registered owner or the
agents of that owner if the motor vehicle was stolen or hijacked at the time
the vehicle was impounded. To demonstrate that the motor vehicle was hijacked
or stolen at the time the vehicle was impounded, the owner or the agents of the
owner must submit proof that a report concerning the motor vehicle was filed
with a law enforcement agency in a timely manner.
(Ord. 2007-6-6C, 6-6-2007; amd. Ord. 2023-5-1, 5-1-2023; Ord. 2023-10-9, 10-9-
2023)
6-10-3: SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT:
   A.   Whenever a public safety officer has reason to believe that a motor
vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this chapter, the
public safety officer shall, in the exercise of discretion, provide for the
towing of the vehicle to a facility approved by the Department of Public
Safety.
   B.   For any motor vehicle that is subject to seizure and impoundment
pursuant to this chapter due to violations of Sections 3-707 (operation of
uninsured motor vehicle), 6-303 (driving while driver's license, permit, or
privilege is suspended or revoked), 11-501 (driving while under the influence
of alcohol, other drug or drugs, intoxicating compound or compounds or any
combination thereof), and 11-506 (street racing, aggravated street racing, or
street sideshows) of the IVC, a public safety officer shall have the discretion
to release said motor vehicle to the owner of record as provided by 625 ILCS 5/
4-203. For example, the public safety officer may not provide for the towing of
the motor vehicle, or may release said vehicle, if:
      1.   The vehicle is not owned by the person under arrest, and the owner
requesting release possesses a valid driver's license, proof or ownership, and
would not, as determined by the arresting public safety officer, indicate a
lack of ability to operate a motor vehicle in a safe manner or, by operating
said vehicle, otherwise violate the IVC; or
      2.   The vehicle is owned by the person under arrest, and the owner gives
permission to another person to operate the vehicle; provided, however, that
the other person possesses a valid driver's license and would not, as
determined by the arresting public safety officer, indicate a lack of ability
to operate a motor vehicle in a safe manner or, by operating said vehicle,
otherwise violate the IVC.
   C.   The public safety officer shall notify or make a reasonable attempt to
notify the owner of record, lessee, person claiming to be the owner or lessee,
or any person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the
alleged violation of the fact of the seizure and of the vehicle owner's right
to request an administrative hearing under this chapter.
(Ord. 2004-12-1G, 12-1-2004; amd. Ord. 2023-10-9, 10-9-2023)
6-10-4: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING:
   A.   Within five (5) business days after a vehicle is seized and impounded
pursuant to this chapter, the Village shall notify, by personal service, first
class mail, or certified mail, the owner of record, lessee, and any lienholder
of recorder of the owner's right to request a hearing to determine whether a
violation of this chapter actually occurred. The name and address of the person
to whom a vehicle is registered as shown on the records of the State in which
the vehicle is registered shall be conclusive evidence of the name and address
of the owner of record of the vehicle, unless the owner of record gave the
Village actual written notice of a different name or address.
   B.   In order to obtain a hearing, the owner of record must file a written
request for a hearing with the Village Clerk or the Department of Public Safety
no later than ten (10) business days after the date the notice was mailed. The
hearing date must be scheduled for a date that is no more than fifteen (15)
business days after a request for a hearing has been filed. The person
requesting the hearing shall be given at least five (5) business days' notice
of the date of the hearing.
   C.   The hearing shall be conducted by a hearing officer appointed in
accordance with this Code and in accordance with this Code.
   D.   If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines, by a
preponderance of evidence, that the vehicle was used in violation of section
6-10-2 of this Code, then the hearing officer shall enter an order finding the
owner of record of the vehicle liable to the Village for the administrative
fees of seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00). If, after a hearing, the
hearing officer does not determine, by a preponderance of the evidence, that
the vehicle was used in violation of section
6-10-2 of this Code, the hearing officer shall enter an order finding for the
owner and ordering the return of the vehicle.
   E.   If the owner of record fails to request a hearing in a timely manner or
fails to appear at the hearing, the owner of record shall be deemed to have
waived the owner's right to a hearing, and the hearing officer may enter a
default order in favor of the Village in the amount of the administrative fees.
However, if the owner of record pays such penalty and the vehicle is returned
to the owner, no default order need be entered if the owner is informed of his
or her right to a hearing and signs a written waiver, in which case, an order
of liability shall be deemed to have been made when the Village receives the
written waiver.
