(Ord. 2004-12-1G, 12-1-2004; amd. Ord. 2023-10-9, 10-9-2023)
6-10-5: REQUIREMENTS FOR RECOVERY OF VEHICLE:
   A.   A vehicle impounded pursuant to this chapter shall remain impounded
until:
      1.   The administrative fees of seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00)
is paid to the Village and all applicable towing fees are paid to the towing
agent, in which case, the owner of record shall be given possession of the
vehicle,
      2.   A bond in the amount of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) is
posted with the Village, and all applicable towing fees are paid to the towing
agent, at which time, the vehicle will be released to the owner of record; or
      3.   The vehicle is deemed abandoned, in which case, the vehicle shall be
disposed of in the manner provided by law for the disposition of abandoned
vehicles.
   B.   A fee imposed pursuant to this chapter shall constitute a debt due and
owing the Village.
(Ord. 2004-12-1G, 12-1-2004; amd. Ord. 2023-10-9, 10-9-2023)
6-10-6: POSTING BOND:
   A.   If a bond in the amount of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) is
posted with the Public Safety Department, the impounded vehicle shall be
released to the owner of record, and the owner of the vehicle shall still be
liable to the towing agent for any applicable towing fees.
   B.   If a seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) fee is imposed pursuant to
this chapter, the bond will be forfeited to the Village; however, if a
violation of this chapter is not proven by a preponderance of the evidence, the
bond will be returned to the person posting the bond, and all towing fees shall
be waived.
   C.   All bond money posted pursuant to this chapter shall be held by the
Village until the hearing officer issues a decision or, if there is a judicial
review, until a final order is entered in the judicial proceeding in which
review is sought.
(Ord. 2004-12-1G, 12-1-2004; amd. Ord. 2023-10-9, 10-9-2023)
6-10-7: DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLE:
Any motor vehicle that is not reclaimed or subject to judicial review within
thirty-five (35) days after the administrative hearing officer issues a final
written decision shall be deemed abandoned disposed of as an unclaimed vehicle
as provided by law.
(Ord. 2004-12-1G, 12-1-2004; amd. Ord. 2023-10-9, 10-9-2023)
CHAPTER 11: REMOVAL OF UNAUTHORIZED VEHICLES FROM PRIVATE PROPERTY
Section
6-11-1:   Definitions
6-11-2:   Authority To Remove
6-11-3:   Notice To Department Of Public Safety
6-11-4:   Notices Posted On Property
6-11-5:   Insurance Required
6-11-6:   Voluntary Removal Of Vehicle
6-11-7:   Penalties
6-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
OWNER: The owner, agent or lessee, or any other person in possession or control
of the premises.
PERSON: Any natural person, trustee, court appointed representative, syndicate,
association, partnership, firm, club, company, corporation, business trust,
institution, agency, government corporation, municipal corporation, district or
other political subdivision, contractor, supplier, vendor, vendee, operator,
user or owner, or any officers, agents, employees or other representatives
acting either for himself or for any other person in any capacity, or any other
entity recognized by law as the subject of rights and duties. The masculine,
feminine, singular or plural is included in any circumstances.
TOW: That event which takes place when the towing vehicle is attached to the
towed vehicle.
TOWING FIRM: Any individual, partnership, corporation or association of
individuals in the business of towing vehicles.
UNAUTHORIZED VEHICLE ON PRIVATE PROPERTY: Any vehicle parked or abandoned on
private property without the consent of the property owner or his authorized
agent.
(Ord. 76-12-15B, 12-15-1976)
6-11-2: AUTHORITY TO REMOVE:
   A.   Any person owning or in possession of private property within the
Village may provide for the removal of unauthorized motor vehicles from such
property within the terms and conditions of this chapter.
   B.   The removal of unauthorized vehicles from private property shall only
be upon the written authorization of the owner or person entitled to possession
of said property to the towing company which will carry out the tow. The
written authorization must contain a description of the specific auto and State
license plate numbers of the vehicle to be towed. Contracts for the general
removal of all vehicles from private property within the Village are hereby
prohibited.
(Ord. 76-12-15B, 12-15-1976)
6-11-3: NOTICE TO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY:
Within thirty (30) minutes of any tow authorized by this chapter, the person
giving authorization for the removal of the car shall notify the Department of
Public Safety of the time of the tow and shall provide the following
information:
   A.   The address of the property from which the car has been towed.
   B.   The name and address of the owner or other person authorizing the tow.
   C.   The name and address of the towing service.
   D.   The name and address of the person or firm carrying out the tow, and
the license plate number of the towing truck utilized.
   E.   The time at which the authorization was given and at which the tow took
place.
   F.   The year and make and license plate number of the vehicle towed.
   G.   The location where the vehicle may be picked up.
   H.   The towing and any storage charge for the pick up of the vehicle.
   I.   Any witnesses to the tow.
   J.   The signatures of the person authorizing the tow and of the person
towing the vehicle.
(Ord. 76-12-15B, 12-15-1976)
6-11-4: NOTICES POSTED ON PROPERTY:
Any person who desires to authorize the towing of unattended vehicles from his
property shall post the property with a notice of the possibility of such
towing at all entrances and exits to the parking areas in clear view, free from
the interference of any natural or manmade objects. The lettering on these
signs shall be in prominent type, at least two inches (2") high, and in a color
that contrasts with the background color of the sign. Such sign must also be
legible at night. This sign shall contain the following information:
   A.   The fact that parking is prohibited and that the towing of unauthorized
vehicles will take place.
   B.   The location to which the vehicles will be towed, a telephone number at
the Village location, and the name and address of the towing company.
   C.   The charge for pick up of the vehicle.
(Ord. 76-12-15B, 12-15-1976)
6-11-5: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
No person shall tow any vehicle from private property, nor shall any person
accept and store a vehicle towed from private property unless, at the time of
the tow, there shall be insurance in effect in the name of the person covering
damage in an amount as required by the Village.
(Ord. 76-12-15B, 12-15-1976)
6-11-6: VOLUNTARY REMOVAL OF VEHICLE:
No vehicle may be towed by any person from private property if the owner or
other person entitled to possession of the vehicle is present and offers to
remove the vehicle voluntarily prior to the time the person attempting to tow
removes the vehicle from the premises in question; provided, that the owner or
other person removes the vehicle immediately.
(Ord. 76-12-15B, 12-15-1976)
6-11-7: PENALTIES:
Any person in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined
not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for the first offense, and not less than three hundred
dollars ($300.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the
second and each subsequent offense. Repeated offenses in excess of three (3)
may also be punishable as a misdemeanor by incarceration in the County Jail for
a term not to exceed six (6) months under the procedure set forth in section 1-
2-1.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code and under the provisions of the Illinois
Code of Criminal Procedure (725 ILCS 5/100-1 et seq.) in a separate proceeding.
(Ord. 76-12-15B, 12-15-1976)

6-12-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND AMENDMENT OF FUND:
   A.   The Public Safety Officers Pension Fund for the Village of Rosemont
(the "Fund") established by Ordinance No. 86-11-5B and thereafter amended is
hereby comprehensively restated and amended in its entirety. All assets and
liabilities of the "Police Pension Fund" established pursuant to Village of
Rosemont Ordinance No. 75-10-15A shall be assets and liabilities of the Fund.
As used in this chapter the term "Fund" includes the Public Safety Officers
Pension Fund and the "Police Pension Fund" established pursuant to Village of
Rosemont Ordinance No. 75-10-15A. The Fund is established as a qualified
governmental defined benefit plan pursuant to Sections 401(a) and 414(d) of the
Internal Revenue Code and such other provisions as applicable, as well as
applicable Treasury Regulations and other guidance.
   B.   The assets of the Fund shall never inure to the benefit of the Village
and shall be held for the exclusive purpose of providing benefits to Public
Safety Officers and their beneficiaries and defraying reasonable expenses of
administering the Fund.
   C.   The trust fund must not revert, and no contributions shall be permitted
to be returned to the Village, except as permitted by Revenue Ruling 91-4 under
a mistake of fact.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-2: DEFINITIONS:
The terms in this chapter have the meanings ascribed to them in section
6-12-1 and sections
6-12-3 through
6-12-10.5 of this chapter except when the context otherwise requires. All
references to the Internal Revenue Code shall mean the Internal Revenue Code of
1986, as amended.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-3: VILLAGE:
VILLAGE. The Village of Rosemont.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-4: BOARD:
BOARD. The Board of Trustees of the Fund as established in section
6-12-38 .
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-5: PENSIONER, DEFERRED PENSIONER, FUND BENEFICIARY:
   A.   PENSIONER. A public safety officer receiving a disability, occupational
disease disability or retirement pension under this chapter.
   B.   DEFERRED PENSIONER. A Public Safety Officer who has retired having
accumulated enough creditable service to qualify for a pension, but who has not
attained the required age.
   C.   FUND BENEFICIARY. Any person to whom pension payments are made pursuant
to this chapter. If a special needs trust as described in Section 1396p(d)(4)
of Title 42 of the United States Code, as amended from time to time, has been
established for a disabled adult child, then the special needs trust may stand
in lieu of the disabled adult child as a beneficiary for the purposes of this
Article.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-6: PUBLIC SAFETY OFFICER, OFFICER:
PUBLIC SAFETY OFFICER or OFFICER. Any person who (1) is appointed by the Board
of Public Safety Commissioners to the Village's Public Safety Department and
sworn and commissioned to perform public safety duties or was appointed by the
Village's Board of Fire and Police Commissioners prior to October 1, 1975 to
the Police Department or the Fire Department of the Village; and (2) within
three (3) months after receiving his or her first appointment, and if
reappointed, within three (3) months thereafter, makes written application to
the Board to come under the provisions of this chapter The Superintendent of
the Department of Public Safety shall not be considered to be a "Public Safety
Officer" or "Officer" while serving as the Superintendent of the Department of
Public Safety unless such person was actively serving as a Public Safety
Officer immediately prior to his or her appointment to be Director. The Deputy
Superintendent of the Department of Public Safety shall not be considered to be
a "Public Safety Officer" or "Officer" while serving as the Deputy
Superintendent. A Public Safety Officer serving a probationary period following
his or her initial appointment, if otherwise eligible, is an Officer within the
meaning of this section. Persons who served as full-time police officers or
firefighters of the Village prior to October 1, 1975, if otherwise eligible,
shall be Public Safety Officers within the meaning of this section.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-7: PERMANENT DISABILITY:
PERMANENT DISABILITY. Any physical or mental disability that (1) can be
expected to result in death, (2) has lasted for a continuous period of not less
than 12 months, or (3) can be expected to last for a continuous period of not
less than 12 months.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-8: GENDER:
GENDER. The masculine gender whenever used in this chapter includes the female
gender unless manifestly inconsistent with the context.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-9: CHILD OR CHILDREN:
CHILD or CHILDREN. "Child" or "children" includes a public safety officer's
natural and legally adopted children. Adopted children shall be eligible for
benefits only if the judicial proceedings for adoption were commenced at least
one year prior to the death or disability of the public safety officer and in
any event prior to his or her attainment of age fifty (50).
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-10: DEPENDENT PARENT:
DEPENDENT PARENT. A parent who furnishes satisfactory proof that the deceased
public safety officer at the time of his or her death was the sole support of
the parent or that the parent was the dependent of the deceased public safety
officer for federal income tax purposes.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-10.5: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX-U:
CONSUMER PRICE INDEX-U. The index published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics
of the United States Department of Labor that measures the average change in
prices of goods and services purchased by all urban consumers, United States
city average, all items, 1982-84 = 100.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-11: PERSONS EXCLUDED:
The following persons shall not be entitled to participate in the Fund: (1) Any
person who is not a Public Safety Officer as defined in section
6-12-6 of this chapter, including but not limited to part-time public safety
officers, security specialists, temporary employees, auxiliary public safety
officers, clerks or other civilian employees assigned to the public safety
department who perform clerical duties exclusively; or (2) any Public Safety
Officer who fails to pay the contributions required under section
6-12-35, computed (i) for a person who was hired as an Officer prior to April
30, 1975, from the date the Village established the Fund, or (ii) for Public
Safety Officers hired after April 30, 1975, from the date of a Public Safety
Officer's first appointment (including an appointment on probation), and
continuing during his or her entire service as a Public Safety Officer. A
Public Safety Officer who is reappointed shall, before being declared eligible
to participate in the Fund, repay to the Fund as required by section
6-12-31 any refund received thereunder.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-12:   CREDITABLE SERVICE:
"Creditable service" is the time served by a Public Safety Officer as an
officer of the Village's Public Safety Department. Any time served as a full-
time police officer of the Village's police department prior to October 1, 1975
and any time served as a full-time firefighter of the Village's fire department
prior to October 1, 1975 shall be included in the determination of creditable
service. In computing creditable service, furloughs without pay exceeding
thirty (30) days shall not be counted, but leaves of absence for illness or
accident (Including periods when Village provided or Pension Board Temporary
Disability Benefits have been provided), regardless of length, and all periods
of disability retirement for which a Public Safety Officer has received no
disability pension payments under this chapter shall be counted.
Creditable service includes:
   A.   Up to three (3) years during which a Public Safety Officer receives a
disability pension under sections
6-12-16,
6-12-17 and
6-12-18 of this chapter provided that:
      1.   The Public Safety Officer returns to active service after the
disability for a period at least equal to the period for which credit is to be
established; and
      2.   The Public Safety Officer makes contributions to the Fund based on
the rates specified in section
6-12-35 of this chapter and the salary upon which the disability pension is
based. These contributions may be paid at any time prior to the commencement of
a retirement pension. The Public Safety Officer may, but need not, elect to
have the contributions deducted from his or her disability pension or to pay
them in installments on a schedule approved by the Board. If not deducted from
the disability pension, the contributions shall included interest at the rate
of six percent (6%) per year, compounded annually, from the date for which
service credit is being established to the date of payment. If contributions
are paid under this subsection in excess of those needed to establish the
credit, the excess shall be refunded. This subsection applies to Public Safety
Officers receiving a disability pension under sections
6-12-16,
6-12-17 and
6-12-18 on October 1, 2000, as well as Public Safety Officers who begin to
receive such a disability pension after that date; and
   B.   1.   All periods of service in the military, naval or air forces of the
United States entered upon while an active Public Safety Officer of the
Village, either on account of any war in which the United States was a
belligerent party, or as required by Act of Congress, provided that upon
applying for a permanent pension, and in accordance with the rules of the
Board, the Public Safety Officer pays into the Fund the amount the Officer
would have contributed if he or she had been a regular contributor during such
period, to the extent that the Village has not made such contributions on the
Officer's behalf. The total amount of such creditable service shall not exceed
five (5) years.
      2.   Effective with respect to deaths occurring on or after January 1,
2007, while a Public Safety Officer is performing qualified military service
(as defined in chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code), to the extent
required by Section 401(a)(37) of the Internal Revenue Code, survivors of the
deceased Officer are entitled to any additional benefits that the Fund would
provide if the Officer had resumed employment and then died, such as
accelerated vesting or survivor benefits that are contingent on the Officer's
death while employed. In any event, a deceased Officer's period of qualified
military service must be counted as creditable service for vesting purposes.
      3.   Effective with respect to deaths and/or disabilities occurring on or
after January 1, 2007, while a Public Safety Officer is performing qualified
military service (as defined in chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code), to
the extent permitted by Section 414(u)(8) of the Internal Revenue Code for all
creditable service purposes, the Officer will be treated as having earned years
of creditable service for the period of qualified military service, having
returned to employment on the day before the death and/or disability, and then
having terminated on the date of death or disability. This provision shall be
applied to all similarly situated individuals in a reasonably equivalent
manner.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011; amd. Ord. 2021-2-8E, 2-8-2021)
6-12-13:   PENSION:
   A.   1.   A public safety officer age fifty (50) or more with twenty (20) or
more years of creditable service, who is no longer in service as a Public
Safety Officer, shall receive a lifetime pension of 1/2 of the salary attached
to the rank of Public Safety Officer held on the date of retirement or 1/2 of
the highest salary paid to the Public Safety Officer during a calendar year for
the five (5) calendar years immediately prior to retirement, whichever is
higher. A public safety officer shall be one hundred percent (100%) vested in
his or her pension retirement benefit upon attaining eligibility for a pension
under this Section. If an Officer was on an approved leave of absence on the
date of retirement, then the pension the Officer shall be entitled to receive
shall be equal to 1/2 the salary attached on the date of retirement to the rank
the Public Safety Officer held immediately prior to going on the leave of
absence, or 1/2 the highest salary paid or which would have been paid to the
Public Safety Officer, had the officer not been on a leave of absence, during a
calendar year for the five (5) calendar years immediately prior to retirement,
whichever is higher, provided that contributions were made to the Fund by or on
behalf of the Officer for the period the Officer was on the approved leave of
absence. As of January 1, 1999, the pension shall be increased from 2.0% to
2.5% of such salary for each additional year of service over twenty (20) years,
to a maximum of seventy five percent (75%) of such salary. This increase
applies to all pensions that became payable on or after January 1, 1999. All
pensions payable under this section that began on or after January 1, 1999 and
before October 1, 2000 shall be recalculated, and the amount of the increase
accruing for that period shall be payable to the public safety officer in a
lump sum. No pension shall be less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) per
month.
      2.   As of January 1, 1999, the minimum retirement pension for a Public
Safety Officer having at least twenty (20) years of creditable service shall be
six hundred dollars ($600.00) per month, without regard to whether he or she
was in service on or after October 1, 2000. A Public Safety Officer whose
pension began prior to October 1, 2000 and is subject to this increase, shall
be entitled to a lump sum payment of the amount of that increase accruing from
January 1, 1999, or the date the pension began, if later, to October 1, 2000.
As of October 1, 2000, the minimum retirement pension for a public safety
officer having at least twenty (20) years of creditable service shall be eight
hundred dollars ($800.00) per month, without regard to whether he or she was in
service on or after October 1, 2000. As of January 1, 2001, the minimum
retirement pension for a public safety officer having at least twenty (20)
years of creditable service shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per
month, without regard to whether he or she was in service on or after October
1, 2000.
   B.   A Public Safety Officer mandatorily retired from service due to age by
operation of law, having at least eight (8) but less than twenty (20) years of
creditable service, shall receive a pension equal to 2.5% of the salary
attached to the rank he or she held on the Public Safety Department for one
year immediately prior to retirement for each year of creditable service.
   C.   A Public Safety Officer who retires or is separated from service having
at least eight (8) years but less than twenty (20) years of creditable service,
who is not mandatorily retired due to age by operation of law, and who does not
apply for a refund of contributions at his or her last separation from service,
shall receive a pension upon attaining age sixty (60) equal to 2.5% of the
salary attached to the rank held by the Officer on the Public Safety Department
for one year immediately prior to retirement, for each year of creditable
service.
   D.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this Article, the provisions of
this subsection D apply to a person who first becomes a Public Safety Officer
on or after January 1, 2012. A Public Safety Officer age fifty five (55) or
more who has ten (10) or more years of service in that capacity shall be
entitled at his option to receive a monthly pension for his service as a Public
Safety Officer computed by multiplying 2.5% for each year of such service by
his or her final average salary. The pension of a Public Safety Officer who is
retiring after attaining age fifty (50) with ten (10) or more years of
creditable service shall be reduced by one-half of 1% for each month that the
Public Safety Officer's age is under age 55. The maximum pension under this
subsection D shall be seventy five percent (75%) of final average salary. For
the purposes of this subsection D, "final average salary" means the average
monthly salary obtained by dividing the total salary of the Public Safety
Officer during the ninety six (96) consecutive months of service within the
last one huundred twenty (120) months of service in which the total salary was
the highest by the number of months of service in that period. Beginning on
January 1, 2012, for all purposes under this chapter (including without
limitation the calculation of benefits and employee contributions), the annual
salary based on the plan year of a member or participant to whom this section
applies shall not exceed $106,800.00; however, that amount shall annually
thereafter be increased by the lesser of (i) three percent (3%) of that amount,
including all previous adjustments, or (ii) one-half the annual unadjusted
percentage increase (but not less than zero) in the consumer price index-u for
the twelve (12) months ending with the September preceding each November 1,
including all previous adjustments.
   E.   [Reserved].
   F.   After August 10, 2016 when determining the additional years of service
over twenty (20) years under subsection A1, or the number of years of
creditable service under subsections B, C, D, and E, the practice of
determining the number of years of creditable service by including partial
years shall be used, with partial years being determined by dividing the number
of full months of creditable service in the partial year by twelve (12).
   G.   The Fund shall pay all benefits in accordance with a good faith
interpretation of the requirements of Section 401(a)(9) of the Code and the
Treasury Regulations in effect under that section, as applicable to a
governmental plan within the meaning of Section 414(d) of the Internal Revenue
Code. The Fund is subject to the following provisions:
      1.   Distribution of a Public Safety Officer's benefit must begin by the
required beginning date, which is the later of the April 1 following the
calendar year in which the officer attains age 70½ or April 1 of the year
following the calendar year in which the officer terminates or retires. If a
Public Safety Officer who qualifies for a pension benefit fails to apply for
benefits by the later of either of those dates, the board shall begin
distribution of the monthly benefit in the form provided in subsection A.
      2.   As a lifetime benefit, the Public Safety Officer's entire interest
must be distributed over the Public Safety Officer's life or the lives of the
Officer and a designated beneficiary, or over a period not extending beyond the
life expectancy of the Officer or of the Officer and a designated beneficiary.
      3.   The Fund, pursuant to a qualified domestic relations order, may
establish separate benefits for a Public Safety Officer and a non-public safety
officer.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011; amd. Ord. 2016-8-10E, 8-10-2016; Ord. 2022-12-
12C, 12-12-2022)
6-12-14:   INCREASE IN PENSION:
   A.   The monthly pension of a Public Safety Officer who retired prior to
January 1, 1988, shall be increased, upon either the first of the month
following the first anniversary of the date of retirement if the Officer was
sixty (60) years of age or over at retirement date, or upon the first day of
the month following attainment of age sixty (60), if it occurs after the first
anniversary of retirement, by three percent (3%) of the originally granted
pension, and by an additional three percent (3%) of the originally granted
pension in January of each year thereafter.
   B.   The monthly pension of a Public Safety Officer who is receiving a
disability pension, shall be increased in January of the year following the
year the Public Safety Officer attains age sixty by 1/12 of three percent (3%)
of the originally granted monthly pension for each full month that has elapsed
since the pension began. On each January thereafter, such Public Safety Officer
shall receive an additional increase of three percent (3%) of the original
monthly pension.
   C.   As of January 1, 1999, the monthly pension of a Public Safety Officer
who retired on or after January 1, 1988 and before January 1, 1990, shall be
increased, upon either the first of the month following the first anniversary
of the date of retirement if the Officer is fifty-five (55) years of age or
over, or upon the first day of the month following attainment of age fifty-five
(55) if it occurs after the first anniversary of retirement, by 1/12 of three
percent (3%) of the originally granted pension for each full month that has
elapsed since the pension began, and by an additional three percent (3%) of the
originally granted monthly pension each January thereafter.
   D.   As of January 1, 1999, the monthly pension of a Public Safety Officer
who retired on or after January 1, 1990, shall, upon either the first month
following the first anniversary date of retirement if fifty-five years of age
or over, or upon the first day of the month following attainment of age fifty-
five if it occurs after the first anniversary of retirement, be increased by 1/
12 of three percent (3%) of the originally granted monthly pension for each
full month that has elapsed since the pension began, and by an additional three
percent (3%) in each January thereafter.
   E.   Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, beginning with
increases granted on or after January 1, 1995, the second and all subsequent
automatic annual increases granted under subsection A, C, or D of this section
shall be calculated as three percent (3%) of the amount of pension payable at
the time of the increase, including any increases previously granted under this
section, rather than three percent (3%) of the originally granted pension
amount.
   F.   The increases in pension granted as of January 1, 1999 in subsections C
and D of this Section apply to all initial increases that become payable under
subsections C and D on or after January 1, 1999. All initial increases that
became payable under subsection C and D on or after January 1, 1999 and before
October 1, 2000 shall be recalculated and the additional amount accruing for
that period, if any, shall be payable to the Public Safety Officer in a lump
sum.
   G.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the monthly
pension of a person who first becomes a Public Safety Officer on or after
January 1, 2012 shall be increased on the January 1 occurring either on or
after the attainment of age sixty (60) or the first anniversary of the pension
start date, whichever is later and on each subsequent January 1 thereafter. The
initial January 1 increase and each subsequent January 1 increase following the
initial January 1 increase shall be calculated at three percent (3%) or one-
half the annual unadjusted percentage increase (but not less than zero) in the
consumer price index-u for the twelve (12) months ending with the September
preceding each January 1 on which an increase is payable, whichever is less, of
the originally granted pension. If the annual unadjusted percentage change in
the consumer price index-u for a twelve (12) month period ending in September
is zero or, when compared with the preceding period, decreases, then the
pension shall not be increased.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-15:   PENSION TO SURVIVORS:
   A.   Upon the death of a Public Safety Officer entitled to a pension under
section
6-12-13, the surviving spouse shall be entitled to the pension to which the
Public Safety Officer was then entitled. Upon the death of the surviving
spouse, or if the spouse remarries prior to January 1, 1995, the Public Safety
Officer's unmarried children who are under age 18 or who are dependent because
of physical or mental disability shall be entitled to equal shares of such
pension. If there is no eligible surviving spouse and no eligible child, the
dependent parent or parents of the Officer shall be entitled to receive or
share such pension until their death or marriage or remarriage after the death
of the Public Safety Officer. Remarriage of the surviving spouse on or after
January 1, 1995 does not affect the surviving spouse's pension, regardless of
whether the deceased Public Safety Officer was in service on or after the
effective date of Ordinance 95-2-1H. In any case, the survivor's pension, if
any, shall be distributed monthly.
   Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, for a person who first
becomes a Public Safety Officer under this chapter or after January 1, 2012,
the pension to which the surviving spouse, children, or parents are entitled
under this subsection A shall be in the amount of 66% of the Public Safety
Officer's earned pension at the date of death. Nothing in this subsection A
shall act to diminish the survivor's benefits described in subsection F of this
Section.
   Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the monthly pension of
a survivor of a person who first becomes a Public Safety Officer under this
chapter on or after January 1, 2012 shall be increased on the January 1 after
attainment of age sixty (60) by the recipient of the survivor's pension and
each January 1 thereafter by three percent (3%) or one-half the annual
unadjusted percentage increase (but not less than zero) in the consumer price
index-u for the twelve (12) months ending with the September preceding each
November 1, whichever is less, of the originally granted survivor's pension. If
the annual unadjusted percentage change in the consumer price index-u for a
twelve (12) month period ending in September is zero or, when compared with the
preceding period, decreases, then the survivor's pension shall not be
increased.
   B.   Upon the death of a Public Safety Officer while in service, having at
least twenty (20) years of creditable service, or upon the death of a Public
Safety Officer who retired from service with at least twenty (20) years of
creditable service, whether death occurs before or after attainment of age
fifty (50), the pension earned by the Public Safety Officer as of the date of
death as provided in section
6-12-13 shall be paid to the survivors in the sequence provided in subsection A
of this section. As of January 1, 1995, the monthly pension to the surviving
spouse shall be as provided in section
6-12-13 or fifty-four percent (54%) of the salary attached to the rank or ranks
held by the Officer for one year immediately prior to death, whichever is
greater.
   C.   Upon the death of a Public Safety Officer while in service, having at
least eight (8) but less than twenty (20) years of service, a pension of fifty-
four percent (54%) of the salary attached to the rank or ranks held by the
Officer for one year immediately prior to death shall be payable to the
survivors in the sequence provided in subsection A of this section. If death
occurs as a result of the performance of duty, the eight (8) year requirement
shall not apply and the pension to survivors shall be payable after any period
of service.
   D.   If a Public Safety Officer dies before distribution of the officer's
benefits has begun, the Officer's entire interest must be distributed within
five (5) years of his death, unless it is to be distributed in accordance with
the following rules:
      1.   If the Public Safety Officer's surviving spouse is the sole
beneficiary under subsection A, the surviving spouse's benefit shall commence
immediately, and in any event, shall begin to be distributed by December 31 of
the calendar year immediately following the calendar year in which the officer
died; or
      2.   If the Public Safety Officer's surviving spouse is not the sole
beneficiary under subsection A, the survivor's benefits shall be distributed
over the period defined in subsection A, and in no event longer than the life
of the survivor, and such distribution shall begin no later than December 31 of
the calendar year immediately following the calendar year of the officer's
death.
   E.   As of January 1, 1999, a minimum pension of six hundred dollars
($600.00) per month shall be paid to all surviving spouses, without regard to
whether the deceased Public Safety Officer was in service on or after October
1, 2000. As of October 1, 2000, the minimum pension to all surviving spouses
shall be eight hundred dollars ($800.00) per month, without regard to whether
the deceased Public Safety Officer was in service on or after October 1, 2000.
As of January 1, 2001, the minimum pension to all surviving spouses shall be
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per month, without regard to whether the
deceased Public Safety Officer was in service on or after October 1, 2000.
   F.   Beginning January 1, 2000, the pension of the surviving spouse of a
Public Safety Officer who dies on or after January 1, 1994 as a result of
sickness, accident, or injury incurred in or resulting from the performance of
an act of duty or from the cumulative effects of acts of duty shall not be less
than one hundred percent (100%) of the salary attached to the rank held by the
deceased Public Safety Officer on the last day of service, notwithstanding any
other subsections or provisions of this section.
   G.   The amount of benefit paid to a Public Safety Officer's survivors may
not exceed the maximum determined under the incidental death benefit
requirement of Section 401(a)(9)(G) of the Internal Revenue Code, and the
minimum distribution incidental benefit rule under Treasury Regulation Section
1.401(a)(9)-6, Q&A-2.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-15.5:   TEMPORARY DISABILITY:
A full-time sworn Public Safety Officer who is unable to perform his or her
regular unrestricted full duties as an employee for longer than thirty (30)
consecutive days because of an illness or injury that does not entitle them to
benefits under either the Illinois Workers' Compensation Act (820 ILCS 305/1 et
seq.) or the Illinois Workers' Occupational Diseases Act (820 ILCS 310/1 et
seq.) may apply for Temporary Disability Benefits. An Officer that is receiving
sick leave benefits from the Village shall not be eligible for any Temporary
Disability Benefits for the same period sick leave benefits are being received.
The application shall be on such forms supplied by the Board of Trustees of the
Public Safety Officers' Pension Fund ("Pension Board") and must include a
written verification from a licensed physician verifying the reason the Officer
cannot perform his/her full unrestricted duties for a period that is longer
than thirty (30) consecutive days. The burden shall be on the applicant to
establish that they will not be able to perform their full unrestricted duties
for a period that is longer than thirty (30) consecutive days. The applicant's
failure to comply with the Pension Board's reasonable request for information
to establish an Officer's inability to perform their full unrestricted duties
for a period that is longer than thirty (30) consecutive days shall be cause to
deny Temporary Disability Benefits. The Pension Board, at its expense, may, in
its sole discretion, obtain a medical examination from one or more appropriate
physicians chosen by the Pension Board in order to verify the Officer's
eligibility for Temporary Disability Benefits.
If the Pension Board finds that the Officer is eligible for Temporary
Disability Benefits, the Officer shall not receive any Temporary Disability
Benefits payable from the Public Safety Officers' Pension Fund for the first
thirty (30) consecutive days after the later of either: (1) the date their
temporary disability began; or (2) the last day they received sick leave
benefits from the Village. During this thirty (30) consecutive day period, the
Officer may receive Village provided Temporary Disability benefits if such
benefits are provided by the Village. At the expiration of this thirty (30)
consecutive day period, an Officer found to be eligible for Temporary
Disability Benefits by the Pension Board shall begin to receive an amount equal
to fifty percent (50%) of their salary attached to their rank from the Public
Safety Officers' Pension Fund. The calculation of the amount that is fifty
percent (50%) of the salary attached to the Officer's rank shall be calculated
as of the first day the Officer's temporary disability began. The amount
received shall be subject to reduction by all taxes and other payroll
deductions as may be required. An Officer eligible to receive Temporary
Disability Benefits from the Public Safety Officers' Pension Fund shall not
receive Temporary Disability Benefits for a period of time that exceeds the
earlier of: (1) the date the Officer is able to return to work; (2) a period of
time equal to one-half (½) of the Officer's creditable service as determined
pursuant to section 6-12-12; or (3) a period that does not exceed thirty (30)
months.
(Ord. 2021-2-8E, 2-8-2021)
6-12-16:   DISABILITY PENSION - LINE OF DUTY:
If a Public Safety Officer, as a result of sickness or injury incurred in or
resulting from the performance of an act of duty or from the cumulative effects
of acts of duty, is found by the Board to be physically or mentally permanently
disabled for service in the Public Safety Department as a Public Safety
Officer, so as to render his or her being placed on disability pension, the
Public Safety Officer shall be entitled to a disability pension equal to the
greater of (i) sixty five percent (65%) of the monthly salary attached to the
rank held by him or her in the Public Safety Department on the date he or she
is removed from the payroll of the Village's Public Safety Department as a
Public Safety Officer or (ii) the retirement pension that the Public Safety
Officer would be eligible to receive if he or she retired, but not including
any automatic annual increase in that retirement pension. A Public Safety
Officer shall be considered "on duty" when on any assignment approved by the
Superintendent of the Public Safety Department, even though away from the
Village, if the assignment is related to the public safety service of the
Village. If a Public Safety Officer on disability pension dies while still
disabled, the disability pension shall continue to be paid to the Officer's
survivors in the sequence provided in subsection
6-12-15A.
As of January 1, 1999, the minimum disability pension for a Public Safety
Officer shall be six hundred dollars ($600.00) per month, without regard to
whether he or she was in service on or after October 1, 2000. A Public Safety
Officer whose pension began prior to October 1, 2000 and is subject to this
increase, shall be entitled to a lump sum payment of the amount of that
increase accruing from January 1, 1999, or the date the pension began, if
later, to October 1, 2000. As of October 1, 2000, the minimum disability
pension for a Public Safety Officer shall be eight hundred dollars ($800.00)
per month, without regard to whether he or she was in service on or after
October 1, 2000. As of January 1, 2001, the minimum disability pension for a
Public Safety Officer shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per month,
without regard to whether he or she was in service on or after October 1, 2000.
Such Public Safety Officer shall also be entitled to a child's disability
benefit of twenty dollars ($20.00) a month on account of each unmarried child
less than eighteen (18) years of age and dependent upon the Public Safety
Officer for support, either the issue of the Public Safety Officer or legally
adopted by him or her. The total amount of the child's disability benefit
payable to the public safety officer, when added to his or her disability
pension, shall not exceed seventy five percent (75%) of the amount of salary
which the Public Safety Officer was receiving at the date of retirement.
Benefits payable on account of a child under this section shall not be reduced
or terminated by reason of the child's attainment of age eighteen (18) if he or
she is then dependent by reason of a physical or mental disability but shall
continue to be paid as along as such dependency continues. Individuals over the
age of eighteen (18) and adjudged to be disabled persons pursuant to Article
Xla of the Probate Act of 1975, except for persons receiving benefits under
Article III of the Illinois Public Aid Code, shall be eligible to receive
benefits under this section.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-17:   DISABILITY PENSION - NOT ON DUTY:
A Public Safety Officer who becomes disabled as a result of any cause other
than the performance of an act of duty, and who is found to be physically or
mentally disabled so as to render necessary his or her suspension or retirement
from service in the Public Safety Department, as a Public Safety Officer, shall
be entitled to a disability pension of fifty percent (50%) of the salary
attached to the Officer's rank in the public safety department on the date of
suspension of duty or retirement. If a Public Safety Officer on disability
pension dies while still disabled, the disability pension shall continue to be
paid to the Officer's survivors in the sequence provided in subsection
6-12-15A.
As of January 1, 1999, the minimum disability pension for a Public Safety
Officer shall be six hundred dollars ($600.00) per month, without regard to
whether he or she was in service on or after October 1, 2000. A Public Safety
Officer whose pension began prior to October 1, 2000 and is subject to this
increase, shall be entitled to a lump sum payment of the amount of that
increase accruing from January 1, 1999, or the date the pension began, if
later, to October 1, 2000. As of October 1, 2000, the minimum disability
pension for a Public Safety Officer shall be eight hundred dollars ($800.00)
per month, without regard to whether he or she was in service on or after
October 1, 2000. As of January 1, 2001, the minimum disability pension for a
Public Safety Officer shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per month,
without regard to whether he or she was in service on or after October 1, 2000.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-18:   OCCUPATIONAL DISEASE DISABILITY PENSION:
An active Public Safety Officer who served after April 30, 1975 and has five
(5) or more years of creditable service who is found by the Board to be unable
to perform his or her duties in the Public Safety Department by reason of heart
disease, stroke, tuberculosis, or any disease of the lungs or respiratory
tract, resulting from service as a Public Safety Officer, is entitled to an
occupational disease disability pension during any period of such disability
for which he or she has no right to receive salary.
Any Public Safety Officer who served after April 30, 1975 and has five (5) or
more years of creditable service and is unable to perform his or her duties in
the Public Safety Department by reason of a disabling cancer, which develops or
manifests itself during a period while the Public Safety Officer is in the
active service of the Public Safety Department, shall be entitled to receive an
occupational disease disability benefit during any period of such disability
for which he or she does not have a right to receive salary. In order to
receive this occupational disease disability benefit, (i) the type of cancer
involved must be a type which may be caused by exposure to heat, radiation or a
known carcinogen as defined by the International Agency for Research on Cancer,
and (ii) the cancer must, and is rebuttably presumed to, arise as a result of
service as a Public Safety Officer.
A Public Safety Officer who retired prior to the effective date of Ordinance
86-11-5B shall be entitled to apply to the Board for benefits under this
Section. Upon receipt of such an application the Board shall determine whether
the applicant meets the requirements of this Section. If the Board determines
the applicant does meet the requirements, the applicant shall receive benefits
retroactive to the date the applicant was removed from the Public Safety
Department payroll less any other benefit payments received pursuant to this
chapter.
A Public Safety Officer who enters the service after November 1, 1986 shall be
examined by one or more practicing physicians appointed by the Board. If the
examination discloses impairment of the heart, lungs or respiratory tract, or
the existence of any cancer, the Public Safety Officer shall not be entitled to
the occupational disease disability pension unless and until a subsequent
examination reveals no such impairment or cancer.
The occupational disease disability pension shall be equal to the greater of
sixty five percent (65%) of the salary attached to the rank held by the Public
Safety Officer in the Public Safety Department at the time of his or her
removal from the Village's Public Safety Department payroll, or (ii) the
retirement pension that the Public Safety Officer would be eligible to receive
if he or she retired, but not including any automatic annual increase in that
retirement pension. If a Public Safety Officer on an occupational disease
disability pension dies while still disabled, the disability pension shall
continue to be paid to the Officer's survivors in the sequence provided in
subsection
6-12-15A.
As of January 1, 1999, the minimum occupational disease disability pension for
a Public Safety Officer shall be six hundred dollars ($600.00) per month,
without regard to whether he or she was in service on or after October 1, 2000.
A Public Safety Officer whose pension began prior to October 1, 2000 and is
subject to this increase, shall be entitled to a lump sum payment of the amount
of that increase accruing from January 1, 1999, or the date the pension began,
if later, to October 1, 2000. As of October 1, 2000, the minimum occupational
disease disability pension for a Public Safety Officer shall be eight hundred
dollars ($800.00) per month, without regard to whether he or she was in service
on or after October 1, 2000. As of January 1, 2001, the minimum occupational
disease disability pension for a Public Safety Officer shall be one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) per month, without regard to whether he or she was in
service on or after October 1, 2000.
The Public Safety Officer is also entitled to a child's disability benefit of
twenty dollars ($20.00) a month for each natural or legally adopted unmarried
child less than age eighteen (18) dependent upon the Public Safety Officer for
support. The total child's disability benefit when added to the occupational
disease disability pension shall not exceed seventy five percent (75%) of the
Public Safety Officer's salary at the time of the grant of occupational disease
disability pension. The occupational disease disability pension is payable
during the period of the disability. The Public Safety Officer thereafter shall
receive such pension benefits as are provided in accordance with other
provisions of this chapter.
The child's disability benefit shall be paid during the period of disability
until the child or children attain age eighteen (18) or marry, whichever event
occurs first.
Benefits payable on account of a child under this section shall not be reduced
or terminated by reason of the child's attainment of age eighteen (18) if he or
she is then dependent by reason of a physical or mental disability but shall
continue to be paid as long as such dependency continues. Individuals over the
age of eighteen (18) and adjudged as a disabled person pursuant to Article Xla
of the Probate Act of 1975, except persons receiving benefits under Article III
of the Illinois Public Aid Code, shall be eligible to receive benefits under
this Act.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-19:   DETERMINATION OF DISABILITY:
A disability pension shall not be paid until disability has been established by
the board by examinations of the Public Safety Officer at Fund expense by three
(3) physicians selected by the board and such other evidence as the board deems
necessary. Medical examination of a Public Safety Officer receiving a
disability pension shall be made at least once each year prior to attainment of
age fifty (50) in order to verify continuance of disability. No examination
shall be required after age fifty (50).
Upon satisfactory proof to the board that a Public Safety Officer receiving a
disability pension has recovered from disability, the Board shall terminate the
disability pension. The Public Safety Officer shall report to the
Superintendent of the Public Safety Department, who shall thereupon order
reinstatement into active service, in the same rank or grade held at the date
he or she was placed on disability pension.
The Public Safety Officer shall be entitled to ten (10) days notice before any
hearing or meeting of the Board at which the question of his or her disability
is to be considered, and shall have the right to be present at any such hearing
or meeting, and to be represented by counsel; however, the Board shall not have
any obligation to provide such Public Safety Officer with counsel.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-20:   RETURN TO ACTIVE DUTY AFTER DISABILITY:
A Public Safety Officer who receives a disability pension for more than two (2)
years and who returns to active duty must remain in active service for at least
five (5) years before becoming eligible for a disability pension greater than
the pension paid for the prior disability.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-21:   REDUCTION OF DISABILITY AND SURVIVOR'S BENEFITS FOR CORRESPONDING
BENEFITS PAYABLE UNDER WORKERS' COMPENSATION AND WORKERS' OCCUPATIONAL DISEASE
ACTS AND COMPLIANCE WITH THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE:
   A.   Whenever a person is entitled to a disability or survivor's benefit
under this chapter and to benefits under the Workers' Compensation Act or the
Workers' Occupational Diseases Act for the same injury or disease, the benefits
payable under this chapter shall be reduced by an amount computed in accordance
with subsection B of this section. There shall be no reduction, however, for
any of the following: payments for medical, surgical and hospital services,
non-medical remedial care and treatment rendered in accordance with a religious
method of healing recognized by the laws of Illinois and for artificial
appliances; payments made for scheduled losses for the loss of or permanent and
complete or permanent and partial loss of the use of any bodily member or the
body taken as a whole under subdivision (d)2 or subsection (e) of Section 8 of
the Workers' Compensation Act or Section 7 of the Workers' Occupational
Diseases Act; payments made for statutorily prescribed losses under subdivision
(d)2 of Section 8 of the Workers' Compensation Act or Section 7 of the Workers'
Occupational Diseases Act; and that portion of the payments which is utilized
to pay attorneys' fees and the costs of securing the workers' compensation
benefits under either the Workers' Compensation Act or Workers' Occupational
Diseases Act.
   B.   The reduction prescribed by this section shall be computed as follows:
      1.   In the event that a person entitled to benefits under this chapter
incurs costs or attorneys' fees in order to establish his entitlement, the
reduction prescribed by this section shall itself be reduced by the amount of
such costs and attorneys' fees.
      2.   If the benefits deductible under this section are stated in a weekly
amount, the monthly amount for the purpose of this section shall be fifty two
(52) times the weekly amount, divided by twelve (12).
      3.   The death and disability benefits provided by the Fund are limited
by the incidental benefit rule set forth in Section 401(a)(9)(G) of the
Internal Revenue Code and Treasury Regulation Section 1.401-1(b)(1)(i) or any
successor regulation thereto. As a result, the total death or disability
benefits payable may not exceed twenty five percent (25%) of the cost for all
the Public Safety Officer's benefits received from the Fund.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-22:   DISABILITY PENSION OPTION:
A Public Safety Officer age fifty (50) or older who is receiving a disability
pension may by written application to the Board, elect the disability pension
option if the period during which a disability pension was paid when added to
the period of active service equals at least twenty (20) years. The election
shall permit the Officer to continue to receive a retirement pension for the
remainder of his or her life of one-half of the salary at the date of the
retirement on disability in lieu of any amounts which would have been payable
to the officer under section
6-12-16,
6-12-17 or
6-12-18.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-23:   EMERGENCY SERVICE:
In case of emergency, a disabled Public Safety Officer may be assigned to and
shall perform such duty without right to compensation as the Director of the
Department of Public Safety or the Mayor of the Village may direct.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-24:   PUBLIC SAFETY OFFICERS OVER AGE 50:
This chapter shall not be construed to require the retirement at age fifty (50)
of any police officer capable of performing his or her duties.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-25:   WAIVER:
A retired Public Safety Officer or surviving spouse may execute a written
waiver of the right to receive all or part of his or her pension. A waiver
shall take effect upon its being filed with the Board and may be revoked only
within the first thirty (30) days after it is filed with the Board.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-26:   MARRIAGE AFTER RETIREMENT:
If a Public Safety Officer marries subsequent to retirement on any pension
under this chapter, the surviving spouse and the children of such surviving
spouse shall receive no pension on the death of the Officer.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-27:   PENSIONS CEASE ON MARRIAGE:
Except as otherwise provided in subsection
6-12-15, the pensions provided in sections
6-12-15,
6-12-16,
6-12-17 and
6-12-18 shall not be paid to a surviving spouse, child or dependent parent
after marriage or remarriage of the surviving spouse, child or dependent parent
following the death of the Public Safety Officer.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-28:   PENSION TO SURVIVORS OF MALE AND FEMALE PUBLIC SAFETY OFFICERS:
All provisions of this chapter relating to pensions to a surviving spouse,
children or dependent parents of a Public Safety Officer shall apply with equal
force to the surviving spouse, minor children and dependent parents of male and
female officers without any modification whatsoever.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-29:   NON-RESIDENT PENSIONER:
A pensioner under this chapter who resides outside of the Village shall from
time to time furnish the Board such proof or affidavits as the Board may
require concerning compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-30:   ELIGIBILITY OF CHILDREN:
Dependent benefits shall be paid to each natural child of a deceased Public
Safety Officer, and to each child legally adopted before the Public Safety
Officer attains age fifty (50), until the child's attainment of age eighteen
(18), or marriage, whichever occurs first. Benefits payable on account of a
child under this chapter to children shall not be reduced or terminated by
reason of the child's attainment of age eighteen (18) if he or she is then
dependent by reason of a physical or mental disability but shall continue to be
paid as long as such dependency continues. Individuals over the age of eighteen
(18) and adjudged as a disabled person pursuant to Article Xla of the Probate
Act of 1975, except for persons receiving benefits under Article III of the
Illinois Public Aid Code, shall be eligible to receive benefits under this
chapter.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-31:   REFUND:
A Public Safety Officer separated from public safety service on or after June
1, 1998 with less than twenty (20) years of service is entitled to a refund
upon request of all contributions made by the Officer to the Fund. A Public
Safety Officer shall be one hundred percent (100%) vested in his or her
accumulated contributions at all times.
Acceptance of a refund shall bar the Public Safety Officer and his or her
dependents from any further participation in the benefits of this chapter
subject to restoration upon re-entry into service and repayment to the Fund
within two hundred seventy (270) days after the date of reentry into service of
the amount of the refund together with interest on such amount calculated at a
rate of six percent (6%) per annum or the prime commercial interest rate as
publicly announced by the largest commercial banking institution in Cook
County, Illinois, that was in effect on the date of reentry into service,
whichever is greater.
If a Public Safety Officer dies with less than ten (10) years of public safety
service, the Officer's contributions to the Fund shall, upon the written
request of his or her surviving spouse, be refunded to the spouse without
interest. lf, upon the death of a Public Safety Officer, there is no surviving
spouse, the excess of the Officer's contributions to the fund over any pension
payment shall be refunded to his or her heir’s estate. Acceptance of this
refund shall bar the Public Safety Officer's dependents or estate from any
further participation in the benefits provided under this chapter.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-32:   RE-ENTRY INTO ACTIVE SERVICE:
   A.   If a Public Safety Officer receiving pension payments re-enters active
service, pension payments shall be suspended while he or she is in service. If
the Public Safety Officer again retires or is discharged, his or her monthly
pension shall be resumed in the same amount as was paid upon first retirement
or discharge unless he or she remained in active service three (3) or more
years after re-entry in which case the monthly pension shall be based on the
salary attached to the Public Safety Officer's rank at the date of last
retirement.
   B.   If a deferred pensioner re-enters active service, and again retires or
is discharged from the Public Safety Department, his or her pension shall be
based on the salary attached to the rank held in the Public Safety Department
at the date of earlier retirement, unless the Public Safety Officer remains in
active service for three (3) or more years after re-entry, in which case the
monthly pension shall be based on the salary attached to the Public Safety
Officer's rank at the date of last retirement.
   C.   If a pensioner or deferred pensioner re-enters or is recalled to active
service and is thereafter injured, and the injury is not related to an injury
for which he or she was previously receiving a disability pension, the three
(3) year service requirement shall not apply in order for the Public Safety
Officer to qualify for the increased pension based on the rate of pay at the
time of the new injury.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-33:   MEDICAL INSURANCE BENEFITS:
   A.   Every pensioner, surviving spouse and dependent child or parent
receiving pension benefits under the provisions of this chapter shall be
entitled to receive from the Village the same hospitalization and medical
insurance coverage as the Village provides to active Public Safety Officers
until such time as the pensioner, surviving spouse or parent reaches age sixty
five (65). After a pensioner, surviving spouse or parent receiving pension
benefits under the provisions of this chapter reaches age sixty five (65), then
the pensioner, surviving spouse or parent shall become eligible to receive the
same benefits supplemental to benefits provided under the federal Medicare
Program as are provided to retired Village employees so that such pensioners,
surviving spouses and parents will receive hospitalization and medical
insurance coverage similar to that provided to active public safety officers
and their dependents, when the supplemental benefits are combined with benefits
available under the Medicare Program. The supplemental benefits to be provided
to pensioners, surviving spouses and parents, after their sixty fifth birthday,
will be the same as the benefits provided to retired Village employees pursuant
to Village of Rosemont Ordinance No. 92-2-5M "An Ordinance Establishing a
Hospitalization and Medical Insurance Benefits Program for Retired Village
Employees" as now or hereafter amended.
   B.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this section
6-12-33 or any other provision of this chapter creating the Public Safety
Officers Pension Fund of the Village of Rosemont, the provisions of this
subsection B only apply to a person who first becomes a Public Safety Officer
for the Village of Rosemont on or after October 11, 2021. A surviving spouse of
a person who first becomes a Public Safety Officer for the Village of Rosemont
on or after October 11, 2021 shall not receive any benefits under subsection A
if they were not residing within the same primary place of residence with the
deceased Public Safety Officer, deceased Pensioner or deceased Deferred
Pensioner on and/or before the date of the death. Under this subsection B, a
surviving spouse shall be considered as residing within the same primary place
of residence as the deceased Public Safety Officer, deceased Pensioner or
deceased Deferred Pensioner as of and/or prior to the date of death if the
surviving spouse was residing within the same primary place of residence with
the deceased Public Safety Officer, deceased Pensioner or deceased Deferred
Pensioner prior to the date of the death until either the Surviving Spouse,
Public Safety Officer, Pensioner or Deferred Pensioner moved to and resided at
a nursing home, hospice center, assisted living facility or home for the aged
on the date of death for the purpose of receiving care and treatment related to
a medical, mental or physical condition.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011; amd. Ord. 2021-10-11A, 10-11-2021)
6-12-34:   FINANCING:
   A.   The Corporate Authorities of the Village may annually levy a tax upon
all taxable property within the Village to meet the expenses, including pension
payments, of the Fund. If such a tax is levied it shall be in addition to any
other taxes that may be levied by the Village. The Corporate Authorities of the
Village may also contribute or transfer monies to the Fund derived from any
other available source.
   B.   The Fund shall consist of the following moneys which shall be set apart
by the treasurer or finance director of the Village:
      1.   All moneys derived from the taxes levied under subsection A of this
section;
      2.   Contributions by Public Safety Officers under subsection
6-12-35.
      3.   All moneys accumulated by the Village in the "Police Pension Fund"
established pursuant to Village of Rosemont Ordinance No. 75-10-15A;
      4.   Donations, gifts or other transfers authorized by this chapter;
      5.   All moneys contributed or transferred by the Village to the Fund.
      6.   In conformity with Section 401(a)(8) of the Internal Revenue Code,
any forfeitures of benefits by Public Safety Officers or former Public Safety
Officers who do not qualify for a pension benefit shall not be applied to
increase the benefits any Public Safety Officer would otherwise receive under
the Fund. Instead, such forfeitures shall be used to reduce Village
contributions to the Fund.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-35:   CONTRIBUTIONS BY PUBLIC SAFETY OFFICERS:
Each Public Safety Officer shall contribute to the Fund the following
percentages of salary for the periods stated: Beginning April 15, 1975 and
prior to July 1, 1975, 7½%, beginning on July 1, 1975 and prior to January 1,
1988, 8½%, beginning January 1, 1988 and prior to September 24, 2000, 9%,
beginning on September 24, 2000, 9.20%. Such sums shall be paid or deducted
monthly.
"Salary" means annual salary, including longevity attached to the Public Safety
Officer's rank, as established by the Village's appropriation ordinance and/or
salary schedule, including any compensation for over-time which is included in
the salary so established, but excluding any "over-time pay," "holiday pay,"
"bonus pay," "merit pay," or any other cash benefit not included in the salary
so established.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-36:   PICK UP OF CONTRIBUTIONS:
The Village may pick up the Public Safety Officers' contributions required by
section
6-12-35 for all salary earned by a Public Safety Officer. If contributions are
picked up, they shall be treated as employer contributions in determining tax
treatment under the United States Internal Revenue Code. The Village shall pay
these contributions from the same source of funds which is used to pay the
salaries of Public Safety Officers. The Village may pick up these contributions
by a reduction in the cash salary of the Public Safety Officer or by an offset
against a future salary increase or by a combination of a reduction in salary
and offset against a future salary increase. If contributions are picked up
they shall be considered for all purposes of this chapter as Public Safety
Officers' contributions made prior to the time that contributions were picked
up. The Public Safety Officer shall not be permitted to opt-out of the pick-up
under this section or receive the contribution amounts directly instead of
having them paid by the Village to the Fund.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-37:   RESERVES:
The Board may establish and maintain a reserve to insure the payment of all
obligations incurred under this chapter. Moneys may be accumulated in the
reserve equal to the estimated total actuarial requirements of the Fund.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-38:   BOARD CREATED:
   A.   A Board of five (5) members shall constitute a Board of Trustees to
administer the Fund to designate the beneficiaries thereof. The Board shall be
known as the "Board of Trustees of the Public Safety Officers Pension Fund of
the Village of Rosemont."
   B.   Two (2) members of the Board shall be appointed by the Mayor of the
Village. The third and fourth members of the Board shall be elected from the
active participants. The fifth member shall be elected by and from the Fund
beneficiaries.
   C.   The members of the Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund
established pursuant to Village of Rosemont Ordinance No. 75-10-14A shall serve
as members of the Board created by this section until the term for which they
were appointed or elected expires or until their successors are appointed and
qualified. Thereafter their successors shall serve for two (2) years each or
until their successors are elected or appointed and qualified except as
provided in subsection D of this chapter for the members of the Board of
Trustees to be elected from the active participants of the Fund at the election
to be held on the third Monday in April, 1987.
   D.   The election for the members of the Board to be elected from the active
participants of the Fund shall be held annually on the third Monday in April,
at such place, or places, in the Village and under the Australian ballot system
and such other regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed members of
the Board provided however that at the election to be held in April, 1987 one
member of the Board shall be elected from the active participants of the Fund
for a one year term and a second member of the Board shall be elected from the
active participants of the Fund for a two (2) year term.
   E.   The election for the member of the Board to be elected by and from the
Fund beneficiaries shall be held bi-annually on the third Monday in April, at
such place or places in the Village under the Australian ballot system and such
other regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed members of the Board.
   F.   The active Fund participants shall be entitled to vote only for the
active participant members of the Board. All beneficiaries of legal age may
vote only for the member chosen from among the beneficiaries. No person shall
be entitled to cast more than one ballot at such election. Except as provided
in subsection D with respect to one of the members of the Board elected from
active Fund participants at the election to be held in April, 1987, the term of
elected members shall be two (2) years, beginning on the second Tuesday of the
first May after the election.
   G.   Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of any elected Board
member, his or her successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a
special election, to be called by the Board and conducted in the same manner as
the regular election.
   H.   Members of the Board shall neither receive nor have any right to
receive any salary from the Fund for services performed as Trustees in that
office. The method of selection of the members of the Board shall not be
modified unless such modification is approved by a majority of active Fund
participants and a majority of Fund beneficiaries of legal age.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-39:   BOARD MEETINGS:
The Board shall hold annually regular quarterly meetings in July, October,
January and April, and special meetings as called by the president.
At the regular July meeting, the Board shall select from its members a
president, vice-president, secretary, and assistant secretary to serve for one
year and until their respective successors are elected and qualified.
The vice-president shall perform the duties of president during any vacancy in
that office, or during the president's absence from the Village, or if he or
she is by reason of illness or other causes unable to perform the duties of the
office.
The assistant secretary shall act for the secretary whenever necessary to
discharge the functions of such office.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-40:   POWERS AND DUTIES OF BOARD:
The Board shall have the powers and duties stated in sections
6-12-41 through
6-12-52 in addition to the other powers and duties provided under this
ordinance.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-41:   TO CONTROL AND MANAGE THE FUND:
To control and manage, exclusively, the Fund and all money donated, paid or
assessed for the pensioning of disabled and retired Public Safety Officers,
their surviving spouses, minor children and dependent parents. All such moneys
shall be placed by the finance director of the Village to the credit of the
Fund, subject to the order of the Board.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-42:   TO ORDER PAYMENTS AND ISSUE CERTIFICATES:
To order the payment of pensions and other benefits and to issue certificates
signed by its president and secretary to the beneficiaries stating the amount
and purpose of the payment.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-43:   TO SUBMIT ANNUAL LIST OF FUND PAYMENTS:
To submit annually to the Village's Board of Trustees at the close of the
Village's fiscal year, a list of persons entitled to payments from the Fund,
stating the amount of payments, and their purpose, as ordered by the Board. It
shall also include items of income accrued to the fund during the fiscal year.
The list shall be signed by the secretary and president of the Board, and
attested under oath. A resolution or order for the payment of money shall not
be valid unless approved by a majority of the Board members, and signed by the
president and secretary of the Board.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-44:   TO DRAW AND INVEST FUNDS AND APPOINT INVESTMENT ADVISORS:
To draw pension funds from the Village and to invest the funds as set forth in
this section and to appoint investment advisors as provided in subsection D.
All investments made by the Board shall be made with the care, skill, prudence,
and diligence that a prudent person acting in like capacity and familiar with
such matters would use in the conduct of an enterprise of like character with
like aims. Interest and any other income from the investments shall be credited
to the Fund. For the purposes of subsections
6-12-40A through
6-12-40C, the "net assets" of the fund include both the cash and invested
assets of the Fund. To the extent there is any conflict between this section
6-12-44 and any investment policy adopted by the Board of Trustees of the
Public Safety Officers Pension Fund of the Village of Rosemont, the provisions
of this section
6-12-44 shall control.
   A.   Assets of the Fund may be invested in the following:
      1.   Interest bearing direct obligations of the United States of America.
      2.   Interest bearing obligations to the extent that they are fully
guaranteed or insured as to payment of principal and interest by the United
States of America.
      3.   Interest bearing bonds, notes, debentures, or other similar
obligations of agencies of the United States of America. For the purposes of
this section, "agencies of the United States of America" include: (i) the
Federal National Mortgage Association and the Student Loan Marketing
Association; (ii) federal land banks, federal intermediate credit banks,
federal farm credit banks, and any other entity authorized to issue direct debt
obligations of the United States of America under the Farm Credit Act of 1971
or amendments to that Act; (iii) federal home loan banks and the Federal Home
Loan Mortgage Corporation; and (iv) any agency created by Act of Congress that
is authorized to issue direct debt obligations of the United States of America.
      4.   Interest bearing savings accounts or certificates of deposit, issued
by federally chartered banks or savings and loan associations, to the extent
that the deposits are insured by agencies or instrumentalities of the federal
government.
      5.   Interest bearing savings accounts or certificates of deposit, issued
by State of Illinois chartered banks or savings and loan associations, to the
extent that the deposits are insured by agencies or instrumentalities of the
federal government.
      6.   Investments in credit unions, to the extent that the investments are
insured by agencies or instrumentalities of the federal government.
      7.   Interest bearing bonds of the State of Illinois.
      8.   Pooled interest bearing accounts managed by the Illinois Public
Treasurer's Investment Pool in accordance with the Deposit of State Moneys Act
(15 ILCS 520/0.01 et seq.), interest bearing funds or pooled accounts of the
Illinois Metropolitan Investment Funds, and interest bearing funds or pooled
accounts managed, operated, and administered by banks, subsidiaries of banks,
or subsidiaries of bank holding companies in accordance with the laws of the
State of Illinois.
      9.   Interest bearing bonds or tax anticipation warrants of any county,
township, or municipal corporation of the State of Illinois.
      10.   Money market mutual funds managed by investment companies that are
registered under the federal Investment Company Act of 1940 (15 U.S.C. §§ 80a-
1 et seq.) and the Illinois Securities Law of 1953 (815 ILCS 5/1 et seq.) and
are diversified, open-ended management investment companies; provided that the
portfolio of the money market mutual fund is limited to the following:
         a.   Bonds, notes, certificates of indebtedness, treasury bills, or
other securities that are guaranteed by the full faith and credit of the United
States of America as to principal and interest;
         b.   Bonds, notes, debentures, or other similar obligations of the
United States of America or its agencies; and
         c.   Short term obligations of corporations organized in the United
States with assets exceeding $400,000,000, provided that (A) the obligations
mature no later than one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of purchase,
