(B) at the time of purchase, the obligations are rated by at least two (2)
standard national rating services at one of their three (3) highest
classifications, and (C) the obligations held by the mutual fund do not exceed
ten percent (10%) of the corporation's outstanding obligations.
      11.   General accounts of life insurance companies authorized to transact
business in Illinois.
      12.   Any combination of the following, not to exceed ten percent (10%)
of the Fund's net assets:
         a.   Separate accounts that are managed by life insurance companies
authorized to transact business in Illinois and are comprised of diversified
portfolios consisting of common or preferred stocks, bonds, or money market
instruments; and
         b.   Separate accounts that are managed by insurance companies
authorized to transact business in Illinois, and are comprised of real estate
or loans upon real estate secured by first or second mortgages.
         c.   Mutual funds that meet the following requirements:
            (1)   The mutual fund is managed by an investment company as
defined and registered under the federal Investment Company Act of 1940 and
registered under the Illinois Securities Law of 1953;
            (2)   The mutual fund has been in operation for at least five (5)
years;
            (3)   The mutual fund has total net assets of $250 million or more;
and
            (4)   The mutual fund is comprised of diversified portfolios of
common or preferred stocks, bonds, or money market instruments.
      13.   Corporate bonds managed through an investment advisor must meet all
of the following requirements:
         a.   The bonds must be rated as investment grade by one of the two (2)
largest rating services at the time of purchase.
         b.   If subsequently downgraded below investment grade, the bonds must
be liquidated from the portfolio within ninety (90) days after being downgraded
by the manager.
   B.   In addition to the items in subsection A, the Fund may invest a portion
of its net assets in the following items if the Fund has net assets of at least
$2,500,000:
      1.   Separate accounts that are managed by life insurance companies
authorized to transact business in Illinois and are comprised of diversified
portfolios consisting of common or preferred stocks, bonds, or money market
instruments.
      2.   Mutual funds that meet the following requirements:
         a.   The mutual fund is managed by an investment company as defined
and registered under the federal Investment Company Act of 1940 and registered
under the Illinois Securities Law of 1953;
         b.   The mutual fund has been in operation for at least five (5)
years;
         c.   The mutual fund has total net assets of $250 million or more; and
         d.   The mutual fund is comprised of diversified portfolios of common
or preferred stocks, bonds, or money market instruments.
   The Fund's total investment in the items authorized under subsection B shall
not exceed thirty five percent (35%) of the market value of the Fund's net
present assets.
   C.   In addition to the items in subsection A and B, if the Fund has net
assets of at least five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) and has appointed an
investment adviser under D, it may, through that investment adviser invest a
portion of its net assets in common and preferred stocks authorized for
investments of trust funds under the laws of the State of Illinois. The stocks
must meet all of the following requirements:
      1.   The common stocks are listed on a national securities exchange or
board of trade (as defined in the federal Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and
set forth in Section 3.G of the Illinois Securities Law of 1953) (15 U.S.C. §§
78a et seq. and 815 ILCS 5/3(G.) or quoted in the National Association of
Securities Dealers Automated Quotation System National Market System
(NASDAQNMS).
      2.   The securities are of a corporation created or existing under the
laws of the United States or any state, district, or territory thereof and the
corporation has been in existence for at least five (5) years.
      3.   The corporation has not been in arrears on payment of dividends on
its preferred stock during the preceding five (5) years.
      4.   The market value of stock in any one corporation does not exceed
five percent (5%) of the cash and invested assets of the Fund, and the
investments in the stock of any one corporation do not exceed five percent (5%)
of the total outstanding stock of that corporation.
      5.   The straight preferred stocks or convertible preferred stocks are
issued or guaranteed by a corporation whose common stock qualifies for
investment by the Board.
      6.   The issuer of the stocks has been subject to the requirements of
Section 12 of the federal Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (15 U.S.C. § 781) and
has been current with the filing requirements of Sections 13 and 14 of that Act
(15 U.S.C. §§ 78m and 78n) during the preceding three (3) years.
   The Fund's total investment in the items authorized under subsections B and
C shall not exceed thirty five percent (35%) of the market value of the Fund's
net present assets.
   D.   In addition to the items in subsections A and B, if the Fund has net
assets of at least ten million dollars ($10,000,000.00) and has appointed an
investment adviser under subsection D, it may, through that investment adviser,
invest a portion of its net assets in common and preferred stocks and mutual
funds.
      1.   The stocks must meet all of the following requirements:
         a.   The common stocks must be listed on a national securities
exchange or board of trade (as defined in the Federal Securities Exchange Act
of 1934 and set forth in paragraph G of Section 3 of the Illinois Securities
Law of 1953) or quoted in the National Association of Securities Dealers
Automated Quotation System National Market System.
         b.   The securities must be of a corporation in existence for at least
five (5) years.
         c.   The market value of stock in any one corporation may not exceed
five percent (5%) of the cash and invested assets of the pension fund, and the
investments in the stock of any one corporation may not exceed five percent
(5%) of the total outstanding stock of that corporation.
         d.   The straight preferred stocks or convertible preferred stocks
must be issued or guaranteed by a corporation whose common stock qualifies for
investment by the Board.
      2.   The mutual funds must meet the following requirements:
         a.   The mutual fund must be managed by an investment company
registered under the Federal Investment Company Act of 1940 and registered
under the Illinois Securities Law of 1953.
         b.   The mutual fund must have been in operation for at least five (5)
years.
         c.   The mutual fund must have total net assets of two hundred fifty
million dollars (($250,000,000.00) or more.
         d.   The mutual fund must be comprised of a diversified portfolio of
common or preferred stocks, bonds, or money market instruments.
      3.   A pension fund's total investment in the items authorized under this
subsections B and D shall not exceed fifty five percent (55%) of the market
value of the pension fund's net present assets.
   E.   The Board may appoint investment advisers. The Board shall appoint an
investment adviser before making such investments if it invests in common or
preferred stock under subsections C or D. The investment adviser shall be a
fiduciary with respect to the Fund and shall be one of the following:
      1.   An investment adviser registered under the federal Investment
Advisers Act of 1940 (15 U.S.C. §§ 80b-1 et seq.) and the Illinois Securities
Law of 1953;
      2.   A bank or trust company authorized to conduct a trust business in
Illinois;
      3.   A life insurance company authorized to transact business in
Illinois; or
      4.   An investment company as defined and registered under the federal
Investment Company Act of 1940 (15 U.S.C. §§ 80A-1 et seq.) and registered
under the Illinois Securities Law of 1953.
   F.   For purposes of this Section 44 an investment adviser shall be a person
who:
      1.   Has the power to manage, acquire, or dispose of any asset of the
retirement system or pension fund;
      2.   Has acknowledged in writing that he or she is a fiduciary with
respect to the pension fund or retirement system; and
      3.   Is at least one of the following: (i) registered as an investment
adviser under the federal Investment Advisers Act of 1940 (15 U.S.C. §§ 80b-1,
et seq.); (ii) registered as an investment adviser under the Illinois
Securities Law of 1953; (iii) a bank, as defined in the Investment Advisers Act
of 1940; or (iv) an insurance company authorized to transact business in this
State.
   G.   All investment advice and services provided by an investment adviser
appointed under this section shall be rendered pursuant to a written contract
between the investment adviser and the Board, and in accordance with the
Board's investment policy. The contract shall include all of the following:
      1.   Acknowledgment in writing by the investment adviser that he or she
is a fiduciary with respect to the Fund;
      2.   The Board's investment policy;
      3.   Full disclosure of direct and indirect fees, commissions, penalties,
and any other compensation that may be received by the investment adviser,
including reimbursement for expenses; and
      4.   A requirement that the investment adviser submit periodic written
reports, on at least a quarterly basis, for the Board's review at its regularly
scheduled meetings. All returns on investment shall be reported as net returns
after payment of all fees, commissions, and any other compensation.
   The Board shall file copies of all contracts which it enters into with
investment advisors with the Village Clerk and with the Village Finance
Director.
   H.   Investment services provided by a person other than an investment
adviser appointed under this Section, including, but not limited to, services
provided by the kinds of persons listed in subsections E1 through E4, shall be
rendered only after full written disclosure of direct and indirect fees,
commissions, penalties, and any other compensation that shall or may be
received by the person rendering those services.
   I.   The Board shall retain records of investment transactions and shall
make them available for inspection upon request by the Village Finance Director
and any auditor retained by the Village.
   J.   The Board shall adopt a written investment policy and file copies of
that policy with the Village Clerk and the Village's Finance Director within
thirty (30) days after its adoption. Whenever the Board changes its investment
policy, it shall file a copy of the new policy with the Village Clerk and the
Village's Finance Director within thirty (30) days.
   K.   The following shall apply to the holding and custody of investments
made with assets of the Fund:
      1.   The Board may register the investments of the Fund in the name of
the Fund, in the nominee name of a bank or trust company authorized to conduct
a trust business in Illinois, or in the nominee name of the Illinois Public
Treasurer's Investment Pool. The assets of the Fund and ownership of its
investments shall be protected through third-party custodial safekeeping.
      2.   The Board may appoint as custodian of the investments of the Fund
the Village's Director of Finance, a bank or trust company authorized to
conduct a trust business in Illinois, or the Illinois Public Treasurer's
Investment Pool.
      3.   A dealer may not maintain possession of or control over securities
of the Fund subject to the provisions of this section unless it is registered
as a broker-dealer with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission and is a
member in good standing of the National Association of Securities Dealers, and
(i) with respect to securities that are not issued only in book-entry form, (A)
all such securities of the Fund are either held in safekeeping in a place
reasonably free from risk of destruction or held in custody by a securities
depository that is a "clearing agency" registered with the U.S. Securities and
Exchange Commission, (B) the dealer is a member of the Securities Investor
Protection Corporation, (C) the dealer sends to the Fund, no less frequently
than each calendar quarter, an itemized statement showing the moneys and
securities in the custody or possession of the dealer at the end of such
period, and (D) an independent certified public account conducts an audit, no
less frequently than each calendar year, that reviews the dealer's internal
accounting controls and procedures for safeguarding securities; and (ii) with
respect to securities that are issued only in book-entry form, (A) all such
securities of the Fund are held either in a securities depository that is a
"clearing agency" registered with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
or in a bank that is a member of the Federal Reserve System, (B) the dealer
records the ownership interest of the Fund in such securities on the dealer's
books and records, (C) the dealer is a member of the Securities Investor
Protection Corporation, (D) the dealer sends to the Fund, no less frequently
than each calendar quarter, an itemized statement showing the moneys and
securities in the custody or possession of the dealer at the end of such
period, and (E) the dealer's financial statement (which shall contain among
other things a statement of the dealer's net capital and its required net
capital computed in accordance with Rule 15c3-1 under the Securities Exchange
Act of 1934) (15 U.S.C. §§ 78a et seq.) is audited annually by an independent
certified public accountant, and the dealer's most recent audited financial
statement is furnished to the Board.
      4.   No broker-dealer serving as a custodian for the Fund as provided in
this section shall be authorized to serve as an investment advisor for the Fund
to the extent that the investment advisor acquires or disposes of any asset of
the Fund. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in no event may a broker or dealer
that is a natural person maintain possession of or control over securities or
other assets of the Fund subject to the provisions of this Section. In
maintaining securities of the Fund subject to the provisions of this Section,
each dealer must maintain those securities in conformity with the provisions of
Rule 15c3-3(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (Physical Possession or
Control of Securities).
      5.   A bank or trust company authorized to conduct a trust business in
Illinois shall register, deposit, or hold investments of the Fund for
safekeeping, all in accordance with the obligations and subject to the
limitations of the Securities in Fiduciary Accounts Act (760 ILCS 75/0.01 et
seq.).
      6.   A bank or savings and loan association shall not receive investment
funds from the Fund unless it has complied with the requirements established
under section 6 of the Public Funds Investment. Act (30 ILCS 235/6). The
limitations set forth in that section 6 are applicable only at the time of
investment and do not require the liquidation of any investment at any time.
   L.   The investment limitations set forth in this section are applicable
only at the time of investment and do not require the liquidation of any
investment at any time. However, no additional funds may be invested in any
investment item while the market value of the Fund's investments in that item
meets or exceeds the applicable limitation.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011; amd. Ord. 2013-4-10E, - -2013)
6-12-45:   TO SUBPOENA WITNESSES:
To compel witnesses to attend and testify before it upon all matters connected
with the administration of this chapter, in the manner provided by law for the
taking of testimony in the circuit courts of this State. The president, or any
board member, may administer oaths to witnesses.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-46:   TO MAKE RULES:
To make necessary rules and regulations in conformity with the provisions of
this chapter, and to publish and transmit copies from time to time to all
pensioners and contributors.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-47:   TO ACCEPT DONATIONS:
To accept by gift, grant, transfer, or bequest, any money, real estate, or
personal property. Such money and the proceeds from the sale of or the income
from such real estate or personal property shall be paid into the Fund.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-48:   TO APPOINT CLERK:
To appoint a clerk and define his duties. No persons drawing a pension under
this chapter shall be employed by the board.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-49:   TO PAY EXPENSES:
To provide for the payment from the Fund of all necessary expenses, including
clerk hire, printing, witness and attorneys' fees.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-50:   TO KEEP RECORDS:
To keep a record of all its meetings and proceedings.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-51:   TO ENFORCE CONTRIBUTIONS:
To assess each Public Safety Officer the contributions required under section
6-12-35. The contributions deducted from salaries, together with all interest
accruing thereon, shall be placed by the finance director of the Village as ex
officio treasurer of the Board, to the credit of the pension fund, subject to
the order of the board.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-52:   ADDITIONAL POWERS:
To do any and all other acts required to implement or comply with the
provisions of this chapter or which are necessary for the prudent
administration of the Fund.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-53:   AUDIT:
An audit by a certified public accountant shall be made annually of all moneys
received by and paid out on behalf of the Fund during each Village fiscal year
and of the amount of funds on hand and owing to the Fund at the end of each
fiscal year.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-54:   PAYMENT OF BENEFITS - FUNDS INSUFFICIENT:
Any Public Safety Officer and any eligible surviving spouse, child or children,
or dependent parent of the officer to whom the board has ordered benefits to be
paid, shall receive a yearly benefit payable in twelve (12) equal monthly
installments, which shall be the aggregate amount to which they are entitled.
If at any time there is not sufficient money in the Fund to pay the benefits
under this chapter, the Village's Board of Trustees shall make every legal
effort to replenish the Fund so that all beneficiaries may receive the amounts
to which they are entitled. If, thereafter, there still remain insufficient
funds, the Village shall be obligated to make any required benefit payments. In
the event of a full or partial termination of, or a complete discontinuance of
Village contributions to the Fund, the accrued benefits of the affected Public
Safety Officers under the Fund shall be one hundred percent (100%) vested and
nonforfeitable to the extent funded and to the extent required by the Internal
Revenue Code.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-55:   REPORT BY BOARD:
The Board shall report annually on or before July 1 of each year to the Board
of Trustees of the Village on the condition of the Fund. The plan year shall be
the twelve month period beginning on July 1 and ending on June 30.
The Board shall certify:
   A.   The assets in its custody at such time;
   B.   The estimated receipts during the next succeeding calendar year from
deductions from the salaries of the public safety officers, and from all other
sources; and
   C.   The estimated amount required during said calendar year to pay all
pensions and other obligations provided in this ordinance.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-56:   OVERPAYMENT - DEDUCTION:
The amount of any overpayment due to fraud, misrepresentation or error, of any
pension or benefit granted under this Article may be deducted from future
payments to the recipient of such pension or benefit.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-57:   FELONY CONVICTION:
None of the benefits provided in this chapter shall be paid to any person who
is convicted of any felony relating to or arising out of or in connection with
his or her service as a Public Safety Officer.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-58:   CONTRACTUAL RIGHT:
The right of participants in the Fund to receive the benefits as provided in
this chapter and to have the Fund administered as provided in sections
6-12-6,
6-12-11 and
6-12-38 of this chapter, shall be a contractual right which shall become vested
upon a participant making the contributions provided for in section
6-12-35 of this chapter provided that the provisions of sections
6-12-6,
6-12-11 and
6-12-38 may be modified if the modification is approved by a majority of the
active Fund participants and a majority of Fund beneficiaries of legal age.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-59:   REPEAL OF PRIOR PROVISIONS:
Any chapter which is inconsistent with the terms and provisions of this chapter
shall be and hereby is repealed to the extent of such inconsistency.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-60:   SEPARABILITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter or the
application thereof to any person or circumstance is, for any reason, held
invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such
portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision and such
holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter
or the application of such portion to other persons or circumstances.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-61:   EXERCISE OF HOME RULE POWERS:
This ordinance and each of its terms shall be the effective legislative act of
a home rule municipality without regard to whether such ordinance should (a)
contain terms contrary to the provisions of current or subsequent non-
preemptive state law, or (b) legislate in a manner or regarding a matter not
delegated to municipalities by state law. It is the intent of the corporate
authorities of the Village of Rosemont that to the extent that the terms of
this Ordinance should be inconsistent with any non-preemptive state law, that
this Ordinance shall supersede state law in that regard within its
jurisdiction.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-62:   MILITARY SERVICE PROVISIONS:
   A.   Effective December 12, 1994, notwithstanding any other provision of
this chapter, contributions, benefits and creditable service with respect to
qualified military service shall be subject to Section 414(u) of the Internal
revenue Code and the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act
of 1994 ("USERRA").
   B.   Beginning January 1, 2009, to the extent required by Section 414(u)(12)
of the Internal Revenue Code, an individual receiving differential wage
payments (as defined under Section 3401(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code)
from the Village shall be treated as employed by the Village, and the
differential wage payment shall be treated as compensation for purposes of
applying the limits on annual additions under Section 415(c) of the Internal
Revenue Code. This provision shall be applied to all similarly situated
individuals in a reasonably equivalent manner.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-63:   IRS COMPLIANCE PROVISIONS:
   A.   The provisions in this section are to satisfy certain Internal Revenue
Code requirements for a qualified governmental defined benefit plan. They
should be read in conjunction with the remainder of the Fund terms, but shall
govern with respect to the topics covered by this Section.
   B.   Limits On Salary Taken Into Account:
      1.   Effective with respect to plan years beginning on and after July 1,
1996, and before July 1, 2002, the annual salary used to calculate the pension
of a Public Safety Officer which exceeds one hundred fifty thousand dollars
($150,000.00) (as adjusted for cost-of-living increases under Section 401(a)
(17)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code) shall be disregarded for purposes of
computing Public Safety Officer and Village contributions to or benefits due
from the Fund.
      2.   Effective with respect to plan years beginning on and after July 1,
2002, the salary used to calculate the pension of a Public Safety Officer which
exceeds $200,000 (as adjusted for cost-of-living increases in accordance with
Section 401(a)(17)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code, i.e. $245,000 for 2009,
2010, and 2011) may not be taken into account in determining benefits or
contributions due for any plan year. The salary used to calculate the pension
of a Public Safety Officer means such salary during the calendar year or such
other consecutive twelve (12) month period over which salary is otherwise
determined under the Fund (the determination period). The cost-of-living
adjustment in effect for a calendar year applies to such salary for the
determination period that begins with or within such calendar year. If the
determination period consists of fewer than twelve (12) months, the limit is an
amount equal to the otherwise applicable limit multiplied by a fraction, the
numerator of which is the number of months in the short determination period,
and the denominator of which is twelve (12). If the salary for any prior
determination period is taken into account in determining an officer's
contributions or benefits for the current plan year, such salary for such prior
determination period is subject to the applicable annual limit in effect for
that prior period.
      3.   As used in this subsection B3, the term "eligible member" means a
person who first became a participant in this Fund prior to the plan year
beginning after December 31, 1995. Pursuant to Section 13212(d)(3)(A) of OBRA
‘93, and the Treasury Regulations issued under that Section, eligible members
are not subject to the limits of Section 401(a)(17) of the Internal Revenue
Code and this Section, and the annual limit shall not apply to the extent that
the application of the limit would reduce the amount of salary that is allowed
to be taken into account under the Fund below the amount that was allowed to be
taken into account under the Fund as in effect on July 1, 1993. The limits
referenced in subsections B1 and B2 above apply only to years beginning after
December 31, 1995, and only to individuals who first become public safety
officers in plan years beginning on and after July 1, 1996.
   C.   Effective as of July 1, 1989, the Board shall determine the amount of
any benefit that is determined on the basis of actuarial assumptions using
assumptions adopted by the Board by ordinance; such benefits shall not be
subject to employer discretion.
   D.   For purposes of compliance with Section 401(a)(31) of the Internal
Revenue Code, this Section applies notwithstanding any contrary provision or
law that would otherwise limit a distributee's election to make a rollover. A
distributee may elect, at the time and in the manner prescribed by the Board,
to have any portion of an eligible rollover distribution paid directly to an
eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee in a direct rollover.
      1.   "Eligible rollover distribution" means any distribution of all or
any portion of the balance to the credit of the distributee, except that an
eligible rollover distribution does not include: any distribution that is one
of a series of substantially equal periodic payments (not less frequently than
annually) made for the life (or the life expectancy) of the distributee or the
joint lives (or joint life expectancies) of the distributee and the
distributee's designated beneficiary, or for a specified period of ten (10)
years or more; any distribution to the extent such distribution is required
under Section 401(a)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code; the portion of any
distribution that is not includible in gross income; and any other distribution
which the Internal Revenue Service does not consider eligible for rollover
treatment, such as certain corrective distributions necessary to comply with
the provisions of Section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code or any distribution
that is reasonably expected to total less than two hundred dollars ($200.00)
during the year.
      2.   Effective January 1, 2002, a portion of a distribution will not fail
to be an eligible rollover distribution merely because the portion consists of
after-tax employee contributions that are not includible in gross income.
However, such portion may be transferred only (i) to an individual retirement
account or annuity described in Section 408(a) or (b) of the Internal Revenue
Code or to a qualified defined contribution plan described in Section 401(a) of
the Internal Revenue Code that agrees to separately account for amounts so
transferred (and earnings thereon), including separately accounting for the
portion of the distribution that is includible in gross income and the portion
of the distribution list that is not so includible; (ii) on or after January 1,
2007, to a qualified defined benefit plan described in Section 401(a) of the
Internal Revenue Code or to an annuity contract described in Section 403(b) of
the Internal Revenue Code, that agrees to separately account for amounts so
transferred (and earnings thereon), including separately accounting for the
portion of the distribution that is includible in gross income and the portion
of the distribution that is not so includible; or (iii) on or after January 1,
2008, to a Roth IRA described in Section 408A of the Internal Revenue Code.
      3.   Effective January 1, 2002, the definition of eligible rollover
distribution also includes a distribution to a surviving spouse, or to a spouse
or former spouse who is an alternate payee under a qualified domestic relations
order, as defined in Section 414(p) of the Internal Revenue Code.
      4.   "Eligible retirement plan" means any of the following that accepts
the distributee's eligible rollover distribution:
         a.   An individual retirement account described in Section 408(a) of
the Internal Revenue Code;
         b.   An individual retirement annuity described in Section 408(b) of
the Internal Revenue Code;
         c.   An annuity plan described in Section 403(a) of the Internal
Revenue Code;
         d.   A qualified trust described in Section 401(a) of the Internal
Revenue Code that agrees to separately account for amounts transferred into
that plan from the Fund; or
         e.   Effective January 1, 2002, an annuity contract described in
Section 403(b) of the Internal Revenue Code that agrees to separately account
for amounts transferred into that plan from the Fund; or
         f.   Effective January 1, 2002, a plan eligible under Section 457(b)
of the Internal Revenue Code that is maintained by a state, political
subdivision of a state, or any agency or instrumentality of a state or a
political subdivision of a state that agrees to separately account for amounts
transferred into that plan from the Fund; or
         g.   Effective January 1, 2008, a Roth IRA described in Section 408A
of the Internal Revenue Code.
      5.   "Distributee" means a Public Safety Officer or former Public Safety
Officer. It also includes the Officer's or former Officer's surviving spouse
and the Officer's or former Officer's spouse or former spouse who is the
alternate payee under a qualified domestic relations order, as defined in
Section 414(p) of the Internal Revenue Code. Effective January 1, 2010, a
distributee further includes a nonspouse beneficiary who is a designated
beneficiary as defined by Section 401(a)(9)(E) of the Internal Revenue Code.
However, a nonspouse beneficiary may only make a direct rollover to an
individual retirement account or individual retirement annuity established for
the purpose of receiving the distribution, and the account or annuity will be
treated as an "inherited" individual retirement account or annuity.
      6.   "Direct rollover" means a payment by the plan to the eligible
retirement plan specified by the distributee.
   E.   Effective as of July 1, 1989, the board may not engage in a transaction
prohibited by Section 503(b) of the Internal Revenue Code.
   F.   The Fund does not accept rollover contributions.
   G.   The Fund does not allow service purchases, except as provided under
USERRA.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-64:   LIMITATIONS ON CONTRIBUTIONS AND BENEFITS:
   A.   General Rules: Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter to
the contrary, the Public Safety Officers' contributions paid to and pensions
paid from the Fund shall be limited to such extent as may be necessary to
conform to the requirements of Section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code for a
qualified pension plan. Notwithstanding any other law, the limitation with
respect to a person who first became a Public Safety Officer under the Fund
prior to January 1, 1990 shall not be less than the accrued benefit of the
Public Safety Officer under the Fund (determined without regard to any
amendment of this chapter adopted after October 14, 1987). The limitation year
is the Village's fiscal year.
   B.   Basic 415(b) Limitation:
      1.   Before January 1, 1995, a Public Safety Officer may not receive an
annual benefit that exceeds the limits specified in section 415(b) of the
Internal Revenue Code, subject to the applicable adjustments in that section.
On and after January 1, 1995, a member may not receive an annual benefit that
exceeds the dollar amount specified in section 415(b)(1)(A) of the Internal
Revenue Code, subject to the applicable adjustments in section 415(b) of the
Internal Revenue Code and subject to any additional limits that may be
specified in the Fund. In no event shall a Public Safety Officer's benefit
payable under the Fund in any limitation year be greater than the limit
applicable at the annuity starting date, as increased in subsequent years
pursuant to section 415(d) of the Internal Revenue Code and the regulations
thereunder.
      2.   For purposes of section 415(b) of the Internal Revenue Code, the
"annual benefit" means a benefit payable annually in the form of a straight
life annuity (with no ancillary benefits) without regard to the benefit
attributable to after-tax employee contributions (except pursuant to section
415(n) of the Internal Revenue Code) and to rollover contributions (as defined
in section 415(b)(2)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code). The "benefit
attributable" shall be determined in accordance with Treasury Regulations.
   C.   Adjustments To Basic 415(b) Limitation For Form Of Benefit: If the
benefit under the Fund is other than the form specified in subsection B2 above,
then the benefit shall be adjusted so that it is the equivalent of the annual
benefit, using factors prescribed in Treasury Regulations.
      1.   If the form of benefit without regard to the automatic benefit
increase feature is not a straight life annuity or a qualified joint and
survivor annuity, then the preceding sentence is applied by either reducing the
Section 415(b) of the Internal Revenue Code limit applicable at the annuity
starting date or adjusting the form of benefit to an actuarially equivalent
amount (determined using the assumptions specified in Treasury Regulation
Section 1.415(b)-1(c)(2)(ii)) that takes into account the additional benefits
under the form of benefit as follows:
      2.   For a benefit paid in a form to which Section 417(e)(3) of the
Internal Revenue Code does not apply (i.e., a monthly benefit), the actuarially
equivalent straight life annuity benefit that is the greater of:
         a.   The annual amount of the straight life annuity (if any) payable
to the member under the plan commencing at the same annuity starting date as
the form of benefit to the member, or
         b.   The annual amount of the straight life annuity commencing at the
same annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the
form of benefit payable to the member, computed using a five percent (5%)
interest assumption (or the applicable statutory interest assumption) and (i)
for years prior to January 1, 2009, the applicable mortality tables described
in Treasury Regulation Section 1.417(e)-1(d)(2) (Revenue Ruling 2001-62 or any
subsequent Revenue Ruling modifying the applicable provisions of Revenue
Rulings 2001-62), and (ii) for years after December 31, 2008, the applicable
mortality tables described in Section 417(e)(3)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code
(Notice 2008-85 or any subsequent Internal Revenue Service guidance
implementing Section 417(e)(3)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code); or
      3.   For a benefit paid in a form to which Section 417(e)(3) of the
Internal Revenue Code applies (i.e., a lump sum benefit), the actuarially
equivalent straight life annuity benefit that is the greatest of:
         a.   The annual amount of the straight life annuity commencing at the
annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the
particular form of benefit payable, computed using the interest rate and
mortality table, or tabular factor, specified in the Fund for actuarial
experience;
         b.   The annual amount of the straight life annuity commencing at the
annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the
particular form of benefit payable, computed using a 5.5% interest assumption
(or the applicable statutory interest assumption) and (i) for years prior to
January 1, 2009, the applicable mortality tables for the distribution under
Treasury Regulation Section 1.417(e)-1(d)(2) (the mortality table specified in
Revenue Ruling 2001-62 or any subsequent Revenue Ruling modifying the
applicable provisions of Revenue Ruling 2001-62), and (ii) for years after
December 31, 2008, the applicable mortality tables described in Section 417(e)
(3)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code (Notice 2008-85 or any subsequent Internal
Revenue Service guidance implementing Section 417(e)(3)(B) of the Internal
Revenue Code); or
         c.   The annual amount of the straight life annuity commencing at the
annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the
particular form of benefit payable (computed using the applicable interest rate
for the distribution under Treasury Regulation Section 1.417(e)-1(d)(3) (the
thirty (30) year Treasury rate (prior to January 1 2007, using the rate in
effect for the month prior to retirement, and on and after January 1, 2007,
using the rate in effect for the first day of the plan year with a one-year
stabilization period)) and (i) for years prior to January 1, 2009, the
applicable mortality tables for the distribution under Treasury Regulation
Section 1.417(e)-1(d)(2) (the mortality table specified in Revenue Ruling 2001-
62 or any subsequent Revenue Ruling modifying the applicable provisions of
Revenue Ruling 2001-62), and (ii) for years after December 31, 2008, the
applicable mortality tables described in Section 417(e)(3)(B) of the Internal
Revenue Code (Notice 2008-85 or any subsequent Internal Revenue Service
guidance implementing Section 417(e)(3)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code),
divided by 1.05.
      4.   The actuary may adjust the 415(b) limit at the annuity starting date
in accordance with the above subsections C2 and C3.
   D.   Benefits For Which No Adjustment Of The 415(b) Limit Is Required: For
purposes of this Section, the following benefits shall not be taken into
account in adjusting these limits:
      1.   Any ancillary benefit which is not directly related to retirement
income benefits;
      2.   That portion of any joint and survivor annuity that constitutes a
qualified joint and survivor annuity;
      3.   Any other benefit not required under Section 415(b)(2) of the
Internal Revenue Code and Treasury Regulations thereunder to be taken into
account for purposes of the limitation of Section 415(b)(1) of the Internal
Revenue Code.
   E.   Other Adjustments In 415(b) Limitation:
      1.   In the event the public safety officer's retirement benefits become
payable before age sixty-two (62), the limit prescribed by this Section shall
be reduced in accordance with Treasury Regulations pursuant to the provisions
of Section 415(b) of the Internal Revenue Code, so that such limit (as so
reduced) equals an annual straight life benefit (when such retirement income
benefit begins) which is equivalent to a one hundred sixty thousand dollar
($160,000.00) (as adjusted) annual benefit beginning at age sixty-two (62).
      2.   In the event the public safety officer's benefit is based on at
least fifteen (15) years of service as a full-time employee of any police or
fire department or on fifteen (15) years of military service, the adjustments
provided for in E1 above shall not apply.
      3.   The reductions provided for in E1 above shall not be applicable to
pre-retirement disability benefits or pre-retirement death benefits.
   F.   Less Than Ten (10) Years Of Participation Adjustment For 415(b)
Limitations: The maximum retirement benefits payable to any public safety
officer who has completed less than ten (10) years of participation shall be
the amount determined under subsection C multiplied by a fraction, the
numerator of which is the number of the member's years of participation and the
denominator of which is ten (10). The reduction provided by this subsection
cannot reduce the maximum benefit below ten percent (10%). The reduction
provided for in this subsection shall not be applicable to pre-retirement
disability benefits or pre-retirement death benefits.
   G.   Ten Thousand Dollar ($10,000) Limit: Notwithstanding the foregoing, the
retirement benefit payable with respect to a Public Safety Officer shall be
deemed not to exceed the 415 limit if the benefits payable, with respect to
such member under this plan and under all other qualified defined benefit
pension plans to which the Village contributes, do not exceed ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00) for the applicable limitation year and for any prior
limitation year and the Village has not any time maintained a qualified defined
contribution plan in which the officer participated.
   H.   Effect of COLA without a Lump Sum Component on 415(b) Testing:
Effective on and after January 1, 2008, for purposes of applying the limits
under Section 415(b) of the Internal Revenue Code (the "Limit") to a Public
Safety Officer with no lump sum benefit, the following will apply:
      1.   A Public Safety Officer’s applicable Limit will be applied to the
Officer's annual benefit in the Officer's first limitation year without regard
to any cost of living increases under section
6-12-14;
      2.   To the extent that the Public Safety Officer's annual benefit equals
or exceeds the Limit, the Officer's benefit will be limited by the Limit; and
      3.   Thereafter, in any subsequent limitation year, a Public Safety
Officer’s annual benefit, including any cost of living increases under section
6-12-14, shall be tested under the then applicable benefit Limit including any
adjustment to the Section 415(b)(1)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code dollar
limit under Section 415(d) of the Internal Revenue Code, and the regulations
thereunder.
   I.   Section 415(c) Limitations On Contributions And Other Additions: After-
tax member contributions or other annual additions with respect to a Public
Safety Officer may not exceed the lesser of forty thousand dollars ($40,000.00)
(as adjusted pursuant to Section 415(d) of the Internal Revenue Code) or one
hundred percent (100%) of the Officer's compensation. Annual additions are
defined to mean the sum (for any year) of Village contributions to a defined
contribution plan, Officer contributions (determined without regard to picked-
up employee contributions that are paid to a defined benefit plan), and
forfeitures credited to a Officer's individual account in a defined
contribution plan. "Compensation" for purposes of this Section, subject to
annual limits under Section 401(a)(17) of the Internal Revenue Code, shall be
as defined under Treasury Regulation Section 1.415(c)-2(d)(4) and shall exclude
officer contributions that are picked up by the employer under Internal Revenue
Code Section 414(h). Amounts described in Treasury Regulation Section 1.415(c)-
2(e)(3)(iii) are included in compensation if paid within the limitations
prescribed under Treasury Regulation Section 1.415(c)-2(e)(3)(i)(A) and (B).
   J.   Repayments Of Cashouts: Any repayment of contributions (including
interest thereon) to the Fund with respect to an amount previously refunded
upon a forfeiture of service credit under the Fund or another governmental plan
maintained by the Village shall not be taken into account for purposes of
Section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code, in accordance with applicable
Treasury Regulations.
   K.   Participation In Other Qualified Plans: Aggregation Of Limits:
      1.   The 415(b) limit with respect to any Public Safety Officer who at
any time has been a member in any other defined benefit plan as defined in
Section 414(j) of the Internal Revenue Code maintained by the Village shall
apply as if the total benefits payable under all such defined benefit plans in
which the member has been a officer were payable from one (1) plan.
      2.   The 415(c) limit with respect to any public safety officer who at
any time has been a member in any defined contribution plan as defined in
Section 414(i) of the Internal Revenue Code maintained by the Village shall
apply as if the total annual additions under all such defined contribution
plans in which the officer has been a member were payable from one (1) plan.
   L.   Reduction Of Benefits Priority: Reduction of benefits and/or
contributions to all plans, where required, shall be accomplished by first
reducing the public safety officer's benefit under any defined benefit plans in
which the officer participated, such reduction to be made first with respect to
the plan in which the officer most recently accrued benefits and thereafter in
such priority as shall be determined by the plan and the plan administrator of
such other plans, and next, by reducing or allocating excess forfeitures for
defined contribution plans in which the officer participated, such reduction to
be made first with respect to the plan in which the officer most recently
accrued benefits and thereafter in such priority as shall be established by the
plan and the plan administrator for such other plans provided, however, that
necessary reductions may be made in a different manner and priority pursuant to
the agreement of the plan and the plan administrator of all other plans
covering such officer.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
6-12-65: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This chapter shall be in full force and effect upon its passage and approval
and shall subsequently be published in pamphlet form as provided by law.
(Ord. 2011-12-14F, 12-14-2011)
TITLE 7: MORALS AND CONDUCT
CHAPTER 1: CITATION VIOLATIONS
Section
7-1-1:   Violators Of Business, Dog, Vehicle And Traffic Regulations
7-1-2:   Contents Of Citations
7-1-3:   Procedure For Compromise Payment
7-1-4:   Prima Facie Proof
7-1-5:   Schedule Of Compromise Payments
7-1-1: VIOLATORS OF BUSINESS, DOG, VEHICLE AND TRAFFIC REGULATIONS:
A public safety officer is authorized to arrest a person without a warrant
because of a violation of this Code or an ordinance in respect of any of the
following subjects:
   A.   Prohibiting the parking of a vehicle in a designated area.
   B.   Restricting the length of time a vehicle may be parked.
   C.   Requiring the purchase and display of a vehicle sticker.
   D.   Regulating and licensing dogs.
   E.   Regulating and licensing businesses.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-1-2: CONTENTS OF CITATIONS:
A public safety officer may, in lieu of the filing of a complaint in court, in
the first instance, issue to the alleged violator a citation:
   A.   Advising the person that he has violated this Code or a specified
ordinance;
   B.   Requesting him to make payment in an amount applicable to such alleged
violation as set forth in section 7-1-5 of this chapter as settlement of the
claim;
   C.   Informing him that, upon failure to so settle, a complaint will be
filed in the appropriate jurisdiction charging him with such violation.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-1-3: PROCEDURE FOR COMPROMISE PAYMENT:
   A.   Pursuant to the citation under this chapter, the person so accused of
such violation may settle and compromise the violation claim in respect of this
Code or such ordinance violation by paying to the Village the applicable amount
as shown in the schedule set forth in section 7-1-5 of this chapter, within a
period to be specified in the citation, not more than seven (7) days of the
time the alleged offense was committed.
   B.   The payment shall be made in accordance with the instructions contained
in the citation at the Office of the Village Clerk who shall issue a receipt
for the money so received and promptly remit such amount to the Finance Officer
to be credited to the proper Village fund.
   C.   In the event that the person to whom the citation is issued fails to
settle and pay the violation claim within the prescribed time or within a
period of time specified in a final notice (if one is served upon him), then
the public safety officer is authorized to cause a notice to appear to be
served upon the alleged violator and is authorized to file a complaint and to
prosecute the same in the Circuit Court of Cook County.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-1-4: PRIMA FACIE PROOF:
The fact that an automobile or motor vehicle which is illegally operated or
parked is registered with the Secretary of State in the name of the alleged
violator, or in the alternative, in the event that a vehicle sticker issued by
a municipality has been issued in the name of and to the alleged violator,
shall be considered prima facie proof that the alleged violator was in control
of or was the operator of the automobile or motor vehicle at the time of the
alleged violation.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-1-5: SCHEDULE OF COMPROMISE PAYMENTS:
The violation claim described in the citation under this chapter so to be
issued pursuant to the terms of this Code or this chapter may be settled,
compromised and paid in the respective amounts set forth in the following
schedule:
   A.   In the event that the payment is made prior to the mailing by the
Village or by the public safety officer of a final notice, the following
amounts shall be accepted as settlement:
 
Improper parking    $25.00
No vehicle sticker  15.00
No dog license      15.00
No business license 75.00
 
   B.   In the event that payment has not been made prior to the mailing of the
final notice and, in fact, final notice has been mailed, the following amounts
shall be accepted as settlement:
 
Improper parking    $35.00
No vehicle sticker  30.00
No dog license      30.00
No business license 75.00
 
   C.   In the event that payment is not made within the time prescribed in the
final notice, and notice to appeal has been served and a complaint filed,
payment of any fine and costs shall be in such amounts as may be determined and
established by the Circuit Court of Cook County or the hearing officer.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
CHAPTER 2: OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY AND PEACE
Section
7-2-1:   Injury To Persons, Damage To Property Upon Public Highway
7-2-2:   Assault, Battery, And Fighting
7-2-3:   Barbed Wire Fences
7-2-4:   Removal Of Safety Devices On Public Ways
7-2-5:   Burning On Public Property
7-2-6:   Casting Rinds Or Peels On Sidewalks
7-2-7:   Exhibiting Dangerous Animals
7-2-8:   Notify Department Of Public Safety Of Alcohol Consumption By A Minor
On Hotel Or Motel Premises
7-2-9:   Intoxicated Persons
7-2-10:   Musical Performances On Public Property
7-2-11:   Obstructing Water Flows
7-2-12:   Sale Or Providing Poisons
7-2-13:   Careless Smoking
7-2-14:   Order In Public Places
7-2-15:   Shooting Birds; Disturbing Nests
7-2-16:   Throwing Objects
7-2-17:   Throwing Glass
7-2-18:   Loitering
7-2-19:   Over Occupancy Of Hotel Or Motel Rooms
7-2-20:   Disturbing Worship Assemblies
7-2-21:   Discharge Of Firearms
7-2-22:   Penalty
7-2-1: INJURY TO PERSONS, DAMAGE TO PROPERTY UPON PUBLIC HIGHWAY: 
Any person who, while riding, driving or propelling a bicycle, motorcycle,
automobile, carriage, wagon or other vehicle, runs against, upon or over any
person upon the public highway, so as to cause an injury to such person or
property, and who does not stop at once to ascertain the extent of such injury
and to render such assistance as may be needed, and who refuses to give his
true name and residence when asked by the person so injured, or by any public
safety officer, or by any other person in behalf of the injured person, shall
be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
Cross-reference:
   See also section
8-1-6  of this Code
7-2-2: ASSAULT, BATTERY, AND FIGHTING:
   A.   Assault: It shall be unlawful for any person, without lawful authority,
to engage in conduct which places another in reasonable apprehension of
receiving a battery.
   B.   Battery: It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally or
knowingly, without legal jurisdiction, and by any means cause bodily harm to
another, or make physical contact of insulting or provoking nature with
another.
   C.   Fighting: It shall be unlawful for any person to physically fight with
another person without legal justification.
   D.   Penalty: Any person who is found liable of violating this section shall
be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 92-7-1C, 7-1-1992; amd. Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017; Ord. 2021-4-12D, 4-
12-2021)
7-2-3: BARBED WIRE FENCES:
   A.   No person shall build, construct, use or maintain any fence or barrier
consisting or made of what is called “barbed wire” or of which barbed wire is a
part, within the Village along the line of or upon or along any street, alley
or public walk or drive, or through, along or around any public park, or in or
about or along any land or lots or parks owned or controlled by the Village.
   B.   Wherever in the Village, in, along or through any public street, alley
or park, barbed wire is found in use in part or in whole for a fence or
barrier, the same shall forthwith be removed by the Department of Public
Safety.
   C.   No person being the owner, lessee or agent of any real estate in the
Village shall erect, maintain or permit to be erected or maintained on or about
the exterior building line of such real estate, or upon any portion of the
sidewalk adjacent to such real estate, any railing, fence, guard or protection
of any kind of barbed wire, or upon which railing, fence, guard or other
protection there shall be affixed or placed or in any manner attached, any
spike, nail or pointed instrument of any kind or description, under the penalty
of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each and every day such person fails
or neglects to remove from such railing, fence or other protection, any such
spike, nail or other pointed instrument, after notice in writing from the
Department of Public Safety, he/she shall be deemed guilty of a new, separate
and distinct offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-4: REMOVAL OF SAFETY DEVICES ON PUBLIC WAYS:
No person shall remove any barricade or light or danger signal erected in front
of or about any defective sidewalk or street within the Village, or in front or
about any sidewalk or street under repair or undergoing reconstruction within
the Village, or in any way interfere with, change or destroy such barricade,
light or other danger signal until such sidewalk or street is repaired or
rebuilt, under a penalty of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-5: BURNING ON PUBLIC PROPERTY:
No person shall burn any standing hay or grass or set fire to or burn any
leaves or other combustible material in any park or public grounds within the
corporate limits of the Village, or burn any leaves or other combustible
material or build any bonfire upon any brick, asphalt or block pavement in the
Village in such a manner as to obstruct passage or endanger neighboring
property, under a penalty of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). It shall be the duty of the
Department of Public Safety to enforce the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-6: CASTING RINDS OR PEELS ON SIDEWALKS:
No person shall throw, cast, lay or place on any sidewalk in the Village the
rind or peel of any orange, banana, apple or other fruit, under a penalty of
not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-7: EXHIBITING DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
No person shall permit any bear or other dangerous animal to run at large, nor
lead any such animal with a chain or rope or other appliance, whether such
animal be muzzled or unmuzzled, in any street, avenue, lane, highway or public
place within the Village, under a penalty of not more than seven hundred
dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-8: NOTIFY DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY OF ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION BY A MINOR ON
HOTEL PREMISES:
Each operator of a hotel or motel shall at all times have an individual present
within the hotel or motel that has the responsibility to supervise the
operation of the hotel or motel. The employee or staff member of a hotel or
motel that has the responsibility of overseeing the operation of said hotel or
motel shall have the affirmative obligation to report any knowledge he/she
obtains of the use of alcohol by any minor on the premises of the hotel or
motel to the Public Safety Department. A violation of this section shall result
in a fine of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) and not more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-9: INTOXICATED PERSONS:
   A.   Generally: If any person shall be in a state of intoxication in any
highway, street, alley, thoroughfare or public place in the Village, or in any
private house or place, to the annoyance of any citizens or persons, he shall
be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, shall be fined in any sum
not exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   B.   Consumption Of Alcoholic Liquor And Possession Of Open Containers Of
Alcoholic Liquor In Parks And On Sidewalks, Streets And Public Rights Of Way
Prohibited; Parking Prohibited: Except as provided in subsections 1, 2 and 3
below, no person may consume, carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor in a
park or on a public street, sidewalk or other public right of way except in the
unopened original container and with the seal, if any, unbroken.
      1.   The provisions of this section shall not apply where a person who
has or is consuming, carrying, or possessing the alcoholic liquor is attending
an event for which a Class G liquor license has been issued by the Village.
      2.   The provisions of this section shall not apply to the passengers in
a limousine when it is being used for purposes for which a limousine is
ordinarily used, the passengers on a chartered bus other than a bus used for
school purposes, when the chartered bus is being used for purposes for which
chartered buses are ordinarily used or on a motor home or mini motor home as
defined in section 1-145.01 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-145/01).
However, the driver of any such vehicle is prohibited from consuming or having
any alcoholic liquor in or about the driver’s area. Any evidence of alcoholic
consumption by the driver shall be prima facie evidence of such driver’s
failure to obey this section. For the purposes of this section, a limousine is
a motor vehicle of the first division as defined in the Illinois Vehicle Code
with the passenger compartment enclosed by a partition or dividing window used
in the for-hire transportation of passengers and operated by an individual in
possession of a valid State driver’s license of the appropriate classification
pursuant to section 6-104 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/6-104).
      3.   The provisions of this section shall not apply to the common area of
the Park at Rosemont Entertainment District.
      4.   For purposes of this section, “alcoholic liquor” shall be defined as
set forth in section 1-3.05 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act (235 ILCS 5/1-
3.05).
      5.   Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject
to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2011-8-10C, 8-10-2011; amd. Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-10: MUSICAL PERFORMANCES ON PUBLIC PROPERTY:
   A.   No person shall use or perform with any hand or band organ or other
musical instrument in any of the streets or public places in the Village before
nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. of each day. This
subsection shall not apply to band music or any organized musical society
engaged in serenading, or civic or military parade.
   B.   Any person violating any provision of this section shall be subject to
a penalty of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-11: OBSTRUCTING WATER FLOWS:
No person shall stop or obstruct the passage of water in any street, gutter,
public sewer, culvert, water pipe or hydrant, under a penalty of not less than
seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-12: SALE OR PROVIDING POISONS:
No poisonous medicine, concoction, or substance shall be held for sale or sold,
except for lawful purposes and with proper motives, and by persons competent to
give the proper directions and precautions as to the use of the same; nor shall
any bottle, box, parcel or receptacle thereof be delivered to any person unless
the same is marked “Poison” nor to any person whom the party delivering the
same has reason to think intends it for any illegal or improper use or purpose,
under the penalty of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for
each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-13: CARELESS SMOKING:
   A.   Any person who, by smoking or attempting to light or smoke cigarettes,
cigars, pipes, or tobacco in any manner in which lighters or matches are
employed, who shall, in any careless, reckless or negligent manner whatsoever,
whether wilfully or wantonly or not, set fire to any bedding, furniture,
curtains, drapes, house or any household fittings, or any part of any building
whatsoever, so as to endanger life or property in any way or to any extent,
shall be guilty of violating this section.
   B.   Any person in the Village failing to comply with the provisions of this
section shall be subject to a penalty of not less than seventy five dollars
($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-14: ORDER IN PUBLIC PLACES:
Hackmen, cabmen, draymen, omnibus drivers, porters, runners and other persons,
when at or about any public place in the Village, shall obey the commands and
directions of the public safety officer who may be stationed or doing duty on
or about such station or other place, for the preservation of order and
enforcing this Code and the ordinances of the Village. Whoever shall refuse to
obey the commands and directions of a public safety officer as aforesaid, shall
be fined not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-15: SHOOTING BIRDS; DISTURBING NESTS:
Every person who shall kill or wound, or attempt to kill or wound, by the use
of firearms, slingshot, bow and arrow, pelting with stones or otherwise any
quail, pheasant, robin, blue jay, or any other song, plumage or game bird,
within any private ground or public park, squares, streets or grounds, or
taking the eggs of young of any such quail, pheasant, robin, blue jay or other
song, plumage or game bird within any private enclosure or public ground
belonging to the Village for the purpose of doing any act prohibited in this
section shall forfeit and pay not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-16: THROWING OBJECTS:
   A.   No person shall throw or cause to be thrown, cast or put into or leave
in or on any street, alley sidewalk, public place or enclosed public ground in
the Village any stone, missile, nails, tacks, ice, glass, broken crockery or
china, iron or metal scraps, or any other article or thing by which persons,
animals or vehicles shall or may be injured or endangered, under a penalty of
not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
   B.   No person shall cast or throw any stone or other missile upon or at any
building, railroad cars, tree, or other public or private property, or upon or
at any person in any street, avenue, alley, lane, public place, or any enclosed
or unenclosed ground in the Village, or aid or abet in the same, under a fine
for each offense of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-17: THROWING GLASS:
   A.   No person shall throw, cast, lay or place upon any street, sidewalk, or
other public place within the Village any glass bottle, window glass, or any
other article made of or containing glass, and in the case of the accidental
breaking of any glass upon any such street, sidewalk or public place, the owner
or person in charge of such glass, or the person responsible for such breakage,
shall at once remove the same from such street, sidewalk or public place.
   B.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be
fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-18: LOITERING:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand or
remain idle, either alone and/or in consort with others, in a public place in
such manner so as to:
      1.   Obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any
other public place or building by hindering or impeding or tending to hinder or
impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic or pedestrians.
      2.   Commit in or upon any public street, public highway, public sidewalk
or any other public place or building any act or thing which is an obstruction
or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any
business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or facing or fronting on any
such public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place
or building, all of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress,
and regress therein, thereon and thereto.
   B.   When any person causes or commits any of the conditions enumerated in
subsection A of this section, a public safety officer or any law enforcement
officer shall order that person to stop causing or committing such conditions
and to move on or disperse. Any person who fails or refuses to obey such orders
shall be guilty of a violation of this section.
   C.   Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be
subject to a fine not exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Any such
violation shall constitute a separate offense on each successive day continued.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-19: OVER OCCUPANCY OF HOTEL OR MOTEL ROOMS:
   A.   The operator of any hotel or motel shall not knowingly allow any room
within the hotel or motel that is intended to be used for sleeping to, at any
time, be occupied by a number of individuals that exceeds the following
formula:
(2 times the number of beds in the room), plus (the number of seating positions
on all the furniture provided by the hotel or motel within the room)
   B.   Any individual that contracts for the use and occupancy of a hotel or
motel sleeping room shall not allow the room they are authorized to use to, at
any time, be occupied by a number of individuals that exceeds the following
formula:
(2 times the number of beds in the room), plus (the number of seating positions
on all the furniture provided by the hotel or motel within the room)
   C.   The operator of any hotel or motel and any individual that is violation
of this section shall, upon conviction, be fined an amount that is not less
than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-20: DISTURBING WORSHIP ASSEMBLIES:
Any person who disturbs any congregation or assembly meeting for religious
worship by making any noise or by rude or indecent behavior or profane
discourse within the place of worship, or so near the same as to disturb the
order and solemnity of the meeting, shall be fined not exceeding seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-2-21: DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS:
   A.   No person, except a member of the Public Safety Department, when on
duty, or any officer of any court whose duty it may be to serve warrants or
make arrests, shall fire or discharge any gun, pistol, fowling piece or other
firearm, within the corporate limits of the Village.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or possess on or about his
person, within the Allstate Arena or on or about the areas adjoining the
Allstate Arena, including, but not limited to all parking areas, any pistol,
revolver, derringer, taser, stun-gun, or other firearm, any knife, the blade of
which is released by a spring mechanism, including knives known as
switchblades, any stiletto, dagger, dirk, bully knife, commando knife, throwing
star, any knife the blade of which is two inches (2") in length or longer, any
billy, blackjack, slingshot, throwing star, stand club, sandbag, knuckles or
bludgeon or any other dangerous or deadly weapon.
   C.   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, the provisions of this
section shall not apply to Public Safety officers and personnel and public
service officers while in the performance of their duties.
   D.   Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not
less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense. In addition to all of the penalties herein
provided, any weapon used or possessed in violation of this section shall be
forfeited to an confiscated by the Village.
(Ord. 91-4-3H, 4-3-1991)
7-2-22: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter, where a
specified fine has not been provided, shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined
not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each and every offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
CHAPTER 3: OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS
Section
7-3-1:   Disorderly Houses
7-3-2:   Disorderly Persons
7-3-3:   Disorderly Conduct
7-3-4:   Obscene Or Immoral Billposting
7-3-5:   Indecent Writings Or Drawings
7-3-6:   Urinating or Defecating In Public
7-3-7:   Unlawful Burials
7-3-8:   Animal Fights And Indecent Exhibitions
7-3-9:   Fortunetelling
7-3-10:   Fraud At Spiritual Or Religious Gatherings
7-3-11:   Possession Of Burglary Tools
7-3-1: DISORDERLY HOUSES:
Every person who shall keep or maintain any bawdy or disorderly house, or any
house or other place where any person is permitted or suffered to make any
improper noise or disturbance, or any house or other place where any minor is
permitted to drink intoxicating drinks of any kind, or play with dice,
dominoes, cards, balls or other articles used in gambling shall, on conviction,
be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-3-2: DISORDERLY PERSONS:
   A.   As used herein, a DISORDERLY PERSON shall be defined as:
      1.   Any person who engages in an illegal occupation or business, and any
person who attends, frequents, operates or who is an occupant of any place
where any illegal or immoral business or occupation is permitted or conducted;
      2.   Any person who shall be drunk or intoxicated in any public place or
under the influence of any narcotic drug in any public place in the Village;
      3.   Any prostitute or any person found loitering in a house of ill fame
or prostitution, or in a place where prostitution or lewdness is practiced,
encouraged or allowed, or any person who frequents or is found present in such
places, or any person soliciting for purposes of prostitution or is offering
himself, herself or others as subjects of prostitution;
      4.   All persons who shall collect or assemble in crowds and bodies for
unlawful or mischievous purposes in any place in the Village to the annoyance
or inconvenience of other persons, or who shall be involved in, or incite, or
attempt to incite a riot, or who shall fail to disperse upon the command of a
public safety officer or other lawful authority;
      5.   All persons who collect or assemble and stand or sit in crowds or
loiter about or hinder, obstruct, impede or block the free and uninterrupted
passage of any sidewalk, street, alley, driveway or the means of entry of any
place of business in the Village, or in any hall, stairway, office, court room
or public hall or building or any other public place in the Village, and who
fails to disperse upon the command of a public safety officer or other lawful
authority;
      6.   All persons who shall be found jostling or roughly crowding people
unnecessarily in a public place by being offensive to public order or decency;
      7.   All persons that stand, loiter or stroll about in any public place
awaiting or seeking an opportunity to obtain money or things of value from
others by trick or fraud or to aid or assist therein;
      8.   All persons that engage in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to
obtain or that do obtain money or other things of value in any place in the
Village, or that aid or abet or in any manner are involved in such scheme,
device or trick;
      9.   Any person that keeps or maintains a gaming room, gaming tables or
any policy or pool tickets used for gaining, or knowingly permits a gaming
room, gaining tables, or any policy or pool tickets to be kept, maintained,
played or sold on any premises occupied or controlled by him, and any person
knowingly frequenting any of the aforementioned places, and any person having
such paraphernalia in his possession;
      10.   Any person who shall commit any indecent, lewd or filthy act in any
public place which is offensive to public order or decency;
      11.   Any person who shall utter any lewd or filthy words, or use any
threatening language toward any other person, or shall make any obscene gesture
to or about any other person in any public place which is likely to provoke the
average person to retaliation and thereby cause a breach of the peace; and
   B.   Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be
guilty of the offense of “disorderly person” and be subject to a fine not
exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-3-3: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
   A.   A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly:
      1.   Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb
another and to provoke a breach of the peace;
      2.   With the intent to annoy another, makes a telephone call, whether or
not conversation thereby ensues;
      3.   Transmits or causes to be transmitted, in any manner to the Public
Safety Department a false alarm of fire, knowing that there was no reasonable
grounds for believing that such fire existed;
      4.   Transmits in any manner to another a false alarm to the effect that
a bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in any place and that its
explosion would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission
but there was no reasonable grounds for believing that such bomb or explosive
was concealed in said place;
      5.   Transmits in any manner to any police or public employee a report to
the effect that an offense has been committed, knowing at that the time of such
transmission that there was no reasonable grounds for believing that such an
offense has been committed;
      6.   Enters upon the property of another and for a lewd or unlawful
purpose deliberately looks in the dwelling on said property through any window
or other opening in it; or
      7.   Assembles, congregates or collects in bodies, crowds, groups of
three (3) or more for any unlawful purpose, or for any purpose to the
annoyances or disturbance of others within the limits of the Village, nor shall
any person in a body of three (3) or more persons congregate, loiter, linger,
stand together or near to each other on any sidewalk, street, alley, public
parking lot, public park or public passageway or in front of, about or upon any
stairway, doorway or window of any church, theater, auditorium, school, hall or
other public building so as to obstruct, block, impede or interfere with the
free passage of any person or persons on or upon said public sidewalks, streets
and ways, so as to obstruct, impede or interfere with free passage of persons
entering or occupying any such public buildings or premises or any premises
fronting upon any public sidewalk, street or way, when requested to immediately
disperse and move any public safety officer, public service officer or other
public official; nor shall any person in a body of three (3) or more persons by
his language, conversation, conduct or signage, annoy, insult or disturb
persons passing on or along any public street, alley, parking lot, park or
passageway, or occupying or being within any public building or any place of
business or occupying or found within any residence or dwelling structure
within the Village.
   B.   Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be
guilty of the offense of disorderly conduct and shall be subject to a fined not
less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 92-7-1B, 7-1-1992)
7-3-4: OBSCENE OR IMMORAL BILLPOSTING:
No person shall, within the limits of the Village, post or cause to be posted
any advertisement containing pictures or illustrations of any obscene or
immoral character which is utterly without any redeeming social value and
predominantly appeals to the prurient interest of the public, all of which
affronts the prevailing contemporary standards of the community as a whole,
under a penalty of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-3-5: INDECENT WRITINGS OR DRAWINGS:
Any person who shall, in any public place, or place open to public view within
the Village, write or draw, cut, make or exhibit any lewd or indecent word,
