sentence, design or figure, (where applicable hereunder, that which is obscene
and utterly without any redeeming social value and which appeals to the
prurient interest of the public so as to affront the prevailing contemporary
standards of the community as a whole), shall be subject to a fine of not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00).
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-3-6: URINATING OR DEFECATING IN PUBLIC:
   A.   Generally: It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate
in or on any street, sidewalk, alley, plaza, park, public building or in any
other place opened to the public or exposed to public view.
   B.   Exceptions:
      1.   This section shall not apply to urination or defecation which is
done in any enclosure or other public facility designated for use as a toilet
or lavatory.
      2.   This section shall not apply to the act of urinating or defecating
in public if the act was due to a verified medical condition or physical
impairment that renders the act beyond a person’s bodily control. A person with
an impairment shall not include intoxicated individuals or individuals who are
impaired due to the ingestion of illegal substances.
   C.   Penalty: Any person found violating the provisions of this section
shall be fined in an amount not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
   D.   Administrative Adjudication: Violations of this section are subject to
prosecution under the Village’s administrative proceedings established pursuant
to Title 1, Chapter 4, Article A of this Code, as now or hereafter amended. The
provisions of this subsection shall not preclude the Village from using other
methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of this section,
including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the Circuit
Court of Cook County, or before another administrative tribunal which has
jurisdiction to consider the violation.
(Ord. 2010-9-1A, 9-1-2010)
7-3-7: UNLAWFUL BURIALS:
Any person who buries or assists in burying any corpse or dead person within
the limits of the Village shall be subject to a penalty of not less than twenty
five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and
the necessary costs and expenses incurred in such prosecution.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-3-8: ANIMAL FIGHTS AND INDECENT EXHIBITIONS:
No person shall instigate, cause or procure any dog fight, cock fight or any
public or private fighting, or in any manner instigate, cause or procure, or
assist in any indecent or immoral show or exhibition of any animal, under a
penalty of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each and every offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-3-9: FORTUNETELLING:
   A.   No person shall advertise by display sign, circular, handbill or any
form of material distributed in the Village or by any other means an ability to
tell fortunes or reveal the future, to find or restore lost or stolen property,
to locate oil wells, gold, silver or other ore or metal or natural product, to
communicate with the deceased, or otherwise give any advice to others by means
of supernatural powers, clairvoyance, the summoning of spirits, mediumship,
seer ship, astrology, palmistry, necromancy, magic, or through the reading and
interpretation of any material or articles including, but not limited to, tarot
cards, cards, talismans, charms, crystal balls, tea leaves, sticks, potions,
magnetic articles or similar articles of any kind or nature.
   B.   No person in the Village shall engage in the practice of, teach, or
demonstrate any method of telling fortunes, revealing the future, finding or
restoring lost or stolen property, locating oil wells, gold, silver or other
ore or metal or natural product, communicating with the deceased, or otherwise
give any advice to others by means of supernatural powers, clairvoyance, the
summoning of spirits, mediumship, seer ship, astrology, palmistry, necromancy,
magic, or through the reading and interpretation of any material or articles
including, but not limited to, tarot cards, cards, talismans, charms, crystal
balls, tea leaves, sticks, potions, magnetic articles or similar articles of
any kind or nature.
   C.   A violation of this section shall be a public nuisance.
   D.   Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall pay a fine of
not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each calendar day on which an act
prohibited by this section shall be a separate offense. Upon the conviction of
a second offense within a one year period, the minimum fine shall be increased
to one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the second offense and for each subsequent
offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-3-10: FRAUD AT SPIRITUAL OR RELIGIOUS GATHERINGS:
Any person who shall hold or give any public or private meetings, gatherings,
cycles or seances of any kind in the name of spiritualism or any other
religious body, society or denomination, and therein practice or permit to be
practiced fraud or deception of any kind shall, on conviction thereof, be
punishable by a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-3-11: POSSESSION OF BURGLARY TOOLS:
No person shall have in his possession any nippers of the description known as
“burglar’s nippers”, picklock skeleton key to be used with a bit or bits,
jimmy, or other burglar instruments or tools of whatsoever kind or description,
unless it be shown that such possession is innocent or for a lawful purpose,
under the penalty of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
ARTICLE A: SEX RELATED OFFENSES
Section
7-3A-1:   Definitions
7-3A-2:   Public Indecency
7-3A-3:   Prostitution
7-3A-4:   Solicitation Of A Sexual Act
7-3A-5:   Soliciting For A Prostitute
7-3A-6:   Keeping A Place Of Prostitution
7-3A-7:   Patronizing A Prostitute
7-3A-8:   Seizure And Forfeiture
7-3A-9:   Prosecution Of Violations
7-3A-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation in this article
unless the context requires otherwise:
PUBLIC PLACE: Any place where the conduct may reasonably be expected to be
viewed by others.
SEXUAL CONDUCT: Any intentional or knowing touching or fondling by a person
over the age of seventeen (17), either directly or through clothing, of the sex
organs, anus or breast of another person over the age of thirteen (13), or of
any part of the body of a child under thirteen (13) years of age, or any
transfer or transmission of semen by a person upon any part of the clothed or
unclothed body of another person for the purpose of sexual gratification or
arousal of either person.
SEXUAL PENETRATION: Any contact, however slight, between the sex organ or anus
of one person by an object, the sex organ, mouth or anus of another person, or
any intrusion, however slight, of any part of the body of one person or of any
animal or object into the sex organ or anus of another person, including but
not limited to cunnilingus, fellatio or anal penetration. Evidence of emission
of semen is not required to prove sexual penetration.
(Ord. 2007-6-6C, 6-6-2007)
7-3A-2: PUBLIC INDECENCY:
   A.   1.   Any person of the age of seventeen (17) years and upwards who
performs any of the following acts in a public place commits a public
indecency:
         a.   An act of sexual penetration or sexual conduct as defined in
section 7-3A-1; or
         b.   A lewd exposure of the body done with intent to arouse or to
satisfy the sexual desire of the person.
      2.   Breast-feeding of infants is not an act of public indecency.
   B.   Any person convicted of any violation of this section shall be subject
to a fine of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each and every offense.
(Ord. 2007-6-6C, 6-6-2007)
7-3A-3: PROSTITUTION:
   A.   Any person who performs, offers or agrees to perform any act of sexual
penetration as defined in section 7-3A-1 for any money, property, token,
object, or article or anything of value, or any touching or fondling of the sex
organs of one person by another person, for any money, property, token, object,
or article or anything of value, for the purpose of sexual arousal or
gratification commits an act of prostitution.
   B.   Any person found guilty of committing an act of prostitution as set
forth in subsection A shall be subject to a fine of not less than seventy five
dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
and every offense. Each separate act of prostitution shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Ord. 2007-6-6C, 6-6-2007)
7-3A-4: SOLICITATION OF A SEXUAL ACT:
   A.   Any person who offers a person not his spouse any money, property,
token, object, or article or anything of value to perform any act of sexual
penetration as defined in section 7-3A-1, or any touching or fondling of the
sex organs of one person by another person for the purpose of sexual arousal or
gratification, commits the offense of solicitation of a sexual act.
   B.   Any person found guilty of committing the offense of soliciting a
sexual act as set forth in subsection A shall be subject to a fine of not less
than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each and every offense. Each separate incident of soliciting a
sexual act shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2007-6-6C, 6-6-2007)
7-3A-5: SOLICITING FOR A PROSTITUTE:
   A.   Any person who performs any of the following acts commits soliciting
for a prostitute:
      1.   Solicits another for the purpose of prostitution;
      2.   Arranges or offers to arrange a meeting of persons for the purpose
of prostitution; or
      3.   Directs another to a place knowing such direction is for the purpose
of prostitution.
   B.   Any person found guilty of committing the offense of soliciting for a
prostitute as set forth in subsection A shall be subject to a fine of not less
than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each and every offense. Each separate incident of soliciting for
a prostitute shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2007-6-6C, 6-6-2007)
7-3A-6: KEEPING A PLACE OF PROSTITUTION:
   A.   Any person who has or exercises control over the use of any place which
could offer seclusion or shelter for the practice of prostitution who performs
any of the following acts keeps a place of prostitution:
      1.   Knowingly grants or permits the use of such place for the purpose of
prostitution;
      2.   Grants or permits the use of such place under circumstances from
which he could reasonably know that the place is used or is to be used for
purposes of prostitution; or
      3.   Permits the continued use of a place after becoming aware of facts
or circumstances from which he should reasonably know that the place is being
used for purposes of prostitution.
   B.   Any person found guilty of committing the offense of keeping a place of
prostitution as set forth in subsection A shall be subject to a fine of not
less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each and every offense. Each six (6) hour period or part
thereof that a person engages in conduct that constitutes keeping a house of
prostitution shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2007-6-6C, 6-6-2007)
7-3A-7: PATRONIZING A PROSTITUTE:
   A.   Any person who performs any of the following acts with a person not his
spouse commits the offense of patronizing a prostitute:
      1.   Engages in an act of sexual penetration as defined in section 7-3A-
1 with a prostitute; or
      2.   Enters or remains in a place of prostitution with intent to engage
in an act of sexual penetration as defined in section 7-3A-1.
   B.   Any person found guilty of committing the offense of patronizing a
prostitute as set forth in subsection A shall be subject to a fine of not less
than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each and every offense. Each separate incident of patronizing a
prostitute shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2007-6-6C, 6-6-2007)
7-3A-8: SEIZURE AND FORFEITURE:
All money, property, token, object, or article or anything of value that is
exchanged in connection with the performance of an act of prostitution, the
soliciting of a sexual act, the soliciting of a prostitute, the keeping of a
place of prostitution or the patronizing of a prostitute is declared to be
contraband subject to seizure and any such money, property, token, object, or
article or thing of value shall be subject to forfeiture upon a finding of
guilty of any person for a violation of sections 7-3A-3 through 7-3A-7 of this
article. Upon appropriate order of court or administrative hearing officer said
money, property, token, object, or article or thing of value shall be disposed
of in accordance with applicable law.
(Ord. 2007-6-6C, 6-6-2007)
7-3A-9: PROSECUTION OF VIOLATIONS:
Violations of the provisions of this article are subject to prosecution under
the Village’s administrative adjudication proceedings established pursuant to
Title 1, Chapter 4, Article A as now or hereafter amended. The provisions of
this section shall not preclude the Village from using other methods or
proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of this article, including,
without limitation, the institution of an action in the Circuit Court of Cook
County, or before another administrative tribunal which has jurisdiction to
consider the violation.
(Ord. 2007-6-6C, 6-6-2007)
CHAPTER 4: OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY
Section
7-4-1:   Damaging Property
7-4-2:   Trespassing
7-4-3:   Damaging Lights And Utility Wires
7-4-4:   Damaging, Trespassing, Putting Materials On Property
7-4-5:   Damaging Trees And Shrubs
7-4-6:   Use Of Parkways
7-4-7:   Obstructing Public Ways Generally
7-4-8:   Obstructing Public Ways By Sports, Games, Amusements Or Exhibitions
7-4-9:   Obstructing Streets By Railroad Companies
7-4-10:   Playing On Railroad Property
7-4-11:   Billposting And Notices
7-4-1: DAMAGING PROPERTY:
   A.   Any person who wilfully, maliciously or negligently breaks, defaces,
injures, displaces or destroys any property of the State, County, Village,
school district or other governmental agency, or any private property, or any
sewer, water pipe or hydrant laid or placed by the Village shall be subject to
a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and the amount of the repair.
   B.   Any person who shall, within the Village, cut, injure, remove or
destroy any fruit, ornamental or shade tree, or the boxing around the same, or
any fence, railing, gate, post, sign, or any topsoil from any public ground,
sidewalk or private premises, or injure, take or destroy any tree, shrub,
fruit, flower, plant, vegetable or other thing which may be therein for
ornament or utility shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-4-2: TRESPASSING:
   A.   Prohibited:
      1.   No person shall commit a trespass within the Village upon either
public or private property.
      2.   For purposes of subsection 1 above, a trespass is committed by any
person who enters upon the land or building or any part thereof of another, if
such person, prior to entering upon the land or building, received notice from
the owner or authorized occupant of the land or building that such entry is
forbidden. For purposes of subsection 1 above, a trespass is also committed by
any person who remains upon the land or building or any part there of another
after receiving notice from the owner or occupant or duly authorized
representative that such person is not permitted to remain on the land or in
the building. For purposes of this subsection 2, a person shall be considered
to have received notice if the person has been notified personally, either in
writing or orally. Written notice may take the form of either a court order, or
a printed or written notice that is posted or exhibited in a conspicuous place
at or near the main entry to the land or building and states that the entry or
remaining on the land or building is prohibited. The provisions of this
subsection 2 are not limited and do not restrict the application of subsection
B below.
   B.   Trespasses Enumerated: Without constituting any limitation upon the
provisions of subsection A of this section, any of the following acts by any
person shall be deemed included among those that constitute trespasses in
violation of the provisions of subsection A of this section, and appropriate
action may be taken hereunder at any time, or from time to time, to prevent or
suppress any violation of subsection A of this section, the aforesaid
enumerated acts so included, being as follows:
      1.   Any entry upon the premises, or any part thereof, of another,
including any public property in violation of a notice posted or exhibited at
the main entrance to such premises or at any point of approach or entry, or in
violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing, by any
owner or occupant thereof;
      2.   The pursuit of a course of conduct or action incidental to the
making of an entry upon the land of another in violation of a notice posted or
exhibited at the main entrance to such premises or at any point of approach or
entry, or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in
writing by any owner or occupant thereof;
      3.   A failure or refusal to depart from the premises of another in the
case of being requested, either orally or in writing, to leave by any owner or
occupant thereof; or
      4.   An entry into or upon any vehicle, aircraft or watercraft made
without the consent of the person having the right to the possession or control
thereof, or a failure or refusal to leave any such vehicle, aircraft or
watercraft after being requested to leave by the person having such right.
   C.   Penalty:
      1.   Violations of this section are subject to prosecution under the
Village’s administrative adjudication proceedings established pursuant to Title
1, Chapter 4, Article A as now or hereafter amended. The provisions of this
section shall not preclude the Village from using other methods or proceedings
to adjudicate alleged violations of this section, including, without
limitation, the institution of an action in the Circuit Court of Cook County,
or before another administrative tribunal which has jurisdiction to consider
the violation.
      2.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall
upon conviction, or upon an administrative determination that a violation
occurred, shall be fined in an amount of not less than seventy five dollars
($75.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Each
trespass shall, constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2008-3-5, 3-5-2008)
7-4-3: DAMAGING LIGHTS AND UTILITY WIRES:
Any person who shall carelessly or maliciously break, deface, disturb,
interfere with, carry away or in any way injure or destroy any electric light,
lamp, globe or any part of or appurtenances to any lamp or light of any kind
used in or upon or about any street, alley or public place in the Village, or
who shall carelessly or maliciously break, injure, destroy or in any way
disturb or interfere with any electric light, or telephone wire, or any
appurtenance thereto at any place within the limits of the Village shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be liable to a penalty of not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-4-4: DAMAGING, TRESPASSING, PUTTING MATERIALS ON PROPERTY:
Any person who shall carelessly or maliciously break, deface, carry away, or in
any way injure or destroy any public lamp or lamppost, or street sign, or any
sign, gate, sidewalk or fence in the Village, or climb upon any public
lamppost, or hand or place any goods or merchandise thereon, or place any
goods, boxes, wood or any other heavy material upon or against the same shall
be liable to a penalty of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-4-5: DAMAGING TREES AND SHRUBS:
No person shall cut down, destroy, break or in any way injure any tree or shrub
standing in any street or public place, except by permission of the Village
President, under a penalty of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-4-6: USE OF PARKWAYS:
   A.   Parkways:
      1.   All parkways in the Village are restricted to grass lawns, access
driveways, cement sidewalks and trees.
      2.   Trees shall be at least four (4) feet from the curb on streets with
a fifty foot (50') right-of-way and at least seven feet (7') from the curb on
streets with a sixty-six foot (66') right-of-way.
      3.   No obstructions, ashes, dirt, garbage, crushed stone, black top,
broken cement or any other offensive matter shall be allowed in such parkways.
   B.   Front Yards In Residential Districts:
      1.   Except as provided in subsection B2 below, all areas within the
front yard set back required under the Village’s Zoning Ordinance in
Residential Districts are restricted to grass lawns or similar plant covering,
access driveways and cement sidewalks; trees, and bushes.
      2.   No obstructions, ashes, dirt, crushed stone, gravel, black top,
broken cement or any other offensive matter shall be allowed in any part of a
front yard. No stone or rock of any description shall be placed within the
front yard setback; except that a circle or line of artistic stone, which in
the case of a circle shall have a radius not in excess of two feet (2') and in
the case of a line shall be not more than one foot (1') in width, may be placed
around or in front of trees and bushes and adjacent to a sidewalk or access
driveway.
   C.   Penalty: Any person violating the terms of this section shall be fined
not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 93-6-2H, 6-2-1993)
7-4-7: OBSTRUCTING PUBLIC WAYS GENERALLY:
   A.   The streets, avenues, alleys and sidewalks in the Village shall be kept
free and clear at all times of all encumbrances and encroachments for the use
of the public, except as may be herein or by ordinance or resolution of the
Village Board otherwise specially provided.
   B.   No person shall at any time congregate or assemble in or upon any of
the public streets, avenues, alleys or sidewalks of the Village in such manner
as to obstruct or interfere with the passage of persons along the streets or
sidewalks, or in such a manner as to disturb or threaten the public peace.
   C.   Any person in such assembly who fails or refuses, upon the order of any
public safety officer of the Village, to move on or away from such assembly
shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-4-8: OBSTRUCTING PUBLIC WAYS BY SPORTS, GAMES, AMUSEMENTS OR EXHIBITIONS:
No person shall, by means of any sport, game, amusement or exhibition or by
exhortation or otherwise, induce or attempt to induce the congregation or
assembling of persons in or upon any of the public streets, avenues, alleys or
sidewalks of the Village whereby the passage of vehicles in and along such
streets or the passage of persons along such streets or sidewalks is obstructed
or interfered with or whereby the public peace is threatened or disturbed under
a penalty of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.0O) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-4-9: OBSTRUCTING STREETS BY RAILROAD COMPANIES:
   A.   No railroad company shall allow any car or train of cars in the Village
to block any crossing or stand on any crossing on any public street for a
longer time than five (5) minutes.
   B.   Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be liable to
a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-4-10: PLAYING ON RAILROAD PROPERTY:
   A.   No person shall play upon or about any locomotive, engine, tender, car,
or train of cars, or any platform or step thereof, while the same or any or
either of them are in motion.
   B.   Any violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-4-11: BILLPOSTING AND NOTICES:
No person shall paste, post, print, paint, nail or otherwise fasten any
handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or other notice of any kind whatsoever,
or cause the same to be done, on any curbstone, flagstone, or other portion or
part of any sidewalk or street, or upon any tree, lamppost, utility pole,
hydrant, bridge, or pier, or upon any structure within the limits of any street
in the Village except such as may be required by this Code, or the ordinances
of the Village, or the laws of the State, or the government of the United
States.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
CHAPTER 5: GAMBLING AND GAMBLING DEVICES
Section
7-5-1:   Definitions
7-5-2:   Payment Of Federal Slot Machine Tax
7-5-3:   Payment Of Federal Wagering Tax
7-5-4:   Gambling Devices Prohibited
7-5-5:   Gambling Participation Prohibited
7-5-6:   Enforcement
7-5-7:   Revocation Of License; Hearing
7-5-8:   Penalty
7-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
LOTTERY: The numbers game, policy and similar types of wagering. The term does
not include:
   A.   Any game of a type in which usually:
      1.   The wagers are placed;
      2.   The winners are determined; and
      3.   The distribution of prizes or other property is made in the presence
of all persons placing wagers in such game.
   B.   In drawings conducted by an organization exempt from taxes under
section 101 of title 26 of the United States Code Annotated, if no part of the
net proceeds derived from drawings inures to the benefit of any private
shareholder or individual.
SLOT MACHINE: A device which operates by means of the insertion of a coin,
token or similar object and which, by application of the element of chance, may
deliver, or entitle the person playing or operating the device to receive,
cash, premium, merchandise or tokens, including a coin-in-the-slot operated
mechanical pinball device played for amusement which rewards the player with
the right to replay such mechanical device.
WAGER:
   A.   Any wager with respect to a sports event or a contest placed with the
person engaged in the business of accepting such wagers;
   B.   Any wager placed in a wagering pool with respect to a sports event or a
contest, if such pool is conducted for profit; and
   C.   Any wager placed in a lottery conducted for profit.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-5-2: PAYMENT OF FEDERAL SLOT MACHINE TAX:
If any person pays a special tax pursuant to the provision of clause (2) of
subsection (a) of section 3267 of title 26 of the United States Code Annotated,
such payment shall be prima facie evidence that the person making such payment
is maintaining for use or permitting the use of a slot machine.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-5-3: PAYMENT OF FEDERAL WAGERING TAX:
If any person pays the excise tax pursuant to the provision of subsection (a)
of section 3285 of chapter 27A of title 26 of the United States Code Annotated,
such payment shall be prima facie evidence that the person making such payment
is in the business of accepting wagers or conducting a wagering pool or lottery
within the Village, provided such person registers with the person collecting
the excise tax, an address within the Village as the address of the place of
business where the activity takes place, which makes the person liable for the
payment of the excise tax.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-5-4: GAMBLING DEVICES PROHIBITED:
No person shall own, operate, use, maintain for use or permit the use of a slot
machine or any table, wheel or device of any kind whatsoever, intended,
calculated or designed to be used for gaming or gambling or for playing any
game of chance. The prohibition contained in this section shall not apply to
“qualified organizations” as that term is defined in the Illinois Charitable
Games Act provided that the qualified organization has been issued a Charitable
Games License by the Illinois Department of Revenue and provided further that
any activities conducted by or on behalf of the qualified organization which
would otherwise violate this section are conducted in compliance with the
Illinois Charitable Games Act. The prohibition contained in this section shall
also not apply to any person, firm or corporation which has been issued a
supplier’s license by the Illinois Department of Revenue pursuant to the
provisions of the Illinois Charitable Games Act.
(Ord. 87-3-11D, 3-11-1987)
7-5-5: GAMBLING PARTICIPATION PROHIBITED:
No person shall play or engage in faro, roulette or gambling for money or other
valuable thing, or accept wagers, or to engage in or conduct a wagering pool or
a lottery. The prohibition contained in this section shall not apply to
“qualified organizations” as that term is defined in the Illinois Charitable
Games Act provided that the qualified organization has been issued a Charitable
Games License by the Illinois Department of Revenue and provided further that
any activities conducted by or on behalf of the qualified organization which
would otherwise violate the prohibition contained in this section are conducted
in compliance with the Illinois Charitable Games Act.
(Ord. 87-3-11D, 3-11-1987)
7-5-6: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the Superintendent of Public Safety to enforce the
provisions of this chapter. He shall report to the President at least once a
week and state in detail the work he has done during the preceding week to
cause this chapter to be strictly enforced and adhered to.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-5-7: REVOCATION OF LICENSE; HEARING:
   A.   Every person holding a license issued by the Village to conduct a
legitimate business shall have the same revoked by the President, after a
hearing held by him, if such licensee is convicted of violating any provision
of this chapter.
   B.   The licensee shall have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing to
be held not less than five (5) days after notice of the time and place of the
hearing, addressed to him at his last known place of business, has been mailed.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-5-8: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
   B.   Each day a violation continues to exist or a person allows to be issued
to him any valid receipt, stamp or other evidence showing payment of the
special tax for the maintenance or use of a slot machine in the Village, or
each day he allows himself to be registered for the purpose of accepting wagers
or conducting a wagering pool or lottery in the Village shall be deemed a
separate offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
ARTICLE A: RAFFLES
Section
7-5A-1:   Definitions
7-5A-2:   License Required
7-5A-3:   Eligibility
7-5A-4:   Powers And Duties Of Raffles Commissioner
7-5A-5:   License Applications
7-5A-6:   Time To Act On Application
7-5A-7:   License Fees
7-5A-8:   Conduct Of Raffles
7-5A-9:   Raffles Manager; Bond
7-5A-10:   Restrictions On License Issuance
7-5A-11:   Retroactive License
7-5A-12:   Record Keeping
7-5A-13:   License Suspension And Revocation
7-5A-14:   Appeals
7-5A-15:   Gambling Not Authorized
7-5A-16:   Penalty
7-5A-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings
indicated, unless the context clearly requires a different meaning:
BUSINESS: A voluntary organization composed of individuals and businesses who
have joined together to advance the commercial, financial, industrial and civic
interests of a community.
CHARITABLE: An organization or institution organized and operated to benefit an
indefinite number of the public. The service rendered to those eligible for
benefits must also confer some benefit on the public.
CLASS A LICENSE: A license authorizing the operation of a raffle where the
aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise by a licensee in a single
raffle does not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
CLASS B LICENSE: A license authorizing the operation of a raffle where the
aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise by a licensee in a single
raffle exceeds one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
EDUCATIONAL: An organization or institution organized and operated to provide
systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by methods common to
schools and institutions of learning which compare favorably in their scope and
intensity with the course of study presented in tax-supported schools.
FRATERNAL: An organization of persons having a common interest, the primary
interest of which is to both promote the welfare of its members and to provide
assistance to the general public in such a way as to lessen the burdens of
government by caring for those who would otherwise be cared for by the
government.
HARDSHIP: A non-profit fundraising organization that has not been in existence
continuously for a period of five (5) years immediately before making
application for a license that the Raffles Commissioner determines to be
organized for the sole purpose of providing financial assistance to an
identified individual or group of individuals suffering extreme financial
hardship as a result of an illness, disability, accident or disaster.
LABOR: An organization composed of workers organized with the objective of
betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such pursuit and the
development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective occupations.
NET PROCEEDS: means the gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less
reasonable sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable
operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION: An organization or institution organized and conducted
on a not-for-profit basis, with no personal profit inuring to anyone as a
result of the operation, that have been in existence continuously for a period
of at least five (5) years immediately prior to their making application for a
license, and which have had a bona fide membership engaged in carrying out
their objective during that time.
RAFFLE: A form of lottery, as defined in section 28-2(b) of the Illinois
Criminal Code (750 ILCS 5/28-2), conducted by an organization licensed under
this article in which:
      1.   The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance,
represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by
some other medium, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning
chance; and
      2.   The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some
other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part
of persons conducting or connected with the lottery, except that the winning
chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting
contest.
RAFFLES COMMISSIONER: The Director of the Health and Licensing Department.
RELIGIOUS: Any church, congregation, society or organization founded for the
purpose of religious worship.
ROSEMONT NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION: A charitable, educational, religious,
veterans, labor, business or hardship nonprofit organization that: (i) has its
headquarters or principal office in the Village of Rosemont; or, (ii) that
primarily serves or benefits persons or organizations that reside within or are
located in the Village of Rosemont.
VETERANS: An organization or association comprised of members of which
substantially all are individuals who are veterans or spouses, widows or
widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of
its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to
confer a public benefit.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation shall conduct any raffle or sell any chances for
a raffle within the Village without first having obtained a license for the
particular raffle pursuant to this article.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-3: ELIGIBILITY:
Licenses shall be issued only to bona fide charitable, educational, religious,
fraternal, veterans, labor, business or hardship nonprofit organizations.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-4: POWERS AND DUTIES OF RAFFLES COMMISSIONER:
The Raffles Commissioner is charged with the administration of this article,
and shall be assisted by the Department of Public Safety. The Raffles
Commissioner shall have the following powers, duties, functions and
responsibilities:
   A.   To grant, suspend or revoke all licenses issued;
   B.   To limit the aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise
awarded by a licensee in a single raffle;
   C.   To limit the maximum retail value of each prize awarded by a licensee
in a single raffle;
   D.   To limit the maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance
issued or sold;
   E.   To limit the maximum number of days during which chances may be issued
or sold;
   F.   To receive or cause to be received all local license fees and pay them
immediately to the Finance Director; and
   G.   To receive complaints from any citizen of the Village that any
provision of this article has been or is being violated, and to act upon such
complaint in the manner provided by law.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-5: LICENSE APPLICATIONS:
The application for a raffles license shall be made on a form provided by the
Village and shall contain the following information.
   A.   The name and address of the nonprofit organization sponsoring the
raffle and submitting the application;
   B.   The type of organization and the number of years that the organization
has been in existence;
   C.   The number of years that the organization has been in existence;
   D.   The name of the president or chairperson of the organization;
   E.   The name of the raffle manager;
   F.   The geographic area(s) where raffle chances are to be sold or issued;
   G.   The cumulative retail value of the prizes to be offered at each raffle
and the maximum value of each prize to be offered at each raffle;
   H.   The maximum price to be charged for each raffle chance sold;
   I.   The time period during which raffle chances will be sold or issued for
each raffle, but not more than one (1) year;
   J.   The date and the location or locations at which winning chances will be
determined for each raffle;
   K.   A sworn statement attesting to the nonprofit character of the
prospective licensee organization signed by its presiding officer and
secretary, if any; and
   L.   In addition to the foregoing information, the applicant shall provide
such other and further information as the Raffles Commissioner may require, not
inconsistent with law.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-6: TIME TO ACT ON APPLICATION:
The Raffles Commissioner, or his designee, shall review all applications for
raffles licenses and shall, if such application is complete and in compliance
with the provisions of this article, issue said license within thirty (30) days
after the submission.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-7: LICENSE FEES:
The fee for each raffle license shall be as established in the Village Fee
Schedule set forth in Title 3, Chapter 10.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-8: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
The conduct of raffles is subject to the following restrictions:
   A.   No person, firm or corporation shall conduct raffles within the Village
without first obtaining a license therefore pursuant to this article.
   B.   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to
the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that raffle.
   C.   No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may
participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
   D.   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in
the management or operation of the raffle.
   E.   A licensee may rent premises on which to determine the winning chance
or chances in a raffle only from:
      1.   An organization which is also licensed under this chapter;
      2.   A nonprofit corporation or organization approved in the license; or
      3.   A commercial entity approved in the license, but only if no rent or
other charge is made or to be made for the renting of the premises above the
lowest rates that are being charged by the entity for use of the same space.
   F.   Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the geographic area
specified in the license, and winning chances may be determined only at those
locations specified in the license.
   G.   No person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the
conducting of raffles or chances. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years
may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when
accompanied by his parent or guardian.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-9: RAFFLES MANAGER; BOND:
   A.   Supervision: The operation of and the conduct of raffles shall be under
the supervision of a single raffles manager designated by the organization.
   B.   Fidelity Bond: For Class A raffles, a fidelity bond may be issued by
responsible individual sureties, or by a responsible insurance company or
financial institution duly authorized to do business in Illinois. For Class B
raffles, a fidelity bond must be issued by a responsible insurance company or
financial institution duly authorized to do business in the State.
   C.   Amount Of Bond: Unless waived as provide in this article, the raffles
manager shall give a fidelity bond in the sum of the total value of the prizes
to be awarded in the raffle which shall be in effect from the commencement of
sales of chances within the Village until at least thirty (30) days after the
raffle is conducted.
   D.   Cancellation: Terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be
given in writing to the Village Finance Director not less than thirty (30) days
prior to its cancellation.
   E.   Waiver Of Fidelity Bond Requirement: A waiver of this bond requirement
may be included in the license issued to any organization under this article as
follows, if requested by a unanimous vote of the members of the licensed
organization:
      1.   This bond requirement may be waived by the Village President for any
Village nonprofit organization.
      2.   This bond requirement may be waived by the Village Board of Trustees
for any licensee.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-10: RESTRICTIONS ON LICENSE ISSUANCE:
No raffle license shall be issued to:
   A.   Any person who has been convicted of a felony;
   B.   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling
promoter;
   C.   Any person who is not of good moral character;
   D.   Any organization in which a person described in subsections A, B, or C
has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest;
   E.   Any organization in which a person defined in subsections A, B or C is
an officer or director, whether compensated or not;
   F.   Any organization in which a person defined in subsections A, B or C is
to participate in the management or operation of a raffle as defined in this
article; or
   G.   Any organization which has in the previous three (3) years had a raffle
license revoked by any governmental unit.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-11: RETROACTIVE LICENSE:
An otherwise qualified Village nonprofit organization that conducts a raffle in
the Village, without first obtaining a license therefore as required under this
article, may obtain a retroactive license authorizing the raffle by:
   A.   Submitting a complete license application to the Raffles Commissioner
in accordance with section
7-5A-5;
   B.   Submitting the reports required under section
7-5A-12; and
   C.   Paying a one hundred dollars ($100.00) retroactive license application
fee.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-12: RECORD KEEPING:
A.   The Raffles Commissioner shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record
of all licenses issued under this article, and shall forward a copy to the
Department of Public Safety.
   B.   Each organization licensed to conduct a raffle under this article shall
keep records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single
gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions
from gross receipts shall be documented with receipts or other records
indicating the amount, a description of the purchased item or service or other
reason for the deduction, and the recipient. The distribution of net proceeds
shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and date of payment.
   C.   Gross receipts from the operation of raffle programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross-
receipts if licensed bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit
organization, and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall keep
separate records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts,
expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same
person who is responsible for accounting for other revenues of the
organization.
   D.   Each organization licensed to conduct a raffle under this article
shall, within sixty (60) days after the conclusion of the raffle, report its
gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the raffle, and the distribution
of net proceeds from the raffle, itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and date
of payment, to its membership and to the Raffles Commissioner.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-13: LICENSE SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION:
   A.   The Raffles Commissioner may revoke or suspend any license issued under
this article if he determines that:
      1.   The application contained a false, fraudulent or materially
misleading statement; or
      2.   The licensee, or any officer or director of licensee, has violated
any provision of this article or of law.
   B.   No such license shall be revoked or suspended except after a hearing by
the Raffles Commissioner or his designee with a three (3) day written notice to
the licensee affording an opportunity to appear, hear the violations found by
the Village and present reasons why the license should not be revoked or
suspended.
   C.   Within five (5) days after such hearing, if the raffles commissioner or
his designee determines that the license should be revoked or suspended, the
licensee shall be served with a written order of revocation or suspension
stating the reason or reasons for such determination.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-14: APPEALS:
   A.   Any decision of the Raffles Commissioner or his designee to revoke or
suspend a raffles licensee under this article may be appealed in writing to the
Village President within ten (10) days from the date of the decision. The
written appeal shall set forth the decision of the Raffles Commissioner and a
brief statement of the basis for the appeal. Any portion of the Raffles
Commissioner’s decision on a license may be appealed.
   B.   Except as provided in section 7-5A-9, waiver of bond shall only be
granted by the Village Board of Trustees upon the organization’s written
request.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-15: GAMBLING NOT AUTHORIZED:
Nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize conducting or operating
any gambling or gaming scheme, enterprise, activity or device other than
raffles as provided for herein.
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
7-5A-16: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this article shall
be subject to a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) and not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00).
(Ord. 2012-8-8H, 8-8-2012)
CHAPTER 6: PINBALL, BAGATELLE AND PIGEONHOLE GAMES
Section
7-6-1:   Definitions
7-6-2:   Games Prohibited
7-6-3:   Confiscation Of Tables And Devices
7-6-4:   Penalty
7-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
PINBALL, BAGATELLE OR PIGEONHOLE: A game played with any number of balls or
spheres upon a table or board having holes, pockets, or cups into which such
balls or spheres may drop or become lodged and having arches, pins, and
springs, or any of them, to control, deflect, or impede the direction or speed
of the balls or spheres put in motion by the player, and shall include the
modern variety of bagatelle or pigeonhole, commonly known as “pinball games”.
PLACE OF PUBLIC RESORT: Any premises wherein any service or merchandise is
offered for sale to the public or where tables or implements for playing the
game of bagatelle or pigeonhole are kept for gain or profit, or any premises
used as a clubhouse or clubrooms.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-6-2: GAMES PROHIBITED:
No person shall keep or use in any place of public resort within the Village
any tables or implements for any game of pinball, bagatelle or pigeonhole.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-6-3: CONFISCATION OF TABLES AND DEVICES:
   A.   It shall be the duty of every public safety officer to seize any table
or implement kept or used in violation of this chapter and, upon conviction of
the keeper thereof, such table or implement so seized shall be destroyed.
   B.   Any person obstructing or resisting any public safety officer in the
performance of any act authorized by this section shall be fined as provided in
section 7-6-4 of this chapter.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-6-4: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined
not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
   B.   Each day that the violation continues shall be regarded as constituting
a distinct and separate offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
CHAPTER 7: NUISANCES
Section
7-7-1:   Burying Dead Animals
7-7-2:   Offensive Premises
7-7-3:   Dumping Of Garbage
7-7-4:   Offensive Businesses
7-7-5:   Excavations
7-7-6:   Abatement Of Nuisances Generally
7-7-1: BURYING DEAD ANIMALS:
When any dead animal shall be found on any lot or part of a lot in the Village,
it shall be the duty of the person owning or occupying such lot or part of such
lot to cause the animal to be removed and buried at least four feet (4') deep;
and the owner or occupant of the lot or part of the lot, or any other person
removing the animal, may collect the expense of removal from the person owning
or depositing the dead animal, and if any owner or occupant of any lot or part
of a lot shall fail or neglect to remove the dead animal, he shall forfeit and
pay not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for every such offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-7-2: OFFENSIVE PREMISES:
If any person shall own, occupy or keep any grounds or other premises in such
condition as to be offensive to the public health of the neighborhood, he shall
be deemed guilty of a nuisance and be subject to a fine of not less than twenty
five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and
to a like fine every day such nuisance shall continue after the first
conviction.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-7-3: DUMPING OF GARBAGE:
   A.   As used in this section:
ASHES: The residue from burning of wood, coal, coke or other combustible
materials.
GARBAGE: Putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking and consumption of food.
LITTER: Any garbage, refuse, rubbish, handbills and all other waste material.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation or organization
of any kind.
REFUSE: All putrescible and non-putrescible solid wastes, except body wastes,
including garbage, rubbish and ashes.
RUBBISH: Non-putrescible solid wastes excluding ashes consisting of both
combustible and non-combustible wastes, such as paper, cardboard, tin cans,
glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials.
   B.   No person shall dump or place any garbage, ashes, litter, refuse or
rubbish which shall have originated outside the corporate limits of the Village
upon real property located within the corporate limits of the Village.
   C.   No person shall dump, deposit or place any garbage, ashes, litter,
refuse, or rubbish upon real property owned by another without the consent of
the owner or person in possession of such real property.
   D.   Any person violating this section shall be deemed guilty of a nuisance,
and upon conviction, shall forfeit and pay not less than two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 77-3-30A, 3-3-1977)
7-7-4: OFFENSIVE BUSINESSES:
   A.   No person shall carry on the business of stilling, or of rendering
lard, tallow, offal, dead animals or other substances of a like nature, or
manufacturing glue or bone dust within the limits of or within a distance of
two (2) miles of the limits of the Village.
   B.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be
deemed guilty of a nuisance and, on conviction, shall forfeit and pay not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00).
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-7-5: EXCAVATIONS:
   A.   It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and to be against the health,
peace and comfort of the Village for any person, including a private
corporation, Municipal corporation or governmental subdivision, to excavate,
dig, or otherwise cause to be removed dirt, rock, sand, debris or other
substance so as to cause a hole or depression in the surface of the earth
within the corporate limits of the Village, except in connection with the
construction of a building, structure, or other improvement pursuant to a
permit granted by the Village.
   B.   Any excavation performed pursuant to such permit must be fenced or
barricaded in such a manner as to prevent any danger as may exist to persons
coming on the land where the excavations are located.
   C.   Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each day the offense shall
continue.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
7-7-6: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCES GENERALLY:
In all cases where no provision has heretofore been made in any ordinance
heretofore adopted and now in effect in the Village defining what are
nuisances, and how the nuisances may be removed, vacated or prevented, in
addition to whatever may be declared therein as a nuisance, those offenses
which are known to the common law of the land and the Statutes of Illinois as
nuisances may, in case the nuisance exists within the limits of the Village or
within one mile thereof, be treated as such and proceeded against by the
Village in accordance with the provisions of this Code and/or in accordance
with the provisions of the Statutes of the State of Illinois providing for the
abatement of nuisances.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
CHAPTER 8: JUVENILE RELATED OFFENSES
Section
7-8-1:   Curfew
7-8-2:   Parental Responsibility For Offenses Committed By Unemancipated Minors
7-8-3:   Weapons; Delivery To And Possession By Minors
7-8-4:   Truancy
7-8-5:   Encouraging Delinquency
7-8-6:   False Identification
7-8-7:   Allowing Unlawful Use Of Motor Vehicles By Unlicensed Minor
7-8-8:   Prosecution of Violations
Cross-reference:
   See
title 6, chapter 6  of this Code for additional regulations regarding minors
7-8-1: CURFEW:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words shall be
defined as follows:
BODILY INJURY: Injury that harms or creates a substantial risk of harm to one’s
person or that causes death, disfigurement, loss or impairment of the function
of any bodily member or organ.
CURFEW HOURS: Eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on any day until five o'clock (5:00)
A.M. of the following day.
CUSTODIAN: A person who has attained the age of eighteen (18) years and who is
authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of a minor.
EMERGENCY: Any unforeseen circumstance or combination of circumstances or the
resulting state that calls for such immediate action as is necessary to protect
a person from imminent threat of bodily injury, loss of life or property from
substantial damage. The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, natural
disaster, automobile accident, medical emergency, or any situation requiring
immediate action to prevent bodily injury, loss of life or loss of property.
ESTABLISHMENT: Any privately-owned place of business operated for a profit to
which the public is invited, including, but not limited to, any restaurant,
retail establishment, place of amusement or entertainment.
GUARDIAN: A person who, by court order, is designated guardian of the person of
a minor; or a public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by a
court of competent jurisdiction.
MINOR: Any person under seventeen (17) years of age.
OPERATOR: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation
operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term includes the
members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a
corporation.
PARENT: A person who is a natural parent, adoptive parent, or step-parent of a
minor.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any place to which the public or a substantial group of the
public has access, including but not limited to streets, highways, public ways
and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings,
transport facilities, shops, parks, places of entertainment or amusement,
arenas, stadiums, and restaurants.
REMAIN: To linger or stay; or fail to leave the premises of an establishment
when requested to do so by a public safety officer or the owner, operator, or
other person in control of the establishment.
   B.   Offenses:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for:
         a.   A minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of any
establishment within the Village during curfew hours;
         b.   A parent, guardian or custodian to knowingly permit, or by
insufficient control allow a minor to remain in any public place or on the
premises of any establishment within the Village during curfew hours; or
         c.   The owner, operator, or any employee of an establishment to
knowingly allow a minor to remain upon the premises of the establishment during
curfew hours.
      2.   Defenses:
         a.   It shall be a defense to prosecution under subsection B1 in this
section that the minor was:
            (1)   Accompanied by the minor’s parent, guardian or custodian;
            (2)   On or returning from an errand at the direction of the
minor’s parent, guardian, or custodian without any unnecessary detour or stop;
            (3)   In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel;
            (4)   Engaged in an employment activity in which such minor may
lawfully engage under the laws of the State of Illinois, or traveling to or
returning home from the employment activity, without any unnecessary detour or
stop;
            (5)   Involved in an emergency;
            (6)   On the sidewalk abutting the minor’s residence, that of a
guardian or custodian, or abutting the residence of a next-door neighbor if the
neighbor does not object to the minor’s presence;
            (7)   Attending an official school, religious, or other
recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the Village, a
school, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes
responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from, without any
detour or stop, an official school, religious, or other recreational activity
supervised by adults and sponsored by the Village, a school, a civic
organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the
minor;
            (8)   Exercising rights protected by the First Amendment to the
United States Constitution or Article 1, Section 3, 4 and 5 of the Constitution
of the State of Illinois, or both, such as the free exercise of religion,
freedom of speech, and the right of assembly; or
            (9)   Married or previously married or has been declared an
emancipated minor in accordance with the Illinois Compiled Statutes.
         b.   It is a defense to prosecution under subsection B1 that the
owner, operator, or employee of an establishment promptly notified the Public
Safety Department that a minor was present on the premises of the establishment
during curfew hours and the minor refused when first requested to leave the
premises.
   C.   Enforcement: Prior to taking any enforcement action under this
subsection, a public safety officer shall inquire as to the apparent offender’s
age and reason for being in the public place. No citation shall be issued and
no arrest shall be made under this section unless the officer reasonably
believes that an offense has occurred and that based on any response of the
minor and all other circumstances known to the officer at the time, no defense
as set forth in subsection B2 exists.
   D.   Penalty: Any person who violates a provision of this section shall be
fined in an amount not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense.
(Ord. 2004-4-7N, 4-7-2004)
7-8-2: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY FOR OFFENSES COMMITTED BY UNEMANCIPATED MINORS:
   A.   Definitions: The following definitions shall apply in the
interpretation of this section:
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by a
court, but does not include a person appointed guardian or given custody of a
minor under the Juvenile Court Act, being 705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq., as amended,
in the State of Illinois.
MINOR: Any person above the age of eleven (11) but not yet eighteen (18) years
of age who has not been determined by a court or other proper authority to be
emancipated.
   B.   Exercise Of Parental Responsibility: It shall be unlawful for the
parent or legal guardian of a minor residing with such parent or legal guardian
to fail to exercise proper parental responsibility by allowing, knowingly
failing to supervise, or knowingly permitting such minor to commit any
violation of a Village ordinance or State statute concerning or relating to
battery, assault, curfew, disorderly conduct, use or possession of fireworks,
indecent exposure, intimidation, possession or use of spray paint or permanent
markers, obscene conduct, vandalism, trespass, truancy, loitering, possession,
consumption or use of alcoholic beverages, consumption or use of cannabis,
consumption or use of controlled substances, possession or use of firearms or
any other kind of weapon, or any offense involving the willful or malicious
destruction of property.
   C.   Violation: A parent or legal guardian of a minor shall be deemed to
have violated this section if:
      1.   The minor has been either adjudicated to have violated any Village
ordinance or State statute as described in subsection B of this section; or has
incurred nonjudicial sanctions from any peace officer, police officer, or
conservator of the peace resulting from an admission by, or on behalf of the
minor, that the minor committed a violation of an ordinance or state statute as
described in subsection B; and
      2.   The parent or legal guardian has received a written notice by
certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service in
substantially the following form:
      LEGAL NOTICE
      To:    (Parents’/Legal Guardians’ Names)
      From:    The Rosemont Public Safety Department
You are hereby notified that (minor’s name) has been involved in the commission
of (specify offense and date of offense), which is a violation of a State
statute or Village ordinance. If your minor child is found to have committed,
or admits to committing, another violation of a state statute or Village
ordinance concerning or relating to battery, assault, curfew, disorderly
conduct, use or possession of fireworks, indecent exposure, intimidation,
possession or use of spray paint or permanent markers, obscene conduct,
vandalism, trespass, truancy, loitering, possession, consumption or use of
alcoholic beverages, cannabis or controlled substances, possession or use of
firearms or any other kind of weapon, or any offense involving the willful or
malicious destruction of property within the next two (2) years, you will be
charged with a violation of section 7-8-2 of the Municipal Code of the Village
which imposes responsibility on parents and legal guardians for illegal acts of
minor children. Conviction for said offense can result in a fine of between
seventy five dollars ($75.00) and seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). You
are hereby notified that you must exercise proper parental responsibility over
the minor by controlling his unlawful conduct.
      3.   If the minor identified in an notice sent pursuant to subsection C2
is found to have committed or admits to committing a violation of any ordinance
or state statute as described in subsection B within two (2) years after the
minor’s parent or legal guardian receives the notice sent pursuant to
subsection C2, the parent shall be deemed to have committed a violation of
subsection B.
   D.   Notice Of Child Arrest: Whenever a minor shall be arrested or detained
for the commission of any criminal act within the Village the Public Safety
Department shall immediately notify the parent of such minor and advise the
parent of such arrest or detention, the reason therefore and his responsibility
under this section. A record of such notification shall be kept by the Public
Safety Department.
   E.   Appearance In Court: The parent or legal guardian of a minor charged
with a violation of a Village ordinance or a State statute which requires that
minor’s appearance in court or at an administrative hearing is required to
accompany the minor to court or the administrative hearing. A notice in
substantially the following form shall be sent to the parents or legal
guardians of a minor who is required to appear in court or at an administrative
hearing because the minor has been charged with violating a Village ordinance
or a State statute:
      LEGAL NOTICE
      To:      (Parents’/Legal Guardians’ Names)
      From:    The Rosemont Public Safety Department
You are hereby notified that your child or a child for whom you are the legal
guardian, (insert minor’s name), has been charged with an offense which is a
violation of a Village ordinance or a State statute, and which requires the
appearance of your child in court or at an administrative adjudication hearing.
You are further notified that one of the parents or legal guardians of said
child must appear in court or at the administrative adjudication hearing before
the matter will be tried or be disposed. If you fail to appear, the Village
Prosecutor has been directed to have a subpoena issued to require your presence
in court or at the administrative adjudication hearing. Failure to obey a
subpoena can result in contempt of court, with a fine or imprisonment as the
penalty.
   F.   Penalty: Any person convicted of any violation of the provisions of
this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than seventy-five dollars
($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense,
and in addition may be sentenced to probation or conditional discharge with the
conditions being that the parent or legal guardian make restitution or
reparation in any amount not to exceed actual the loss or damage to property or
pecuniary loss arising from the violation of a Village ordinance or State
statute. The court or the administrative hearing officer shall determine the
amount and conditions of payment. Where the conditions have not been satisfied
or payment has not been made, the court or administrative hearing officer may,
at any time prior to the expiration or termination of the period of probation
or of conditional discharge, impose an additional fine. The Village Prosecutor,
at his discretion, shall seek to nonsuit and ask for dismissal of the charge
upon satisfactory termination of the conditions of the conditional discharge
set forth by the trial judge or administrative hearing officer. In addition to
and in lieu of penalties set forth above, a period of community service not to
exceed one hundred sixty (160) hours may be imposed on a person who violates a
provision of this section. Community service may consist of one or more of the
following:
      1.   Providing manual labor for a school district, a park district or the
Village;
      2.   Completing a project involving the minor who committed a violation
of a Village ordinance or State statute as described in subsection B determined
by the court or the administrative adjudication hearing officer that is
intended to result in a positive behavioral change in the minor; and/or
      3.   Participating in training intended to result in the parent or legal
guardian becoming a more responsible and effective parent.
   G.   Injuries To Persons And Damage To Property:
      1.   Liability Of Parent: The parent or legal guardian of a minor who
resides with such parent or legal guardian is liable for actual damages for the
willful or malicious acts of such minor, which cause injury to a person or
damage to property and result from the minor committing a violation of a
Village ordinance concerning or relating to battery, assault, curfew,
disorderly conduct, use or possession of fireworks, indecent exposure,
intimidation, possession or use of spray paint or permanent markers, obscene
conduct, vandalism, trespass, truancy, loitering, possession, consumption or
use of alcoholic beverages, consumption or use of cannabis, consumption or use
of controlled substances, possession or use of firearms or any other kind of
weapon, or any offense involving the willful or malicious destruction of
property.
      2.   Recovery Of Damage Costs; Limit: Recovery of damages under this
section shall include actual damages, court costs and/or and attorneys fees. In
no event shall the amount recoverable under this section exceed the sum of two
thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
      3.   Judgments; Applicability of Other Laws: Section 12-107 of the
Illinois Code of Civil Procedure, 735 ILCS 5/12-107, as amended, is not
applicable to judgments obtained under this section.
      4.   Common Law Damages: Nothing in this subsection G shall affect the
recovery of damages in any other cause of action where the liability of the
parent or legal guardian is predicated on a common law basis.
(Ord. 2006-7-12, 7-12-2006)
7-8-3: WEAPONS; DELIVERY TO AND POSSESSION BY MINORS:
   A.   Unlawful Possession: It shall be unlawful for any person under the age
of eighteen (18) years to be in possession of any of the following items:
      1.   Bowie, switchblade, ballistic knives, throwing stars or other edged
weapons as defined in section 5/24-1(1) of the Illinois Criminal Code, 720 ILCS
5/24-1(1);
      2.   Metallic knuckles or nunchakus;
      3.   Slingshots;
      4.   Arrows designed for firing from a bow or crossbow device, except
when such person is engaged in lawful hunting, supervised target shooting or
the otherwise legal transportation of such device;
      5.   Stun gun or taser;
      6.   Any device or attachment of any kind designed, used or intended for
use in silencing the report of a firearm;
      7.   Machine gun, as defined by section 5/24-1(7) of the Illinois
Criminal Code, 720 ILCS 5/24-1(7);
      8.   Any bomb, bombshell, grenade, bottle or other container containing
an explosive substance of over one-quarter (1/4) ounce for like purposes, such
as, but not limited to, black powder bombs, Molotov cocktails, pipe bombs or
artillery projectiles;
      9.   Firearms, or the ammunition therefor, as defined by section 65/1.1
of the Illinois Firearm Owners Identification Card Act, 430 ILCS 65/1.1, except
when such person is engaged in lawful hunting, supervised target shooting, or
otherwise legal transportation of such device; or
      10.   Fireworks, as defined by section 30/2 of the Fireworks Regulation
Act of Illinois, 425 ILCS 30/2.
   B.   Delivery To Minors: It shall be unlawful for any person to deliver,
sell, give or offer to any person, under the age of eighteen (18) years, any of
the items listed in subsection A.
   C.   Penalty: Any person found guilty of a violation of any of the
provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than seventy-
five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00)
for each and every offense.
(Ord. 2006-7-12, 7-12-2006)
7-8-4: TRUANCY:
   A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following terms,
words and their derivations shall have the following meanings:
CRIMINAL ACTS: The intentional commission of an act or acts, which violate the
statutes of the State of Illinois or the ordinances of the Village.
LEGAL GUARDIAN: Any foster parent, or any person appointed guardian or
otherwise awarded custody of a minor by an Illinois court having jurisdiction
over the matter, or any person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor
under the Illinois Juvenile Court Act, 705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq., but shall not
include any person appointed guardian only of the estate of a minor.
MINOR: Any person under the age of eighteen (18).
PARENT: The father or mother of an unemancipated minor child, whether by birth
or adoption. The word PARENT as used in this section shall also be deemed to
mean legal guardian. In the event that the minor’s parents are divorced or
separated within the meaning of the Illinois Marriage and Dissolution of
Marriage Act, 750 ILCS 5/101 et seq,, the parent having lawful physical custody
of the minor shall be deemed to be the parent authorized to give consent as
required by this section.
VALID CAUSE FOR ABSENCE: Means illness, observance of a religious holiday,
death in the immediate family, family emergency and other situations beyond the
control of the minor as determined by the board of education in a given school
district, or such other circumstances which cause reasonable concern to the
parent for the health or safety of the minor.
   B.   Truancy Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for a minor who is enrolled in
a public, private or parochial school to absent himself from attendance at
school during such period when school is in session, without the permission of
his parent or legal guardian for absences for “valid cause” as defined in
subsection A5 or by the school in which the minor is enrolled. Any person who
shall so absent himself from school attendance without valid cause or parental
permission, as provided herein, shall be guilty of the offense of truancy and,
upon conviction, shall be subject to the penalties hereinafter set forth in
this section. Emergency or unforeseen absences due to illness or other causes
beyond the control of the person so absenting himself from school without
parental permission shall not constitute truancy if permission for such absence
has substantially been obtained from the parent or legal guardian and such
permission is submitted in writing to the proper school authorities within
twenty-four (24) hours after such absence.
   C.   Penalty: Any minor who shall absent himself from school attendance
without valid cause or parental permission as provided herein shall be guilty
of the offense of truancy and, upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine of
not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that such person shall absent
himself from school attendance shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2006-7-12, 7-12-2006)
7-8-5: ENCOURAGING DELINQUENCY:
   A.   Encouraging Delinquency Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person
by any act or willful omission, to encourage, aid or cause a child to violate a
Village ordinance or State statute concerning or relating to battery, assault,
curfew, disorderly conduct, use or possession of fireworks, indecent exposure,
intimidation, possession or use of spray paint or permanent markers, obscene
conduct, vandalism, trespass, truancy, loitering, possession, consumption or
use of alcoholic beverages, consumption or use of cannabis, consumption or use
of controlled substances, possession or use of firearms or any other kind of
weapon, or any offense involving the willful or malicious destruction of
property.
   B.   Penalty: Any person who shall violate section 7-8-5A shall have
committed the offense of encouraging delinquency by a minor and, upon
conviction, shall be subject to a fine of not less than seventy-five dollars
($75.00) nor more than seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense.
(Ord. 2006-7-12, 7-12-2006)
7-8-6: FALSE IDENTIFICATION:
   A.   Using False Identification Prohibited: Any underage person found guilty
of attempting to obtain delivery of an alcoholic beverage or tobacco product by
use of a false proof of age, shall be subject to a mandatory fine of seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and/or a period of community service. If the
false proof of age was an improperly used driver's license, a report shall be
filed with the Illinois Secretary of State.
   B.   Penalty: Any person who shall violate subsection A shall have committed
the offense of use of false identification by a minor and, upon conviction,
shall be subject to a fine of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each separate
incident where false identification is used by a shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord. 2006-7-12, 7-12-2006)
7-8-7: ALLOWING UNLAWFUL USE OF MOTOR VEHICLE BY UNLICENSED MINOR:
   A.   Allowing Use Of Motor Vehicle By Unlicensed Minor Or Minor Whose
License Has Been Suspended Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person, to
knowingly allow a minor who does not have a required license to operate the
motor vehicle or whose operator’s license has been suspended or revoked, to
permit such minor to operate a motor vehicle.
   B.   Penalty: Any person who shall violate subsection A shall have committed
the offense of allowing the unlawful use of a motor vehicle by a minor and,
upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine of not less than seventy-five
dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense. Each separate occurrence where an unlicensed minor or a minor whose
operator’s license has been suspended operates a motor vehicle shall constitute
a separate offense.
(Ord. 2006-7-12, 7-12-2006)
7-8-8: PROSECUTION OF VIOLATIONS:
Violations of the provisions of this chapter are subject to prosecution under
