the person named in the certified report.
   C.   1.   Any person receiving a notice of impending driver's license
suspension from the Village or a notice from the Secretary of State that the
person's driving privileges may be suspended as a result of a failure to pay
the fines set forth in five (5) or more notices of final determinations of
violations of section
8-2A-2 of this article may challenge the accuracy of the certified report
prepared by the Traffic Compliance Administrator by making a written request to
the Traffic Compliance Administrator that the Traffic Compliance Administrator
conduct an informal hearing within not more than twenty one (21) days after the
date of the notice of impending driver's license suspension or the date of the
notice from the Secretary of State. If an informal hearing is requested, the
hearing may be conducted by the Traffic Compliance Administrator or such other
person as is designated by the Superintendent of Public Safety. The hearing may
be held in person, over the telephone or by mail. At the hearing, the person
requesting the hearing shall be entitled to introduce documents and other
evidence that is intended to establish either:
         a.   That the person was not the registered owner or lessee, if the
lessee is considered the registered owner under subsection
8-2A-2A3 of this article, of the vehicle or vehicles for which five (5) or more
notices of violation of section
8-2A-2 of this article were issued on the dates of the notices; or
         b.   That the person has already paid the fine or penalty for the five
(5) or more violations of section
8-2A-2 of this article indicated on the certified report submitted to the
Secretary of State pursuant to subsection A of this section.
      2.   If the person conducting the informal hearing determines that the
person requesting the hearing was not the registered owner or lessee, if the
lessee is considered the registered owner under subsection
8-2A-2A3 of this article, of the vehicle or vehicles for which five (5) or more
notices of violation of section
8-2A-2 of this article were issued on the dates of the notices or that the
person has already paid the fine or penalty for the five (5) or more violations
of section
8-2A-2 of this article indicated on the certified report, the Traffic
Compliance Administrator shall notify the Secretary of State that the certified
report was issued in error. A certified copy of the notice informing the
Secretary of State that the certified report was issued in error shall also be
sent upon request and at no charge to the person who requested the hearing.
(Ord. 2018-5-9A, 5-9-2018)
8-2A-8: PROSECUTIONS OF VIOLATIONS:
Violations of the provisions of section
8-2A-2 of this article are subject to prosecution under the Village
administrative adjudication proceedings established pursuant to
title 1, chapter 4, article A of this Code, as now or hereafter amended. The
provisions of this section shall not preclude the Village from using other
methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of this article
including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the Circuit
Court of Cook County or before another administrative tribunal which has
jurisdiction to consider the violation.
(Ord. 2018-5-9A, 5-9-2018)
CHAPTER 3: TRAFFIC SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKINGS
Section
8-3-1:   Signs Posted
8-3-2:   Obedience Required
8-3-3:   Traffic Control Signal Legend
8-3-4:   Crosswalks
8-3-5:   Unauthorized Signs, Signals And Markings
8-3-6:   Damage To, Interference With Signs Or Signals
8-3-1: SIGNS POSTED:
The Village shall post appropriate traffic signs to notify the operators of
vehicles of the provisions of this title.
(1971 Code § 21-2)
8-3-2: OBEDIENCE REQUIRED:
No driver of any vehicle shall disobey the instructions of any traffic sign or
signal placed in view by authority of the Board of Trustees or in accordance
with the laws of the State.
(1971 Code § 21-5)
8-3-3: TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNAL LEGEND:
Whenever traffic at an intersection is regulated by the type of signal commonly
known as a stop and go signal, the following colors shall indicate the
following commands:
   A.   Red requires that traffic faced by this color shall stop and remain
standing.
   B.   Green requires that traffic faced by this color shall move and continue
in motion, except when stopped for the purposes of avoiding an accident or when
stopped at the command of a public safety officer.
   C.   Amber or yellow indicates preparation for a change in direction of
traffic movement.
   D.   When a red lens is illuminated by rapid intermittent flashes, drivers
of vehicles shall stop before entering the intersection.
   E.   When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes,
drivers of vehicles may proceed into the intersection only with extra caution.
(1971 Code § 21-6)
8-3-4: CROSSWALKS:
The Village Board, with respect to highways under its jurisdiction, may
designate any highway, roadway, part of a roadway or specified lanes upon which
crosswalk lines or crosswalk markings are to be placed, and such markings may
be placed at intersectional and nonintersectional locations, and at other
appropriate points of pedestrian concentration. All such crosswalk lines or
crosswalk markings shall conform to the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control
Devices as supplemented by the State of Illinois, and as amended from time to
time.
(Ord. 83-4-13E, 4-13-1983)
8-3-5: UNAUTHORIZED SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKINGS:
No person shall place, maintain or display any device, other than an official
warning or direction sign or signal authorized by statute, this Code or
ordinance, upon or in view of any street, if such device purports to be, or is
in imitation of, an official warning or direction sign or signal, or directs or
purports to direct the movement of traffic. Any such unauthorized device is
hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be removed by any public safety
officer.
(1971 Code § 21-7)
8-3-6: DAMAGE TO, INTERFERENCE WITH SIGNS OR SIGNALS:
No person shall deface, injure, move or interfere with an official traffic sign
or signal.
(1971 Code § 21-8)
CHAPTER 4: DRIVING RULES
Section
8-4-1:   Department Of Public Safety Vehicles
8-4-2:   Right-Of-Way
8-4-3:   Through Streets And Stop Intersections
8-4-4:   Speed Regulations
8-4-5:   Drive On Right
8-4-6:   Turning Movements
8-4-7:   Passing, Overtaking Vehicles
8-4-8:   Driver Signals
8-4-9:   Railroad Crossings
8-4-10:   General Driving Restrictions
8-4-11:   Driving On Sidewalks Or Curbs Or In Safety Zones
8-4-12:   Riding On Bicycles And Motorcycles
8-4-13:   Miscellaneous Prohibitions
8-4-14:   Reckless Driving
8-4-15:   Driving Under The Influence
8-4-1: DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY VEHICLES:
   A.   Pull Over At Sound Of Warning Devices: Upon the sounding of gongs or
warning devices used upon fire apparatus or fire patrol vehicles, drivers shall
draw their vehicles as near to the right curb as is reasonably possible and
shall remain standing until such fire apparatus has passed.
   B.   Following, Parking Near Fire Apparatus: No driver of any vehicle, other
than one on official business, shall follow any fire apparatus in response to a
fire alarm closer than five hundred feet (500'), or to park any vehicle within
five hundred feet (500') where fire apparatus has stopped to answer a fire
alarm.
   C.   Driving Over Fire Hose: No driver of any streetcar or vehicle shall
drive over any unprotected hose of the Bureau of Fire Suppression without the
consent of the Superintendent of Public Safety or the Deputy Chief of Bureau of
Fire Suppression.
(1971 Code § 21-21)
8-4-2: RIGHT-OF-WAY:
Subject to subsection
8-1-3B of this title, the driver of a vehicle shall give the right-of-way to
the driver of a vehicle approaching along an intersecting street from the right
and shall have the right-of-way over those approaching from the left.
(1971 Code § 21-20)
8-4-3: THROUGH STREETS AND STOP INTERSECTIONS:
   A.   Authority To Designate: The Superintendent of Public Safety shall be
and hereby is authorized to designate:
      1.   That streets under the Village’s jurisdiction are to be through
streets;
      2.   That certain intersections of streets under the Village’s
jurisdiction are to be stop intersections; and
      3.   To designate other locations on streets and alleys under the
jurisdiction of the Village where motor vehicles shall be required to come to a
full stop prior to proceeding.
   B.   Signs Posted:
      1.   The Director of Public Works shall be and hereby is authorized to
have stop signs erected at all appropriate locations where streets have been
designated as through streets or intersections have been designated as stop
intersections by the Superintendent of Public Safety pursuant to the authority
granted by subsection A of this section. The Director of Public Works is also
authorized to have stop signs erected at such other locations as may be
designated by the Superintendent of Public Safety pursuant to the authority
granted by subsection A of this section.
      2.   The Corporate Authorities of the Village do hereby approve, ratify
and confirm the erection of any stop sign located along a street or alley that
is under the jurisdiction of the Village which was erected prior to the
effective date hereof. The Corporate Authorities of the Village further
approve, ratify and confirm:
         a.   Any designation of a street under the Village’s jurisdiction as a
through street that occurred prior to the effective date hereof;
         b.   Any designation of an intersection of streets under the
jurisdiction of the Village as a stop intersection that occurred prior to the
effective date hereof; and
         c.   The designation of any other location where a stop sign has been
erected on streets and alleys under the jurisdiction of the Village as a place
where motor vehicles are required to come to a full stop before proceeding
further that occurred prior to the effective date hereof.
(Ord. 95-10-4H, 10-4-1995)
8-4-4: SPEED REGULATIONS:
   A.   Prudent Speed: No person shall drive a vehicle upon any public highway
at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper having regard to the traffic
and the use of the way or so as to endanger the life or limb or injure the
property of any person.
   B.   Speed Limits Established: If the rate of speed of any motor vehicle
through the business district of the Village exceeds twenty (20) miles an hour,
or if the rate of speed of any such motor vehicle operated on any public
highway where the same passes through any residence district of the Village
exceeds twenty five (25) miles an hour, or if the rate of speed of any such
motor vehicle operated on any public highway in a suburban district exceeds
thirty five (35) miles an hour, such rates of speed shall be prima facie
evidence that the person operating such motor vehicle is running at a rate of
speed greater than is reasonable and proper having regard to the traffic and
use of the way or so as to endanger the life or limb or injure the property of
any person.
(1971 Code § 21-25)
8-4-5: DRIVE ON RIGHT:
   A.   Any driver of a vehicle, upon meeting another vehicle, shall turn
toward the right side of the roadway so far as may be necessary in order to
avoid a collision with such vehicle.
   B.   No person shall operate any vehicle upon the left side of any roadway
except where necessary because of obstructions.
(1971 Code § 21-22)
8-4-6: TURNING MOVEMENTS:
   A.   Left Turns: The driver of any vehicle intending to turn to the left at
an intersection or into any alley or driveway shall approach the point of
turning in the traffic lane nearest the center of the roadway.
(1971 Code § 21-15)
   B.   Right Turns: The driver of a vehicle intending to turn to the right at
an intersection shall approach the point of turning in the traffic lane nearest
the right hand edge of curb of the roadway.
(1971 Code § 21-16)
8-4-7: PASSING, OVERTAKING VEHICLES:
Any driver of a vehicle, upon overtaking another vehicle, shall pass on the
left side of the overtaken vehicle. When requested so to do, any driver of a
vehicle traveling upon any street shall, as soon as practicable, turn to the
right so as to allow any overtaking vehicle free passage to the left of the
overtaken vehicle.
(1971 Code § 21-23)
8-4-8: DRIVER SIGNALS:
   A.   No driver of a vehicle shall suddenly start, slow down, stop or attempt
to turn without first giving a suitable signal in such a manner as to apprise
others who might be affected by his action.
   B.   The signals herein required shall be given either by means of the hand
and arm or by a signal lamp or signal device, but when a vehicle is so
constructed or loaded that a hand and arm signal would not be visible both to
the front and rear of such vehicle, then such signals must be given by a lamp
or device.
   C.   All signals herein required given by hand and arm shall be given from
the left of the vehicle in the following manner, and such signals shall
indicate as follows:
      1.   Left turn: Hand and arm extended horizontally.
      2.   Right turn: Hand and arm extended upward.
      3.   Stop or decrease of speed: Hand and arm extended downward.
(1971 Code § 21-17)
8-4-9: RAILROAD CROSSINGS:
   A.   The driver of a vehicle approaching a railroad grade crossing when a
signal device gives warning of the immediate approach of a train, shall stop
within fifty feet (50') but not less than fifteen feet (15') from the nearest
track of such railroad and shall not proceed until he can do so safely.
   B.   The driver of a vehicle shall stop and remain standing and not traverse
such grade crossing when a crossing gate is lowered or when a flagger gives a
signal of the approach of a train.
   C.   The driver of any motor vehicle carrying passengers for hire, or any
school bus, or of any vehicle carrying explosives or flammable liquids as cargo
shall stop such vehicle within fifty feet (50') but not less than fifteen feet
(15') from the tracks and shall listen and look in both directions from which a
train might come before proceeding across such tracks at a grade crossing.
(1971 Code § 21-33)
8-4-10: GENERAL DRIVING RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Obstructing Traffic: No vehicle shall be operated or allowed to remain
upon any street in such a way as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the
traffic thereon.
(1971 Code § 21-26)
   B.   Emerging From Alleys, Driveways Or Garages: The driver of a vehicle
emerging from an alley, driveway or garage shall stop the vehicle immediately
prior to driving onto a sidewalk or across a sidewalk line projected across an
alley, sound the horn of the vehicle, and exercise unusual care in driving upon
the sidewalk or across the line.
(1971 Code § 21-18)
   C.   Unattended Vehicles: Except for a law enforcement officer or an
operator of an authorized emergency vehicle while performing his official
duties, no person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to
stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition,
removing the key from the ignition, effectively setting the brake thereon and,
when standing upon any perceptible grade, turning the front wheels to the curb
or side of the highway. An unattended motor vehicle shall not include an
unattended locked motor vehicle with the engine running after being started by
a remote starter system.
(1971 Code § 21-27)
8-4-11: DRIVING ON SIDEWALKS OR CURBS OR IN SAFETY ZONES:
   A.   No driver of a vehicle shall drive within any sidewalk area, except at
a permanent or temporary driveway, nor at any time into or upon any portion of
a roadway marked as a safety zone.
   B.   No person shall drive a vehicle upon, across or over any public
sidewalk or public curb in the Village where no provision has been made for
crossing any sidewalk or curb by the construction of a suitable driveway or
crossing.
(1971 Code § 21-19)
   C.   No person shall drive over any curb and gutter except at a permanent
driveway designed and approved by the Village Engineer or when a special permit
has been issued by the Director of Building and Code Enforcement.
(1971 Code § 21-34)
8-4-12: RIDING ON BICYCLES AND MOTORCYCLES:
Only one person shall ride upon any bicycle propelled by human power upon any
street, and no person shall ride upon any motorcycle except upon a seat
attached to the motorcycle.
(1971 Code § 21-27)
8-4-13: MISCELLANEOUS PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Clinging To Vehicles: No person on any street riding a bicycle,
motorcycle or any toy vehicle shall cling to or attach himself or his vehicle
to any moving vehicle or wagon.
(1971 Code § 21-29)
   B.   Toy Vehicles: No person upon skates, a coaster, sled or other toy
vehicle shall go upon any roadway other than at a crosswalk.
(1971 Code § 21-30)
   C.   Riding On Fenders Or Running Boards: No person shall ride upon the
fenders, running board or outside step of any vehicle.
(1971 Code § 21-31)
8-4-14: RECKLESS DRIVING:
No person shall operate any vehicle in the Village in a reckless or wanton
manner or so as to unnecessarily endanger life or property; or knowingly drive
a vehicle and uses an incline in a roadway, such as a railroad crossing, bridge
approach, or hill, to cause the vehicle to become airborne.
(1971 Code § 21-24)
8-4-15: DRIVING UNDER THE INFLUENCE:
   A.   A person shall not drive or be in actual physical control of any
vehicle within the Village while:
(Ord. 83-4-13D, 4-13-1983)
      1.   The alcohol concentration in such person’s blood or breath is 0.10
or more based on the definition of blood and breath units contained in 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501.2.
(Ord. 83-4-13D, 4-13-1983; amd. 2019 Code)
      2.   Under the influence of alcohol.
      3.   Under the influence of any other drug or combination of drugs to a
degree which renders such person incapable of safely driving.
      4.   Under the combined influence of alcohol and any other drug or drugs
to a degree which renders such person incapable of safely driving.
   B.   The fact that any person charged with violating this section is or has
been legally entitled to use alcohol or other drugs, or any combination of
both, shall not constitute a defense against any charge of violating this
section.
(Ord. 83-4-13D, 4-13-1984)
   C.   Every person convicted of violating this section shall be guilty of a
Class A misdemeanor and shall be sentenced according to the provisions of 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes.
(Ord. 83-4-13D, 4-13-1984; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 5: PARKING REGULATIONS
Section
8-5-1:   Method Of Parking
8-5-2:   Parking Prohibited In Specified Places
8-5-3:   Permit Parking
8-5-4:   Parking In Spaces Reserved For Persons With Disabilities
8-5-5:   Parking During Snowfall
8-5-6:   Fire Lanes
8-5-7:   Commercial Vehicle Parking And Storage
8-5-8:   Parking During Loading Or Unloading
8-5-9:   Parking Lots
8-5-9-1:    Municipal Parking Lots Generally
8-5-1: METHOD OF PARKING:
   A.   No vehicle shall be parked with the left side of such vehicle next to
the curb.
   B.   No person shall stand or park any vehicle in a street other than
parallel with the curb and with the two (2) right wheels of the vehicle within
twelve inches (12") of the regularly established curb line; except, that upon
those streets that have been marked for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked
at the angle to the curb indicated by such marks.
(1971 Code § 21-52)
8-5-2: PARKING PROHIBITED IN SPECIFIED PLACES:
At any time, no person shall permit any vehicle to stand in any of the
following places except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or
in compliance with the direction of a public safety officer or a traffic signal
or when otherwise authorized by law:
   A.   In any intersection.
   B.   In a crosswalk.
   C.   Upon any bridge or viaduct or the approach thereto.
   D.   Where there are two (2) lanes designated for moving traffic on a street
or highway so as to prevent other vehicles from using a lane designated for
moving traffic.
   E.   Within thirty feet (30') of a traffic signal or a through street sign
on the approaching side.
   F.   Within twenty feet (20') of any intersection.
   G.   At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce the paved
width of a street or highway that can be used by moving traffic to less than
eighteen feet (18').
   H.   At any place within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant or any fire
connection or similar water outlet which is designed to provide a source of
water to be used in the case of fire or within a designated fire lane.
   I.   At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway.
   J.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad grade
crossing.
   K.   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire station
and on the side of the street opposite the entrance of a fire station within
seventy five feet (75') of such entrance.
   L.   On a sidewalk or other walkway designated or designed for use of
pedestrians or nonmotorized vehicles.
   M.   At any place within a Village owned or operated parking lot or parking
structure so as to occupy two (2) or more designated parking spaces or so as to
prevent the use of a designated parking space by another vehicle, other than
the designated parking space in which the vehicle is parked.
   N.   At any place within a Village owned or operated parking lot or parking
structure that is not a designated parking space.
   O.   Where signs posted by the Village or other official signs state that
parking is restricted or limited and the vehicle does not meet the applicable
restrictions or limitations.
   P.   Where signs posted by the Village or other official signs state that
parking is prohibited.
(Ord. 2001-10-3C, 10-3-2001)
8-5-3: PERMIT PARKING:
   A.   Residential Streets: It shall be unlawful for any person to park any
vehicle at any time on a residential street within the Village without first
having notified and secured permission from the Department of Public Safety to
park said vehicle.
(Ord. 94-7-6A, 7-6-1994)
   B.   Nonresidential Streets:
      1.   Authority To Designate: The Superintendent of Public Safety shall be
and hereby is authorized to designate and establish locations where on street
parking of motor vehicles shall be allowed by permit only; provided, that no
location within an area that is classified as being within a residential zoning
district under the Village zoning ordinance and map shall be designated as a
location where on street parking of motor vehicles is allowed by permit only
unless the Village Corporate Authorities have approved such designation.
      2.   Signs Posted: The Superintendent of Public Safety and the Director
of Public Works are authorized and directed to erect signs along the curbs of
those areas that have been designated for permit parking only. Such signs shall
be designed to inform persons using the street where the sign is located that
parking a vehicle on the street is prohibited unless the vehicle displays a
permit allowing it to park on the street. No citation or complaint shall be
issued for parking a vehicle on a street in an area where on street parking is
allowed only if the vehicle displays a permit, unless signs have been installed
along the street which are designed to inform the public that parking on the
street is allowed only if a vehicle displays a permit.
      3.   Permit Requirements:
         a.   The Superintendent of Public Safety is authorized to issue
permits which will allow a vehicle to be parked on a street that has been
designated as a street where a vehicle can be parked only if it displays a
permit.
         b.   The Superintendent of Public Safety is directed to develop and
authorized to issue and enforce rules and regulations for the issuance of
permits that will allow a vehicle to be parked on a street where parking is
limited to vehicles which display a permit.
         c.   The rules and regulations shall be designed so as to provide that
permits to park on the street are issued primarily to Village officials and
other persons for whom it is regularly necessary and convenient to be able to
park on the street for periods of time not exceeding three (3) hours in order
to transact business relating to the Village. The rules and regulations shall
not provide for the issuance of permits for the primary purpose of allowing a
person who is not a Village officer or employee to avoid having to pay a fee to
park in a garage, parking lot or other parking structure.
      4.   Penalties:
         a.   Fine: The owner and operator of a parked motor vehicle which does
not display a required permit and is parked on a street at a location where
parking is allowed only if a permit is displayed shall, upon conviction, be
jointly and severally subject to being fined up to twenty five dollars ($25.00)
for each one hour period or portion thereof that the motor vehicle was parked
on the street.
         b.   Towing Vehicle: In addition to any penalty or fine to which the
owner or operator of the motor vehicle may be subject, if a motor vehicle is
parked in violation of the permit parking requirements contained in this
subsection or any rules or regulations issued pursuant to this subsection for a
period of more than two (2) hours, the motor vehicle shall be subject to being
towed or otherwise relocated at the sole risk and expense of the owner or
operator of the vehicle. The owner and operator of the motor vehicle towed
pursuant to this subsection shall be jointly and severally liable for the
payment of any towing fees which may be incurred.
(Ord. 2001-8-1D, 8-1-2001)
8-5-4: PARKING IN SPACES RESERVED FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES:
   A.   1. It shall be prohibited to park any motor vehicle which is not
properly displaying registration plates or digital registration plates or
decals issued to a “person with disabilities”, as defined by 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-159.1, pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-
616, 5/11-1301.1 or 5/11-1301.2, or to a disabled veteran pursuant to 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-609, as evidence that the vehicle is operated by
or for a person with disabilities or a disabled veteran, in any parking place,
including any private or public off street parking facility, specifically
reserved by the posting of an official sign as designated under 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-301 for motor vehicles displaying such registration
plates. It shall be prohibited to park any motor vehicle in a designated access
aisle adjacent to any parking place specifically reserved for persons with
disabilities by the posting of an official sign as designated under 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-301 for motor vehicles displaying such
registration plates. When using the parking privileges for persons with
disabilities, the parking decal or device must be displayed properly in the
vehicle where it is clearly visible to law enforcement personnel, either
hanging from the rearview mirror or placed on the dashboard of the vehicle in
clear view. Any motor vehicle properly displaying a disability license plate or
a parking decal or device containing the international symbol of access issued
to persons with disabilities by any local authority, state, district, territory
or foreign country shall be recognized as a valid license plate or device and
receive the same parking privileges as residents of Illinois.
      2.   An individual with a vehicle displaying disability license plates or
digital registration plates or a parking decal or device issued to a qualified
person with a disability under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-616, 5/11-
1301.1, or 5/11-1301.2 or to a disabled veteran under 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3-609 is in violation of this subsection if: a) the person using the
disability license plate or parking decal or device is not the authorized
holder of the disability license plate or parking decal or device or is not
transporting the authorized holder of the disability license plate or parking
decal or device to or from the parking location; and b) the person uses the
disability license plate or parking decal or device to exercise any privileges
granted through the disability license plate or parking decal or device under
this Code or the Illinois Vehicle Code.
(Ord. 2006-2-1F, 2-1-2006)
   B.   1. Any person or municipality owning or operating any public or private
off street parking facility may, after notifying the Department of Public
Safety, remove or cause to be removed to the nearest garage or other place of
safety any vehicle parked within a stall or space reserved for use by the
physically handicapped which does not display handicapped registration plates,
digital registration plates, or decals as required under subsection A of this
section.
      2.   The Village may remove or cause to be removed to the nearest garage
or other place of safety any vehicle which does not display the registration
plates, digital registration plates or decals as specified parked within a
stall or space on a public street reserved for use by persons with
disabilities.
      3.   No vehicle shall be removed or caused to be removed as set forth
herein from a public street unless such parking space is marked with an
appropriate sign setting forth that improperly parked vehicles may be towed
from such parking space.
(Ord. 85-3-6C, 3-6-1985)
8-5-5: PARKING DURING SNOWFALL:
   A.   Parking Prohibited: No person shall park any vehicle on any street or
alley in the Village for a period of more than five (5) minutes if there has
been a snowfall with an accumulation of greater than three inches (3") during
the preceding forty eight (48) hours.
   B.   Signs Posted: The Public Works Department is authorized and directed to
post signs which are intended to inform persons entering the Village that
vehicles parked on Village streets and alleys are subject to being towed if
there has been a snowfall of more than three inches (3") during the previous
forty eight (48) hours.
   C.   Impoundment And Towing Of Vehicle:
      1.   The Public Safety Department is authorized to impound and cause to
be towed by a towing service any vehicle which is parked in violation of
subsection A of this section.
      2.   The provisions of chapter 9 of this title relating to the towing and
disposition of inoperable motor vehicles shall be applicable to vehicles towed
pursuant to this section.
   D.   Fine And Costs: Any person who violates subsection A of this section
shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
violation. This fine shall be levied in addition to any towing and storage
charges that may have been incurred.
(Ord. 79-12-19B, 12-19-1979)
8-5-6: FIRE LANES:
   A.   Designation; Signs Posted: All privately owned alleys, streets and
driveways less than twenty feet (20') in width located on property used for
industrial or commercial purposes or located adjacent to or on the same lot as
a multi-family residential building containing four (4) or more dwelling units
are hereby designated as fire lanes. For purposes of this section, the width of
an alley, street or driveway shall be measured at its narrowest point from the
edge of the pavement to the edge of the pavement or, if unpaved, from the edge
of the driving surface to the edge of the driving surface.
(Ord. 88-10-5F, 10-5-1988)
   B.   Parking Prohibited: No vehicle shall be parked or stopped in a
designated fire lane except for an “authorized emergency vehicle” as defined by
the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code.
   C.   Signs Posted:
      1.   The owner of the premises on which a fire lane is located shall post
and maintain, or cause to be posted and maintained, signs along the curbs and
sides of the fire lane which state “Fire Lane/No Parking/No Stopping/At Any
Time”.
      2.   The signs shall be erected or placed along each curb or side of the
fire lane at least once each fifty feet (50').
      3.   The signs shall be not less than twelve inches by eighteen inches
(12" x 18") and shall have white lettering on a red background or shall be of
such other size and design as approved by the Deputy Chief of the Bureau of
Fire Suppression of the Village Public Safety Department.
   D.   Penalty: Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall,
upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each violation.
For purposes of this section, a separate and distinct violation of subsection B
of this section shall occur for each thirty (30) minute period or part thereof
during which a vehicle is parked or stopped in violation of said subsection B,
and a separate and distinct violation of subsection C of this section shall
occur on each day or part thereof that signs are not erected or maintained in
violation of said subsections C.
(Ord. 88-3-2H, 3-2-1988)
8-5-7: COMMERCIAL VEHICLE PARKING AND STORAGE:
   A.   Definition: Whenever the term “commercial vehicle” is used in this
section, it shall be construed to include all trucks, trailers, semitrailers
and motor coaches which are designated for use and equipped for carrying goods,
freight, wares, merchandise or more than seven (7) passengers.
(1971 Code § 21-48)
   B.   Restricted Parking:
      1.   No person shall park any commercial vehicle on or upon any street,
alley or public way within the Village limits between the hours of nine o'clock
(9:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
      2.   Any commercial vehicle may park on such streets, alleys or public
ways for the purpose of loading or unloading during such hours for a period of
time not to exceed thirty (30) minutes.
(1971 Code § 21-51)
   C.   Storage Of Commercial Vehicle: No person shall park or store any truck,
trailer, bus or other commercial vehicle on any premises within the Village
which is zoned for commercial or residential use unless such truck, trailer,
bus or other commercial vehicle is housed in a garage or other structure.
(1971 Code § 21-50)
8-5-8: PARKING DURING LOADING OR UNLOADING:
   A.   Parking may be permitted for reasonably expeditious loading or
unloading of passengers, provided such loading or unloading shall not consume
more than five (5) minutes, or to stand any commercial vehicle for a period of
time longer than is necessary for the reasonably expeditious loading, unloading
and delivery or pick up of goods or materials, provided such loading, unloading
and delivery or pick up shall not consume more than thirty (30) minutes on any
street in the Village.
(1971 Code § 21-55)
   B.   During the times specified herein it shall be unlawful for the driver
of a vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for a period of time longer than is
necessary for the loading or unloading of passengers, not to exceed three (3)
minutes, and for the driver to stand any freight carrying vehicle for a period
of time longer than is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials, not to
exceed thirty (30) minutes, in any of the following places:
      1.   Any public alley, during any hours of the day or night.
      2.   At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb
before the entrance to any hospital or hotel at any time.
      3.   At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb
before the entrance to a public building between eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) P.M., except on Sunday.
      4.   Directly in front of the entrance to any theater at any time the
theater is open for business.
(1971 Code § 21-56)
8-5-9: PARKING LOTS:
8-5-9-1: MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS GENERALLY:
   A.   Signs Posted: The Director of Public Works, with the approval of the
Village Engineer and Village President, is hereby authorized to erect official
signs establishing the days and/or overnight hours during which it is unlawful
to park a motor vehicle in a Village owned parking structure or parking lot.
Such official signs establishing overnight parking restrictions shall be posted
in locations reasonably visible to vehicle drivers entering the restricted
parking structure or parking lot.
   B.   Exemptions: The restriction set forth in subsection A of this section
shall not apply to vehicles bearing parking permits issued by the Village
authorizing overnight parking of the motor vehicle in the Village parking
structure or parking lot, or to motor vehicles registered to the Village.
   C.   Parking Lots For Village Employees, Visitors And Commercial Property
Tenants:
      1.   The Director of Public Works, with the approval of the Mayor, is
authorized to erect official signs in Village owned and operated parking
structures or parking lots making it unlawful for persons other than: a)
Village employees and visitors; and b) Village commercial property tenants and
their guests and invitees to park a motor vehicle in such parking structure or
parking lot, or in specified areas of such parking structure or parking lot.
      2.   The restrictions may include, but are not limited to, the assignment
of parking spaces to Village employees and visitors and/or to commercial
tenants and their guests and invitees during specified hours and days, and/or
restricting parking to vehicles displaying Village issued parking passes.
      3.   The official signs establishing parking restrictions for Village
commercial property parking structures or parking lots shall be posted in
locations to reasonably advise vehicle drivers entering the restricted parking
structure or parking lot of the parking spaces or areas that are reserved for:
a) Village employees and visitors; or b) Village commercial property tenants
and their guests and invitees and, if applicable, the hours or days such
parking restrictions are in effect.
   F.   Violations:
      1.   Prima Facie Proof: Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in
violation of the provisions of this section, the person in whose name such
vehicle is registered shall be subject to and responsible for the penalty for
such violation.
      2.   Nuisance Declared; Impoundment Of Vehicle: A vehicle parked in a
Village owned parking structure or parking lot in violation of any of the
provisions of this section is hereby declared to be a nuisance, which may be
abated by any public safety officer by impounding the vehicle and by removing
and conveying the vehicle, or by causing the vehicle to be removed and
conveyed, to a vehicle pound. A vehicle pound is hereby declared to be any
suitable place designated by the Public Safety Department as a vehicle pound.
The owner or operator of the vehicle may have the same removed from the vehicle
pound by paying the costs and expense of the towage or impounding the vehicle,
together with all fines and penalties, as provided in this title. In all cases
of violations referred to in this section, the right to impound shall be in
addition to any other remedy provided in this title or any other remedy
provided by law, and the registered owner of the vehicle at the time of the
violation shall be presumed to be the violator, as well as the vehicle itself,
and the actual operator thereof.
   G.   Penalty: Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be
subject to a minimum fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and a maximum
fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 2015-4-8V, 4-8-2015)
CHAPTER 6: PEDESTRIANS
Section
8-6-1:   Application Of Traffic Regulations
8-6-2:   Right-Of-Way
8-6-3:   Use Of Roadways
8-6-4:   Use Of Sidewalks
8-6-1: APPLICATION OF TRAFFIC REGULATIONS:
At intersections where traffic is directed by a public safety officer or by a
stop and go signal, no pedestrian shall cross the roadway other than with
released traffic if such crossing interferes with the lawful movement of
traffic.
(1971 Code § 21-13)
8-6-2: RIGHT-OF-WAY:
   A.   No driver of any vehicle shall drive into any crosswalk without the
exercise of due and proper care in view of the special use made thereof by
pedestrians.
   B.   No person shall drive any vehicle into any crosswalk while there is in
the crosswalk upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling
any pedestrian engaged in crossing the roadway until the pedestrian shall have
passed beyond the path of the vehicle when the pedestrian shall indicate his
intention to cross.
   C.   The driver of a vehicle shall stop before entering any crosswalk when
any other vehicle proceeding in the same direction is stopped at the crosswalk
for the purpose of permitting a pedestrian to cross.
(1971 Code § 21-11)
8-6-3: USE OF ROADWAYS:
   A.   At no place shall a pedestrian cross any roadway other than by the most
direct route to the opposite curbing, and when crossing at any place other than
a crosswalk, he shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway.
   B.   No person shall stand or loiter in any roadway other than in a safety
zone if such act interferes with the lawful movement of traffic.
   C.   No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride
from the driver of any vehicle.
(1971 Code § 21-12)
8-6-4: USE OF SIDEWALKS:
No pedestrian shall stand upon any sidewalk except as near as is reasonably
possible to the building line or curb line if such standing interferes with the
use of the sidewalk by other pedestrians.
(1971 Code § 21-14)
CHAPTER 7: VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND CONDITION
Section
8-7-1:   Compliance With Provisions
8-7-2:   Definitions
8-7-3:   Clear Vision; Mirror
8-7-4:   Lights
8-7-5:   Brakes
8-7-6:   Tires; Nonskid Devices
8-7-7:   Horn And Warning Devices
8-7-8:   Noise And Emissions Control
8-7-1: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
It is unlawful for any person to drive or move on, upon or across, or for the
owner to cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved on, upon or across,
any highway any vehicle or vehicles of a size and weight exceeding the
limitations stated in this chapter, including article A, or otherwise in
violation of this chapter, including article A.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
8-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, including article A, the following words and
terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
DEPARTMENT: Department of Transportation of the State of Illinois acting
directly or through its duly authorized officers and agents.
LOCAL AUTHORITY: Every county, municipal and other local board or body having
authority to adopt local police regulations under the Constitution and laws of
this State other than the corporate authorities of park districts.
MOTOR VEHICLE TRANSPORT: Any motor vehicle, singly or in lawful combination,
specially designed to transport other motor vehicles or bodies, commonly
referred to as a truckaway or haulaway operation and not including the
driveaway or towaway operations of a transporter.
PUBLIC UTILITY: Each firm lawfully licensed and engaged in any of the
following: the transmission of telephonic messages; the production, storage,
transmission, distribution, sale, delivery or furnishing of heat, cold, light,
power, electricity, gas or water; the disposal of sewage; the conveyance of oil
or gas by pipeline; the drilling of water wells; or the installation or repair
of facilities for any of the foregoing activities.
STREET OR HIGHWAY: The entire width between boundary lines of every way or
place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the public
as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular traffic, other than public ways
for vehicular traffic, within a park district for which the park district has
maintenance responsibility, excepting the Chicago Park District.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
8-7-3: CLEAR VISION; MIRROR:
No person shall operate any vehicle which is so loaded or in such a condition
that the operator does not have clear vision of all parts of the roadway
essential to the safe operation of the vehicle. Any vehicle that is so
constructed or loaded that the driver's view of the roadway to the rear is
obstructed shall be equipped with a mirror so attached as to give him a view of
the roadway behind him.
(1971 Code § 21-37)
8-7-4: LIGHTS:
No person shall operate or park on any street any vehicle not equipped with
adequate lights conforming to the requirements of State law.
(1971 Code § 21-44)
8-7-5: BRAKES:
No person shall drive any motor vehicle upon any street unless such vehicle is
equipped with good and sufficient brakes in good working condition, as required
by State law, or operate any vehicle which is so loaded so that the operator
does not have ready access to the mechanism operating the brakes of the
vehicle.
(1971 Code § 21-42)
8-7-6: TIRES; NONSKID DEVICES:
   A.   Tires: No person shall operate any motor vehicle on any street which is
not equipped with tires conforming to the requirements of State law.
(1971 Code § 21-46)
   B.   Nonskid Devices: No person shall operate any motor vehicle upon any
street equipped with any nonskid device so constructed that any rigid or
nonflexible portion thereof comes in contact with the pavement or roadway.
(1971 Code § 21-45)
8-7-7: HORN AND WARNING DEVICES:
   A.   Every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a good and sufficient
audible signaling device in efficient working condition. Such signaling device
shall be sounded when necessary to give timely warning of the approach of a
vehicle, but the horn or other signaling device shall not be sounded for any
purpose other than as a warning of impending danger.
   B.   No motor vehicle, other than an emergency vehicle, shall be equipped
with a siren or gong signaling device.
(1971 Code § 21-39)
8-7-8: NOISE AND EMISSIONS CONTROL:
   A.   Mufflers; Use Of Cutout Prohibited: No motor vehicle shall be operated
on any street unless the vehicle is provided with a muffler in efficient actual
working condition. The use of a cutout is prohibited.
(1971 Code § 21-43)
   B.   Noisy Vehicles Prohibited: No person shall operate a vehicle on the
streets which makes unusually loud or raucous noises.
(1971 Code § 21-38)
   C.   Prohibited Emissions: No person shall operate any vehicle which emits
dense smoke or such an amount of smoke or fumes as to be dangerous to the
health of persons or as to endanger the driver of other vehicles.
(1971 Code § 21-40)
   D.   It is hereby declared to be a nuisance for any person to violate the
provisions of this section. Any person who shall violate any of the provisions
of this section shall be fine not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2017-10-11D, 10-11-2017)
Cross-reference:
   See also section 7-7-8 of this Code
ARTICLE A: VEHICLE SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD
Section
8-7A-1:   Height
8-7A-2:   Length And Width; Projecting Loads
8-7A-3:   Vehicles Being Towed
8-7A-4:   Weight Limitations
8-7A-5:   Identification Of Second Division Vehicles
8-7A-6:   Truck Routes
8-7A-7:   Planking Edge Of Pavement
8-7A-8:   Spilling Loads
8-7A-9:   Officers To Weigh Vehicles; Removal Of Excess Loads Required
8-7A-10:   Exemptions
8-7A-11:   Violations; Penalties
8-7A-1: HEIGHT:
The height of a vehicle from the under side of the tire to the top of the
vehicle, inclusive of load, shall not exceed thirteen feet six inches (13'6").
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
8-7A-2: LENGTH AND WIDTH; PROJECTING LOADS:
   A.   The maximum width of any vehicle and its load shall not exceed eight
feet (8') excepting loads of loose hay, straw, corn fodder, or similar farm
products, agricultural implements and threshing machines.
   B.   No passenger type vehicle shall be operated on the streets with a load
extending beyond the line of the fenders on the left side of the vehicle nor
extending more than six inches (6") beyond the line of the fenders on the right
side thereof.
   C.   No vehicle, empty or with a load, shall exceed a length of thirty five
feet (35') overall dimension. A truck-tractor and a semitrailer shall be
regarded as one vehicle for the purpose of determining length.
   D.   No combination of vehicles coupled together shall consist of more than
two (2) units, and no such combination of vehicles, empty or with a load, shall
exceed the total length of forty feet (40'), but such length limitation shall
not apply to vehicles operated in the daytime when transporting poles, pipes,
machinery or other objects which cannot be readily dismembered, nor to such
vehicles operated at night by a public utility when engaged in emergency repair
work. Such loads carried at night shall be clearly marked with sufficient
lights to show the full dimensions of the load.
   E.   No part of the load of a vehicle shall extend more than three feet (3')
in front of the extreme front portion of the vehicle.
(1971 Code § 21-41)
8-7A-3: VEHICLES BEING TOWED:
   A.   When one vehicle is towing another, the drawbar or other connection
shall be of sufficient strength to pull all the weight towed thereby, and the
drawbar or other connection shall not exceed fifteen feet (15') from one
vehicle to the other, except for the connection between any two (2) vehicles
transporting poles, pipes, machinery or other objects of structural nature
which cannot readily be dismembered.
   B.   Outside a business, residential or suburban district or on any
controlled access highway, no vehicle other than a pole trailer or a
semitrailer which is being towed by a truck-tractor and is connected by the
means of a fifth wheel shall be towed on a roadway except by a drawbar, and
each such vehicle so towed shall, in addition, be coupled with two (2) safety
chains or cables to the towing vehicle. Such chains or cables shall be of
sufficient size and strength to prevent the towed vehicle parting from the
drawing vehicle in case the drawbar should break or become disengaged.
   C.   The provisions of this section shall not apply to any second division
vehicle owned, operated or controlled by any person who is registered with the
Bureau of Motor Carrier Safety of the Federal Highway Administration and has
complied with the Federal safety provisions of the Bureau of Motor Carrier
Safety of the Federal Highway Administration and the rules and regulations of
the Bureau.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
8-7A-4: WEIGHT LIMITATIONS:
   A.   Compliance With State And County Laws: No person shall drive on any
State or County highway any motor vehicle with a weight, including load, in
excess of that permitted by the State or County traffic laws for driving on
improved State or County highways or with the weight distributed in a manner
not conforming to law.
(1971 Code § 21-47)
   B.   Wheel And Axle Loads And Gross Weights:
      1.   a. No vehicle or combination of vehicles equipped with pneumatic
tires shall be operated, unladen or with load, upon the highways of this State
when the gross weight on the road surface through any axle thereof exceeds
sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds; provided, that upon any street or highway
included in the system of State highways and constructed of concrete, brick on
a concrete base or asphalt on a concrete base, which the department designates
as adequate to carry such a maximum gross weight without undue deterioration or
which the department designates as obsolete and requiring reconstruction, or
upon any street in the Village, the gross weight on the road surface through
any axle may exceed sixteen thousand pounds (16,000) pounds but shall not
exceed eighteen thousand pounds (18,000) pounds per axle. No vehicle or
combination of vehicles equipped with other than pneumatic tires shall be
operated, unladen or with load, upon the highways of this State when the gross
weight on the road surface through any wheel thereof exceeds eight hundred
(800) pounds per inch width of tire tread or when the gross weight on the road
surface through any axle thereof exceeds sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds. An
"axle load" shall be defined as the total load transmitted to the road by all
wheels whose centers may be included between two (2) parallel transverse
vertical planes forty inches (40") apart extending across the full width of the
vehicle.
         b.   Any two (2) or more consecutive axles whose centers are more than
forty inches (40") and not more than seventy two inches (72") apart, measured
to the nearest inch between any two (2) adjacent axles in the series, shall be
defined as “tandem axles”, and the gross weight transmitted to the road surface
through such series shall not exceed thirty two thousand (32,000) pounds, and
no axle of the series shall exceed the maximum weight permitted under this
subsection for a single axle.
         c.   A truck specially equipped with a self-compactor and used
exclusively for garbage or refuse operations may, however, when laden with
garbage or refuse, transmit upon the road surface of any highway, except when
part of the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways, a gross weight
upon a single axle not more than twenty two thousand (22,000) pounds and upon a
tandem axle not more than forty thousand (40,000) pounds. When unladen,
however, such trucks shall comply with the axle limitations applicable to all
other trucks.
      2.   The gross weight of vehicles and combination of vehicles, including
the weight of the vehicle or combination and its maximum load, shall be subject
to the foregoing limitations and further shall not exceed the following gross
weights dependent upon the number of axles and distance between extreme axles
of the vehicle or combination measured longitudinally to the nearest foot:
Vehicles having 2 axles: 36,000 pounds

      3.   Weight limitations shall not apply to vehicles (including loads)
operated by a public utility when transporting equipment required for emergency
repair of public utility facilities or properties or water wells nor to a
combination of vehicles consisting of a tow truck and a disabled vehicle or
vehicles when engaged in towing such disabled vehicle or vehicles from the
highway to the nearest qualified repair station; provided, that neither the
disabled vehicle, nor any vehicle being towed, nor the tow truck itself shall
exceed the weight limitations permitted under this subsection. However, nothing
in this subsection shall prohibit a tow truck, under instructions of a public
safety officer, from legally clearing a disabled vehicle that may be in
violation of weight limitations of this subsection from the roadway to the berm
or shoulder of the highway.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
      4.   No vehicle or combination of vehicles equipped with pneumatic tires
shall be operated, unladen or with load, upon the highways of the Village in
violation of the provisions of any permit issued under the provisions of 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-301 through 5/15-319.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982; amd. 2019 Code)
      5.   a. Notwithstanding any other provision in this subsection, the
weight limitations contained in this subsection B5 shall apply to the National
System of Interstate and Defense Highways and other highways in the system of
State highways that have been designated by the department. No vehicle shall be
operated on said highways with a weight in excess of twenty thousand (20,000)
pounds carried on any one axle, or with a tandem axle weight in excess of
thirty four thousand (34,000) pounds, or a gross weight in excess of eighty
thousand (80,0000) pounds for vehicle combinations of five (5) axles or more,
or a gross weight on a group of two (2) or more consecutive axles in excess of
that weight produced by the application of the following formula:
W = 500 times the sum of (LN divided by N-1) + 12N + 36 where “W” equals the
overall gross weight on any group of two (2) or more consecutive axles to the
nearest five hundred (500) pounds; “L” equals the distance measured to the
nearest foot between extremes of any group of two (2) or more consecutive
axles; and “N” equals the number of axles in the group under consideration;
except, that two (2) consecutive sets of tandem axles may carry a gross load of
thirty four thousand (34,000) pounds each, provided the overall distance
between the first and last axles of such consecutive sets of tandem axles is
thirty six feet (36') or more. Provided, also, that a three (3) axle vehicle
manufactured prior to the model year of 1984, and first registered in Illinois
prior to January 1, 1985, with a distance greater than seventy two inches (72")
but not more than ninety six inches (96") between the two (2) rear axles may
transmit to the road surface a maximum weight of eighteen thousand (18,000)
pounds on each of the two (2) rear axles. Any such vehicle manufactured in the
model year of 1984 or thereafter or first registered in Illinois after December
31, 1984, may transmit to the road surface a maximum of thirty four thousand
(34,000) pounds through the two (2) rear axles, and neither of the rear axles
shall exceed twenty thousand (20,000) pounds. For purposes of this subsection
B5, "tandem axles" shall be defined as any two (2) or more single axles whose
centers are more then forty inches (40") and not more than ninety six inches
(96") apart, measured to the nearest inch between extreme axles in the series.
         b.   The formula described in subsection B5a of this section when
expressed in tabular form results in allowable loads as follows:

         c.   In applying the above formula to a vehicle having more than four
(4) axles which is not a combination, only four (4) axles shall be considered
in determining the maximum gross weight.
         d.   Notwithstanding the above table, two (2) consecutive sets of
tandem axles may carry a gross weight of thirty four thousand (34,000) pounds
each if the overall distance between the first and last axles of such
consecutive sets of tandem axles is thirty six feet (36') or more.
         e.   Combinations of vehicles, which include a semitrailer
manufactured prior to the model year of 1984 and first registered in Illinois
prior to January 1, 1985, having five (5) axles with a distance of forty two
feet (42') or less between extreme axles may have a gross weight on the
National System of Interstate and Defense Highways and the highways in the
system of State highways designated by the department of seventy two thousand
(72,000) pounds, provided the weight shall not exceed eighteen thousand
(18,000) pounds on any single axle nor thirty two thousand (32,000) pounds on
any tandem axle. All such combinations of vehicles which include a semitrailer
manufactured in the model year of 1984 or thereafter or first registered in
Illinois after December 31, 1984, or which has had its cargo container replaced
in its entirety after December 31, 1984, are limited to the gross weight
allowed by the above formula.
         f.   Vehicles operating under this subsection B5 shall have access for
a distance of five (5) highway miles on a street or highway included in the
system of State highways to points of loading and unloading and to facilities
for food, fuel, repairs and rest.
(Ord. 86-5-7C, 5-7-1986)
8-7A-5: IDENTIFICATION OF SECOND DIVISION VEHICLES:
   A.   Identification Required: No second division vehicle, other than a
second division vehicle having a gross weight of eight thousand (8,000) pounds
or less, which is used by the owner or a member of his immediate family solely
for personal use, other than farm tractors, farm machinery and implements, farm
wagons, wagon-trailers or like vehicles used primarily in agricultural
pursuits, vehicles licensed by the Secretary of State as a recreational vehicle
and all vehicles registered in another state, which if titled in this State
would qualify for such recreational plate, house trailers, trailers designed to
carry a single watercraft or vehicles owned by licensed vehicle dealers and
manufacturers while used for demonstration or delivery purposes, may be
operated upon the highways of the Village unless there is painted or otherwise
firmly affixed to the vehicle on both sides thereof, in a color or colors
vividly contrasting to the color of the vehicle, the name and address of the
owner and the certificate or permit number of the vehicle, if any.
   B.   Specifications: The size of the letters must be at least two inches
(2") high, and the stroke of the brush must be at least one-half inch (1/2")
wide.
   C.   Waiver Of Requirements: The department may, upon application, waive the
requirements of the address on such a vehicle when there is painted or
otherwise firmly affixed to the vehicle a seal or trademark sufficiently well
known to clearly identify the owner of the vehicle.
   D.   Removal Of Previous Identification Information: Any person acquiring a
second division vehicle bearing the name, trademark or other identification of
the previous owner shall obliterate such name, trademark or other
identification.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
8-7A-6: TRUCK ROUTES:
   A.   Authority To Designate: The Superintendent of Public Safety shall be
and hereby is authorized to designate those streets under the jurisdiction of
the Village on which trucks and other commercial vehicles which have a gross
weight, including vehicle and load, of greater than eight thousand one (8,001)
pounds are prohibited from operating.
   B.   Signs Posted: The Director of Public Works shall be and hereby is
authorized to have signs erected at all appropriate locations where a street
has been designated by the Superintendent of Public Safety as a street on which
trucks and other commercial vehicles having a gross weight, including vehicle
and load, of eight thousand one (8,001) pounds or greater are prohibited from
operating.
(Ord. 95-12-6B, 12-6-1995)
8-7A-7: PLANKING EDGE OF PAVEMENT:
No tractor, traction engine or other metal tired vehicle weighing more then
four (4) tons, including the weight of the vehicle and its load, shall drive up
onto, off or over the edge of any paved public highway in the Village without
protecting the edge by putting down solid planks or other suitable device to
prevent the vehicle from breaking off the edges or corners of the pavement.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
8-7A-8: SPILLING LOADS:
   A.   No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any highway unless such vehicle
is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any of its load from dropping,
shifting, leaking or otherwise escaping therefrom; except, that sand may be
dropped for the purpose of securing traction, or water or other substance may
be sprinkled on a roadway in cleaning or maintaining the roadway.
   B.   No person shall operate on any highway any vehicle with any load unless
the load and any covering thereon is securely fastened so as to prevent the
covering or load from becoming loose, detached, or in any manner a hazard to
other users of the highway.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
8-7A-9: OFFICERS TO WEIGH VEHICLES; REMOVAL OF EXCESS LOADS REQUIRED:
   A.   Any public safety officer having reason to believe that the weight of a
vehicle and load is unlawful shall require the driver to stop and submit to a
weighing of the same either by means of a portable or stationary scales. If
such scales are not available at the place where such vehicle is stopped, the
public safety officer shall require that the vehicle be driven to the nearest
available scale that has been tested and approved by the Illinois Department of
Agriculture.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
   B.   Whenever an officer, upon weighing a vehicle and the load, determines
that the weight is unlawful, the officer shall require the driver to stop the
vehicle in a suitable place and remain standing until such portion of the load
is removed as may be necessary to reduce the weight of the vehicle to the limit
permitted under this article, or to the limit permitted under the terms of a
permit issued pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-301 through 5/15-
318 and shall forthwith arrest the driver or owner. All materials so unloaded
shall be cared for by the owner or operator of the vehicle at the risk of such
owner or operator.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982; amd. 2019 Code)
   C.   Whenever any axle load of a vehicle exceeds the weight limits permitted
by subsection
8-7A-4B1 of this article by two thousand (2,000) pounds or less, the owner or
operator of the vehicle must shift or remove the excess so as to comply with
subsection
8-7A-4B1 of this article. Whenever the gross weight of a vehicle exceeds the
weight limits of subsection
8-7A-4B2 of this article by two thousand (2,000) pounds or less, the owner or
operator of the vehicle must remove the excess. In either case, no arrest
ticket shall be issued to the owner or operator of the vehicle by any officer
if the excess weight is either shifted or removed as required by this
subsection.
   D.   Whenever an axle load of a vehicle exceeds axle weight limits allowed
by the provisions of a permit, an arrest ticket shall be issued, but the owner
or operator of the vehicle may shift the load so as to comply with the
provisions of the permit. Where such shifting of a load to comply with the
permit is accomplished, the owner or operator of the vehicle may then proceed.
   E.   Any driver of a vehicle who refuses to stop and submit his vehicle and
load to weighing after being directed to do so by an officer, or removes or
causes the removal of the load or part of it prior to weighing, is guilty of a
business offense and shall be fined not less than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00).
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
8-7A-10: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this article governing size, weight and load do not apply to
fire apparatus or equipment for snow and ice removal operations owned or
operated by any governmental body or to a vehicle operated under the terms of a
special permit issued under this article.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
8-7A-11: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
   A.   Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of
subsection
8-7A-4B of this article, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed
guilty of such violation, and either the owner or the driver of the vehicle may
be prosecuted for such violation. Any person, firm or corporation convicted of
any violation of subsection
8-7A-4B of this article shall be fined in an amount equal to six cents ($0.06)
per pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds two thousand (2,000) pounds
and is three thousand (3,000) pounds or less; eight cents ($0.08) per pound for
each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds three thousand (3,000)
pounds and is four thousand (4,000) pounds or less; ten cents ($0.10) per pound
for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds four thousand (4,000)
pounds and is five thousand (5,000) pounds or less and twelve cents ($0.12) per
pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds five thousand
(5,000) pounds.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982)
   B.   Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a
permit issued under the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-301
through 5/15-319 by operating under a fraudulent permit or under a permit not
specifically covering the move, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be
deemed guilty of a business offense, and either the owner or the driver of such
vehicle may be prosecuted for the violation. When any person, firm or
corporation is convicted of such violation, the permit shall be null and void,
and the person, firm or corporation shall be fined in an amount not less than
ten cents ($0.10) per pound for each pound the gross weight of the vehicle
exceeds the gross weight of such vehicles allowable under subsection 8-7A-4B of
this article.
   C.   Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a
permit issued under the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-301
through 5/13-319 by operating with axle weights in excess of those authorized
in such permit, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of a
business offense, and either the owner or the driver of the vehicle may be
prosecuted for the violation. Any person, firm or corporation convicted of such
violation shall be fined in an amount not less than two cents ($0.02) nor more
than five cents ($0.05) per pound for each pound of excess weight on such axle
or tandem axle in excess of the weight authorized In the permit when the excess
is one thousand (1,000) pounds or less; not less than five cents ($0.05) nor
more than ten cents ($0.10) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the
excess exceeds one thousand (1,000) pounds and is two thousand (2,000) pounds
or less; not less than ten cents ($0.10) nor more than fifteen cents ($0.15)
per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds two thousand
(2,000) pounds and is three thousand (3,000) pounds or less; and not less than
fifteen cents ($0.15) nor more than twenty cents ($0.20) per pound for each
pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds three thousand (3,000) pounds.
   D.   Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a
permit issued under the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-301
through 5/15-319 by operating with the gross weight in excess of that
authorized in the permit, the owner or driver of the vehicle shall be deemed
guilty of a business offense, and either the owner or the driver of the vehicle
may be prosecuted for the violation. Any person, firm or corporation convicted
of such violation shall be fined in an amount not less than two cents ($0.02)
nor more than five cents ($0.05) per pound for each pound of excess weight in
excess of the gross weight authorized in the permit when the excess is one
thousand (1,000) pounds or less; not less than four cents ($0.04) nor more than
seven cents ($0.07) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess
exceeds one thousand (1,000) pounds and is two thousand (2,000) pounds or less;
not less than seven cents ($0.07) nor more than ten cents ($0.10) per pound for
each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds two thousand (2,000) pounds
and is three thousand (3,000) pounds or less; not less than ten cents ($0.10)
nor more than fifteen cents ($0.15) per pound for each pound of excess weight
when the excess exceeds three thousand (3,000) pounds and is four thousand
(4,000) pounds or less; not less than fifteen cents ($0.15) nor more than
twenty cents ($0.20) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess
exceeds four thousand (4,000) pounds and is five thousand (5,000) pounds or
less; and not less than seventeen cents ($0.17) nor more than twenty five cents
($0.25) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds five
thousand (5,000) pounds.
(Ord. 82-1-6A, 1-6-1982; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 8: MOTORIZED SKATEBOARDS AND SCOOTERS
Section
8-8-1:   Definitions
8-8-2:   Operation On Property Of Others
8-8-3:   Operation On Public Ways And Property
8-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
MOTORIZED SCOOTER: A scooter which has a motor attached thereto.
MOTORIZED SKATEBOARD: A skateboard which has a small motor attached thereto.
SCOOTER: A board which has small wheels attached and also has a perpendicular
pole or similar extension attached thereto which is used to steer and/or as a
hand rest.
SKATEBOARD: A board that has a small wheels attached thereto.
(Ord. 2002-4-3M, 4-3-2002)
8-8-2: OPERATION ON PROPERTY OF OTHERS:
It shall be unlawful and is hereby declared a nuisance for any person to use or
operate any motorized skateboard or motorized scooter on the private property
of another person, which shall include property of the Village, not open to the
public without first obtaining the permission of the owner of such property.
(Ord. 2002-4-3M, 4-3-2002)
8-8-3: OPERATION ON PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to operate or ride on a motorized skateboard or
motorized scooter in the public streets, upon the public sidewalks, within a
public right-of-way or within a parking lot or parking structure owned, leased
or operated by the Village.
   B.   No person shall operate or ride on a motorized skateboard or motorized
scooter upon any parking lot or within a parking structure which is owned,
leased or operated by the Village.
   C.   The restrictions contained in subsections A and B of this section shall
not be applicable to persons who operate or ride on a motorized skateboard or a
motorized scooter in connection with an event such as a parade or a block party
for which a permit has been issued or which has otherwise been approved or
authorized by the Village.
(Ord. 2002-4-3M, 4-3-2002)
CHAPTER 9: INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES
Section
8-9-1:   Definitions
8-9-2:   Nuisance Declared
8-9-3:   Removal Or Towing Of Inoperable Vehicle
8-9-4:   Sale Of Vehicle; Proceeds
8-9-5:   Unsold Vehicles
8-9-6:   Exemptions From Provisions
8-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the term INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE means any motor
vehicle from which, for a period of at least six (6) months, the engine, wheels
or other parts have been removed, or on which the engine, wheels or other parts
have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is
incapable of being driven under its own motor power. The term INOPERABLE MOTOR
VEHICLE shall not include a motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily
incapable of being driven under its own motor power in order to perform
ordinary service or repair operations.
(1971 Code § 21-69)
8-9-2: NUISANCE DECLARED:
Any inoperable motor vehicle parked on either private or public property shall
be a nuisance.
(1971 Code § 21-71)
8-9-3: REMOVAL OR TOWING OF INOPERABLE VEHICLE:
   A.   Removal: It shall be the duty of the Department of Public Safety to
cause any inoperable motor vehicle declared to be a nuisance to be removed and
conveyed by, or under the direction of, a member of the Department of Public
Safety to a vehicle pound.
(1971 Code § 21-72)
   B.   Towing: The Department of Public Safety shall make provisions with some
garage or some other agency for the purpose of providing towing of such
inoperable motor vehicle and carrying out the provisions of this chapter.
(1971 Code § 21-73)
   C.   Notice Of Removal Or Tow: Whenever the Department of Public Safety has
impounded or relocated any inoperable motor vehicle, the department shall
ascertain the address of the owner thereof and shall give, or cause to be
given, written notice to the owner of the fact of such removal and impounding,
the reason therefor and the place to which the vehicle has been removed.
(1971 Code § 21-74)
   D.   Costs: The owner of any impounded vehicle, or his duly authorized
agent, may, upon presentation of the notice to the person in charge of the
pound, reclaim the possession of the motor vehicle upon the payment of the fee
as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1L of this Code,
which covers the cost of impounding and towing and, in addition thereto, any
storage charges incurred.
(1971 Code § 21-75; amd. 2019 Code)
8-9-4: SALE OF VEHICLE; PROCEEDS:
   A.   Sale Of Vehicle: Whenever any vehicle so impounded shall remain
unclaimed by the owner or other person legally entitled to possession thereof
for a period of thirty (30) days and after notice shall have been given, it
shall be the duty of the Department of Public Safety to sell such vehicle at
public auction to the highest bidder, the time and place of the sale to be
published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the area, such
publication to be not less than ten (10) nor more than fifteen (15) days from
expiration of the thirty (30) days. The department shall also cause a notice of
the sale to be mailed to the Secretary of State.
(1971 Code § 21-76)
   B.   Disposition Of Proceeds: The proceeds of the sale, after paying all
liens and deducting all reasonable charges and expenses incurred, shall be
deposited with the Finance Director.
(1971 Code § 21-77)
8-9-5:    UNSOLD VEHICLES:
Whenever any inoperable motor vehicle shall remain unsold for a period of
ninety (90) days, such vehicle may be used by any department of the Village, or
other governmental agency desiring the same, or it may be removed and
dismantled.
(1971 Code § 21-78)
8-9-6: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
Nothing in this chapter shall apply to:
   A.   Any motor vehicle that is kept within a building when not in use;
   B.   Historic vehicles over twenty five (25) years of age; or
   C.   A motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business engaged in the
wrecking or junking of motor vehicles.
(1971 Code § 21-70)
TITLE 9: PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1: STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
Section
9-1-1:   Obstructing Public Ways
9-1-2:   Moving Buildings
9-1-3:   Fastening Animals To, Damaging Public Ways And Property
9-1-4:   Placing Ashes, Yard Waste Dirt And Rubbish In Public Ways
9-1-1: OBSTRUCTING PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Building Materials; Excavations:
      1.   Permit Required: Any person who shall encumber or obstruct, or cause
to be encumbered or obstructed, any street, alley, or other public place in the
Village by placing therein or thereon any building materials, or any other
material or thing whatsoever, or by digging or excavating in any such street,
alley, or other public place without first having obtained written permission
from the Village President or the Village Board of Trustees shall be subject to
a penalty of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a further penalty
of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each day or part of a day such
encumbrance or obstruction shall continue.
(1971 Code § 19-1)
      2.   Removal Of Obstruction:
         a.   The Director of Public Works, and each of them, are hereby
authorized to order any article or thing whatsoever which may encumber or
obstruct any street, alley or other public place within the Village to be
removed.
         b.   If such article or thing shall not be removed within six (6)
hours after notice to the owner or person in charge thereof to remove the same,
or if the owner cannot be readily found for the purpose of the notice, to cause
the article or thing to be removed to some suitable place, to be designated by
the Director of Public Works.
         c.   The owner of any article so removed shall forfeit a penalty of
twenty five dollars ($25.00) in addition to the cost of such removal.
(1971 Code § 19-2)
      3.   Disposal Of Obstruction: Any article or thing which may be removed
in accordance with the subsection A2 of this section shall be advertised for
ten (10) days and sold by the Director of Public Works, unless the same shall
be sooner reclaimed and the penalty and costs paid by the owner thereof. The
proceeds of the sale shall be placed into the Village Treasury, and the
balance, if any, after deducting the penalty and costs, shall be paid to any
person furnishing satisfactory proof of ownership.
(1971 Code § 19-3)
   B.   Buildings; Fences; Steps:
      1.   Prohibited: No person shall erect or place any building, in whole or
in part, upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground within the Village
under a penalty not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
(1971 Code § 19-6)
      2.   Removal Required; Notice: The owner of any building, fence, porch,
steps, gallery or other obstruction now standing or which may hereafter be
erected or placed upon any street, alley sidewalk or public ground within the
Village, or which may be left standing upon any new street that has been or may
hereafter be opened, shall remove the same within such reasonable time, not
