accepted and agreed to be bound by the terms and conditions of the permit and
any applicable agreement between the Village and the prior owner if the new
owner uses the small wireless facility or allows it to remain on the Village
right-of-way.
   C.   Insurance And Bonding: All required insurance coverage or bonding must
be changed to reflect the name of the new owner upon transfer.
(Ord. 2018-7-11B, 7-11-2018)
9-2B-13: REMOVAL, RELOCATION OR ABANDONMENT:
   A.   Removal By Village:
      1.   Under this article, the Village is not required to install or
maintain any specific utility pole or to continue to install or maintain any
specific utility pole in any location if the Village determines to eliminate
aboveground utility poles of a particular type generally, such as electric
utility poles, in all or a significant portion of its geographic jurisdiction.
      2.   If the Village determines to eliminate aboveground Village utility
poles of a particular type generally, and collocated small wireless facilities
are in place, the Village shall either: a) continue to maintain the utility
pole or install and maintain a reasonable alternative utility pole or wireless
support structure for the collocation of the small wireless facility; or b)
offer to sell the utility pole to the wireless provider at a reasonable cost or
allow the wireless provider to install its own utility pole so it can maintain
service from that location.
   B.   Emergency Removal Or Relocation: The Village retains the right and
privilege to cut or move any small wireless facilities within the rights-of-way
of the Village as the Village may determine to be necessary, appropriate or
useful in response to any public health or safety emergency. If the
circumstances permit, the Village shall attempt to notify the wireless provider
prior to cutting or removing the facility and shall notify the wireless
provider after cutting or removing the facility.
   C.   Abandonment: A small wireless facility that is not operated for a
continuous period of twelve (12) months shall be considered abandoned. The
owner of the facility must remove the small wireless facility within ninety
(90) days after the date of the written notice from the Village notifying the
wireless provider of the abandonment. The notice shall be sent by certified or
registered mail, return receipt requested, by the Village to the owner at the
last known address of the owner. If the small wireless facility is not removed
within ninety (90) days of the notice, the Village has the right to remove or
cause the removal of the facility pursuant to the terms of its pole attachment
agreement for Village utility poles, or through whatever actions are provided
for abatement of nuisances, or by other law for removal and cost recovery. The
Village shall charge the cost of the removal against the wireless provider or
any successor in interest to the wireless provider.
(Ord. 2018-7-11B, 7-11-2018)
9-2B-14: PROHIBITIONS:
Nothing in this article authorizes a person to collocate small wireless
facilities on:
   A.   Property owned by a private party or property owned or controlled by
the Village or another unit of local government that is not located within
public rights-of-way, or a privately owned utility pole or wireless support
structure without the consent of the property owner;
   B.   Property owned, leased, or controlled by a park district, forest
preserve district, or conservation district for public park, recreation, or
conservation purposes without the consent of the affected district, excluding
the placement of facilities on rights-of-way located in an affected district
that are under the jurisdiction and control of a different unit of local
government as provided by the Illinois Highway Code (605 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.);
or
   C.    Property owned by a rail carrier registered under section 18c-7201 of
the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/18c), Metra Commuter Rail or any other
public commuter rail service, or an “electric utility”, as defined in section
16-102 of the Public Utilities Act (220 ILCS 5/16-102), without the consent of
the rail carrier, public commuter rail service, or electric utility. The
provisions of this article do not apply to an electric or gas public utility or
such utility’s wireless facilities if the facilities are being used, developed
and maintained consistent with the provisions of subsection (i) of section 16-
108.5 of the Public Utilities Act (220 ILCS 16-108.5(i)). For the purposes of
this subsection, “public utility” has the meaning given to that term in section
3-105 of the Public Utilities Act (220 ILCS 5/3-105). Nothing in this article
shall be construed to relieve a person from any requirement: 1) to obtain a
franchise or a State issued authorization to offer cable service or video
service; or 2) to obtain any required permission to install, place, maintain,
or operate communications facilities, other than small wireless facilities
subject to this article.
(Ord. 2018-7-11B, 7-11-2018)
9-2B-15: PENALTIES:
   A.   Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply
with any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to fine in
accordance with the penalty provisions of this Code (See title 1, chapter 4 of
this Code).
   B.   Nothing in this article shall be construed as limiting any additional
or further remedies that the Village may have for enforcement of this article.
(Ord. 2018-7-11B, 7-11-2018)
9-2B-16: DISPUTE RESOLUTIONS:
The Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois shall have exclusive jurisdiction to
resolve all disputes arising under the Small Wireless Facilities Deployment
Act. Pending resolution of a dispute concerning rates for collocation of small
wireless facilities on Village utility poles within the right-of-way, the
Village shall allow the collocating wireless provider to collocate on its poles
at annual rates of no more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year per
Village utility pole, with rates to be determined upon final resolution of the
dispute.
(Ord. 2018-7-11B, 7-11-2018)
CHAPTER 3: DRIVEWAYS
Section
9-3-1:   Permit Required; Restrictions
9-3-2:   Application For Permit; Review
9-3-3:   Permit Fees
9-3-4:   Conditions Of Permit
9-3-5:   Location Restrictions
9-3-6:   Residential Driveways Crossing Sidewalks
9-3-7:   Commercial And Industrial Driveways
9-3-8:   Maintenance And Repairs
9-3-9:   Revocation Of Permit
9-3-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; RESTRICTIONS:
No person shall hereafter construct, repair or maintain a driveway across a
public sidewalk without first having obtained a permit therefor from the
Director of Public Works; provided, that no permit for a driveway more than
sixteen feet (16') in width in districts zoned for residences and apartments
shall be granted without approval by the Village Board, nor shall any permit
for a driveway more than thirty five feet (35') in width in districts zoned for
commercial or industrial purposes be granted without approval by the Village
Board.
(Ord. 75-11-19B, 11-19-1975)
9-3-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; REVIEW:
   A.   Application for a permit for a driveway shall be made to the Director
of Public Works and shall contain the name and address of the person making
application and the proposed location and dimensions of the driveway. Plans and
specifications of the driveway shall accompany the application.
   B.   No permit shall be issued until the Village Engineer shall have
reviewed the application and certified to the Director of Public Works that the
application complies with all requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 75-11-19B, 11-19-1975)
9-3-3: PERMIT FEES:
The permit fees for the issuance of a driveway permit shall be as set forth in
the Village Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1G of this Code.
(Ord. 75-11-19B, 11-19-1975; amd. 2019 Code)
9-3-4: CONDITIONS OF PERMIT:
Permits required by this chapter shall contain conditions providing as follows:
   A.   That same may be revoked by the Village President or by an order duly
passed by the Village Board and signed by the President at any time without
consent of the grantee, in which case, the authority and privileges granted
shall thereupon cease and terminate.
   B.   That upon the termination by revocation, expiration or otherwise of the
authority, rights and privileges granted by the permit, the driveway therein
authorized shall be removed and the sidewalk and parkway space where the same
shall have been located shall be restored to its proper condition to the
satisfaction of the Director of Public Works, so that the portion of the
sidewalk and parkway space used for the driveway shall be safe for public
travel and in the same condition as the remaining portion of the sidewalk and
parkway space, at the sole expense of the grantee therein, without cost or
expense of any kind whatsoever to the Village; provided, that in the event of
the failure, neglect or refusal on the part of the grantee to remove the
driveway when directed so to do, the Village may proceed to remove same and
charge the expense thereof to the grantee.
(Ord. 75-11-19B, 11-19-1975)
9-3-5: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   On corner lots, no driveway shall be constructed nearer than ten feet
(10') from the sidewalk abutting such lots and running in the general direction
of the proposed driveway.
   B.   Where no sidewalks are existing, the proposed driveway shall not be
located nearer than ten feet (10') from the sidewalk line as established or to
be established by the Village.
(Ord. 75-11-19B, 11-19-1975)
9-3-6: RESIDENTIAL DRIVEWAYS CROSSING SIDEWALKS:
No driveway shall cross a public sidewalk or cut into a curb along a public
street more than once in districts zoned for residences unless the issuance of
the permit for such a driveway has been approved by the Village Board.
(Ord. 80-7-16B, 7-16-1980)
9-3-7: COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL DRIVEWAYS:
All driveways in commercial districts shall be made of concrete. The grade of
driveways and the radii of the sides of the driveways at the curb and the mix
for the construction material of driveways shall be in accordance with other
ordinances of the Village, as applicable, or as specified by the Village
Engineer.
(Ord. 75-11-19B, 11-19-1975)
9-3-8: MAINTENANCE AND REPAIRS:
The grantee of a permit or the owner or occupant of any premises where a
driveway is maintained shall, at his own expense, make such repairs to a
defective driveway as the Director of Public Works shall direct.
(Ord. 75-11-19B, 11-19-1975)
9-3-9: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
If any person obtaining or possessing a permit under the terms of this chapter
shall at any time fail or neglect to comply with the provisions herein
prescribed, such permit may be revoked by the Village Board.
(Ord. 75-11-19B, 11-19-1975)
CHAPTER 4: BLOCK PARTIES
Section
9-4-1:   Definitions
9-4-2:   Permit And Compliance Required
9-4-3:   Application For Permit
9-4-4:   Processing And Approval Of Application
9-4-5:   Restrictions On Parties
9-4-6:   Enforcement
9-4-7:   Penalty
9-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
BLOCK PARTY: A party or social gathering held on a public street within the
Village of Rosemont where the street is closed to motor vehicle traffic during
the duration of the party or gathering.
SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL AREA: Those areas of the Village which are zoned A
Single-Family District under the Village of Rosemont Zoning Map and zoning
ordinance.
(Ord. 2006-9-13E, 9-13-2006)
9-4-2: PERMIT AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
No block party shall take place unless a permit for the block party has been
issued by the Village as provided in this chapter. Persons who organize a block
party for which a permit has not been issued as provided in this chapter and
those persons who participate in a block party with knowledge that a permit for
the block party has not been issued as provided in this chapter shall be in
violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 2006-9-13E, 9-13-2006)
9-4-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Applications for permits shall be submitted to the Village Clerk. The Village
Clerk may prescribe and furnish permit application forms. Each application
shall contain the date and hours of the proposed block party, the location
where the block party will occur and the name, address and telephone number of
the person submitting the application. An application for a permit shall be
submitted not less than three (3) working days prior to the date on which the
block party is to be held. The person submitting an application for a permit
for a block party must reside on the block where the block party is to occur.
(Ord. 2006-9-13E, 9-13-2006)
9-4-4: PROCESSING AND APPROVAL OF APPLICATION:
   A.   The Village Clerk shall forward a copy of each application for a block
party to the Superintendent of Public Safety, or his designee, and to the
Director of Public Works for their review and approval.
   B.   The block party permit shall be issued if the permit application is
approved by the Superintendent of Public Safety, or his designee, and by the
Director of Public Works and if the permit application indicates that the block
party will otherwise comply with the requirements of this chapter.
   C.   The Superintendent of Public Safety, or his designee, shall approve an
application for a block party permit unless it is determined that holding the
block party on the date or during the hours specified in the permit application
will cause traffic congestion.
   D.   The Director of Public Works shall approve an application for a block
party permit unless it is determined that the holding of the block party on the
date or during the hours specified in the permit application will interfere
with maintenance work or construction related work that may be occurring in the
public right-of-way.
(Ord. 2006-9-13E, 9-13-2006)
9-4-5: RESTRICTIONS ON PARTIES:
The following restrictions shall apply to block parties:
   A.   A block party may only be held in a single-family residential area.
   B.   Block party permits shall be valid for one day, between the hours of
nine o’clock (9:00) A.M. and eleven o’clock (11:00) P.M. No street or other
public right-of-way shall be blocked off for a block party earlier than nine
o’clock (9:00) A.M. or after eleven o’clock (11:00) P.M.
   C.   A block party may only be held on a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday.
(Ord. 2006-9-13E, 9-13-2006)
9-4-6: ENFORCEMENT:
A public safety officer working in a supervisory capacity may terminate a block
party and revoke a block party permit if, after investigation, the supervisory
public safety officer determines that violations of an applicable ordinance,
law, rule or regulation have occurred at a block party and that there is a
reasonable likelihood that such violations will continue to occur if the block
party is allowed to continue.
(Ord. 2006-9-13E, 9-13-2006)
9-4-7: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined
not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00). Each separate four (4) hour period that a violation is
found to exist shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2006-9-13E, 9-13-2006)
CHAPTER 5: VILLAGE PARKS
ARTICLE A: DONALD E. STEPHENS PARK
Section
9-5A-1:   Description Of Park
9-5A-2:   Bicycles Prohibited
9-5A-3:   Dogs Prohibited
9-5A-1: DESCRIPTION OF PARK:
The Donald E. Stephens Park is defined as the open space area owned and
maintained as a park by the Village of Rosemont and located at the intersection
of Scott Street and Higgins Road in the Village.
(Ord. 76-4-21A, 4-21-1976; amd. Ord. 76-7-7, 7-7-1976; Ord. 76-7-7A, 7-7-1976)
9-5A-2: BICYCLES PROHIBITED:
   A.   Prohibited: No person shall drive or ride a bicycle in the Donald E.
Stephens Park nor shall any person enter the Donald E. Stephens Park with the
intention to drive or ride a bicycle therein.
   B.   1. A person violating the provisions of this section for the first time
shall have the bicycle confiscated by a public safety officer whereupon the
bicycle shall be taken to the Public Safety Department of the Village. In the
event said person found violating the provisions of this section is a minor,
the bicycle may only be recovered by the parents or lawful guardians of the
minor after confiscation by the Public Safety Department. In the event the
person found violating the provisions of this section for the first time shall
be an adult, the bicycle may be picked up at the Public Safety Department seven
(7) days after the offense and confiscation of the bicycle shall have occurred.
The Public Safety Department shall keep a record of all offenders of this
section.
      2.   Any person found violating the provisions of this section more than
one time shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. 76-7-7A, 7-7-1976)
9-5A-3: DOGS PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person shall bring a dog into Donald E. Stephens Park or allow a dog
under his/her ownership or control to enter Donald E. Stephens Park.
(Ord. 76-4-21A, 4-21-1976; amd. Ord. 76-7-7, 7-7-1976)
   B.   Any person found to have violated the provisions of this section shall,
upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 76-4-21A, 4-21-1976)
TITLE 10: WATER AND WASTEWATER
CHAPTER 1: WATER AND SEWER UNIT
Section
10-1-1:   Designated
10-1-1: DESIGNATED:
There shall be designated a Water and Sewer Unit within the Public Works
Department.
(1971 Code § 22-1)
CHAPTER 2: WATER USE AND SERVICE
Section
10-2-1:   Connection To Water System Required; Wells Prohibited
10-2-2:   Application And Permit To Connect To Water System
10-2-3:   Connection Specifications And Restrictions
10-2-4:   Water Meters
10-2-4-1:   Maintenance Of Commercial And Industrial Meters
10-2-4-2:   Service To Premises Which Have Not Been Provided With Water Service
10-2-5:   Water Rates, Penalties, Deposits And Shut-Off
10-2-6:   Water Used For Construction Of Improvements And Buildings
10-2-7:   Conservation Measures
10-2-8:   Closed System Air Conditioning
10-2-9:   Interference With, Damage To System
10-2-10:   Changes To Provisions
10-2-11:   Penalty
10-2-1: CONNECTION TO WATER SYSTEM REQUIRED; WELLS PROHIBITED:
   A.   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, unless the context
requires otherwise, the following terms shall have the following definitions:
PLUMBING SYSTEM. The actual installation, repair, maintenance, alteration or
extension of a plumbing system by any person. Plumbing includes all piping,
fixtures, appurtenances and appliances for a supply of water for all purposes
including, without limitation, lawn sprinkler systems from the source of
private water supply on the premises or from a main in the street, alley or at
the curb to, within and about any building or buildings where a person or
persons live, work or assemble. Plumbing includes all piping from discharge of
pumping units to and including pressure tanks in water supply systems. Plumbing
includes all piping, fixtures, appurtenances, and appliances for a building
drain and a sanitary drainage and related ventilation system of any building or
buildings where a person or persons live, work or assemble from the point of
connection of such building drain to the building sewer or private sewage
disposal system five feet (5') beyond the foundation walls.
POTABLE WATER. Water which meets the requirements of applicable State law and
regulations for drinking, culinary, and domestic purposes.
PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY. All mains, pipes and structures through which water is
obtained and distributed to the public by the Village of Rosemont, intakes,
pumping stations, reservoirs, storage tanks and appurtenances, collectively or
severally, actually used or intended for use for the purpose of furnishing
water for drinking or general domestic use.
   B.   Use Of Public Water System Required: All residences, buildings and
other structures located within the corporate limits of the Village including,
but not limited to, residences, buildings and other structures that are owned,
occupied or operated by the Village, that have a plumbing system installed on
the premises and which provide potable water through such system shall be
properly connected to the Village public water supply system.
   C.   Private And Public Wells Prohibited:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to drill or install any well for the purpose of
securing water for use in any residence, building or structure within the
Village.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to use water in a plumbing system from any well
drilled, dug or installed in violation of the provisions of this subsection.
      3.   The restrictions in subsections C1 and C2 of this section apply to
all residences, buildings, and structures located within the corporate limits
of the Village including but not limited to, residences, buildings and
structures that are owned, occupied, or operated by the Village.
(Ord. 99-4-7H, 4-7-1999)
10-2-2: APPLICATION AND PERMIT TO CONNECT TO WATER SYSTEM:
   A.   Application To Connect:
      1.   Any person desiring to make any connection with the water system or
plant or use water therefrom shall first make application to the Director of
Public Works for that purpose upon a blank form to be furnished by the Director
or Village Engineer.
      2.   Every applicant shall state specifically and in detail the place,
location and kind of connection appendages sought, the purpose for which the
water is to be used and all the plumbing or plumbing work in any manner or way
connected therewith.
      3.   Applications for water service must state fully all the purposes for
which it is required, and when paying the charges therefor, the parties must
frankly and without concealment answer all questions put thereto relative to
its consumption. The applicant shall, in such application, agree that in
consideration of the insertion of the tap, he will pay or cause to be paid the
assessment levied on the premises for the water pipe that is proposed to be
tapped and all water rates or rents to accrue against the premises and that he
will faithfully comply with the rules established in this chapter and all
ordinances of the Village relative to the use of water. All applications for
water must be made in all cases by the owner of the premises, or his duly
authorized agent, for which water is sought to be supplied.
   B.   Compliance With Provisions: Every person so making the connection with
the water system or plant or using water therefrom shall make the connection
and use the water and maintain the same subject at all times to the provisions
and conditions of this Code or the ordinances of the Village in force or to
become in force at any time during the period the connections are maintained or
the water is used and shall in all respects conform to the provisions and
conditions of this Code or ordinances of the Village. The Village Plumbing
Inspector must be there when tapping into any Village water main.
   C.   Issuance And Contents Of Permit:
      1.   When the applicant hereunder has complied with all the provisions of
this Code or the ordinances of the Village and any rules or regulations of the
Board of Trustees and paid to the Village Collector all of the charges
connected with securing water service, a permit shall then be issued by the
Director of Public Works authorizing the connection to be made, and specifying
the size thereof and the location of the proposed tap and shutoff box.
      2.   The permit shall show the location of the tap and the shutoff box,
size, length and weight of pipe and shall be endorsed by the Director showing
that he has inspected the tap before the trench was refilled, and the tap and
shutoff box are in the places specified, and in accordance with the
requirements of this Code or the ordinances of the Village and the rules and
regulations of the Board of Trustees, and the kind, location and size of tap
service pipe and shutoff box shall then be entered upon the map or profile kept
for that purpose as herein provided.
(1971 Code § 22-13)
Cross-reference:
   See subsection
3-10-1 G of this Code for connection fees
10-2-3: CONNECTION SPECIFICATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   The connections from the water main to the water meter shall be placed
at least five feet (5') below the surface of the ground and shall be made of
copper pipe of the quality known in commerce as extra strong. It shall be laid
sufficiently waving at least one foot (1') longer for each twenty feet (20') or
fraction thereof than if laid straight and placed in such manner to prevent
rupture or breakage from settling of the ground. Copper pipe of the size and
weight per linear foot following will be accepted as extra strong and complying
with the provisions of this chapter:
3/4 inch copper pipe: Three and one-half (3-1/2) pounds.
1 inch copper pipe: Four and three-fourths (4-3/4) pounds.
1-1/4 inch copper pipe: Six (6) pounds.
   B.   All copper pipe and copper plumbing and all service cocks, stopcocks
and shutoff boxes shall be of the kind and quality specified and approved by
the Director of Public Works. Service taps of two inches (2") or more in
diameter shall be made of ductile iron and be of T type connection of the same
material as the present water mains, and connections must be called the same as
the present water main connection.
   C.   No person shall make any excavation in any of the streets, avenues or
other public places in the Village for the purpose of laying water pipes
without authority of the Director of Public Works or the Village Engineer.
   D.   No person shall tap any water or service pipe between the water supply
main and the shutoff box.
   E.   No person shall make any tap or connection between the shutoff box and
the water meter without first obtaining a permit as provided in this chapter,
and then only under the supervision of the Director.
   F.   Before any backfilling is done between the shutoff and water meter, all
pipe and connection thereto must be inspected by the Director.
(1971 Code § 22-15)
10-2-4: WATER METERS:
   A.   Metered Service Required: All water consumers supplied by the Village
shall be supplied through meters only and shall pay for the water at meter
rates as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1G of this
Code.
(1971 Code § 22-16; amd. 2019 Code)
   B.   Location And Installation: All meters shall be placed in the buildings
under the direction and supervision of the Director of Public Works or Village
Pluming Inspector and shall be located as near as possible to where the service
pipe enters the building or structure so as to afford easy access for examining
and reading. After the meter is placed, only the Director or members and
employees of the Village Water and Sewer Department shall be allowed to repair
or in any manner interfere with the same. A stopcock shall be placed on each
side of the meter.
   C.   Repairs And Renewals: All repairs and renewals of meters shall be at
the expense of the applicant or owner of the premises, and the applicant or
owner shall at all times be responsible for any damage done by negligence or
freezing of the meter.
   D.   Defective Meters: It shall be the duty of the owner to promptly notify
the Director of Public Works of all defects in any meter or of its failure to
properly register the quantity of water. All defects in any meter shall be
promptly repaired by the Director or his designee, and the expense thereof
shall be paid at once by the owner; except, that corroded meters are to be
repaired at the expense of the Village. Whenever any meter, by reason of its
being out of repair or for any reason fails to register properly the amount of
water passing through the same, the consumer shall be charged at the rates
shown for the corresponding time of the previous year under like conditions. If
no record of the previous year exists, then it shall be the duty of the
Director to estimate or determine, so far as he can, the amount of water
consumed during the period the meter failed to operate, and the consumer shall
pay the amount estimated by the Director.
   E.   Access To Premises For Inspection, Reading And Testing Of Meters: The
Director of Public Works or any person by him duly authorized to inspect or
read meters shall have ready access to the premises, place or building where
the meters are located for the purpose of reading, examining, testing and
repairing same and examining and testing the consumption, use and flow of
water, and it shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, prevent or
obstruct the Director or any other person by him authorized in his work
hereunder. Every consumer of the Village water shall take the same upon the
conditions prescribed in this section.
   F.   Damage To Or Tampering With Meters Prohibited:
      1.   All meters shall, upon installation, be thoroughly sealed to prevent
tampering with the same. No person shall break or remove the seal or cause same
to be done.
      2.   No person shall injure, mar, deface, destroy or in any manner
interfere with the meter.
   G.   Replacement Of Worn Meters: When a water meter is so worn or otherwise
rendered unfit for proper service, if same cannot be readily repaired, the
Director of Public Works may, and it hereby becomes his duty, to condemn the
same and order a new meter installed and paid for by the Village.
(1971 Code § 22-16)
10-2-4-1: MAINTENANCE OF COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL METERS:
   A.   All commercial and industrial customers receiving water from the
Village shall have an affirmative obligation and responsibility to maintain any
valves, stopcocks or other shutoff devices located immediately adjacent to both
sides of their water meter (upstream and downstream) in working order so that
the flow of water can be fully stopped on both sides of the water meter. Upon
receipt of written notice from the Village advising that a valve, stopcock or
other shutoff device located immediately adjacent to their water meter
(upstream or downstream) is not in working order, the commercial or industrial
water customer shall have thirty (30) days from the date of the notice, at its
expense, repair the valve, stopcock or other shutoff device so that it is in
working order.
   B.   All commercial and industrial customers receiving water from the
Village shall have an affirmative obligation and responsibility to exercise the
valves, stopcocks or other shutoff devices located immediately adjacent to both
sides of their water meter (upstream and downstream) on a quarterly basis by
fully closing and immediately reopening each valve, stopcock or other shutoff
device located on each side (upstream and downstream) of their water meter. All
commercial and industrial customers receiving water from the Village shall
maintain a log of the dates and times when the valves, stopcocks or other
shutoff devices located immediately adjacent to both sides of their water meter
(upstream and downstream) are exercised. The log shall contain the name and
signature of the individual that exercised the valves, stopcocks or other
shutoff devices on each date and time. This log shall be made available to
Village Public Works Department personnel upon request.
   C.   Any entity that commits a violation of any obligation imposed by this
section shall be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
separate offense. The fine imposed shall be in addition to any cost of repair
incurred.
(Ord. 2017-11-8K, 11-8-2017)
10-2-4-2: SERVICE TO PREMISES WHICH HAVE NOT BEEN PROVIDED WITH WATER SERVICE:
   A.   For purposes of this section, the phrase “major remodeling” means any
remodeling which has a cost or value of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00)
or more, and the phrase “major structural modification” means any structural
modification which has a cost or value of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00)
or more.
   B.   1. Whenever the Village provides water service to premises which have
not previously been provided with water service, the water service shall be
metered.
      2.   Whenever there is any major remodeling of any premises to which the
Village is providing water service and such service is unmetered, the water
service shall be metered as part of the remodeling.
(Ord. 83-7-6B, 7-6-1983)
10-2-5: WATER RATES, PENALTIES, DEPOSITS AND SHUT-OFF:
   A.   Effective July 1, 2024 with respect to commercial water consumers,
residential water consumers and government/non-profit water customers, the
rates charged for water supplied to consumers by the Village shall be as
follows:
      1.   Effective with all bills issued for usage on or after July 1, 2024,
the rate of six dollars and forty-one cents ($6.41) per one thousand (1,000)
gallons shall be charged for each consumer utilizing water in a single-family
home, residential apartment or condominium unit. The minimum amount to be
charged to and paid by each such consumer shall be nineteen dollars and twenty-
three cents ($19.23) for each billing period.
      2.   Effective with all bills issued for usage on or after July 1, 2024,
the rate of thirteen dollars and five cents ($13.05) per one thousand (1,000)
gallons shall be charged for each consumer utilizing water in a commercial unit
or industrial unit. The minimum amount to be charged to and paid by each such
consumer shall be thirty-nine dollars and fifteen cents ($39.15) for each
billing period.
      3.   Effective with all bills issued for usage on or after July 1, 2024,
the rate of six dollars and forty-one cents ($6.41) per one thousand (1,000)
gallons shall be charged for each consumer utilizing water in a non-profit,
educational, religious, charitable, governmental or similar unit. The minimum
amount to be charged to and paid by each such customers shall be nineteen
dollars and twenty-three cents ($19.23) for each billing period.
   B.   Prior Rates and Charges Saved. Nothing in this amendatory ordinance
adopted April 8, 2024 shall be deemed to amend, alter or repeal the water
rates, charges or billings under Section
10-2-5 of the Village of Rosemont Code of Ordinances in effect for bills issued
for usage prior to July 1, 2024 as all such prior rates, charges and related
billings are expressly saved.
   C.   Temporary Water Meter Fee. The fee for the temporary rental of a water
meter shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00). Water usage through a temporary
meter shall be billed at the commercial rate unless the user is a non-profit,
in which case the non-profit rate shall apply.
   D.   Single family residential water accounts shall be billed every three
(3) months. Except as otherwise set forth in this Section, all other consumers
shall be billed monthly. Billing for Village accounts, Rosemont Park District
accounts and Rosemont School District 78 accounts shall be suspended upon the
direction of the Finance Director during the off-season. The minimum monthly
fee will not be charged to Village accounts, Rosemont Park District accounts
and Rosemont School District 78 accounts for any months in which the billing is
suspended.
   E.   If water service to any customer is shut-off or disconnected, then in
addition to the payment of all amounts owed, a reactivation fee of fifty
dollars ($50.00) shall be paid to the Village by the owner or occupant of such
building or structure before water service is resumed. In addition, if water is
shut-off while the Village is holding a deposit from the customer, the customer
shall pay any amount necessary to ensure that the Village continues to hold the
full amount of the deposit required by section 10-2-5(G) before water service
is resumed.
   F.   A penalty of ten percent (10%) shall be charged and due from all
consumers of water for payment of bills that are not paid by the due date. If
the full amount due, including penalties, is not then paid within thirty (30)
days after the bill due date, an additional ten percent (10%) penalty shall
then be assessed only upon the principal amount due (and not on any prior
penalty amounts) with additional ten percent (10%) penalties thereafter being
assessed on only the principal amount due after each subsequent thirty (30)-day
period passes without full payment being received. Any payments received shall
first be applied to all penalties that are due and then to the principal amount
due on the water bill that has remained unpaid for the longest period of time.
   G.   All new commercial and industrial accounts shall pay a deposit equal to
the estimated average monthly charge for water as determined by the Director of
Public Works but not exceeding five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The applicant
shall truthfully comply with all requests for information reasonably deemed
necessary to estimate the average monthly charge for water. In addition, a
consumer who shall be late in making any payment due or in violation of other
provisions of this Chapter, whether or not his water has been shut off as
hereafter provided, may be required at the discretion of the Director of Public
Works to post a deposit equal to the anticipated amount of an average monthly
water bill. All deposits shall be credited to the consumer's water account
after a continuous one-year period of on-time payment history. No interest
shall be paid upon any deposit. Any deposit credits remaining after the
termination of a consumer's water service shall be refunded to the consumer.
   H.   A twenty-five dollars ($25.00) fee shall be charged to all consumers
for each payment that is rejected for non-sufficient funds.
   I.   If any water account is not fully paid within thirty (30) days after
the bill due date, a shut-off notice may be mailed to the account address
requiring full payment of all amounts due within a date that is at least ten
(10) days after the date the shut-off notice was mailed in order to avoid
disruption of service. After the shut-off notice is mailed, the only acceptable
method of payment is cash, money order or other method acceptable to the
Village. If the account is not paid by the date set forth in the shut-off
notice, the Village shall affix a notice to the front door of the location
indicating that the water will be shut-off if the account is not paid in full
by eleven o’clock (11:00) A.M. on the next business day. In the event the
Rental Property Utility Service Act, 765 ILCS 735/1 et seq. or any other
statute governing a municipality's shut-off of water is applicable, the
relevant provisions of such statue shall be followed for the shutoff of water
instead of the procedures set forth of this section. The fact that the Village
is holding any deposit shall. not prevent the shut-off of water for lack of
payment. After water is shut-off, any deposit held by the Village shall be
applied to pay the amount due the Village with any remainder being returned to
the customer.
   J.   Rates A Lien: In addition to any other remedy provided for the
enforcement or collection of any water rent or rate, all rates provided in this
chapter shall be a lien against the premises to which any water may be supplied
and charged against the owner thereof, and the property owner of rented
buildings in the Village shall be responsible to the Village for all charges
for Village water used therein, or on or about the grounds adjacent thereto, in
any action waged by the Village in any court of competent jurisdiction for the
amount of all water rents or rates as may be due and unpaid, together with all
penalties provided herein and costs. Any change of ownership or occupancy shall
not affect the application of this subsection.
(1971 Code § 22-19) (amd. Ord. 2020-5-11, 5-11-2020; Ord. 2021-4-12A, 4-12-
2021; Ord. 2022-4-11, 4-11-2022, eff. 7-1-2022; Ord. 2023-3-13G, 3-13-2023;
Ord. 2024-4-8B, 4-8-2024)
10-2-6: WATER USED FOR CONSTRUCTION OF IMPROVEMENTS AND BUILDINGS:
   A.   Where Village water shall be required from a fire hydrant for
improvements, public or private, or for building purposes in the Village, the
contractor or builder shall pay to the Village for the same the scheduled rate
for one thousand (1,000) gallons as per rates adopted by this chapter to be
measured through a meter to be furnished by the Village set forth in the
Village Fee Schedule, subsection 3-10-1G of this Code.
   B.   The contractor, owner or builder shall make application to the Director
of Public Works for a permit to make such construction or improvement and also
make a deposit with the Finance Director of three hundred dollars ($300.00) to
ensure the return of the meter to the Village in good condition and the payment
of the amount due for water used.
   C.   Upon the return of the meter in good condition to the Village and the
payment by the contractor, builder or owner of all charges for the meter and
for the water used thereby in the construction of the building or improvement,
the money so deposited with the Village Collector shall be returned to the
person so making the deposit.
   D.   All water taken for building purposes shall in all cases be water taken
from inside of the lot line. In construction of buildings, a permit for a tap
shall be applied for at the time the building permit is applied for, and if
granted, a meter shall be furnished and placed at the time of making the tap
for water service to the building, and all water used in such construction
shall be paid for each dwelling and commercial and construction use to pay the
meter rates.
(1971 Code § 22-13)
10-2-7: CONSERVATION MEASURES:
   A.   Right Of Village To Impose Restrictions: The right is reserved by the
Village to suspend the use of yard fountains and hoses for sprinkling whenever,
in the opinion of the Board of Trustees, the public exigency requires it.
   B.   Outdoor Fountains: The service pipe of a fountain out of doors must be
provided with a stopcock or shutoff valve under the control of the Director of
Public Works.
(1971 Code § 22-13)
   C.   Flushing Sanitary Sewers: The flushing of sanitary sewers with potable
water is prohibited except when performed through the use of a high velocity
type sewer jet.
(Ord. 80-10-1B 10-1-1980)
   D.   WaterSense Fixtures: Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained
within this chapter, pursuant to 17 Illinois Administrative Code 3730.307(c)4,
and subject to the Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Illinois Administrative Code 890)
and the Lawn Irrigation Contractor and Lawn Sprinkler System Registration Code
(77 Illinois Administrative Code 892), all new or replacement plumbing fixtures
and irrigation controllers installed after the effective date hereof shall bear
the WaterSense label as designated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
WaterSense Program when such labeled fixtures are available.
   E.   Lawn Sprinkling:
      1.   Definition: For purposes of this subsection, “lawn” shall mean that
portion of any lot under cultivation with grass, trees, shrubs, bushes or other
type of vegetation.
      2.   Days And Hours Restricted:
         a.   During the period from May 15 through September 15 of each year,
it shall be unlawful for any person to use water for hose fed sprinkling or
electronic irrigation of lawns on any day between the hours of twelve o’clock
(12:00) noon through six o’clock (6:00) o’clock P.M.
         b.   During the period from May 15 through September 15 of each year,
it shall be unlawful for any person to use water for hose fed sprinkling or
electronic irrigation of lawns on the thirty first day of any month.
         c.   In addition to the prohibitions stated in subsections E2a and E2b
of this section, it shall be unlawful during all hours during the period from
May 15 through September 15 of each year, on even numbered days of the month,
for any person to use water for hose fed sprinkling or electronic irrigation of
lawns located on odd numbered lots.
         d.   In addition to the prohibitions stated in subsections E2a and E2b
of this section, it shall be unlawful during all hours during the period from
May 15 through September 15 of each year, on odd numbered days of the month,
for any person to use water for hose fed sprinkling or electronic irrigation of
lawns located on even numbered lots.
      3.   Exemptions: The restrictions contained in subsection E2 of this
section shall not apply during the first two (2) weeks after new sod has been
placed, or during the first two (2) weeks after a lawn has been newly seeded;
provided, that the owner or occupant of the property has obtained a sod
watering permit from the Village Department of Public Works.
      4.   Emergencies: If the Village President determines that an emergency
exists which requires that the consumption and use of water within the Village
be limited in order to protect the health and safety of persons within the
Village, the Village President may issue an emergency order which limits and
otherwise restricts the use of water within the Village. Such an emergency
order shall remain in effect for up to seventy two (72) hours unless the order
is extended by vote of the Village Corporate Authorities.
      5.   Penalty: Any person who violates the provisions of subsection E2 or
E3 of this section, or who violates an emergency order issued pursuant to
subsection E4 of this section shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense. Each that day that a violation occurs or continues shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Ord. 2015-11-18F, 11-18-2015)
10-2-8: CLOSED SYSTEM AIR CONDITIONING:
   A.   For purposes of this section, the phrase “major remodeling” means any
remodeling which has a cost or value of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00)
or more, and the phrase “major structural modification” means any structural
modification which has a cost or value of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00)
or more.
   B.   All air conditioning systems installed in any building or structure
which is constructed in the Village shall be of the “closed system” type so as
to provide for the recirculation and reuse of water. Whenever there is any
major remodeling or major structural modification of any building or structure
within the Village which is air conditioned with an air conditioning system
which does not recirculate and reuse water, such air conditioning system shall
be replaced as part of the remodeling or structural modification with closed
system air conditioning which will provide for the recirculation and reuse of
water. (Ord. 83-7-6B, 7-6-1983)
10-2-9: INTERFERENCE WITH, DAMAGE TO SYSTEM:
   A.   No person shall in any manner obstruct the access to any stopcock,
hydrant or valve or any public faucet or opening for taking water in any
street, alley, public ground or place connected with or part of the water or
sewer system or plant, nor pile or place any material of any kind whatsoever so
as to hinder, delay or obstruct the members of the Public Safety Department in
reaching the same.
   B.   No person shall in any manner interfere with or obstruct the flow,
retention, storage or authorized use of water in the water or sewer system or
plant or any part thereof or injure, deface, remove or displace any water main,
hydrant, service pipe, water meter, shutoff box, public fountain, valve,
engine, or building connected with the water or sewer system or plant, or
cause, suffer, or permit any of such things to be done.
   C.   When water service has been shut off by the Director of Public Works or
his designee, it shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to turn on or
otherwise tamper with the shutoff valve in any way, shape or manner.
   D.   No person not duly authorized shall turn the water on at any fire
hydrant or service cock or use water therefrom when so turned on.
(1971 Code § 22-18)
10-2-10: CHANGES TO PROVISIONS:
Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the Village from changing or altering the
provisions hereof, and the Village shall have and retain authority from time to
time to change, increase, decrease or improve the system or plant or any part
or portion thereof or to establish new or different rates, regulations or
provisions concerning the use or change the source of supply or to later amend,
change or repeal any of the provisions of this chapter.
(1971 Code § 22-20)
10-2-11: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each and every offense. In
addition to the fine, the person shall be liable for any and all physical
damage to the water and sewer system or plant or any part thereof.
(1971 Code § 22-21)
ARTICLE A: CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL
Section
10-2A-1:   Applicability Of Backflow And Cross-Connection Requirements
10-2A-2:   Cross-Connection Prohibited
10-2A-3:   Cross-Connection Control Survey And Inspections
10-2A-4:   New/Replacement Cross-Connection Control Installation Inspections
10-2A-5:   Registry
10-2A-6:   Testing Inspection Fee
10-2A-7:   Compliance Required
10-2A-8:   Disconnection Of Service
10-2A-9:   Annual Inspections; Penalty
10-2A-10:   Penalty
10-2A-11:   Prosecution Of Violations; Injunctions
10-2A-1: APPLICABILITY OF BACKFLOW AND CROSS-CONNECTION REQUIREMENTS:
All existing water supply systems receiving potable water from the Village
shall comply with all the regulations and requirements of the Illinois Plumbing
Code addressing cross-connections and backflow, including, but not necessarily
limited to, the requirements of 77 Ill. Admin. Code 890 and 77 Ill. Admin. Code
900. In the event, the standards and requirements of the Illinois Plumbing Code
pertaining to the regulations of cross-connections and the protection against
backflow are in the future amended, such amended requirements shall be
applicable.
(Ord. 2019-1-9A, 1-9-2019; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11C, 4-11-2022)
10-2A-2: CROSS-CONNECTION PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the public water supply
enters the Village's public water supply unless such private, auxiliary or
emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply
shall be in compliance with the Illinois Plumbing Code and approved by the
Director of Public Works and the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency
("IEPA").
   B.   No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any arrangement or
connection by which a pollutant or contaminant may enter the Village's public
water supply.
   C.   Connections between potable water systems and other systems or
equipment containing water or other substances of unknown or questionable
quality are prohibited except when and where cross- connection control devices
or methods which meet the requirements of the Illinois Plumbing Code are
installed, tested and maintained to insure proper operation on a continuing
basis.
   D.   No physical connection shall be permitted between the potable portion
of a water supply system and any other water supply that is not in compliance
with the Illinois Plumbing Code and has not been approved by the Director of
Public Works and the IEPA.
(Ord. 2019-1-9A, 1-9-2019; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11C, 4-11-2022)
10-2A-3: CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL SURVEY AND INSPECTIONS:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the Director of Public Works ("Director") to
cause a survey to be made of properties served by the public water supply to
determine whether actual or potential hazards to the public water supply may
exist by reason of cross-connections or potential backflow risks. Such surveys
and investigations shall be repeated as often as the Director of Public Works
shall deem necessary.
   B.   The survey conducted by the Director of Public Works shall include the
inspection of the premises of all individuals/entities receiving water from the
Village's water system ("water customer" or "customer") to ascertain the
presence or absence of cross-connections within the premises and the need for
the installation of any new cross-connection control devices. It shall be the
duty of all individuals/entities receiving water from the Village's to have any
existing cross-connection control device inspected and tested by a State
licensed cross-connection control inspector annually or more frequently if
recommended by the device's manufacturer. If the owners or occupants of the
premises does not have any cross-connection control device inspected annually
or more frequently if recommended by the device's manufacturer, the Village or
the Village's Director of Public Works is authorized to petition any court
having competent jurisdiction, through the Village Attorney, for the issuance
of a warrant or order authorizing the owners or occupants of a premises to
obtain an inspection, sampling, examination and photocopying and the
performance of any other duties as required by the State Plumbing Code. If the
Director finds that it is necessary to conduct sampling and monitoring
operations, the Director shall request permission from the customer to set up
such sampling and monitoring operations. If the consumer refuses to grant such
permission, the Village or Director shall apply to the appropriate court,
through the Village Attorney, for a warrant or order which will allow such
monitoring and sampling to take place on the premises.
   C.   Commercial, institutional or industrial establishments receiving water
from the Village's public supply shall conduct annual surveys of water use
practices on the customer's premises to determine whether there are actual or
potential cross-connections to the customer's water system through which
contaminants or pollutants could backflow into the public water supply system.
   D.   All individuals/entities receiving water from the Village's water
system shall prevent backflow into the public water system by ensuring that:
      1.   All cross-connections are removed; or cross-connection control
devices are installed in compliance with the Illinois Plumbing Code to protect
against backflow and back-siphonage;
      2.   All cross-connection control devices are installed only in
compliance with the Illinois Plumbing Code and in accordance with the
manufacturer's instructions; and
      3.   Backflow prevention devices shall not be bypassed, made inoperative,
removed or otherwise made ineffective.
(Ord. 2019-1-9A, 1-9-2019; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11C, 4-11-2022)
10-2A-4: NEW/REPLACEMENT CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL INSTALLATION INSPECTIONS:
The installation of all new cross-connection control devices and/or the
replacement of any cross-connection device shall be performed by a licensed
plumber in conformance with the Illinois Plumbing Code and the device
manufacturer's instructions. Before any such new or replacement cross-
connection control device is placed into service, its installation shall be
approved by the Village's plumbing inspector for compliance with the Illinois
Plumbing Code.
(Ord. 2019-1-9A, 1-9-2019; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11C, 4-11-2022)
10-2A-5: REGISTRY:
   A.   The Village through its hired third-party contractor shall maintain a
registry of all cross-connection devices located within the Village. The owner
or occupant receiving water from the Village shall have an obligation to
maintain records of the information required below for the registry and shall
provide such information to the Village's third-party contractor upon request.
The State licensed cross-connection control inspector hired by the owner/
occupant shall also have an obligation to provide the information required
below to the Village's third-party contractor. The registry shall include the
following information:
      1.   The water customer or owner of the device;
      2.   The address where the device is located and a reasonably specific
description of where the device is located on the premises;
      3.   The make and model of the device;
      4.   The date of the inspection and testing of the device;
      5.   The results of any testing;
      6.   The date installed, if known;
      7.   The inspection and testing frequency;
      8.   Name of the State licensed cross-connection control inspector
performing the test and/or the name of the Village Plumber performing the
inspection;
      9.   Any repairs or servicing required;
      10.   The date any repairs or servicing was completed and the name of the
licensed plumber performing the repair; and
      11.   Any additional information that may be required by the Illinois
Plumbing Code.
   B.   In addition, each device shall have a tag attached listing the date of
most recent test or visual inspection, name of tester, and type and date of
repairs.
(Ord. 2019-1-9A, 1-9-2019; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11C, 4-11-2022)
10-2A-6: TESTING INSPECTION FEE:
Each water customer shall pay a two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) testing fee
to the Village for each cross-connection control device tested by the Village's
CCCDI Inspector. The testing fee includes one (1) retesting of any cross-
control device that may be necessary to insure the device is properly
functioning following any necessary repairs or replacement of a device required
as a result of the initial inspection. In the event more than one retesting is
required for any cross-connection device, an additional fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) shall be payable for each additional retesting of the device.
The inspection fee shall be paid within twenty one (21) days after the receipt
of an invoice is received from the Village.
(Ord. 2019-1-9A, 1-9-2019)
10-2A-7: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Consumers must comply with this article in order to continue to receive
water service from the Village's public water supply system.
   B.   If the public water supply is contaminated or polluted by back siphoned
material or backflow, and the contamination or pollution occurs through an
improperly installed, maintained or repaired backflow prevention device, or
because a backflow prevention device has been bypassed, then the water customer
responsible shall, in addition to any fines or other amounts due under this
article, pay to the Village any and all costs incurred in removing the
contaminant or pollutant from the public water supply system, including the
cost of effecting compliance with and enforcing this article.
(Ord. 2019-1-9A, 1-9-2019; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11C, 4-11-2022)
10-2A-8: DISCONNECTION OF SERVICE:
   A.   The premises of a water customer who violates a provision of this
article may be disconnected from the public water supply system as provided in
this section.
   B.   Procedures For Immediate Disconnection:
      1.   A water customer is subject to having the customer's premises
immediately disconnected from the Village's public water supply system whenever
immediate disconnection is required to halt or prevent any pollutant or
contaminant from flowing from the premises into the public water supply system
which reasonably appears to the Director of Public Works to present a severe
health hazard.
      2.   The Director of Public Works shall have the authority, after
informal notice to the consumer, to immediately and effectively halt or prevent
any discharge of pollutants or contaminants to the public water supply system
that reasonably appears to present a severe health hazard. When the Director
determines that such an emergency situation exists, he shall issue a verbal
order (followed immediately by a written order) to the water customer, stating
the problem and requiring immediate cessation of the discharge. The Director's
actions may include the disconnection of water service if there is an imminent
threat of a severe health hazard. Methods of informal notice shall include, but
not be limited to, any of the following: personal conversation between the
water customer and Village employees, telephone calls, letters, hand-delivered
messages or notices posted at the water customer's premises or point of
discharge.
      3.   Right To Request Hearing: A water customer who is disconnected
pursuant to subsection B1 or B2 above, shall have the right to request a
hearing, at which time the customer shall be given the opportunity to show
cause as to why it should not be disconnected from the public water supply
system. Such hearings shall commence within seven (7) days after a written
request for the hearing is received by the Village President. Such hearing
shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures contained in subsection C
below.
   C.   Procedures For Disconnection In Non-Emergency Situations:
      1.   The Director of Public Works may order a water customer who causes
or allows any condition to occur which violates the provisions of this article
to show cause at a hearing as to why the premises where the condition occurred
should not be disconnected from the public water supply system. A notice shall
be served on the consumer specifying the time and place of a hearing regarding
the violation, the reasons why the action is to be taken, the proposed action
and directing the customer to show cause why the premises should not be
disconnected. The notice of the hearing shall be served personally or by
registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, at least ten (10) days
before the hearing. Service may be made on any agent or officer of a
corporation.
      2.   The Village President may conduct the hearing and take the evidence
or may designate the Village Attorney to:
         a.   Issue notices of hearings requesting the attendance and testimony
of witnesses and the production of evidence relevant to any matter involved in
such hearing;
         b.   Take the evidence; and
         c.   Transmit a report of the evidence and hearing, including
transcripts and other evidence, together with recommendations to the Village
President for action thereon.
      3.   After the Village President has reviewed the evidence, he may issue
an order to the water customer directing either that the premises be
disconnected from the public water supply system; or following a specified
time, the premises shall be disconnected and water service discontinued, unless
the condition causing the violation is corrected.
      4.   Following an order to disconnect, the Director of Public Works shall
cause whatever action is needed to be taken in order to disconnect the
consumer's premises from the public water supply system.
   D.   Restoration Of Water Service: If water service to the premises is
disconnected pursuant to this section, water service shall not be restored to
the premises until such time as the condition which caused the violation is
corrected and a reconnection fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) is paid
to the Village.
(Ord. 2019-1-9A, 1-9-2019; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11C, 4-11-2022)
10-2A-9: ANNUAL INSPECTIONS; PENALTY:
   A.   It shall be the affirmative duty of every owner/occupant of a building
or structure receiving water from the Village to have all cross-connection
control devices inspected annually by a State licensed cross-connection control
inspector or more frequently if required by the manufacturer of the cross-
connection control device. It shall be a violation of the Village Code for any
water customer to fail to have the inspection and testing of any cross-
connection control device completed on or before the due date for such testing.
If a water customer fails to undertake the inspection or testing of and cross-
connection control device prior to the due date for the inspection/testing the
water customer shall, upon being found liable, pay the following fines:
      1.   Zero (0) to forty-four (44) days past due: a fine of two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) for each past due device; and
      2.   Forty-five (45) or more days past due: a fine of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each past due device plus an additional fine of five
hundred dollars ($500.00) per each past due device for each additional thirty
(30) day period after the first forty five (45) days.
   B.   If the inspection is past due by more than one hundred twenty (120)
days the Village, in addition to any monetary fines that shall continue to
accrue, shall have the ability to seek the non-emergency disconnection of the
premises from the Village's public water supply. Nothing contained in this
section shall preclude the Village from undertaking an immediate disconnection
from the public water supply when such action is required to halt or prevent
any pollutant or contaminant from flowing into the public water supply system
which reasonably appears to the Director of Public Works to present a severe
health hazard.
(Ord. 2019-1-9A, 1-9-2019; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11C, 4-11-2022)
10-2A-10: PENALTY:
A violation of this article (other than a violation addressed in section
10-2A-9) shall, upon conviction thereof, shall be punishable by a fine of not
less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) with each day a violation occurs being considered as a
separate and distinct violation.
(Ord. 2019-1-9A, 1-9-2019; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11C, 4-11-2022)
10-2A-11: PROSECUTION OF VIOLATIONS; INJUNCTIONS:
Violations of the provisions of this article are subject to prosecution under
the Village's administrative adjudication proceedings established pursuant
title 1, chapter 4, article A of this Code as now or hereafter amended. The
provisions of this section shall not preclude the Village from using other
methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of this article,
including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the Circuit
Court of Cook County, or before another administrative tribunal which has
jurisdiction to consider the violation. In the event that a person commits
repeated violations of this article, the Village may institute an action to
enjoin further such person from committing further violations of this article.
In the event such an action is instituted and an injunction is issued, the
person whose conduct is enjoined shall be required to compensate the Village
for the attorneys' fees and other costs incurred in obtaining the injunction.
(Ord. 2019-1-9A, 1-9-2019; amd. Ord. 2022-4-11C, 4-11-2022)
CHAPTER 3: WASTEWATER CONTROL
Section
10-3-1:   Connections Inside Village Limits
10-3-2:   Discharges Into Storm Sewers Prohibited
10-3-3:   Grease Interceptors
10-3-1: CONNECTIONS INSIDE VILLAGE LIMITS:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall make or cause to be made any
connection with a public sewer without first having received a permit for such
connection from the Village Clerk.
(1971 Code § 22-2)
   B.   Application For Permit: Application for a permit must be made by the
owner of the property on which it is desired to drain, or by his duly
authorized agent, and it must be accompanied by a clear and exact description
of the premises and the character and location of the drains it is proposed to
put in place, together with the number and location of all water closets,
sinks, bathtubs, receiving basins and other sanitary fixtures it is designed to
connect with, which description must be left and placed on file in the Office
of the Director of Public Works for future reference.
   C.   Issuance Of Permit: Upon the approval of the application by the
Director of Public Works, the Village Engineer shall issue to the applicant a
permit to connect the private or house drain with any public sewer or drain;
provided, that the applicant is justly and legally entitled thereto.
(1971 Code § 22-3)
   D.   Tap In Permit Fees: The tap in permit fees for connections made to the
public sewer system shall be as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule,
subsection 3-10-1G of this Code.
(1971 Code § 22-5; amd. 2019 Code)
   E.   Installation Of Connections:
      1.   All work in connection with the installation of sewer connections
shall be done by licensed drain layers or by competent servants, agents or
employees in the employ of such drain layers and shall be subject to the
inspection, supervision and approval of the Director of Public Works.
      2.   All sewer pipe and catch basin work shall be left exposed for
thorough inspection as to grades and quality of pipe, brick, and cement and
comparison with plans, and shall not be covered up until passed upon by the
Director of Public Works.
      3.   All work on sewer connections shall be done in accordance with plans
and specifications approved by the Director of Public Works and subject to such
rules and regulations as may be adopted by the Village Board of Trustees.
(1971 Code § 22-4)
   F.   Separate Permits And Connections Required: A separate permit and a
separate connection shall be required for each building connected to the
Village sewer system under the terms of this section.
(1971 Code § 22-5)
   G.   Penalty: Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall
be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day an illegal
connection shall remain in place shall constitute a separate offense.
(1971 Code § 22-6)
10-3-2: DISCHARGES INTO STORM SEWERS PROHIBITED:
No person shall permit, make, or cause to be made a connection or otherwise
discharge sewage or industrial waste into any storm sewer located in the
Village.
(1971 Code § 22-22)
10-3-3: GREASE INTERCEPTORS:
   A.   Definition: As used in this section, the term “grease basin or
interceptor” means a receptacle designed to cause separation and retention of
oil or grease from liquid wastes.
(1971 Code § 22-23)
   B.   Regulations:
      1.   Sinks, dishwashers, or other fixtures in restaurants, hotels,
motels, clubhouses, public institutions, butcher shops, or other establishments
from which greasy wastes are discharged shall be connected to a grease
interceptor approved by the Director of Public Works and the Village Engineer,
located as close as possible to the fixtures served, and within the limits of
the same room.
      2.   All grease interceptors located within buildings shall be
constructed of heavy cast-iron and shall be provided with a tight metal cover,
securely fastened.
      3.   All grease interceptors shall have a capacity sufficient to
intercept and retain not less than ninety five percent (95%) of the grease
received.
      4.   All grease interceptors shall be provided with suitable vents to
prevent loss of seal, as required for plumbing fixtures. Traps shall have not
less than a four inch (4") seal.
      5.   a. A grease catch basin located outside a building shall be of
concrete, precast in blocks, or of MWRD construction standards.
         b.   The basin shall be watertight and shall not be less than thirty
six inches (36") in diameter below the top of the highest inlet pipe. It shall
be partitioned by a vertical baffle plate of cast iron. One face of the baffle
shall be perpendicular to the line of the outlet pipe and eight inches (8")
from it. The top of the baffle shall be twelve inches (12") above the top of
the outlet pipe, and the bottom of the baffle shall be twelve inches (12")
below the invert of the pipe. The bottom of the basin shall be twelve inches
(12") below the bottom of the baffle. The outlet pipe shall not be trapped. The
basin shall be covered with an all cast-iron cover or cast-iron lid in a stone
or concrete ring and with a minimum opening of sixteen inches (16"). The lid
shall not be less than one-fourth inch (1/4") thick.
      6.    The inverts of the inlet pipes carrying grease bearing wastes shall
not be less than six inches (6") above the outlet pipe. Interior covered garage
drains may be connected to a grease catch basin without any other intervening
basin when the capacity of the garage does not exceed two (2) cars and the roof
area is not more than five hundred feet (500'). Such drains shall connect on
the inlet side of the grease basin and shall be trapped at the basin unless
traps are provided elsewhere. Traps at the grease basin for garage drains shall
be cast-iron elbows, cast-iron offsets, or cast-iron tile, or concrete half
traps, all of them to be built into the wall of the basin and so placed as to
give at least a four inch (4") seal for garage drains.
(1971 Code § 22-24)
   C.   Inspections: The Department of the Health and Licensing shall
periodically inspect the grease interceptors to ensure the proper maintenance
and operation of the interceptors.
(1971 Code § 22-25)
   D.   Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section
shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day a violation is
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense.
(1971 Code § 22-26)
TITLE 11: BUILDING AND DEVELOPMENT
CHAPTER 1: GENERAL BUILDING REGULATIONS
Section
11-1-1:   Maximum Number Of Occupants In Dwelling Units
11-1-2:   Multi-Family Residential Buildings
11-1-3:   Underground Utility Lines
11-1-1: MAXIMUM NUMBER OF OCCUPANTS IN DWELLING UNITS:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
      DWELLING UNIT. An apartment or house which can legally be used as a
permanent residence. A room in a hotel or motel which is intended for occupancy
overnight by transients shall not be considered a “dwelling unit”.
      HABITABLE ROOM. A room which has an area larger than fifty (50) square
feet and which is not a kitchen, bathroom or closet.
      OCCUPANT. A person who occupies or resides in a dwelling unit for fifteen
(15) or more days in a calendar month.
   B.   Maximum Number Of Occupants: The maximum number of persons who shall be
permitted to be occupants of a dwelling unit shall be one and one-half (11/2)
times the number of habitable rooms in the dwelling unit. For purposes of this
section, a child under one year of age shall not be considered to be a person
and a child less than twelve (12) years of age shall be considered to be one-
half (1/2) a person.
   C.   Violation; Penalty: Any owner, manager or lessee of a dwelling unit who
authorizes, allows or permits the number of occupants of a dwelling unit to
exceed the maximum number of occupants permitted under subsection B of this
section shall be in violation of this section. Any person who violates this
section shall, upon conviction be subject to a fine of not less than two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00)
for each violation. Each day any violation of this section shall exist shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 88-4-6C, 4-6-1988)
11-1-2: MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS:
   A.   Parking Spaces Designated; Use Regulations:
      1.   Definitions: As used in this subsection, the following words and
terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection A1:
         MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL BUILDING. Any residential building not owned
by either a Federal, State or local governmental body which has four (4) or
more residential dwelling units. Hotels and motels are not multi-family
residential buildings.
         PARKING LOT. A parking lot located on the same lot as or located
adjacent to a multi-family residential building which is intended for use by
the residents of the multi-family residential building and their guests.
      2.   Parking Spaces Designated; Dimensions: On and after December 1,
1988, all parking spaces within a parking lot must be designated. All such
parking spaces shall be designated either by pavement markings at least four
inches (4") in width or by the placement of bumper guards or wheel guards. Each
parking space shall be at least sixteen feet (16') in length and nine feet (9')
in width and shall open directly on an aisle or driveway at least twelve feet
(12') wide.
      3.   Park Within Designated Space: No vehicle shall be parked in a
parking lot unless such vehicle is parked within a designated parking space.
      4.   Towing Illegally Parked Vehicles: The Village Public Safety
Department shall have the authority to have any vehicle parked in violation of
the provisions of this subsection towed in accordance with Village ordinances,
rules and regulations relating to the towing of illegally parked vehicles (See
section
8-2-3 of this Code).
      5.   Signs Posted; Specifications: On and after December 1988, the owner
and manager of each multi-family residential building which has a parking lot
shall post and maintain a sign at least twenty four inches (24") in height by
thirty six inches (36") in width in a conspicuous place in the parking lot.
Such sign shall be at least four feet (4') from the ground but less than eight
feet (8') from the ground and shall be either illuminated or painted with
reflective paint, or both. The sign shall state that parking is permitted in
designated spaces only and that any vehicle not parked in a designated space in
the parking lot shall be subject to being towed.
      6.   Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this subsection
shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not less than seventy five
dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense. Each day that a violation of a provision of this subsection occurs
shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 88-10-5E, 10-5-1988)
   B.   Snow Removal From Apartment Building Parking Lots:
      1.   Application Of Provisions:
         a.   The provisions of this subsection shall not a apply to buildings
which have three (3) or fewer dwelling units.
         b.   The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to an apartment
building which is under condominium ownership as provided in the Illinois
Condominium Property Act (765 ILCS 605/1 et seq.)
      2.   Definitions: The following definitions shall apply in the
interpretation and enforcement of this subsection:
         APARTMENT BUILDING. A residential building which contains four (4) or
more separate dwelling units.
         MANAGER. An agent or independent contractor of the owner of an
apartment building who provides management services for the owner. Services
such as the rental or the leasing of apartments, janitorial services, and
rental collection services shall be considered to be management services which
shall make the person furnishing such services a “manager” for purposes of this
subsection.
         OWNER. Any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others, has
legal or equitable title to an apartment building.
         PARKING LOT OR APARTMENT BUILDING PARKING LOT. An outdoor or uncovered
parking lot which is designated or intended for use by residents of an
apartment building.
         TWO INCH SNOWFALL. A snowfall which is reported by a Federal, State or
local governmental agency as being two inches (2") or more at Chicago-O’Hare
International Airport.
      3.   Removal By Owner Or Manager:
         a.   Removal Required:
             (1)   Whenever there is a snowfall of two inches (2") or more, the
parking lot of an apartment building shall be plowed or snow shall otherwise be
removed from the parking lot of such an apartment building within two (2) hours
after the snowfall ends, so as to allow motor vehicles to make use unimpeded by
snow or ice of: a) the driveways leading to and from the parking lot to the
