public street; b) any fire lanes located within the parking lot or alongside
the apartment building; and c) the driving lanes located in the parking lot
which are used to access parking spaces in the parking lot.
             (2)   Whenever there is a snowfall of two inches (2") or more, the
parking lot of an apartment building shall be plowed or snow shall otherwise be
removed from the parking lot of the apartment building within two (2) hours
after the snowfall ends so as to allow the waste disposal service that removes
trash, garbage, and other refuse from the apartment building to have access
unimpeded by snow or ice to the dumpsters and any other receptacles where
trash, garbage and other refuse from the apartment building are deposited prior
to pick up by the waste disposal service.
         b.   Responsibility Of Owner And Manager: The owner and any manager of
the apartment building shall be jointly and severally responsible for the
plowing or other removal of snow as required by subsection B3a this section.
         c.   Penalty: If an apartment building parking lot is not plowed or
snow otherwise removed from the parking lot as required by subsection B3a of
this section, the owner and/or any manager of the apartment building, upon
conviction, shall be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) nor more than one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00)
for each offense. A separate offense shall be considered to have been committed
for each twelve (12) hour period, or part thereof, that an apartment building
parking lot is not plowed or snow is not otherwise removed from the apartment
building parking lot as required by subsection B3a of this section.
      4.   Removal By Village; Costs A Lien:
         a.   Removal By Village: If the parking lot of an apartment building
is not plowed or snow is not otherwise removed from the parking lot of an
apartment building so as to permit motor vehicles to make unimpeded use of the
parking lot as required by subsection B3a of this section within four (4) hours
after the snowfall ends, the Village Director of Public Works may, but shall
not be obligated to, have the parking lot plowed or to otherwise have the snow
removed from the parking lot.
         b.   Costs A Lien:
             (1)   If the Director of Public Works has an apartment building
parking lot plowed or snow otherwise removed from an apartment building parking
lot, as provided in subsection B4a of this section, then the costs incurred by
the Village in having the parking lot plowed or the snow otherwise removed from
the parking lot shall be recoverable from the owner of the apartment building,
and the Village shall have a lien on the real estate on which the apartment
building is located for the cost of plowing or other snow removal; provided,
that within ninety (90) days after the date on which the plowing or other snow
removal occurred, the Village files notice in the Office of the Cook County
Recorder that the Village has a lien for the costs and expenses the Village
incurred in plowing or otherwise removing snow from the parking lot of the
apartment building, plus interest on the amount of the costs and expenses at a
rate of one percent (1%) per month, or part thereof, from the date the costs
and expenses were incurred.
             (2)   The notice of lien filed pursuant to subsection B4b(1) of
this section must include:
               (A)   A description of the property sufficient for
identification thereof;
               (B)   The amount of the costs and expenses incurred by the
Village in plowing the apartment building parking lot or otherwise removing
snow from the apartment building parking lot; and
               (C)   The date or dates when the costs and expenses were
incurred by the Village.
             (3)   The lien provided in this subsection B4b may be enforced by
proceedings to foreclose as in the case of mortgages or mechanic’s liens. A
suit to foreclose the lien shall be commenced within three (3) years after the
date the notice of lien was filed in the Office of the Cook County Recorder.
             (4)   Upon payment of the costs and expenses as set forth in the
notice of lien, the lien shall be released by the Village, and the Village
shall tender a release of the lien to the owner of the apartment building in a
form which may be filed of record in the Office of the Cook County Recorder.
(Ord. 2001-1-10C, 1-10-2001)
   C.   Outside Lighting Requirements:
      1.   Definition: As used in this subsection, the term “multiple-family
dwelling” shall mean any dwelling that is either owned, rented, leased, let or
hired out to be occupied, or is occupied, as the residence or home of three (3)
or more families living independently of each other.
      2.   Requirements:
         a.   The owner and manager of every multiple-family dwelling shall
install and maintain a light or lights at or near the outside of the side of
the building which is adjacent to an alleyway which shall, in the aggregate,
provide not less than seventy five (75) watts incandescent illumination for the
alleyway.
         b.   The lights shall be kept illuminated from sunset every day to
sunrise on the day following.
         c.   The owner or manager shall determine the actual location, design
and nature of the installation of such light or lights to meet practical,
aesthetic and other considerations so long as the minimum level of illumination
is maintained.
(Ord. 94-4-6M, 4-6-1994)
11-1-3: UNDERGROUND UTILITY LINES:
   A.   New Utility Lines Not In A Public Right-Of-Way:
      1.   Underground Lines Required: All utility lines installed after the
effective date hereof that are not within a public right-of-way shall be
installed underground. For purposes of this subsection, a "utility line" is a
cable, wire, pipe, or other form of conduit used to transmit or convey
electricity, natural gas, oil, water, sewage and similar substances. A wire,
cable or line used to transmit telephone, telegraph, television, streaming,
and/or internet services is a "utility line". When a utility line is located in
an underground conduit, it may only be replaced by a utility line located in
the same underground conduit.
      2.   Waivers: Where, because of unusual circumstances, it is either not
reasonably possible to install a utility line underground or where the cost of
underground installation of a utility line will be so great as to make it
economically unfeasible to install the utility line underground, the Director
of Public Works may waive the requirements of subsection A.1. of this section
upon written request submitted by the person claiming the existence of the
unusual circumstance. In the event such a request is made, copies of the
request shall be forwarded to the Village President along with a copy of the
Director's decision granting or denying the request. Any request for waiver
submitted pursuant to this subsection A.2. shall describe in reasonable detail
why there are unusual circumstances which either make it not reasonably
possible to install a utility line underground or which make it economically
unfeasible to install a utility line underground. Before acting on a request
for a waiver, the Director may require the person making the request to submit
documents and other evidence to substantiate the claim of unusual
circumstances.
      3.   Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this subsection
shall be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each
day that a violation of this subsection is permitted to exist shall constitute
a separate offense.
   B.   Certain Utility Lines Located In The Public Right-Of-Way To Be
Underground:
      1.   Definitions: As used in this subsection, the following words and
terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection B1:
         ABUTTING RIGHT-OF-WAY. That portion of the public right-of-way, title
to which will vest in the owners of the lot, parcel or tract upon which the
building or structure is located in the event the public right-of-way were to
be abandoned or vacated.
         BUILDING OR STRUCTURE. Any building or structure for which an
occupancy permit is required and which is not a single-family or two family
residence.
         UTILITY LINE. A cable, wire, pipe, or other form of conduit used to
transmit or convey electricity, natural gas, oil, water, sewage or similar
substances. A wire cable or line used to transmit telephone or telegraph
messages is a “utility line”.
      2.   Underground Lines Required; Exemptions: After the effective date
hereof, no occupancy permit shall be issued for any building or structure
unless the utility lines located within the abutting right-of-way are installed
and/or relocated underground; provided, however, that such relocation and/or
installation shall not be required for utility lines belonging to the Central
Telephone Company, Commonwealth Edison Company or the Illinois Bell Telephone
Company in the event that the utility company which owns such a line refuses to
permit the line to be installed or relocated underground.
      3.   Waivers: Where, because of unusual circumstances, it is either not
reasonably possible to install or relocate a utility line underground or where
the cost of underground installation or relocation of a utility line will be so
great as to make it economically unfeasible to install or relocate the utility
line underground, the Director of Public Works may waive the requirements of
subsection B2 of this section upon written request submitted by the person
claiming the existence of the unusual circumstance. In the event such a request
is made, copies of the request shall be forwarded to the Village President
along with a copy of the Director’s decision granting or denying the request.
Any request for waiver submitted pursuant to this subsection B3 shall describe
in reasonable detail why there are unusual circumstances which either make it
not reasonably possible to relocate or install a utility line underground or
which make it economically unfeasible to relocate or install a utility line
underground. Before acting on a request for a waiver, the Director may require
the person making the request to submit documents and other evidence to
substantiate the claim of unusual circumstances.
(Ord. 85-7-3E, 7-3-1985; amd. Ord. 86-5-7G, 5-7-1986; Ord. 2025-2-10B, 2-10-
2025)

11-2-1: ADOPTION OF CODES BY REFERENCE:
The erection, construction, repair, alteration, maintenance and occupancy of
all buildings and structures shall be in compliance with the provisions of the
codes referenced in this chapter, which are adopted by reference and
incorporated as if fully set forth herein, with the amendments, additions,
deletions and modifications provided herein.
(Ord. 2015-11-18G, 11-18-2015; amd. Ord. 2024-12-9A, 12-9-2024)

and K10, which is adopted by reference, with the following amendments,

   Section 510 Basements.
   510.1 General. Buildings of other than use group R-3 shall be provided with
at least one stair access direct from the exterior to a basement for fire
department use. One such access shall be provided for each 25,000 sq. ft. of
basement area or fraction thereof. The stairway(s) shall be constructed in
accordance with sections 1009.4, 1009.5 and 1009.6.

foundation or floor/ceiling assembly below to the underside of the floor or
roof sheathing, slab or deck above. The supporting construction shall be
protected to afford the required fire-resistance rating of the wall supported.

Chapter 9 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   Section 913 Fire Department Access
   913.1 Fire Department access. When the access to or within a building,
structure or area is unduly difficult because of secured openings or where
immediate access is necessary for life saving or firefighting purposes, the
Code Official may require a key box to be installed in an approved accessible
location. The key box shall be a type approved by the fire official and shall
contain keys to gain access as required by the fire official.

ceiling height and allow bathrooms, toilet rooms and storage rooms to have a
minimum height of 7 feet 6 inches.
Chapter 15 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   Section 1511 Roof Top Anchors
   1511.1 General. All Buildings 4 stories or higher shall be provided with
fire fighter roof top anchors in accordance with sections 1511.2 through 1511.
7 for the purpose of attaching fire fighter lift lines. Only approved anchors
and anchor fittings shall be used. Anchors are to be in the shape of a 2 1/
2 inch inside diameter eye bolt with shoulder and designed for attachment to
the roof structure.
   1511.2 Material. Anchor material shall be of corrosion resistant material
and have an ultimate tensile strength of not less than 55,000 psi, with an
elongation of at least 25% in two inches. Machined fastenings and other
fittings shall be of the same material as the forgings to which they are
attached except that machined parts of stainless steel may be of AISI type 303
or 316 or ASTM designation A582-67 type 303 or 316. The material shall conform
to one of the following specifications; Nickel-copper alloy-ASTM 8164-61 class
A Stainless Steel - AISI type 304, SAE type 30304, AISI type 316, ASTM
designation A314-63 types 304 and 306.
   1511.3 Location. Anchors shall be set in pairs with the first anchor set
back 15 feet from the face of the exterior wall and the second anchor being
located 3 feet behind and 2 feet to the side of the first anchor. Anchor pairs
shall be spaced at not more than 50 foot intervals around the perimeter of the
building.
   1511.4 Loads. All anchors and anchor fittings as a unit shall be capable of
withstanding the following loadings, of which at least two units shall be
tested under actual laboratory conditions.
      1511.4.1 A tension pull without fracture of 15,000 pounds applied at 90
degrees from the vertical.
      1511.4.2 A drop test with a 500 pound rigid weight falling a distance of
4 feet without fracture of the anchor or anchor fittings.
      1511.4.3 The supporting roof structure shall be capable of resisting a
load of 15,000 pounds applied to the eye of the anchor at 90 degrees from the
vertical.
   1511.5 Testing. Anchors and anchor fittings shall be tested in accordance
with Chapter 17 of this code.
   1511.6 Maintenance. Fire fighter life line anchors shall be maintained in a
good and safe condition without obstructions.
   1511.7 Inspections. Within two years of installation and at least every five
years thereafter all anchors and anchor connections shall be subjected to a
critical examination by a structural engineer registered in the State of
Illinois, employed by the building's owner or owner's agent. Said engineer
shall prepare and submit to the fire official a written report on the
structural condition of the anchor assemblies and its supports.
Section 1805.4.3 is deleted in its entirety.
Section 2702.1 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   2702.1.3 Status indicators. Status indication of normal power on and
emergency power on shall be provided at the Fire Command Center generator
control panel.
   2702.1.3 Remote start. A single action start switch shall be provided at the
Fire Command Center generator panel for test run of the generator. When
activated the generator shall start, cycle through the test run period and shut
down automatically.
   2702.1.4 Trouble alarm. A remote trouble condition shall be activated at the
fire department alarm center when the generator is taken out of service.
Chapter 27 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   2702.4 Generator room. Emergency and standby power generator(s) located
within a building shall be in a room with a minimum 2 hour fire resistance
rating.
Section 3001 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   3001.5 Emergency lighting. In all passenger and freight elevator cars a
battery back-up emergency lighting system with a minimum of two lamps shall be
provided. The emergency lighting shall activate within 10 seconds of a primary
power failure and operate for a minimum duration of three (3) hours.
   3001.6 Pit lighting. A permanent switched light powered by the buildings
power supply shall be provided in the elevator pit.
   3001.7 Emergency communication. Two-way emergency communication shall be
provided between the elevator cab and the Fire Command Center where provided.
   3001.8 Capacity. The minimum weight capacity of an elevator cab shall be
3500 lbs.
Section 3003 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   Two way communication. In addition to any other communication systems
required for an elevator car, a two way voice communication system shall be
provided between the car and the fire panel.
Section 3105 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   3305.5 Height. Awnings and canopies over driving lanes, aisles, or fire

above of at least 14 feet. Section 3304 is amended by adding thereto the

   3304.1.5 Fire hydrants. Operable and accessible fire hydrant(s) shall be

above grade level as approved by the fire official.

of sufficient load bearing capacity to support fire department apparatus shall
be installed and maintained as approved by the fire official.
   Section 3310.1 is amended to substitute "12 feet" for "50 feet" and "2
stories" for "four stories".

Chapter Three is amended by adding thereto the following section:
Section R325 Automatic Fire Sprinkler System (See also sections 11-2-8 (Section
903.6.2.1), 11-5-1 and 11-5-2 of this title)
   R325.1 General. An automatic fire sprinkler system shall be installed in
accordance with this section.
   R325.2 Detached dwelling. Any newly constructed dwelling 4,000 square feet
or more in gross floor area shall be provided with an automatic fire sprinkler
system. Gross floor area is defined as the floor area within the inside
perimeter of the exterior walls of the building, exclusive of basement,
attached garage less than 650 sq. ft. in size, screen rooms less than 240 sq.
ft., shafts, courts, without deduction for corridors, hallways, stairways,
closets, the thickness of interior walls, columns or other features.
   R325.3 Townhouse dwelling. An approved automatic fire sprinkler system shall
be installed in townhouse units in accordance with section 903.3.1 of the
International Building Code, 2006 edition.
   R325.4 Installation. An automatic fire sprinkler system shall be a system
designed and installed in accordance with NFPA 13-02, NFPA 13D-02 or NFPA 13R-
02.
   R325.5 Retroactivity. Any detached dwelling constructed after and not
required to install an automatic fire sprinkler system per section R325.2 shall
install such a system should the building be added onto resulting in a gross
floor area of 4,000 sq. ft. or greater.

shall be provided for a porch, terrace slab, concrete or masonry steps and
stoops which adjoin the foundation.

   604.8 Conditions. Notwithstanding all of the above, manufactured wiring
systems are prohibited except when the following conditions are met:
      (a)   The building within which the system is installed must be use group
B as defined by the International Building Code and have a gross floor area in
excess of 50,000 sq. ft.
      (b)   The system is confined to an accessible space below a raised floor,
except that the secondary distribution cables not in excess of 12 feet in
length shall be allowed to serve all wall receptacles and switches.
      (c)   The voltage drop from the supply panel to the last outlet shall not
exceed 5%.
      (d)   Prior to issuance of a permit for a system, a detailed drawing
prepared by a registered design professional shall be submitted, reviewed and
approved.
      (e)   The system shall be subject to any and all terms and conditions as
may be prescribed by the authority having jurisdiction.

   306.3 Use group F-2 building's fire area exceeding 1,000 sq. ft.
   306.4 Use group U building's fire area exceeding 1,000 sq. ft.
Section 903.3.5 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   Only double check detector fire protection backflow prevention assemblies
are allowed. Reduced pressure principle backflow preventers shall not be
allowed on fire protection systems.
Section 903.3 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   903.3.7 Fire pumps. Fire pump(s) shall be located in a dedicated room with a
minimum 2 hour fire resistance rating.
Section 903.6 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   903.6.2 Existing buildings and structures. All buildings and structures,
except one and two family dwellings, shall be equipped with an approved
automatic fire sprinkler system when 10,000 sq. ft. in area as a result of
remodeling, connection, penetration, alteration, or addition.
   903.6.2.1 System requirements. All automatic fire sprinkler systems shall be
installed and maintained, in accordance with NFPA pamphlet #13 governing
sprinkler systems. The following requirements shall also apply:
      (a)   any sprinklered structure larger than 10,000 sq. ft. in area shall
have the flow alarm from the sprinkler system connected directly to the
Rosemont Public Safety Department Communication Center.
      (b)   any sprinklered structure larger than 10,000 sq. ft. in area shall
have a minimum of one (1) 1-1/2 inch fire department hose drop from the system,
for each 10,000 sq. ft. of floor area or fraction thereof.
      (c)   an outside audible alarm bell, connected to the flow alarm, shall
be installed and maintained on all automatic sprinkler systems.
      (d)   all fire department connections to the sprinkler system shall be
National Standard thread type.
      (e)   on all automatic sprinkler systems covering 5,000 sq. ft. or more
in area, a jockeypump shall be provided to maintain the system's pressure.
Section 905.3 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   905.3.8 Parking structures. Parking structures, open or enclosed, shall be
equipped throughout with a Class I manual dry standpipe system provided that
the hose connections are located as required for Class II standpipes in
accordance with section 905.5.
Section 905 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   905.11. Air purging. Dry standpipe systems with fire department connections
shall be equipped with an approved air purging valve at the high point of the
system.
   Section 906.9 is amended by substituting "4 feet" for "5 feet" as applicable
to the mounting height of fire extinguishers weighing not more than 40 pounds.
Section 907 is amended by adding thereto the following:
   907.20 Sequence of alarm. Upon activation from a single device the system
alarm notification shall operate on the alarm floor, the floor above and the
floor below for a period of five (5) minutes at which time the entire building
shall go into alarm notification mode. In the event more than one device is
activated the entire building shall go into alarm notification mode.
(Ord. 2015-11-18G, 11-18-2015; amd. Ord. 2024-12-9A, 12-9-2024)

11-2-11: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY:
   A.   Administrative Adjudication:
      1.   Violations of the provisions of this chapter are subject to
prosecution under the Village's administrative adjudication proceedings set
forth in Title 1, Chapter 4, Article A of the Village code, as now or hereafter
amended.
      2.   The provisions of this section shall not preclude the Village from
using other methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of this
chapter, including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the
Circuit Court of Cook County or before another administrative tribunal which
has jurisdiction to consideration of the violation.
   B.   Penalty: Any person violating any provisions of this chapter, shall,
upon conviction or upon an administrative determination that a violation
occurred, be fined in the amount of less not less two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. Each
twenty-four (24) hour period that a violation continues shall constitute a
separate violation.
(Ord. 2024-12-9A, 12-9-2024)
CHAPTER 3: PLUMBING CODE AND REGULATIONS
Section
11-3-1:   Plumbing Code
11-3-2:   Overhead Plumbing; Footing Drains
11-3-3:   Enforcement And Penalty
11-3-1: PLUMBING CODE:
The current edition of the Illinois Plumbing Code, published by the Illinois
Department of Public Health, 77 Ill. Adm. Code, Part 890, and as amended from
time to time, three (3) copies of which are on file in the Office of the
Village Clerk.
(Ord. 88-1-6E, 1-6-1988)
11-3-2: OVERHEAD PLUMBING; FOOTING DRAINS:
   A.   All new buildings within the Village with basements, floors, rooms or
occupancy areas below ground level at the building site and served by a public
or private sewer system shall have overhead plumbing.
   B.   All footing drains constructed within the Village after December 31,
1970, shall be connected to sump pumps and shall discharge into storm sewers or
drainage ditches. No footing drains or drainage tiles constructed or installed
after December 31, 1970, shall be connected to the sanitary sewer.
   C.   No building permit shall be issued by the Village for any construction
unless the plans and specifications submitted with the building permit
application indicate that the building has been designed to be constructed in
compliance with requirements of this section.
(Ord. 93-7-14H, 7-14-1993)
11-3-3:    ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY:
   A.   Administrative Adjudication:
      1.   Violations of the provisions of this chapter are subject to
prosecution under the Village’s administrative adjudication proceedings set
forth in Title 1, Chapter 4, Article A of the Village Code, as now or hereafter
amended.
      2.   The provisions of this section shall not preclude the Village from
using other methods or proceedings to adjudicate alleged violations of this
chapter, including, without limitation, the institution of an action in the
Circuit Court of Cook County or before another administrative tribunal which
has jurisdiction to consideration of the violation.
   B.   Penalty: Any person violating any provisions of this chapter, shall,
upon conviction or upon an administrative determination that a violation
occurred, be fined in the amount of less not less two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
Each twenty four (24) hour period that a violation continues shall constitute a
separate violation.
CHAPTER 4: ELEVATORS, ESCALATORS AND SIMILAR DEVICES
Section
11-4-1:   Documents Adopted
11-4-2:   Conflicting Provisions
11-4-1: DOCUMENTS ADOPTED:
The current edition of the Illinois Elevator Safety Code as adopted by the
State of Illinois and its agencies is hereby adopted for the purpose of
regulating and governing the inspection, operation, maintenance and repair of
elevators, escalators and similar devices in the Village.
(Ord. 2008-9-10A, 9-10-2008; amd. Ord. 2024-12-9A, 12-9-2024)
11-4-2: CONFLICTING PROVISIONS:
If there is a conflict between the provisions of this chapter or any of the
documents adopted by reference pursuant to section
11-4-1 of this chapter and any currently existing ordinance, code, rule or
regulation of the Village, the provisions of this chapter or the document
adopted by reference pursuant to section
11-4-1 of this chapter shall govern and control.
(Ord. 2008-9-10A, 9-10-2008; amd. Ord. 2024-12-9A, 12-9-2024)
CHAPTER 5: FIRE PREVENTION REGULATIONS
Section
11-5-1:   Automatic Fire Suppression Systems
11-5-2:   Gas Or Charcoal Grills Restricted; Furniture In Common Areas Of
Condominiums
11-5-1: AUTOMATIC FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEMS:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
APPROVED. Acceptable by the authority of the Deputy Chief of the Bureau Fire
Suppression of the Rosemont Public Safety Department.
AREA. The floor area of buildings or of sections of buildings divided by
approved fire walls, each such section being considered a separate area.
AUTOMATIC SPRINKLER EQUIPMENT. An approved system of pipes with orifices to
apply water automatically to fire.
BASEMENT. Any story of a building where less than half the height between the
floor and ceiling is above the average level of street grade.
FIRE RESISTIVE BUILDINGS. A building in which walls are of approved masonry or
reinforced concrete, and the structural members of which have fire resistive
ratings sufficient to withstand the hazard involved in the occupancy, but not
less than four (4) hour rating for bearing walls, fire walls, party walls,
isolated piers, columns and wall supporting girders; a three (3) hour rating
for walls and girders other than herein specified and for beams, floors and
roofs; and a two (2) hour rating for fire protection in partitions.
   B.   Authority To Establish Rules: Authority is hereby conferred upon the
Deputy Chief of the Bureau of Fire Suppression of the Village Public Safety
Department to promulgate rules for the approval of sprinkler plans, equipment
and installation within the Village. These rules shall be subject to compliance
with the requirements set forth in the NFPA Pamphlet 13 on automatic sprinkler
systems.
   C.   Where Installation Required: Automatic sprinkler approved protection
shall be provided, installed and maintained within the limits of the Village in
the required structures as follows:
      1.   In all new construction herein:
         a.   All industrial occupancies over one thousand (1,000) square feet
in area.
         b.   All business occupancies over one thousand (1,000) square feet in
area.
         c.   All mercantile structures over one thousand (1,000) square feet
in area.
         d.   All educational occupancies over one thousand (1,000) square feet
in area.
         e.   All healthcare facilities.
         f.   All residential occupancies, except single-family, which contain
more than fifteen (15) living units or are more than thirty five feet (35') in
height from grade.
         g.   All new structures not covered in this subsection C1 which are
more than one thousand (1,000) square feet in area.
      2.   In all existing structures when there is any remodeling, alterations
or additions to the structure that will bring the total area of the structure
to ten thousand (10,000) square feet or more.
(Ord. 81-12-16A, 12-16-1981)
      3.   In the following multi-family buildings:
         a.   All multi-family buildings containing four (4) or more dwelling
units for which a building permit for new construction is issued after the
effective date hereof;
         b.   All existing multi-family buildings containing four (4) or more
dwelling units which undergo renovation after the effective date hereof where
the fair market cost of the renovation is more than fifty percent (50%) of the
replacement cost of the building; and
         c.   All multi-family buildings containing four (4) or more dwelling
units which are converted to condominium ownership where the declaration
provided in section 3 and the plat provided in section 5 of the Condominium
Property Act (765 ILCS 605/3 and 605/5, respectively) are recorded after the
effective date hereof.
The automatic sprinkler system or equivalent fire suppression system required
to be installed under this section must be approved by the Public Safety
Department prior to installation as meeting the applicable National Fire
Protection Association standards for the type of building in which the
sprinkler system or equivalent type of fire suppression system is to be
installed and must be installed so that the applicable National Fire Protection
Association standards are met and so that the sprinkler system or equivalent
fire suppression system complies with any other applicable ordinances, rules
and regulations.
(Ord. 2004-7-7G, 7-7-2004)
   D.   System Requirements: All automatic sprinkler systems shall be installed
and maintained in accordance with NFPA Pamphlet 13 governing sprinkler systems.
The following requirements shall also apply:
      1.   Any sprinklered structure larger than ten thousand (10,000) square
feet in area shall have the flow alarm from the sprinkler system directly
connected to the Public Safety Department Communications Center.
      2.   Any sprinklered structure larger than ten thousand (10,000) square
feet in area shall have a minimum of one and one-half inch (11/2") fire
department hose drop from the system provided for each ten thousand (10,000)
square feet of area.
      3.   An outside ringer connected to the flow alarm shall be installed and
maintained on all automatic sprinkler systems.
      4.   All fire department connections to the sprinkler system shall be
installed with National Standard threads on piping.
      5.   On all automatic sprinkler systems covering five thousand (5,000)
square feet or more in area, a jockey pump shall be provided to maintain system
pressure.
   E.   Plan Approval And Requirements For Exemption Or Variance:
      1.   No automatic sprinkler systems may be installed or altered in any
building in the Village without express written consent of the Deputy Chief of
the Bureau of Fire Suppression or his designated agent. All plan approval
requests or any requests for variances, substitutions or exemptions must be
delivered to the Deputy Chief in writing.
      2.   The requirements of this subsection shall in no way be misconstrued
to require installation of sprinklers in any vault, room or building where the
application of water will cause or increase the risk of fire or explosion nor
shall it be misconstrued to interfere with any other approved automatic fire
protection equipment.
   F.   Appeals: The owner or occupant of any building covered under this
section or notified by the Deputy Chief of the Bureau of Fire Suppression to
install automatic sprinkler protection under the provisions of this section
may, when it is claimed that the provisions of this section do not apply,
appeal to the Village Board of Trustees, in writing, within thirty (30) days of
such notice.
   G.   Penalties: Any person who violates any terms of this section shall be
subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. For the purposes
of this section, each ten (10) days that the violation exists shall constitute
a separate offense. The imposition of any penalty for any offense under the
provisions of this section shall not excuse the violation to continue, and all
such persons cited under this section shall be required to correct all
violations immediately. The application of the penalty provisions of this
subsection shall not be held to prevent the removal of prohibited violations by
the authority having jurisdiction.
(Ord. 81-12-16A, 12-16-1981)
Cross-reference:
   See also section
11-2-3, section R325 and section
11-2-8, section 903.6.2.1 of this title
11-5-2: GAS OR CHARCOAL GRILLS RESTRICTED; FURNITURE IN COMMON AREAS OF
CONDOMINIUMS:
   A.   Prohibitions:
      1.   No person shall use or maintain a gas or charcoal grill or any open
flame intended for use in cooking on any balcony.
      2.   No person shall use or maintain a gas or charcoal grill or any open
flame intended for use in cooking on or within eighteen inches (18") of a
public right-of-way or on or within eighteen inches (18") of a sidewalk or
walkway which is part of the common elements of a condominium.
      3.   No person shall use or maintain any items of furniture on a sidewalk
or walkway or within a hallway which is a part of the common elements of a
condominium.
   B.   Penalties: Any person who violates any provision of this section shall,
upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first
offense and to a fine of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the second and any subsequent
offense. Each day that a violation of this section occurs shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Ord. 95-10-4G, 10-4-1995)
ARTICLE A: PLACES OF PUBLIC ASSEMBLY
Section
11-5A-1:   Fire And Emergency Safety In Commercial Places Of Assembly
11-5A-2:   Fire Prevention Regulations For Places Of Assembly
11-5A-3:   Emergency Lighting
11-5A-1: FIRE AND EMERGENCY SAFETY IN COMMERCIAL PLACES OF ASSEMBLY:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
COMMERCIAL PLACE OF ASSEMBLY. Any privately owned banquet hall, meeting room,
exhibition hall, arena or similar place of assembly with a capacity of at least
three hundred (300) persons. The capacity of a commercial place of assembly
shall be determined in accordance with the 2018 edition of the Life Safety Code
published by the National Fire Protection Association, as amended from time to
time.
EVENT. Any meeting, performance, concert, banquet, exhibit or other similar
activity which occurs at a commercial place of assembly.
   B.   Inspections Prior To Start Of Event: Immediately prior to the start of
any event in a commercial place of assembly, the owner or manager of the
commercial place of assembly must inspect every exit from the commercial place
of assembly and every exit from the building which the commercial place of
assembly is located. If this inspection reveals that any such exits are
blocked, the owner or manager may not allow the event to begin until all such
exits are cleared and made readily accessible to persons who will be attending
the event.
   C.   Announcements Regarding Exits:
      1.   Immediately after the start or opening of any event, the owner or
manager of the commercial place of assembly shall make an announcement asking
that persons attending the event familiarize themselves with the location of
exits which are to be used in case of fire or other emergency. Said
announcement shall be made in substantially the following form:
Ladies and Gentlemen, the (name of the commercial place of assembly) in
cooperation with the Rosemont Public Safety Department would like you to take a
moment to familiarize yourselves with the exits to be used in case of fire or
other emergencies. These exists are located (state the location of the exits).
Thank you.
      2.   If the nature of the event is such that most persons attending the
event will not arrive at the commercial place of assembly within one hour of
one another, then the announcement required by subsection C1 of this section
shall be made by the owner or manager of the commercial place of assembly at
least once every ninety (90) minutes during the time that the event is taking
place.
   D.   Penalty: Any person who violates the terms of this section shall be
subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more
than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. For purposes of this
section, each event at which a violation of this section occurs shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 81-12-16A, 12-16-1981)
11-5A-2: FIRE PREVENTION REGULATIONS FOR PLACES OF ASSEMBLY:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
APPROVED. Acceptable by the authority of the Superintendent of Public Safety of
the Village of Rosemont and the applicable codes of the Village.
ENFORCEMENT. Shall designate the act of notification of a violation of this
section, the act of correcting said violation and the subsequent citation or
fine if the violation is not corrected. This will fall under the jurisdiction
of a public safety officer of the Village of Rosemont or his agent.
FIRE PROTECTION EQUIPMENT. Shall include the following: all fire extinguishers,
sprinkler heads, sprinkler system siamese connections, standpipe system valves,
fire hose connections, fire alarms, emergency telephones and fire hydrants.
MERCHANDISING EQUIPMENT. Items used in the set up, display and decoration of
any table, booth or area utilized during a public or private trade show,
exhibit or seminar in a place of assembly.
PLACE OF ASSEMBLY. Any privately owned or operated banquet hall, meeting room,
exhibition hall, arena or similar place of assembly where fifty (50) or more
people are gathered. The maximum capacity of any place of assembly shall be
governed by the 2018 edition of the Life Safety Code, as amended from time to
time.
SET UP. Shall designate all preparations prior to the actual occupancy “show”
hours of any event in a place of assembly. The term shall include the approval
of the physical layout of the area of the event and all operations conducted in
that area.
VILLAGE FIRE CODE. Hereafter referred to as “Code” shall mean the previously
adopted Fire Code of the Village of Rosemont (See section 11-2-8 of this
title).
(Ord. 2015-11-18G, 11-18-2015; amd. 2019 Code)
   B.   Exits:
      1.   All exits and exitways shall be kept clear and unobstructed during
all hours of occupancy.
      2.   All exit doors must be equipped with approved hardware, operate
freely and be unlocked during hours of occupancy.
      3.   The amount and location of exit doors shall be determined by the
following:
         a.   Class A occupancy (1,000 people or more) shall have at least four
(4) separate exits as remote as possible.
         b.   Class B occupancy (600 to 1,000 people) shall have at least three
(3) separate exits as remote as possible.
         c.   Class C occupancy (0 to 600 people) shall have at least two (2)
separate exits as remote as possible.
      4.   All exits must be appropriately marked and illuminated. If the exit
doors are obstructed from view, directional exit signs must be installed
indicating the path of travel to the exits.
      5.   All exits shall comply with the requirements of the 2018 edition of
the Life Safety Code, regarding places of assembly, and as amended from time to
time.
   C.   Flammable Liquids And Gases: This Code requires that any vehicle
burning Class I fuel that is brought into a place of assembly comply with the
following:
      1.   No liquified petroleum gas tanks may be used or stored in a place of
assembly without express written permission of the Deputy Chief of the Bureau
of Fire Suppression. This shall include, but not be limited to, portable
“propane” tanks. Where it is necessary for an open flamed or heating device to
be demonstrated or displayed, the Bureau of Fire Suppression shall be notified
ahead of time for approval as additional fire protection equipment may be
needed.
      2.   Any quantities of flammable liquids that are kept on the premises
must be approved by the Bureau of Fire Suppression and kept in an approved
safety can.
   D.   Merchandising Equipment:
      1.   All items used in the display and/or decoration of any area, such as
tables, carpets, curtains, backdrops, etc., shall be of noncombustible or fire
retardant material and approved by the Bureau of Fire Suppression. If extension
cords are used in a display or event, they shall be of adequate size, UL
approved and must be in operable condition.
      2.   Excessive quantities of combustible equipment in displays will not
be allowed.
      3.   Trash containers for those in attendance at any event shall be of
noncombustible construction.
   E.   Booths, Aisles And Seating:
      1.   Booths will be arranged, if used, to allow adequate aisles for the
amount of persons in attendance. They shall be approved as per subsection G of
this section.
      2.   Where theater style seating is used, there shall be access aisles
provided for each fourteen (14) rows of seats. The width of aisles shall be in
accordance with subsection G of this section.
      3.   Where banquet seating is used, there shall be an access aisle to
every exit. A fifteen foot (15') radius of clear floor space shall be
maintained around every exit. Aisles shall be in accordance with subsection G
of this section.
   F.   Fire Protection Equipment: All fire protection equipment shall be
clear, unobstructed and in proper working order at all times. All fire
protection equipment shall be visible to those in attendance, and if not
visible, proper signs designating such equipment shall be visible.
   G.   Setup Requirements:
      1.   No smoking will be allowed during the set up of any function in a
place of assembly unless so designated by the Bureau of Fire Suppression. All
floor plans for any functions in a place of assembly that will have an
attendance of two hundred fifty (250) or more persons must be approved by the
Bureau of Fire Suppression thirty (30) days prior to the dates of the function.
      2.   All storage for any functions in a place of assembly shall be in a
separate location, separated by construction, having a two (2) hour minimum
fire rating.
      3.   Access aisles to a booth-type set up shall be a minimum of six feet
(6') wide. Main cross aisles shall be a minimum of ten feet (10') wide. These
widths may be increased depending on the amount of people in attendance.
      4.   Access aisles in a theater-type set up of any function shall be
forty two inches (42") wide and service no more than fourteen (14) seats in any
row. Main aisles in this type of set up shall be five feet (5') wide.
      5.   In banquet-type seating, the maximum amount of persons in the room
shall be one for each fifteen feet (15') of floor area.
   H.   Life Safety Announcements: In any occupancy being used as a place of
assembly where more than three hundred (300) persons are gathered, a life
safety announcement shall be made in accordance with subsection 11-5A-1C of
this article.
   I.   Penalty: Anyone who violates the terms of this section shall be subject
to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. For purposes of this
section, each day that this violation takes place shall constitute a separate
offense unless a life hazard is present, then each hour shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Ord. 81-12-16A, 12-16-1981)
11-5A-3: EMERGENCY LIGHTING:
   A.   Where Required:
      1.   All schools, churches, hospitals, nursing homes, motels, hotels,
restaurants, clubs, offices, industrial plants, and other places of assembly
that accommodate one hundred (100) persons or more shall be equipped with
emergency lighting.
      2.   All exits, corridors, stairwells, and lobbies leading to an exit
shall be equipped with emergency lighting.
   B.   Separate Systems; Operation:
      1.   All emergency lighting shall be separate and independent to normal
electrical service.
(1971 Code § 11-1)
      2.   Emergency lighting shall either be constant or shall automatically
go into operation when any interruption of the normal electrical service
occurs, such as accidentally thrown switch or a burned out fuse and/or circuit
breaker. Also, emergency lighting shall go into operation within a maximum of
ten (10) seconds and remain in operation for a minimum of ninety (90) minutes
after a normal system failure.
   C.   Compliance With NFPA: Approved emergency lighting shall meet the
requirements set forth in NFPA Pamphlet 101, chapter 5, section 5-9, this being
the 2000 edition thereof.
   D.   Modification Of Regulations: The Deputy Chief of the Bureau of Fire
Suppression shall have the power to modify any of the provisions of this
section upon application in writing by a petitioner regarding the enforcement
of this section. Any revisions thereof granted shall be set forth in writing
and a copy served on the applicant.
(Ord. 81-12-16A, 12-16-1981)
CHAPTER 6: BUILDING NUMBERS
Section
11-6-1:   Numbering System
11-6-2:   Compliance With Provisions
11-6-3:   Application For Number
11-6-4:   Size And Location Of Number
11-6-5:   Penalty
11-6-1: NUMBERING SYSTEM:
The numbering system shall be the present house numbering system in use in the
City of Chicago, which provides for eight hundred (800) numbers to the mile or
one hundred (100) numbers to the six hundred thirty foot (630') block. On north
and south streets, even numbers shall be on the north side and odd numbers
shall be on the south side. Each thirty feet (30') of frontage shall be given a
separate number, as designated by the Director of Building and Code
Enforcement.
(1971 Code § 19-24)
11-6-2: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
It is hereby made the duty of the owner, agent or person in possession of any
building in the Village to number it in the manner herein provided.
(1971 Code § 19-25)
11-6-3: APPLICATION FOR NUMBER:
Application for a building number shall be made to the Village Clerk in the
form and manner prescribed in printed applications on file in the Clerk’s
Office, which may be obtained upon request.
(1971 Code § 19-25)
11-6-4: SIZE AND LOCATION OF NUMBER:
Each figure of every number shall be not less than three inches (3") in height
and shall be placed in the most conspicuous and extended part of the front of
the building.
(1971 Code § 19-26)
11-6-5: PENALTY:
Any person being the owner or agent or occupant of any building now erected or
to be erected who shall refuse or neglect to number any building owned or
occupied or represented by him, in conformity with the provisions of this
chapter shall be subject to a penalty of not less than two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and a
similar penalty for every thirty (30) days thereafter that such building shall
be without its number.
(1971 Code § 19-27)
CHAPTER 7: SIGNS AND OTHER ADVERTISING STRUCTURES
Section
11-7-1:   Definitions
11-7-2:   Permit Requirements
11-7-3:   General Requirements
11-7-4:   Exempt Signs
11-7-5:   Prohibited Signs
11-7-6:   Signs In Public Rights-Of-Way
11-7-7:   Ground And Pole Signs
11-7-8:   Wall Signs
11-7-9:   Changing Signs
11-7-10:   Roof Signs
11-7-11:   Illuminated Signs
11-7-12:   Temporary Signs
11-7-13:   Unsafe, Obsolete Or Noncompliance Signs
11-7-14:   Awnings
11-7-15:   Penalty
11-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following
words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
AWNING. Any structure made of cloth or metal with a metal frame attached to a
building and projecting over a thoroughfare, when the same is so erected as to
permit its being raised to a position flat against the building when not in
use.
CANOPY. Any structure, other than an awning, made of cloth or metal with metal
frames attached to a building, projecting from the wall of a building above an
entrance and extending over a thoroughfare.
CHANGING SIGNS. Outdoor clocks, outdoor barometers, outdoor electric message
centers, outdoor signs and any other sign whose advertisement or message is
changed mechanically.
FACING OR SURFACE. The surface of the sign upon, against, or through which the
message is displayed or illustrated.
GROUND SIGN. Any sign supported by uprights or braces placed upon the ground
and not attached to any building.
ILLUMINATED SIGN. Any sign which has characters, letters, figures, designs, or
outline illuminated by electric lights or luminous tubes as a part of the sign
proper.
INCOMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL. Any material which will not ignite at or below a
temperature of one thousand two hundred degrees Fahrenheit (1,200°F) and will
not continue to burn or glow at that temperature.
MARQUEE. Any hood or awning of permanent construction projecting from the wall
of a building above an entrance and extending over a thoroughfare.
OTHER ADVERTISING STRUCTURE. Any “marquee”, “canopy”, or “awning”, as defined
herein.
PERSON. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
POLE SIGNS. Any and all freestanding signs located atop a pole or other similar
standard.
PROJECTING SIGN. Any sign which is attached to a building or other structure
and extends more than ten inches (10") beyond the building line established for
said premises by the zoning ordinances or other ordinances or deed restrictions
governing the premises upon which said sign is located.
ROOF SIGN. Any sign erected, constructed and maintained wholly upon or over the
roof of any building with the principal support on the roof structure.
SIGN. Every sign, billboard, ground sign, wall sign, roof sign, illuminated
sign, projecting sign, pole sign, changing sign, marquee, awning, and canopy,
and includes any announcement, declaration, demonstration, display,
illustration or insignia used to advertise or promote the interests of any
person when the same is placed out of doors in view of the general public.
TEMPORARY SIGNS. Any sign, banner, pennant, valance, or advertising display
constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric, cardboard, wallboard or other light
materials, with or without frames, intended to be displayed for a short period
of time only.
WALL SIGN. All flat signs of solid face construction which are placed against a
building or other structure and attached to the exterior front, rear, or side
wall of any building or other structure.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
11-7-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, repair,
alter, relocate or maintain within the Village any “sign” or “other advertising
structure”, as defined in section 11-7-1 of this chapter, without first
obtaining a permit from the Village Board of Trustees and making payment of the
fee required thereof. All illuminated signs shall, in addition, be subject to
the provisions of the Building Code and the permit fees required thereunder
(See subsection 3-15-1F of this Code).
   B.   Application For Permit: Applications for a permit shall be made upon
forms provided by the Village Clerk and shall contain or have attached thereto
the following information:
      1.   Name, address and telephone number of the applicant.
      2.   Location of building, structure, or lot to which or upon which the
sign or other advertising structure is to be attached or erected.
      3.   Position of the sign or other advertising structure in relation to
nearby buildings or structures.
      4.   Two (2) blueprints or ink drawings of the plans and specifications
and method of construction and attachment to the building or in the ground.
      5.   Copy of stress sheets and calculations showing the structure is
designed for dead load and wind pressure in any direction in the amount
required by this chapter and all other laws and ordinances of the Village.
      6.   Name of persons, firm, corporation or association erecting the
structure.
      7.   Written consent of the owner of the building, structure or land to
which or on which the structure is to be erected.
      8.   Any electrical permit required and issued for the sign.
      9.   Insurance policy or bond as required by subsection E of this
section.
      10.   Such other information as the Village Board may determine is
required to show full compliance with this chapter and all other laws and
ordinances of the Village.
   C.   Review Of Application:
      1.   It shall be the duty of the Director of Building and Code
Enforcement, after the filing of an application for a permit to erect a sign or
other advertising structure, to examine the plans and specifications and other
data relating to the proposed sign or advertising structure and the premises
upon which it is proposed to erect the sign or other advertising structure, and
to report to the Village Board on whether the proposed sign or advertising
structure will comply with the requirements of this chapter and all other laws
and ordinances of the Village. The Village Board, after reviewing the Director
of Building and Code Enforcement’s report, shall determine whether an erection
permit shall be issued. If the work authorized under a permit has not been
completed within six (6) months after the date of issuance, the permit shall
become null and void.
      2.   The application for a permit for erection of a sign or other
advertising structure in which electrical wiring and connections are to be used
shall be submitted to the Director of Building and Code Enforcement. The
Director shall examine the plans and specifications respecting all wiring and
connections to determine if the same complies with the Electrical Code of the
Village (see section
11-2-5 of this title), and shall report to the Village Board whether the plans
and specifications comply with said Code.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
   D.   Permit And Inspection Fees:
      1.   Permit Fees: Every applicant, before granted a permit hereunder,
shall pay to the Village Clerk the permit fee for each sign or other
advertising structure regulated by this chapter as provided in the Village Fee
Schedule, subsections 3-10-1I, J and K of this Code.
      2.   Annual Inspection Fee: For each sign not advertising a business
existing on the property, the owner thereof shall pay to the Village an annual
inspection fee as set forth in the Village Fee Schedule, subsections
3-10-1J and K of this Code. No inspection fee shall be charged in the same year
a permit fee is paid.
(Ord. 82-4-7B, 4-7-1982; amd. 2019 Code)
   E.   Bond Requirements; Insurance In Lieu:
      1.   Any person lawfully maintaining a sign or other advertising
structure regulated by this chapter at the effective date hereof shall, within
thirty (30) days after said enactment, comply with all the provisions set forth
in this section.
      2.   A liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company
authorized to do business in the State of Illinois conforming to this section
may be permitted in lieu of a bond.
   F.   Revocation Of Permits: All rights and privileges acquired under the
provisions of this chapter are mere permits revocable at any time by the
Village Board, and all such permits shall contain this provision. In the event
that, by action of the Village Board, any permit is revoked, it shall be
unlawful to thereafter allow such sign to continue to remain on the premises,
and it shall be the duty of the owner, agent, or person in possession of the
premises and each of them to remove the same forthwith.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
11-7-3: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Information Required: Every sign or other advertising structure shall
have painted in a conspicuous place thereon, in letters not less than one inch
(1") in height, the date of erection, the permit number and the voltage of any
electrical apparatus used in connection therewith. In addition, all illuminated
signs and any other signs which use electricity shall be labeled as conforming
to the standards of the United States Bureau of Standards and as having been
approved by Underwriters Laboratories, Inc.
   B.   Location And Language Restrictions:
      1.   No sign shall be erected, relocated or maintained as to prevent free
ingress to or egress from any door, window or fire escape. No sign of any kind
shall be attached to a standpipe or fire escape.
      2.   No sign or other advertising structure as regulated by this chapter
shall be erected at the intersection of any streets in such a manner as to
obstruct free and clear vision or at any location where, by reason of the
position, shape or color, it may interfere with, obstruct the view of, or be
confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal or device, or which makes use
of the words “Stop”, “Look”, “Drive-In”, “Danger” or any other word, phrase,
symbol or character in such manner as to interfere with, mislead or confuse
traffic.
   C.   Design And Construction Standards: All signs and other advertising
structures shall be designed and constructed to withstand a wind pressure of
not less than forty (40) pounds per square foot of area, and shall be
constructed to receive dead loads as required in the Building Code or other
ordinances of the Village.
   D.   Maintenance Requirements: The owner of any “sign”, as defined and
regulated by this chapter, shall be required to have properly painted at least
once every two (2) years the facing and all parts and supports of the sign,
unless the same is constructed of noncorrosive material, in which event, it
shall be cleaned at least every two (2) years.
   E.   Lighting: Gooseneck reflectors and lights shall be permitted on ground
signs and wall signs; provided, that any lights be installed only in such
manner that the direct rays of such lights be concentrated on the sign and be
prevented from causing a glare on or striking the street or nearby property, or
reflectors shall be provided with proper glass lenses concentrating the
illumination upon the area of the sign so as to prevent glare upon the street
or nearby property.
   F.   Attachment Of Letters And Figures: All letters, figures, characters or
representations in cutout or irregular form, maintained in conjunction with,
attached to, or superimposed upon any sign shall be safely and securely built
or attached to the sign structure.
   G.   Signs Near Public Rights-Of-Way: All signs or other advertising
structures which are constructed adjacent to or within five feet (5') of a
public right-of-way shall have a smooth surface, and no nails, tacks or wires
shall be permitted to protrude therefrom, except electrical reflectors and
devices which may extend over the top and in front of the advertising
structures.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
11-7-4: EXEMPT SIGNS:
The provisions and regulations of this chapter shall not apply to the following
signs:
   A.   Nonilluminated real estate signs not exceeding eight (8) square feet in
area which advertise the sale, rental or lease of the premises upon which the
signs are located only.
   B.   Nonilluminated professional nameplates not exceeding one square foot in
area.
   C.   Memorial signs or tablets, names of buildings and date of erection when
cut into any masonry surface or when constructed of bronze or other
incombustible materials.
   D.   Traffic or other Municipal signs, legal notices, railroad crossing
signs, danger, and such temporary, emergency or nonadvertising signs as may be
approved by the Village Board.
   E.   Signs which advertise garage sales on the premises upon which the sign
is located (see section 4-42-6 of this Code).
   F.   Lettering and pictures on trucks, automobiles, or semitractor-trailers
which identify only the owner or operator of the vehicle or a product sold by
the owner or operator of the vehicle.
   G.   Signs located on the interior or the exterior of buses.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
11-7-5: PROHIBITED SIGNS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to:
      1.   Erect, display or maintain within the Village a mobile or portable
sign which is attached to a base that has wheels or any other sign which is not
fixed to a permanent base.
      2.   Erect, maintain or display a sign in any area within the Village
which is zoned for residential use except signs which advertise garage sales or
that a residence is for sale or for rent.
      3.   Paint and/or maintain a sign that is painted directly on the surface
of the walls or roof of any building or structure within the Village. It shall
be unlawful for any person to paint, paste, or post in a similar manner a sign
on any fence, utility pole or other type of standard within the Village.
      4.   Park a motor vehicle or trailer upon which there is an advertising
message or a device which advertises a product or directs persons to the
location of a business or other activity so that the motor vehicle or trailer
is visible from a public right-of-way.
      5.   Erect or maintain any sign which is wholly or partially illuminated
by flashing lights or intermittent lights.
      6.   Erect or maintain any sign which is wholly or partially illuminated
by floodlights or spotlights.
      7.   Erect or maintain any revolving light, revolving beacon or revolving
sign.
      8.   Display upon any sign or other advertising structure any obscene,
indecent, or immoral matter.
      9.   Erect, alter, relocate, or maintain any projecting sign.
      10.   Erect, alter, relocate, or maintain any awning.
      11.   Erect, alter, relocate, or maintain any canopy.
      12.   Erect, alter, relocate, or maintain any marquee.
   B.   All signs not expressly permitted under the provisions of this chapter
shall be prohibited; provided, however, if the Village Board determines that a
proposed sign is substantially similar and is not more objectionable to a type
of sign which is permitted, the Village Board may issue a permit to allow the
proposed sign to be erected. Said sign shall be subject to all provisions of
this chapter which pertain to the type of sign to which it is substantially
similar.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
11-7-6: SIGNS IN PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY:
   A.   Purpose: This section is adopted for the following purposes:
      1.   To promote and protect the public safety and welfare of the
residents and businesses located in the Village.
      2.   To enhance the physical appearance of the Village.
      3.   To protect pedestrians and motorists within the Village from damage
or injury caused by distractions, obstructions and hazards created by
commercial, political, or advertising signs that are installed or posted in
public rights-of-way.
      4.   To prevent the proliferation of signs in public rights-of-way which
distract from the development, beauty and aesthetic appeal of the public areas
in the Village.
   B.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following words and
terms have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this subsection,
except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
ADVERTISING SIGN. Any advertising device, poster, notice, or display which
directs attention to an object, product, place, activity, person, institution,
organization or business.
COMMERCIAL SIGN. A sign which identifies, advertises, or directs attention to a
business, commodity, service, activity, idea, slogan or entertainment, or is
intended to induce the purchase of goods, property, or a service, including,
without limitation, any sign naming a brand of goods or service and real estate
signs, as defined in this section.
GOVERNMENTAL SIGN. A sign posted by or on behalf of a unit of local government,
the State of Illinois and the government of the United States, and shall
include, but not be limited to, regulatory signs, directional signs and
identification signs.
POLITICAL SIGN. Signs or posters announcing candidates seeking political office
and/or political issues, and data pertinent thereto.
POST. To erect, attach, install, or affix in any manner including, without
limitation, nailing, tacking, tying, gluing, pasting, painting, staking,
marking, or writing.
PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY. The entire area between property boundaries which is owned
by a government, dedicated to public use, or impressed with an easement for
public use; which is primarily used for pedestrian or vehicular travel; and
which is publicly maintained, in whole or in part, for such use. PUBLIC RIGHT-
OF-WAY includes, without limitation, the street, gutter, curb, shoulder,
sidewalk, sidewalk area, crosswalk, parking or parking strip, planting strip,
hydrant, street sign, traffic sign, traffic control device, utility pole,
lamppost or wire appurtenance thereof, fire alarms, Village owned flowers,
trees or shrubbery in any public place, and any public way.
REAL ESTATE SIGN. A sign indicating the availability for sale, rent, or lease
of a lot, building, or portion of a building.
SIGN. A name, identification, description, display or illustration which is
affixed to or painted upon nondurable materials, including paper, cardboard,
cloth, plastic, and/or wallboard. Under this section, “sign” also includes
names, identification, description, display or illustrations which are affixed
to or painted on handbills, banners, flags, pennants, balloons, streamers,
spinners, and ribbons. Signs include real estate signs, commercial signs,
political signs, and advertising signs.
   C.   Posting Signs In Public Rights-Of-Way Prohibited: It is unlawful for
anyone to post a sign, direct that a sign be posted or contract for the posting
of any sign, other than a governmental sign, in any public right-of-way located
within the Village except for a directional sign for which a permit has been
issued or which is otherwise allowed pursuant to subsection D of this section.
   D.   Permit For Private Directional Sign:
      1.   A person other than a unit of government may post a sign in the
public right-of-way which identifies or locates the entrance or exit to
premises located along the right-of-way; provided, that each of the following
conditions has been met:
         a.   The sign contains no markings, numbering or lettering other than
that necessary to identify the entrance or exit and, provided
         b.   A permit for the sign has been issued by the Village or the sign
was posted prior to February 1, 2006.
      2.   The Director of Building and Code Enforcement of the Village shall
be authorized to issue any permits for signs allowed under this subsection;
provided, that the applicant for the permit first submits to the Director a
diagram which shows where the sign will be located and a drawing or photograph
which shows how the sign will appear and the dimensions of the sign; and
provided, that the Director determines that: a) the sign is no larger than
reasonably necessary; b) it is impractical for the sign to be located outside
of the right-of-way; and c) the sign otherwise complies with the provisions of
this section and any other applicable ordinance or regulation of the Village.
   E.   Removal Of Signs From Public Right-Of-Way:
      1.   Any sign, other than a governmental sign or sign which is allowed
under subsection D of this section, which is found posted or otherwise affixed
within any public right-of-way in violation of this section is hereby declared
a public nuisance and may be removed at any time by or at the direction of the
Public Safety Department, the Department of Public Works or the Village
President.
      2.   The person who posted or directed the posting of a sign in a public
right-of-way and the person or company advertised or promoted on a sign which
is removed pursuant to subsection E1 of this section, including a candidate
promoted on a political sign, are jointly and severally responsible for the
costs incurred by the Village in the removal of said sign. The cost of removal
shall be deemed to include any incidental expenses, as well as all direct and
indirect costs incurred by the Village in connection with the removal of a
sign.
      3.   Proof that the person or company advertised or promoted on the
handbill or sign, including a candidate promoted on a political sign, had no
actual knowledge and also had no reason to know that said sign was posted or
might be posted within the public right-of-way is an affirmative defense to any
liability which such person may have under subsection E2 of this section for
the cost of removing the sign.
      4.   The Village may institute any appropriate action or proceeding to
prevent, restrain, correct or abate a violation of this section, including such
actions as may be necessary for the Village to recoup costs incurred in
connection with the removal of signs from public rights-of-way as provided by
subsection E1 of this section.
      5.   If the Village institutes an action to recoup costs incurred in
connection with the removal of signs from public rights-of-way by filing an
action in the Circuit Court of Cook County or another court which has
jurisdiction over such an action, the Village shall also be entitled to recover
the filing fees and other court costs, attorney fees and any other costs
incurred in bringing such action; provided, that the Village gives the person
against whom such an action is brought not less than fourteen (14) days’ notice
of its intent to bring the action.
   F.   Penalties: Any person who violates this section shall be subject to a
fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven
hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. The costs incurred by the
Village in removing a sign that is in violation of this section may be included
in determining the appropriate amount of the fine to be assessed; provided,
that if a finding is made that such fine takes into account the cost of
removal, then the Village shall not be entitled to bring another action to
recoup or otherwise separately recoup the cost of removal as provided in
subsection E1 of this section. Each twelve (12) hour period such violation is
committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense with
respect to the computation of fines.
(Ord. 2006-2-1G, 2-1-2006)
11-7-7: GROUND AND POLE SIGNS:
   A.   Ground Signs:
      1.   All ground signs for which a permit is required under this chapter
shall have a surface or facing of incombustible material; provided, however,
that combustible structural trim may be used thereon.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
      2.   All ground signs for which a permit is required under this chapter
shall have a surface or facing less than thirty two (32) square feet in area.
(Ord. 84-7-2, 7-2-1984)
      3.   It shall be unlawful to erect any ground sign with a total height
greater than six feet (6') above the level of the street upon which the sign
faces, or above the adjoining ground level, if such ground level is above the
street level.
      4.   Ground signs shall have an open space not less than two feet (2')
between the base line of said sign and the ground level. This open space may be
filled in with a platform or decorative lattice work which does not close off
more than one-half (1/2) of any square foot of such open space. No ground sign
shall be nearer than two feet (2') to any other sign, building or structure.
      5.   No ground sign shall be nearer the street than the building line
established by law.
      6.   All ground signs shall be securely built, constructed and erected
upon posts and standards sunk at least three feet (3') below the natural
surface of the ground, and shall be supported and braced by timbers or metal
rods in the rear thereof, extending from the top thereof to a point in the
ground at least a distance equal to one-half (1/2) of the height of the sign,
measured along the ground, from the posts or standards upon which the same is
erected.
      7.   All posts, anchors and bracings of wood shall be treated to protect
them from moisture by creosoting or other approved methods when they rest upon
or enter into the ground.
      8.   All ground signs and the premises surrounding the same shall be
maintained by the owner thereof in a clean, sanitary, and inoffensive
condition, and free and clear of all obnoxious substances, rubbish and weeds.
   B.   Pole Signs:
      1.   The total area of the facing of a pole sign shall not exceed two
hundred (200) square feet.
      2.   It shall bee unlawful to erect any pole sign with a weight greater
than twenty feet (20') above the level of the street which the sign faces or
above ground level, if the level of the ground upon which the sign is erected
is above street level.
      3.   All pole signs and the premises surrounding the same shall be
maintained by the owner thereof in a clean, sanitary and inoffensive condition,
and free and clear of all obnoxious substances, rubbish and weeds.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
   C.   Number Of Pole And Ground Signs:
      1.   No more than one ground or one pole sign shall be permitted per lot
of record or per business, whichever is less.
      2.   No person shall be permitted to erect or maintain more than either
one pole sign or one ground sign within the Village.
(Ord. 80-8-20B, 8-20-1980)
11-7-8: WALL SIGNS:
   A.   All wall signs for which a permit is required under this chapter shall
have a surface or facing of incombustible noncorrosive material; provided,
however, that combustible structural trim may be used thereon. Every wall sign,
including the frames, braces and supports thereof, shall be designed by a
structural engineer or manufacturer, and shall be approved by the Village Board
as in compliance with the Village Building Code.
   B.   No wall sign shall cover wholly or partially any wall opening, nor
project beyond the ends or top of the wall to which it is attached, and no wall
sign shall exceed an area of one hundred fifty (150) square feet.
   C.   The front facing of a wall sign shall not be permitted to extend more
than ten inches (10") beyond the surface of the building to which it is
attached, and shall not be attached to a wall at a height of less than ten feet
(10') above the sidewalk or ground.
   D.   No wall sign shall be erected, relocated or maintained so as to prevent
free ingress to or egress from any door, window or fire escape.
   E.   All wall signs shall be safely and securely attached to the building
wall by means of noncorrosive metal anchors, bolts, or expansion screws of not
less than three-eighths inch (3/8") in diameter embedded in said wall at least
five inches (5"); provided, however, that such signs may rest in or be bolted
to strong, noncorrosive heavy metal brackets or saddles set not over six feet
(6') apart, each of which shall be securely fixed to the wall as hereinbefore
provided. In no case shall any wall sign be secured with wire, strips of wood
or nails.
   F.   Not more than one wall sign shall be mounted, attached, or painted upon
any building.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
11-7-9: CHANGING SIGNS:
   A.   Changing signs must comply with all applicable provisions of this
chapter and all applicable ordinances and codes, including the Village Building
Code and Electrical Code.
   B.   No new permit shall be required for alteration of a changing sign
because of painting, repainting, cleaning, maintenance or repair of the sign
which does not involve a structural change. No new permit shall be required for
replacement or repair of the plastic face of a changing sign due to breakage or
deterioration.
   C.   A new permit shall be required if the advertisement or message of a
changing sign is altered.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
11-7-10: ROOF SIGNS:
   A.   All roof signs shall be installed or erected in such a manner that no
angle iron structural iron supports, braces, grip wires, or secondary supports
shall be visible from any public place.
   B.   Roof signs may not rotate.
   C.   The facing of a roof sign shall not exceed one hundred (100) square
feet in area and cannot extend more than ten feet (10') above a flat roof or
above the highest point of a gabled roof.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
11-7-11: ILLUMINATED SIGNS:
   A.   All signs which use electricity must conform to the standards of the
United States Bureau of Standards and may be approved by Underwriters
Laboratories, Inc.
   B.   All illuminating elements in signs which use electricity shall be kept
in satisfactory working condition or immediately repaired or replaced.
   C.   All signs using electricity shall have a disconnecting switch which is
located in accordance with the requirements of the Village Building and
Electrical Codes.
(Ord. 80-4-16G, 4-16-1980)
11-7-12: TEMPORARY SIGNS:
   A.   No temporary sign of combustible material shall exceed four feet (4')
in one of its dimensions or one hundred (100) square feet in area, and provided
such signs in excess of sixty (60) square feet shall be made of rigid
materials, that is, of wallboard or other light materials with frames.
   B.   Every temporary sign weighing in excess of fifty (50) pounds must be
approved by the Director of Building and Code Enforcement as conforming to the
